hom.sense: The seventh letter of the alphabet: called xaMCN [and xaA (respecting which latter see the letter b)]. It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice]; and of those termed Haloqiy-ap [i. e. faucial, or guttural]: its place of utterance is the same as that of g [which differs from it in being vocal]. (L.)
[As a numeral, it denotes Six hundred.]

entry.sense: xaA and xaMCN: see the letter x, and arts. xwO and xI.
xaAtuwnN: see art. xtn.
xaAnaqaAhN and xaAnaqaAhiI-N: see art. xnq.

hom.sense: 1. xab-a, (A, L, Ḳ,) sec. pers. xabibota, like Ealimota, aor. yaxab-u, inf. n. xib-N; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;*) or xab-a, [sec. pers. xababota,] aor. yaxub-u, like yaqotulu, inf. n. xab-N; (Mṣb; [in which xib-N is regarded as a simple subst.; but I doubt the correctness of this, and of the verb's being like qatala;]) He (a man) was, or became, deceitful, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) wicked, dishonest, or dissimulating, (Ḳ, TA,) and a mischief-maker: (TA:) [or] he was, or became, a great deceiver, or very deceitful, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ, TA,) wicked and deceitful, and a mischief-maker. (Ṣ,* A,* L, TA.) [In the Ḳ and TA, neither the aor. nor the inf. n. of xab-a as signifying “he was, or became, a great deceiver, or very deceitful,” is specified; nor the sec. pers. of the pret., which indicates the form of the aor.]

[Hence, app.,] xab-a signifies also He alighted and abode in a depressed tract of ground, in order that his place might be unknown, from a motive of niggardliness [to avoid claims upon his hospitality, thus deceiving passers by]. (Ḳ, TA.)
And He denied, or refused, what he possessed. (Ḳ.)

xab-a, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. yuxub-u, with damm, (Ṣ, A,) deviating from a general rule, accord. to which an intrans. v. of this class [of the measure faEala] should be with kesr, (MF,) inf. n. xab-N (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xababN and xabiybN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He went the pace, or in the manner, denoted by xababN as explained below; said of a horse; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also Axtb-↓: (Th, Ḳ:) and in like manner said of a man. (TA.) You say, jaAWuwA taxub-u bihimu Ald-awaAb-u [They came, the beasts going with them the pace, or in the manner, termed xababN]. (A.) And xab-a fiI AlOamori, aor. _u {yaxobubu}, inf. n. xababN, He hastened to begin the affair. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] xab-a, (aor. yaxub-u, TA, [inf. n. xab-N,]) said of the sea, ‡ It was, or became, agitated, or in a state of commotion; (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA;) the waves dashing together, and the winds whirling; (T, A, TA;) such being the case at a certain period, when the ships make for the shore, for safety, or cast anchor. (T, TA.) You say, OaSaAbahumu Alxab-u ‡ Agitation, or commotion, of the sea, with a whirling of the winds, befell them: (T, A, TA:) or ASAbhm xab-N, i. e. xab-a bihimu AlbaHoru ‡ The sea became agitated, or in a state of commotion, with them. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also, said of the dust, ‡ It rose high: (JK, TA:) and ‡ it ran along. (TA.)
And said of a plant, or of herbage, ‡ It became tall. (JK, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

2. xb-b, (JK, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxobiybN, (JK, TA,) He deceived another; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, another's young man, or slave: (Ṣ:) or deceived much or greatly: (Ḥar p. 591:) and he corrupted another; (JK, A, TA;) namely, another's male or female slave. (TA.) You say, xb-b Ealayohi Sadiyqahu, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) and Eabodahu, and Haliylatahu, (A,) He corrupted, and rendered disaffected to him, (Aboo-Bekr, A,) his friend, (Aboo-Bekr,) and his male slave, and his wife. (A.)
He bound his arm, or hand, with a xib-ap, i. e. a piece of rag like a fillet. (A, TA.)
It (one's flesh) wasted so that there appeared streaks upon the skin. (TA.)
See also R. Q. 1.

entry.sense: 3. xAb-: see muxaAb-N. [It seems that xAb-hu, if used, signifies He acted treacherously towards him, and took him unawares.]
And [the inf. n.] muxaAb-apN signifies The being heavy, or sluggish, and holding back from a thing. (JK.)
4. Axb- He made a horse to go the pace, or in the manner, denoted by xababN as explained below. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 8. Axtb-: see 1.
Axtb- mino vawobih xub-apF, (Ṣ,) or, xib-apF, and Axtb- vawobahu, (JK,) He took forth [or, app., tore] from his garment a piece of ray like a fillet. (Ṣ.)
R. Q. 1. xaboxaba He (a man, TA) acted perfidiously, unfaithfully, faithlessly, or treacherously. (Ḳ.)

xaboxaba Eani AlZ-ahiyrapi He stayed until the mid-day heat had become assuaged, and the air was cool: (Ḳ:) or the phrase is xaboxaba Eanohu mina AlZ-ahiyrapi. (TA.) [Hence, in a trad. relating to the postponement of the noon prayers,] xaboxibuwA Eanokumo mina AlZ-ahiyrapi, (Ṣ,) or fiI AlZ-ahiyrapi, (JK, [but the former is more probably the correct phrase,]) Stay ye until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool: (JK, Ṣ:) it is originally xab-abuwA↓, and is altered therefrom for the purpose of distinction: (Ṣ in the present art.:) or originally baxobixuwA. (Ṣ in art. bx.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. taxaboxaba It was, or became, lax, flaccid, or flabby: said of a thing in a state of commotion, moving to and fro, quivering, or the like. (Ḳ.) [See also xaboxabapN, below; and see R. Q. 1.]
He was, or became, empty [in the belly], after repletion. (JK.) And jaMCa yataxaboxabu He came hungry. (JK.)

taxaboxaba laHomuhu, (JK,) or badanuhu, (Ḳ,) He became lean after having been fat, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) so that his shin became lax, flaccid, or flabby, (TA,) and a sound was heard to proceed from him [when he moved], (JK, TA,) by reason of his leanness. (TA.)
taxaboxaba AlHar-u The heat became allayed, or assuaged, (Ḳ, TA,) somewhat, (TA,) in its vehemence. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: xab-N (JK, Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) [said in the Mṣb to be originally an inf. n.] and xib-N↓ (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) [originally an inf. n. accord. to most authorities] and xub-N↓, (MF,) applied to a man, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb,) fem. xab-apN, [which casts doubt upon the assertion that xab-N is originally an inf. n., for were it so the masc. and fem. accord. to a general rule would be the same, as well as the sing. and pl.,] applied to a woman, (JK, A,) A great deceiver, or very deceitful; (JK,* Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) wicked and deceitful; a mischief-maker; (Ṣ,* A,* L, Ḳ,* TA;) deceitful, guileful, artful, crafty, or cunning; syn. mak-aArN. (Ḥam p. 537, in explanation of the first and second.)
Also the first of these words, A long, elevated tract (Habol, in some copies of the Ḳ erroneously written jbl, TA) of sand, cleaving to the ground. (Ḳ, TA.)
And A plain, or soft, tract, between two rugged tracts, in which (i. e. in the former of which) are truffles. (AA, Ḳ.)
xub-N: see xab-N.
See also xib-apN. Hence vawobN OaxobaAbN: see, again, xib-apN.
OaxobaAbu AlfaHivi The HawaAyaA [or winding guts, or intestines into which the food passes from the stomach]: (Ḳ:) thus used in the pl. form, as though pl. of xub-N. (TA.)
Also The bark (liHaMC) of a tree. (JK, Ḳ.)
And Low, or depressed, land: (JK, Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxobaAbN and [of mult.] xubuwbN. (TA.)
See also xab-N.
‡ A rising, or state of agitation and commotion, of the sea; (JK, Ḳ, TA;) as also xibaAbN↓. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xab-apN: see xib-apN.
xub-apN: see xib-apN and xabiybapN.

Also A place where water collects and remains or stagnates, (AA, Ḳ, TA,) and around which grow herbs, or leguminous plants: (TA:) a tract of land neither fruitful nor unfruitful, between two other tracts of land; pl. xubabN: (AḤn:) a tract of land between that which abounds with herbage and that which is unproductive: (Ru-beh:) a narrow tract of soft land abounding with herbage, not rugged nor plain, but inclining to be plain; (ISh;) but ADk disapproves of this explanation: (TA:) or a tract producing herbage between two long and elevated tracts of sand; as also xabiybapN↓: (Ibn-Nujeym:) and, accord. to AA, also pasture, or herbage. (TA.) Also or maxab-apN↓, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, or both, TA,) and xabiybapN↓, The bottom (baTon) of a valley. (Ḳ.)

xib-apN and xub-apN↓ and xab-apN↓ A narrow tract, or streak, of sand; [in one copy of the A, I find xib-apN and xabiybapN thus explained; but in another, maxab-apN↓ is written in the place of the former of these two words;] or of clouds; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xabiybapN↓: (Aṣ:) or, of sand, what resembles a faAliq [or depressed tract between two hills], except in its being wider and more spreading, and not having abrupt sides; so says AḤn in explaining xb-p [thus in the TA] and xabiybapN↓: (TA:) or all three signify a piece of rag like a fillet; as also xabiybapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xub-N↓: (Lḥ:) or the last two (xbybp and xb-) signify a piece of rag from a garment, with which one binds his arm or hand. (JK, TA.) [Hence,] vawobN OaxobaAbN↓, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) [like OahobaAbN,] and vwb xibabN, (Lḥ, JK, Ḳ,) like hibabN, (JK,) and vwb xabaAYibu↓, like habaAYibu; (Ṣ;) [the latter word in the first of these phrases being pl. of xub-N; that in the second, pl. of xib-pN; and that in the third, pl. of xabiybapN;] A garment, or piece of cloth, rent in pieces, ragged, or tattered. (Lḥ, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also xabiybapN, below.] It is also said that the xib-ap of a garment, or piece of cloth, is [A portion thereof] like the Tur-ap [q. v.]: and accord. to Sh, the xub-ap thereof is its Tur-ap. (TA.) And xb-p [so in the TA] signifies A piece of rag which a woman wears, covering her head with it: erroneously written by Lth Hn-p. (Az, TA.)
Also, i. e. xib-apN and its two vars., and xabiybapN↓, of which the pl. is xabaAYibu, A streak of the flesh appearing in the skin, occasioned by the loss of flesh. (TA.)

hom.sense: xababN: see xib-N.

Also A kind of run, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with wide steps, but falling short of that termed EanaqN; (Mgh, Mṣb;) i. e. a quick pace: (TA:) or a certain pace which is not quick: (Ḥar p. 157:) or i. q. ramalN [q. v.]: or a pace of a horse, (Ḳ,) and of a camel, (TA,) in which he remores both his right legs together and both his left legs together; i. e. an amble: (Ḳ, TA:) or in which a horse rests on his right and left fore legs alternately, (yuraAwiHu bayona yadayohi, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and in like manner on his kind legs: (Ṣ, TA: [app., as thus explained in the Ṣ and TA, meaning the same as the explanation next before it:]) and (accord. to some, TA) quickness. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xibaAbN: see xib-N.
xabiybN A trench, or furrow, (xad-N,) in the ground. (Ḳ.)
xabiybapN, and its pl. xabaAYibu: see xib-apN, in five places. It is also said to signify A fillet, or bandage. (TA.)

Also ‡ A long strip, or slice, of flesh, or flesh-meat; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so xub-apN↓; (A, TA;) pl. of the former as above: (JK:) or any compact and long portion of flesh: any such portion is also termed xaSiylapN: either in the arm or elsewhere: (AO, TA:) or a [portion such as is termed] xSylp thereof, intermixed with [sinews, or tendons, such as are termed] Eaqab. (TA.) And xabaAYibu Almatonayoni The flesh of the two corresponding portions extending along the two sides of the backbone. (TA.) [Hence,] laHomuhu xabaAYibu His flesh is dissundered, or cut in pieces. (TA.)
See also xub-apN, in two places.

Also The wool of a vaniI- [or sheep in its third year]; (Ṣ, L;) which is better than that termed Eaqiyqap, i. e. the wool of a jacaE [or sheep in or before its second year], and cleaner, and more abundant: (ISk, Ṣ:) so accord. to most of the leading lexicologists; though said in the Ḳ to be a mistake of J, for janiybapN. (TA.)

xaboxabapN [by rule an inf. n. of R. Q. 1:] Laxness, flaccidity, or flabbiness; and a state of commotion, moving to and fro, quivering, or the like: (Ṣ:) or laxness, flaccidity, or flabbiness, of a thing in a state of commotion, moving to and fro, quivering, or the like; (TA;) as also xaboxaAbN↓. (JK, Ḳ, TA.) [See also R. Q. 2.]
xaboxaAbN: see what next precedes.

xaAb-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in one copy of the Ḳ xaAb-apN, [as in the CK,] but the former is the more correct, (TA,) Relationship; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and affinity, syn. SihorN: (Ṣ:) pl. xawaAb-u. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, liI mino fulaAnK xawaAb-u [I have ties of relationship, or affinity, to such a one]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: maxab-apN: see xub-apN:
and see also xib-apN.

entry.sense: muxaAb-N, as though from xaAb-a↓, One who acts treacherously towards another, and takes him unawares. (TA.)

1. xabaOahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxobaOu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaboCN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He hid, or concealed, it; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also xb-Ohu↓, [but app. in an intensive sense, or applying to a number of things,] (Ḳ,) inf. n. taxobiYapN; (TA;) and AxtbOhu↓. (Ḳ.)
He kept it, preserved it, guarded it, or took care of it. and xb-Ohu↓ he did so much; and well, or carefully. (Mṣb.) [He laid it up; stored it, or reposited it, in a place of safety.]
2: see 1, in two places. [Hence, xb-O jaAriyapF He kept a girl carefully concealed from view: see the pass. part. n., below.]
3. xaAbaOotuhu maA kacaA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaAbaOapN, (TḲ,) I proposed to him as an enigma, What is such a thing? syn. HaAjayotuhu. (Ḳ. [See also 8.])

hom.sense: 8. AxtbO It was, or became, hidden, or concealed: (Mgh:) he hid, or concealed, himself. (Ṣ.)
It is also trans.: see 1.
[Hence,] AxtbO lahu xabiyoYFA↓ He expressed a thing enigmatically to him, and then asked him respecting it. (IDrd, Ḳ. [See also 3.])

entry.sense: xaboCN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xiboCN↓ (TA) and xuboOapN↓, of the measure fuEolapN from AlxbO [or rather AlxaboCu], like gurofapN and quboDapN from Algarofu and AlqaboDu, (Ḥar p. 426,) and xabiIoCN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xabiyoYapN↓, (Ḳ,) of which last the pl. is xabaAyaA, (TA,) A thing that is hidden, or concealed, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) and absent, or unseen. (Ḳ.) [Hence,] xaboCu Als-amaMCi The rain. (Th, Ṣ, Ḳ.) And xaboCu AlOaroDi The plants, or herbage. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And xabaAyaA↓ AlOaroDi The seed which the sower has hidden in the earth: or what God has hidden in the mines of the earth. (TA, from a trad.) Al-aciI yuxoriju AlxaboCa fiI Als-amewaAti waAlOaroDi, in the Ḳur [xxvii. 25], is held by Az to mean Who knoweth what is unseen in the heavens and the earth; agreeably with an explanation of AlxaboCu by Fr. (TA.)
xiboCN: see the next preceding paragraph.

xaboOapN A daughter; syn. binotN. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, Aln-abotu is put for Albinotu.]) Hence the prov., xaboOapN xayorN mino yafaEapi sawoCK [A daughter is better than a grown-up boy of evil deeds]. (TA.) [In Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 438, the first word in this prov. is written xubaOap, and followed by SidoqK.] Aboo-Zeyd Saʼeed Ibn-Ows El-Anṣáree entitled one of his books ktAb xbOp because he commenced it by mentioning xbOp in the sense of bnt, quoting the foregoing prov. in confirmation thereof. (TA.)
xuboOapN: see xaboCN.
AimoraOapN xubaOapN A woman who shows herself and then hides herself: (Ṣ, O, TA:) [like qubaEapN:] or a woman who keeps to her house, or tent. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: xibaMCN A well-known kind of structure; (Ḳ;) [i. e.] a kind of tent, (Mgh, TA,) made of wool, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or of camels' fur, or sometimes of [goats'] hair, sometimes upon two poles, or three; what is above this kind being termed bayotN: (Mṣb:) or a tent having one pole; that which has more than one pole being termed byt: (AZ, TA in art. rbE:) [or] also applied to a byt [or tent] of any kind: (Towsheeh, TA voce bayotN, q. v.:) pl. OaxobiYapN, (TA,) or OaxobiyapN: (Mṣb:) it is from xabaOahu “he hid it,” or “concealed it:” (Mgh:) or it belongs to art. xbI: (Ḳ:) most of the lexicologists hold that its radical letters are xbI: some, that they are xbw: IDrd asserts that they are xbO. (TA:) [See also art. xbI.]
A mark made with a hot iron upon some secret part of an excellent she-camel: pl. OaxobiYapN. (Lth, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xabiIoCN: see xaboCN: and see also 8.
xabiyoYapN, and its pl. xabaAyaA: see xabNCN, in two places.
kayodN xaAbiYN An artifice, or a stratagem, resulting in disappointment; i. q. xaAYibN; (AḤei, Ḳ;) formed [from the latter] by transposition. (AḤei.)

xaAbiYapN, as sometimes pronounced, (Mṣb,) or xaAbiyapN, with the C suppressed, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) because of frequent usage, (Mṣb,) i. q. Hub-N [q. v.]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. A large jar: pl. xwAbI [i. e. xawaAbiYu, or xawaAbK]: (TA:) from xabaOahu “he hid it,” or “concealed it.” (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
[Hence,] binotu AlxaAbiyapi † Wine. (Ḥar p. 365.)
maxobaON A place, or chamber, for hiding or concealing [anything]; a secret place or chamber: pl. maxaAbiYu. (MA.)

jaAriyapN muxab-aOapN; so in the [Ṣ and] O, and in some of the correct copies of the Ḳ; in other copies of the Ḳ muxobaOapN; (TA;) [and thus in the CK;] A girl that is [kept in the house, or tent,] concealed from view; or that conceals herself; (Ṣ;) that is kept behind, or within, the curtain; (Ḳ, TA;) not going forth: or (TA) that is not yet married. (Lth, Ḳ, TA.)
muxotabiYN One who conceals himself in order that he may see without the knowledge of him who is seen. (Mgh.)

hom.sense: 1. xabata cikoruhu The mention of him, or it, was, or became, concealed: (L:) [app. meaning he, or it, was, or became, obscure; or of no reputation, or repute.]
xabuva, accord. to Z, i. q. xabuva [q. v.]: occurring in a trad. (TA.) [See xabiytN.]

entry.sense: 4. Axbt He became in what is termed xabotN [q. v.]. (A, TA.)

And, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) [hence, or] from xabotN, (Ksh and Bḍ in xi. 25, and TA,) or from xabata cikoruhu, (L,) inf. n. UixobaAtN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) ‡ He (a man, Mṣb, TA) was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) in heart, (Mṣb,) and obedient, (TA,) lil-ehi to God. (Ṣ, TA.) And in like manner, in the Ḳur [xi. 25], (TA,) waOaxobatuwA UilaI rab-ihimo means ‡ And who have become lowly, humble, or submissive, [and obedient,] to their Lord; or have lowered, humbled, or abased, themselves to their Lord; or have trusted to their Lord: (A,* TA:) for the Arabs put UilaI in the place of li. (TA.)

xabotN A low, or depressed, tract of ground: (TA:) or a low, or depressed, (Ṣ,) or concealed and low, (TA,) tract of ground, in which is sand: (Ṣ, TA:) or a wide, or spacious, low tract of ground: (IAạr, A, Ḳ:) or a plain, or soft, tract of ground in a [stony tract such as is termed] Har-ap: (TA:) and a wide bottom, or bed, or interior, of a valley: (A:) or a deep valley, easy to be walked or ridden through, extended [to a great length], and in which grow varieties of the EiDaAh: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxobaAtN (Ḳ) and [of mult.] xubuwtN: (A, Ḳ:) it is a genuine Arabic word. (TA.)
fiyhi xabotapN ‡ In him is lowliness, humility, or submissiveness. (Ṣ, TA.)

xabiytN A thing that is contemptible, or despicable; (Ḳ, TA;) bad, corrupt, abominable, vile, base, or disapproved; [&c.;] (TA;) and [thus] i. q. xabiyvN. (Aṣ, Ḳ.) The Jew of Kheyber says,
yanofaEu AlT-ay-ibu Alqaliylu mina Alr-izo
qi walaA yanofaEu Alkaviyru Alxabiytu
[The lawful, but small, supply of the means of subsistence is beneficial, but the large and unlawful is not beneficial]. (TA.) Kh asked Aṣ respecting Alxbyt in this verse; and the latter replied that the poet meant Alxabiyv; the former word being of the dial. of Kheyber: but Kh rejoined, “If so, the poet would have said Alktyr: it behooves you only to say that the people of Kheyber change v into t in some words:” AM thinks that Alxbyt in this verse is a mistranscription for Alxatiyt, which means the thing that is “contemptible and bad,” and is syn. with Alxasiys. (TA.)
It is also applied to a man; meaning as above; or Bad, corrupt, vitious, or depraved. (TA.)
muxobitN † Still; motionless: as also muxobiTN. (TA in art. xmd.)

1. xabuva, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yaxobuvu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xabaAvapN, (Ṣ,) or xubovN, the former being a simple subst., (Mṣb,) or both, (Mgh, Ḳ, [the latter word erroneously written in the CK xabov,]) and xabaAviyapN, (Ḳ,) said of a thing, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) It was, or became, xabiyv [q. v., meaning bad,, &c.]; contr. of TaAba. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [Hence,] xabuvato raAYiHatuhu ‡ [Its, or his, odour was, or became, bad, foul, or abominable]. (A.) And xabuva TaEomuhu ‡ [Its taste was, or became, bad, foul, abominable, or nauseous]. (A.) And xabuvato nafosuhu ‡ His soul [or stomach] became heavy; (TA;) it heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. gavato: (A and TA in the present art., and Ṣ and Ḳ in art. gvI: [see also macirato nafosuhu, in art. mcr:]) a phrase forbidden by Moḥammad to be used; as though he disliked the word xubovN. (TA.) One says of certain food, taxobuvu Eanohu Aln-afosu ‡ [The soul, or stomach, becomes heavy, or heaves, or becomes agitated by a tendency to vomit, in consequence of it]. (TA.)

xabuva, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. xubovN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) said of a man, signifies [in like manner] He was, or became, xabiyv, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) meaning bad, corrupt, base, or abominable; wicked, deceitful, guileful, artful, crafty, or cunning. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA. [See also 4.]) [Hence,] xabuva bihaA ‡ He committed adultery, or fornication, with her. (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
[It is also said of a venomous reptile and the like, meaning It was, or became, malignant, or noxious; impure, unclean, foul, or filthy.]

2. hecaA mim-aA yuxab-ivu Aln-afosa, (TA,) or yuxobivu↓, Alnfs, (so in a copy of the A, [but the former I believe to be the right,]) This is of the things that cause the soul [or stomach] to become heavy, or to heave, or become agitated by a tendency to vomit. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Axbv He (a man) was, or became, characterized by xubov (Mṣb, TA) and Xar- (Mṣb) [meaning badness, wickedness, deceit,, &c.: see also xabuva].

He had bad, wicked, or deceitful, companions or friends, and a bad, wicked, or deceitful, family: (L:) or his companions, or friends, became bad, wicked, or deceitful: (Ṣ in art. fls:) or he took to himself bad, wicked, or deceitful, companions or friends (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) or connexions or assistants. (TA.)
Axbvhu He taught him to be bad, wicked, or deceitful: and rendered him bad, corrupt, vitious, or depraved. (Ṣ.)
See also 2.

entry.sense: 5: see what next follows {6}.

6. tHAbv (A, TA) He made a show of being, or pretended to be, bad, wicked, or deceitful. (TA.) And you say also txb-v↓ [either in the same sense, or as meaning He affected, or endeavoured, to be bad, wicked, or deceitful; or to do that which was xabiyv, or bad,, &c.]. (A, TA.)

10. Astxbv [He deemed, or esteemed, xabiyv, i. e. bad,, &c.]. kaAnati AlEarabu tasotaxobivu mivola AlHay-api waAlEaqorabi [The Arabs used to deem impure, unclean, foul, or filthy, such as the serpent and the scorpion]. (Mṣb.)
‡ He deemed bad, or corrupt, a word, or a dialectic variant. (A, TA.)

xubovN an inf. n. of xabuva: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [used as a simple subst., it means Any of the qualities denoted by the epithet xabiyvN, q. v., i. e. badness,, &c.:] and xib-iyvaI↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ:) or this is a subst. from Oaxobva meaning “he had a bad, wicked, or deceitful, family;” (TA;) and signifies the state of having bad, wicked, or deceitful, companions or friends or connexions: (L:)
xaAbivapN↓, also, is syn. with [xubovN, and so is] xabaAvapN↓, (Ḳ,) [for] this last is another inf. n. of xabuva, like xubovN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or it is a simple subst. (Mṣb.) [Hence,] the first particularly signifies ‡ Adultery, or fornication. (Ḳ, TA.) See also xabiyvN, in three places.

xabavN The dross of iron, (Ṣ, TA,) and of silver, when they are molten. (TA.) [Hence the saying,] layosa AlUiboriyzu kaAlxabavi [lit. Pure gold is not like dross]; meaning ‡ the good is not like the bad. (A, TA.)
Adulterating alloy in gold and iron, &c. (Ḥar p. 135.)
A thing wherein is no good. (TA.)

‡ Excrement, or ordure: impurity, or filth. (Mgh in art. ql, and TA.) Hence the saying in a trad., UicaA balaga AlmaMCu qul-atayoni lamo yaHomilo xabavFA [explained in art. AHl]. (Mgh ubi suprà, and TA.)
yaA xubavu: see xabiyvN.

hom.sense: yaA xibovapu: see xabyvN.

xibovapN with respect to a slave signifies † Unlawful capture; capture from a people whom it is unlawful to make slaves, (Mgh,* Ḳ, TA,) by reason of a treaty, or league, made with them, (Mgh, TA,) or of some sacred, or inviolable, right, originally belonging to them. (TA.) You say of a slave, laA xibovapa fiyhi mino UibaAqK walaA sariqapK ‡ [There is no unlawful capture in his case, from having run away, nor from having been stolen]. (A.)
fulaAnN lixibovap is like the saying lizinoyapK † [Such a one is the offspring of adultery, or fornication]. (Ṣ.) And wulida fulaAnN lixibovapK means ‡ Such a one was born spuriously. (A,* L.)

entry.sense: xabaAvi: see the next paragraph, in two places.

xabiyvN contr. of Tay-ibN; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) applied to objects of the senses and to those of the intellect; (Kull p. 177;) to sustenance, or victuals, and to offspring, and men, and to other things: (TA:) Bad; corrupt: (Mṣb, TA:) disapproved, hated, or abominable; (Mṣb, TA;) this accord. to IAạr, being its primary signification: (TA:) or so in respect of taste, and of odour: (Mgh:) [nasty, nauseous, loathsome, or disgusting:] impure, unclean, foul, or filthy: (Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) unlawful; (Mgh, Mṣb;) applied in this sense to certain food: and, applied to certain beverage, injurious: (TA:) applied to medicine such as is forbidden in a certain trad., it means either impure and unlawful, such as wine, &c., or nauseous to the taste: (IAth, TA:) you say that a thing is xabiyv in taste, [and in odour,] and in colour: and you apply this epithet to adultery, or fornication; and to property unlawfully acquired; and to blood, and to the like things which God has forbidden: (TA:) also to such things as garlic and onions (Mṣb, TA) and leeks, (TA,) which are disagreeable in taste and odour: (TA:) and to such things as the serpent and the scorpion: (Mṣb:) applied to language, it means † opprobrious, or of a reviling nature; (TA;) and ‡ bad or corrupt [in respect of authority; or of a bad dialect]: (A, TA:) applied to religion, † infidel, or of the nature of infidelity: (TA:) applied to a man, bad, corrupt, base, or abominable; wicked, deceitful, guileful, artful, crafty, or cunning; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also xaAbivN↓: (Ḳ:) and an adulterer, or a fornicator: (Mṣb:) and a blamer, or censurer: or a slanderer, or calumniator: (Ḥar p. 611:) [and, applied to a venomous reptile and the like, malignant, or noxious; as well as impure, unclean, foul, or filthy:] the fem. is xabiyvapN: (Mṣb:) the pl. masc. is xibaAvN (A, TA) and xubuvN, for which it is allowable to say xubovN↓, accord. to the dial. of Temeem, (Mṣb,) and xubavaMCu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA,) like XurafaMCu [pl. of XariyfN], (Mṣb,) and OaxobaAvN, like OaXaraAfN [another pl. of XariyfN], (Mṣb, MF, TA,) and xabavapN, (Kr, Mṣb, MF, TA,) like DaEafapN pl. of DaEiyfN, (Mṣb, MF, TA,) two instances of which the like can scarcely be found, (Mṣb,) or is not found among sound words, for saraApN pl. of sariI-N is an unsound word, (MF, TA,) and xubuwvN, (AZ, TA,) which is also extr., (TA,) [and xabaAvaI, (like as HazaAnaI is a pl. of HaziynN,) applied in the A, in art. xnv, to xanaAvaI, pl. of xunovaI,] and xabiyvuwna [applied only to rational beings]: (Mgh:) and the pl. fem., i. e. of xabiyvapN, is xabaAYivu (Mṣb, TA) and xabiyvaAtN. (Mgh.) AlX-ajarapu Alxabiyvapu, mentioned in the Ḳur [xiv. 31], (TA,) means The colocynth: or the kaXuwv, (Ḳ; TA,) which is a certain plant that clings to the branches of trees and has no root in the earth; (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. kXv;) [a species of cuscuta, or dodder;] or yellow Euruwq that cling to trees: (TA in the present art.:) also occurring in a trad., as meaning the garlic-plant; and the onion; and the leek; because of their disagreeable taste and odour. (IAth, TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting the slain at Bedr, OuloquwA fiI qaliybK xabiyvK muxobivK↓ They were cast into a well corrupt, and corrupting what fell into it. (TA.) xabiyvN muxobivN↓, (Ṣ, L,) or xabiyvN and muxobivN↓, (Ḳ,) and xaAbivN↓ (TA) and maxobavaAnN↓, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) applied to a man, signify One who takes to himself bad, wicked, or deceitful, companions or friends (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, TA) or connexions or assistants: (TA:) or maxobavaAnu↓, as a determinate noun, [without the article Al] is only used in calling to, or addressing, a person: (Ḳ:) you say, yaA maxobavaAnu; (Ṣ;) fem. maxobavaAnapu↓: and to a man and woman together, yA maxobavaAnu: (L, TA:) and in the phrase xabiyvN muxobivN↓, the former word signifies bad, wicked, or deceitful, in himself; and the latter, having bad, wicked, or deceitful, companions or friends and assistants. (AʼObeyd, TA.) One says also, yaAxubavu↓, meaning yA xabiyvu [O bad or wicked or deceitful man!]; and to a woman, yaAxabaAvi↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) indecl., with kesr for its termination, (Ṣ,) and yA xabiyvapu. (Ḳ [accord. to SM: so in all the copies in his hands; but not found by him in any other lexicon: not in the CK, nor in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ.]) xabaAvi↓ also occurs, in a saying of El-Ḥasan, addressed to the present world, Ald-unoyaA. (L.) And yaA xibovapu↓ was said by El-Hajjáj to Anas, as meaning yA xabiyvu: and is also used as meaning O [thou of] bad, wicked, or deceitful, qualities or dispositions! [app. addressed to a woman, as the context seems to show; and agreeably with an assertion in Ḥam p. 810, that xibovpN is sometimes used in speaking of an old woman]. (L, TA.) xabiyvu Aln-afosi means ‡ Having the soul [or stomach] heavy, [or heaving, or agitated by a tendency to vomit,] and in a disagreeable state. (TA.) And maxobavaAnN↓ applied to a lie occurs in a trad, as meaning xabiyvN app. in an intensive sense [i. e. Very abominable]. (TA.) In the saying, OaEuwdu biQll-ehi, (Mgh,) or Aall-ehum-a Uin-iI OaEuwdu bika, (Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA,) mina Alxubuvi waAlxbaAYivi, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) or mina Alxubovi↓ waAlxabaAYivi, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) a form of words which Moḥammad directed his followers to pronounce on entering a privy, or place of retirement for the relief of nature, because devils are in such a place, (Mgh, TA,) Alxubuv is pl. of Alxabiyv, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) and so is Alxubov accord. to the dial. of Temeem, (Mṣb, TA,) and AlxabaAYiv is pl. of Alxabiyvap; (Mgh, TA;;) and the meaning is, I seek protection by God, or O God, I seek protection by Thee, from the male devils and the female devils, (IAth, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) of the genii and of mankind: (Mgh:) or, reading Alxubov↓, [as a subst,] from infidelity and the devils: (Aboo-Bekr, TA:) or, [so reading, and regarding AlxbAYv as pl. of Alxabiyvapu↓ used as a subst.,] from infidelity and acts of disobedience: (Mṣb, TA:) or, from wicked, or unrighteous, conduct, such as adultery and the like, and culpable actions and evil qualities or dispositions: El-Khaṭṭábee asserts that the reading Alxubov, with the b quiescent, is a mistake of the relaters of traditions; but En-Nawawee rejects this assertion. (TA.)
xabaAvapN: see xubovN.
xabiyvapN fem. of the epithet xabiyvN. (Mṣb.)

Also, [used as a subst.,] A bad, wicked, or deceitful, quality or disposition; and a culpable action: pl. xabaAYivu. (L, TA.) [Hence,] Oum-u AlxabaAYivi † [The mother of bad qualities, &c.; meaning] wine. (T in art. Am.) See also xabiyvN, last sentence.

AlxabaAYivu also signifies Those things which the Arabs deemed foul, or filthy, or unclean, and which they did not eat; such as vipers, and scorpions, and the brS [i. e. either baroS or buroS], and the waral, and beetles, and the rat, or mouse. (L.)
xib-iyvN, applied to a man, (TA,) signifies kaviyru Alxubovi [i. e. Very bad or wicked or deceitful; or much addicted to adultery or fornication]: pl. xib-iyvuwna. (Ḳ.)
xib-iyvaI: see xubovN.
xaAbivN: see xabiyvN, in two places.
xaAbivapN: see xubovN.

[Oaxobavu compar. and superl. of xabiyvN]: pl. OaxaAbivu. (TA.) You say, humo OaxaAbivu Aln-aAsi [They are the worst, or the most wicked or deceitful, of men]. (TA.) And huwa mina AlOaxaAbivi [He is of the worst,, &c., of men]. (A, TA.)
And hiIa Oaxobavu Al-ugatayoni ‡ It is the worse, or more corrupt, [in respect of authority,] of the two words, or dialectic variants. (A, TA.)

AlOaxobavaAni Urine and dung (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) of a human being: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or vomit and human ordure or thin human ordure: (Fr, TA:) or fetor of the mouth, and sleeplessness: or sleeplessness, and disquietude of mind by reason of grief. (Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., laA yuSal-iI Alr-ajulu wuhuwa yudaAfiEu AlOaxobavayoni [The man shall not pray while he is striving to suppress the urine and ordure]. (TA.)

waqaEa fiI waAdiI tuxub-iva, (Ḳ,* TA,) in which the last word, also pronounced tuxub-ava, is imperfectly decl., (TA,) is similar to wqE fI wAdI tuxuy-iba [and means He fell into a state of things that was bad, corrupt, disapproved,, &c.]. (Ḳ, TA.)
muxobivo One who teaches others to be bad, wicked, or deceitful: and some allow it to be applied to one who attributes, or imputes, to others what is bad, wicked, or the like. (TA.)
See also xabiyvN, in four places.

maxobavapN A cause of evil or corruption: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. maxaAbivu. (TA.) So in the saying of 'Antarah,
nub-iYotu EamorFA gayora XaAkiri niEomatiI
waAlkuforu maxobavapN linafosi AlmunoEimi
[I have been told that ʼAmr is not thankful for my beneficence: and ingratitude is a cause of evil to the soul of the benefactor]. (Ṣ.) One says also, fiyhi maxaAbivu jam-apN [In him, or it, are many causes of evil or corruption]. (A.) And TaEaAmN maxobavapN ‡ Food that is a cause of heaviness to the soul [or stomach]; or of heaving, or becoming agitated by a tendency to vomit: or that is unlawful. (TA.)
maxobavaAnN and maxobavaAnu and maxobavaAnapu: see xabiyvN, in four places.

hom.sense: 1. xabura, aor. _u {yaxoburu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xubuwrN; (TA;) and Axtbr↓, and txb-r↓; (Ḳ;) He knew; or had, or possessed, knowledge; biXaIoCK [of a thing; generally meaning, with respect to its internal, or real, state]. (Ḳ, TA.)

xabarahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaxoburu}, (Mṣb, MṢ,) inf. n. xaborN; (Mṣb, MṢ;*) and xabirahu, [aor. _a {yaxobaru},] (A,) inf. n. xabarN; (TA;) and Axtbirhu↓, and txb-rhu↓; (TA;) He knew it; syn. Ealimahu; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb;) [generally meaning, with respect to its internal, or real, state; like xabura bihi: see xuborN, its simple subst., as distinguished from its inf. n.] You say, mino Oayona xabarota hacaA AlOamora, (so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or xabirota, (so in another copy of the Ṣ, and so in the A, where it is expressly said to be with kesr,) Whence knewest thou this thing? (Ṣ, A.*)

And xabarahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxoburu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. xuborN and xiborapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) and Axtbrhu↓ [which is the more common in this sense]; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He tried, made trial of, made experiment of, tested, proved, assayed, proved by trial or experiment or experience him, or it. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Hence the phrase, (Ṣ,) laOaxoburan-a xabaraka, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in some good lexicons xuboraka, (TA, [and so in the CK, but this I think to be a mistake, suggested by the explanation, which is not literal,]) i. q. laOaEolaman-a Eilomaka [which properly signifies I will assuredly know thy knowledge, or what thou knowest, but here means, as is shown by the manner in which the phrase that it explains is mentioned in the Ṣ, I will assuredly try, prove, or test, thy state, and so know what thou knowest]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Hence, also,] the saying of Abu-dDardà, wajadotu Aln-aAsa Auxoburo taqolihimo, (Ṣ,) or taqolihi, (A, Ḳ,) I found the people to be persons of whom it is said thus: [Try, prove, or test, them, or him, and thou wilt hate them, or him:] i. e. there is not one [of them] but his conduct is hated when it is tried, or proved, or tested: (Ḳ:) or when thou triest, provest, or testest, them, thou wilt hate them: the imperative form being used, but the meaning being that of an enunciative: (Ṣ, A, L, B:) [wajadotu is a verb of the kind called OafoEaAlu Alquluwbi, which govern two objective complements; therefore Auxoburo taqolihimo and Auxoburo taqolihi are for maqoliy-iyna Einoda Alxiborapi and maqoliy-FA End Alxbrp.]
xabara AlOaroDa, [and, as appears from a passage in the L, xb-rhA↓, (see xaborN,)] He furrowed, or ploughed, the land for sowing. (Mṣb.)
xabara AlT-aEaAma, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxoburu}, inf. n. xaborN, (TA,) He made the food greasy; or put grease to it. (Ḳ, TA.)
xabira It (a place) was, or became, what is termed xaboraMC: (Ṣ:) or abounded with sidor [or lote-trees]. (TA.)
And xabirati AlOaroDu, aor. _a {yaxobaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xabarN, (TA,) The land, or ground, abounded with xabaAr [app. meaning soft soil: see 3]. (Ḳ.)
xbrt, [probably xaburato, like gazurato, &c.,] inf. n. xubuwrN, ‡ She (a camel) abounded with milk. (Lḥ, TA. [See xaborN.])
2: see 4, in two places:
and see 1.

entry.sense: 3. xAbrhu, (TA,) inf. n. maxaAbarapN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) [He made a contract, or bargain, with him to till and sow and cultivate land for a share of its produce:] the inf. n. signifies i. q. muzaAraEapN [i. e. the making a contract, or bargain, with another to cultivate land for a share of its produce], (AO, Lḥ, Ṣ, A, IAth, Mgh, Mṣb,) for somewhat of its produce, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or for a third or a quarter, (AO, Mgh,) or for a determined share, such as a third or a quarter or some other portion, (IAth,) or for half or the like: (so in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA:) or the tilling the ground for half or the like: (so in other copies of the Ḳ:) and i. q. muWaAkarapN: (Ḳ:) and xiborN↓ is syn. with muxaAbarapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it is a forbidden practice: (A, Mgh, TA:) it is from xabiyrN signifying “a tiller, or cultivator, of land:” (Ṣ, Mgh:) or from xabara “he furrowed, or ploughed (land) for sowing;” whence xabiyrN also: (Mṣb:) or from xabirati AlOaroDu “the land abounded with xabaAr:” or from [the fortress of] xayobar, because the Prophet made it to remain in the possession of its inhabitants for half of its revenue; and therefore it was said, xaAbarahumo. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Axbrhu, [inf. n. UixobaArN;] (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and xb-rhu↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxobiyrN; (Ḳ;) are syn. [as signifying He informed him, told him, or acquainted him]. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say, Oaxobarotuhu bikacaA, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [and Eano kcA,] and xab-arotuhu↓, (Ṣ,) [I informed him, or told him, of such a thing; or acquainted him with such a thing; or made him to know the internal, or real, state of such a thing.] And Axbrhu xubuwrapF↓, i. e. OanobaOahu maA Einodahu [He informed him, or told him, of what he had, or knew]. (Ḳ. [Whether it be meant that Axbr is doubly trans. without a particle, in this instance, like OaEolama, or whether xbwrp be a quasi-inf. n, is not explained.]) One says also, tuxobiru Eano majohuwlihi maroMtuhu ‡ [His aspect acquaints one with his unknown state or qualities]. (A.) [And Axbr Eanohu He predicated of him, or it.]
Oaxobarotu All-iqoHap ‡ I found the milch camel to be abounding with milk. (Ḳ. [See 1, last sentence.])
5: see 1, in two places:
and see 10, in four places.

txb-rwA, (Ḳ,) or txb-rwA xuborapF, (Ṣ,) They bought a sheep or goat, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) for different sums, (TA,) and slaughtered it, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and divided its flesh among themselves, (Ṣ, TA,) each of them receiving a share proportioned to the sum that he had paid. (TA.)
8: see 1, in three places.
maA Qxotabarota liOaholika What xuborap, or flesh-meat, hast thou bought for thy family? (TA.)

entry.sense: 10. Astxbrhu (A, Ḳ) and txb-rhu↓ (Ḳ) He asked, or sought, or desired, of him information, or news, or tidings: (A,* Ḳ:) or he asked him respecting news, or tidings, and desired that he should inform him thereof. (TA.) And Astxbr and txb-r↓, (Ṣ,) or Astxbr Alxabara and txb-rhu↓, (TA,) He asked, or inquired, after the news, or tidings, (Ṣ, TA,) that he might know the same: (TA:) and txb-r↓ AlOaxobaAra He searched after the news, or tidings, diligently, or time after time. (A, TA.)

hom.sense: xaborN: see xuborN.

Also Trees of the kind called sidor [or lote-trees], (Lth, Ḳ,) and OaraAk, with abundant herbage around them; (Lth;) as also xabirN↓: (Lth, Ḳ:) [both coll. gen. ns.:] ns. un. xaborapN and xabirapN. (TA.)
Seed-produce. (Ḳ.)

A place where water rests, or stagnates, in a mountain: (Ḳ:) a place where water has fallen, such as the water-course has furrowed (xab-ara [perhaps a mistranscription for xabara]) in the summits (ruWuws) [of mountains], and through which one wades. (L.)

A large [leathern water-bag of the kind called] mazaAdap [q. v.]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xaboraMCu↓ (Kr, Ḳ) and xiborN↓: (Ḳ:) but this last is disallowed, in the sense above-explained, by AHeyth; and others say that the first word is better: (TA:) pl. of the first xubuwrN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Hence, by way of comparison thereto, (Ṣ,) ‡ A she-camel abounding with milk; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xiborN↓, (Ḳ,) and maxobuwrapN↓ [naAqapN]. (TA.)

xuborN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and xiborN↓ (Ḳ) and xaborN↓, an inf. n., (Mṣb,) and xabarN↓, also an inf. n., (TA,) and xuborapN↓ and xiborapN↓ and maxobarapN↓, (Ḳ,) Knowledge, syn. EilomN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) biXaIoCK [of a thing]: (A, Ḳ:)
or, accord. to some, xubozN signifies knowledge of the secret internal state: and xibozapN↓ and xubozapN↓ signify knowledge of the external and internal state; or, as some say, of secret internal circumstances or properties; but this necessarily involves acquaintance with external things. (TA.) You say, liI bihi xuborN and xiborapN↓ [&c.] I have knowledge of it. (TA.) And maA liI bihi xuborN [&c.] I have not knowledge of it. (A.)
See also xiborapN.
And see xabiyrN:
and xuborapN.
xiborN: see xuborN:
and see also 3:
and see xaborN, in two places.

entry.sense: xabarN [originally] an inf. n. of xabirahu: see xuborN. (TA.)

Also Information; a piece of information; a notification; intelligence; an announcement; news; tidings; a piece of news; an account; a narration, or narrative; a story; syn. nabaON; (T, Ḳ;) that comes to one from a person of whom he asks it: (TA:) or xabarN and nabaON are not synonymous; for, accord. to Er-Rághib and others, the latter relates to a thing of great importance: and accord. to the leading authorities in lexicology and the science of conventional language, the former signifies properly, and in its common acceptation, what is related from another or others: to which authors on the Arabic language add, that it may be true or false: (MF:) or what is related from another or others, and talked of: (Mṣb:) pl. OaxobaArN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and pl. pl. OaxaAbiyru. (Ḳ.)

By the relaters of traditions, it is used as syn. with HadiyvN [signifying A tradition; or narrative relating, or describing, a saying or an action, &c. of Moḥammad]: (TA:) or this latter term is applied to what comes from the Prophet; and xabarN, to what comes from another than the Prophet; or from him or another; and OavarN, to what comes from a Companion of the Prophet; but it may also be applied to a saying of the Prophet. (Kull p. 152.)
[In grammar, as correlative of mubotadaON, An enunciative: and as correlative of AisomN, the predicate of the non-attributive verb kaAna and the like, and of kaAda, &c.]
Also A man's state, or case; AlOamoru Al-aciI huwa Ealyohi. (Ḥar p. 20.)

hom.sense: xabirN: see xabiyrN, in two places.
See also xaborN.
xabirapN, or OaroDN xabirapN; and mawoDiEN xabirN, and xabirN alone: see xuborN.
xuborapN: see xuborN, in two places.
Also A portion, or share, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) which one takes, of flesh-meat or fish. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

A sheep, or goat, which is bought by a number of persons, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) for different sums, (TA,) and slaughtered, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of which the flesh is then divided by them among themselves, (Ṣ,) each of them receiving a share proportioned to the sum that he has paid; (TA; [see 5;]) as also xabiyrapN↓: (Ḳ:) and XaApN xabiyrapN↓ a sheep, or goat, divided among several persons; thought by ISd to be formed by rejection of the augmentative letter [in its verb txb-r]. (TA.)
What one buys for his family; as also xuborN↓: (Ḳ:) accord. to some, (TA,) flesh-meat (Ḳ, TA) which one buys for his family. (TA.)
Food, (Ḳ, TA,) consisting of flesh-meat and other kinds. (TA.)

A thing brought forward or offered [for entertainment]. (Lḥ, Ḳ.) So in the saying, AijotamaEuwA EalaI xuboratihi [They congregated over what he had brought forward, or offered, for their entertainment]. (Lḥ.)
A mess of crumbled, or broken, bread, moistened with broth, large, (Ḳ, TA,) and greasy. (TA.)
A bowl in which are bread and flesh-meat for four or five [persons]. (Ḳ.)
Food which the traveller carries in his journey, (Ḳ,) and provides for himself. (TA.)
Seasoning, condiment, or savoury food; as also xabiyrN↓: whence the saying, OataAnaA bixubozapK walamo yaOotinaA bixuborapK [He brought us a cake of bread, but he brought us not any seasoning]. (TA.)
Hence, by the Karaj, whose land is adjacent to 'Irák el-'Ajam, applied to A date; and by some of them pronounced xubolapN. (TA.)

entry.sense: xiborapN Trial, proof, or test; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so xuborN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as in the saying, Sad-aqa Alxabara Alxuboru [The trial, proof, or test, verified the information]. (Ṣ.)
See also xuborN, in three places.

hom.sense: xaboraMCu, (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and OaroDN xaboraMCu, (Ṣ,) and xabirapN↓, (Lth, Ḳ, [in the CK xaborap,]) or OaroDN xabirapN, (Ṣ,) A plain, or level, tract of land, that produces sidor [or lote-trees]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a tract abounding with trees, in the lower part of a meadow, in which water remains until the hot season, and in which grow trees of the kinds called sidor and OaraAk, with abundant herbage around them: (Lth:) the pl. of xaboraMCu is xabaAraI and xabaArK and xaboraAwaAtN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xibaArN; (Ḳ;) and the pl. of xabirapN is xabirN↓; (TA;) [or this is neither a pl. nor a quasi-pl. n.: it may be a coll. gen. n.: but it is probably only an epithet, of which xabirapN is the fem.; for] one says also mawoDiEN xabirN↓, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning a place abounding with sidor. (TA.)

xaboraMCu also signifies A place where water collects and stagnates: (TA:) or where water collects and stagnates at the roots of trees of the kind called sidor: (Ḳ, TA:) or a round low tract of level ground in which water collects. (T.)
See also xabaArN.
And see xaborN.

entry.sense: xabaArN Soft land or soil, (IAạr, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) in which are burrows (IAạr, Ṣ, A) and hollows; (IAạr;) as also xaboraMCu↓: (A:) or soft land or soil, in which beasts sink and are embarrassed: or crumbling ground, in which the feet of beasts sink. (TA.) It is said in a prov., mano tajan-aba AlxabaAra Oamina AlEivaAra [He who avoids soft ground in which the feet sink will be secure from stumbling]. (A, Ḳ.)
Also Heaps of earth, or dust, collected at the roots of trees. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And Burrows of jirocaAn [or large field-rats]: (Ḳ:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {xabaArapN}. (TA.)
Alxabuwru The lion. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: xabiyrN Knowing; having knowledge; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb;) as also xabirN↓: (AḤn:) or possessing much knowledge with respect to internal things; like XahiydN with respect to external things: (L in art. Xhd:) or possessing knowledge of matters of information, news, tidings, accounts, narratives, or stories; of what is termed xabarN; (Ḳ;) or of what are termed OaxobaAr; (TA;) as also xaAbirN↓ and xabirN↓, (Ḳ,) which last is thought by ISd to be a possessive [as distinguished from a verbal] epithet, (TA,) [or it is from xabira, a form which ISd may not have known,] and xuborN↓, (Ḳ,) which is an intensive epithet: (TA:) also informed; possessing information. (TA.) You say, OanaA bihi xabiyrN I have knowledge of it. (A.) And [hence] Alxabiyru is a name of God, meaning He who knoweth what hath been and what is or will be: (TA:) or He who well knoweth the internal qualities of things. (Sharh Et-Tirmidhee.)
Also Possessing knowledge of God, (Ḳ, TA,) by being acquainted with his names and his attributes. (TA.)
A lawyer; one skilled in the law, or practical religion. (TA.)
A head, or chief. (TA.)
A tiller, or cultivator, of land. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Fur, or soft hair, syn. wabarN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of camels, and ‡ of the wild ass. (TA.)
Hair that has fallen: and with p {xabiyrapN}, a portion thereof. (Ḳ.) [See also xabiyrapN below.]

‡ Plants, or herbage; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) fresh herbage: (Ḳ, TA:) likened to the wabar of camels, because growing like the latter: and seed-produce. (TA.) It is said in a trad., nasotaxolibu Alxabiyra ‡ We cut (Ṣ, TA) with the reaping-hook, (TA,) and eat, the plants, or herbage. (Ṣ, TA.)
Froth, or foam: (TA:) or the froth, or foam, of the mouths of camels. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
Seasoned, or made savoury. (TA.)
See also xuborapN.

entry.sense: xubuwrapN: see 4.

hom.sense: xabiyrapN: see xuborapN, in two places.
Also Good wool, of the first shearing. (Ḳ.) [See also xabiyrN.]
An invitation to the Eaqiyqap [q. v.] of a boy. (TA.)

entry.sense: xaAbirN: see xabiyrN.
Also One who tries, proves, or tests, things; having experience. (TA.)

xaAbuwrN A certain plant: (Ḳ:) or a kind of tree, having a blossom beautiful and bright, yellow, and of good odour, with which gardens are adorned: MF says, I do not think it to be found in the East. (TA.)

hom.sense: AlxaybaraI, (Ḳ, TA,) in some copies of the Ḳ written AlxayobariI-u, (TA,) The black serpent. (Ḳ.) So in the saying, balaAhu Qll-ehu biAlxayobaraI [May God afflict him, or it, with the black serpent]: app. because a ruined place becomes the resort of deadly serpents. (TA.)

One says also, Ealayohi Ald-abaraI waHum-aI xayobaraI [May perdition befall him, and the fever of Kheyber: AldbrI being app. an inf. n., syn. with Ald-abaAr, which is used in a similar phrase (Ealayohi Ald-abaAru) mentioned in the TA in art. dbr, and xayobar being altered to xayobaraI, as is indicated in the Ṣ, in order to assimilate it in form to AldbrI]: (Ṣ, TA:) the fever of Kheyber is mutanaAcarap [i. e. a fever “against which people warn one another,” because it is generally fatal]. (TA.) [See also xaAsirN.]

entry.sense: OaxobaAriI-N A historian: a rel. n. formed from the pl., like OanoSaAriI-N and OanomaATiI-N. (TA.)

maxobarN (Ṣ) and maxobarapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and muxobarapN↓ (Ṣ, M) The internal state; an internal, or intrinsic, quality; the intrinsic, or real, as opposed to the apparent, state, or to the aspect, of a thing; [whether pleasing or displeasing; but when used absolutely, meaning the former;] opposite of maroMpN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and of manoZarN [q. v.]. (Ṣ.) See also maxobaraAniI-N.

hom.sense: maxobarapN: see xuborN:
and see maxobarN.
Also [A privy;] a place where excrement, or ordure, is voided. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: maxoburapN: see maxobarN.
rajulN maxobaraAniI-N A man of goodly internal, or intrinsic, qualities; syn. cuw maxobarK↓; like manoZaraAniI-N as meaning cuw manoZarK. (TA.)

hom.sense: maxobuwrN Well seasoned; (Ḳ;) having much grease. (TA.)
naAqapN maxobuwrapN: see xaborN, last sentence.

entry.sense: muxotabarN † A camel having much flesh. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xabaza xubozFA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxobizu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xabozN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made [or kneaded and baked] xuboz [or bread]; (Ḳ, TA;) as also Axtbzhu↓: (Sb, Ṣ, TA:) or the ↓the latter signifies he made [or kneaded and baked] it for himself: (Ḳ:) or Axtbz↓ signifies he kneaded flour, and made dough of it, and then baked it in a mal-ap [see xubozapN below] or in an oven: (T, TA:) [and yuxotabazu↓ signifies it is made into bread: see Ṣ and Ḳ voce fav-N.]

xabaza Alqawoma, (Ṣ, A,) aor. _i {yaxobizu}, (TA,) inf. n. xabozN, (A, Ḳ,) He fed the people, or company of men, with xuboz [or bread]: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:*) like as tamarahumo signifies “he fed them with tamor:” (A:) but Lḥ quotes the saying of certain of the Arabs, Oatayotu baniI fulaAnK faxabazuwA waHaAsuwA waOaqaTuwA, meaning [I came to the sons of such a one, and] they fed me with xuboz and Hayos and OaqiT: he does not say xabazuwniI waHaAsuwniI waOaqaTuwniI. (TA.)

xabazahu, aor. _i {yaxobizu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. xabozN, (Ḳ,) † He beat him, or it: (Ḳ,* TḲ:) accord. to some, with the hand: or with the two hands: (TA:) and some say that xuboz [or bread] is thus called because they beat it with their hands: but this assertion is not valid: (TA:) and you say also, xabaTaniI birijolihi, and xabazaniI, ‡ [He beat me with his foot,] and taxab-aTaniI and taxab-azaniI↓. (A, TA.) And xabaza AlbaEiyru, (TḲ,) inf. n. xabozN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) ‡ The camel beat the ground with his fore foot, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) or, as in some lexicons, with his fore feet. (TA.) And txb-zt↓ AlUibilu Als-aEodaAna † The camels beat the [herbage called] sEadAn with their legs. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, latter part, in two places.
8: see 1, first sentence, in four places.

xubozN a word of well-known meaning; (Ḳ;) [Bread;] that which is eaten. (Ṣ.) It is said in a prov., kul-u OadaApi Alxubozi EinodiI gayoruhu [All the apparatus of bread is in my possession except it, namely, the bread itself]: the origin of which was this: a company of men demanded hospitality of a certain man; and when they sat down, he threw down a [piece of leather such as is called] niToE, and put upon it a mill-stone, and adjusted its pivot, and covered it [with the upper stone]: and the presence of his apparatus made the company to wonder: then he took the handle of the mill, (haAdiI Alr-aHaI,) and began to turn it: whereupon they said to him, What dost thou? and he answered in the words of this proverb. (Ḳ.)
[Hence,] Alxul-apu xubozu AlUibili ‡ [Sweet herbage is the bread of camels: and AlHamoDu faAkihatuhaA, or AaHomuhaA, sour herbage is their fruit, or flesh-meat]. (A, TA.)

xubozapN i. q. TulomapN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) meaning Dough put in a mal-ap, until it is thoroughly baked, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e., in ashes, and earth, in which fire is kindled; (TA;) a cake of bread, (MA, KL,) [or lump of dough,] baked in ashes (KL) [or in any way]; i. q. quroSN and quroSapN. (Ḳ in art. qrS.)
Also A large variydap [or mess of crumbled or broken bread moistened with broth]: or, as some say, flesh-meat. (TA.) [See also xabiyzN.]
xabiyzN Bread made [or kneaded and baked], (Ḳ, TA,) of whatever grain it be. (TA.)
Also i. q. variyd [Bread crumbled or broken, and moistened with broth]. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) [See also xubozapN.]
Also a vulgar term for xabiySapN. (Esh-Shereeshee, in Ḥar p. 21.)
xibaAzapN The trade, or occupation, of the xab-aAz. (Ḳ.)
xubaAzaI: see xub-aAzN.
xab-aAzN A maker of bread; one whose office it is to make bread: (TA:) a baker; syn. furoniI-N. (Mṣb in art. frn.)

xub-aAzN (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ) and xub-aAzapN↓, (Ḳ,) [or the former is a coll. gen. n., and the latter the n. un.,] and xubaAzaI↓ (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ) [which last is the most common form] and xub-aAzaI↓, (Ḳ,) or when with teshdeed the I is elided, (IDrd,) and xub-ayozN↓, (Ḳ,) [Malva, or mallow;] a certain plant, well known, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) of the leguminous kind, having broad leaves and a round fruit; [whence perhaps its name;] accord. to the Minháj, a species of the maluwxiy-apN [corchorus olitorious, or Jew's mallow]: or, as some say, the mlwxy-p is the garden-kind, and the xbAzI is the wild kind: some also say that the baqolap yahuwdiy-ap [sonchus, or sow-thistle,] is one of the species of xbAzI; and there is a kind thereof that turns with the sun. (TA.)
xub-ayuzN: see the next preceding paragraph.
xub-aAzapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
xub-aAzaI: see the next preceding paragraph.
xaAbizN A man possessing xuboz [or bread]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) like taAmirN [possessing dates] and laAbinN [possessing milk]. (Ṣ.)
maxobazN An oven; syn. furonN. (M and Ḳ in art. frn.)
maxobazapN A place where bread is made: pl. maxaAbizu. (Meyd, in Golius.)
1. xabaSahu, aor. _i {yaxobiSu}, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaboSN, (Mṣb,) He mixed it. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
xabaSa, aor. _i {yaxobiSu}; and xb-S↓, inf. n. taxobiySN; He turned over and mixed and made [xabiyS, q. v.]: and txb-S↓ * (Ḳ) and AxtbS↓ (A, Ḳ) he made, or prepared, for himself xabiyS. (Ḳ,* TA.)
2: see 1.
5: see 1.
8: see 1.
10. AstxbS Dayofuhumo Their guest asked for, or demanded, a mess of xabiyS [q. v.]. (A, TA.)
xabiySN Mixed; syn. maxobuwSN. (TA.)

A kind of food, (Mṣb, TA,) sweet, (TA,) well known, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) made of dates and clarified butter, (A, Ḳ, TA,) mixed together: (TA:) [Golius adds, on the authority of Ibn-Maạroof, “aut amylo et defruto;” app. meaning, or of starch and of new wine of which half or a third part has been boiled away: and one kind, called xabiySN muram-alN, was made with coarse flour: (see jariyXN:)] of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Mṣb:) xabiySapN is a more particular term [signifying a mess of xabiyS]. (Ṣ.)

mixobaSapN A spoon, or thing like a spoon, with which xabiyS is made; (Ṣ, as in two different copies;) a spoon with which xbyS is stirred about, or turned over, (A, L, Ḳ,) in the [vessel called] Tinojiyr: (Ḳ:) or the thing in which xbyS is stirred about, or turned over. (L, TA.)

1. xabaTa, aor. _i {yaxobiTu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. xaboTN, (Mṣb, TA, &c.,) He struck, or beat, (Mṣb, TA,) anything: (TA:) or he struck, or beat, it, or him, vehemently: (M, Ḳ, TA:) or xaboTN signifies a camel's striking, or beating, a thing with his fore foot: (T, TA:) or in the cases of beasts, (dawaAb-, [generally meaning horses and mules and asses,]) the striking, or beating, with the fore feet; not with the hind feet: and in the case of the camel, with the fore foot and the hind foot: or vehement treading; or of the fore feet of beasts (dwAb-): (TA:) or, accord. to the Keshsháf, the act of striking, or beating, in a way that is not right:
or, as some say, the going, or journeying, upon what is not the middle, or main part, of the road, or what is not the main road, or upon a road not open to view: or continuous, or consecutive, striking, or beating, in different ways: and afterwards tropically applied to any ‡ beating, or striking, that is not approved: or originally, the striking, or beating, with the fore foot or the hind foot, and the like: (MF, TA:) with the fore feet or legs, it is like ramoHN with the hind feet or legs. (TA.) You say, of a camel, xabaTa AlOaroDa, (Mṣb,) or xabaTa AlOaroDa biyadihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) He struck, or beat, the ground with his fore foot: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or he struck, or beat, vehemently the ground with his fore foot; and txb-T↓ and AxtbT↓ signify the same: (Ḳ:) it is said in the O that xabaTahu signifies he struck him with his fore foot, or hand, and prostrated him, as also txb-Thu↓: and AxtbT↓, said of a camel, is syn. with xabaTa: and in the T, that taxab-aTaniI↓ birijolihi is syn, with xabaTaniI. (TA.) Hence the trad., laA taxobiTuwA xaboTa Aljamali [lit. Ye shall not beat the ground as the camel does with his fore foot in rising]; meant to forbid a man's putting forward his foot in rising from prostration [in prayer]. (TA.) And xabaTahu, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) signifies also He trod him, or it, vehemently, (Ḳ, TA,) as the camel does with his fore foot. (TA.)

Hence, (Ṣ,) fulaAnN yaxobiTu xaboTa EaXowaMCa (Ṣ,* TA) ‡ [Such a one goes at random, in a headstrong and reckless manner,] like the weak-sighted she-camel that beats the ground with her fore feet (taxobiTu) as she goes along, not guarding herself from anything. (Ṣ, TA.) It is a prov., applied to him who turns away from a thing as though he were not cognizant of it: or to him who is continually falling into a thing. (Ḥar p. 239.) Zuheyr says,
raOayotu AlmanaAyaA xaboTa EaXowaMCa mano tuSibo
tumitohu wamano tuxoTiYo yuEam-aro fayahorami
I saw the fates [treading mankind] like the treading of the weak-sighted she-camel; whom they smote, him they killed: and whom they missed, he was made to continue in life so that he lived to extreme old age. (TA, and EM p. 132.) In like manner you say, fulaAnN yaxobiTu fiI EamoyaMCa ‡ Such a one undertakes what he undertakes with ignorance. (TA.) And xabaTa Oamorahu EalaI gayori baSyrapK † [He prosecuted his affair without mental perception, or without certainty]. (Ṣ in art. EXw, q. v.) And yaxobiTu fiI AlZ-alaAmi ‡ He goes in the night without a lamp, and so becomes confounded and perplexed, and unable to see his right course, and errs from the way, and perchance may fall into a well. (TA.) And xabaTa All-ayola, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He went, or journeyed, in the night without direction. (Ḳ, TA.) And baAta yaxobiTu AlZ-alomaMCa ‡ [He passed the night traversing the darkness without direction]. (TA.) xaboTN is said to signify † The act of journeying, or going, without direction: or upon what is not the middle, or main part, of the road, or what is not the main road. (TA.)

[And hence, perhaps,] xabaTahu ‡ He asked of him a benefit, or favour, without any tie of relationship; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also AxtbThu↓: (IB, Ḳ:) or this is from xaboTu waraqi AlX-ajari [explained in what follows]: (Ḥar p. 425:) or the latter, [or both,] he came to him seeking his beneficence without any such tie: (Ṣ:) or he came to him seeking a gift; because he who does so must beat the ground with his feet: (IF:) and you also say, AxtbT↓ maEoruwfahu. (Aboo-Málik, TA.) [The latter verb is the more common. See also 10.]

And ‡ He conferred a benefit upon him without there having been any acquaintance between them, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and without there being anything to draw them near, and without there being any relationship: (TA:) and xabaTahu bixayori signifies the same: (TA:) or he bestowed on him a benefit, (Ḳ, TA,) being asked: (TA:) and you say also, AxtbThu↓ bixayorK: (Aboo-Málik, TA:) and xabaTa fiyhimo bixayorK signifies † He benefited them. (TA.) 'Alkameh Ibn-'Abadeh says, (Ṣ, TA,) praising El-Hárith Ibn-AbeeShemir, (TA,)
wafiI kul-i HaI-K qado xabaTota biniEomapK
† [And upon every tribe thou hast conferred benefit, app. meaning without being related to them]: (Ṣ, TA:) but it is said in a marginal note to the Ṣ, that xabaT-a would be better; and so it is accord. to one relation: in the L, however, it is said that xabat-a would be more agreeable with analogy. (TA.) Accord. to AZ, xabaTotu Alr-ajula, inf. n. xaboTN, signifies † I held loving communion, commerce, or intercourse, with the man. (TA.)

[In respect of the places which I have given to the abovementioned significations of asking and conferring a benefit, I have followed the opinion of IF; but it is said in the TA, and, I think, with greater probability, that they are from what here next follows.]

xabaTa Alwaraqa mina AlX-ajari, aor. _i {yaxobiTu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xaboTN, (Lth, T, Mṣb,) He made the leaves to fall from the trees: (Mṣb:) or he beat the leaves of the trees, (Lth, T,) meaning large trees of the kind called TaloH, [acacia, or mimosa, gummifera,] with a staff, or stick, (Lth,) so that they fell off, or became scattered, (Lth, T,) after which he gave them as food to camels; (Lth;) refrainfrom injuring thereby the trunks and branches of the trees: (T:) and AxtbT↓ lahu xabaTFA signifies the same as xabaTa. (TA.) And xabaTa AlX-ajarapa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ,) He beat the tree with a staff, or stick, in order that its leaves might fall off: (Ṣ:) or he bound the tree, and then made its leaves to fall, (Ḳ, TA,) by beating it with a staff, or stick, to give them as food to camels and other beasts. (TA.) The leaves are stored up for the camels; and in wintertime are bruised, or broken up, for them, and moistened with water, and given to them as fodder. (Ḥar p. 218.) Moḥammad was asked, Does AlgaboT [i. e. “the wishing for a blessing on the condition that it shall not become transferred from its possessor”] injure [its author]? and he answered, laA Uil-aA kamaA yaDur-u AlEiDaAha AlxaboTu [No, save as the beating off the leaves injures the trees called 'idáh]; i. e., it only diminishes, without annulling, its author's recompense, like the beating off the leaves of the 'idáh, without cutting them down and extirpating them; for the leaves will grow again. (TA.) [See also art. gbT.]
Hence, (A, TA,) xabaTa Alqawoma bisayofihi ‡ He struck the people with his sword. (A, Ḳ, TA.)

xabaTahu AlX-ayoTaAnu ‡ The devil touched him with a hurt, (Ḳ, TA,) so as to corrupt him, or disorder him, and render him insane; (TA;) as also txb-Thu↓: (Ḳ, TA:) or the latter, [which is the more common,] the devil corrupted him, or disordered him: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:*) lit., struck him: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or prostrated him, and sported with him: or trampled upon him, and prostrated him. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [ii. 276], laA yaquwmuwna Uil-aA kamaA yaquwmu Ql-aciI yataxab-aTuhu↓ AlX-ayoTaAnu mina Qlomas-i ‡ [They shall not rise save as he riseth whom the devil prostrateth by reason of possession, or insanity]; i. e., as he who is affected by diabolical possession rises, in his state of possession, when he is prostrated, and falls: or it means, whom the devil corrupts, or disorders, by rendering him insane. (Ḳ,* TA.) [You say also, of a drug, xb-T↓ AlEaqola † It disordered the intellect: see the act. part. n., below.]

xabaTa also signifies † He (a man) threw himself down (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) where he was, (Ṣ, L,) to sleep, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or and slept. (L.) And † He (a man) slept. (A' Obeyd, TA.) In the Ḳ, qaAma is erroneously put for naAma. (TA.)
xabaTa EalaI AlbaAbi He knocked upon the door, or at the door. (TA.)
xabaTa AlEiroqu The vein beat, or pulsated. (TA.)
2: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

hom.sense: 5. txb-T It was, or became, in a state of commotion, agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance; syn. AiDoTaraba. (Az, TA in art. HbT.)
It is also trans.: see 1; second sentence, in three places; and again, near the end of the paragraph, in two places.

entry.sense: 8: see 1, in six places.
You say also, Aln-aAqapu taxotabiTu AlX-awoka † The she-camel eats the thorns. (Th, TA.)
10. AstxbThu † He asked of him a means of access, nearness, intimacy, or ingratiation. (TA.)
xabaTN What is beaten by beasts, (Ḳ, TA,) with their feet, (TA,) and broken. (Ḳ, TA.)

Leaves (Mṣb, Ḳ) of any kind (Ḳ) that have been made to fall from a tree; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) by its being beaten with a staff, or stick; (Ḳ,* TA;) used as food for camels: (TA:) and leaves that have been beaten off with staves, or sticks, then dried, and ground, and mixed with flour or other substance, and beaten with the hand, and moistened in a basin, with water, until they have become viscous, or cohesive, when they are put into the mouths of camels. (AḤn, Ḳ.) The word is of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, like many other instances that have been heard, (Mṣb,) as nafaDN and hadamN. (TA.)
xaboTapN ‡ A touch, or stroke, of diabolical possession, or insanity. (TA.) You say also, bifulaAnK xaboTapN biAlmas-i ‡ [In such a one is a touch of diabolical possession, or insanity]. (TA.)
† A single act of a stallion-camel's covering of the female. (TA.)
xubaATN A certain malady, (Ḳ,) like diabolical possession, or insanity, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but not identical therewith: (Ṣ, TA:) the word is also related with H (TA.) [See also HubaATN.]
farasN xabuwTN and xabiyTN↓ A horse that strikes, or beats, with his hind feet: (Ḳ:) or with his fore feet. (T, TA.)

xabiyTN A watering-trough beaten by the feet of the camels, and so demolished: (Ḳ:) or a wateringtrough; so called because its clay is beaten with the feet at its construction: (TA:) or a small watering-trough: (Aboo-Málik, TA:) pl. xubuTN (Ḳ.)
See also xabuwTN.
xubaATapN, determinate, [and imperfectly decl.,] † The stupid: like xuDaArapN applied to “the sea.” (TA.)

xab-aATu EaXawaAtK ‡ One who [frequently] goes in the night without a lamp, and so becomes confounded and perplexed, and unable to see his right course, and errs from the way, and perchance may fall into a well: occurring in a trad. of ʼAlee. (TA.)

xaAbiTN Going, or journeying, without direction: or one who beats the ground with his foot, and knows not in what land he is going; either because of the darkness or because he is blind. (Ḥar p. 55.) You say, maA OadoriI OaI-u xaAbiTi layolK huwa, (Ṣ, TA,) and OaI-u xaAbiTi All-ayoli, (TA,) ‡ I know not what man he is. (Ṣ, TA.)
maA lahu xaAbiTN walaA naATiHN, ‡ He has not a camel nor a bull; meaning he has not anything. (TA.)
xaAbiTN also signifies A beating, or throbbing, in the head. (TA.)
OaxobaTu That strikes, or beats, (Ḳ, TA,) the ground, (TA,) with his feet: (Ḳ, TA:) by poetic license written OaxobaT-u: (TA:) pl. xuboTN. (Ḳ.)
muxobiTN Still; motionless; like muxobitN: (TA in art. xmd:) or i. q. muToriqN [silent; not speaking: or lowering his eyes, looking towards the ground]. (JK, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, muxobaT and muToraq.])
See also muxotabiTN.
mixobaTN A staff, or stick, with which the leaves of trees are beaten off: (Ḳ:) and mixobaTapN↓, also, signifies a staff, or stick; and a rod, or twig: (TA:) pl. of the former, maxaAbiTu. (Ḳ, TA.)
mixobaTapN: see what next precedes.
muxab-iTN liloEaqoli [Disordering the intellect; said of a drug]. (Ḳ in art. bnj.)

muxotabiTN ‡ One who asks [a benefit or favour] of another without there being anything to draw him near, and without acquaintance. (JK, TA.* [In the latter, muxobiTN↓, which is doubtless a mistake, is explained in one place as signifying ‡ One who seeks a gift without any previous acquaintance.])
xabaEovanN: see xabaEovinapN.
xubaEovinN: see xubaEovinapN.
Also Plump in body; or fat, soft, thin-skinned, and plump, in body; applied to any thing [i. e. to any animal]. (Ḳ.)

xubaEovinapN, like qucaEomilapN, Big and strong; (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a man; and (in like manner, TA) a lion; (Ḳ;) and so xubaEovinN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as in the phrase xubaEovinu Alxaloqi [big and strong of make]; (AA, Ṣ;) and xabaEovanN↓: (Ḳ:) the first is applied as an epithet to a lion by Aboo-Zubeyd Et-Tá-ee: and [the pl.] xubaEovinaAtN, by El-Farezdaḳ, to camels. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1. xabila, aor. _a {yaxobalu}, inf. n. xabaAlN (JK, Ḳ, TA) and xabalN, (TA,) He was, or became, corrupted, unsound, vitiated, or disordered, [in an absolute sense; and particularly] in his reason, or intellect: (TA:) [or he was, or became, in a corrupt, an unsound, a vitiated, or a disordered, state, occasioning him agitation like that of possession or insanity, by disease affecting the reason and thought: (see xabaAlN, below:) and hence,] he was, or became, possessed, or insane. (JK, Ḳ, TA.)
And xabila, [inf. n. xabalN, (q. v. voce xabaAlN,)] He was, or became, affected with [the palsy termed] faAlij. (JK.)
And xabilato yaduhu His arm, or hand, became corrupted, unsound, vitiated, or disordered, so as to be rendered motionless; or dried up; or became lost; (Ḳ, TA;) or was cut off. (TA.)

xabalahu, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxobilu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xabolN; (TA;) and xb-lhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxobiylN; (TA;) and Axtblhu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) It (grief, JK, Ḳ, and love, JK, T, TA, and time, or fortune, and the ruling power, and disease, T, TA) rendered him possessed, or insane: (JK, Ḳ, TA:) and it corrupted, rendered unsound, vitiated, or disordered, his reason, or intellect; or his limb, or member: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it (grief) deprived him of his heart: and he corrupted, rendered unsound, vitiated, or disordered, one of his limbs or members: or deprived him of his reason, or intellect. (Mṣb.) And xabala qalobahu, aor. _i {yaxobilu} and _u {yaxobulu}, It (love) corrupted, or rendered unsound, his heart. (JM.) And xabala fulaAnN yada fulaAnK Such a one corrupted, rendered unsound, vitiated, or disordered, the arm, or hand, of such a one, so that it became motionless; or caused it to dry up; or deprived him of it. (JK.)

Also xabalahu, (TA,) [aor. _i {yaxobilu},] inf. n. xabolN, (Ḳ, TA,) He restrained, withheld, or debarred, him: (Ḳ,* TA:) and Axtbl↓ likewise signifies he restrained, withheld, or debarred. (TA.) You say, maA xabalaka Ean-aA What withheld, or has withheld, thee from us? (TA.) And xabalahu Eano kacaA, aor. and inf. n. as above, He prevented, or hindered, him from doing such a thing. (Ḳ,* TA.)
xabala Eano fiEoli Oabiyhi He fell short of the doing of his father. (JK, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

4. UixobaAlN signifies The act of lending; (JK;) as also AixotibaAlN↓. (TA.) You say, Oaxobalotuhu AlmaAla, (Ṣ,) i. e. Aln-aAqapa, or Alfarasa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) I lent him the she-camel (Ṣ, Ḳ *) in order that he might ride her (TA) or in order that he might make use of her milk and her fur, or the horse in order that he might go on a hostile, or hostile and plundering, expedition upon him. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And Axblhu UibilFA, and ganamFA, He lent him camels, and sheep or goats. (M, TA.) See also 10.
Also The dividing one's camels into two halves, that one half might breed in each year; like as one does in land and sowing. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.*)

hom.sense: 8: see 1, in two places:
and see 4.
Axtblt Ald-aAb-apu The beast remained not in its accustomed place. (Lth, ISd, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 10. Astxbl maAla fulaAnK He sought to corrupt, render unsound, vitiate, or disorder, some of the camels of such a one. (Er-Rághib.)

[And hence,] Astxblhu mino maAlihi He asked of him the loan of some of his camels, or the like, until the time of abundance of herbage. (JK, O,* TA.*) And AstxblnI naAqapF, or farasFA, He asked of me the loan of a she-camel (Ḳ, TA) in order that he might ride her (TA) or in order that he might make use of her milk and her fur, or a horse in order that he might go on a hostile, or hostile and plundering, expedition upon him. (Ḳ, TA.) And Astxblhu UibilFA, and ganamFA, He asked of him the loan of camels, and sheep or goats. (M, TA.) Zuheyr says,
hunaA laka Uino yusotaxobaluwA AlmaAla yuxobiluwA↓
[There, if they be asked to lend cattle, they lend]. (Ṣ, TA. [See also 10 in art. xwl.])

hom.sense: xabolN: see xabaAlN, in four places.

Also Corruptness, unsoundness, or a vitiated or disordered state, of the limbs or members, (M, Ḳ,) of a man, so that one knows not how to walk; (Az, TA;) and so xabalN↓; (Ḳ;) which likewise signifies the same in the legs of a beast. (JK, Ḳ.*)
And The [palsy termed] faAlij; as also xabalN↓. (Ḳ.)

Also The cutting off of arms or hands, and legs or feet: (JK, Az, ISd, Ḳ:) pl. xubuwlN. (Ḳ.) So in the saying, qawomiI yuTaAlibuwna baniI fulaAnK bidimaMCK waxabolK [My people, or party, prosecute the sons of such a one for blood (lit. bloods) and the cutting off of arms or hands, and legs or feet]. (JK.) And so xubuwlN in the saying, lanaA fiI baniI fulaAnK dimaMCN waxubuwlN [We have a claim, upon the sons of such a one, to blood (lit. bloods) and the cutting off of arms, &c.]. (Ṣ.)
And Wounds: (JK:) and xabalN↓ signifies a wound: and is so explained as used in the saying, banuw fulaAnK yuTaAlibuwnanaA bixabalK [The sons of such a one prosecute us for a wound]. (TA.)
And i. q. fitonapN and harojN [i. e. Trial, punishment, slaughter, civil war, conflict and faction, discord, dissension, &c.]. (TA.)
Also A loan: and a demand of a loan: (Ḳ, TA:) relating to anything. (TA.)
And An addition which one gives, beyond what the jam-aAl [i. e. owner, or attendant, of a camel or camels (in the CK Ham-Al i. e. porter)] imposes on one by stipulation. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
xubolN: see xabaAlN.

waqaEa fiI xuboliI It came into my mind; (JK, Ḳ;) a phrase like the saying, saqaTa fiI yadiI: (JK, Ḳ:* [in the Ḳ, meaning the same as this saying:]) and sometimes (JK) one says also fiI xaboliI↓. (JK [and so in the Ḳ accord. to the TA, but not in the CK, nor in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ].)
xabalN: see xabaAlN, in four places:
and see xabolN, in three places.

Also The jinn, or genii; (IAạr, Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so xaAbilN↓: (JK, Ḳ:) or the latter has this signification; and the former is a quasi-pl. n. of the latter, or, as some say, a pl., as is also xub-alN: (TA:) and xaAbilN↓ signifies also a devil, or the devil. (Ḳ.) One says, bihi xabalN, meaning In him is somewhat of [the jinn, or genii, called] Oaholu AlOaroDi. (Ṣ. [See AlOaroDu, near the end of the paragraph: and see other explanations of xabalN voce xabaAlN, which may apply in this case.])
Accord. to IAạr and Fr, it is also applied to Mankind. (TA.)
Also A certain bird, that cries all the night, with one cry, resembling maAtato xabalo. (M, Ḳ,* TA.)
Also A mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag]. (Fr, Ḳ.)
And A full qirobap [or water-skin]. (Fr, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xabilN and Oaxobalu↓ (Ḳ, TA) Corrupted, unsound, vitiated, or disordered, [in an absolute sense; and particularly] in his reason, or intellect; as also maxobuwlN↓: (TA:) [or in a corrupt, an unsound, a vitiated, or a disordered, state, occasioning him agitation like that of possession or insanity, by disease affecting the reason and thought: (see xabaAlN, below:) and hence,] possessed, or insane; (Ḳ, TA;) as also muxab-alN↓ and muxotabilN↓: (TA:) or muxab-alN↓ signifies a man having no heart; (JK;) as also maxobuwlN↓: (JK, Mṣb:) or this last, haring one of his limbs, or members, corrupted, rendered unsound, vitiated, or disordered: (Mṣb:) and xabilN and muxab-alN↓ signify also a beast corrupted, rendered unsound, vitiated, or disordered, in the legs, so as not to know how to walk: (JK:) or muxab-alN↓ signifies a man who is as though his extremities were amputated. (Ṣ.)
dahorN xabilN ‡ A time difficult to the people thereof; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) in which they see not happiness. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: xubolapN Corruption from a wound. (TA.)
See also xuborapN, last signification.

entry.sense: xabaAlN Corruptness, unsoundness, or a vitiated or disordered state, [in an absolute sense;] (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) said in the O and the Mufradát [of Er-Rághib] to be the primary signification; (TA;) as also xabalN↓ (Ḥam p. 542) and xabolN↓, of which last the pl. is xubuwlN: (Ṣ:) [and particularly in the reason, or intellect: (see xabila, of which it is an inf. n.:)] and in actions, as well as in bodies and in minds: (TA:) or, primarily, such as is incident to an animal, occasioning him agitation like that of possession or insanity, by disease affecting the reason and thought; as also xabalN↓ and xabolN↓: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or xabalN↓ signifies possession, or insanity; (Ḳ;) and so xabolN↓ (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xubolN↓ (Ḳ) and xabaAlN; (Mṣb;) or xabalN↓ signifies an affection, in the heart, resembling possession or insanity; (Az, TA;) or egregious stupidity or foolishness, without possession or insanity; (TA;) and xabolN↓ also signifies a state, or quality, resembling possession or insanity, such as stupidity, or foolishness; and heedlessness, or weakness of intellect, and the like. (Mṣb.) maA zaAduwkumo Uil-aA xabaAlFA, in the Ḳur [ix. 47], means They had not added to you aught save corruption and evil. (Bḍ, TA.) And laA yaOoluwnakumo xabaAlFA, in the same [iii. 114], They will not fall short, or flag, or be remiss, in corrupting, or vitiating, your affairs. (TA.)
Hence, (TA,) Loss, or a state of diminution; syn. nuqoSaAnN: (O, Ḳ, Er-Rághib:) or this is the primary signification. (TA.)
And hence, (TA,) A state of perdition or destruction: (O, Ḳ, Er-Rághib:) or a thing's going, passing, or wasting, away; or being consumed or destroyed. (Zj, TA.)
Also The condition of a well when it is hollowed in the sides, and old, so that sometimes the bucket enters into its hollowed part and becomes lacerated. (Fr, Ḳ.)

And Fatigue, weariness, distress, embarrassment, affliction, trouble, or difficulty. (JK, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) So in the saying, fulaAnN xabaAlN EalaI Oaholihi [Such a one is a cause of fatigue,, &c., to his family]. (JK,* Ṣ, O.)
And A deadly poison. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
And The fluid squeezed, or wrung, (IAạr, TA,) or flowing, (Ṣ, Ḳ. TA,) from the inhabitants of Hell, or from their skins. (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) [See also radagapN.]
xaAbilN Corrupting, rendering unsound, vitiating, or disordering, [in an absolute sense;] (M, Ḳ;) and particularly in the reason, or intellect. (TA.)
See also xabalN, in two places.
It is also added to xabolN to give intensiveness to the signification. (TA.)
Oaxobalu: see xabilN.
muxab-alN: see xabilN, in four places.
muxab-ilN a [proper] name of Time. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
maxobuwlN: see xabilN, in two places.

hom.sense: muxotabilN: see xabilN.
muxotabilu daAb-apK The legs of a beast. (JK. [But this I do not find in any other lexicon; and I doubt its correctness.])

entry.sense: 1. xabanahu, aor. _i {yaxobinu}, inf. n. xabonN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xibaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xubaAnN, (Ṣ, ISd,) He folded it, namely, a garment, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,), &c., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in its skirt, (Mṣb,) and sewed it, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in order that it might become shorter; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) he contracted it [in its length], and sewed it; (M, TA;) he raised its (a garment's) skirt, or lower part, and sewed it higher up, in order that it might become contracted and shortened, as is done with the garment of a child; (Lth, TA;) [he made a tuck in it, to shorten it;] i. q. vabanahu. (Ṣ in art. vbn.)
