[Hence, † He shortened it; namely, a period.] You say, [of a she-camel, or of camels,] xubina mino Tuwli ZimoYihaA, meaning † The length of the interval between her, or their, two waterings was shortened. (TA.)

Also, (Mṣb, TA,) aor. _u {yaxobunu}, (Mṣb,) [or. _i,] He hid it, or concealed it; (Mṣb, TA;) kept it, or preserved it; or stored it; namely, a thing. (TA.) You say, xabana AlT-aEaAma He hid, or concealed, kept, or preserved, or stored, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and prepared, (Ṣ,) wheat, or food, for [a time of] dearth, or adversity. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
yaxobinu Alkaciba † He prepares falsehood. (Ḳ,* TA.)

xabanatohu xabuwnu↓ [as though signifying † Death hid him, or perhaps death shortened his existence,] is a phrase like XaEabatohu XaEuwbu, meaning he died. (Ḳ. [In copies of the Ḳ, xabuwnN and XaEuwbN: but both are imperfectly decl., as fem. proper names of more than three letters.])

4. Axbn He (a man, TA) hid, or concealed, a thing in the xubonap [q. v.] of his trousers, (Ḳ, TA,) next the back: Avbn signifies “he hid, or concealed, [a thing] in his vubonap, next the belly.” (TA.) [See also what next follows {8}.]
8. Axtbn AlX-aIoCa He took [and carried] the thing beneath the part extending from his armpit to his flank. (Ḥar p. 552.) [See also what next precedes.]

xubonN The part of a mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag that is hung on either side of a camel] which is between its xurot [or loop at either of its upper corners, whereby it is suspended, (in the CK xurob, which may signify the same,)] and its mouth [which is in the middle of the upper part]: (JK, Ḳ:) [thus] there are two such parts, [on either side of the mouth,] together called xubonaAni. (JK, TA.)

xubonapN The doubled upper border of the trousers, (IAth, TA,) next the back, in which one hides, or conceals, [or carries,] a thing; (IAạr, TA;) the vubonap being [similar to it, but] in the waistwrapper, (IAth, TA,) next the belly: (IAạr, TA:) or the raised skirt, or lower part, of the garment, in which one carries a thing: pl. xubanN. (Ḥar p. 427.) And What one carries in the HiDon [or part between the armpit and the flank,, &c.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or what one carries beneath the armpit, (JK, Mṣb,) and in the sleeve: (JK:) or what is put, of food, and carried under the armpit or in the sleeve. (Ḥar p. 427.) It is said in a trad. of ʼOmar, UicaA mar-a OaHadukumo biHaAYiTK faQloyaOokulo minohu walaA yat-axico xubonapN [When any one of you passes by a garden of palm-trees, let him eat thereof, but not make, or take for himself, a xbnp]. (Ṣ,* TA. [See another reading voce vibaAnN.])
xabanatohu xabuwnu: see 1.

hom.sense: xaAbinu [applied to a she-camel, or to a number of camels,] † Whose interval between two water-ings has been shortened. (IAạr.)
† One who prepares falsehood. (JK,* Ḳ,* TA.)
I. q. XadiydN [Strong,, &c.]. (JK, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 1. xabati Aln-aAru, aor. taxobuw, inf. n. xubuw-N (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xabowN, (Ḳ,) The fire became allayed; subsided; (Ḳ;) became extinguished; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the flaming, or blazing, of the fire ceased, or became allayed or extinguished. (JK, Mṣb.) [The verb is used, in this sense, of Hell, in the Ḳur xvii. 99.]

[Hence,] xabati AlHarobu ‡ The war became allayed, assuaged, or appeased; (JK, Ḳ, TA;) became extinguished. (Ḳ, TA.) And xabato Hid-apu Aln-aAqapi ‡ The sharpness, or irascibility, of the she-camel became allayed, assuaged, or appeased. (JK, Ḳ,* TA.) And xabaA lahabuhu ‡ The heat, or vehemence, of his anger became allayed, assuaged, or appeased. (TA.)
4. AxbI Aln-aAra He extinguished the fire; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) he allayed, or extinguished, the flaming, or blazing, of the fire. (JK, Mṣb.)

And [hence,] AxbI AlHaroba ‡ He extinguished [or allayed] the fire of the war. (Ḳ, TA.) And AxbI Hid-apa Aln-aAqahi ‡ He extinguished [or allayed] the sharpness, or irascibility, of the she-camel. (Ḳ,* TA.)
xibaMCN accord. to some belongs to this art. (TA in art. xbO.) See arts. xbO and xbI.
2: see what next follows {4}.

4. AxbI, inf. n. UixobaMCN; (Ks, TA;) or AxbI xibaMCN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and txb-I↓, (Ks, TA,) or txb-I xibaMCF; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and xb-I↓ xibaMCF, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) inf. n. taxobiyapN; (Ṣ;) He made a [tent such as is called] xbMC: (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and he set it up. (Ḳ.) [see also 10.] And Oaxobayotu kisaAYiI I made my [garment called] ksMC to be [as] a xibaMC. (TA.)
5: see 4.
10. AstxbI xibaMCF He set up a [tent such as is called] xbMC, and entered into it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also 4.]

xibaMCN A kind of structure; (Ḳ;) [i. e.] one of the buyuwt [or kinds of tents] of the Arabs, (IAth, TA,) peculiarly of wool, (Yaạḳoob, Th,) or of camels' fur, or of wool, (IAạr, Ṣ, IAth, Ḳ,) or of [goats'] hair, (Ḳ,) or not of [goats'] hair, (Ṣ,) [except in cold countries and in fertile regions, where the goats have abundant hair, for the goats of the Arabs of the desert have short hair, not long enough to be spun, (see bayotN,)] smaller than the miZal-ap, (IAạr,) upon two poles, or three; what is above this kind being termed bayotN; (Ṣ;) or a tent having one pole; that which has more than one pole being termed bayotN: (AZ, TA in art. rbE:) pl. OaxobiyapN, (Ṣ, TA,) without C: (TA:) most of the lexicologists hold that its radical letters are xbI. (TA in art. xbO, q. v.)
Sometimes, † A dwelling, such as is in a city. (TA, from a trad.)
Also ‡ A receptacle for oil or ointment. (Ḳ, TA.)
And ‡ The calyx or a flower. (TA.)
And ‡ The husk of a grain of wheat, and of a grain of barley, in the ear. (Ḳ, TA.)

And AlxibaMCu signifies ‡ Certain round stars, [or stars in a circle,] (Ḳ, TA,) forming one of the Mansions of the Moon, [namely, the Twenty-fifth,] also called AlOaxobiyapu [or saEodu AlOaxobiyapi: see saEodN]. (TA.)
xaAbiyapN, originally xaAbiYapN: see art. xbO.

hom.sense: 1. xatarato nafosuhu His soul [or stomach] became heavy; or heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. xabuvato: (IAạr, Ḳ:) and became in a corrupt, or disordered, state. (Ḳ.)

xatarahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) aor. _i {yaxotiru} and _u {yaxoturu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xatorN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and xutuwrN, (Ḳ,) He acted, or behaved, towards him with perfidy, treachery, or unfaithfulness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or with the foulest perfidy or treachery or unfaithfulness: (A, Ḳ:) or with deceit, guile, or circumvention: (Ḳ:) or in a bad, or corrupt, manner. (Ibn-ʼArafeh.) And xatara biAlEahodi [He was unfaithful,, &c., to the compact, or covenant]. (TA, from a trad.)

entry.sense: 2. xt-rhu, inf. n. taxotiyrN, said of wine, or beverage, It corrupted, or disordered, his soul [or stomach], (Ibn-ʼArafeh, Ḳ,) and rendered him relaxed. (Ibn-ʼArafeh.)

5. txt-r He (a man, TA) was, or became, languid, (tafat-ara,) and relaxed, and heavy, or sluggish, and fevered: (Ḳ:) he was, or became, languid in body, in consequence of disease, &c.: (TA:) and his intellect became confused, from drinking milk and the like. (Ḳ.) And txt-rt nafosuhu His soul [or stomach] was, or became, languid. (TA.)
He walked with the gait of him who is heavy, or sluggish. (Ḳ.)
xatarN Languor (xadarN), (Ḳ,) or the like thereof, (TA,) that betides on the occasion of drinking medicine or poison, (Ḳ, TA,) such as weakens and intoxicates. (TA.)
xatuwrN: see what follows.
xatiyrN: see what follows.
xat-aArN: see what follows.
xit-iyrN: see what follows.

xaAtirN (Ḳ) and [in an intensive sense] xat-aArN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and xatiyrN↓ and xatuwrN↓ and xit-iyrN↓ (Ḳ) One who acts, or behaves, with perfidy, treachery, or unfaithfulness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or with the foulest perfidy or treachery or unfaithfulness: (A, Ḳ:) or with deceit, guile, or circumvention: (Ḳ:) [or in a bad, or corrupt, manner: (see 1:) the second and following epithets signifying one who does so much, or frequently, or habitually.]
Q. 1. xatoEara, inf. n. xatoEarapN, It passed away, and came to nought: (Ḳ: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned:) said of the mirage. (Kr.)
xayotaEuwrN Anything that does not remain in one state; and that passes away, and comes to nought; (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or that has no real existence. (IAth.)
The mirage; syn. saraAbN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or what remains of the latter part of the mirage, when it becomes dispersed, and delays not to pass away and come to nought. (Kr, L.)

[Gossamer; i. e.] what descends from the air in a time of intense heat, like spiders' webs; (Ṣ;) a thing like spiders' webs, which appears in a time of heat, (Ḳ,) descending from the sky, (TA,) resembling threads, (Ḳ,) or white threads, (TA,) in the air. (Ḳ.) [See luEaAbu AlX-amosi, in art. lEb.]
The present world or life. (Ḳ.)
The devil: (Fr, Ḳ:) or the devil of the 'Akabeh, called Oazab-u AlEaqabapi (IAth.)
The [imaginary creature called] guwl: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) because it changes its appearance. (TA.)
A certain insect, (Ḳ,) of a black colour, (TA,) that is upon the surface of water, and that does not remain in one place (Ḳ) save as long as the time of the winking of an eye. (TA.)
A perfidious, or an unfaithful, man. (TA.)
A woman whose affection does not last: (TA:) a woman evil in disposition: (Ḳ:) likened to a guwl inasmuch as her love does not last. (TA.)
The wolf: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) because of his unfaithfulness. (TA.)
The lion: (Ḳ:) because of his perfidiousness. (TA.)
A calamity; syn. daAhiyapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nawFI xayotaEuwrN [A point towards which one journeys] that is not in a right direction; syn. Aal-atiI laA tasotaqiymu: (L:) or far distant. (Ḳ.)

1. xatalahu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _i {yaxotilu} (M, Ṣgh, Ḳ) and _u {yaxotulu}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. xatolN and xatalaAnN, (Ḳ,) i. q. xadaEahu, or xaAdaEahu; (so accord. to different copies of the Ṣ;) and xAtlhu↓ signifies the same: (Ṣ:) or the former, i. q. xadaEahu (Mgh, Ḳ, TA) [i. e.] He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him, (KL, PṢ,) unawares: (TA:) and xAtlhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaAtalapN, (TA,) i. q. xaAdaEahu [which means the same as xadaEahu; or he practised with him mutual deceit, delusion,, &c.; or he strove, endeavoured, or desired, to deceive, delude, beguile, circumvent, or outwit, him]; (Ḳ, TA;) and raAwagahu [which means he endeavoured to turn him, or to entice him to turn, to, or from, a thing, &c.]. (TA.)

xatolu AlS-aAYidi means The sportsman's going along by little and little, stealthily, lest he should make a sound to be heard. (JM.) And xatala AlS-ayoda, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xatolN, (TA,) said of a wolf, He concealed himself to seize the prey. (Ḳ.)
3: see 1, in two places.

6. taxaAtulN i. q. taxaAduEN [as meaning The deceiving one another; thus explained in the KL: and app. also as meaning the pretending deceit,, &c.; or the pretending to be deceived,, &c.: accord. to the PṢ, the being deceived; but for this I know not any other authority]. (Ṣ.) You say, txAtlwA, meaning txAdEwA [They deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, one another]. (Ḳ.) And txAtl Eano gafolapK [app. meaning He pretended deceit, &c., or pretended to be deceived, &c., unawares]. (TA.)

8. Axttl He (a man, TA) listened to the secret of a party of men. (T, Ḳ,* TA.) El-Aạshà says,
walaA taraAhaA lisir-i AljaAri taxotatilu
[Nor wilt thou see her listen to the secret of the neighbour]. (TA.)
xitolN A place of retreat, or concealment. (Ḳ.) And Any similar place in which one listens to hear secrets [&c.]. (TA.) The form of a hare, or burrow of a rabbit. (Ḳ.)
xatuwlN: see xaAtilN and xat-aAlN.
xaAtilN and [in an intensive sense] xatuwlN↓ [like xat-aAlN, q. v.,] Deceiving, deluding, beguiling, circumventing, or outwitting. (Ḳ, TA.)

xawotalN Elegant; polite; acute, or sharp, or quick, in intellect; clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent: (Ḳ,* TA:) thought by ISd to be, perhaps, from Alxatolu signifying “the act of deceiving”, &c. (TA.)

xawotalaI A stealthy walk or gait: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or a walking on one side. (T, TA.) Hence the saying, huwa yaxolijuniI biEayonihi wayamoXiI liI AlxawotalaI [He makes a sign to me with his eye, and walks to me stealthily, or sideways]. (TA.)
Oaxotalu [More, and most, deceitful, deluding, guileful,, &c.]. You say Oaxotalu mino ciYobK More deceitful,, &c., than the wolf. (Mgh.)

1. xatamahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxotimu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xatomN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xitaAmN, (Lḥ, Ḳ, TA,) with kesr, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, xataAm,] i. q. TabaEahu [He sealed, stamped, imprinted, or impressed, it]: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he put the xaAtam [or signet] upon it: (Mgh:) namely, a thing, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or a writing or book and the like: and xatama Ealayohi signifies the same [or he put a seal, or the impression of a signet, upon it]. (Mṣb.) Accord. to Er-Rághib, xatomN and TaboEN signify The impressing a thing with the engraving of the signet and stamp: and the former [as is indicated, but not plainly expressed, as distinguished from the latter,] is tropically used, sometimes, as meaning the securing oneself from a thing, and protecting [oneself] from it; in consideration of protection by means of sealing upon writings and doors: and sometimes as meaning the producing an impression, or effect, upon a thing from another thing; in consideration of the impress produced [by the signet]: and sometimes it is used as relating to † the reaching the end [of a thing]: (TA:) or the primary signification of xatomN is the act of covering over [a thing]: (Az, TA:) accord. to Zj, the proper meaning of xatomN and TaboEN is the covering over a thing, and securing oneself from a thing's entering it: some say that the former signifies the concealing a notification of a thing, [as] by putting one's fingers over it, by way of guarding oneself thereby. (TA.)

Hence, xatomu AlX-ahaAdapi [The sealing of the testimony]; which is thus described by El-Hulwánee: the witness, when he wrote his name upon a Sak- [q. v.], caused his written name to be beneath a piece of lead, [i. e. covered it with a piece of lead,] and put upon it the impress of his signet, in order that there might be no falsification of it or substitution for it. (Mgh.)

As to xatomu AlOaEonaAqi [The sealing of the necks], the case is related, in the “Risáleh Yoosufeeyeh,” to have been this: ʼOmar sent Ibn-Honeyf to seal the Euluwj [or unbelievers] of the Sawád; and he sealed five hundred thousand of them, in classes; that is, he marked them twelve dirhems, and twenty-four, and forty-eight; tying a thong upon the neck of each, and putting upon the knot a seal of lead. (Mgh.)
xatomN also signifies The protecting what is in a writing by marking [or stamping] a piece of clay [upon it, or by means of a seal of any kind]. (TA.)
And you say, of a man, xatama Ealayoka baAbahu [He sealed his door against thee]; meaning ‡ he turned away from thee, avoided thee, or shunned thee. (TA.)
And xatama laka baAbahu [He sealed for thee his door]; meaning ‡ he preferred thee to others. (TA.)

xatama EalaI qalobihi [which may be rendered He sealed his heart] means ‡ he made him to be such that he understood not, and such that nothing proceeded from him; or he made his heart, or mind, to be such that it understood not,, &c. (Ḳ, TA.) xatama Qll-ehu EalaI quluwbihimo, in the Ḳur [ii. 6], is like the phrase in the same [xvi. 110 and xlvii. 18] TabaEa Qll-ehu EalaI quluwbihimo: (TA:) it points to what God has made to be usually the case when a man has ended in believing what is false and in committing that which is forbidden, so that he turns not his face to the truth; this occasioning, as its result, his becoming inured to the approval of acts of disobedience, so that he is as though this habit were impressed upon his heart: the assertion of El-Jubbáee, that it means God hath put a seal upon their hearts, as a sign, to the angels, of their infidelity, is nought: (Er-Rághib, TA:) Alxatomu is explained by IAạr as meaning the preventing of the heart from believing. (L in art. xdE.) [See also TabaEa.]

xatama AlX-aIoCa, inf. n. xatomN, also signifies [as indicated above] † He reached the end of the thing. (Ḳ.) And Aixotatamotu↓ AlX-aIoCa † [I ended, or finished, the thing,] contr. of AifotataHotuhu. (Ṣ, TA.) You say, xatama AlquroMna † He reached the end of the Ḳur-án [in reciting it]; (Ṣ, Er-Rághib;) [he recited the whole of the Ḳur-án;] he completed [the recital of] the Kur- án: (Mgh:) he retained in his memory the last portion of the Ḳur-án; meaning he retained the whole of it in his memory. (Mṣb.) It is said of Suleymán El-Aamash, kaAna yaqoraOu xatomFA, meaning † He used to recite the whole of the Ḳur-án; at one time, according to the reading of Ibn-Mesʼood; at another time, from the edition of ʼOthmán. (Mgh.)
You say also, xatama Qll-ehu lahu bixayorK † [May God make his end to be good]. (Ṣ.)

xatama Albacora † He covered over the sown seed: (Az, TA:) or xatamuwA EalaI Albacori † they turned up the earth over the sown seed, and then watered it: (Et-Táïfee, TA:) or xatama Alz-aroEa, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) aor. _i {yaxotimu}, inf. n. xatomN, (TA,) ‡ he watered the seed-produce, or sown field, the first time; (JK, Ḳ, TA;) because, when it is watered, it is finished (xutima) with the rHA [app. raHaA, which here seems to mean the “roller,” as being likened to a mill-stone, though I find no authority for this meaning]; (TA;) as also xatama Ealayohi: (Ḳ:) or xatamuwA EalaI zuruwEihimo means † they watered their sown fields while these were as yet kiraAb [app. meaning clear of vegetation]. (JK, TA.)

xatama Aln-aHolu ‡ The bees filled with honey the place in which they deposited it: (JK, A, TA:) or xatomN signifies bees' collecting some thin wax, thinner than the wax of the comb, and smearing with it the orifices of their xalaAyaA [or hives]. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
2. xt-mhu, inf. n. taxotiymN, He sealed it, stamped it,, &c., much. (TA.)
[In modern Arabic, He put a xaAtam, or signet-ring, upon his (another's) finger.]

5. txt-m, or txt-m xaAtamFA, (accord. to different copies of the Ṣ,) or txt-m bixaAtamK, (Ḳ, [agreeably with a trad. cited in the TA,]) He put on [i. e. put on his own finger] a xAtm [or signet-ring]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And txt-m ‡ He put on a turban: (Ḳ, TA:) or txt-m biEimaAmatihi he put on his turban in the manner of a niqaAb [q. v.]; syn. tanaq-aba bihaA. (Z, TA.) The subst. [signifying the act or mode, of doing so] is taxotimapN↓ [q. v. infrà]. (Ḳ.)
txt-m biOamorihi † He concealed his affair, or case. (Z, Ḳ.)
txt-m Eanohu ‡ He feigned himself heedless of him, and was silent [to him]. (Ḳ, TA.)
8: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

hom.sense: xatomN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Also The impress produced by the engraving of a signet. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
See also xaAtamN.
OaEoTaAniI xatomiI means ‡ He gave me my sufficiency, or what sufficed me: because what suffices a man is the last [or utmost] of his desire, or demand. (TA.)
Also ‡ Honey. (Ḳ, TA.)
And ‡ The orifices of the xalaAyaA [or hives] of bees. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: xatamN: see xaAtamN.

Also A sealed piece of clay [or wax]: like nafaDN in the sense of manofuwDN, and qabaDN in the sense of maqobuwDN: so in the saying of El-Aạshà,
waOaborazahaA waEalayohaA xatamo
waSaHobaMCa TaAfa yahuwdiy-uhaA
[And a jar of reddish-coloured wine, the Jew -vender whereof came, and brought it out, with a sealed piece of clay upon it]. (Ṣ.) [See also xitaAmN.]
xatomapN [an inf. n. of un. of 1, † A recitation of the whole of the Ḳur-án: used in this sense in the present day: pl. xatamaAtN.]
[And also] vulgarly used as meaning † A copy of the Ḳur-án: and so xitomapN↓. (TA.)
xitomapN: see what next precedes.
xataAmN: see the last sentence of the next paragraph.

hom.sense: xitaAmN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
And a subst. signifying The first watering of seedproduce, or of a sown field: (JK, TA:) or the turning up the earth over sown seed, and then watering it. (Et-Táïfee, TA.)
See also xaAtimN.

Also The clay, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the wax, (TA,) with which one seals, or stamps, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) upon a writing, (JK,) or upon a thing: (Ḳ:) or which is sealed, or stamped, upon a writing. (Mṣb.) [See also xatamN. And see an ex. in a verse of Lebeed cited in art. dkn.]

‡ [The hymen; as being the seal of virginity; as also xaAtamN↓.] You say, zuf-ato Uilayoka bixitaAmihaA ‡ [She was conducted as a bride to thee with her seal of virginity], and bixaAtami↓ rab-ihaA [with the seal of her Lord]. (TA.) And [hence, app.,] siyqato hadiy-atuhumo Uilayohi bixitaAmihaA ‡ [if it mean, as I suppose it to do, Their present was sent to him with what rendered it perfect or complete, or with what appertained to it]. (TA.)

† The furthest part of a valley. (JK, TA.) † The last of a company of men; (Lḥ, TA;) as also xaAtamN↓ and xaAtimN↓: (Ḳ:) whence xaAtamu↓ Aln-abiy-iyna † [The last of the prophets], in the Ḳur [xxxiii. 40]; accord. to one reading, xaAtum↓, with damm to the t; (TA;) or xAtmu AlOanobiyaMCi, i. e. Moḥammad; (Ṣ;) also called AlxaAtamu↓ and AlxaAtimu↓. (TA.) And † The last portion of anything that is drunk [&c.]. (TA.) xitaAmuhu misokN, in the Ḳur [lxxxiii. 26], means † The last that they will perceive thereof will be the odour of musk: (Ṣ, TA:) or, accord. to 'Alkameh and Mujáhid, its admixture shall be musk: accord. to Ibn-Mesʼood, its result shall be the taste of musk: Fr says, xaAtamN↓ and xaAtimN↓ and xitaAmN are nearly the same in meaning; whence the reading of ʼAlee, xaAtamuhu↓ misokN: and the explanation is this; that when any one shall drink thereof, he will find the last cup thereof to have the odour of musk: Er-Rághib says that the meaning is, the end, and the last draught, i. e. what shall remain, thereof shall be in perfume [like] musk: and that the assertion that it means it shall be sealed with musk is nought. (TA.) [See also xaAtamN and xaAtimapN.]

Also, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and xaAtimN↓, (Ḳ,) or, accord. to IAạr, xataAmN↓, (TA,) sings. of xutumN, which signifies † The places of separation (fuSuwS [q. v.]) of the joints (mafaASil) of horses. (IAạr, Ḳ.) xaAtamN (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xaOotamN (TA) and xaAtimN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is more commonly known than xaAtamN, (Mṣb, [but see what follows,]) and xaAtaAmN↓ and xiytaAmN↓ (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, the last in the CK and TA xayotaAm↓) and xitaAmN↓ (Ḳ and TA but omitted in the CK) and xatamN↓ (ISd, IHsh, Ḳ) and xatomN↓ (Ez-Zeyn El-'Irákee, TA) and xayotamo↓ (Ibn-Málik, TA) and xayotuwmN↓ (EzZeyn El-'Irákee, TA) and xaAtiyaAmN↓ (Ḳ) signify the same; (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) [A signet; generally a signet-ring; i. e.] a certain ornament (HaloIN, M, Ḳ) for the finger, (Ḳ,) app., at the first, used for sealing, or stamping, therewith; so that the word is of the same class as TaAbaEN: afterwards, in consequence of frequency of usage, applied to one not used for that purpose: (ISd, TA:) or a ring having a faS- of a substance different therefrom [set in it; i. e., having a stone, or gem, set in it]: if without a faS-, it is called fataxapN: (Mṣb:) or xaAtimN↓ signifies the agent [i. e. the person sealing, or stamping]: (JK, Az, Mṣb:) xaAtamN, the thing that is put upon the piece of clay [or wax, for the purpose of sealing, or stamping]: (Az, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the pl. [of xaAtamN and xaAtimN] is xawaAtimN (Ḳ) and [properly of xaAtaAmN] xawaAtiymu: (Ṣ, in which the former pl., though more common, is not mentioned, and Ḳ:) Sb says that those who use the latter pl. make it to be pl. of a sing. of the measure faAEaAlN, though it be not in their language; which shows that he knew not xaAtaAmN: the pl. of xatomN is xutuwmN. (TA.)

xaAtamN also signifies A seal, or stamp, and a mark: so in a trad., in which it is said, Mmiyna xaAtamu rab-i AlEaAlamiyna EalaI EibaAdihi AlmuWominiyna, i. e. [Mmiyna (or Amen) is] the seal, or stamp, and the mark, [of the Lord of the beings of the whole world upon his servants the believers,] which removes from them accidents, and causes of mischief; for the seal of the writing protects it, and precludes those who look from [seeing] what is within it. (TA.)

See also xitaAmN, in seven places. [It is nearly syn. with xitaAmN, as Fr says: and thus,] it signifies also, (JK, Ḳ,) and so does xaAtimapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) † The end, or last part or portion, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and result, or issue, (Ḳ,) of a thing (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) of any kind: (JK, Ḳ:) ↓the latter [particularly] signifies † the last part or portion (JK, Mṣb) of a chapter of the Ḳur-án, (JK,) and of the Ḳur-án itself: (Mṣb:) [and † a concluding chapter or section: an epilogue: and an appendix:] and muxotatamN↓ signifies [in like manner] the contr. of mufotataHN; as in the saying, Alt-aHomiydu mufotataHu QloquroMni waQliAsotiEaAcapu muxotatamuhu † [The declaration of the praises of God is the opening portion of the Ḳur-án, and the prayer for the protection of God is its closing portion]; (A, TA;) and it is a chaste word, of frequent occurrence, though the contr. has been asserted. (TA.) One says also, AlOaEomaAlu bixawaAtiymihaA [Actions are characterized, or to be judged, as good or evil, by their results]. (TA.)

Also, i. e. xaAtamN, of a mare, ‡ The lower ring (AlHaloqapu Ald-unoyaA [app. meaning the extremity, in which is the orifice, see HaloqataA Alr-aHimi and Haloqapu Ald-uburi, in art. Hlq,]) of the Tuboyap [evidently here used as a dial. var. of TuboI, i. e. the teat, though I do not find it mentioned in its proper art. in any lexicon; unless mino TuboyatihaA be a mistranscription for mn TuboyihaA]: (Ḳ, TA:) so called by way of comparison [to a signet or seal]. (TA.)
And ‡ The hollow (nuqorap) of the back of the neck; (JK, Ḳ, TA;) which is the cuppingplace. (TA.)
And † The least waDaH [or whiteness] of the legs (JK, Ḳ, TA) of horses; (JK, TA;) i. e. a slight whiteness in the parts next the hoof, less than what is termed taxodiymN. (TA.)

entry.sense: xaAtumN: see xitaAmN.
xaAtimN: see xaAtamN, in two places:
and see also xitaAmN, in five places.
xayotamN: see xaAtamN, first sentence.
xaAtimapN: see xaAtamN, in two places, in the latter half of the paragraph.
xaAtaAmN: see xaAtamN, first sentence.
xayotaAmN: see xaAtamN, first sentence.
xiytaAmN: see xaAtamN, first sentence.
xayotuwmN: see xaAtamN, first sentence.
xaAtiyaAmN: see xaAtamN, first sentence.
taxotimapN: see 5. You say, maA OaHosana taxotimatahu [How good, or beautiful, is his act, or mode, of putting on the turban! or, of putting it on in the manner of the niqaAb!]. (Ez-Zejjájee, TA.)
muxot-amN Sealed, or stamped,, &c., much. (Ṣ,* TA.)
Applied to a horse, (TA,) † Having the whiteness of the legs which is termed xaAtamN. (Ḳ, TA. [See the latter word, last sentence.])
maxotuwmN Sealed, or stamped,, &c. (Ṣ,* TA.)

Also The [measure commonly called] SaAE: (AʼObeyd, Mgh, Ḳ:) or the sixth part of the [measure called] qafiyz. (Mgh in art. kr. [It is there added that the qfyz is the tenth part of the jariyb: but it seems that this is the qfyz which is a measure of land; not what is here meant in the explanation of mxtwm, which is a measure of corn and the like.]) [Pl. maxaAtiymu.]
muxotatamN: see xaAtamN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. xatana, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxotinu} (Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yaxotunu}, (Ḳ, TA, but omitted in the CK,) inf. n. xatonN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He circumcised (Ḳ, TA) a boy, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and a girl also: or, as some say, xatonN relates to men [or boys], and xafoDN to women [or girls]. (TA.) xutina: see 8.

And xitaAnN↓ [which see below, app. as an inf. n. of which the verb is as above,] signifies The making a feast, or banquet, to which people are invited, on account of a wedding, and of a circumcision also. (KL.)
[And accord. to Golius, as on the authority of a gloss. in the KL, xatana also signifies He diminished; he rendered imperfect: and he acted unjustly.]

xatanahu is also syn. with xatalahu [He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him, unawares]: and muxaAtanapN↓ is syn. with muxaAtalapN [which signifies in like manner the act of deceiving, deluding,, &c.; or practising mutual deceit,, &c.; or striving, endeavouring, or desiring, to deceive,, &c.]. (TA.)

3. xAtnhu He allied himself to him by marriage; syn. tazaw-aja Uilayohi. (Ḳ.) muxaAtanapN is syn. with muSaAharapN [The becoming that kind of relation that is termed Sihor]: (ISh, Mgh:) as some say, mSAhrp on the side of the wife, and on the side of the husband: so that one says xaAtanotuhumo as meaning SaAharotuhumo [I became a relation to them on the side of the wife, and on the side of the husband]. (Mṣb.)
See also 1, last sentence.

entry.sense: 8. Axttn He (a boy) was circumcised; (TA;) syn. xutina↓: or he circumcised himself; syn. xatana nafosahu. (Mgh.)

xatanN i. q. SihorN, (Lth, Mgh, Ḳ, &c.,) as meaning A man married among a people: (Lth, Mgh:) [such a man is said to be that people's xatan:] or any relation on the side of the wife; (Ṣ, IAạr, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) such as a man's wife's father, (Lth, IAạr, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and wife's mother, (Lth, Mgh,) and wife's brother, (IAạr, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and the like; (Ḳ;) so it signifies with the Arabs: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:) thus Aboo-Bekr was the Prophet's xtn, and so was ʼOmar: (Mgh, TA:) and [it is said that] with the vulgar it signifies a man's daughter's husband: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:) but it is used in this sense by a rájiz; and, in a trad., ʼAlee is called the Prophet's xtn: (TA:) accord. to Az, it signifies a man's wife's father: (Mṣb:) and xatanapN is applied to the female; and means a man's wife's mother: (Az, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) the pl. is OaxotaAnN: (Az, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) accord. to Aṣ, (Mgh,) the OaxotaAn are [the relations] on the side of the wife; and the OaHomaMC, on the side of the husband; and the OaSohaAr, on either side: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or a man's AxtAn are his wife's relations; and a woman's AxtAn are her husband's relations: and a man's AxtAn are also said to be his daughters' husbands and sisters' husbands and paternal aunts' husbands and maternal aunts' husbands, and the husbands of any women whom, by reason of relationship, it is unlawful for him to marry, and any relations on the side of these husbands to whom marriage is unlawful, of men and of women. (Mgh.)

xitaAnN Circumcision, of a boy, (Ṣ,* Mgh,* Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA,) and of a girl; (TA;) a subst. from 1 in the first of the senses explained above; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also xitaAnapN↓. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, OuToHirato xitaAnatuhu↓ His circumcision was made to be extirpative. (Ṣ, TA.)
And A feast, or banquet, to which people are invited on account of a circumcision. (JK, Ṣ, TA.) You say, kunotu fiI xitaAni fulaAnK I was at the feast, or banquet,, &c., of such a one. (TA.)
See also 1, third sentence.

Also The part, of the male, which is the place of circumcision; (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) and of the female likewise; (T, Mgh, TA;) the part, of the faroj, which is the place of circumcision. (Mṣb.) Hence, in a trad., UicaA QlotaqaI AlxitaAnaAni [When the two places of circumcision meet together]: (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* TA:) AilotiqaMCu AlxitaAnayoni is a euphemism, metonymically denoting the disappearing, or causing to disappear, of the part of the penis that is above, or beyond, the place of circumcision (Mgh,* Mṣb, TA) in the vulva of the woman. (Mgh,* TA.)
xutuwnN: see xutuwnapN.
xatiynN Circumcised, applied to a boy, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) as also maxotuwnN↓ (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ) and muxotatinN↓; (TA;) and to a girl likewise, (Mṣb, TA,) as also maxotuwnapN↓. (Mṣb.)
xitaAnapN: see xitaAnN, in two places.
Also The art, or business, of circumcising. (JK, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, Aw AlxitAnapu is erroneously put for waAlxtAnp.])
xutuwnapN The alliance by which one acquires the relationship of a xatan, (Az, Mgh,) or of a Sihor; (Ḳ;) as also xutuwnN↓. (Az, Mgh, Ḳ.) And A man's marrying, or taking to wife, a woman. (Ḳ.)
xaAtinN A circumciser. (JK,* Mṣb,* TA.)
xaAtuwnN A lady, or noble woman; a foreign word, (Ḳ, TA,) used by the Persians and Turks: pl. xawaAtiynu. (TA.)
EaAmN maxotuwnN ‡ A year of drought, or barrenness, or dearth. (A, TA.)
muxotatinN: see xatiynN.

1. xavara, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxovuru}; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and xavura, aor. _u {yaxovuru}, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a rare dial. var.; (Fr, Ṣ;) and xavira, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxovaru}, (Mṣb,) a form heard by Ks; (Ṣ;) inf. n. (of the first, TA) xavorN and xuvuwrN and xavaraAnN, (Ḳ, TA,) which last is irregular, because this word does not imply motion, (TA,) [but this assertion requires consideration,] and (of the second [accord. to rule], TA, or of the first, Mṣb, [or used as inf. n. of the first because it is the most common form,]) xuvuwrapN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of the second accord. to rule] xavaArapN (Ḳ) and of the third xavarN; (Mṣb, TA;) [and probably txv-r↓, (mentioned by Freytag, though without any indication of his authority,) as quasi-pass. of xav-arahu; but I have more than once found it erroneously written for txt-r, which has a different signification;] it (milk, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, and honey, and the like, TA, and a liniment or the like, A, or some other thing, Mṣb) was, or became, thick, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and strong. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] xavarato nafosuhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or xavirato, (A,) or xavuratN, (Mgh,) inf. n. xuvuwrN and xavaArapN, but not, as some write it, xuvaArapN, (TA,) ‡ His soul [or stomach] heaved, became agitated by a tendency to vomit, or became heavy; (A, Mgh, Ḳ, TA;) as also xavara alone; (IAạr, TA;) became disordered; syn. AixotalaTato. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And xavara; (Ṣ;) or xavira, aor. _a {yaxovaru}; (Ḳ;) or xavira fiI AlHaI-i; (A;) ‡ He remained among the tribe, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) not going forth with people to procure wheat or corn or other provisions, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) by reason of shame, or of heaviness of the soul [or stomach]. (TA.)
And xavira † He felt, or had a sense of, or he was, or became, moved or affected with, shame, shyness, bashfulness, or honest shame. (Ḳ.)
2: see 4.

4. Axvrhu; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and xv-rhu↓, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxoviyrN; (TA;) He thickened it; made it thick, (Mṣb, A, Ḳ,) and strong; (Mṣb;) namely, milk, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and honey, and the like, (TA,) and a liniment or the like, (A,) or some other thing. (Mṣb.)

And the former signifies also He left it in a thick state; namely, fresh butter; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) not melting it. (Aṣ, Ṣ.) It is said in a prov., maA yadoriI Oayuxoviru Oamo yuciybu [He knows not whether to leave in a thick state or to melt]: (Ṣ Ḳ; in one copy of the former of which, the fem. forms of the verbs are used:) applied to him who is confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, and who wavers, or vacillates: its origin being this: a woman melts fresh butter, and what is thick thereof becomes mixed with what is thin, and she is vexed and wearied by her case, and knows not whether to raise the fire with fuel, in order that it may become clear; fearing that, if she do so, it will burn: thus she is perplexed. (Ḳ.)
5: see 1.
xavoraI AlOanofusi and xavoraMCu AlAnfs: see xaAvirN.
xuvaArN What remains upon a table of food. (Ṣ.)

xuvaArapN What remains (Ṣ, Ḳ) of a thing, (Ṣ,) or of milk: (Ḳ:) the dregs; lees; or thick, or turbid, portion that sinks to the bottom of a thing, beneath the clear portion. (TA in art. vfl.) You say, cahaba Safowuhu wabaqiyato xuvaAratuhu [The clear part of it went away, and the thick part of it remained]. (A.)
xaAvirN, applied to milk, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and to a liniment or the like, (A,), &c., (Mṣb,) Thick, or thickening, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) and strong. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] xaAviru Aln-afosi ‡ Having the soul [or stomach] in a heaving state, agitated by a tendency to vomit, or heavy: (TA:) or not in a good state: (A, Mgh:) and languid: (A:) and qawomN xavoraMCu↓ AlOanofusi (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xavoraI↓ AlOanofusi (Ḳ) a party disordered [in souls or stomachs]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And xaAvirapN † A woman feeling a little pain (Ḳ) and languor; as also muxov-irapN↓ [or, more probably muxov-arapN]. (TA.)

hom.sense: xaAvirapN [fem. of xaAvirN, q. v.]
[And also, as a subst.,] ‡ A party of men: (Ḳ, TA:) or ‡ a dense body of men. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: muxav-arapN: see xaAvirN.

1. xavaI, aor. yaxoviI, inf. n. xavoIN, said of a beast of the ox-kind, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or of a bull, but not [xavato] of a cow, (AʼObeyd, TA,) and of an elephant, (Ḳ,) He dunged. (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See also xivoIN.]
4. AxvI He (a man, TA) kindled [dry dung such as is called] xivoI. (Ḳ.)

xivoIN Dung of a beast of the ox-kind; (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also xavFI↓: (Mṣb:) or of a bull: (IAạr, TA:) and of the elephant: (Ḳ:) and metaphorically, of the camel; as used in a trad.: or, accord. to AZ, compact dung of a beast of the ox-kind, and of the sheep or goat, and of any cloven-hoofed animal, and of the camel: (TA:) pl. OaxovaMCN [a pl. of pauc.] (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xaviI-N, (CK, [a quasi-pl. n. like EabiydN,]) or xiviI-N, (Ḳ accord. to the TA, [like HiniI-N, q. v., a pl. of HinowN,]) and xuviI-N [originally xuvuwIN], (Ḳ,) these two from Fr. (TA.)
xivoIN also signifies † A number of people in a state of dispersion: (Ṣgh, TA:) or so xivoIN mina Aln-aAsi. (JK.)
xavFI: see the next preceding paragraph.

mixovFI, (JK, TA,) so in the Tekmileh, (TA,) [or mixovFA accord. to the CK, there, with the article, written AlmixovA,] or mixovaMCN↓, (Ḳ accord. to the TA,) The [kind of pouch called] xariyTp, (JK, Ḳ,) and small [bag such as is termed] jiraAb, (JK,) of the gatherer of [wild] honey, (JK, Ḳ,) which he puts beneath the part between his armpit and his flank, (TA,) and in which he deposits the honey. (JK.)
mixovaMCN: see what next precedes.

1. xajila, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _a {yaxojalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xajalN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, &c.,) but not xajaAlapN, [though authorized by the KL, in my copy of which I find it thus written (not xijaAlapN as written by Golius),] for this is a vulgar mistake for xajalapN or xajolN, (Mgh, [so in my copy, but correctly xajalapN↓ (which may be either a simple subst. or an inf. n. of un.) or xajalN,]) He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of shame: (Ṣ, O:) or he was, or became, ashamed, and confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, (T, M, Ḳ,) [or, simply, ashamed, (see xajilN,)] in consequence of a deed that he had done: (T, M, TA:) thus Alxajalu has a more particular signification than AlHayaMCu: (TA:) or it is like AlAisotiHoyaMCu. (Mṣb.)
And He remained silent, (T, Ḳ,) or still, (M,) not speaking nor moving. (Ḳ.)
And He was, or became, in a confused and dubious case, (JK, M,* Ḳ,*) so that he knew not how to extricate himself from it. (M, Ḳ.)
Also, said of a camel, ‡ He went in mud, and became like him who is confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (JK,* M, Ḳ, TA:) or he stuck fast in mire. (T, TA.)

And in like manner, † He became agitated, or convulsed, or he struggled, or floundered, with his load: (JK:) or xajila biAloHimoli he was oppressed by the load, (Ḳ, TA,) so that he was agitated, or convulsed, or he struggled, or floundered, beneath it. (TA.)
And, said of a plant, or of herbage, ‡ It was, or became, tall, and tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense; (ISd, Ḳ, TA;) and so Axjl↓ said of the kind of trees termed HayoD. (JK, Ḳ.)

[And, as inf. n. of xajila,] xajalN also signifies The bearing richness ill; as when, being rich, one exults, or exults greatly or excessively, and behaves insolently and unthankfully: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) or the taking a wide, or an ample, range, or being profuse, when rich. (TA.) It is related in a trad. that he [Moḥammad] said to the women, UicaA juEotun-a waUicaA XabiEotun-a xajilotun-a, (Ṣ,* TA,) i. e. When ye are hungry, ye become lowly, humble, or submissive, and cleave to the dust, or earth; (Ṣ and TA in art. dqE;) or ye bear poverty ill: (TA in the present art.;) and when ye are satiated, [ye bear richness ill; or] ye exult, or exult greatly or excessively, and behave insolently and unthankfully. (Ṣ in the present art.) [See also a verse of El-Kumeyt cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. dqE.]
And i. q. baramN [The being affected with disgust, loathing, or aversion; the being vexed, grieved, disquieted by grief,, &c.] (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, Albaromu is erroneously put for Albaramu.])
And The being remiss in seeking subsistence. (Ḳ.)
And The being lazy, or indolent: (Az, ISd, Ḳ:) from the verb in the sense explained in the second sentence of this paragraph. (TA.)
And i. q. [The being bad, corrupt,, &c.]. (M, Ḳ.)
Also, in a shirt, † The being much slit, or rent, in the lower parts, or skirts. (Fr, Ḳ.)
2: see what next follows {4}.

hom.sense: 4. Axjlhu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) i. q. xj-lhu↓, (Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. taxojiylN; (TA;) He, (Ṣ,) or it, namely, an affair, or event, (TA,) caused him to become confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of shame: (Ṣ in explanation of the former:) [or caused him to become ashamed, and confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, in consequence of a deed that he had done: (see 1:)] or he said to him xajilota. (Mṣb. [But it is not clear whether this meaning be there assigned to both of these verbs, or only to the latter of them.])
See also 1.

entry.sense: xajilN part. n. of xajila; (Mṣb;) [Confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of shame: or ashamed, and confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, in consequence of a deed that he has done: or, simply,] ashamed. (Ṣ, Mṣb.*)
[Other meanings are shown by explanations of the verb.]

Applied to herbage, ‡ Tall, (Ḳ, TA,) and tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and goodly, and ISd adds, full-grown: and muxojilN↓ [in like manner], applied to the kind of trees termed HamoD, dense, or tangled, and tall: or, applied to herbage, or pasturage, wide, abundant, full-grown, that detains one so that he stays among it, not passing beyond. (TA.)

And, applied to a place, and a valley, † Abounding with tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, herbage: (Ṣ:) or, applied to a valley, (JK, Ḳ,) as also muxojilN↓, (Ḳ,) ‡ exceedingly abundant in herbage: (Ḳ, TA:) or tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, therewith; (JK, Ḳ, TA;) resounding with the humming of flies. (JK.)

Also, applied to a garment, † Wide and long: (ISh, Ḳ:) or ample: or such that the wearer is impeded and clogged therein: (TA:) and, so applied, † old, and worn out: (Ḳ:) or † much slit, or rent, in the lower parts, or skirts. (Fr, TA.)

And, applied to a jul- [or horse-cloth, or covering for a beast], (ISh, Ḳ,) [or] such as is put upon a camel, (ISh,) That moves to and fro, or from side to side, (ISh, Ḳ,) upon the camel, (ISh,) or upon the horse, (Ḳ,) by reason of its width. (ISh.)

xajolapN: see 1: [it seems to be most probably a subst. signifying Confusion, or perplexity, and inability to see one's right course, by reason of shame: or shame, and confusion, or perplexity, and inability to see one's right course, in consequence of a deed that one has done: or simply,] i. q. HayaMCN [shame, or a sense of shame,, &c.]. (Ṣ.)
muxojilN: see xajilN, in two places.

1. xad-a AlOaroDa, aor. _u {yaxodudu}, (Ṣ,) or xad-a fiI AlOaroDi, (A,) [aor., if accord. to rule, _i,] inf. n. xad-N, (T,) He furrowed, or trenched, or clave, the ground; (Ṣ, L;) he made a furrow, or trench, [or furrows, or trenches,] in the ground. (T, A.) The latter (xd- fI AlArD) is also said of a torrent, meaning It furrowed, or clave, the ground by its course. (L.)

xad-a, (L,) inf. n. _u, (L, Ḳ,) also signifies He, or it, marked, scored, or impressed, a thing: (L:) and made a mark or marks, or an impression or impressions, upon a thing. (L, Ḳ.*) You say, xad-a Alfarasu AlOaroDa biHawaAfirihi The horse marked, or scored, [or furrowed,] the ground with his hoofs. (L.) And xad-a Ald-amoEu fiI xad-ihi The tears made marks upon his cheeks. (L.)
Also He (a camel) clave a thing with his nAb [or tush]. (L.)
And He cut a thing. (IAạr.)

2. xad-ada laHomuhu, (as in the Ṣ and Ḳ,) or xud-ida, (as in one place in the L,) [both of which may be correct, for the verb is said in the Ḳ to be both intrans. and trans.,] ‡ His flesh became contracted, shrunk, or wrinkled; (Ṣ, TA;) as also txd-d↓: (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ:) or his flesh wasted so that there appeared streaks upon his skin: (TA in art. xb:) or he (a beast) became lean, or lank, or light of flesh, or slender or lank in the belly, so that his flesh became furrowed, or wrinkled: and txd-d↓ laHomuhu his flesh became flaccid and quivering, by reason of leanness. (L.) And xd-dhu ‡ It (travel) rendered him lean and wasted: (Ḳ:) and so evilness of state or condition. (A,* TA.)
3. xAd-hu ‡ He opposed him, being opposed by him: (A:) or he was, or became, angered, or enraged, against him, and opposed him in his deed, or work. (Ḳ.)
5. txd-d It (the ground) became furrowed, or cleft, by a torrent. (L in art. fSd.)
See also 2, in two places.
txd-d Alqawomu ‡ The people became divided into distinct bodies, or parties. (L in the present art.)
6. txAd-A ‡ They opposed each other. (A, TA.)

hom.sense: xad-N, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) of the masc. gender (Lḥ, Ḳ) only, (Lḥ,) and xud-apN↓, with damm, (Ḳ,) but the latter is rare, (TA,) The cheek; the part extending from the circuit of the eye (AlmaHojir [in the CK AlmiHojan]) to the part where the beard grows, on either side of the face: (L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or from the outer angle of each eye to the extremity of the side of the mouth: or the part bordering upon the nose, on either side: (L, Ḳ:) each of the xad-aAni, in the face: (Ṣ:) pl. of the former xuduwdN: (Mṣb, TA:) it has no other pl. (TA.)

The former is also sing. of xuduwdN meaning ‡ The planks on the right and left of the daf-ataAni [or two boards that lie against the camels' sides] of the [vehicles termed] hawaAdij (Aṣ, A, TA) and gubuT: (Aṣ, TA:) or xad-N signifies the plank (SafiyHap) of the hawodaj: and the pl. is Oaxid-apN, (Ḳ,) [a pl. of pauc., but] contr. to rule, (TA,) and (pl. of mult., TA) xidaAdN and xid-aAnN. (Ḳ.)
Also ‡ A side, or lateral portion, of a [tract of high and rugged ground such as is termed] quf-. (A, TA.)

And ‡ An assembly, a company, or a congregated body, (Ḳ, TA,) of men: (TA:) a rank, or class, of men: (A, L:) and a race, or generation, of men. (L.) You say, raOayotu xad-FA mina Aln-aAsi † I saw a rank, or class, of men. (L.) And qatalonaA, (A,) or qatalahumo, (L,) xad-FA faxad-FA, (A, L,) ‡ We slew, (A,) or he slew them, (L,) rank after rank, (A, L,) and class after class. (A.) And maDaIa xad-N mina Aln-aAsi † A race, or generation, of men passed away. (L.)
A road. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
See also OuxoduwdN, in four places.
xud-apN: see OuxoduwdN, in four places:
and see also xad-N.

entry.sense: xadadN: see OuxoduwdN.
xidaAdN A mark made with a hot iron upon the cheek (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) of a camel. (A.)

OuxoduwdN A furrow, trench, or channel, in the ground; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also xad-N↓ (A, Ḳ) and xud-apN↓: (Ḳ:) a deep trench in the ground; as also xad-N↓: applied in the Ḳur [lxxxv. 4] to a deep trench into which, it being filled with fire, some believers in the true God were cast by some idolaters among whom they dwelt: (TA:) a hole, hollow, cavity, pit, or the like, dug, or excavated; (Mṣb;) as also xud-apN↓: (Ṣ:) pl. OaxaAdiydu: (A, Mṣb:) the pl. of xad-N↓ is xuduwdN; (A;) and the pl. of xud-apN↓ is xudadN. (TA.)
A rivulet, or streamlet; syn. jadowalN; (Mṣb;) as also xad-N↓; (L, Ḳ;) of which the pl. [of pauc.] is Oaxid-apN, contr. to rule; and of mult. xidaAdN and xid-aAnN. (L.)

OaxaAdiydu and xadadN↓ [the latter probably a mistranscription for xudadN, pl. of xud-apN↓,] The main or middle parts, or open or obvious tracks, (Xarak,) of a road: (L:) [because furrowed by the feet of beasts and men.]
OaxaAdiydu AlOaroXiyapi The furrows, or grooves, of wellropes, in a well; made by drawing them. (L.)
OaxaAdiydu Als-iyaATi The marks of whips; (Ḳ;) the furrows made by whips upon the back. (L.)
DarobapN OuxoduwdN, (Ṣ,) or Darobapu OuxoduwdK, (so in a copy of the A,) ‡ A blow, or stroke, or beating, that furrows the skin. (Ṣ, A,* TA.)
mixad-N Each of the tushes, or canine teeth; the two together being termed the mixad-aAni. (L.)

hom.sense: mixad-apN [A pillow, or cushion]: so called because it is put beneath the cheek: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) pl. maxaAd-u. (A, Mṣb.)
Also An iron implement with which the ground is furrowed, trenched, or cleft. (Ṣ, L.)

entry.sense: maxoduwdN A camel having the mark called xidaAd made upon his cheek. (Ṣ, A.)
mutaxd-idN ‡ A man (L) lean, or emaciated; (Ṣ, L;) having little flesh. (L.) And the fem., with p {mutaxd-idapN}, ‡ A woman fat but wasted in body [so that she is furrowed, or wrinkled]. (L.)

1. xadabahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxodubu}, inf. n. xadobN, (TA,) He smote him with a sword: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he cut him: (AZ:) or he smote him with a sword, cutting the flesh, without cutting the bone: (T, Ḳ:) or he smote him on the head, (JK, Ḳ,* TA,) and the like, (JK, TA,) with a sword. (JK.)
xadobN signifies also The act of rending, or cutting open, the skin and the flesh together, (JK, Ṣ, TA.) with the canine tooth. (JK, TA.)
And The act of biting. (Ḳ.) You say, xadabatohu AlHay-apu The serpent bit him. (Ṣ.)
And The act of lying, or saying what is untrue. (Ḳ.) You say, xadaba He lied. (JK, Ṣ.)
And The act of milking much. (Ḳ.)
5. txd-b He went a middling pace. (Aṣ, Ḳ.)

xadabN Stupidity; (JK;) i. q. hawajN [which means the same; or tallness combined with stupidity;, &c.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and [simply] tallness, or length; (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA;) as also xudobapN↓. (TA.) One says, kaAna binaEaAmapa xadabN There was, in Na'ámeh, hawaj [i. e. stupidity,, &c.]: (Ṣ, TA:) Na'ámeh being the surname of Beyhes, (TA,) who became the subject of a prov. respecting the taking of blood-revenge: (Ḳ in art. bhs:) Beyhes El-Fezáree, surnamed En-Na'ámeh, [or simply Na'ámeh,] was one of seven brothers, who were slain [in a case of blood-revenge], except himself; he being left because of his stupidity; for which he became proverbial. (TA in art. bhs.) One says also, fiI lisaAnihi [He is long-tongued; lit.] in his tongue is length. (Ṣ.)
Also The act of making haste. (KL.)

hom.sense: xadibN Cutting; or sharp: (IAạr, Ḳ:) applied to a sword, and a spear-head, and a dog-tooth. (IAạr.)
See also Oaxodabu, in three places.

entry.sense: xudobapN: see xadabN.

waqaEuwA fiI waAdiI xadibaAtK [They fell into the valley of Khadibát]: a prov., applied to a man who falls into perdition; or to one who misses the object of his aim, or pursuit: (Aṣ, Ḳ:*) see, respecting it, [jacabaAt, in] art. jcb. (TA.)

xadib-N An old man. (A, Ḳ.) Great, big, or bulky; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) applied to a man, (Ṣ,) or to an ostrich, &c.; (Ḳ;) fem. with p {xadib-apN}, applied to a girl: (Ṣ:) great, and thick or coarse or rude [in make]: (TA:) big in the sides: (Ḥam p. 439:) big and strong; applied to an old man: (JK:) a man, and a camel, perfect and strong in make: (A:) a camel strong and hardy (A, Ḳ, TA) and big. (TA.)
xaAdibapN, (JK, TA,) or Xaj-apN xaAdibapN, (TA,) A severe wound breaking the head. (JK, TA.)
xayodabN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or xayodabapN↓, (JK,) A conspicuous road: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) so says Esh-Sheybánee. (Ṣ.)
And the latter, A way of acting or conduct: so in the saying, fulaAnN EalaI xayodabapK SaAliHapK [Such a one is following a good, righteous, or just, way of acting or conduct]. (TA.)
Opinion, judgment, or counsel: (Ḳ:) so in the saying, tarakotuhu waxayodabatahu [I forsook him and his counsel]. (TA.)
One's first, or original, affair, concern, or business: (AZ, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) so in the saying, Oaqobilo EalaI xayodabatika [Apply thyself to thy first, or thine original, affair,, &c.] (AZ, JK, Ṣ.)
xayodabapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

Oaxodabu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xadibN↓ (JK) and mutaxad-ibN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ,) applied to a man, (JK, Ṣ,) Stupid; (JK;) characterized by hawaj [i. e. stupidity, or tallness combined with stupidity,, &c.]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and [simply] by tallness: (Ḳ: [in which Oaxodabu is said to be syn. with TawiylN:]) fem. [of the first], applied to a woman, xadobaMCu: (Ṣ:) and the first, one who cannot restrain himself, by reason of stupidity: (TA:) and the same, (Ḳ,) or xadibN↓, (JK,) one who goes his own way, at random, or heedlessly, without any certain aim or object, or without consideration, not obeying a guide to the right course, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) by reason of ignorance, (JK,) or from boldness. (TA.)

Also [the fem.] xadobaMMu, applied to any [she-] animal, That is wont to wound, and kill, and seize its prey and break its neck. (IAạr.) And HarobapN xadobaMCu and xadibapN↓ [A dart, or javelin,] that inflicts a wide wound. (Ḳ.) And TaEonapN xadobaMCu, (Ṣ,) and DarobapN xadobaMCu, (Ḳ,) [A thrust, and a blow,] with which the jawof [or belly,, &c.,] is assaulted: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the former, a wide thrust or wound with a spear or the like: and the latter, a continuous and long act of beating. (TA.)
And diroEN xadobaMCu A coat of mail that is smooth, or pliable, (lay-inapN, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and (so in the JK, but in the Ḳ “or”) wide. (JK, Ḳ.)
mutaxad-ibN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1. xadajato, aor. _i {yaxodiju} (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yaxoduju}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xidaAjN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb,)
She (a camel, AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, and any cloven-hoofed or solid-hoofed animal, AZ, Mṣb, TA, or sometimes another female, TA) cast her young one before the completion of the days of gestation, (AZ, IḲt, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) to which IḲooṭ adds, (Mṣb,) even if it were completely formed; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also xadajato waladahaA; (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb;) and xd-jt↓, inf. n. taxodiyjN: (TA:) or, as some say, she cast her young one when her pregnancy had become apparent, between the commencement of its formation and the period a little before the completion; as also Axdjt↓ waladahaA; but see the latter verb below: (Mṣb:) or she (a camel) cast her young one in a defective state, before the time: or without any hair upon it: or miscarried, bringing forth merely blood: and Thábit mentions the last but one of these significations as relating to a human being: (TA:) or you say of a woman, xadajato waladahaA and Oaxodajatohu↓ in one and the same sense, (Aboo-Kheyreh, TA,) meaning she cast her fœtus in such a state that its form had become apparent: and xadajato she miscarried, bringing forth merely blood: when she has brought it forth before its hair has grown, one says of her gaDanato: so says Az. (TA.)
And xadaja ‡ He (a man) was, or became, deficient in a limb, or member. (A.)
See also 4, in two places.
2: see 1.

4. Axdjt She (a camel) brought forth her young one imperfectly formed, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) even if the period of gestation were complete: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or so Axdjt waladahaA: and the former, she brought forth her young one imperfectly formed at the completion of the period: (IḲt, Mṣb:) or she brought forth her young one completely formed before the proper time of bringing forth. (TA.) See also 1, in two places.

Hence, (TA,) Axdjt AlX-atowapN, (IAạr, Ṣ,) or AlS-ayofapu, (Ḳ,) ‡ [The winter, or the spring or summer (but more probably the former),] had little rain. (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And Axdjt Alz-anodapu, (T, TA,) or xadajat↓, (TA,) ‡ [The lower of the two wooden instruments for producing fire] failed to emit fire. (T, TA.) And Axdj ‡ He rendered a man defective in a limb, or member: said of God. (A.) And ‡ He performed incompletely his prayer; (Es-Sara- kustee, A, Mṣb;) or so xadaja↓: (Mṣb:) and in like manner, (i. e. the former verb,) † a salutation: (TA, from a trad.:) and ‡ he performed unsoundly his affair: (A, TA:) and ‡ he formed unsoundly his opinion. (A.)
xidojN: see muxodajN.

hom.sense: xidaAjN inf. n. of 1 in the first of the senses explained above; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) or a simple subst. therefrom; (Mṣb;) or a subst. from 4 in the first of the senses explained above. (Mgh.) See also mixodaAjN.
And hence, (Mṣb,) ‡ Defect, or deficiency. (Aṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA.)

SalaApN xidaAjN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) in which the latter word is an inf. n. used as an epithet, (A,) or for caAtu xidaAjK, (Mgh, TA,) ‡ Prayer incompletely performed; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ;) as also muxodajapN↓ and xaAdijapN↓: (A:) applied in a trad. to prayer in which the Fátihah is not recited. (Ṣ, Mgh, TA.) And Haj-N UixodaAjN↓, in which [likewise] the latter word is for cuw UixodaAjK, or is an inf. n. used as an epithet, † Pilgrimage incompletely performed. (Ḥar p. 392.)
Also a pl. of xaduwjN. (TA.)

entry.sense: xaduwjN: see xaAdijN:
and see also muxodajN.
xadiyjN The young one of a camel brought forth before the completion of the days [of gestation], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) even if it be completely formed; (Ṣ;) [and so, accord. to rule, maxoduwjN↓.]
See also muxodajN.

It is applied in a trad. respecting the poor-rate to A calf one year old, or under, that still follows its mother; resembling a xadiyj [properly so called] in the smallness of its limbs, and in its having less strength than a van-iI or a rubAEiI-. (TA.)

xaAidjN A she-camel (or a female of another kind, TA) casting her young one before the completion of the days [of gestation], (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) even if it be completely formed; (Ṣ, A;) as also xaduwjN↓, of which the pl. is xuduwjN and xidaAjN and xadaAYiju: or a she-camel casting her young one in a defective state, before the time. (TA. [See 1, of which it is the act. part. n. And see also muxodijN.])
[Hence,] ‡ A man deficient in a limb, or member. (A. [See also muxodajN.]) SalaApN xaAdijapN: see xidaAjN.
Haj-N UixodaAjN: see xidaAjN.

muxodajN The young one of a camel brought forth imperfectly formed, even if the period of gestation have been completed; (IḲt, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also maxoduwjN↓ (TA) and xadiyjN↓ [q. v.] (A, TA) and xaduwjN↓ and xidojN↓: (TA:) or brought forth completely formed before the proper time of bringing forth. (TA.)

‡ A man made deficient in a limb, or member: (A:) or defective in make. (TA, from a trad. [See also xaAdijN.]) And muxodaju Alyadi ‡ A man deficient in the arm, or hand. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ.) SalaApN muxodajapN: see xidaAjN.

muxodijN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and muxodijapN (TA) A she-camel bringing forth her young one imperfectly formed, even if the period of gestation be complete: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA:) or bringing forth her young one completely formed before the proper time of bringing forth. (TA. [See also xaAdijN.])

mixodaAjN and caAtu xidaAjK↓ [A she-camel that usually casts her young before the completion of the days of gestation, even if completely formed: (see 1:) or] a she-camel that usually brings forth her young imperfectly formed, (A, TA,) even if at the proper time, (A,) or before the proper time: (TA:) or that usually brings forth her young completely formed before the proper time of bringing forth. (TA.)
maxoduwjN: see xadiyjN: and see also muxodajN.

hom.sense: 1. xadara and xadira, as intrans. vs.: see 4, in six places:
and for the former, as a trans. v.: see 2, in two places.

xadira, aor. _a {yaxodaru}, inf. n. xadarN, said of a limb, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of the body, (TA,) and xadirato, inf. n. as above, said of the leg or foot, (Ṣ, A,) and of the arm or hand, (TA,) It was, or became, benumbed, or torpid, or affected by a languidness, or laxity, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or by a heaviness, (IAạr,) and an impotence of exercising motion, (IAạr, Mṣb,) or by a contraction of the sinews; (TA;) said of the leg or foot [&c.], it became asleep. (TA in art. bsr.)

Also xadira, inf. n. as above, † He became languid from drinking wine or medicine. (TA: but only the inf. n. of the v. in this sense is there mentioned.) And † He was, or became, lazy, or slothful, and languid. (Ḳ,* TA: but in this instance, also, only the inf. n. is mentioned.) And xadirato EiZaAmuhu (Ṣ, A) ‡ His bones became feeble. (A.) And xadirato Eayonuhu, (A,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) ‡ His eye became languid: (Ḳ, TA:) or became heavy, (A, Ḳ,) by reason of rubbing, (A,) or from a mote in it. (A, Ḳ.)
And xadira, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ, TA,) said of the day, (TA,) † It became intensely hot:
and † intensely cold: (Ḳ, TA: [see also the part. n. xadirN:])
and ‡ it was, or became, calm; without wind, and without a breeze. (A, TA.)

2. xd-r, (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. taxodiyrN; (Ḳ;) and Axdr↓, (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. UixodaArN; (Ḳ;) and xadara↓, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xadorN; (Ḳ;) He, (Mṣb,) or they, namely, her family, (A, Mṣb,) made a girl to keep herself behind, or within, the curtain; (A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and kept her from menial employments and from going out to accomplish her wants. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] xad-arato † She (a gazelle) concealed her young one in a covert of trees or the like, or in a hollow. (TA.) And Axdr↓ ‡ It (a lurking-place) concealed a lion; (Ḳ, TA;) [as also xadara↓: (see maxoduwrN:)] and † it (anything) prevented a thing from being seen. (TA.)
[And hence,] xd-r † It (rain) confined people in their houses or tents. (TA.) And Axdr↓ † It (night) confined, detained, or withheld, a person. (TA.)
See also 4, where it is app. a mistranscription for txd-r.

xd-r (A) and Axdr↓ (Ḳ) also signify It made a limb, (Ḳ,) and the body, (TA,) and a leg or foot, (A,) and an arm or a hand, (TA,) to become xadir, i. e. benumbed,, &c. (A, Ḳ, TA. [See xadira.]) You say, xad-aratohu AlmaqaAEidu, meaning Long sitting [lit. the sitting-places] made his legs, or feet, to be in that state. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: 3. xaAdaraniI [He acted covertly with me]. (A, TA. [In both, yuxaAdiruniI is coupled with yusaAtiruniI.])

hom.sense:
4. Oaxodarato She (a girl) kept herself behind, or within, the curtain; (Es-Sarakustee, Mṣb;) as also txd-rt↓, (A, TA,) and Axtdrt↓,
and xadarato↓ fiI xidorihaA. (TA.)

[Hence,] txd-r↓ [in the CK xd-r↓ (app. a mistranscription)] and Axtdr↓ † He concealed, or hid, himself; (Ḳ, TA;) as also xadira↓, like fariHa [in measure]: (TA:) whence the saying, Aixotadarati↓ AlqaArapu biAls-araAbi, i. e. [The small isolated mountain, or the like,] became concealed by the mirage. (TA.) [Hence also,] Axdr ‡ He (a lion) kept himself in his lurking-place; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also xadira↓ and xadara↓, (TA,) or xadara fiI Eariynihi. (A, TA.) And † It (a bird) remained in its nest. (Ṣ.) And † He (a man) remained, stayed, or abode; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) bimakaAnK in a place; as also xadara↓, inf. n. xadorN; (Ḳ;) and fiI Oaholihi among his family. (Ṣ.) And xadara↓, (Ṣ,) inf. n. xadorN (Ḳ,) † He (a gazelle) remained behind the herd; not going with it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and he (a beast) remained behind; not overtaking, or coming up with, the others. (TA.) And AxdrwA † They entered upon night [and so became concealed from view]. (TA.) And † They entered upon a day of rain, and of clouds or mist, and of wind: (Ḳ:) or rain came upon them. (Ṣ.)
Axdr as a trans. v.: see 2, in four places.

entry.sense: 5: see 4, in two places.
8: see 4, in three places.

xidorN A curtain (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) that is extended for a girl in a part of a house, or chamber, or tent; as also OuxoduwrN↓: (Ḳ:) and hence, (M,) any chamber, or house, or tent, or the like, that conceals a person: (M, Ḳ:) or a chamber, or house, or tent, in which is a woman; not otherwise: (Mṣb:) pl. [of mult.] xuduwrN (A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OaxodaArN, and pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of the latter of these two, or pl. of OuxoduwrN,] OaxaAdiyru. (Ḳ.)
[And hence, A vehicle composed of] pieces of wood set up over the saddle (qatab) of the camel, and curtained with a piece of cloth; (Ḳ;) i. e. a hawodaj. (TA.)
[Hence also,] ‡ The lurking-place of a lion. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
See also what next follows.

hom.sense: xadarN: inf. n. of xadira [q. v.]. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Also, and xidorN↓, † The darkness of night: (Ḳ:) or darkness absolutely; as also xudorapN↓: (TA:) or this last signifies intense darkness: (Ḳ TA:) or, accord. to some, the night consists of five divisions, sudofapN and sutofapN and hajomapN and yaEofuwrN and xudorapN; so that this last signifies the last [of five divisions] of the night: or, accord. to Kr, the division next before this is called haziyEN. (TA.)
† A dark place: (Ḳ:) or a dark, and low or depressed, place. (Ḥam p. 234.)
See also xudaAriI-N.
† Rain: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or clouds, or mist, and rain. (ISk.)
See also xudorapN.

entry.sense: xadurN: see xudaAriI-N.
xadirN, applied to a limb, Affected with xadar, or numbness,, &c. (Ḳ.)

[Hence,] EayonN xadirapN and xadoraMCu↓ ‡ An eye in a languid state: or heavy, by reason of rubbing, or from a mote in it. (TA.) And yaEofuwrN xadirN ‡ [A gazelle, or young gazelle,, &c., with languid eyes,] as though drowsy, (Ṣ, A,) by reason of the motionless state of its eye, and its weakness. (A.)
yawomN xadirN † A day intensely hot: (Lth:)
and [intensely cold: (see xadira:) or] cold and damp: (TA:) or damp: (Ṣ:) or rainy, and cloudy or misty: (Az:) and layolapN xadirapN † A night cold and damp: (TA:) or damp. (Ṣ.)
See also xudaAriI-N.
xadorapN † A rain. (TA.)
xudorapN [i. q. xadarN↓ (inf. n. of xadira) as meaning Numbness,, &c., or] heaviness of a leg, and inability thereof to walk. (IAạr.)
See also xadarN.
xudoriI-N † A black ass: (Ḳ:) as though a rel. n. from xudorapu All-ayoli [The darkness, or intense darkness, of night]. (TA. [See also xudaAriI-N.])
xaduwrN: see xaAdirN, in two places.

xudaAriI-N ‡ A dark night; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also Oaxodaru↓ (Ḳ) and muxodirN↓ (A) and xadirN↓ and xadarN↓ and xadurN↓. (Ḳ.) † A black cloud. (Ṣ.) † A camel intensely black: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) fem. with p {xudaAriy-apN}. (Ṣ. [See also xudoriI-N.]) ‡ Black hair. (A.) And xudaAriy-apN AlX-aEari ‡ A black-haired girl. (A.)

xudaAriy-apN also signifies † An eagle; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because of its colour; (Ṣ;) i. e. its intense blackness. (IB.) In the following verse,
kaOan-a EuqaAbFA xudaAriy-apF
tunaX-iru fiI Aljaw-i minohaA janaAHaA [which may be rendered, As though a black eagle spread in the sky its wing], Th says that the poet may mean, by EuqaAbFA, the bird [so called], or a banner, or garments of the kind called OaboraAd, which they spread over them. (TA.)

hom.sense: xaAdirN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and muxodirN↓ (A, TA) [originally Keeping behind, or within, the xidor, or curtain.]

[And hence,] ‡ A lion keeping, or abiding, in his lurking-place: (A,* Ḳ,* TA:) or entering into it. (Ṣ, TA.) And the former, and xaduwrN↓, † A gazelle remaining behind the herd; not going with it: and † a beast that remains behind; not overtaking, or coming up with, the others: and xaduwrN↓ likewise signifies † a camel that is in the rear of the other camels; that remains behind them, and when it sees them go on, goes on with them. (TA.)
xaAdirN signifies also † Languid, and lazy, or slothful. (Ṣ.)
And ‡ A gazelle having feeble bones. (TA.)
Oaxodaru: [fem. xadoraMCu:] see xudaAriI-N.
EayonN xadoraMCu: see xadirN.
banaAtu AlOaxodari: see what next follows.

entry.sense: OaxodariI-N A wild ass: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called from a certain stallion named AlOaxodaru: (TA:) some say, (TA,) this was a horse, (A, TA,) belonging to Ardasheer, that became wild: (A:) and some say that he was an ass: or so called in relation to El-'Irák, but ISd says, I know not how this is: (TA:) the pl. is Oaxodariy-aAtN; (A;) and banaAtu AlOaxodari↓ is used as a pl.; (TA;) and [in like manner] bnAt AlOaxodariI-i means the [wild] she-asses. (TA in art. bnI.)
AlOaxodariy-apu A certain race of horses: so called from a stallion named Oaxodaru. (Ḳ.)
OuxoduwrN: see xidorN.
muxodarN and muxodarapN: see muxad-arapN.

hom.sense: muxodirN: see xaAdirN:
and muxad-arapN:
and see also xudaAriI-N.

entry.sense: muxad-arapN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and muxodarapN↓ and maxoduwrapN↓ (Ḳ) A girl kept behind, or within, the curtain. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
And muxad-arN (TA) and maxoduwrN↓ (A, TA) A curtained [vehicle of the kind called] hawodaj. (A, TA.)
[And hence,] maxoduwrN↓ and muxodarN↓ (in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA muxodarN and muxodirN↓) ‡ A lion concealed in his lurking-place. (Ḳ, TA.)
maxoduwrN and maxoduwrapN: see what next precedes, in three places.

1. xadaXahu, (Az, Ṣ, A, &c.,) aor. xadoXN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xadoXN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) He scratched him, or it, (namely, the face, Az, Ṣ, Mgh,) with the nails, so as to cause bleeding or not; (Az, Ṣ,* Mgh, TA;) i. q. xamaXahu: (Az, A, Ḳ, TA:) he wounded him in the outer skin, so as to make it bleed or not: (Mṣb:) he lacerated it, namely, the skin, (A, Ḳ,) little or much: or tore off its surface with a stick or the like. (Ḳ.) You say, xadaXato wajohahaA Einoda AlmuSiybapi She scratched her face with her nails in the upper parts of what appeared thereof, so as to make it bleed or not, on the occasion of affliction. (Az. TA.)

2. xd-Xhu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. taxodiyXN, (A, TA,) [meaning He scratched him, or it, (namely, the face,) with the nails, vehemently, or much,] is with teshdeed to denote intensiveness, or muchness. (Ṣ, TA.)
[Hence,] waqaEa fiI AlOaroDi taxodiyXN ‡ A little rain [such as scratched the ground in many places] fell upon the land. (A, TA.)
3. xaAdaXotu Alr-ajula, inf. n. muxaAdaXapN and xidaAXN, I scratched the man's face with my nails, he scratching my face in like manner. (TA.)

xadoXN, an inf. n. used as a subst., (Mgh, Mṣb,) The mark made by scratching with the nails, (Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ,*) whether it cause bleeding or not: (Mgh:) pl. xuduwXN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is syn. with kuduwHN. (Ṣ, TA.)
biqalobihi xadoXapN ‡ In his heart is somewhat of hurt. (A, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xadaEahu, (TA,) [aor. _a {yaxodaEu},] inf. n. xadoEN, (Bḍ in ii. 8,) He hid it, or concealed it; (TA;) as also AxdEh↓, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. UixodaAEN. (TA.)
[And hence, app.,] (Lḥ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Lḥ,) ‡ He doubled it, or folded it, one part upon another; namely, a garment, or piece of cloth. (Lḥ, Ḳ, TA.)

[And hence, also, accord. to some,] xadaEahu, aor. _a {yaxodaEu}, inf. n. xadoEN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xidoEN, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb, TA,) and xadiyEapN, (TA,) or this [also] is a simple subst., (Mṣb, TA,) like xidaAEN, [which is also an inf. n. of 3,] and like xudNEapN, (TA,) He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; syn. xatalahu; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) and desired to do to him a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, without his knowing whence it proceeded: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he dissembled [or acted deceitfully] with him; pretended to him the contrary of what he concealed: (TA:) or he made him to resign, or relinquish, the object that he had in view, by pretending to him something the contrary of what he concealed: (Er-Rághib, B:) and xAdEhu↓, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. muxaAdaEapN (Ṣ) [and xidaAEN], signifies the same; (Ṣ,* TA;) as also AxtdEhu↓; and txd-Ehu↓; and xd-Ehu↓, inf. n. taxodiyEN: (TA:) or this last signifies he deceived him, deluded him, beguiled him, circumvented him, or outwitted him, much: (KL:) [and of another of these verbs we find the following various explanations:] xAdEhu↓ is syn. with kaAyadahu [which has the first of the meanings assigned in this sentence to xadaEahu; or signifies he practised with him mutual deceit, delusion, guile, or circumvention; he deceived him,, &c., being deceived,, &c., by him; and this latter meaning, if not each meaning, may be intended here by kAydh; for Bḍ says, (in ii. 8,) that muxaAdaEap is between two]: (TA:) or it signifies he strove, endeavoured, or desired, to deceive, delude, beguile, circumvent, or outwit, him; (AAF, L;) [agreeably with what is said by Kemál Páshá Zádeh, (as I find in a marginal note in a copy of the MṢ, and also in the Kull p. 178,) that one says of a man xAdE when he has not attained his desire, and xadaEa when he has attained his desire;] for many a verb of the measure faAEala relates to one only; as in the instances of EaAqabotu All-iS-a and TaAraqotu Aln-aEola: (L:) or it signifies, [like xadaEahu,] he pretended to him something different from that which was in his mind. (Ḳ.) It is said in the Ḳur [ii. 8], yuxaAdiEuwna↓ Qll-eha waQl-aciyna MmanuwA, (TA,) meaning They pretend, to God and to those who have believed, something different from that which is in their minds, by concealing unbelief and pretending belief; for when they do thus to the believers, they do thus to God: (Ḳ:) and again, [in iv. 141], yuxaAdiEuwna↓ Qll-eha wahuwa xaAdiEuhumo [They strive, endeavour, or desire, to deceive God, or] they think that they deceive God, but He is [their deceiver, i. e.,] the requiter, to them, of their xidaAE [or deceit,, &c.]: (TA:) or the meaning is [they deceive] the friends of God: (Ṣ:) and [agreeably with this last rendering, and that given in the Ḳ,] Aboo-Hayáh reads, in the former passage, yaxodaEuwna Qll-eha: (TA:) [which passage continues thus:] wamaA yuxaAdiEuwna↓ Uil-aA Oanofusahumo [but they do not deceive any save themselves]; i. e., the re- sult of their xidaAE [or deceit] does not befall any save themselves: (Ḳ:) here, again, Aboo-Hayáh reads yaxodaEuwna: (TA:) Muärrik reads wamaA yaxad-iEuwna↓, meaning yaxotadiEuwna. (Ḳ.) Accord. to IAạr, AlxadoEu signifies manoEu AlHaq-i [meaning The preventing from discovering, or accepting, the truth]. (L.) [“He deceived him,” or the like, seems to be generally regarded as the primary signification of xadaEahu, for it occupies the first place in all the lexicons to which I have access: but Bḍ says (in ii. 8) that this meaning is from xadaEa said of the Dab-i, and that the primary signification of xadoEN is the act of “concealing:” the action of the Db-, however, as will appear in what follows, implies, and originates from, a desire of deceit; and so, often, does the act of concealing.]
[Hence, app.,] xadaEotuhu I gained the mastery over him. (TA.)

xadaEa, (Lth, TA, &c.,) aor. _a {yaxodaEu}, inf. n. xadoEN, (TA,) said of a [lizard of the kind called] Dab-, [as though meaning either xadaEa AlmuHotariXa It deceived the hunter, or xadaEa nafosahu it concealed itself,] signifies it entered into its hole; (Lth;) as also xadaEa fiI Hujorihi: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it scented a man, and therefore entered its hole, in order that it might not be caught; as also AnxdE↓: (TA:) or it entered into its hole in a tortuous manner: and in like manner, a gazelle into its covert: but mostly said of a Db-: (Abu-l-ʼOmeythil:) also said of other things: (Lth:) of a fox, meaning he took to going to the right and left, deceitfully, or guilefully: and of a man, meaning he hid himself from another: and he assumed a disposition not his own. (TA.) [See also xidaAEN, below.]
Hence, i. e. from xadaEa said of the Db-, (A, TA,) xadaEato Eayonu AlX-amosi ‡ The disc of the sun set; (A, Ḳ, TA;) like xaDaEato. (TA in art. xDE.)
[And] xadaEato Eayonuhu ‡ His eye sank, or became depressed, in his head. (Lḥ, Ḳ, TA.) [Also meaning † His eye did not sleep: for] xadaEati AlEayonu signifies † the eye did not sleep. (TA.)

[Hence also, as indicated in the Ṣ,] maA xadaEato fiI EayoniI naEosapN † [A slumber did not enter my eye]: (Ṣ:) or maA xadaEato biEayonihi naEosapN, (so in the L,) or xadoEapN, i. e. naEosapN, (so in the TA,) meaning ‡ a slumber did not pass by his eye. (L, TA.) [And from the same source have originated several other tropical significations, of which exs. here follow.]
xadaEati AlOumuwri ‡ The affairs varied in their state; or were, or became, variable. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

xadaEati Als-uwqu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xadoEN, (TA,) ‡ [The market varied in its state; at one time being brisk, and at another time dull, in respect of traffic: (see xaAdiEN, below:) or] the market became dull in respect of traffic; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AnxdEt↓; (Lḥ, TA;) or AnxdE: (Ḳ: [but swq is generally fem.:]) and, as some say, it became brisk in respect of traffic: thus it appears to have two contr. significations: (TA:) and xadaEa Als-iEoru ‡ The price became high, or dear. (TA.)
Said of a man, xadaEa also signifies ‡ His wealth, (Ḳ, TA,) and the like, (TA,) became small in amount, or little. (Ḳ, TA.)
Said of a time, inf. n. xadoEN, ‡ Its rain became little: (TA:) and of rain, ‡ It became little. (Ḳ, TA.)

Said of spittle, or saliva, ‡ It dried: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or it became little, and dried, in the mouth: (A, TA.) or it became deficient; and when it becomes deficient, it becomes thick; and when it becomes thick, it becomes stinking: (TA:) or it became corrupt: (IAạr, TA:) and in like manner, said of a thing, it became corrupt, or bad. (TA.) [See also xaAdiEN, below.]
Said of a generous man, (Ḳ,) ‡ He refrained [from giving], (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and refused. (L.) You say, kaAna fulaAnN yuEoTiI vum-a xadaEa ‡ [Such a one used to give; then he refrained, and refused]. (Ṣ.)
xadaEahu aor. _a {yaxodaEu}, inf. n. xadoEN, He cut, or severed, his [vein called the] OaxodaE. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. xd-Ehu, inf. n. taxodiyEN: see 1, third sentence.

xud-iEa He was deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, repeatedly, so that he became experienced: or he was deceived,, &c., in war, time after time, so that he became skilful: or he became experienced in affairs: or he became experienced in affairs, sound in judgment, cunning, and guileful. (TA.)
3. xAdEhu, inf. n. muxaAdaEapN and xidaAEN: see 1, in five places.
muxaAdaEapN AlEayoni means The causing the eye to doubt respecting that which it sees. (Ḥam p. 541.)
xAdE Almajoda, (Aṣ, Ḳ,*) or AlHamoda, (AA,) a phrase used by Er-Rá'ee, (TA,) He forsook, or relinquished, (Aṣ, AA, Ḳ,) glory, (Aṣ,) or praise, not being worthy of it. (AA.)

hom.sense: 4. AxdEhu: see 1, first signification.

He incited him to deceive, delude, beguile, circumvent, or outwit; or to desire to do to another a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, without the latter's knowing whence it proceeded; or to pretend to another something different from that which was in his mind. (Ḳ.) In the Ḳur ii. 8, quoted above, Yaḥyà Ibn-Yaamar reads, wamaA yuxodiEuwna. (TA.)
5. txd-E He constrained himself to deceive, delude, beguile, circumvent, outwit, or the like. (Ḳ,* TA.)
txd-Ehu: see 1, third sentence.

entry.sense: 6. txAdEwA They deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, one another; or practised deceit, guile, circumvention, or the like, one to another. (TA.)

txAdE He pretended deceit, delusion, guile, or circumvention, (Ṣ,* P Ṣ,) on his part: (Ṣ:) or he pretended to be deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, not being so; (Ḳ, TA;) as also AnxdE↓. (TA.)

hom.sense: 7. AnxdE quasi-pass. of xadaEotuhu [i. e. He became deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) or he was content to be deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted. (Lth, Ḳ.)
See also 6.
See also 1, latter half, in two places.

entry.sense: 8. AxtdEhu; and yaxad-iEuwna, for yaxotadiEuwna: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places.
xidoEN: see xadiyEapN.
xadiEN: see xaAdiEN, in two places.

hom.sense: xadoEapN A single act of deceit, delusion, guile, circumvention, or outwitting. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., (Mgh, TA,) AlHarobu xadoEapN, and xudoEapN↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and xidoEapN↓, (Ḳ,) and xudaEapN↓, (AZ, Ks, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) accord. to different relaters; (Th, Mgh, Ḳ;) the first being the most chaste, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) said to be the form used by Moḥammad; (Th, Mgh, Mṣb;) the second ascribed by El-Khaṭṭábee to the vulgar; (TA;) the last the best in point of meaning: (Mgh:) i. e., accord. to the first reading, (Mgh,) War is finished by a single act of deceit,, &c.; (Mgh, O, Ḳ;) accord. to the second, war is a thing by which one is deceived; (Mgh, Mṣb;) or war is deceived; for when one of the two parties deceives the other, it is as though the war itself were deceived; (IAth, TA;) [accord. to the third, war is a mode, or manner, of deceiving;] and accord. to the fourth, war is a deceiver of those engaged in it (IAth, Mgh, TA) by the frequent deceits which occur therein. (Mgh.)
‡ A slumber. (TA.)

entry.sense: xudoEapN A thing by which, or with which, one deceives, deludes, beguiles, circumvents, or outwits; (Mgh, Mṣb;) like as luEobapN signifies “a thing with which one plays.” (Mṣb.) See xadoEapN.

One whom people deceive, delude, beguile, circumvent, or outwit, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) much; (Ḳ;) like as luEonapN signifies one “who is much cursed.” (TA.) [See, again, xadoEapN. The comparison of xudoEapN in one sense with luEobapN, and in another sense with luEonapN, suggests that one of the explanations above may perhaps be founded upon a mistranscription. On fuEolapN as the measure of a word having the sense of a pass. part. n., see a remark of IB voce laqaTN.]
See also xadiyEapN.
xidoEapN [A mode, or manner, of deceiving, deluding, beguiling, circumventing, or outwitting]: see xadoEapN.
xudaEapN: see xaAdiEN, in three places:
and see also xadoEapN.
