xidaAEu AlD-ab-i signifies The procedure of the [lizard called] Db- when it is attacked by a serpent, or hunted by a man feeling the head of its hole in order that it may imagine him to be a serpent: if the Db be experienced, it puts forth its tail to half the length of the hole, and if it feel a serpent, it strikes it, and cuts it in halves; and if it be a hunter, it does not suffer him to lay hold upon its tail, and so it escapes, for the hunter does not dare to put his hand into its hole, because it may not be free from a scorpion, of which he fears the sting, as a strong friendship subsists between the Db and the scorpion, and the former makes use of the latter to defend itself from the hunter: or, as some say, it signifies its concealing itself, and remaining long in its hole, and seldom appearing, and being very cautious. (O, TA.)
xaduwEN: see xaAdiEN, in three places.
Also † A she-camel that yields milk abundantly at one time, and withholds it at another. (Ḳ.)

xadiyEapN Deceit, delusion, guile, circumvention, or outwitting; and a desire to do to another a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, without the latter's knowing whence it proceeds; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a subst. from xadaEahu; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also xidoEN↓, (Mṣb, TA,) or this is an inf. n.; (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and xudoEapN↓; (TA;) and xidaAEN↓; (TA;) which [is also an inf. n. of xaAdaEahu, and] originally signifies concealment: (Ḥam p. 541:) [and hence as above: and] also signifies prevention (manoEN); and art, artifice, cunning, or skill, in the management of affairs; (IAạr, Ṣgh, Ḳ;) or a making another to resign, or relinquish, the object that he has in view, by pretending to him something the contrary of what he conceals. (Er-Rághib, B.)

xaAdiEN [Deceiving, deluding, beguiling, circumventing, outwitting, or the like;] act. part. n. of xadaEahu; as also xaduwEN↓; (Mṣb;) or [rather] this latter is an intensive epithet, signifying one who deceives,, &c., much, or often; or very deceitful,, &c.; or a great deceiver,, &c.; (Mgh, Ḳ;) and xad-aAEu↓, (Mṣb, TA,) and xadiEN↓, and xayodaEN↓; (TA;) [but these three are also intensive epithets, like xaduwEN;] and xudaEapN↓ signifies one who deceives,, &c., other men; (Ṣ;) or [rather] this last is syn. with xaduwEN as explained above, (Ḳ,) or xad-aAEN: (Mgh:) [the pl. of xaAdiEapN, fem. of xaAdiEN, is xawaAdiEu:] and the pl. of xaduwEN↓ is xuduEN. (Mgh.)
[Hence,] Dab-N xAdiEN A [lizard of the kind called] Db- that deceives, beguiles, or circumvents; (Z, TA;) as also xadiEN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And dahorN xaAdiEN and xudaEapN↓ † [Deceiving, or varying, and very deceitful, or very variable, fortune, or time]. (TA.) [Whence, or] because of its variableness, (TA,) AlxudaEapu↓ is ‡ a name for Fortune, or time. (Ḳ, TA.)
And fulaAnN xaAdiEu Alr-aOoIi ‡ Such a one remains not steadily in one opinion. (TA.)
And xuluqN xaAdiEN ‡ A varying, or variable, disposition. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

And suwqN xaAdiEapN ‡ A market varying, or variable, in its state; (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ;) at one time being brisk, and at another time dull, in respect of traffic: (A, TA:) or a market dull in respect of traffic: or a market in which one cannot obtain a thing because of its dearness. (TA.) xaAdiEN also signifies ‡ Anything unsaleable, or difficult of sale, and in little demand. (TA.) And accord. to Fr, the Benoo-Asad use the epithet muxaAdiEu↓ [perhaps a mistake for xaAdiEN] in the sense of ‡ High, or dear, applied to a price. (TA.)

And TariyqN xaAdiEN ‡ A road that appears at one time and disappears at another; as also xaduwEN↓: (Ḳ:) a road which one does not know: (TA:) a road deviating from the right course; (TA;) as also xayodaEN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) which one does not know. (Ṣ, TA.) And maMCN xaAdiEN ‡ A water to which one does not know the way. (TA.)

[Hence also,] sinuwna xawaAdiEu ‡ Years in which is little good; bad years: (Sh, TA:) and sinuwna xad-aAEapN↓ ‡ ‡ years in which is little increase: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) from xadaEa said of rain, or of spittle; and therefore doubly tropical: (TA:) or, as some say, years in which is much rain, and in which the produce is little. (Ṣgh.) xaAdiEN also signifies † Corrupt, or bad; applied to food and other things. (TA.) And you say, diynaArN xaAdiEN † A deficient, or defective, deenár. (Ṣ.) And rajulN xaAdiEN ‡ A man who brings evil upon others. (TA.)
xayodaEN: see xaAdiEN, first sentence. [Hence,] ‡ A wolf that acts deceitfully, or mischievously; or that practises artifice. (Z, Ṣgh, Ḳ. [In the CK, AlmuxotaAlu is erroneously put for AlmuHotaAlu.])
Also A person in whose love, or affection, no confidence is placed. (Ḳ.)
And hence, (TA,) AlxayodaEu is also applied to ‡ The mirage; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) accord. to some. (Ṣ.) You say, gar-ahumu AlxayodaEu ‡ The mirage deceived them. (TA.)
[For the same reason,] it is also applied to † The cat. (IB.)
And from the former of the last two meanings is derived the phrase (TA) guwlN xayodaEN (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) ‡ ‡ A very deceitful, or guileful, ghool; (Ḳ, TA;) so that it is doubly tropical. (TA.)
TariyqN xayodaEN: see xaAdiEN; in the latter part of the paragraph.
xaAdiEapN fem. of xaAdiEN [q. v.].
Also A small door in a large door. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
See also muxodaEN.

hom.sense: OaxodaEu [More, and most, deceitful, deluding, guileful, outwitting, or the like]. [Hence,] OaxodaEu mino Dab-K [More deceitful, or guileful, than a dabb]; a prov.; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a person over whom one has not power, by reason of deceit, or guile. (IAạr.) They said also, Uin-aka laOaxodiEu mino Dab-K HaraXotuhu [Verily thou art more deceitful, or guileful, than a dabb that I have hunted]. (AZ, AAF, O.) [See xidaAEN.]

AlOaxodaEu [app. Each of the two branches of the occipital artery which are distributed upon the occiput;] a certain vein, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) one of a pair of veins, called the OaxodaEaAni, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) in the cupping-place (Mgh, Mṣb) of the neck, (Mgh,) or in the place [of the application] of the two cupping-instruments; being a branch from the wariyd [or carotid artery]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) sometimes the scarification [for cupping] happens to be upon one of them, and the patient consequently is exhausted by loss of blood: (Ṣ:) the AxdEAn are two concealed veins in the place of the cupping of the neck: Lḥ says, they are two veins in the neck: some say that they are the wadajaAni, q. v.: (TA:) the pl. is OaxaAdiEu. (Ḳ.)
fulaAnN Xadiydu AlOaxodaEi means Such a one is strong in the place of the AxdE. (Aṣ, Ṣ, O.)
It also means † [Such a one is] a person who resists; unyielding; uncomplying. (TA.) And lay-inu AlOaxodaEu † One who does not resist; yielding; complying. (TA.)

You say also, lawaI fulaAnN OaxodaEahu ‡ Such a one turned away, or aside, and behaved proudly, or haughtily. (TA.)
And saw-aI OaxodaEahu ‡ He relinquished pride, or haughtiness. (TA.) And to him who is proud, one says, laOuqiyman-a OaxodaEayoka, meaning † I will assuredly dispel thy pride. (Ḥam p. 432.)

entry.sense: maxodaEN: see what next follows.

muxodaEN and mixodaEN↓ (Fr, Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maxodaEN↓; (Mṣb, TA;) the first of which is the original form, the second being adopted because the first was found to be difficult of utterance; (Fr, Yaạḳoob, Ṣ;) and the first is the only proper subst. of the measure mufoEalN; other words of that measure being epithets; (Sb;) A closet, or small chamber, in which a thing is kept, or preserved; (Mṣb;) i. q. xizaAnapN; (Fr, Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Ḳ;) by which is meant a small chamber within a large chamber: (TA:) from OaxodaEahu meaning “he hid it,” or “concealed it:” (Mṣb:) and [in like manner] xaAdiEapN↓ signifies a chamber within a chamber: (Ḳ:) Er-Rághib says, as though its builder made it a deceiver of him who might seek, or desire, to take, or reach, a thing in it. (TA.)
mixodaEN: see the next preceding paragraph.
muxad-aEN: see muxad-aEN, in two places.

hom.sense: maxoduwEN and muxad-aEN↓ are syn. [as signifying Deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, outwitted, or the like: or rather, the latter signifies much deceived,, &c.]. (TA.)

And [hence] ↓the latter, A man (Ṣ, L) Deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) in war, (Ṣ, L,) time after time, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) so that he has become experienced, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or so that he has become skilful: (L:) or experienced in affairs: (TA:) or experienced in affairs, sound in judgment, cunning and guileful: (ISh:) or characterized by deceit, delusion, guile, or circumvention, in war. (AO.)
Also the former, One whose [vein called the] OaxodaEu is cut, or severed. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: muxaAdiEN: see xaAdiEN.

1. xadula, inf. n. xadaAlapN [and app. xuduwlap also], He was, or became, large, and full [or plump], in the shank and fore arm. (TA.) [And in like manner, xadulato; or xadilato, inf. n. xadalN (q. v.); She (a woman) was, or became, full, or plump, in the shanks and fore arms.] And xadulato, inf. n. xadaAlapN [and xuduwlapN]; (JK;) or xadilato, [inf. n. xadalN;] (Ḳ;) said of the shank (Als-aAq, JK, Ḳ), It was, or became, round: (JK:) or full [or plump]. (Ḳ.)

xadolN Full [or plump]: and large, big, or bulky: (Ḳ:) or large, and full [or plump], in the shank and fore arm: or, as some say, large, big, or bulky. (TA.) You say AimoraOapN xadolapN and xadilapN↓ (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, by an omission, the latter is made to be xidolapN,]) A woman thick and round in the shank: pl. xidaAlN: [in the CK, erroneously, AaxodaAlN:] or full of flesh in the limbs, with slenderness of the bones; as also xadolaMCu↓ and xidolimN↓: (Ḳ:) or these two, in the latter of which the m is augmentative, a woman full [or plump] in the shanks and fore arms. (Ṣ.) And xadolapN Als-aAqi A woman round in the shank. (JK.) And maxaloxaluhaA xadolN Her place of the anklet [i. e. her ankle] is large, or big. (Ṣ.) And saAqN xadolapN A full [or plump] shank: (Ḳ:) or a round shank: pl. xidaAlN. (JK.)

xadalN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xadaAlapN↓ (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and xuduwlapN↓ (Ḳ) Fulness [or plumpness], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or roundness, (JK,) of the shank, (JK, Ḳ,) or of the shanks and fore arms. (Ṣ.) [All are properly inf. ns.: see 1.]
xadolapN fem. of xadolN [q. v.]. (JK, Ḳ.)
Also A grape that is small and worthless by reason of blight, or the like, and want of moisture. (AḤát, Ḳ * TA.)
And The stem of the tree called SaAb, (M, Ḳ,) which is a sort of bitter tree; (TA;) as also xudolapN↓. (M, Ḳ.)
xudolapN: see what next precedes.
xadilapN: see xadolN.
xadolaMCu: see xadolN.
xidolimN: see xadolN.
xadaAlapN: see xadalN.
xuduwlapN: see xadalN.

xadal-ajN Large, big, or bulky; (Mgh, Mṣb;) applied to the shank, (Mgh,) or to a man: (Mṣb:) or large, or big, in the shank, with a goodly fulness therein; applied to a female: (Lth, L:) or, with p {xadal-ajapN}, applied to a woman, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) juicy, (TA,) full in the fore arms and the shanks. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) You say xadal-aju Als-aAqayoni, meaning Large, or big, in respect of the shanks; like xadol. (Mgh, TA.)

1. xadamahu, aor. _u {yaxodumu} (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _i {yaxodimu}, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xidomapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xadomapN, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) or, as some say, the latter is the inf. n., and the former [though generally used as the inf. n.] is a simple subst., (TA,) He served him; did service for him; ministered to him; (PṢ, TA;) syn. mahanahu. (TA.) And xadama biTaEaAmi baTonihi [He served for, meaning in return for, the food of his belly]. (Ṣ and A, &c. in art. wgd.)

One says also, hecaA AlqamiySu yaxodumu sanapF ‡ [This shirt will serve, or last, a year]: and vawobN saxiyfN laA yaxodumu ‡ [A thin, or flimsy, garment, that will not serve or last, long; or that will not be serviceable]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 2. xd-mhu xidomapF He occupied, or busied, him with service. (TA.)
xad-amahaA He gave her several, or many, female servants. (Mṣb.)
[xd-m AlbaEiyra He attached a xadamap, meaning the thong thus called, upon the pastern of the camel.]

[Hence,] taxodiymN, [as inf. n. of xud-ima,] in a horse, † The having a whiteness (Ṣ, Mgh, TA) such as is termed taHojiyl (Ṣ, TA) surrounding the pastern of each kind foot, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA,) above the OaXaAEir [or extremities next the hoof], and stopping short of the shank; (Ṣ, TA;) but not in the fore foot. (Ṣ, Mgh, TA.) [See also xaAtamN, last sentence.] When it is in one hind leg, the horse is termed Oarojalu. (Ṣ, TA.)
[Hence, also,] xad-amahaA zawojuhaA † Her husband attired her with the xadamap [or anklet]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Axdmhu He gave him a servant. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA. [kaAxodamahu in the CK is erroneously put for faOaxodamahu.]) And OaxodamotuhaA I gave her a female servant. (Mṣb.)
El-Kutb Er-Ráwendee asserts that one says, Oaxodamotuhu linafosiI, peculiarly; [I made him a servant to myself;] but Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed says, This is of the things that I know not. (TA.) [See Axtdmhu.]

hom.sense: 8. Axtdm He served himself; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) as one must do who has not a servant. (Lḥ.)
Axtdmhu He made him a servant. (TA.)
See also what next follows {10}, in two places.

entry.sense: And Aisotaxodamotuhu I asked him to serve me; (Mṣb, TA;) as also Aixotadamotuhu↓: (TA:) [or I took him as my servant:] or I made him to serve me. (Mṣb) Accord. to El-Kutb Er-Ráwendee, one says, Aisotaxodamotuhu linafosiI and ligayoriI [I took him as a servant for myself and for another than myself: or I made him to be a servant to myself and to another than myself]. (TA.)

hom.sense: xadamN: see xaAdimN:
and see also xadamapN, in four places.

entry.sense: xadomapN, (Ḳ,) or xidomapN↓, (JK,) A space, or period, (saAEapN,) of the night (JK, Ḳ) or of the day: (Ḳ:) and xacomapN [or xicomapN, q. v.,] is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.)

xudomapN a subst. signifying † The characteristic denoted by the epithet xadomaMCu [fem. of Oaxodamu], in a sheep or goat; (JK, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. whiteness in the lower end of the shank. (JK, Ḳ,) upon blackness; (Ḳ;) such whiteness resembling the xadamap, (JK, TA,) or being likened to xadam, or anklets: (TA:) or blackness upon whiteness:, &c. (Ḳ.) [See Oaxodamu: and see also xadamapN.]

hom.sense: xidomapN, accord. to some, and inf. n. of 1: accord. to others, a simple subst. [signifying Service]. (TA.)
[Also Pay for service: but in this sense probably post-classical.]
See also xadomapN.

entry.sense:
xadamapN A thong, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) plaited, (TA,) thick and strong, like a ring, (JK, Ḳ,) which is fastened upon the pastern of a camel, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to which is attached the sariyHap [or thong] of the naEol [or leathern shoe with which the foot is sometimes protected], (Ṣ,) or to which are attached the saraAYiH [or thongs] of the nEl: (Ḳ:) [it is the n. un. of xadamN↓: and its pl. is xidaAmN; as below: in the TA, said to be tropical; but this is probably a mistake: the other significations here following are all tropical:]
accord. to AA, [the pl.] xidaAmN signifies shackles, or hobbles; syn. quyuwdN. (TA.)

Hence, (Ṣ,) ‡ i. q. xaloxaAlN [meaning An anklet]; (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) because sometimes made of thongs, with gold and silver affixed thereon: (Ṣ:) pl. xidaAmN, (Ṣ,) and [coll. gen. n.] xadamN↓. (Ḥam p. 612.) kaQlomamohuwrapK UiHodaI xadamatayohaA is a prov. [meaning † Like her who has been dowered with one of her two anklets]. (JK, TA. [See also mahomuwrapN.])

[And hence, † A ring of white a little above the hoof of a horse, &c.] You say of a horse, lahu xadamataAni mino xilaAfK, meaning † He has a whiteness [or rather a ring of white a little above the hoof] in his fore leg [or right fore leg] and another in his left fore leg [probably a mistake of a copyist for his left kind leg]. (TA in art. xlf.) [The coll. gen. n. xadamN↓ is used in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, as stated by Freytag, in the sense of † A place where the colour differs, like an anklet, on the foot: and a whiteness on the foot of a bull, surrounding it like a circle: and xidaAmN as meaning whiteness: or, as some say, streaks (“striæ”). See also xudomapN.]
[Hence, also,] † The place where each foot comes forth from the trousers. (TA.)

Also † The shank; (Ḳ;) because it is the place of the xadamap, i. e. the anklet: (TA:) pl. xidaAmN and [coll. gen. n.] xadamN↓. (Ḳ.) Hence, in a trad. of Selmán, kaAna EalaI HimaArK waEalayohi saraAwiylu waxadamatAhu tucabocibaAni [He was upon an ass, and upon him were trousers, and his shanks were dangling]: or, as some say, the meaning here is, the parts from which his two feet came forth, of the trousers. (TA.) And one says, Oabodati AlHarobu Eano xidaAmi Almuxad-araAti ‡ [The war made apparent the shanks, or the anklets, of the girls that had been kept behind the curtains]; meaning the war became vehement. (A, TA.)

Also † A ring of people; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a compact ring thereof: likened to the thong described in the first sentence of this paragraph. (TA.) Hence the saying of Khálid Ibn-El-Weleed, in a letter that he wrote to the Satraps of Persia, (TA,) AlHamodu lil-ehi Al-aciI faD-a xadamatakumo, meaning [Praise be to God,] who hath dispersed, or broken up, your congregation: (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA:) for when the thong above mentioned is broken, or parted, the saraAYiH [or thongs of the leathern shoe] become loosed, and the shoe falls off: so says IAth, and AʼObeyd says the like. (TA.)
xadimapN A thong: (Ḳ:) or a plaited thong. (TA.)
xaduwmN: see what next follows.

xad-aAmN One who does much service; (TA in the present art.;) as also xaduwmN↓. (TA in art. Eqrb.) And also applied to A xaAdim [q. v.]. (TA in the present art. [It is commonly used in the latter sense in the present day: fem. with p {xad-aAmapN}.])

xaAdimN A servant; (Ṣ,* Mgh,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA;) applied to a young man, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) or a male: (Ḳ:) and, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as also xaAdimapN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) each in chaste Arabic, (TA,) but the latter rare, (Mṣb,) to a young woman, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) or a female: (Ḳ:) and xad-aAmN [q. v.] is also used in the same sense as xaAdimN: (TA:) the pl. of xaAdimN is xadamN↓, (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or rather this is a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) and xud-aAmN (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xadamapN, and vulgarly xudomaAnN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., of ʼAbd-Er-Raḥmán, (TA,) Tal-aqa QmoraOatahu famat-aEahaA bixaAdimK sawodaMCa, meaning [He divorced his wife, and gave her on that occasion] a black young woman [as a slave]. (Mgh,* TA.) In the saying fulaAnapu xaAdimapu gadFA, the word xAdmp is not properly an epithet: the meaning is, Such a woman will be a servant to-morrow; like as one says HaAYiDapN gadFA. (Mṣb.)
[xaAdimiy-apN Servitude; or the state, or condition, of a servant: a term in common use; and mentioned by Freytag on the authority of Meyd.: opposed to maxoduwmiy-apN.]

Oaxodamu i. q. muxad-amu↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) as meaning, applied to a horse, ‡ Having a whiteness (Ṣ, Mgh) such as is termed taHojiyl (Ṣ) surrounding the pastern of each kind foot, (Ṣ Mgh,) above the parts next the hoof, and stopping short of the shank; (Ṣ;) but not in the fore foot: (Ṣ, Mgh: [see 2:]) or, so applied, whose taHojiyl encircles [the pastern] above the OaXaAEir [or extremities next the hoof]: or the latter epithet, so applied, whose whiteness passes beyond the pasterns or part thereof. (Ḳ.) And xadomaMCu, [fem. of Oaxodamu,] applied to a sheep or goat, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. to a XaAp, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) † Having in the lower end of her shank a whiteness (JK, Ḳ) like the xadamap [or anklet], (JK,) upon blackness; or a blackness upon whiteness; and in like manner applied to a mountain-goat: (Ḳ:) or having white shanks; (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) like HajolaMCu; [but see this latter word;] and so muxad-amN↓ applied to a mountain-goat: (Ṣ:) or having one white shank; the rest of her being black. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: muxad-amN [pass. part. n. of 2, q. v.]. You say qawomN muxad-amuwna A people, or party, having many servants and other dependents. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And in like manner muxad-amapN is applied to a woman. (A, TA.)
And muxad-amapN ‡ A woman attired, or adorned, with anklets. (A, TA.)
See also Oaxodamu, in two places.

And muxad-amN and muxad-amapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) The place of the thong [called xadamap] (Ḳ, TA) in the leg of the camel: (TA: [there said to be above the kaEob; but this is a mistake:]) and † the place of the anklet [so called] (Ḳ, TA) in the shank of a woman: (TA:) the place of the xidaAm in the shank: (Ṣ:) the place of the xadama; like as musaw-arN is the place of the siwaAr. (M in explanation of the former, in art. swr.)

And the former ‡ The band of the trousers, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) at the lower part of the leg of a woman: (Ḳ, TA:) or the band at the lower part of the leg of the trousers: (M, TA:) the woman seems to be specified in the Ḳ because women generally tic the legs of the trousers upon the middle [or upper part] of the shank, and then make them to fall down over it. (TA.)

entry.sense: muxad-amapN as a subst.: see muxad-amN; of which it is also the fem.
maxoduwmN [lit. Served:]
[and hence, A master;] a head, or chief: pl. maxaAdiymu. (TA.)
And A man having a servant of the jinn, or genii. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[maxoduwmiy-apN The state, or condition, of a master: opposed to xaAdimiy-apN.]

3. xAdnhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaAdanapN, (Mgh, TA,) He was, or became, his xidon [or friend; or his secret, or private, friend;, &c.]: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) he associated, or kept company, with him as a friend: (Mgh:) or [simply] he associated, or kept company, with him. (TA.)
muxaAdanapN also signifies The contracting of the eyes (Mgh, JM, TA) in holding amatory and enticing talk, or conversation, with another, the latter doing the same. (Mgh, JM.)

The saying of certain of the lawyers, (JM,) laA yajuwzu XahaAdapa SaAHib AlginaMCi Al-aciI yuxaAdinu Ealayohi means The testimony of the singer who has made singing to be his habitual occupation, or means of subsistence, and thereby associates as a xidon with people, and collects them to him, is not allowable. (Mgh, JM.)

xidonN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and xadiynN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) A friend: (Ṣ, TA:) or a secret, or private, friend; a friend in secrecy or privacy: (Mgh, Mṣb, and Ksh and Bḍ in iv. 29:) or a companion, or an associate, who converses, or talks, with one: (M, TA:) or [simply] a companion, or an associate: (Ḳ:) but accord. to Er-Rághib, mostly used as meaning an amorous companion or associate; a companion, or an associate, affected with sensual appetency: (TA:) the former is applied alike to the male and the female: (Ksh and Bḍ in v. 7:) and ↓the latter signifies also one who is thy friend,, &c., (mano yuxaAdinuka, Ḳ,) and who is with thee, (TA,) in every affair, or case, open and secret: (Ḳ:) pl. (of the former, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) OaxodaAnN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA) and [of the latter] xudanaMCu. (TA.) Hence, xidonu AljaAriyapi [The friend,, &c., of the girl]: (Ṣ:) or he who converses, or talks, with the girl. (JK.) It is said in the Ḳur [iv. 29], walaA mut-axicaAti OaxodaAnK, (Ṣ,) meaning [Nor taking to themselves] friends [or associates] to commit fornication with them in secret. (Jel.) xadiynu↓ AlEulaI is a metaphorical expression, used by a poet, [meaning ‡ Lover of eminence,] like EaXiyqu AlEulaI. (TA.)
xudanapN One who associates with men as their xidon [or friend, or secret friend,, &c.,] (yuxaAdinu Aln-aAsa) much. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
xadiynN: see xidonN, in three places.
Oaxodanu Having OaxodaAn [or friends, or secret friends,, &c.]. (TA.)

hom.sense:
Q. 1. xacorafa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xacorafapN, (TA,) He hastened, sped, or went quickly. (Ḳ.)
And xacorafato, said of a [wild] she-ass, She hastened, sped, or went quickly, and threw out her legs. (TA.) And, said of camels, They threw the pebbles with their feet by reason of quickness. (Ḳ.)
xacorafahu He cut off his (a man's) extremities with a sword. (Ḳ.)
He sharpened it; namely, a sword. (Ḳ.)
He filled it; namely, a vessel. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
Q. 2. taxacorafa It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became rent, or pierced with holes. (TA.)
taxacorafatohu Aln-awaI [The place which was the object of a journey] caused him to go forth, or depart; (L, Ḳ, TA;) as also taxacoramatohu. (TA.)
xacorafapN inf. n. of Q. 1.
Also Roundness of the legs of an animal, or quadruped. (TA.)
And A piece of a garment or cloth. (TA.)

entry.sense: xicoraAfN A certain plant of the spring, which dries up when it feels the [heat of] summer: (Lth, Ḳ:) or a species of the [kind called] HamoD, (AḤn, Ṣ, Ḳ,) having a small leaf, and rising to the height of a cubit: (AḤn:) the latter is said by Az to be the correct explanation: the former he disapproves: (TA:) n. un. with p {xicoraAfapN}. (Ṣ.)

xucoruwfN [A kind of whirling plaything;] a thing which a boy turns round by means of a thread, or string, in his hands, causing it to make a sound such as is termed dawiI-: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a small piece of wood, or a slit, or split, reed or cane, in the middle of which is cut a notch, and which is then tied with a thread, or string, which being pulled, it turns round, and is heard to make a sound such as is termed Hafiyf: boys play with it; and it is also called xar-aArapN: (Lth, TA: [in the latter of which, in art. xr, the xr-Arp is said to be a piece of wood like the half of a sandal, tied with a thread or string, which, being put in motion, draws along the piece of wood and causes it to make a sound:]) or a small, round, piece of skin, attached to which are two connected threads or strings, which being pulled by a boy, with his fingers, it turns round, causing a sound to be heard such as is termed dawiI-: (EM p. 43:) pl. xacaAriyfu. (Ṣ.) Imra-el-Ḳeys likens to it a swift horse: (Ṣ:) and it is applied as an epithet to a horse; (Lth;) meaning Swift in his running, (Lth, Ḳ, TA,) or in going. (TA.) And one says, tarakati Als-uyuwfu raOosahu xacaAriyfa, meaning † The swords made his head to be pieces, each piece like the xcrwf. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Clay kneaded, and made like sugar, (yuEomalu XabiyhFA biAls-uk-ari, in the CK yuEomalu mnhu XabiyhFA biAls-uk-uri, [the latter reading evidently wrong, and the former I think doubtful,]) with which boys play. (Ḳ.)
The piece of wood that is put [app. as a handle] in the hole of the upper millstone. (TA.)
A herd of camels: and one separate therefrom. (Ḳ.)
Lightning gleaming, or shining brightly, in the clouds, and separate therefrom. (Ḳ.)
Anything scattered from, or of, a thing. (L, O, Ḳ.)
The xacaAriyf of the hawodaj are The pieces of wood (saqaAYif) with which the hwdj is made of a square form. (Ḳ.) [See also daAmigapN.]
rajulN mutaxacorifN A man of good natural disposition. (TA.)

1. xacafa, (Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _i {yaxocifu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. xacofN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) trans. without a particle, (Mṣb,) and by means of bi, (Ṣ,) He threw a pebble, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or a datestone, (Mgh, Ḳ,) or the like, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with the fingers; (Ṣ;) or by taking it between his two fore fingers; (Mgh, Ḳ;) or with the extremity of the thumb and that of the fore finger, (Mgh, Mṣb,) by putting the extremity of the thumb upon that of the fore finger [and then jerking the latter forward]; (Mgh;) or with a mixocafap of wood. (Lth, Ḳ.) The doing this was forbidden by Moḥammad, because game cannot be taken thereby, nor an enemy defeated, but a tooth may be broken, and an eye put out. (TA.) HaSaI Alxacofi [properly] Pebbles that are thrown [in the manner described above], (Mṣb,) is used as meaning ‡ small pebbles. (Mṣb, TA.)
[Hence,] xacafa bibawolihi He emitted his urine and then stopped it. (TA.)
And xacofu Aln-uTofapi The emitting of the sperma genitale into the midst of the womb. (TA.)
And xacafa bihaA, aor. and inf. n. as above, † He broke wind with a sound. (TA.)
And Alxacofu The hastening, speeding, or going quickly, of camels. (TA. [See also xacafaAnN.])
And The act of cutting, or cutting off. (Kr, TA.)
6. [taxaAcafaA app. signifies They vied with each other in throwing in the manner described in the first sentence above.]
[And hence,] EayonaAhu taxaAcafataA biAld-amoEi ‡ i. q. AsrtA [app. a mistranscription for OajorataAhu, i. e. His eyes shed tears]: so in the A. (TA.)
xacafaAnN A certain pace, or manner of going, of camels. (ʼEyn, T, Ḳ. [See also 1, last sentence but one.])
xacuwfN A horse or the like (Lth) quick in pace. (Lth, Ḳ.)

A she-ass that throws the pebbles by reason of her quickness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or whose navel is near to the ground by reason of her fatness: (Ḳ:) or so fat that, if a pebble is thrown at her with the fingers, or with two fore fingers, or with the extremity of the thumb and that of the fore finger, it sinks into her fat: (Z:) and that raises her legs to the side of her belly: (TA:) pl. xucufN. (Aṣ, TA.)
Alxac-aAfapu † The anus; syn. AlAisotu; (TA;) as also Almixocafapu↓. (Ḳ.)
mixocafN The loops of the miqoran [q. v.] with which the [quiver termed] kinaAnap is connected with the [case termed] jaEobap: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) pl. maxaAcifu. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)

mixocafapN A kind of sling; syn. miqolaAEN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a thing with which one throws: (Ṣ:) or it signifies also a wooden instrument with which one throws in the manner termed xacofN: (Ḳ:) or a thing into which stones are put, and with which they are thrown at birds, &c., like a miqolaAE. (ISd.) [In the TA in art. dv, it is said (in my opinion erroneously) to signify a bullet.]
See also Alxac-aAfapu.

1. xacalahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and xacala Eanohu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxoculu}, (JK, Mṣb,) inf. n. xicolaAnN (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and xacolN, (JK, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) or xicolaAnN↓ is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) and Axclhu↓; (TA;) He abstained from, or neglected, aiding him, or assisting him; (JK,* Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and held back from him: (Mṣb:) and xacalahu he left, forsook, or deserted, him: (MA:) and, accord. to AZ, xacala Eanohu, aor. _u {yaxoculu}, inf. n. xucuwlN, he left him, and held back from going with him. (T in art. tlw.) And xicolaAnN↓ signifies God's failing to preserve a man; accord. to Az, from an evil action; so that he falls into it. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [iii. 154], waUino yaxoculokumo famano caA Ql-aciI yanoSurukumo mino baEodihi [But if He fail to aid you, or to preserve you, then who is he that will aid you after Him?]: here ʼObeyd Ibn-ʼOmeyr read yuxodilokumo↓, with damm to the I and kesr to the c. (TA.)

And xacala He (a gazelle) held back from going with the herd; or remained behind the herd. (Aṣ, Ṣ.) And xacalato She (a gazelle, &c., Ḳ, as, for instance, a [wild] cow, TA) held back from going with her female companions, and remained alone: or held back, or remained behind, not overtaking [the others]: (Ḳ:) or you say, of a female gazelle, and of a [wild] cow, taxoculu SawaAHibaAtihaA She holds back from going with her female companions, or remains behind them, with her young one, in the place of pasturage: or remains alone with him; as AʼObeyd says, on the authority of Aṣ. (T, TA.) And xacalato She (a wild animal, Ṣ, O, or a gazelle, Ḳ) remained attending to her young one [when the rest of the herd had gone]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) said by some to be inverted [as to the meaning], because she is [not the one that leaves, but] the one that is left; (Ṣ;) as also txAclt↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Axclt↓. (Ḳ.)

A poet says, (namely, 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, TA,) describing a horse,
fahowa kaAld-alowi bikaf-i AlmusotaqiI
xacalato Eanohu AlEaraAqiI faQnojacamo
meaning [And he is, or was, like the bucket in the hand of the drawer of water,] of which the cross pieces of wood have become separated from it [so that it has become severed from the wellrope]. (Ṣ.)

2. xc-lhu, inf. n. taxociylN, He incited him, or induced him, to abstain from, or to neglect, aiding him, or assisting him; and hindered him, withheld him, or prevented him, from aiding his companion, or assisting him. (T, TA.) And xc-l Eanohu OaSoHaAbahu, inf. n. as above, He incited, or induced, his companions to abstain from, or to neglect, aiding him, or assisting him. (Ṣ.)
He induced him to be cowardly and weak-hearted, and to abstain from fighting. (Mṣb.)
4: see 1, in three places.

Also Axcl, (Ḳ,) or Axcl Oum-ahu, (T, TA,) said of the young one of a wild animal, (Ḳ,) or of the young one of a gazelle or [wild] cow, (T,) means wajada Oum-ahu taxoculuhu (Ḳ, TA) [which may be rendered He found his mother to hold back from him; or to leave him, and hold back from going with him: or it means] he found his mother to hold back from going with her female companions, or to remain behind them, with him; or to remain alone with him. (T.)

6. txAclwa They abstained from, or neglected, aiding, or assisting, one another: (Ṣ:) i. q. tdAbrwA [which has the foregoing signification accord. to the TA, but properly means they turned their backs, one upon another]: (Ḳ:) they left, forsook, or deserted, one another in trouble. (MA.) [And, accord. to Freytag's Lex., They fled from fight, or battle.]
txAclt rijolaAhu (said of an old man, TA) His legs became weak (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) in consequence of some evil affection. (TA.)
And txAcl He was, or became, behind. (KL.)
See also 1.
[7. AnxclwA, accord. to Freytag's Lex., They were destitute of aid, or assistance: they fled.]

xucalapN A man constantly abstaining from, or neglecting, the rendering of aid, or assistance. (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ.* [In the Ḳ, this is not distinguished from xaAcilN in the first of the senses assigned to this latter below. See also xacuwlN.])
xicolaAnN: see 1, in two places.

xacuwlN One who often abstains from, or neglects, the rendering of aid, or assistance: so in the Ḳur xxv. 31, applied to the Devil; (TA;) because he forsakes the unbeliever, and declares himself to be clear of him, on the occasion of trial, or affliction. (Jel.)
See also xaAcilN.
Also A mare that, when suffering from the pain of parturition, moves not from her place. (ISd, Ḳ.)
xacuwlu Alr-ijoli A man whose leg aids him not, in consequence of weakness, (Ṣ,* TA,) or of some evil affection, or of intoxication. (TA.)
xaAcilN Abstaining from, or neglecting, the rendering of aid, or assistance. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And Any one leaving, forsaking, or deserting. (TA.)

Also, and xacuwlN↓, (T, Ḳ,) A female gazelle, and a [wild] cow, holding back from going with her female companions, or remaining behind them, with her young one, in the place of pasturage: or remaining alone with him: (T:) or a female gazelle, &c., (Ḳ,) as, for instance, a [wild] cow, (TA,) holding back from going with her female companions, and remaining alone: or holding back, or remaining behind, not overtaking [the others]: (Ḳ:) or the latter signifies a female gazelle that has left, forsaken, or deserted, her young ones. (EM p. 60.)
Also Routed, defeated, or put to flight. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
muxocilN: see the next preceding paragraph.
maxocuwlN Having no aider, or assister. (Jel in xvii. 23.)

hom.sense: 1. xacamahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxocimu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xacomN, (JK, Ṣ, TA,) He cut it, or cut it off: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he did so quickly: (JK, Z, TA:) and xc-mhu↓ and txc-mhu↓ signify the same: (Ḳ:) or ↓the second, inf. n. taxociymN, he cut it in pieces; (Ṣ, in which only the inf. n. is mentioned;) and so ↓the third. (TA.) [It is like jacamahu.] Hence, in a trad., xacamuwA biAls-uyuwfi, said of men stopping the road, and robbing and slaying passengers, They cut, and smote, men with the swords. (TA.) And xacama lahu mino maAlihi xicomapF He cut off for him a portion of his property. (JK.)
Also, said of a hawk, He struck him, or it, with his talon, or claw. (IAạr, Ḳ.*)

xacima, aor. _a {yaxocamu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xacomN, (TḲ, [as indicated in the Ḳ by its being said that the verb is like samiEa,]) It became cut, or cut off; as also txc-m↓: (Ḳ:) [or] the latter is quasi-pass. of xac-amahu [and therefore signifies it became cut in pieces]. (TA.) And xacimati Aln-aEolu The [thong called] XisoE [q. v.] of the sandal became cut, or severed. (TA.)

xacima, aor. _a {yaxocamu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xacamN (Ṣ, TA) [and app. xacamaAnN, q. v. infrà]; or xacama, [so in the JK, which may be also correct, agreeably with the primary signification of this verb, though the aor. is there said to be _a, which may perhaps be a mistranscription for _i,] inf. n. xacomN [there mentioned in two places] and xacamN; (JK;) ‡ He was quick (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) in pace, or rate of going; (JK, Ṣ, TA;) as also Axcm↓. (JK. [But this last may be erroneously taken from the phrase mar-a muxocimFA, there immediately following; for this phrase may be mistranscribed for mar-a yaxocamu, which I find in the TA.])
[And hence,] xacamN signifies also † [The being liberal, or bountiful; (see the part. n. xacimN;) or] the giving a gift, or making a present. (KL.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence, in two places.

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in the latter part.
Axcm Aln-aEola He repaired the [thong called] XisoE of the sandal. (AA, TA.) [Here, as in many other instances, the A has a privative effect: see xacimati Aln-aEolu, above.]
5. as an intrans. v.: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph:
as a trans. v.: see 1, first sentence, in two places.

entry.sense: 8. AixotacaAmN, [accord. to some, seems to signify The cutting off a thing for oneself:] accord. to some, Tiybu Aln-afosi [as meaning the being pleased, content, or willing: see xacimN]. (Ḥam p. 703, q. v.)

xacimN A cutting, or sharp, sword; (Ḳ;) as also xacuwmN↓ (JK, Ḳ) and mixocamN↓; (JK, T, Ṣ, ISd, TA;) the last erroneously said in the Ḳ to be like muEaZ-amN. (TA.) One of the swords of Moḥammad was named Almixocamu↓: it was formerly the sword of El-Hárith El-Ghassánee. (TA.)

A garment, or piece of cloth, altogether, or wholly, old and worn out. (TA.) [And in like manner, accord. to Freytag (who does not name his authority), xacuwmN↓, applied to a scabbard of a sword, Lacerated and worn by use.]
‡ Quick, or swift of pace, applied to a horse; (JK, Ṣ;) and so xacuwmN↓, applied to an ostrich. (Ṣ.)

[And hence.] ‡ A man (JK, Ṣ) liberal, or bountiful, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in giving; (Ṣ;) pleased, content, or willing, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) to be liberal or bountiful; plenteous in gifts: (TA:) pl. xacimuwna: (JK, Ḳ:) it has no broken pl. (TA.)
xacomapN A snatching away; a snatch: and a stroke, or blow. (TA.)

A certain mark (simapN) of camels: (JK, Ḳ:) an Islámee term: (Ḳ:) a certain mark of sheep or goats, (JK, T, TA,) being a slit across the ear, (T, TA,) which leaves the ear dried up. (JK, T, TA. [See xacomaMCu.])
Also, [or xicomapN, q. v.,] A space, or period, syn. saAEapN, (Ḳ,) [of the night, or of the day:] and xadomapN [or xidomapN] is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.)
xicomapN [like jicomapN] A piece cut off of a garment. (JK. [See also xucaAmapN.]) A portion cut off from property. (JK.) A portion of the night. (JK. [See also xacomapN.])
A company of men. (JK. [But perhaps this may be a mistake for xadamapN.])

xacomaMCu A sheep or goat, (XaApN, JK, Ḳ,) or a she-goat, (Ṣ,) having the mark in the ear termed xacomapN; (JK;) [i. e.] having the ear slit across, without its being separated: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a ewe having the extremity of her ear cut off. (T, TA.)
xacamaAnN [app. an inf. n. of xacima] Quickness of pace, or of rate of going. (TA.)
xacuwmN: see xacimN, in three places.
OucunN xaciymN An ear cut, or cut off: (Ḳ:) pl. xucumN. (TA.)
xucaAmapN A piece cut off. (JK, Ḳ. [See also xicomapN.])
mixocamN: see xacimN, in two places.

1. xar-a, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoriru} (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and _u {yaxoruru}, (M, Ḳ,) [the latter of which is anomalous,] inf. n. xariyrN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It (water) sounded; [i. e., murmured; rumbled; or gurgled;] (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also xaroxara↓, (A,) inf. n. xaroxarapN: (TA:) or xar-a,, aor. _i {yaxoriru}, (IAạr, T,) inf. n. xar-N, (IAạr,) it (water) ran vehemently [so as to make a noise: as used in the present day, it ran, flowed, or trickled down; and leaked, or oozed, out: and also it ran so as to make a murmuring, or similar, sound]: (IAạr, T:) and xur-a it was made to run: (TA: but the subject of this verb is not mentioned.) And xar-ato, (A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoriru} and _u, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xariyrN, It (the wind, Alr-iyHu) sounded; [i. e., murmured; rumbled; or rustled;] (A, Ḳ;) among reeds or canes; as also xaroxarato↓, (A,) inf. n. as above: (TA:) or the latter signifies it made a quick xariyr [or rustling] among reeds or canes or the like. (Lth.)
Also It (an eagle, EuqaAb) made a rustling (Hafiyf) with its wings, in flying. (Lth, Ḳ.) And xar-a, (Ṣ,) inf. n. xariyrN, (Ḳ,) He (a man sleeping) snored, or made a sound in breathing; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) as also xaroxara↓, (Ṣ,) inf. n. xaroxarapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the latter, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) has the same signification when said of a leopard (Ḳ,* TA) in his sleep; (TA;) as also the former, inf. n. as above; (TA;) and when said of a cat; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also the former, (TA,) inf. n. xuruwrN (so in the CK and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, but in the text of the Ḳ in the TA, xaruwrN,) and xariyrN; (TA;) [i. e. he made a loud purring in his sleep;] and it is likewise significant of the sound, or sounds, made by a person suffering strangulation. (Ṣ, TA: but of the verb applied in this last manner, only the inf. n., xaroxarapN, is mentioned.) And xar-a, aor. _u {yaxoruru}, It (a stone) made a sound in its descent. (TA.)

[Hence,] xar-a, aor. _i {yaxoriru} (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u, (Ḳ,) the latter of which is anomalous, (TA,) inf. n. xuruwrN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xar-N, (Ḳ,) He, or it, fell, or fell down: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) originally, he, or it, fell, making a sound to be heard at the same time: afterwards used in the sense of falling absolutely: you say xar-a AlbinaMCu The building fell down: (TA:) and xar-a lil-ehi saAjidFA He fell down prostrating himself to God: (Ṣ, A,* TA:) or xar-a signifies He, or it, fell from a high to a low place: (Ḳ, TA:) so in the Ḳur [xxii. 32], fakaOan-amaA xar-amina Als-amaMCi [He is as though he fell from the shy]. (A,* TA.) And xar-uwA liOacoqaAnihimo, inf. n. xuruwrN, [They fell down prostrate, with their chins to the ground: see the Ḳur xvii. 108 and 109:] (A:) [whence the saying,] EaSafato riyHu faxar-ati AlOaXojaAru liloOacoqaAni ‡ [A wind blew violently, so that the trees fell, or bent themselves, down to the ground]. (A.)
You say also, xar-a, (TA,) inf. n. xar-N, (Ḳ,) meaning † He died: (Ḳ, TA:) because a man, when he dies, falls down. (TA.) In the Ḳur xxxiv. 13, it may mean † He died, or he fell down. (TA.)
Also (xar-a) He stumbled after going right. (TA.)
And xar-ato xaTaAyaAhu † His sins fell; [or fell from him; q. d. fell to the ground;] went away; or departed. (TA, from a trad.)
And xar-a mina Aljabali, inf. n. xuruwrN, He, (a man,) and it, (a stone, &c.,) rolled down from the mountain. (TA.)
And AlOaEoraAbu yaxir-uwna mina AlbawaAdiI AlquraI ‡ The Arabs of the desert come down, or descend, from the deserts to the towns or villages. (A.)
And xar-uwA EalayonaA, (TA,) inf. n. xar-N, (Ḳ,) † They came upon us suddenly, or unawares, from a place unknown. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And xar-uwA † They came from one town, or country, or the like, to another. (TA.)
And † They passed along, or away, or by. (TA.)

xararota Eano yadayoka, or mino yadayoki, is a metonymical phrase, well known, meaning ‡ Mayest thou be confounded and stupified by shame; or, so as to be speechless and motionless: xrrt [properly] signifying saqaTota. (TA in the present art. and in art. Arb.)
4. Axr- yadahu He made his arm, or hand, to fall, by a stroke of the sword. (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
7. Anxr- He, (a man, TḲ,) or it, (the belly, TḲ,) became lax, or flabby. (Ḳ, TḲ.) [See also R. Q. 2.]
R. Q. 1: see 1, in three places.
R. Q. 2. taxaroxara It (a man's belly) quivered, or shook about, with bigness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or by reason of leanness. (TA.) [See also 7.]
xur-N and xur-iI-N↓ The luhowap of a mill or mill-stone; i. e. the place into which the wheat is thrown with the hand; (Ṣ;) the mouth of a mill or millstone. (Ḳ.)
hir-apN xaruwrN A she-cat that makes much loud breathing or purring (xariyr) in her sleep. (TA.)

xariyrN A depressed tract between two hills, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) stretching along: (Ṣ:) pl. Oaxir-apN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The pl. occurs in a verse of Lebeed, commencing biOaxir-api Alv-alabuwti, as Khalaf El-Aḥmar heard the Arabs recite it: so says AʼObeyd: (Ṣ:) but the common reading is biOaHiz-ap, with H and z. (TA.)
xur-iI-N: see xur-N.

EayonN xar-aArapN A sounding [i. e. murmuring or gurgling] spring or source: (Ṣ:) or a running spring or source: so called because of the sound of its water: (IAạr:) or a spring, or source, welling forth abundantly. (Mṣb.)
See also xaAr-N.
xaroxarN The sound of water: and of wind: and of an eagle making a rustling with its wings in flying. (Ḳ.) [See 1.]
xaroxaArN Water flowing (Ḳ) vehemently, (TA,) or copiously. (Ḥam p. 821.)
xaAr-N part. n. of 1. (TA.)

1. xariYa, aor. _a {yaxoraOu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaraMCapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and xiraMCapN↓, (Ḳ,) which is the more chaste form, (O,) or this may be a quasi-inf. n., (El-Khaṭṭábee, Mṣb,) and, accord. to some, xiraMCN↓, (MF,) or this is a quasi-inf. n., (Lth,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* MF,) like SiyaAmN for SawomN, or, as some say, a pl. of xaroCN, (Mṣb, MF,) and xaroCN also is an inf. n., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and xuruwoCN, (Ḳ, TA,) like quEuwdN, (TA,) or xuruwoCapN, (so in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ and in the CK,) He voided his excrement, or ordure: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or xiraMCapN signifies the retiring alone, and sitting down, to satisfy a want [of nature]. (IAth.)
xaroCN: see what next follows.

xuroCN Human excrement, or ordure: (Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also xaroCN↓: (Mṣb, TA:) and sometimes applied to the dung of the dog, and of the field-rat, and of the ant, and of the fly: (TA:) pl. xuruwoCN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is also a pl. of xaroCN, (Mṣb, TA,) and xuroMnN, (Ḳ,) which is anomalous, and xuruWN; (TA;) and some say that xiraMCN is a pl. of xaroCN. (Mṣb, MF.)
xiraMCN: see 1.
xiraMCapN: see 1.
xaAriYN act. part. n. of 1. (TA.)

maxoraOapN A place where excrement, or ordure, is voided; [a privy;] (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also maxoraApN, (Ḳ,) and maxoruWapN↓; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) the last written in some copies of the Ḳ maxoriYapN; and in one, mixoraOapN. (TA.)
maxoruWapN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: 1. xariba, (JK, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, &c.,) aor. _a {yaxorabu}, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaraAbN, (JK, Ṣ,* A, Mgh,* Mṣb, KL, TA,) said of a place, (Ṣ,) or a country, (A, Mgh,*) or a dwelling, or place of abode, (Mṣb,) or a house, (TḲ,) It was, or became, in a state of ruin, waste, uninhabited, depopulated, deserted, desolate, uncultivated, or in a state the contrary of flourishing: (JK, Ṣ, A, Mgh, KL, TA:) xaraAbN is the contr. of EimaArapN. (Ṣ.)
xariba, aor. _a {yaxorabu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xarabN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It had in it a slit, or a round perforation: (Ṣ:) or he had his ear slit, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or bored with a round perforation. (Mṣb.)
xaraba: see 4.

Also, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxorubu}, inf. n. xiraAbapN, (Mṣb,) He stole: (Mṣb:) or he became a thief, or robber. (Ḳ.) And xaraba Uibila fulaAnK, (Ṣ, A,*) or xaraba biUibili fulaAnK, (Ḳ,) both mentioned as on the authority of Lḥ, (TA,) aor. _u {yaxorubu}, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. xiraAbapN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and xaraAbapN and xarobN and xuruwbN, (Ḳ,) He stole the camels of such a one. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And He struck his xurobapN, (Ḳ,) meaning the part where the head of his thigh-bone was inserted; or xrbp here has some other of the significations assigned to it in this article. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 4, in four places.

4. Axrb, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UixoraAbN, (TA,) He reduced to ruin; or rendered waste, uninhabited, depopulated, deserted, desolate, uncultivated, or in a state the contrary of flourishing; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) a house, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a dwelling, or place of abode, (Mṣb,) or a country; (A;) as also xr-b↓, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxoriybN; (TA;) and xaraba↓, (Ḳ,) [inf. n. xaraAbN, as in the Ḳur ii. 108:] or xr-b↓ signifies the same, but in a more extensive, or a superlative or an intensive sense: you say, xar-abuwA buyuwtahumo [They ruined their houses; the r being doubled because the verb has many objects: or they demolished their houses]. (Ṣ, TA.) yuxar-ibuwna↓ buyuwtahumo, in the Ḳur [lix. 2], means They demolishing their houses: this is the reading of AA:
all others read yuxoribuwna bywthm, meaning they going forth from their houses, and leaving them; (TA;) or evacuating their houses; or leaving them in a state of ruin. (Bḍ.)
[Hence the saying,] Einodahu tuxar-abu↓ AlOamaAnaAtu ‡ [Deposits entrusted to him become lost, or perish]. (A.)
5. txr-b It (a building) became demolished. (TA.)
10. Astxrb It (a skin for water or milk) became perforated with many holes; became full of holes. (A, TA.)
† He became broken by misfortune. (JK, Ḳ.)
Aisotaxorabotu lihecaA AlOamori † I lamented for this event, or case. (JK.)

Astxrb Uilayohi † He was angry with him; or was angry with him with the anger that proceeds from a friend; (wajada Ealayohi;) namely, one who had separated himself from him: (JK:) or he yearned towards, longed for, or desired, him. (Ḳ.)

Q. Q. 1. naxoraba [in the CK, erroneously, taxar-aba,] It (the canker-worm) corroded a tree: (Ḳ, TA:) but accord. to some, this verb is [radically] quadriliteral, and as such it occurs again in the Ḳ [in art. nxrb]. (TA.)

hom.sense: xarobN: see xurobapN, in five places:
and see also xarabN.
xurobN: see xurobapN, in seven places.
Also The place where an elevated accumulation of sand terminates, (JK, Ṣ,* TA,) producing trees of the kind called gaDFA. (TA.)
xarabN The male of the [species of bustard called] HubaAraI: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or i. q. HubaAraI, absolutely: (TA:) pl. xirobaAnN. (Ṣ.)
And hence, (A,) or xaribN↓, (JK,) or xarobN↓, (TA,) and xirib-aAnN↓, (Ḳ,) ‡ Cowardly; or a coward. (A, Ḳ, TA.)
See also xurobapN, near the end of the paragraph.

xaribN (Ṣ, TA) and xaraAbN↓ (A, Mṣb) In a state of ruin, waste, uninhabited, depopulated, deserted, desolate, uncultivated, or in a state the contrary of flourishing; (Ṣ, A, TA;) applied to a place, (Ṣ,) or a country, (A,) or a dwelling, or place of abode. (Mṣb.) You say daArN xaribapN A house which its owner has reduced to ruin, or rendered uninhabited,, &c. (Ṣ, TA.) [In the phrase, hecaA juHoru Dab-K xaribK, meaning This is a deserted hole of a lizard of the kind called dabb, the word xrb is put in the gen. case EalaI AljiwaAri, i. e. because of its proximity to a preceding word in that case, not being so properly.]
[Hence,] huwa xaribu AlEaZomi ‡ [He is without marrow in the bone]. (A, TA.) And xaribu AlOamaAnapi ‡ [One in whom trust is not safely reposed]. (A, TA.)
See also xaraAbN.
And see xarabN.
xarobapN see the next paragraph, in two places.
See also xirobapN.

xurobapN A hole, perforation, or bore; (Mṣb, TA;) whether round or not: (TA:) or any round hole or perforation or bore; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) such as that of the ear; (TA;) [and] so xurobN↓: (A:) pl. [of mult.] of the former (in this and in other senses here following, Ḳ,* TA) xurabN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and xuruwbN, which latter is extr. [with respect to rule], and [of pauc.] OaxoraAbN [which is irregular as pl. of the former, but regular as pl. of the latter]. (Ḳ. [See also xurotN and xurotapN.]) [Hence,] xurobapN Als-inodiI-i The bore of the lobe of the ear, when not slit: [the Sindee being particularly noted by the Arabs for his pierced ears:] when slit, it is termed xarobapN↓ Als-inodiI-i. (TA.)
Width of the hole, or perforation, of the ear; (JK;) as also xarobN↓, (JK,) or xurobN↓, (A,) and OaxorabN↓, (Ḳ,) this last being a subst. like OafokalN. (TA.)

The eye of a needle: [like xurotN and xurotapN:] and the foramen of the anus: as also xurobN↓ and xarobN↓ and xar-aAbapN↓ and xur-aAbapN↓ and xuraAbapN↓; (Ḳ, MF;) in both of these senses, though this is not clearly shown in the Ḳ: (MF:) and likewise, of the vagina; the dual of xurobapN occurring in a trad., as some relate it, applied to the foramen of the anus and that of the vagina together: (TA:) and the last, xuraAbapN↓, also signifies any perforation like the eye of a needle. (Ḳ.)

Alxurobapu and Alxurobu↓ and AlxuraAbapu↓ and Alxur-aAbapu↓ The hole [or socket] of the hip, (Ṣ, TA,) where the head of the thigh-bone is inserted; as also xurobapu Alwariki and xurobu↓ Alwrk and xarobu↓ Alwrk and xaraAbapu↓ Alwrk [or, probably, xuraAbap↓] and xur-aAbapu↓ Alwrk and xar-aAbapu↓ Alwrk: and the pl., OaxoraAbN, also signifies the lower extremities of the shoulder-blades. (TA.)

And Alxurobapu, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or xurobapu AlmazaAdap, (A,) and Alxur-aAbap↓, and sometimes AlxuraAbap↓ without teshdeed, (TA,) [and perhaps Alxurobu↓ also, (see xubonN,)] The loop of the [leathern water-bag called] mazaAdap; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because of its round form: every mzAdp having two loops [whereby it is suspended upon either side of the camel], each of which is thus called; and two kidney-shaped pieces of leather (kuloyataAni) [at the two upper corners]; and the two loops are sewed to these. (TA. [See also xurotapN.])

A vice, or fault; (IAth, TA;) as also xarabapN↓: (Ḳ:) and corruption, or unsoundness, in religion; (JK, Ḳ;) as also xarabapN↓ (JK, TA) and xarobapN↓ [like HarobapN] (Mgh,* Ḳ) and xurobN↓ and xarobN↓ (Ḳ) and xarabN↓: and a quality inducing suspicion, or evil opinion: [a meaning app. belonging to all of the foregoing words:] (TA:) pl., of the first, xurubaAtN; and of the second, xarabaAtN: (JK:) also, the first (i. e. xurobapN), a crime: a bad, an evil, or a foul, word or saying: and a trial, or an affliction. (TA.) You say, maA fiyhi xurobapN There is not in him a vice, or fault. (TA.) And maA raOayonaA mino fulaAnK xurobapF (JK, TA) and xarobFA↓, (TA,) or xarabapF↓, (JK,) We have not seen in such a one unsoundness of religion nor anything disgraceful. (JK, TA.)
faAr-N bixurobapK, occurring in a trad., means One who flees with a thing desiring to appropriate it to himself and to take possession of it unlawfully. (TA.)
xirobapN: see xaraAbN, in three places.

Also The state, or condition, or guise, of him who is termed xaAribN: (Ḳ:) also explained as signifying a thing whereof one is ashamed: or as derived from [xarabapN, meaning] “contemptibleness, and disgrace, or ignominy:” or it may be xarobapN↓, meaning a single act [of a shamefal nature, or the like]. (Et-Tirmidhee, TA.)

entry.sense: xarabapN: see xurobapN, in three places, near the end of the paragraph.
Also i. q. cil-apN [Baseness, vileness,, &c.]: (Ḳ, TA:) in one copy of the Ḳ, zal-apN [a slip, lapse, fault,, &c.]: (TA:) and disgrace, or ignominy, and contemptibleness. (TA.)
And AlxarabapN signifies AlEaworapu [The part, or parts, of the person, which it is indecent to expose]. (Ḳ.)
xaribapN and its pls.: see xaraAbN, in five places.
xirib-aAnN: see xarabN.

hom.sense: xaraAbN inf. n. of xariba in the first of the senses explained above. (JK, Ṣ,* A, &c. [See 1, first sentence.])
[Then used as an epithet:] see xaribN.

[And then used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, as appears from what follows;] contr. of EumoraAnN: (JK, A, Ḳ:) and xaribapN↓ signifies [the same; or] mawoDiEu xaraAbK; (A, Ḳ;) as also xirobapN↓: (Lth, Ḳ:) [all may be rendered A ruin, or waste; a place, country, place of abode, or house, in a state of ruin, waste, uninhabited, depopulated, deserted, desolate, uncultivated, or in a state the contrary of flourishing:] the pl. of xaraAbN is OxoribapN, (JK, Ḳ,) a pl. of pauc., (JK,) and xirabN, which latter is mentioned by El-Khaṭṭábee, (Ḳ,) as occurring in a trad. respecting the building of the mosque of El-Medeeneh: kaAna fiyhi naxolN waqubuwru AlmuXorikiyna waxaribN faOamara biAlxirabi fasuw-iyato [There were in it palm-trees, and the graves of the believers in a plurality of gods, and ruins; and he gave orders respecting the ruins, and they were levelled]: but IAth says that xirabN may be pl. of xaribapN↓, or of xirobapN↓: or it may be xaribN↓ [coll. gen. n.] of xaribapN↓: and accord. to one reading of the trad., the word is HarovN, meaning “a place ploughed for sowing:” (TA:) [accord. to F,] the pl. of xirobapN↓, also, is xirabN: and the pl. of xaribapN↓ is xaribN [mentioned above] and xaraAYibu [which is anomalous] and xaribaAtN. (Ḳ.) [Hence,] waqaEuwA fiI waAdiI xaribaAtK↓ [They fell into a valley of ruins, or waste places,, &c.]: (A, TA:) i. e., into destruction: (TA:) [a prov., of which there are various readings: see jacabaAt, in art. jcb.]
[Also inf. n. of xaraba as syn. with Axrb, q. v.]

entry.sense: xaraAbapN: see xurobapN.
xuraAbapN: see xurobapN, in five places.

xar-uwbN (Az, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and xuronuwbN↓, (Az, Ṣ, Ḳ,) mentioned by Az as radically quadriliteral, (TA in art. xrnb,) and xaronuwbN↓, (Mgh, Ḳ,) but this last is of weak authority, (TA,) or not allowable, (Ṣ,) a coll. gen. n.; n. un. with p {xar-uwbapN}; (TA;) A kind of tree, growing upon the mountains of Syria, having grains (Hab-) like those of the yanobuwt [q. v.], called by the children of El-’Irák Alqiv-aMCu AlX-aAmiI-u, dry, or tough, and black: (Az, TA in art. xrnb:)
a certain plant, (Ṣ, Mgh,) well known: (Ṣ:) said by some to be kind of tree [or plant] called xaXoxaAX [i. e. poppy]: (Mgh:) certain trees, of which there are two kinds, wild (bar-iI-N), and Syrian (XaAmiI-N): (AḤn, Ḳ:) the former kind is also called yanobuwtapN; (AḤn;) and this is thorny, (AḤn, Ḳ,) used as fuel, rising to the height of a cubit, having branches, (AḤn,) with a fruit (AḤn, Ḳ) black (OaHam-u) and light, like bubbles, (AḤn, TA,) in the copies of the Ḳ kaAlt-uf-aAHi, but correctly kaAln-ufaAxi, (TA,) disagreeable in taste, (AḤn, Ḳ,) not eaten except in cases of difficulty, or distress; having grains (Hab-) which are hard and lubricous: (AḤn:) the Syrian kind [is that to which the name of xr-wb is now commonly applied, the carob, or locust-tree; ceratonia siliqua; the fruit of which] is sweet, and is eaten; having grains (Hab-) like those of the yanobuwt, but larger; (AḤn;) the fruit of this kind is like the xiyaAr Xanobar [or cassia fistula], but wide; and from it are prepared an inspissated juice and [a kind of] sawiyq [or parched meal]. (AḤn, Ḳ.) [Its grain is used as a weight: see qiyraATN and dirohamN and diynaArN.]
xar-aAbapN: see xurobapN, in two places.
xur-aAbapN: see xurobapN, in four places.
xuronuwbN and xaronuwbN: see xar-uwbN.

xaAribN A stealer of camels: (Aṣ, Ṣ, A:) and (by extension of its original meaning, TA) any thief, or robber: (JK, Ṣ:) dim. xuwayoribN↓: (TA:) and pl. xur-aAbN, (Ṣ, A, TA,) or OaxoraAbN. (JK.) [See also xirobapN.]
xuwayoribN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: Oaxorabu Slit: or having a round hole or perforation: (Ṣ:) [fem. xarobaMCu; as in] OucunN xarobaMCu An ear having the lobe slit. (Ḳ.)

A man, (Ṣ,) or a ram, (Mṣb,) having his ear slit; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also muxar-abN↓ and muxar-amN; (TA;) from maxoruwbN↓ signifying slit: (Ṣ:) and (so in the Ṣ and TA, but in the Mṣb “or”) having his ear pierced, or bored: when it is slit (after the piercing, Ṣ, TA), he is said to be Oaxoramu: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA: [but see this last in art. xrm:]) and Oaxorabu AlOucunayoni having the ears pierced, or bored: (AM, TA in art. xrt:) and xarobaMCu a female slave having the lobe of her ear slit [or pierced, or bored]: and muxar-abapN↓ a female slave having her ear [slit or] pierced, or bored: (TA:) and xarobaMCu a she-goat having her ear slit, but so that the slit is not long nor wide. (Ḳ.)
OaxorabN: see xurobapN.

entry.sense: xaliy-apN muxoribapN An empty bee-hive, (Ḳ,) in which honey has not been collected. (TA.)
muxar-abN, and its fem. (with p) {muxar-abapN}: see Oaxorabu.
maxoruwbN: see Oaxorabu.

nuxoruwbN sing. of naxaAriybu, (TA,) which latter signifies Holes like those of hornets' nests: and the holes, or cells, (prepared with wax, Ḳ in art. nxrb,) in which the bees deposit their honey. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, txAryb.]) Accord. to some, the n is a radical letter. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xarata, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxorutu}, inf. n. xarotN, (TḲ,) He perforated, bored, or pierced, (Ḳ,) the ear, (TḲ,) or a thing. (TA.) And xarata Oanofa Aljamali [It perforated, or slit, (see the pass. part. n., below,) the nose of the camel]: said of the xiXaAX [or wooden thing that is inserted in the bone of the camel's nose]. (A.)

xaratonaA AlOaroDa We knew the land and its roads. (Ks, Ṣ.) [Golius omits this; but mentions, as on the authority of Ibn-Maạroof, xarita, signifying He was skilful, or expert, in showing the way. What Ibn-Maạroof says, however, is that the inf. n. xaratN signifies the being acquainted with a road; and, with a place. See xir-iytu.]

entry.sense: xarotN: see what next follows, in two places.

xurotN The perforation, bore, or hole, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) of a needle; [i. e. its eye;] (Ṣ, A;) [see also xurotapN;] and of the ear, (Ṣ,) or in the ear, [but see xurotapN,], &c.; (A, Ḳ;) and of the faOos, [i. e. hoe, or adz, or axe,] (Ṣ, A, TA,) meaning, of the handle thereof; (A, TA;) as also xurapN; (Fr, TA in art. xrw;) [see again xurotapN;] and xarotN↓ signifies the same: (A, Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxoraAtN (Ṣ, A) and [of mult.] xuruwtN. (Ṣ.) You say OaDoyaqu mino xuroti AlUiborapi [Narrower than the eye of the needle]. (A.) And maDaAyiqu kaOaxoraAti AlUibari [Narrow passes like the eyes of needles]. (A.) The xurot of a sandal is The hole, or perforation, of the cuWaAbap [q. v.], into which the thong [called the XiraAk] enters. (An anon. Arabic MṢ. in my possession.)

Also The rings at the heads [or extremities] of [camels' plaited fore-girths of the kind called] nusuwE; and so [the pls.] xuratN (Ḳ) and OaxoraAtN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and xurotapN↓ signifies one of these; (Ḳ;) i. e. the ring in which is [inserted the end of] the nisoEap. (TA.) [Hence the phrase,] qaliqa xurotu fulaAnK [lit. The rings of the fore-girths of the camels of such a one became unsteady; meaning] ‡ the state of such a one became disordered, or perverted. (A, TA.) And similar to this are the phrases, raAda xurotu Alqawomi and raAdato OaxoraAtuhumo, [in the TA zAd and zAdt, but the comparison evidently shows that the verbs should be rAd and rAdt,] said of a people when they do not receive or entertain hospitably him who alights at their place of abode: so says IAạr on the authority of Es-Saloolee. (TA.)
See also xurotapN.
Also A small rib, at, or near, the breast; and so xarotN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. OaxoraAtN, which Lth explains as meaning the ribs at, or near, the breast, collectively. (TA.)
And [the pl.] OaxoraAtN signifies The obscure roads or ways, and the narrow passes, of a desert. (TA.)
xurotapN: see xurotN.

Its pl. OaxoraAtN, [also pl. of xurotN↓, (see xubonN,)] in the formation of which the p of the sing. seems to have been considered as elided, also signifies The loops of a [leathern water-bag such as is called] mazaAdap: it is said in the T that in the mzAdp are its AxrAt, the loops between which is the qaSabap [commonly signifying cane, or reed, but here app. meaning the mouth, which has the form of a short cylinder, and is in the middle of the upper part of the mzAdp, between the two loops, these being at the two upper corners], whereby [app. referring to the AxrAt] it is carried [and suspended on the side of a camel, counterpoised by another mzAdp on the other side of the camel]: and AM adds that one says [also] OaxoraAbu AlmazaAdapi, sing. xurobapN [q. v.]; and in like manner, xurobapu AlOucuni [“the bore of the ear”]; with b: and gulaAmN Oaxorabu AlOucunayoni [“a boy having his ears pierced, or bored”]: he says, also, that the xurotap, with t, is [the hole] in the iron of the faOos, and [the eye] of the needle; and the xurobap, with b, is in the skin: and AA says that xurotapN signifies the eye of the [kind of needle called] Xagiyzap, i. e. the misal-ap: (TA:) and Lth says that it signifies a round hole. (TA in art. Hrt.)

AlxaraAtaAni Two stars, (Ḳ,) of the stars of the Lion, two whips' lengths apart, [(see sawoTN,) in] the two shoulder-blades of the Lion, (TA,) also called zuborapu AlOasadi, (Ḳ,) [composing the Eleventh Mansion of the Moon: (see zuborapN: and see also manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl:)] the word is mentioned here in the Ḳ, as though it were of the measure faEaAlaAni; but accord. to Kr and others, it is dual of xaraApN, belonging to art. xrw, in which it is again mentioned in the Ḳ: (TA:) accord. to ISd, however, only the dual form is known, and the radical t and the augmentative t [by which latter is meant p] are in the dual alike: (TA in art. xrw:) Zj asked Th respecting the xrAtAn, and he answered, IAạr says that they are two stars, of those of the Lion; and Aboo-Naṣr, the companion of Aṣ, says that they are two stars in the zbrp of the Lion, i. e. in the middle thereof; but in my opinion they are two stars after [i. e. to the eastward of] the jabohap and the qalob: Zj disapproved of this, and replied, I say that they are two stars in that part of the breast which is the stabbing-place, derived from xurotu AlUiborapi, “the eye of the needle:” but Th rejoined, that this was an error, because the word is the dual of xaraApN; and he cited some verses in which a poet speaks of certain stars in the Lion, and, among them, of AlxaraApu. (MF, TA.)

xir-iytu (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and xir-iytN mir-iytN (Sh) A skilful, or an expert, guide of the way; (Sh, Ṣ, Ḳ;) one who pursues the right course to the OaxoraAt, i. e. the obscure roads or ways, and the narrow passes, of the deserts; or who pursues the right course in a way that may be likened to the xurot [or eye] of the needle: (TA:) or skilful; applied to a man, and [particularly] to a guide: (A:) pl. xaraAritu, occurring in a verse [perhaps used by poetic licence for the regular pl. xaraAriytu]. (Ṣ.)
maxoratN A strait, direct, or right, road or way. (Ḳ.)
maxoruwtN originally Perforated, bored, or pierced. (TA.)
Then, (TA,) Having the nose slit; (Ḳ;) [and] so maxoruwtu AlOanofi, applied to a camel: (A, TA:) or mxrwt signifies having a slit lip. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

xuroviI-N The utensils and furniture of a house or tent: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) and the refuse, or the worthless or mean or vile articles, thereof; (Ṣ, A, Mgh;) thus accord. to the lawyers: (Mgh:) or bad furniture and utensils: (A:) or the worst thereof, and of spoils: (Ḳ:) or [rubbish,] such as a fragment of a bowl, and ashes, and [the dung that is termed] baEor, of a house: (AZ, TA in art. AsI:) [pl. xaraAviI-N.] You say, naqaluwA xuroviI-a mataAEihimo They removed the worthless articles of their furniture and utensils. (A.)

[Hence,] fulaAnN yasomaEu xuroviI-a AlkalaAmi ‡ Such a one hears language in which is no good. (A, TA.) And OaloqaI fulaAnN xaraAviI-a and xaraAviI-a qawolihi ‡ [Such a one cast forth the unprofitable things of his mind and the unprofitable things of his speech]. (A, TA.)

1. xaraja, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yaxoruju}, (L,) inf. n. xuruwjN and maxorajN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He, or it, went, came, passed, or got, out, or forth; issued, emanated, proceeded, went, or departed; contr. of daxala; (TA;) mina AlmawoDiEi [from the place]. (Mṣb.) One says, xaraja maxorajFA HasanFA [He, or it, went, came, passed, or got, out, or forth,, &c., well: and it turned out well]. (Ṣ.) [And xaraja mino TaAEatihi: see TaAYiEN, in art. TwE. When xaraja means It was disbursed, or expended, the inf. n. is xarojN.] xaraja bihi [lit. He went out,, &c., with him, or it]: see 4. (TA.) yawomu Alxuruwji [The day of going forth] means the day of the Eiyd [or festival]. (A, TA, from a trad.) And [as used in the Ḳur l. 41] The day when men shall come forth from their graves; (TA;) a name of the day of resurrection. (AO, Ḳ.)

[† It became excluded by a definition or a rule or the like, or by a portion thereof.] manoSuwbN EalaI Alxuruwji is a phrase of the Basree grammarians, said of the objective complement of a verb, meaning † Put in the accus. case as being out of the predicament of the subject and that of the attribute. (TA.)

xaraja mino OamorK † [He got out of, escaped from, extricated himself from, evaded, or became quit of, affair, or a state]. (ISh, TA in art. nks.) [And xarajamino HaAlK UilaI HaAlK † He passed from one state to another state. And xaraja mino diynihi † He quitted, or forsook, his religion. And xaraja mino dayonihi, and mn maraDihi, † He became quit of his debt, and of his disease.] And xaraja UilaI fulaAnK mino dayonihi † He paid such a one his debt: a phrase used in law. (TA.) [And xaraja EalaI Als-uloTaAni, and Eano Oamori Als-uloTaAni, † He rebelled against the Sultán.] And xarajato EalaI xiloqapi Aljamali ‡ [She became formed like the he-camel]; said of a she-camel that is termed muxotarajapN↓. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) And xaraja UilaI AlbacaMCa † [He became foul, or obscene, in his language]. (L and Ḳ in art. xnc.) And xaraja fiI AlEilomi waAlS-inaAEapi, inf. n. xuruwjN, ‡ He was, or became, conspicuous in science and art. (A, TA. [See also 5.])

maA OaHosana xuruwjahaA, said of a cloud (saHaAbap), ‡ How good is its first rising from the horizon! (A.) [You say also, xaraja Als-aHaAbu, inf. n. xuruwjN, meaning † The clouds became extended, or expanded: see xarojN.] And xarajati Als-amaMCu ‡ The sky became clear, after having been cloudy. (T, A.)

hom.sense: 2. xr-j, inf. n. taxoriyjN, [sometimes resembles in signification Oaxoraja:] see the inf. n. voce xariyjN.

[† He resolved, explained, or rendered, a saying. EalaI hecaA xar-ajuwA qawola kacaA † According to this meaning, &c. they have resolved, explained, or rendered, such a saying, is a phrase of frequent occurrence in the larger lexicons, &c.]

† He educated, disciplined, or trained, well a youth: and in like manner, a horse [and a camel; for muxar-ajN, as is indicated in the Ḳ voce mudar-abN, applied to a camel, is syn. with muWad-abN]. (IAạr.) You say, xr-jhu fiI AlOadabi, (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, ‡ He educated, disciplined, or trained, him well in polite accomplishments; i. e. a teacher, his pupil. (TA.)

[He, or it, rendered a thing Oaxoraj, i. e. of two colours, white and black:, &c.] You say, Aln-ujuwmu tuxar-iju All-awona The stars render the colour [of a thing, such as an expanse of water,] a mixture of black and white, by reason of its blackness and their whiteness. (TA.) And xr-j All-awoHa, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) ‡ He (a boy, A) wrote upon part of the tablet and left part of it without writing. (A,* Ḳ.) And xr-j kitaAbFA ‡ He wrote a book leaving [blank] the places [of the titles] of the sections and chapters. (A.) And xr-j AlEamala, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He made the work to be of different kinds. (A, Ḳ,* TA.) And xr-jti Alr-aAEiyapu AlmaroEaI, inf. n. as above, The pasturing animals ate part of the pasture and left part. (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ,* TA. [See also 4.]) And OaroDN fiyhaA taxoriyjN: and EaAmN fiyhi taxoriyjN, and EAm cuw taxoriyjK: see Oaxoraju.

entry.sense: 3. AlmuxaArajapu i. q. AlmunaAhadapu biAlOaSaAbiEi, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e. (TA) One person's putting forth as many of his fingers as he pleases, and the other's doing the like: (Ḳ, TA:) [or the playing at the game called morra; micare digitis: see xariyjN. You say, xArjhu He played with him at the game of morra. See also 6.]
xaArajahumo, [inf. n. as above,] He contributed with them to the expenses of a journey or an expedition against an enemy, sharing equally with each of them; like naAhadahumo. (L in art. nhd.)

And xArjhu He made an agreement with him, namely, his slave, that he (the latter) should pay him a certain import at the expiration of every month; (Mgh, L, TA;) the slave being left at liberty to work: (L, TA:) in which case the slave is termed EabodN maxaArajN↓. (Mgh, L, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Axrjhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. [UixoraAjN and] bihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made, or caused, him, or it, to go, come, pass, or get, out, or forth; to issue, emanate, proceed, or depart: [he put, cast, or thrust, him, or it, out, or forth; expelled, ejected, or dislodged, him, or it: he took, led, drew, or pulled, him, or it, out, or forth: he gave it forth: he, or it, produced it:] as also xaraja↓ bihi: [but it should be observed that this latter properly and generally denotes accompaniment, like cahaba bihi; and may be literally rendered he went, came, passed, or got, out, or forth, with him, or it:] and Axtrj↓, also, is syn. with Oaxoraja; as in the saying, in a trad., faQxotaraja tamaraAtK mino qirobapK [And he took forth, or took forth for himself (accord. to a property of many erbs of this form), some dates from a water-skin]: (TA:) [so, too, is Astxrj↓; as meaning he took, led, drew, or pulled, out, or forth: but this generally implies some degree of effort, or labour; as does also Axtrj↓; and likewise, desire: i. e. it means he sought, or endeavoured, to make a thing come forth: the former is also syn. with OabodaEahu (q. v.) and OaHodavahu: and both of them signify, and so does Axrj in many instances, he drew out, or forth; extracted; educed; produced; elicited; fetched out by labour or art; got out; or extorted: this is what is meant by its being said that] AlAisotixoraAju↓ is syn. with AlAisotinobaATu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and so is AlAixotiraAju↓. (Ḳ.) OaxorijoniI maxoraja SidoqK, in the Ḳur xvii. 82, means Cause Thou me to go forth from Mekkeh in a good, or an agreeable, manner, so that I may not turn my heart [or affections] towards it: (Jel: [see also various similar explanations in Bḍ:]) or mxrj is here a n. of place, or, accord. to the more approved opinion, of time. (TA.)
Axrj maA fiI Sadorihi † [He vented that which was in his bosom, or mind]. (TA in art. srH.)
[Axrj said of a definition or a rule or the like, or of a portion thereof, means † It excluded something.]
Axrjhu mina AlOamori † [He excluded him from participation in the affair]. (TA in art. HDn, &c.)
Axrj [intrans.] He paid his xaraAj; (Ḳ;) i. e. his land-tax, and poll-tax. (TA.)
He hunted ostriches such as are termed xurojN, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK Alxaraja is erroneously put for Alxuroja,]) pl. of Oaxoraju. (TA.)
He married to a woman of brown complexion, white intermixed with black, whose parents were, one, white, and the other, black. (T, Ḳ.)
‡ He passed a year of fruitfulness and sterility, (Ḳ, TA,) or half fruitful and half sterile. (TA.)
Axrjti Alr-aAEiyapu ‡ The pasturing animals ate part of the pasture and left part. (Ḳ, TA. [See also 2.])

entry.sense: 5. txr-j [† It (a saying) was resolved, explained, or rendered. EalaI hecaA yataxar-aju qawolu kacaA † According to this meaning, &c. is, or may be, resolved, explained, or rendered, such a saying, is a phrase of frequent occurrence in the larger lexicons, &c.]
‡ He was, or became, well educated or disciplined or trained, (A,* TA,) in polite accomplishments, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or in science and art. (A. [See also 1: and see 2, of which it is quasi-pass.])

6. taxaArujN i. q. tanaAhudN; (Ṣ;) similar to muxaArajapN with the fingers, as explained above. (TA.) You say, txArjwA, meaning tnAhdwA [i. e. They played together, one putting forth as many of his fingers as he pleased, and another doing the like: or they played together at the game called morra: see xariyjN]. (A.)

txArjwA is also syn. with tnAhdwA as meaning They contributed equally to the expenses which they had to incur on the occasion of a journey, or an expedition against an enemy; or contributed equal shares of food and drink. (L in art. nhd.)

And txArjA They (two copartners, Ḳ, TA, or two coinheritors, TA) became quit of claim to sharing property by one's taking the house and the other's taking the land; (Ḳ,* TA;) or by selling the property by mutual consent and then dividing it; or by one's taking ready money and the other's taking a debt. (TA.)
8: see 4, in three places: and see also 10.

10. Astxrj: see 4, in two places. You say, Aisotaxorajotu AlX-aIoCa mina AlmaEodini I extracted the thing from the mine, clearing it from its dust. (Mṣb.) And AisotixoraAju AlmuEam-aI matobaEapN liloxawaATiri † [The eliciting of the meaning of that which is made enigmatical is a cause of fatigue to minds]. (A in art. tEb.)
[Also † He tilled land, and made it productive. (See Ḳ voce gaAmirN.]) And Ausotuxorijati AlOaroDu † The land was put into a good state for sowing or planting. (AḤn, TA.)
Astxrjhu and Axtrjhu↓ He asked him, or petitioned him, to go, or come, out, or forth; or he desired of him that he should go, or come, out, or forth. (TA.)
xarojN [originally an inf. n.] Outgoings, disbursements, expenditure, or expenses; what goes out, or is expended, of a man's property; contr. of daxolN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also xaraAjN, throughout.

Also, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and xuruwjN↓, (L,) Clouds when first rising and appearing: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or the rain that comes forth from clouds: (Akh:) or the xuruwj of clouds is their becoming extended, or expanded. (TA. [See 1.])

hom.sense: xurojN: see xaraAjN.

Also A well-known kind of wiEaMC; [a pair of saddle-bags; i. e. a double bag, or double sack, for the saddle;] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a juwaAliq having two corresponding receptacles [the mouths whereof are generally closed by means of loops which are inserted one into another]: (TA:) [also, app., a single saddle-bag; and xurojaAni a pair of saddle-bags: (see badiydN:)] an Arabic word, (Ṣ,) accord. to the more correct opinion; but said by some to be arabicized: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] xirajapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OaxoraAjN. (TA.)

entry.sense: xarajN [The quality of being of] two colours, white and black. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [See Oaxoraju.])

xarojapN [n. un. of 1: pl. xarajaAtN]. You say, maA xaraja Uil-aA xarojapF waAHidapF He went not, or came not, out, or forth, save once: and maA Oakovara xarajaAtika How many are thy goings, or comings, out, or forth! (A.)

rajulN xurajapN wulajapN (Ṣ, Ḳ *) and xar-aAjN↓ wal-aAjN and xaruwjN↓ waluwjN (TA in art. wlj) A man frequently going, or coming, out and in: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and the second phrase [and app. the others likewise] ‡ a man of much cleverness, ingenuity, or acuteness, and artifice, or cunning; (Ḳ, TA;) ‡ a man who uses art, artifice, or cunning, in the disposal, or management, of affairs: (A:) or ‡ one who does not hasten in an affair from which he cannot easily escape when he desires to do so. (TA.)

xaraAjN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xarojN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) both also written with damm, [i. e. xuraAjN↓ and xurojN↓,] (Ḳ,) but the former mode of writing them is that which more commonly obtains, (TA,) i. q. UitaAwapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) A tax, or tribute, which is taken from the property of people; an impost, or a certain amount of the property of people, which is given forth yearly; a tax upon lands, &c.: (TA:) or the revenue, or gain, derived from land, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) or from a slave, (Mgh,) or also from a slave: (A:) and then applied to the land-tax, which is taken by the Sultán: (A, Mgh:) and the poll-tax paid by the free non-Muslim subjects of a Muslim government: (A, Mgh, Mṣb:) or xaraAjN signifies especially a land-tax: and xarojN↓, a poll-tax: (IAạr:) or the former also signifies the poll-tax paid by the free non-Muslim subjects of a Muslim government: it is a term which was applied to a yearly land-tax which ʼOmar imposed upon the people of the Sawád [of El-'Irák]: then, to the landtax which the people of a land taken by convention agreed to pay; and their lands were termed xaraAjiy-apN: accord. to Bḍ, it is a name for the proceeds of land: and has then been used to signify the profits arising from possessions; such as the revenue derived from the increase of lands, and from slaves and animals: accord. to Er-Ráfi'ee, its primary signification is an impost which the master requires to be paid him by his slave: accord. to Zj, xarojN↓ is an [obsolete] inf. n.: and xaraAjN, a name for that which comes forth: and he also explains the latter word by faIoCN: and xarojN↓, by DariybapN and jizoyapN: (TA:) the pl. (of xaraAjN, L, TA) is OaxoraAjN and OaxaAriyju [a pl. pl.] and OaxorijapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) AlxaraAju biAlD-amaAni, a saying ascribed to Moḥammad, (Ḳ, TA,) occurring in a trad. of ʼÁïsheh, of disputed authority, but affirmed by several authors to be genuine, means, accord. to most of the lawyers, (TA,) The revenue derived from the slave is the property of the purchaser because of the responsibility which he has borne for him: (A,* Mgh,* Ḳ, TA:) for one purchases a slave, and imposes upon him the task of producing a revenue for a time, and then may discover in him a fault which the seller had concealed; wherefore he has a right to return him and to receive back the price; but the revenue which he had required the slave to produce is his lawful property, because he had been responsible for him; and if he had perished, part of his property had perished: (Ḳ,* TA:) in a similar manner IAth explains it, as relating to a male or female slave or to other property. (TA.)
xarojN↓ and xaraAjN as used in the Ḳur xxiii. 74 mean A recompense, or reward. (Fr.) Some, for xarojFA↓, in this instance, read xaraAjFA. (TA.)
And xaraAjN is also used as meaning ‡ The taste of fruit; this being likened to the xrAj of lands, &c. (TA, from a trad.)
