See also xariyjN, in five places.

hom.sense: xuraAjN Pimples, or small swellings or pustules: [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {xuraAjapN}: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or [the kind of pustule termed] dum-al, and the like, that come forth upon the body: (Mgh:) or purulent pustules, or imposthumes, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) that come forth upon the body: (Ṣ:) or a spontaneous swelling that comes forth upon the body: or an ulcerous swelling that comes forth upon a beast of the equine kind and upon other animals:pl. [of pauc.] OaxorijapN and [of mult.] xirojaAnN. (TA.)
See also xaraAjN.

entry.sense: xaruwjN: see xaArijN, and xuraHapN.
Also A horse that outstrips in the race. (TA.)

And ‡ A horse having a neck so long that, by reason of its length, he plucks away at unawares (yagotaAlu) every bridle that is attached to his bit: (A,* L, Ḳ:*) and in like manner, without p, a mare. (TA.)

And A she-camel that lies down apart from the [other] camels: (Ḳ:) and one excellent in the pace termed Eanaq, that goes before others: (TA:) pl. xurujN, (Ḳ, TA,) [in the CK xurojN, but it is] with two dammehs. (TA.)
xuruwjN an inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
See also xarojN.

xariyjN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xaraAjN↓ and taxoriyjN↓ (TA) A certain game, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) played by the Arab youths, (TA,) in which they say xaraAji xaraAji↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) accord. to ISk, you say, laEiba AlS-iboyaAnu xaraAji↓ [The boys played at xrAj], with kesr to the j: Fr says, xrAj is the name of a well-known game of the Arabs, in which one of the players holds a thing in his hand and says to the others, Elicit ye (OaxorijuwA) what is in my hand: in the T, xrAj↓ and xryj are explained by the word muxaArajapN [meaning micare digitis; and hence it appears that the game thus termed, accord. to the T, is the morra, a game common in ancient and modern Italy, and in very remote times in Egypt, in which one of the players puts forth some, or all, of his fingers, and another is required to name instantly the number put forth, or to do the same];
and it is there added, that it is A game of the Arab youths: Aboo-Dhu-eyb El-Hudhalee says,
Oaziqato lahu caAta AlEiXaMCi kaOan-ahu
maxaAriyqu yudoEaI taHotahun-a xariyju
I was sleepless in consequence of it, (referring to lightning,) at nightfall, as though it were kerchiefs twisted for the purpose of beating with them, under which was uttered the cry xryj; likening the thunder to the cry of the players: but Aboo-ʼAlee says that xryj [thus used] is incorrect; that he should have said xaraAji↓, but that the rhyme required him to say xryj. (TA.)
bilaAdN xaraAjiy-apN Countries subject to a [xaraAj, or] tax upon their lands. (MF.)
xar-aAjN: see xaArijN, and xurajapN.

xir-iyjN has the meaning of a pass. part. n.: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) you say, huwa xir-iyju fulaAnK ‡ He is, or has been, well educated or disciplined or trained by such a one (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ *) in polite accomplishments, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or in science and art. (A.)

xaArijN and [in an intensive sense] xaruwjN↓ and [in an intensive or a frequentative sense] xar-aAjN↓ Going, coming, passing, or getting, out, or forth; issuing, emanating, proceeding, or departing: [the second signifying doing so much: and the third, doing so much or frequently.] (TA.)

[External; extrinsic; foreign:] the exterior, or outside, of anything. (TA.) You say, kunotu xaArija Ald-aAri [I was outside the house]: (A:) [or,] accord. to Sb, xaArij is not used adverbially unless with the particle [fiI]. (TA.)

[Hence, AlxaAriju as meaning † What is external, or extrinsic, to the mind; what is objective; reality. (See also xaArijiI-N.) And fiI AlxaAriji † In what is external, or extrinsic, to the mind;, &c.].
xaArijapN [fem. of xaArijN: and sing. of xawaAriju used as a subst.].

AlxawaAriju in the phrase Ald-awaAxilu waAlxawaAriju means The arches, or vaults, and niches, in the inner side of a wall; AldwAxl meaning the figured forms, and inscriptions, upon a wall, executed with gypsum or otherwise: or AldwAxl wAlxwArj means the ornamental [depressed and] projecting forms of a building, differing from the forms adjacent thereto. (Mṣb, from a saying of Esh-Sháfiʼee.)
xawaAriju AlmaAli † The mare and the female slave and the she-ass. (Ḳ.)

xarajato xawaArijuhu ‡ His generosity became apparent, and he applied himself to the sound management of affairs, (Ḳ,* TA,) and became intelligent like others of his class, after his youth, or ignorant and youthful conduct. (TA.)

xaArijiI-N One who makes himself a lord, or chief, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and goes forth [from his party, or fellows], and becomes elevated, or exalted, (TA,) without his having noble ancestry: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and it is also said to signify anything that surpasses, or excels its kind and fellows: (TA:) accord. to Abu-l-ʼAlà, in ancient times, before El-Islám, it was applied to a courageous, or generous, man, the son of a coward or niggard, and the like:

and in like manner, to a A fleet, or swift, horse; or one excellent in running; or that outstrips others; not the offspring of a sire and dam possessing the like qualities: [and in the TA, the coll. gen. n. xaArijiy-apN is explained as applied to such horses:]

then, in the times of El-Islám, it was applied to A rebel: and a heretic. (Ḥam p. 188.) [The pl.] AlxawaAriju is the appellation of A party [of heretics, or schismatics,] of those following erroneous opinions, having a singular, or particular, persuasion: (Ḳ:) they are [said by some to be] the Haruwriy-ap [q. v.]; and the xaArijiy-a are [said to be] a sect of them; and they consist of seven sects: (TA:) they were so called because they went forth from, (as in one copy of the Ḳ,) or against, (as in other copies,) the rest of the people; (Ḳ, TA;) or from the religion, or from the truth, or from ʼAlee after [the battle of] Siffeen. (TA.)

[Also † Relating to what is external, or extrinsic, to the mind; objective; real. Hence, AlOumuwru AlxaArijiy-apu † The things that are external, or extrinsic, to the mind; the things that are considered objectively; real things; opposed to AlOumuwru Alc-ihoniy-apu. (See also xaArijN.)]
[xaArijiy-apN fem. of xaArijiI-N:]
[and also a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is xaArijiI-N.]
xaAruwjN A certain sort of palm-trees, (L, Ḳ,*) well known. (Ḳ.)
[xawaAriju pl. of xaArijapN:]
[and also of xaArijiI-N as an epithet applied to a man, &c., not as a rel. n.]

Oaxoraju A ram, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and (so in the Ṣ, but in the Ḳ “or”) a male ostrich, (AA, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) of two colours, white and black: (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ:) or a male ostrich of a colour in which black predominates over white, like the colour of ashes: and in this sense also applied to a mountain: (Lth, TA:) and a goat half white and half black: and a horse of which the belly, and the sides as far as the back, but not the back itself, are white, and the rest of any colour: (TA:) fem. xarojaMCu: (A, TA:) which is applied to a female ostrich: (A:) and to a ewe or she-goat having white hind legs and flanks: (AZ, Ṣ:) or a ewe that is black, with one hind leg, or both hind legs, and the flanks, white; the rest being black: (TA:) or a ewe white in the hinder part, half of her being white, and the other half of any colour: (T, TA:) and a small isolated mountain (qaArapN) of two colours, (A, TA,) white and black: (A:) pl. xurojN. (Ḳ.) Also ‡ A garment white and red; rendered so by being besmeared with blood. (TA.) El-ʼAjjáj says,
Uin-aA UicaA mucokiI AlHuruwbi Oar-ajaA
walabisato lilomawoti vawobFA OaxorajaA : (so in the TA: in the Ṣ, jul-FA AxrjA:) meaning ‡ [Verily we, when the inflamer of wars excites them, and] they (the wars) have put on, for death, a garment white and red, rendered so by being besmeared with blood: i. e., have been rendered notable like a thing that is black and white. (Ṣ, TA.)
AlOaxoraju The [bird called] muk-aMC; (Ḳ;) because of its colour. (TA.)

OaroDN xarojaMCu (TA) and muxar-ajapN↓ (Sh, Ṣ, Ḳ) and fiyhaA taxoriyjN↓ (TA) ‡ Land having plants, or herbage, in one place and not in another: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) that has been rained upon, and has produced herbs, in some parts and not in others: (Sh:) or the second means land upon which rain has not fallen. (L in art. SH.)

EaAmN Oaxoraju (TA) and muxar-ajN↓ (A, TA) and fiyhi taxoriyjN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and cuw taxoriyjK (Ḳ) ‡ A year of fruitfulness, or of abundant herbage, and of sterility: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA:) or half fruitful, or abundant in herbage, and half sterile. (TA.)
maxorajN an inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Also A place of xuruwj [i. e. of going, coming, passing, or getting, out, or forth; a place of egress, or exit; an outlet]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) pl. maxaAriju. (TA.) You say, wajadotu fiI AlOamori maxorajFA † I found, in the affair, or case, a place [or way] of escape, evasion, or safety. (Mṣb.) And fulaAnN yaEorifu mawaAlija AlOumuwri wamaxaArijahaA ‡ Such a one knows the ways of entering into affairs and those of withdrawing himself out of them. (A, TA.)
[Hence, A privy: used in this sense in the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. HX, &c.]
[And The anus: used in this sense in the Mṣb in art. Hqn.]
Also A time of xuruwj [i. e. of going,, &c., out, or forth; of egress, or exit]. (TA.)
fulaAnN Hasanu Almadoxali wAlmaxoraji means † Such a one is good, and laudable, in his way of acting, or conduct. (TA in art. dxl.)
muxorajN an inf. n. of the trans. v. Oaxoraja. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [So accord. to some in a phrase in the Ḳur xvii. 82, respecting which see 4.]
Also pass. part. n. of the same. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And n. of place of the same. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And n. of time of the same. (Ṣ.)
yawomN maxoruwjN occurs in poetry for yawomN maxoruwjN fiyhi [A day in which one goes forth; or in which people go forth]. (TA.)
EabodN muxaArajN: see 3, last sentence.
naAqapN muxotarajapN ‡ A she-camel formed like the he-camel: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA:) or like the male buxotiI- camel. (TA.) See 1.

1. xaridato, aor. _a {yaxoradu}, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaradN, (L,) She was an untouched virgin; (L, Ḳ;) as also Axrdt↓, inf. n. UixoraAdN; (L;) and txr-dt↓: (L, Ḳ:) or she was bashful and grave or staid or sedate, or very bashful, long silent, low in voice, one who concealed herself from public view, (L, Ḳ,) and did not remain long in her parents' house, or tent, unmarried, after having attained the usual proper age for marriage. (L.)
And xarida He was, or became, affected with shame, bashfulness, or pudency; (IAạr;) as also Axrd↓ (Ḳ.)
He was, or became, abject. (IAạr.)

Also, inf. n. as above; and Axrd↓; He kept long silence: (L, Ḳ:) and the latter signifies also he kept silence by reason of abjectness; not by reason of bashfulness: so accord. to the Ḳ: but accord. to the A, he kept silence by reason of bashfulness; and Aqrd signifies “he kept silence by reason of abjectness:” (TA:) and so says IAạr: (TA in art. qrd:) or Axrd accord. to IAạr signifies he spoke little. (Ḥar p. 250.) [See also xaAridN.]
4: see 1, in three places.
Axrd UilaI All-ahowi He inclined to play, sport, or diversion. (Ḳ.)
5: see 1.
xaruwdN: see xariydapN, in two places.
xariydN: see the next paragraph.
SawotN xariydN A gentle voice, characterized by bashfulness, or modesty. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

xariydapN A virgin: (IAạr, Ṣ, A:) and a bashful, or modest, woman: and sometimes they said jaAriyapN xaruwdN↓, meaning a girl bashful and grave or staid or sedate; or very bashful: (Ṣ:) or xriydapN and xariydN↓ and xaruwdN↓ signify an untouched virgin: or a female bashful, and grave or staid or sedate, or very bashful, long silent, low in voice, who conceals herself from public view, (L, Ḳ,) and does not remain long in her parents' house, or tent, unmarried, after having attained the usual proper age for marriage: (L:) pl. xaraAYidu and xur-adN (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ) and xurudN; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) the second of which is contr. to rule. (L.)
Also ‡ An unbored pearl. (Lth, IAạr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

xaAridN Silent by reason of bashfulness; not by reason of abjectness: and muxoridN↓ silent by reason of abjectness; not by reason of bashfulness: so accord. to AA: and the latter, simply, silent. (L.) [See also 1.]
muxoridN: see the next preceding paragraph.

xarodalN [Mustard-seed;] the grain of a certain tree, (Ḳ,) well known; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a species of Hurof [q. v.]; (JK;) heating; emollient; drawing; a phlegmagogue; lenitive; digestive; used as a liniment, good for the niqoris [or gout], and [especially] the nasaA [or sciatica], and the [malignant species of leprosy termed] baraS (Ḳ,) and the [mild species thereof termed] bahaq; clearing to the face; good for the alopecia, especially the wild sort thereof; (TA;) its smoke drives away serpents, or, as in the Kánoon, venomous or noxious reptiles or the like; (TA;) its juice, dropped, allays earache, (Ḳ,) and in like manner its oil; (TA;) and its powder, upon the aching tooth, is extremely efficacious, (Ḳ,) especially when Hilotiyt [or assa] has been cooked with it: (TA: [in which many other properties assigned to it are mentioned:]) n. un. with p {xarodalapN}. (Ṣ.)
Alxarodalu AlfaArisiI-u is A certain plant in Egypt known by the name of HaXiyXapu Als-uloTaAni. (Ḳ.)

1. xaraza, aor _i and _u, inf. n. xarozN, He sewed (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) a skin, or hide, (Mṣb, TA,) or a boot, &c. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say, kalaAmu fulaAnK kaxarozi AlUimaMCi [The language of such a one is like the female slaves' sewing of skins]; i. e., [its ornaments, lit.] its pearls, and its cowries, are far apart. (A, TA.)

xarazN [a coll. gen. n.,] a word of well-known meaning, (Mṣb,) [i.e., Beads;] what are strung: (Ṣ:) a thing that is hung [or rather things that are hung] upon the neck, made of coloured stone, red and green: (Ḥar p. 431:) or gems, or similar stones, both good and bad: (JK:) [also factitious gems, and the like: (see fusayofisaMCu as explained in the Ḳ, &c.:)] n. un. xarazapN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) the latter signifying [a single bead;] what is strung: (Ḳ:) and also, (i.e. the latter,) a gem, or precious stone, (Ḳ, TA,) such [for instance] as is set in a ring, whether good or bad: (TA:) pl. of the latter, xarazaAtN. (TA.) Hence, xarazaAtu Almaliki, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Almuloki, (Ṣ, A,) The gems of the king's crown: when the king had reigned a year, a xarazap was added to his crown, in order that the number of the years of his reign might be known: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) such is said to have been the case. (Ṣ.) You say, OuwtiIa xarazaAti Almuloki sit-iyna Hij-apF ‡ [meaning He reigned sixty years: lit., he received the gems of the crown sixty years]. (A.)
xarazapu AlEayoni signifies The Hadaqap [or lens] of the eye. (TA in art. Hdq)
And xarazN is also applied to The small shells called wadaE. (Ṣ* and Ḳ* and TA in art. wdE.)
It also signifies ‡ The vertebræ of the back, (Ṣ, A, TA,) and of the neck: each one is called xarazapN: which latter is also explained as meaning ‡ what is between two vertebræ. (TA.)
xarozapN, with fet-ḥ, A single puncture [or stitchhole, made in sewing a skin or a boot; and so xurozapN]; syn. garozapN. (TA.)

xurozapN i. q. kutobapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) A seam, or suture, in a skin, or hide, (KL, PṢ, TḲ,*) or in a boot, &c.; (PṢ;) [app. made by sewing together two edges so that one laps over the other: and app. also a single stitch in such a seam;] what is between two punctures; i. e., every puncture with its thread: (TA:) also, a puncture, or stitch-hole, in a skin [&c.]: (TA voce wacaAbN: [its pl. being there said to be syn. with xurabN, pl. of xurobapN: and this last meaning, (for evidences of the correctness of which see OatomN and OatuwmN and xuSofapN, &c.,) common to it and to xarozapN, it perhaps bears in exs. here following:]) and any round perforation: (JM:) pl. xurazN (Ṣ, Ḳ) [and app. xuruwzN, which see below]. AijomaEo sayorayoni fiI xurozapK [lit, Conjoin thou two thongs in a single seam, or stick, or puncture,] is a prov., meaning ‡ accomplish thou two wants at once. (TA.) And you say to him who seeks to attain two wants together, sayorayoni fiI xurozapK [lit., Wilt thou conjoin two thongs in a single seam, or stitch, or puncture? the first word being in the accus. case because OatajomaEu is understood]. (A, TA.)
Also † The foramen podicis: and † the foramen vaginæ. (TA voce xurobapN.)
xarazapN; pl. xarazaAtN: n. un. of xarazN [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)
xuruwzu Als-afiynapi [The seams of the ship: xuruwzN being app. a pl. of xurozapN, like as xuruwbN is a pl. of xurobapN]. (Ḳ voce jam-apN q. v.)
xiraAzapN The art, or occupation, of sewing [skins, or hides, or] boots, &c. (A, Ḳ.)
xar-aAzN A sewer of [skins, or hides, or] boots,, &c. (Ṣ, A.)
mixorazN [and vulg. mixoraAzN↓] The instrument [i. e. the needle, or awl,] with which one sews [skins, or hides, or] boots, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
muxar-azN Any bird, (A, Ḳ,) as a pigeon, &c., (TA,) having upon its wings marks resembling xaraz [or beads]. (A, Ḳ, TA.)
mixoraAzN: see mixorazN.

hom.sense: 1. xarisa, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxorasu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xarasN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He (a man) was dumb; was naturally, by conformation, prevented from speaking; (Mṣb;) [he was destitute of the faculty of speech, by natural conformation, like the beast: see Oaxorasu:] or he was, or became, tonguetied, or withheld from speech, (A, Ḳ,) either from inability to find words to express what he would say, or by natural conformation [of the organs of speech]. (TA.) You say also xarisa Almajolisu The assembly was, or became, mute, or speechless. (A.)

xarasa AlmaroOapa, (Lḥ, IAth,) aor. _u {yaxorusu}, (Lḥ,) [inf. n., app., xarosN,] He fed the woman with what is termed xurosap; (Lḥ, IAth;) He fed her on the occasion of child-birth; (Lḥ;) as also xr-s↓ EalyhaA, inf. n. taxoriysN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and taxorisapN. (TA.) In like manner you say, xr-shaA↓, inf. n. taxoriysN; and xrs EanohaA; [so in the TA, without any syll. signs to the verb;] He made for her what is termed xurosap. (TA.) And xurisato↓, (Ṣ, L,) or xurisato, (so in a copy of the A,) She was fed with what is so termed: (A:) or a feast on the occasion of her having given birth to a child was made for her. (Ṣ, L.)
xarisa, aor. _a {yaxorasu}, He drank from the [kind of wine-jar called] xaros, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) i. e. the dan-. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see xarasa, in three places.

4. Axrshu Qll-ehu [God made him to be dumb: see xarisa]: (Ṣ:) God made him to be tonguetied, or speechless, (A, Ḳ,) either from inability to find words to express what he would say, or by natural conformation [of the organs of speech]. (TA.)

5. txr-st She made for herself the food for the occasion of child-birth, (A,* Ḳ,) i. e., what is called xurosap. (TA.)
Hence the prov. taxar-asiI yaAnafosu laA muxar-isapa laki (A,* TA) Make thou the food for child-birth for thyself, O self: there is no maker of it for thee: said by a woman who had given birth to a child and had not any one to care for her: alluding to a man's taking care for himself: (Ḳ, TA:) and also related [in the A] without the words yA nfs. (TA.)

6. txArs [He feigned himself dumb, or speechless,] is from xarisa Almajolisu: hence UicaA Xahidota mano laA yafohamu Eanoka fataxaArasN [When thou art present with, or beholdest, him who will not understand what thou sayest, then feign thyself dumb, or speechless]. (A.)
xarosN A [wine-jar such as is called] dan-; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xirosN↓, (Kr, Ḳ,) and xiroSN: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxoraAsN (JK) and [of mult.] xuruwsN. (Ḳ.)
xurosN Food that is prepared on the occasion of the birth of a child; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also xiraAsN↓. (Lḥ, TA.) IJ seems to assign to it also the sense of xurosapN. (TA.)

Hence, as also ↓the second word, A feast, or banquet, that is prepared on that occasion, and to which people are invited: so in a trad. of Hassán, kaAna UicaA duEiIa UilaI TaEaAmK qaAla UilaI EurosK Oamo xurosK Oamo UiEocaArK [He used, when he was invited to food, to say, To a weddingfeast, or a feast for child-birth, or a circumcisionfeast?]; and if it were for one of these, he consented: but if not, he did not consent. (TA.)
xirosN: see xarosN.

xurosapN Food for a woman who has given birth to a child; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) what is made for her, such as fariyqap and the like; as also [xuroSapN,] with S. (TA.) xurosapu maroyama [The child-birth-food of Maryam], applied to dates, and occurring in a trad., alludes to verse 25 of chap. xix. of the Ḳur, wahuz-iI Uilayoki Alx: and Khálid Ibn-Safwán uses in the same manner the phrase taxorisapu↓ maroyama; in which txrsp is an inf. n. used as a subst.; or it may be a subst., like taworiyapN. (TA.)
xurosaI A she-camel that does not utter the cry termed rugaMC. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
xiraAsN: see xurosN, in two places.

xaruwsN A bikor [or female that has not yet brought forth] in the first period of her pregnancy: and (some say, Ṣ) one for whom xurosap is made: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and one having a scanty flow of milk. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
xar-aAsN A maker (Ṣ, TA) and seller (Ḳ, TA) of the [kind of wine-jar called] xaros. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
And A vintner. (JK, TA.)

Oaxorasu (Ṣ, &c.) Dumb; prevented from speaking by natural conformation; (Mṣb;) speechless, or destitute of the faculty of speech, by natural conformation, (T and Mṣb in art. bkm,) like the beast that lacks the faculty of articulation; (T ibid;) differing from Oabokamu, q. v.: (T and Mṣb ibid:) or tonguetied, or speechless, (Ḳ, TA,) either from inability to find words to express what he would say, or by natural conformation [of the organs of speech]: (TA:) fem. xarosaMCu: (Mṣb:) pl. xurosN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and xurosaAnN. (Ḳ.)

jamalN Oaxorasu A he-camel that has no perforation to his XiqoXiqap, for his bray to issue therefrom, so that he reiterates it therein: such a one they like to send among the [she-camels in the state in which they are termed] Xawol, because in most instances he begets females: and naAqapN xarosaMCu a she-camel that is not heard to utter the cry termed rugaMC. (TA.)

EalamN Oaxorasu ‡ A sign of the way, (Ḳ,) [or a mountain,] from which, (A,) or at, or in, which, (fiyhi, Ḳ,) no echo is heard: (A, Ḳ:) or a sign of the way in the mountain whereof no echo is heard: (Lth, T:) or [it seems to be applied to a mountain where no echo is heard; for] it is said when no sound of an echo is heard in the mountain. (Ṣ.)
saHaAbapN xarosaMCu ‡ A cloud that does not thunder: (A:) or a cloud in which is no thunder nor lightning, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and of which no sound is heard; which is mostly in winter. (TA.)
EayonN xarosaMCu † A spring of the running whereof no sound is heard. (TA.)
SaxorapN xarosaMCu † A hard and solid rock: (Akh, TA:) and EiZaAmN xurosN † hard and solid bones. (Th, TA.)

katiybapN xarosaMCu ‡ An army, or a portion thereof, without any clamour or confused noise: (A:) or whereof no sound is heard, by reason of their staidness in war: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or that is silent, by reason of the multitude of the coats of mail, without any clashing of arms. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

labanN Oaxorasu ‡ Thick milk, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) that makes no sound in the vessel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or that does not shake about in its vessel: (A:) or thick milk, of which no sound is heard when it is poured out: (Az, TA:) and XarobapN xarosaMCu † a thick draught of milk. (M, TA.)
wal-iAniI EiroDFA Oaxorasa Oamorasa [or EuroDFA?] † He turned from me, and would not speak to me. (Fr, TA.)
xarosaMCu † A viper: (A:) pl. xurosN. (TA.)
Hence, (A,) ramaAhu bixarosaMCa ‡ He smote him with a calamity. (A, Ḳ.*)
taxorisapu maroyama: see xurosapN.

1. xaraXahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoriXu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaroXN, (Lth,) He, or it, (namely, a cat, A,) scratched him, or it, (namely, the skin, A,) with the nails, (Lth, Ṣ, A,* Ḳ,) in any part of the body, (Lth,) so as to cause bleeding or not; or wounded him in the outer skin, so as to make it bleed or not; or lacerated it (namely, the skin) little or much; or tore off its surface with a stick or the like; syn. xadaXahu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [as also HaraXahu;] and so AxtrXhu↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and AxtrXhu↓ biZuforihi He scratched him,, &c., with his nail. (TA.) You say also, xaraXahu biHadiydapK wanaHowihaA [He scratched it with an iron thing, and the like]. (Ḳ.)
It (a fly) bit him; (A, TA;) as also HaraXahu. (TA.)

xaraXa AlbaEiyra, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He drew the camel (Ṣ, Ḳ) towards him (Ṣ) with the mixoraAX, i. e., the miHojan: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he struck the camel and then drew him to wards him therewith; desiring thereby to excite him to quicken his pace: and he struck him with its extremity in the side of his neck, or [elsewhere] in his skin, so as to scrape off from him his fur. (TA.) [See also HaraXahu.]

xaraXa liEiyaAlihi, aor. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) † He earned for his family, or household; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) collected, and practised artifice, for them; (TA;) and sought sustenance for them; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AxtrX↓. (Ḳ.)

You say also, fulaAnN yaxoriXu mino fulaAnK AlX-aIoCa baEoda AlX-aIoCi ‡ Such a one takes from such a one thing after thing; as also yaxotariXuhu↓. (A.) And maA xaraXa XayoYFA ‡ He has not taken anything. (TA.) And fulaAnN yataxar-aXu↓ mino fulaAnK AlX-aIoCa ‡ Such a one takes and acquires from such a one the thing. (TA.) And muxaAraXapN↓ signifies † The taking against one's will. (TA.)
2. xr-Xhu, inf. n. taxoriyXN, [He scratched him, or it, with the nails, vehemently, or much; like xd-Xhu.] (TA.)
xr-X Alz-aroEu, inf. n. as above, † The seed-produce put forth the first extremity of the ear. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
3. xArXhu, inf. n. muxaAraXapN and xiraAXN, [He scratched him with the nails, being scratched by him in like manner; like xAdXhu.] (TA.)
[Hence,] kalobu xiraAXK [An irritable, or a quarrel-some, dog]; like kalobu hiraAXK: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) IF holds that the x is a substitute for h. (TA.)
See also 1, last signification.
5: see 1, last sentence but one.
6. txArXt AlkilaAbu, (A, Ḳ,) and Als-anaAniyru, (A,) The dogs, and the cats, [scratched, or] fought and assailed, (thArXt, Ḳ, TA,) and lacerated, or tore, one another. (TA.)
8: see 1, in four places.
xaroXN Gain; or earning: pl. xuruwXN. (TA.)

xiroXaMCN The skin, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or slough, (A, TA,) of a serpent. (Ṣ, A, TA.) To this one likens a thin, transparent, shirt. (A, TA.) AḤn applies its pl., xaraAXiI-u, metaphorically, to [the skins of] all [animals of the class termed] HaXaraAt. (TA.)

The upper covering, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) which is dry, or tough, or hard, [app. meaning the shell,] (TA,) of an egg, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) after it has been broken, and what was in it, (Ṣ, TA,) of moisture, (TA,) has been extracted: (Ṣ, TA:) or the inner skin, (T, TA,) or inner covering, (A,) of an egg; (T, A, TA;) also called giroqiYN: (TA:) pl. as above. (TA.)
To this is likened † Anything in which are an inflation and a bursting and holes. (AZ,* Ṣ.)
The thin skin upon the surface of milk: (Ḳ:) or the bubbles that rise upon the surface of milk: (A:) froth, or foam. (Ṣ, TA. [See an ex. in a verse cited voce qaSara.])

‡ Phlegm: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or viscous phlegm in the chest: (TA:) and what is termed nuxaAmap, q. v. (A, TA.) You say, OaloqaI xaraAXiI-a Sadorihi ‡ He cast forth the phlegm (lit. phlegms) of his chest. (Ṣ.) [See also a tropical meaning below.] And OaloqaI mino Sadorihi xaraAXiI-a ‡ He cast forth from his chest what is termed nuxaAmap (Az, A, TA) and phlegm: (A:) or thick spittle. (Ḳ.)
xiroXaMCu AlEasali The was of honey, and the dead bees in it: (TA:) or the young bees, or the wings, that are upon honey. (M and L in art. jv.)
TalaEati AlX-amosu fiI xiroXaMCK ‡ The sun rose in dust; (Ṣ, A;) syn. gabarap. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
OaloqaI fulaAnN xaraAXiI-a Sadorihi ‡ Such a one cast forth what he concealed of rancours and enmities, and of grief. (A, TA.)
xuraAXapN What falls from a thing when it is scratched with an iron instrument or the like. (Ḳ.)
mixoraXN: see what next follows.

mixoraAXN A miHojan [or stick of which the end is naturally curved, or crooked]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [see 1;] sometimes written [miHoraXN,] with H: (Ṣ:) a stick with a curved, or crooked, head, like the SawolajaAn; as also mixoraXN↓. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xaraSa Aln-axola, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaxoruSu} (A, Mṣb) [and _i, as appears from what follows,] inf. n. xaroSN, (Ṣ, A Mgh, Mṣb,) [and xiroSN is also allowable, (see what follows,)] He computed by conjecture the quantity of the fruit upon the palm-trees: (A, Mgh, Mṣb:) or he computed by conjecture the quantity that was upon the palmtrees of fresh ripe dates that would be dried dates. (Ṣ.) xaroSN signifies The computing quantity by conjecture; (A, Ḳ, TA;) conjecturing; opining: or forming an opinion of a thing of which one is not certain: you say, xaraSa AlEadada, aor. _u {yaxoruSu} and _i {yaxoriSu}, inf. n. xaroSN and xiroSN, the latter said by ISh to be like EilomN as inf. n. of Ealima, and said by Az to be allowable because a simple subst. is put in the place of an inf. n., He computed by conjecture the number: and hence xaroSu Aln-axoli, and Alt-amori, [the computing by conjecture the quantity of fruit upon palm-trees, and of dates,] because xaroSN is the computing quantity by opinion, not by knowledge. (TA.)
xaroSN also signifies Any speaking by opinion, or conjecture. (Ḳ,* TA.) You say, xaraSa fiyhi He spoke of him, or it, by opinion, or conjecture. (TḲ.)

And hence, (TA,) xaraSa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxoruSu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. xaroSN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) ‡ He lied; spoke falsely; said what was untrue; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) as also txr-S↓. (Ṣ.) You say also, Ealayohi ‡ txr-S↓ ‡ He forged a lie against him. (A, Ḳ, TA.) And qaAla celika taxar-uSFA↓ ‡ [He said that forging a lie]. (A.) And AxtrS↓ Alqawola, (A, Ḳ,*) and txr-iShu↓, (A,) ‡ He forged the saying. (A, Ḳ.*)

xariSa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxoraSu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaraSN, (Ṣ, A,) He (a man) was hungry and cold: (Ṣ, A:*) or hungry in cold. (Ḳ.) Being hungry without being cold is not termed xaraSN: but being cold without being hungry is termed xaSarN. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in four places, near the end.
8: see 1, near the end.

xuroSN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xiroSN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) A ring: (Mṣb:) or a ring of gold, and of silver: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or an ear-ring with one bead, (A, TA,) of the kind called quroT: (TA:) or the ring of a quroT: (Ḳ:) or a small ring; one of the ornaments of women; (Sh, Ḳ;) in the form of the quroT or some other thing: (Sh:) pl. xiroSaAnN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Hence,] maA tamoliku fulaAnapu xuroSFA, meaning ‡ Such a woman has not in her possession anything. (A.)

hom.sense: xiroSN a subst. from xaraSa as explained above; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) Conjectural computation of quantity: (ISh:) or quantity computed by conjecture of the fruit upon palm-trees. (A, Mgh.) You say, kamo xiroSu naxolika [What is the conjectural computation of the quantity, or the quantity computed by conjecture, of the produce of thy palm-trees?]. (TA.) And kamo xiroSu OaroDika [What is the conjectural computation, or the quantity computed by conjecture, of the produce of the palm-trees of thy land?]. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
See also xuroSN.
And see xarosN.

entry.sense: xariSN A man hungry and cold: (Ṣ, TA:) or hungry in cold: (Ḳ:) and xaAriSN↓ signifies the same. (TA.) [See also xaSirN.]
xuroSapN Food for a woman who has given birth to a child: (Ḳ:) app. a dial. var. of xurosapN. (TA.)
xar-aASN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: xaAriSN One who computes by conjecture the quantity of the fruit upon palm-trees: pl. xur-aASN. (A,* TA.)

‡ A liar; (Mṣb, TA;) as also xar-aASN↓. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA.) qutila Alxar-aASuwna, in the Ḳur [li. 10], (TA,) means, ‡ Slain be the liars; (Fr, Zj, A, Bḍ, TA;) i. e., cursed be they; (Bḍ;) who say that Moḥammad is a poet, and the like thereof, conjecturing that which they know not: (Fr, TA:) or it may mean, they who only opine, and do not ascertain; and therefore act according to that which they know not. (Zj, TA.)
See also xariSN.

1. xaraTa Alwaraqa, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaxoruTu} and _i {yaxoriTu}, inf. n. xaroTN, (Mṣb,) He rubbed off the leaves (Ṣ, Mṣb) from the branches, (Mṣb,) by grasping the upper part, and passing the hand along it to the lower part. (Ṣ.)

xaraTa AlX-ajara, aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He pulled off the leaves, (Ḳ, TA,) and the bark, or peel, (TA,) from the trees (Ḳ, TA) with his hand [in the manner above described]. (TA.) It is said in a prov., duwnahu xaroTu AlqataAdi [Before one can attain it he has to strip the tragacanth of its leaves by grasping each branch and drawing his hand down it: i. e. he has to perform what will be extremely difficult, if not impossible]. (Ṣ, TA. [In the Ṣ and L in art. qtd, we find mino duwnihi.]) You say also, xaraTa AlEunoquwda He pulled off the grapes, or the like, from the bunch with all his fingers: (AHeyth:) or he put the bunch in his mouth and drew forth its stalk bare; as also AxtrThu↓. (Ḳ.) It is said of Moḥammad, kaAna yaOokulu AlEinaba xaroTFA [He used to eat grapes by putting the bunch in his mouth and drawing forth its stalk bare: or by stripping them off with all his fingers]. (TA.)

xaraTa AlEuwda, aor. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ,) He removed the bark, or peel, from the wood, or stick, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and planed it, or made it even, (Ḳ,) with the mixoraT, which is also called baloT and buloT, (TA in art. blaT,) or with his hand. (TA in the present art.)
[Hence, in modern Arabic, He turned the wood, or stick; i. e., shaped it, or made it round, with a lathe.]
xaraTa AlHadiyda, inf. n. as above, He made the iron long, like a column, or pole, or rod. (Ṣ.)
xaraTa AljawaAhira He collected the jewels in a xariyTap [q. v.]. (MF.)

entry.sense: 4. AxrT AlxariyTapa He bound, or made fast, the xryTp [q. v.]; or closed it by inserting its loops one into another; syn. OaXorajahaA. (Ṣ, Ḳ *)
7. AnxrT [It (a piece of wood, or a stick,) had its bark, or peel, removed, and was planed, or made even, with the mixoraT, (as appears from what here follows,) or with the hand: see 1].
[And hence,] AnxrT jisomuhu ‡ His body became slender; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as though it were barked and planed (xuriTa) with the mixoraT. (TA.)
8: see 1.
[Hence,] AxtrT sayofahu, (Ṣ,) or Als-ayofa, (Mgh, Ḳ,) ‡ He drew his sword, or the sword, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) from its scabbard. (Mgh, TA.)
xuraATapN The parings, or shavings, that fall from the work of the xar-aAT; like nujaArapN and nuHaAtapN. (TA.)
What falls from a bunch of grapes, or the like, when the fruit is pulled off with all the fingers. (AHeyth.)
xiraATapN The art, or craft, of the xar-aAT. (Ḳ.)

xariyTapN A receptacle, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [a pouch,] or thing like a kiys [or purse], (Lth, Mṣb,) of leather, (Lth, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or of rag, (Lth,) or other material, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is bound, or made fast, or closed by the insertion of its loops one into another, (yuXoraju, Lth, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) upon its contents: (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. xaraAYiTu. (Mṣb.)
Also A thing likened thereto, which is made for the letters of the sultán, and of prefects, or agents, to be sent therein. (Lth, L.)
Also A similar thing [which was formerly, in the time of paganism,] put upon the head of the she-camel [that was] confined [to perish] at the tomb of a dead person. (Lth.)
[Also The pod, or oblong capsule or pericarp, of sesamum and the like: pl. as above. Used in this sense by writers on botany, and in the spoken language of the present day.]
See also bidaAdN.
xaraAYiTiI-N [A maker, or seller, of xaraAYiT, pl. of xariyTapN]; a rel. n. formed from a pl., like OanomaA TiI-N. (TA.)

xar-aATN One whose occupation is to remove the bark, or peel, of wood, or sticks, and to plane it, or make it even, (Ḳ,) with the mixoraT, which is also called baloT and buloT, (TA in art. blT,) or with the hand. (TA in the present art.)
[Hence, in modern Arabic, A turner of wood, &c.]
mixoraTN The iron instrument with which the xar-aAT performs his work; also called baloTN and buloTN. (TA in art. blT, q. v.)
maxoruwTN [pass. part. n. of 1].

† A man (TA) having a scanty beard: (Ḳ, TA:) [or you say,] rajulN maxoruwTu All-iHoyapi A man having a beard in which is length without breadth. (Ṣ.) And liHoyapN maxoruwTapN † A beard that is scanty in its side, (Ḳ,) or, correctly, in its two sides, (TA,) and lank and long in the part on and beneath the chin. (Ḳ.)
† A face in which is length (Ḳ, TA) without breadth. (TA.) You say, rajulN maxoruwTu Alwajohi † A man whose face has length without breadth. (Ṣ.)
biYorN maxoruwTapN ‡ A narrow well. (A, TA.)
[maxoruwTN and maxoruwTapN↓, in mathematics, signify A cone.]
maxoruwTapN: see what next precedes.
[maxoruwTiI-N, in mathematics, Conical.]
Q. 1. xaroTamahu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaroTamapN, (TḲ,) He hit, or struck, his xuroTuwm [or nose,, &c.]: or he twisted it. (Ḳ.)
Q. 3. AixoranoTama He (a man, TA) elevated his nose: (Ḳ:) or twisted it, and was silent, in his anger: (TA:) and was proud and angry, (Ḳ, TA,) raising his head. (TA.)
xuroTumN and xuroTum-N: see xuroTuwmN.
xuroTumaAnN Long, or tall: (JK, Ḳ:) or longnosed. (TA.) And A man having a large nose. (IKh, IB.)

hom.sense: xuroTuwmN The nose, (AZ, JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [properly,] accord. to Th, of a beast of prey: (TA:) or the fore part thereof: (Ḳ:) or a large, or an elevated, nose: (MA:) or the part upon which a man contracts, or closes, the HanakaAni [or upper and lower portions of the mouth]: as also xuroTumN↓; (Ḳ;) sometimes, by poetic license, written xuroTum-N↓: (TA:) or it signifies also the part upon which contracts, or closes, the front of the HanakaAni: (JK:) [and a snout: often used in this sense; and so, in describing the fish termed kawosaj, in the Ṣ and Ḳ:] and the proboscis of an elephant; and, as being likened thereto, of a flea: (Th, TA:) pl. xaraATiymu. (Mṣb.) sanasimuhu EalaI AlxuroTuwmi, in the Ḳur [lxviii. 16], means ‡ [We will brand him] upon the nose; the nose of a man being thus termed metaphorically: (ISd, TA:) or it is like the phrase jadaEotu Oanofahu; and means † we will stigmatize him with indelible disgrace; the term xrTwm, which signifies the “proboscis” of an elephant, being applied to his nose because it is regarded as unseemly: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it means † [we will brand him] upon the face. (Fr, Th, TA.)
[Hence, † A spout. You say] AlAboriyqu AnaMCN lahu xuroTuwmN † [The Abryq is a vessel having a spout]. (Mgh in art. brq, and Bḍ and Jel in lvi. 18.)
[Hence also, † The pointed toe of a boot and the like: pl. as above: see xifaAfN muxaroTayapN, below.]
[And app. † The point of a sword: whence,] cuw AlxuroTuwmi the name of a certain sword. (Ḳ.)
[Hence, also,] xaraATiymu Alqawomi ‡ The chiefs of the people or party; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) those who are made the foremost of the people or party, in affairs, (JK, TA,) and in the military forces. (JK.)
Also Wine: (JK, Ṣ:) or wine that quickly intoxicates: (Ḳ:) and the juice that first flows from the grapes, before they are trodden. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xuraATimN A woman advanced in age. (M, Ḳ.)

[muxaroTamN † Elongated like a snout or nose; and so, app., muxoranoTimN↓: see a verse cited voce mataAwiju. Hence,] xifaAfN muxaroTamapN [in the sing. xuf-N muxaroTamN (occurring in the Ḳ in art fqE)] i. q. caAtu xaraATiyma↓; i. e. † [Boots] having their fore parts pointed. (TA.)
muxornoTimN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Also Angry and proud, with his head raised: (Ṣ:) or angry when his nose is twisted. (JK.) [See AinobaAEa, in art. bwE.]

hom.sense: 1. xaraEahu, (Ṣ,) aor. _a {yaxoraEu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaroEN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He cut it, or divided it, lengthwise; slit it; split it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AxtrEhu↓. (Ḳ.)

xaraEa Oucuna AlX-aApi, aor. and inf. n. as above, He slit the ear of the sheep, or goat: or he slit it in the middle, cutting the upper part thereof lengthwise, so that it became three pieces, and the middle piece hung down upon the cavity of the ear. (TA.)

xaruEa, aor. _u {yaxoruEu}, inf. n. xaraAEapN (IDrd, Ḳ) and xuruwEapN, (IDrd, TA,) in the Ḳ xuruwEN, which is a mistake, (TA,) and xuroEN, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) [and quasi-inf. n. xaraEN, which see below,] He was, or became, supple in the joints: (IDrd, Ḳ:) and it (a thing, TA) was, or became, soft, yielding, flaccid, flabby, lax, or fragile. (Ḳ.)

xariEa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxoraEu}, (Ḳ,) [inf. n. xaraEN, app. signifies the same as xaruEa: (see xaraEN, below:) and also] He (a man, Ṣ, IAth) was, or became, weak, or infirm; (Ṣ, IAth, Ḳ) as also AnxrE↓: (Lth, Ḳ:) he was, or became, weak, or infirm, in body, after firmness, strength, or hardiness: (IAạr:) and he (a man, Lth) was, or became, languid, or languishing, or broken in spirit; syn. Ainokasara; as also AnxrE↓: (Lth, Ḳ:) and [in like manner] txr-E↓ he (a man) was, or became, relaxed, or flaccid, and weak, or infirm, and soft, or tender. (TA.)
† He (a man) was, or became, weak (AisotaroxaI) in his opinion, after being strong. (IAạr.)

Also, (Sh, IAth,) inf. n. xaraEN, (Sh, Ḳ,) † He (a man, Sh, IAth) became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or bereft of his reason or intellect, in consequence of shame, or fear, or grief, or the like. (Sh, IAth, Ḳ.) Hence the saying of Aboo-Tálib, when death overtook him, [and he was urged to make profession of El-Islám,] lawolaA rahobapa Oano taquwla qurayoXN waharahu AlxaraEu lafaEalotu † [Were it not for fear that Kureysh would say, “Confusion,”, &c. “put him into a state from which there was no escape for him, “ I would do what thou desirest]. (TA.)
xariEati Aln-axolapu The palm-tree lost the stumps of its lopped branches [from its trunk, which thus became comparatively smooth]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1:
and 7.
7. AnxrE It became cut, or divided, lengthwise; it became slit, or split; it slit, or split. (Ṣ.) And AnxrEt AlqanaApu The spear-shaft split, and broke into pieces, or into small pieces. (Ḳ.)
See also two significations above, voce xariEa, in two places.
[Whence,] AinoxaraEotu lahu † I became gentle, or mild, to him. (TA.)

hom.sense: 8. AxtrEhu: see 1, first signification.
He broke it off; namely a branch, or piece of wood, from a tree. (TA.)
He cut it off for himself; or took it; namely, a man's property, &c. (TA.)
He acted treacherously towards him, (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ,) and took of his property; (Ḳ;) as also AxtzEhu, with z (TA.)
He expended it; exhausted it; caused it to pass away and come to an end, or to cease; or made an end of it. (ISh, Ḳ.)
AxtrE Ald-aAb-apa He made use of, or rode, the beast of another person for some days, and then restored it. (Ibn -ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

He did it, or produced it, without premeditation; syn. Airotajalahu: (TA:) or AiXotaq-ahu [app. here meaning he constructed it, or founded it, (banaAhu) without premeditation; this meaning being one assigned to AXtq-h in its proper art. in the TA]: (Ṣ:) or he originated it; invented it; devised it; excogitated it; innovated it; made it, did it, produced it, caused it to be or exist, or brought it into existence, newly, for the first time, it not having been or existed before, and not after the similitude of anything preexisting; syn. OanoXaOahu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and AibotadaEahu, (Ṣ, O,) or AibotadaOahu. (Ḳ.) You say, AxtrE Qll-ehu AlOaXoyaMCa God originated, brought into existence, or created, the things [that exist], without any means, or second cause. (TA.) And AxtrE baATilFA He forged a falsehood. (A, TA.)

xaraEN A mark in the ear of a sheep or goat; the upper part [OaEolaI, for which we find in the CK EalI,] of the animal's ears being cut (yuqoTaEu, in the CK tuqaT-aEu,) lengthwise, so that the ear becomes three pieces, and the middle piece hangs down upon the cavity of the ear. (Ḳ, TA.)
Suppleness of the joints: (IDrd, Ḳ:) and softness, yieldingness, flaccidity, flabbiness, laxness, or fragility, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in a thing. (Ṣ.) [See xaruEa.]
‡ Cowardice; and weakness, or feebleness, and languor, or languidness; in a man. (TA.) [See also xariEa.]

entry.sense: xariEN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xariyEN↓ (Ḳ) Weak, or infirm; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a man: (Ṣ:) anything weak; and soft, yielding, flaccid, flabby, lax, or fragile: (O:) also the former, applied to a young camel, weak; or, as some say, small, that is [or may be] raised, or lifted: and, applied to a branch, soft, tender, or supple. (TA.)

xiroEapN a subst. from AixotaraEa AlX-aIoCa signifying Airotajalahu [&c.; app. meaning A thing done, or produced, without premeditation;, &c.; like bidoEapN from AibotadaEahu, a syn. of AixotaraEahu, q. v.]. (TA.)
xaruwEN: see xariyEN.

xirowEN Any weak, bending plant, of whatever kind it be: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) any plant weak, or fragile, (qaSiyf,) and sappy, whether it be a tree or a herb: (TA:) a plant weak by reason of its softness, or tenderness, and sappiness. (Ṣgh.) [See also xariEN.]

Hence, as some say, (TA,) [The ricinus communis; common palma Christi; or castor-oil-plant;] a certain plant, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known, (Ṣ,) soft, tender, or pliant, (Mṣb,) not serving for pasturage, (Ḳ,) bearing a berry resembling sparrows' eggs, called Als-imosimu AlhinodiI-u; accord to Ibn-Jezleh, the best thereof is that called AlbaHoriI-u; it has the property of loosening phlegm, and it is useful for counteracting the colic and palsy and the [disease in the face called] laqowap, the dose extending to a mivoqaAl. (TA.) The word is of the measure fiEowalN; (Mṣb;) and J says [in the Ṣ] that there is no other word of the same measure except EitowadN, which is the name of a certain valley; but to this have been added cirowadN, the name of a certain mountain; and EitowarN, the name of a certain valley, and not a mistranscription of EitowadN; and jidowalN, a dial. var. of jadowalN. (TA.)
[Hence also] AimoraOapN xirowaEapN A beautiful, and soft, or tender, woman: and [the pl.] xaraAwiyEu, applied to women, signifies [the same, or merely] beautiful. (TA.)
And xirowaEN is likewise applied to youth, or youthfulness, and to life, meaning ‡ Soft, or delicate. (TA.)
xariyEN: see xariEN.
Anything that quickly breaks. (TA.)
Soft; applied to a lip (Xafap): (TA:) and pendulous; applied to the lip of a camel. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

Applied to a woman, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) Youthful, and soft, tender, or delicate: or beautiful: (TA:) or that walks with an affected bending of the body, and with softness, or delicacy: (Mṣb:) or that affects a bending of the body by reason of softness, or delicacy; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xiriyEapN and xaruwEN↓: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) or † vitious; or immoral; or an adulteress; or a fornicatress; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) but this explanation is disallowed by Aṣ: (Ṣ:) or † that does not repel the hand of a feeler, or toucher; as though she were gentle, or mild, (tanoxariEu,) to him; as also with p {xariyEapN}: or hard, or † impudent, not caring for what is said or done, and inordinately brisk, lively, or sprightly: pl. xuruwEN and xaraAYiEu and xur-aEN. (TA.) Also † One who induces, or is an object of, suspicion; because such a person fears, and is therefore as though he were weak. (TA.)
Also, [as a subst.,] A branch; because of its softness, or tenderness, and its bending. (TA.)
xaraAEapN a dial. var. of xalaAEapN, which is syn. with daEaArapN [i.e. Vice, or immorality; or vitious, or immoral, conduct;, &c.]. (Ṣ.)
XaApN maxoruwEapN A sheep, or goat, having the mark termed xaraEN [q. v.] in the ear. (Ḳ.)

xaroEabN (Ḳ) and xaroEabapN↓ (TA) and xuroEuwbN↓ and xuroEuwbapN↓ (Ḳ) A branch, or twig, until a year old; or of a year's growth: or fresh, or juicy, and tall: (Ḳ, TA:) or (TA) soft, or tender, and of recent growth, (Ḳ, TA,) that has not yet become hard: (TA:) or xuroEuwbN↓ [is an epithet, and] signifies a bending branch or twig. (Ṣ.) [Compare xariEN, and xirowaEN, and xariyEN.]

Also, [i. e. all the words above,] (Ḳ,) or xaroEabapN↓ [only], (TA,) A young woman of goodly make, soft, or tender: (Ḳ:) or a young woman large in body, and of goodly make: or soft, or tender, and pliant: (TA:) or fair, tender, or pliant, fat, large in body, fleshy, with small, or delicate, bones: (Ḳ:) or fair: (TA:) or soft, or pliant, in the waist, and tall: (Aṣ, TA:) or large in the body, and fleshy: (TA:) or xuroEuwbapN↓ and xaroEabapN↓ signify a girl slender in the bones, (Ṣ, TA,) having much flesh, (TA,) and soft, or tender: (Ṣ, TA:) or a young woman of goodly stature, resembling a twig (xuroEuwbapi) of a year's growth. (Lth, TA.) And xaroEabN signifies A soft, or tender, body. (TA.) And A tall and fleshy man. (Ḳ.)
xaroEabapN: see above, in three places.
xuroEuwbN: see xaroEabN, in two places.
Also A tall and well-made camel: (Ṣ:) or a tall and large she-camel: and one having much milk. (Ḳ.)
xuroEuwbapN: see xaroEabN, in two places.
Also A piece of a gourd, and of a cucumber, and of fat; as in the L, &c.: in the Ḳ written xucoEuwbapN. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xarafa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxorufu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. xarofN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and maxorafN and xaraAfN and xiraAfN; (Ḳ;) and Axtrf↓; (Ṣ Mṣb, Ḳ;) He gathered, or plucked, fruit: (Ṣ Ḳ:) or cut it off. (Mṣb.) Accord. to the M, xarafa Aln-axola signifies He cut off the fruit of the palm-trees: and accord. to AḤn, AixotiraAfN↓ signifies the picking up the fruit of the palm-trees, whether unripe or ripe. (TA.)
xarafa fulaAnFA, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxorufu}, inf. n. xarofN, (TA,) He picked up, for such a one, dates (tamorFA), or fruit (vamorFA), accord. to different copies of the Ḳ: from Sh. (TA.)
yaxorufu mino haAhunaA wamino haAhunaA, said of a lamb, means He depastures, and eats, from this place and from this. (Mṣb, TA.*)
And xarafa, said of a man, (JK, TA,) aor. _i {yaxorifu}, (JK,) or _u, (TA,) He took of the Taraf [app. meaning the choice part] of the fruits. (JK, TA.)

xarafa also signifies He remained, stayed, or abode, in the [season called] xariyf: (Ḥam p. 676:) and in like manner, AxrfwA↓ they remained, stayed, or abode, in a place during their xariyf. (TA.) You say, xarafuwA fiI HaAYiTihimo They remained, stayed, or abode, in their HAYT [or garden, or walled garden of palm-trees,] in the time of the gathering of the fruits. (TA, from a trad. of ʼOmar.)

xurifonaA We were rained upon by the rain called Alxariyf. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And xurifati AlOaroDu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. xarofN, (TA,) The land was rained upon by the rain so called. (Ṣ, TA) And xurifati AlbahaAYimu The beasts were rained upon by the rain so called: or had that upon which they might pasture produced for them by that rain. (TA.)
xarifa, aor. _a {yaxorafu}, He (a man, TA) was, or became, fond of, or addicted to, the eating of xurofap, (Ḳ,) i. e. gathered, or plucked, fruit (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) of the palm-tree. (TA.)

xarifa, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxorafu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xarafN; (Ṣ,* Mṣb;) and xarafa, aor. _u {yaxorufu}; and xarufa, aor. _u {yaxorufu}; (Ḳ;) He (a man, Ṣ, Mṣb) doted; or was, or became, corrupted, rendered unsound, or disordered, in his intellect; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) in consequence of old age. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) [The first of these three verbs, in the present day, is used as meaning He doted; told stories such as are termed xuraAfaAt, i. e. fictions,, &c.; and talked nonsense: as also xr-f↓.]

xarafatohu OaxaAriyfu [app. Stories such as are termed AxAryf, i. e. xuraAfaAt↓, or fictions,, &c., caused him to dote, or talk nonsense]. (JK, TA.* [Mentioned in the former immediately after xuraAfapN explained as meaning “a fiction that is deemed pretty.” See also 4.])
2. xr-fhu, inf. n. taxoriyfN, He attributed to him xaraf, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. [dotage; or] a corrupt, an unsound, or a disordered, state of intellect. (TA.)
See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.

entry.sense: 3. xArfhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaArafapN and xiraAfN, (TA,) He bargained, or made an engagement, with him, for work, for the xariyf [or autumn]; (Ḳ;) from Alxariyfu, like AlmuXaAharapu from AlX-ahoru; (O, TA;) as also EaAmalahu muxaArafapF (Ṣ, TA) and xiraAfFA: and so AisotaOojarahu muxaArafapF and xiraAfFA [He hired him, or took him as a hired man or a hireling, for the autumn]. (Lḥ, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Axrf, said of the palm-tree, It attained, or nearly attained, the time for its fruit to be cut off. (JK, Ḳ.)
And, said of a people, or party, They entered upon the [season called] xariyf. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also 1.
Axrft, said of a ewe, or she-goat, She brought forth in the [season called] xryf. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Said of a she-camel, She brought forth in the like of the time [of the year] in which she became pregnant (Ṣ, Ḳ) in the preceding year: so says El-Umawee: (Ṣ:) [or, so applied, it means the same as when said of a ewe or she-goat; for] the epithet applied to her in this case is muxorifN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) but this is more correctly explained as signifying, applied to a she-camel and to a ewe or she-goat, that brings forth in the xryf. (TA.)
Also, said of curap [or millet], It became very tall. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
Axrfhu naxolapF He assigned to him a palm-tree of which he should cut, or gather, the fruit. (Lth, Ḳ.)

Also, (said of anxiety, JK, or of time, or fortune, TA,) It corrupted him, or disordered him; (Ḳ, TA;) [app., in his intellect; or caused him to dote; as is indicated in the JK;] namely, an old man. (JK.)

entry.sense: 8: see 1, first and second sentences.

hom.sense: xarafN A corrupt, an unsound, or a disordered, state of the intellect; dotage. (Ṣ. [See xarifa, of which it is the inf. n.])
The [bad sort of] dates called XiyS. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: xarifN Corrupted, unsound, or disordered, in his intellect, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in consequence of old age; doting: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) fem. with p {xarifapN}. (TA.)

xurufN A time of going forth of camels, (Nh,) or of men, (O, Ḳ,) to the [herbage of the season called] xariyf: so in the saying of El-Járood, yaA rasuwla Qll-ehi qado Ealimota maA yakofiynaA mina AlZ-ahori cawodN naOotiI Ealayohin-a fiI xurufK [O Apostle of God, verily thou knowest that a number such as is termed cwd, of camels for riding or carriage, whereon we come in a time of going forth, &c., is not sufficient for us]. (Nh, O, Ḳ.)

xurofapN Gathered, or plucked, fruits; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) and particularly of the palm-tree: (TA:) and xuraAfapN↓ signifies the same. (Mgh, Ḳ, TA. [See also xariyfN.]) It is said in a trad., Alt-amoru xurofapu AlS-aAYimi [Dates are the gathered fruit of the faster]; (Ṣ, TA;) because breaking the fast upon them is approved: and in another, Aln-axolapu xurofapu AlS-aAYimi, meaning The palm-tree is that of which the fruit is eaten by the faster. (TA.) See also maxorafN, last sentence.

xarofaI The jlbAn, (i. e. julub-aAn, or julobaAn, &c., accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, [see art. jlb,]) a well-known grain or seed, (AḤn, Ḳ,) of the kind called qaTaAniI- [i. e. pulse]: (AḤn:) an arabicized word, from xarobaI, (AḤn, Ḳ,) which is Persian; also called xul-arN. (AḤn.)
xarofiI-N and xirofiI-N: see what next follows.

xarafaI-N and xarofiI-N↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter a contraction of the former, (Mṣb,) and xirofiI-N↓, (Ḳ,) Of, or relating to, the season called xariyf; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and applied to the rain of that season; (JK;) rel. ns. from Alxariyfu; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) irregularly formed. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
The first also signifies The increase (nitaAj) [of sheep and goats] in the end of the [season called] qayoZ. (Aboo-Naṣr, TA voce SafariI-N, q. v.)
xaraAfN and xiraAfN↓ The time of the gathering, or plucking, of fruits: (Ks, Ḳ:) like HaSaAdN and HiSaAdN [&c.]. (TA.)
Also inf. ns. of xarafa in the first of the senses explained above. (Ḳ.)
xiraAfN: see the next preceding paragraph: and see maxorafN, last sentence.

xaruwfN A lamb; syn. HamalN [q. v.]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or the male young one of the sheep-kind: or such as has pastured, and become strong: (Lth, Ḳ:) younger than the jacaE: (Lth, TA:) so called because it depastures from this place and this: (Mṣb, TA: [see 1:]) fem. with p {xaruwfapN}: (Ḳ:) pl. (of pauc., TA) OaxorifapN and (of mult., TA) xirofaAnN. (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) The latter pl. is sometimes used as meaning † Young and ignorant persons; like as kibaAXN is used as meaning aged and learned persons. (TA.) And hence the prov., kaQloxaruwfi OayonamaA Qt-akaOa EalaI SuwfK [Like the lamb: wherever he reclines, he reclines upon wool]: (JK, TA: but in the latter, At-kI:) applied to him who leads a soft and delicate life. (TA.)

Also, (sometimes, Ṣ,) A colt; the male offspring of a mare; when he has attained the age of six months, or seven months; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a meaning assigned to it by Aṣ, in the “Book of the Horse;” but unknown to Abu-l-Ghowth: (Ṣ:) or, until a year old: (ISk, Ḳ:) it is said by some to be applied to a horse: in the L it is said that the xrwf of horses is such as is brought forth in the [season called] xariyf: but Khálid Ibn-Jebeleh says that it means such as pastures upon the [herbage of the season called] xariyf: and Suh thinks that it is an epithet applied to a horse, and any beast, as meaning that depastures the trees and herbage. (TA.)
xariyfN Fresh ripe dates, (Ḳ, TA,) or fruits [in general], (Ṣ, TA,) gathered, or plucked; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also maxoruwfN↓. (Ṣ, TA. See also maxorafN, last sentence. [And see xurofapN.])
And hence, ‡ Fresh milk; milk recently drawn from the udder. (Hr, TA.)
Palm-trees (naxolN) whereof the quantity of the fruit that is upon them is computed by conjecture. (Ḳ. [See also xaraAYifu, voce xariyfapN.])

[The autumn;] one of the divisions of the year, (Ṣ, Mgh,) the division (Mṣb) [consisting of] three months between the end of the qayoZ [or summer] and the beginning of the XitaMC [or winter], (Lth, Ḳ,*) in which the fruits are gathered. (Lth, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

And hence, (Mgh, TA,) † A year: (Mgh, Ḳ, TA:) so in the saying, mano SaAma yawomFA fiI sabiyli Qll-ehi baAEadahu Qll-ehu mina Aln-aAri OarobaEiyna xariyfFA Oawo saboEiyna, i. e. [Whoso fasteth a day in the way of God, God will remove him from the fire of Hell] to the distance of a journey of forty years, or seventy. (Mgh: and similar exs. are given in the TA, from three trads.: see also an ex. voce Uin-a.)

Also The rain of the season so called: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the rain, (JK,) or the first of the rain, (Ḳ,) in the beginning of the XitaMC [or winter], (JK, Ḳ,) which comes at the time of the cutting off of the fruit of the palmtrees: then follows the wasomiI-, at the coming in of the winter; then, the rabiyE; then, the Sayof; and then, the Hamiym: so says Aṣ: El-Ghanawee says that the xryf is between the [auroral] rising of AlX-iEoraI [or Sirius, which commenced, in central Arabia, about the epoch of the Flight, on the 13th of July, O. Ṣ.,] and the [auroral] setting of AlEaroquwataAni [or AlfarogaAni, the 26th and 27th of the Mansions of the Moon, commencing, in the same region and period, on the 8th and 21st of Sept., O. Ṣ., and continuing thirteen days]: El-Ghowr and Rekeeyeh [? (imperfectly written)] and El-Ḥijáz are all rained upon by the xryf; but Nejd is not: AZ says, the first rain is the wasomiI-; the follows the XatawiI-; then, the dafaYiI-; then, the Sayof; then, the Hamiym; then, the xariyf: and therefore the year is made to consist of six seasons: accord. to AḤn, [who seems in this matter to differ from most others,] Alxryf is not originally the name of the division of the year; but the name of the rain of the qayoZ [or summer]; and then the season was named thereby. (TA.) [See also nawoCN.]

[Also The herbage of the season so called, or of the rain so called; like as rabiyEN signifies the “herbage of the season, or of the rain, so called.” So in the phrase used by Khálid Ibn-Jebeleh (in explaining the word xaruwf), maA raEaI Alxariyfa Such as pastures upon the xryf.]
Also, accord. to AA, (TA,) A rivulet, streamlet, or small channel for irrigation. (JK, Ḳ, TA.)
xuraAfapN i. q. xurofapN, q. v. (Mgh, Ḳ.)

Hence xuraAfaAtN meaning Stories that are deemed pretty: similar to fukaAhapN from faAkihapN: (Mgh:) [or] xuraAfapu was the name of a man, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) of [the tribe of] 'Odhrah, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) whom the Jinn (or Genii) fascinated, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) as the Arabs assert, (Mgh,) and carried off, (TA,) and who related what he had seen, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) of them, when he returned, (Mgh,) and they pronounced him a liar, and said, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) of a thing that was impossible, (Mgh,) Hadiyvu xuraAfapa [a story of Khuráfeh]: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) but it is related of the Prophet, that he said, xuraAfapu Haq-N, (Ṣ, Mgh,) meaning What Khuráfeh relates [as heard] from the Jinn [is true]: (Mgh:) the r is without teshdeed; and the article Al is not prefixed, because the word is determinate [by itself], unless one mean thereby xuraAfaAtN as signifying fictictious night-stories: (Ṣ:) or xuraAfapN signifies a fictitious story that is deemed pretty: (Lth, Ḳ:) [and OaxaAriyfu↓ app. signifies the same as xuraAfaAtN, as though its sing. were OuxoruwfapN, like as OasaATiyru and OaHaAdiyvu, which have similar meanings, are pls. of which the sings. are said to be OasoTuwrapN and OuHoduwvapN:] see 1, last signification.
xaruwfapN: see what next follows.

xariyfapN and xaruwfapN↓ A palm-tree (naxolapN) of which a man gathers, or plucks, the fruit for himself and his household; as also maxorafN↓: (AḤn:) or a palm-tree which one takes for the picking up of its fresh ripe dates: (Sh, O, Ḳ:) or the latter signifies a palm-tree of which the fruit is cut off; being of the measure faEuwlapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: and the former is said to signify one that is set apart for its fruit that is [to be] gathered, or plucked: (TA:) or a selected palm-tree: (JK:) and its pl. is xaraAYifu: (JK, TA:) or xaraAYifu signifies palmtrees whereof the quantity of the fruit that is upon them is computed by conjecture. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ. [See also xariyfN.]) Also, the former, [A palm-tree set in the manner described in the following explanation:] one's digging, for a palm-tree, in a water-course, or channel of a torrent, in which are pebbles, until reaching hard ground, and then filling up the hollow with sand, and setting the palm-tree therein. (O, Ḳ.)
xaArifN A keeper, or watcher, of palm-tree: (Ḳ:) pl. xur-aAfN. (TA.)

maxorafN The place of the gathering, or plucking, or cutting off, of fruit. (Mṣb.) A place of abode of a people, or party, during their xariyf. (TA. [It is there added, “as though formed from OaxorafuwA, by the rejection of the augmentative letter:” but it is rather to be regarded as regularly formed, from xarafuwA: see 1.])

Also A garden; (Mgh, TA;) and so maxorafapN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a garden of palm-trees; as also maxorifN↓ and maxorafapN↓: (TA:) a single palm-tree: or a few palm-trees, up to ten; more than these being termed a busotaAn or a Hadiyqap: (El-Ḥarbee, TA:) see also xariyfapN: or a small collection of palmtrees, six or seven, which a man purchases for the fruit that is [to be] gathered, or plucked: or any collection of palm-trees: (L, TA:) or a walled garden of palm-trees: (IAth, TA:) or palm-trees [absolutely]: (Mgh:) and an avenue between two rows of palm-trees, such that one may gather, or pluck, the fruit from whichever of them he will; (Ḳ;) as also maxorafapN↓: (Sh, Ḳ:) and, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) as also maxorafapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a road, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) such as is conspicuous, clear, or open: (Ḳ:) pl. maxaArifu. (Mgh, TA.) It is said in a trad., EaAYidu AlmariyDi EalaI maxaArifi Aljan-api Hat-aI yarojiEa, i. e. The visitor of the sick is as though he were in the gardens of Paradise until he returns: or upon the palm-trees of Paradise; gathering, or plucking, their fruits: or upon the roads of Paradise: (Mgh,* TA:) or, as some relate it, ElI maxorafapi↓ Aljn-pi. (TA. [See also another explanation, and other readings in what follows.]) And it is said in a trad. of ʼOmar, tarakotukumo EalaI maxorafapi↓ Aln-aEami, (Ṣ,) or turikotumo, (TA,) i. e. [I have left you, or ye have been left,] upon a conspicuous road, like the road of the camels, (Aṣ, Ṣ,* TA,) which they have trodden with their feet so that it has become plainly apparent. (Aṣ, TA.)

Also Gathered, or plucked, fruit of palm-trees: (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, IAmb, Ḳ:) a correct meaning, though IḲt says that the proper word in this sense is only maxoruwfN: it is like maXorabN and maToEamN and marokabN as meaning maXoruwbN and TaEaAmN maOokuwlN and marokuwbN; and may signify fresh ripe dates gathered or plucked: (IAmb, TA:) pl. as above. (Aṣ, &c.) So in the former of the two trads. mentioned above accord. to Aṣ and AʼObeyd: (TA:) and this interpretation is corroborated by another reading, i. e., ElI xurofapi↓ Aljn-pi: (Mgh:) another reading is, fiI xiraAfi↓ Aljn-pi: [see xaraAfN:] and another, lahu xariyfN↓ fiI Aljan-api, i. e. [The visitor of the sick shall have] gathered fruits in Paradise. (TA.)
maxorifN: see the next preceding paragraph.
muxorifN: see 4.

mixorafN The thing in which fruits are gathered; (Ṣ, Ḥar p. 374;) called by the Arabs xaAfapN: (Ḥar ib.:) a [basket of the kind called] mikotal, (Mṣb,) or zinobiyl, of small size, in which the best fresh ripe dates are gathered: (O, Ḳ:) pl. maxaArifu. (A, TA.) One says, xarajuwA UilaI AlmaxaArifi bAlmaxaArifi, i. e. They went forth to the gardens with the baskets (zubul) [for gathering fruit]. (A, TA.)
And hence, † The basket (znbyl) in which the importunate beggar puts his food. (Ḥar ubi suprà.)
maxorafapN: see maxorafN, in six places.

hom.sense: maxoruwfN: see xariyfN.
Also Rained upon by the rain called xariyf; pl., applied to men, maxoruwfuwna: (TA:) [so, too, applied to a beast:] and so, with p {maxoruwfapN}, applied to land (OaroD). (Aṣ, Ṣ.)

entry.sense: muxaArafN Denied, or refused, good, or prosperity; prevented, or withheld, from obtaining good, good fortune, or sustenance; (Ḳ;) i. q. muHaArafN; (JK, TA;) as also mujaArafN. (TA.)
Q. 1. xarofajahu, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. xarofajapN, (TA,) He took it plentifully, or largely. (L, Ḳ.)
He made it to be of the best kind; namely, food, or meat and drink. (Er-Riyáshee.)
xarofajN: see muxarofajN:
and xirofiyjN.
xurofj and xuraAfj↓ [app. xurofujN and xuraAfijN, but in the CK xurofaj and xuraAfaj,] and xirofaAjN↓ and xirofiyjN↓ A plentiful and pleasant state of life. (Ḳ.)
See also xirofiyjN.
xarofajapN Goodness of food, aliment, or nutriment, or of meat and drink, with plenty. (TA.)
Also inf. n. of the verb above. (TA.)
xirofaAjN: see xurofj:
and see also xirofiyjN.
xurofanojN A flourishing and fresh condition, or softness, or tenderness, of a plant, or of herbage. (L.)
See also what next follows.
xirofiyjN: see xurofj.

Also Fresh, or juicy; flourishing and fresh, or soft, or tender; (L, Ḳ;) applied to a plant, or to herbage; and so xirofaAjN↓ and xuraAfijN↓ and xurafijN↓ and xurofanojN↓. (L.) [And xarofajN↓ seems to have a similar meaning.] The rájiz [El-ʼAjjáj (so in a copy of the Ṣ)] says,
jaAriyapN Xab-ato XabaAbFA xarofajaA [app. meaning A girl that had attained to flourishing, or soft, or tender, youthfulness.] (Ṣ.)
xuraAfijN: see xurofj:
and xurafijN:
and xirofiyjN:
and what here follows.

muxarofajN Ample: (Ḳ:) applied to anything. (TA.) It is said in a trad., kariha Als-araAwiyla Almuxarofajapa He disliked, or disapproved of, ample trousers: (AʼObeyd:) or they say it means trousers reaching down to the upper part of the foot. (Ṣ.) And you say, EayoXN muxarofajN A plentiful life. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1. xaraqahu, (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoriqu} (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yaxoruqu}, (Ḳ,) the former of which is the more chaste, (TA,) inf. n. xaroqN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, KL,) He made a hole in it, perforated it, pierced it, or bored it; (Mṣb,* KL;) syn. jaAbahu [in this sense, as well as in another to be explained below], (Ḳ, [in the CK, erroneously, jACa bhi,]) and vaqabahu: (TA:) and he cut it [so as to make a hole or a slit in it]: (Mṣb:) and he rent it, or tore it. (JK, Ḳ, KL.) You say, xaraqa Alvawoba, (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoriqu} [and _u,] inf. n. as above, (Mgh,) He [made a hole in, or] rent, or tore, the garment, or piece of cloth; (JK, Ḳ;) and Alxuf-a [the boot]; and the like. (Mgh.) And xaraqa AlS-axorapa He made a hole in the rock; syn. jaAbahu. (A in art. jwb.) [And xaraqa AlHaAYiTa He made a hole in, or through, the wall: see xaroqN, below.] And xaraqahu biAlmivoqabi He made a hole in it or through it, perforated it, pierced it, or bored it, with a drill or the like; syn. vaqabahu. (Mṣb in art. vqb.) xaraqa Als-afiynapa [He made a hole in the ship], in the Ḳur xviii. 70, means that he did so by taking out, from the ship, with an axe, (Ksh, Bḍ, Jel,) a plank, (Jel,) or two planks. (Ksh, Bḍ.)

[Hence,] xaraqa AlOaroDa, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb,) or AlmafaAzapa, (Mgh, Ḳ,*) ‡ He traversed, crossed, or cut through by journeying, (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the earth, or land, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb,) or the desert; (Mgh, Ḳ;) syn. qaTaEahaA; (JK, Mgh, Ḳ;*) or jaAbahaA; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) so as to reach the furthest part thereof. (Mgh, TA.) [See also 8.] It is said in the Ḳur [xvii. 39], Uin-aka lano taxoriqa AlOaroDa, meaning, For thou shalt not reach the extremities of the earth: or, accord. to Az, thou shalt not traverse the earth in length and breadth: (TA:) or it means thou shalt not bore through the earth, (Jel, TA,) so as to reach the end thereof: (Jel:) or thou shalt not make a hole in the earth by thy vehement treading: (Ksh, Bḍ:) accord. to one reading, ln taxoruqa. (Ksh, TA.)
[And xaraqati Alr-iyHu † The wind passed along: and † blew: for] the inf. n. xaroqN signifies † the passing of the wind: and † the blowing thereof. (KL.) [See also 7 and 8.]

xaraqa Alkaciba ‡ He forged, or feigned, the lie; as also Axtrqhu↓. (Ḳ, TA.) It is said in the Ḳur vi. 100, waxaraquwA lahu baniyna wabanaAtK, i. e. ‡ And they have feigned Him to have, or falsely attributed to Him, sons and daughters. (Ksh, Bḍ, Jel. [See also 2.]) And xaraqa [alone, the object being understood], (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (KL,) signifies ‡ He lied; told a lie: (Ḳ, KL, TA:) and txr-q↓ ‡ he forged, or feigned, a lie. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
xariqati AlX-aApu, aor. _a {yaxoraqu}, inf. n. xaraqN, The sheep had in its ear a xaroq, i. e. a round hole or perforation. (Mṣb.)
xariqa fiI Albayoti, aor. _a {yaxoraqu}, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. xuruwqN, (JK,) or xaraqN; (TḲ;) and xaraqa, inf. n. xuruwqN; (Ḳ;) He remained in the house, or tent, not quitting it. (JK,* Ḳ.)

And xariqa, aor. _a {yaxoraqu}, inf. n. xaraqN, said of a gazelle, or young gazelle, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) when hunted, (TA,) or when overtaken by the dog, (IAạr,) It was frightened, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, Aano yaEoraqa is erroneously put for Oano yaforaqa,]) so as to be unable to go away, (Mṣb,) or so as to be unable to rise, (Ḳ, TA,) and clave to the ground: (IAạr, TA:) and in like manner said of a bird, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) it became frightened, (Ḳ,) or impatient, (TA,) so as to be unable to fly away. (Ḳ, TA.)

And hence, (Mṣb,) the same verb, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with the same aor., (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and the same inf. n., (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said of a man, (Mṣb,) He became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or he became bereft of his reason or intellect, because of fear, or of shame: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he was confounded, perplexed, or amazed, [for yatahay-aba in the CK, I read yabohata, as in other copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,] opening his eyes, and looking: (Ḳ, TA:) and he remained confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of anxiety, or of hardship, or distress. (TA.) waqaEa faxariqa [He fell down and clave to the ground], occurring in a trad, means he fell down dead. (TA.)

xariqa, aor. _a {yaxoraqu}, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaraqN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) and xaruqa, aor. _u {yaxoruqu}, (JK, Ḳ,) [of which xuroqN, said in the Ṣ and Mṣb to be a simple subst., may be the inf. n., like as HusonN is of Hasona;] He was rough, ungentle, clumsy, or awkward, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in doing, or making, a thing: (Mṣb:) and he was unskilful in work, and in the management of affairs: and he was foolish; stupid; or unsound, or deficient, in intellect or understanding: (Ḳ:) or he was ignorant: (JK:) or the latter verb signifies he knew not his work with his hand, or his handicraft. (Mṣb.) And xaruqa biAlX-aIoCi He was ignorant of the thing, (Ḳ, TA,) and did it not well. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. xr-qh, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. taxoriyqN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) is similar to xaraqahu, but has an intensive signification; [He made holes in it; perforated it, pierced it, or bored it, in several, or many, places: he cut it so as to make holes or slits in it:] (Mṣb:) he rent it, or tore it, much, or in several, or many, places: (Ḳ, TA:) namely, a garment, (Ṣ, TA,), &c. (TA.)

And xr-q, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) † He lied much. (Ḳ, TA.) Aboo-Jaạfar and Náfi' read, [in the Ḳur vi. 100,] waxar-aquwA lahu baniyna wabanaAtK † [And they have very falsely attributed to Him sons and daughters]. (TA. [See also 1.])
4. Axrqhu He (a man, Ṣ) caused him to be confounded, or perplexed, so that he was unable to see his right course; or caused him to be bereft of his reason, or intellect. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

5. txr-q quasi-pass. of xar-aqa; [thus signifying It had holes made in it; became perforated, pierced, or bored, in several, or many, places: it became cut so as to have holes or slits made in it: it became rent, or torn, much, or in several, or many, places:] (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) as also Anxrq↓; (Ḳ;) [or rather the latter, as is indicated in the Ṣ, is quasi-pass. of xaraqa, and thus signifies it had a hole made in it; became perforated, pierced, or bored: it became cut so as to have a hole or slit made in it: it became rent, or torn:] and Axrwrq↓ signifies the same [as the former or as the latter]: all said of a garment [&c.]: (Ṣ:) and Anxrq↓ signifies also it became wide, or expanded. (TA.)
[Hence,] txr-q fiI Als-axaMCi ‡ He took a wide, or an ample, range, or was profuse, in liberality, bounty, or munificence; syn. tws-E. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
See also 1, in the middle of the paragraph.
And see what next follows {7}, in two places.
7: see 5, in two places.

Anxrqti Alr-iyHu ‡ The wind blew [app. in any manner, (see munoxaraq,) or] irregularly; not in one uniform manner: (TA:) [and txr-ft↓ app. signifies the same: for you say,] baladN waAsiEN tanoxariqu bihi Alr-iyaAHu [† A wide country in which the winds blow, or blow irregularly]: (El-Muärrij, TA:) and OaroDN waAsiEapN tataxar-aqu↓ fiyhaA Alr-iyaAHu [app. meaning, in like manner, † A wide land in which the winds blow,, &c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

8. Axtrq ‡ He, or it, passed through, or over, or across. (Mgh, Ḳ,* TA.) [See also 1, in the former half of the paragraph.] ‡ He traversed, or crossed, (Mgh, TA,) a desert, (Mgh,) or a land, (TA,) not following a road. (Mgh, TA.) [† He travelled a road: see an ex. voce vugorapN.] ‡ He made a mosque, (Mgh, TA,) and a house, (TA,) to be his way, or thoroughfare. (Mgh, TA.) Hence, Axtrq AlHijora † He entered into the midst of the Hijor [q. v.], without going around the HaTiym. (Mgh.) And Alxayolu taxotariqu maAbayona AlquraI waAlOaroDi ‡ The horses, or horsemen, pass through the midst of the intervening spaces of the towns, or villages, and the land. (TA.) And Aixotaraqotu Alqawoma † I stepped into the midst of the people, or party. (TA.) And Alr-ayHu taxotariqu AlOaXojaAra † [The wind passes, or blows, through the trees.] (JK.) AixotiraAqu Alr-iyaAHi signifies † The passing [or blowing] of the winds. (Ṣ.) [See also 1, in the middle of the paragraph; and see 7.]
Axtrq Alkaciba: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph.

hom.sense: xaroqN, originally an inf. n., of 1: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) A hole, or perforation, (Mgh, Mṣb, KL,) in a garment, (Ṣ, TA,) and in a wall, (Mṣb, TA,), &c.: (Mṣb:) and a round hole, or perforation, in the ear of a sheep: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. xuruwqN. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.) Hence the saying, Ait-asaEa Alxaroqu EalaI Alr-aAqiEi [The hole was, or became, wide to the patcher]. (TA.)
And A part that has a hole made in it, or that is rent, or torn, of, or from, a thing. (TA.)

Also A desert; and so maxoraqN↓: (Ḳ:) or the former, a desert far extending, (JK, TA,) whether level or not level: and ↓the latter, a wide desert in which the winds [blow, or] blow irregularly: (TA:) and the former, (El-Muärrij, Ḳ,) as also xaroqaMCN↓, (Ḳ,) signifies likewise a wide land, (Ḳ,) or a wide country, (El-Muärrij,) in which the winds [blow, or] blow irregularly: (El-Muärrij, Ḳ: [see 7:]) ISh says, the space between El-Basrah and Hafr Abee-Moosà is a xaroq, and that between En-Nibáj and Dareeyeh is a xaroq: (TA:) pl. xuruwqN. (Ḳ.) You say also mafaAzapN xaroqaMCu↓ xawoqaMCu A farextending desert. (TA.) And qaTaEonaA Uilayokumo OaroDFA xaroqaMCa↓ and xaruwqFA↓ [We have traversed, in journeying to you, a wide land, or a wide land in which the winds blow,, &c.]. (TA.)
Also A certain plant, resembling the qusoT [q. v.], (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) having leaves. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád.)

xuroqN a subst. from xariqa, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [or perhaps inf. n. of xaruqa as syn. with xariqa, (see 1, last two sentences,)] and xuruqN↓, (TA,) Roughness, ungentleness, clumsiness, or awkwardness; contr. of rifoqN; (JK, Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA;) in doing, or making, a thing: (Mṣb:) unskilfulness in work, and in the management of affairs: foolishness; stupidity; or unsoundness, or deficiency, in intellect or understanding; as also xuroqapN↓: (Ḳ:) and ignorance. (TA.) [Hence,] nawomapu Alxuroqi The sleep of [the time of morning called] the DuHaI. (Ḥar p. 223. [See also HumoqN and xuluqN.])
The first of these words is also pl. of Oaxoraqu and of [its fem.] xaroqaMCu. (Ḳ.)
Also The she-camel's vulva. (JK.)

entry.sense: xiroqN and xir-iyqN↓ ‡ Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also mixoraAqN↓: (IAạr, Ḳ:) or ↓the second signifies very liberal or bountiful, &c.: (Ḳ: [so in a later part of the art.:]) or this and the first signify one who takes a wide, or an ample, range, or is profuse, in liberality or bounty, &c.: (TA:) or a youth, or young man, (JK,) excellent, or elegant, in mind, manners, address, speech, person, and the like; or clever, or ingenious; with liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity, (Lth, JK, Ḳ,) and courage: (Lth, JK:) and a goodly youth or young man, [for AlfatiI-u in the CK, I read AlfataI, as in other copies of the Ḳ,] of generous disposition: (Ḳ:) the pl. (of xiroqN, TA) is OaxoraAqN [a pl. of pauc.] (Ḳ) and xuraAqN, or xur-aAqN, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, [both anomalous, and perhaps it is xiraAqN, agreeably with analogy,]) and xuruwqN; (Ḳ;) and the pl. of xir-iyqN↓ is xir-iyquwna; no broken pl. of it having been heard. (T, TA.) One says also, huwa mataxar-iqu↓ Alkaf-i biAln-awaAli ‡ [He has a liberal hand, largely beneficent]. (TA.) And huwa maxoruwqu↓ Alk-f-i biAln-awaAli ‡ He is liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous. (TA. [But see maxoruwqN below.])
xiroqN is also applied to a spear, meaning † Highly esteemed or prized; excellent; or rare. (TA.)
xaruqN: see Oaxoraqu.

hom.sense: xariqN [part. n. of xariqa, q. v.:] A young gazelle weak in the legs, (Ḳ, TA,) cleaving to the ground, and not rising: (TA:) a gazelle, or young gazelle, (Ḳ, TA,) when hunted, (TA,) frightened, so as to be unable to rise: (Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner a bird (Ḳ, TA) frightened, (Ḳ,) or impatient, (TA,) so as to be unable to fly away: (Ḳ, TA:) fem. with p {xariqapN}. (Ḳ.)

And [hence,] A man (Mṣb) confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or bereft of his reason or intellect, by reason of fear, or of shame: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or confounded, perplexed, or amazed, opening his eyes, and looking. (Ḳ, TA.) See also Oaxoraqu.
Also Ashes: because they remain [cleaving to the ground] while the people thereof go away. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xuruqN: see xuroqN.
xuroqapN: see xuroqN.
xiroqapN A piece, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or piece torn off, (TA,) of a garment, or of cloth; [a rag;] pl. xiraqN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)
[A ragged, patched, garment: and particularly one worn by a devotee; also called muraq-aEapN, q. v.: but this is probably post-classical. Hence, OaSoHaAbu Alxiraqi The devotees.]
‡ A portion of a swarm of locusts, (Ḳ, TA,) less than a rijol; as also HizoqapN. (TA.)
xaruwqN: see the next paragraph:
and see also xaroqN.
xariyqN A womb rent by the fœtus, and that consequently does not conceive (Ḳ, TA) afterwards; (TA;) [of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN;] as also mutaxar-iqapN↓. (Ḳ.)

And A she-camel whose womb has been rent. (JK.) Applied to a well (biYor), it signifies Al-atiI kusira jibolatuhaAEani AlmaMCi: (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) [in the CK jabalatuhA: neither of these readings affords an admissible meaning: the right reading I believe to be jiyluhaA; and the meaning, Of which the side, or lateral part, is broken, from the water upwards:] pl. xaraAYiqu (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ, TA) and xuruqN, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ, TA, [the latter erroneously written in the CK xuruwoqN,]) like safaAYinu and sufonN. (TA.)
A channel of water that is not deep, and not without trees. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
The place of expanding of a valley, where it ends. (JK, Ḳ.)
