A low, or depressed, tract of land, containing herbage: pl. xuruqN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, mararotu bixariyqK mina AlOaroDi bayona masoHaAwayoni [I passed by a low tract of land, containing herbage, between two plain tracts containing small pebbles and without herbage]. (Fr, Ṣ.)
Hard ground. (A, TA.)

‡ A violent wind; (A, TA;) as also riyHN xaroqaMCu↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the latter signifies ‡ a wind that blows violently: or, that does not continue to blow in the same direction: (TA:) or the former signifies ‡ a cold wind that blows violently; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xaruwqN↓: (Ḳ:) [it is an epithet; for] one says riyHN xariyqN which is anomalous, as by rule one should say xariyqapN: (Ṣ:) it is [also] one of the names for ‡ a cold wind that blows violently; (JK, T, TA;) as though it perforated, or rent; the agent [riyHN] being unused: (T, TA:) and (as some say, TA) it signifies also † a gentle, soft, wind; thus bearing two contr. meanings: or that returns, and [then] continues its course: (Ḳ:) or, as in the L, does not continue its course: (TA:) or that blows long. (Ḳ.)

xur-aqN A certain bird, (JK, IDrd, Ḳ,) smaller than the qunobur [or lark], (JK,) that cleaves to the ground: (IDrd:) or a kind of sparrow: (Ḳ:) so says AḤát, in the “Book of Birds:” (TA:) pl. xaraAriqu. (JK, IDrd, Ḳ.)
xir-iyqN: see xiroqN, in three places.
xaAriqN [act. part. n. of xaraqa].
[And hence,] sayofN xaAriqN A sharp, or cutting, sword: pl. xuruqN. (TA.)
[Hence also,] OamorN xaAriqN liloEaAdapi † [An event breaking through, or infringing, the usual course of nature]. (KT, in a definition of muEojizapN, q. v.)
[In the present day, xaAriqN signifies also † Profound, or penetrating, in learning or science.]
Oaxoraqu and [its fem.] xaroqaMCu have for their pl. xuroqN. (Ḳ.)
The fem., applied to a ewe, signifies Having her ear perforated (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) with a round hole. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) And, applied to an ear, Perforated, or bored. (TA.)

And the masc., applied to a camel, That puts his manosim [or toe] upon the ground before [the sole of] his xuf- [or foot]: the doing of which is a result of generous quality. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) And the fem., applied to a she-camel, That does not retread (laA tataEaAhadu, in the L lA ttEh-d,) [with her hind feet] the places of her [fore] feet (JK, L, Ḳ) upon the ground: mentioned by Ibn-ʼAbbád and Z. (TA.)

Applied to a man, (Mgh, Mṣb,) Rough, ungentle, clumsy, or awkward, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb,) in doing, or making, a thing: (Mṣb:) unskilful in work [and in the management of affairs see xariqa]; as also xariqN↓ and xaruqN↓: (Ḳ:) or foolish; stupid; or unsound, or deficient, in intellect or understanding: (Mgh, Ḳ:) ignorant: (TA:) not knowing his work with his hand, or his handicraft: (Mṣb:) fem. as above. (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, &c.) It is said in a prov., (JK, Ṣ,) laA taEodamu AlxaroqaMCu Eil-apF [The stupid woman is not in want of an excuse]: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) used in forbidding excuses: (Ḳ:) i. e., excuses are many: the stupid woman is skilled in making them: how then must be the clever? (Ṣ, Ḳ:) applied to every one who excuses himself being able. (Ḳ in art. El.)
xaroqaMCu applied to a desert, and to a land: see xaroqN, in three places.
And applied to a wind: see xariyqN.
Hence, riHolapN xaroqMCu † A hard journey. (Ḥar p. 177.)
maxoraqN: see xaroqN, in two places.

maxoraqu HawoDK A stone that is at the Euqor [or hinder part] of a watering-trough, for the purpose of their [standing upon it, and] drawing forth the water from it, [i. e. the trough,] when they will. (Ḳ.)
maxoriqN, though unheard by us, is the sing. of maxaAriqu signifying The orifices of the body; such as the mouth and the nose and the ears and the anus and the like. (Mgh.)
muxoraqN [pass. part. n. of 4; Confounded,, &c.: and hence,] silent. (JK: but there written without the vowel of the r.)

gayoru muxoriqK, applied to a road, means [That does not cause one to be confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or] in which one is not confounded, or perplexed, so as to be unable to see his right course. (IAạr in TA: but the latter word is there written without the vowel of the r.)

mixoraAqN A kerchief twisted for the purpose of beating therewith: (JK, Ṣ:) a genuine Arabic word: (Ṣ:) or a thing made of twisted rags, with which boys play: (TA:) or a twisted kerchief, or an inflated [skin such as is termed] ziq-, or the like, with which boys play, beating one another therewith: so called because it rends (yaxoriqu) the air when they make use of it: (Ḥam p. 702:) pl. maxaAriyqu. (Ṣ, TA.) ʼAmr Ibn-Kulthoom says,
kaOan-a suyuwfanaA min-aA waminohumo
maxaAriyqN biOayodiI laA EibiynaA
[As though our swords, ours and theirs, were kerchiefs twisted for beating therewith, in the hands of players]: (Ṣ:) or mxAryq in this verse [written with tenween by poetic license] is the pl. of mixoraAqN signifying a wooden sword with which boys play: the poet means, we cared not for the smiting with the swords, like as the players care not for the smiting with the mxAryq. (EM p. 198.) [See also another ex., in a verse cited voce xariyjN.] ʼAlee is related, in a trad., to have said that the lightning is the maxaAriyq of the angels; (Ṣ, TA;) meaning thereby the instruments with which the angels chide and drive the clouds. (TA.)
Also A garment, or piece of cloth. (JK. [But this I find not elsewhere.])
And ‡ A sword [in the ordinary sense of the word]: so in the A and O and L: in the Ḳ, Als-ay-idu is erroneously put for Als-ayofu. (TA.)
† A man goodly in body, or person, whether tall or not tall. (JK, Ḳ.)
† One who falls not into a case without escaping, or extricating himself, therefrom. (Sh, TA.)
† One who exercises art in the management of affairs. (Ḳ.)

‡ A wild bull: (Aṣ, Ḳ:) so called because he traverses far-extending districts: (Aṣ, TA:) or because the dogs pursue him and he escapes from them: said in the A to be called mixoraAqu AlmafaAzapi. (TA.)
† A man who engages in wars, or fights, and is active therein. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also xiroqN.
maxoruwqN ‡ One who is denied good, or prosperity; into whose hand wealth falls not. (Ḳ, TA.) And maxoruwqu Alkaf-i † A man who gains not, or gets not, anything. (JK.) See also xiroqN.

muxoraworiqN One who goes round about camels, [meaning who has them within the compass of his rule and care,] (JK, Ḳ, TA,) and urges them against their will, (TA,) and is active, and exercises art in his management [of them]: (JK, Ḳ, TA:) mentioned by Ṣgh on the authority of Ibn-ʼAbbád. (TA.)
muxotaraqN † A passage, or place of passing. (Ṣ. [See xawoxapN, in two places.])
[Hence,] baladN baEiydu Almuxotaraqi † [A country, or district, wide to traverse; lit., far extending in respect of the place of passing]. (TA.)
muxotaraqu Alr-iyaAHi † A place in which the winds blow: (Ḳ:) and munoxaraqu↓ Alr-iyHi † a place in which the wind blows [in any manner, or irregularly: see 7]. (Ṣ.)
mutaxar-iqu: see the last paragraph in this art.: and see also xariyqN:
and xiroqN.
munoxaraqN: see muxotaraqN.
munoxariqN [Having a hole made in it,, &c.: see its verb]. rajulN munoxariqu Als-irobaAli A man having his clothing rent, or torn, (JK, Ḳ,) by long travel; as also mutaxar-iqu↓ Als-irobaAl. (Ḳ.)
Also † Quick, or swift. (Ḥam p. 42.)

hom.sense: 1. xaramahu, aor. _i {yaxorimu} inf.n. xaromN, He perforated, or pierced, it; namely, a thing. (Mṣb.) [And so xazamahu. (Mgh in art. xzm.)]

And He cut it, or cut it off. (Mṣb.) You say, maA xaramotu minohu XayoYFA I did not diminish, and did not cut off, from it, or him, anything. (Ṣ.) And maA xarama mina AlHadiyvi HarofFA He did not diminish [from the narrative, or tradition, a letter, or a word]. (TA.) And xarama fulaAnFA, (Ḳ,) aor, and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He slit the partition between the nostrils of such a one: (Ḳ:) or xaromN signifies the mutilating (qaToE) of the nose: (JK:) or mutilation (qaToE) in the partition between the nostrils and in the naAXirataAni [or two alœ], or in the extremity of the Oaronabap [or lobule of the nose]; not amounting to what is termed jadoEN; (Lth, TA;) and the epithet is Oaxoramu↓, fem. xaromaMCu: (Lth, JK, TA:) and the like in the lip; or in the upper part of the fuwq [app. meaning the front edge of the lobe, which at its termination above forms a crena,] of the ear: (Lth, TA: [see Oaxoramu, as relating to the ear:]) accord. to Sh, it is both in the nose and in the ear; but in the nose, it is the mutilation (qTE) of the fore part of the nostril of a man, and the Oaronabap [or lobule of the nose], after the mutilation of the upper part of this, so as to reach the interior of the nose; and the epithet applied to the man is Oaxoramu↓. (TA.) And xaramahu, inf. n. as above, also signifies He hit, or hurt, his xaworamap [q. v.]. (TA.) You say also, xarama Alxurozapa, (Ḳ, TA, in the CK [erroneously] Alxarazapa,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n.; (TA;) and xr-mhA↓, (Ḳ,) inf.n. taxoriymN; (TA;) He cracked, or tore without separating, the suture, or seam, of a skin; syn. faSamahaA: (Ḳ, TA, in the CK qaSamahA:) or xaramotu Alxaroza, aor. and inf. n. as above, i. q. OavoOayotuhu [meaning I spoiled the sewing of the skin, or hide; as when one uses a thick instrument for sewing or perforating, and a thin thong; or as when one rends two stitch-holes into one]. (Ṣ.) [And xaramahu sayolN app. A torrent cut into it, or trenched it; namely, the ground, or the side of a mountain: see xaromN.] And xaramatohu xawaArimu↓ [lit. Cutting-off events cut him off]; meaning † he died: like as one says, XaEabatohu XaEuwbu. (TA. [See also 8.])
xarama AlqiroTaAsa He hit the target with his arrow without perforating it. (TA.)
maA xarama Eani AlT-ariyqi He (a guide) did not turn aside from the way. (JK, Ṣ.)

xarima, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxoramu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaramN, (Ṣ,) said of a man, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He had the partition between his nostrils cut, or mutilated: or the extremity of his nose, but not to the extent denoted by the term jadoEN: the epithet applied to the man in this case is Oaxoramu↓: (Ṣ:) or he had the partition between his nostrils slit; i. e. taxar-amato↓ wataratuhu. (Ḳ.)
xaruma, aor. _u {yaxorumu}, He cared not for what he did nor for what was said to him. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
[Hence,] DaroEN fiyhi taxoriymN An udder in which are incisions [or crackings of the skin]; and so fyh taXoriymN. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5. txr-mt wataratuhu: see 1, last sentence but one. txr-mt Alxurozapu (Ḳ, TA, in the CK [erroneously] xaramahaA,) The suture, or seam, of a skin cracked, or became torn without separating; quasi-pass. of xaramahaA [q. v.]. (Ḳ, TA.) Anxrm↓ [in like manner] signifies It became slit; said of the bore of the ear. (Ṣ.) And you say also, txr-m Alz-anodu [The wooden instrument for producing fire cracked, or split]. (TA.) Hence the phrase, OaraAka yataxar-amu zanoduka, mentioned by IAạr, meaning † I see thee to have no good in thee: for when the znd cracks, or splits, (UicaA taxar-ama,) one cannot produce fire by mean of it, and there is no good in it. (TA.) [Hence likewise,] txr-m zanoduhu means also ‡ His anger became appeased: [or,] accord. to the Ṣ, txr-m zabaduhu has this meaning: and accord. to the A, txr-m Oanofuhu has the same meaning. (TA.) Accord. to IAạr, (TA,) jaMCanaA fulaAnN yataxar-amu zabaduhu means ‡ Such a one came to us doing to us that which was wrongful, or injurious, and foolish, or stupid. (Ḳ,* TA.)
See also 8, in two places.
txr-m also signifies He followed, or adopted, the religion of the xur-amiy-ap. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA: in the CK, the maxorimiy-ap.)

entry.sense: 7. Anxrm It became cut, or cut off. (Mṣb.) See also 5. Said of a writing, or book, it means It became deficient; part of it went. (TA.) And said of a generation, It went away; came to an end. (TA.) See also Oaxoramu.

8. Aixotaramahumu Ald-ahoru Time, or fortune, cut them off; and extirpated them; as also taxar-amahumo↓: (Ṣ:) or destroyed them by its calamities. (Mṣb.) And Aixotaramatohumu Almaniy-apu and taxar-amatohumo↓ Death, or the decree of death, cut them off; and extirpated them. (Ḳ.) And Aixotaramatohu Almaniy-apu Death, or the decree of death, [cut him off, or] took him away, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) mino bayoni OaSoHaAbihi [from amidst his companions.] (TA. [A phrase similar to xaramatohu xawaArimu: see 1.]) And Auxoturima Ean-aA (JK,* Ḳ,) [He was cut off from us by death;] he was taken away [from us by death]; (JK;) he died, (Ḳ, TA,) and went away [from us]. (TA.) Accord. to some, AixotirAmN [as an inf. n. of Auxoturima] signifies The dying suddenly. (Ḥar p. 123.)

xaromN A prominence, or projecting part, of a mountain: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. xuruwmN. (JK.) And A bed trenched by a torrent (maA xarama sayolN [see 1]): (JK:) so some say: (TA:) or a road in a [tract of high ground such as is termed] quf-; or on the summit of a mountain. (JK, TA.) [See also maxorimN.]
xuromN The place of the bore, or perforation, of a thing. (Mṣb.) The eye of a needle. (TA.)
See also maxorimN.

xaramapN The place of perforation of the ear: (Ṣ:) or the place of slitting, of the nose, in the partition between the nostrils [and in either of the alœ, as appears from what here follows]. (Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., fiI AlxaramaAti Alv-alaAvi mina AlOanof Ald-iyapu, by AlxrmAt being app. meant AlmaxoruwmaAt↓, i. e. [In the case of the mutilation of] the two alœ and the partition between the nostrils [the blood-wit, or fine for homicide, shall be paid]. (TA.)
xuromaAnN A lie, or falsehood. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, jaMCa fulaAnN biAlxuromaAni (Ṣ, TA) i. e. [Such a one uttered] that which was a lie. (TA.)
xariymN One who cares not for what he does nor for what is said to him. (Ḳ.)

Alxur-amiy-apu The sect who held the doctrine of the transmigration of the soul, and allowed general license: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) they were in the time of El-Moatasim: their sheykh, Bábak [El-Khurramee, i. e. of Khurram, in Persia], was then slain, and they scattered themselves in the countries; and there remains of them a remnant in the mountains of Syria. (TA.)

xur-aAmN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] Young men (TA) such as follow the licentious ways of the xur-amiy-ap [so I render mutaxar-imuwna↓] in acts of disobedience. (Ḳ, TA.) [See what next follows.]

hom.sense: xaArimN [act. part. n. of xarama: fem. with p {xaArimapN}; and pl. of the latter xawaArimu]. One says, xaramatohu xawaArimu [explained above]: see 1. (TA.)
Corrupting; acting corruptly; doing evil, or mischief. (Ḳ.) [See xur-aAmN, which is probably a pl. thereof.]
Neglecting; or leaving undone [what ought to be done]. (Ḳ.)
Cold, as an epithet (Ḳ.)
A cold wind: (Ḳ:) so accord. to AʼObeyd: but accord. to Kr, [xaAzimN,] with zAI. (TA.)

entry.sense: xaworamN: see what next follows.
xaworamapN The end, or tip, of the nose (JK, Ṣ) of a man: (Ṣ:) or the fore part of the nose: or the part between the nostrils. (Ḳ.)
Also, (JK, Ḳ,) as being likened thereto, (TA,) † A rock in which are holes; (JK, Ḳ;) n. un. of xaworamN↓: (Ḳ:) [or] the latter has this signification. (Ṣ. [But this seems to be a mistake.])

hom.sense: Oaxoramu [Having the nose mutilated in any of the manners explained in the first paragraph of this art.]: fem. xaromaMCu: see 1, in three places.

And Having the ear perforated, when it is not slit: (Ṣ:) or having the ear slit after it has been pierced: (Ṣ and Mṣb* and TA in art. xrb:) and muxar-amN↓, likewise, signifies having the ear slit; as also Oaxorabu and muxar-abN. (TA in that art.) And the fem., applied to a she-goat, Having her ear slit crosswise. (Ḳ. [See also xacomaMCu.]) Also, the fem., applied to an ear, Slit, or perforated, or mutilated. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Also A pool of water left by a torrent; because one part thereof passes a way (yanoxarimu↓) to another: pl. xuromN. (TA.)

And the fem. also signifies Any hill, or rising ground, sloping down into a [hollow such as is termed] wahodap; (Ḳ;) and so the masc.: (TA:) or any [hill such as is termed] Oakamap having a side whereby it cannot be ascended. (Ḳ.)

Oaxoramu Alkatifi The extremity of the spine of the scapula: (Ṣ:) or a notch, or small hollowed place, [app. the glenoid cavity,] at the extremity of the spine of the scapula, (JK, T, TA,) next the socket: (T, TA:) pl. OaxaArimu: (JK, T, TA:) or OaxoramaA Alkatifayoni, in the Ḳ miswritten Mxiru maA fiI Alkatifayoni, signifies the heads of the two scapulæ, next the upper arms: (Ḳ,* TA:) or the two extremities, or edges, of the lower portion of the two scapulæ, which surround, or border, the kuEoburap [app. here meaning the thick part next to the inferior angle] of the scapula: and AlOaxoramu the end of the spine [of the scapula]. (Ḳ,* TA. [In the Ḳ is here added, accord. to different copies, Hayovu yanoxadiEu, as in the TA; or Hyv yanoxadimu, as in the CK; or Hyv yanoxacimu: the right reading seems to be Hayovu yanoxarimu, where it forms a kind of cleft; app. meaning where it forms the glenoid cavity. In the CK, for munoqaTaEu AlEayori, is erroneously put munoqaTiEu AlEayoni; and w is erroneously prefixed to the former noun.])
AlOaxoramaAni Two cleft bones at the extremity of the interior of the upper part of the inside of the mouth. (Ḳ.)
Oaxoramu Alr-aOoIi ‡ A man weak in judgment. (JK, TA.)

entry.sense: maxorimN The end of a prominence, or projecting part, of a mountain: pl. maxaArimu: (Ṣ:) or maxorimu jabalK signifies the prominence, or projecting part, of a mountain: [like xaromN:] and maxorimu sayolK, the extremity of a torrent: (Ḳ: [accord. to the TḲ, of a sword; for mxrm Alsyf is there put in the place of mxrm Alsiyl:]) pl. as above: (TA:) and maxorimu OakamapK and xuromu↓ AkmpK signify the place where a hill such as is termed Akmp ends. (Ḳ.) Also A [road such as is termed] vaniy-ap, between two mountains: (TA:) [or the pl.] maxaArimu signifies the mouths of [mountain-roads such as are termed] fijaAj: (Ṣ:) or roads in rugged tracts: (Skr, Ḳ:) or roads in mountains, and in sands. (IAth, TA.) [Hence,] yamiynN caAtu maxaArima ‡ An oath in which are ways of evasion. (Ṣ, TA.) And laA xayora fiI yamiynK laA maxaArima lahaA ‡ There is no good in an oath that has not ways of evasion: from maxorimN signifying “a vaniy-ap between two mountains.” (TA.) And hecihi yamiynN qado TalaEato fiI AlmaxaArimi ‡ [This is an oath that has come forth in expressions that admit of ways of evasion]: said of an oath that affords a way [or rather ways] of evasion to the utterer thereof. (AZ, TA.)
[The pl.] AlmaxaArimu [or maxaArimu All-ayoli] also signifies The first portions of the night. (Ḳ.) It occurs in an instance in which some read AlmaHaArimu [pl. of maHoramN, q. v.]. (TA.)

mux-r-amN: see Oaxoramu. It is said in a trad., nahaI Oano yuDaH-aI biAlmuxar-amapi AlOucuni He forbade the sacrificing as an OuDoHiy-ap [q. v.] the animal having the ear cut, or cut off, or mutilated: or having many perforations, and slits, in its ear. (TA.)
maxoruwmaAtN: see xaramapN.
mutaxar-imuwna: see xur-aAmN.
xuronuwbN and xaronuwbN: see xar-uwbN, in art. xrb.
xironaAbataAni: see xin-aAbataAni, in art. xnb.

xurapu AlfaOosi, as in the Tekmileh, on the authority of Fr; in the Ḳ and accord. to Ṣgh, xurowapu↓ AlfaOosi, which is a mistake; (TA;) The xurot [q. v. in art. xrt] of the fOs: pl. xuraAtN; (Fr, Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA;) like as vubapN has for its pl. vubaAtN. (TA.)

AlxaraAtaAni Two stars, (Ḳ,) mentioned [and described] in art. xrt, (TA,) each of which is [said to be] called xaraApN: (Ḳ:) accord. to ISd, only the dual form of the word is known; and the radical t and the augmentative t [by which latter is meant p] are in the dual alike: (TA:) but Kr and others say that it is dual of xaraApN, and belongs to this art. (TA in art. xrt.)
xurowapN: see the first paragraph in this art {1}.

xaz-N A certain kind of cloth, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ, TA,) woven of wool and silk: (TA:) and also a kind of cloth entirely of silk; and this is the kind which one is forbidden to ride upon and to sit upon; not the former kind, which is allowable, and was sometimes worn by companions of the Prophet and by the next succeeding generation, as IAth has ascertained: (TA:) derived from xuzazN, (Ḳ, TA,) accord. to some: (TA:) or it is the name of a certain beast [thought by Golius to be the beaver]: and afterwards applied to the cloth made of its fur: (Mgh, Mṣb:) pl. xuzuwzN. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [Golius seems to derive it from the Persian qazo, meaning raw silk; and assigns to it also the meaning of a coarser kind of spun silk.] xuzuwzN wabuzuwzN signifies Good cloths, or stuffs, or garments. (A in art. bz.)

xuzazN The male of the Oaronab [or hare]: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the offspring of the Arnb: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] Oaxiz-apN (Ḳ) and [of mult.] xiz-aAnN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, mas-uhu mas-u Alxuzazi [The feel of him, or it, is like the feel of the male, or young, hare]. (A, TA.)
xaz-aAzN A seller of xaz-. (TA.)
OaroDN maxaz-apN A land containing, (Ḳ * TA,) or abounding with, (TA,) xiz-An, pl. of xuzazN, (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xazirati AlEyonu, aor. _a {yaxozaru}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xazarN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) The eye was, or became, narrow and small: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or it contracted its sight, naturally: (Ḳ:) or xazira, aor. _a {yaxozaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) signifies he (a man) was as though he looked from the outer angle of the eye: (Ṣ, A:*) or he looked as though on one side: or he opened and closed his eyes; (Ḳ;) or, his eye: (M:) or he had a distortion (HawalN) of one of his eyes: (Ḳ:) [or he had eyes looking towards his nose; or, looking sideways; (see Oaxozaru;) or, looking towards their outer angles; (see xuzorapN;) see also 2, and 6, and Q. Q. 1.]

xazarahu, aor. _u {yaxozuru}, (TA,) inf. n. xazorN, (Ḳ,) He looked at him from the outer angle of the eye; (Ḳ,* TA;) as one does in pride, and in light estimation of the object at which he looks. (MF.) A poet says,
laA taxozuri Alqawoma XazorFA Eano muEaAraDapK
[Look not thou at the people from the outer angle of the eye, askew, sideways]. (TA.)
xazara [as an intrans. v.] He affected, or pretended, to be cunning; i. e. intelligent, or sagacious; or intelligent with a mixture of craft and forecast; syn. tadaAhaI. (IAạr, Ḳ. [See also 2.])
Also He fled. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. xz-r, (TA,) inf. n. taxoziyrN, (Ḳ,) He made narrow. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, xz-r Eayonayohi He (an old man) narrowed his eyes; contracted his eyelids as though they were sewed together; to collect the light: when a young man does so, yatadaAhaI bicelika [i. e. he affects, or pretends, thereby, to be cunning; i. e. intelligent, or sagacious; or intelligent with a mixture of craft and forecast]. (IAạr. [See also xazara: and see 6.])
6. txAzr He looked from the outer angle of his eye. (TA. [See also Q. Q. 1.])
He pretended, or made a show of, what is termed xazarN: [see 1.] (TA, and Ḥar p. 62.)
He contracted his eyelids, to sharpen the sight: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) a verb similar to tEAmI and tjAhl. (Ṣ. [See also 2.])
Q. Q. 1. xanozara He looked from the outer angles of his eyes: from the subst. xinoziyrN, because the animal so called is Oaxozaru. (A. [See also 6.])
Also He acted like the swine. (TA in art. xnzr.)
xazarN [commonly known only as inf. n. of xazira or xazirati AlEayonu]: see xaziyrN.
xaziru AlEayoni: see Oaxozaru.
xazorapN: see xuzarapN.
xuzorapN A turning of the pupil towards the outer angle of the eye. (TA. [See 1.])

xuzarapN (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ) and xazorapN↓ (Ḳ) A pain in the back: (Ḳ:) a pain in a vertebra of the back: (Ṣ:) a pain in the slender part of the back, in [the vertebra called] fiqorapu AlqaTani: (TA:) the pl. of the former is xuzaraAtN. (Ṣ, TA.)

xaziyrN and xaziyrapN↓ A kind of food like EaSiydap with flesh-meat; (Ḳ;) made of flesh-meat (Ṣ, TA) that has remained throughout a night, (TA,) cut into small pieces, and put into a cooking-pot with abundance of water, (Ṣ, TA,) and with salt; (TA;) and when it is thoroughly cooked, some flour is sprinkled upon it, (Ṣ, TA,) and it is stirred about with it, and seasoned with any seasoning that the maker pleases to add: (TA:) when there is no flesh-meat, it is called EaSiydap: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or a broth made with the water in which bran has been soaked, (Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) which water is strained, and then cooked: (Mgh, TA:) this is what is called by the Persians sabuwsabaA: (Mgh:) [see also HariyrapN:] or xaziyrap is flour thrown upon water or upon milk, and cooked, and then eaten with dates, or supped: it is also called saxiynapN and saxuwnapN and nafiytapN and Hucoruq-apN: Hariyarp is thinner: (AHeyth, on the authority of an Arab of the desert:) and a soup made of grease or gravy (Ḳ) and flour; (TA;) as also xazarN↓: (Ḳ:) but no one except the author of the Ḳ mentions this last form: in the other lexicons, soup of grease or gravy is said only to be called xaziyrN and xaziyrapN. (TA.)
xaziyrapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
xaAzirN A man possessing much cunning; i. e. intelligence, or sagacity; or intelligence with a mixture of craft and forecast. (AA, Ḳ.)

xinoziyrN [The swine; the hog; the pig;] a certain foul animal, (Mṣb,) well known; (Ḳ;) said to be forbidden [to be eaten] by every prophet: (Mṣb:) [fem. with p {xinoziyrapN}:] pl. xanaAziyru: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) not, as some say, xuzorN: [though this is an epithet applicable to swine:] (TA:) accord. to some, it is of the measure fiEoliylN; because n is not [generally] added as a second letter: but accord. to others, of the measure finoEiylN; because n is sometimes added as a second letter, and because it is held to be derived from xazira, since all xnAzyr are xuzor; as it is said in the A, kul-u xinoziyrK Oaxozaru. (TA.)

xanaAziyru also signifies A well-known disease; (Ṣ;) [scrofula; or glandular swellings in the neck;] ulcers, (Ḳ,) or hard ulcers, (Ṣ,) which arise in the neck: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or ganglions, or hard or nodous lumps beneath the skin, in the neck, and in soft parts, such as the armpits; but most frequently in the neck. (Mgh.)
xawozaraI: see what next follows, in two places.

xayozaraI and xawozaraI↓ A certain mode of walking, with a looseness of the joints, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) as though the limbs were dislocated; (A;) as also xayozalaI and xawozalaI: (Ṣ in art. xzl, and TA:) or a limping, or halting, manner of walking: or an elegant, and a proud and self-conceited, gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (TA.) You say, huwa yamoXiI AlxayozaraI and AlxawozaraI↓ He walks with a looseness of the joints,, &c. (A.)

xayozuraAnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) vulgarly pronounced xayozaraAn, (TA,) [a coll. gen. n., The kind of cane called rattan; so in the present day;] a kind of Indian tree, which consists of roots extending upon the ground; as also xayozuwrN↓: (Ḳ:) or [a kind of tree] not growing in the country of the Arabs, but only in that of the Greeks; whence the saying of En-Nábighah El-Jaadee,
bilaAduhumo bilaAdu AlxayozuraAni
[Their lands are the lands of the kheyzurán]: it is a kind of plant with pliable and smooth twigs: (ISd:) or a kind of tree, (Ṣ,) the roots of the qanaA [by which are app. meant the canes of which spear-shafts are made]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. xayaAziru. (Ṣ.)
Reed, or reeds; cane, or canes. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And hence, Musical reeds or pipes. (TA.)
Spears: (IAạr, Ḳ:) because of their pliableness: (TA:) [or because commonly made of canes:] pl. as above. (TA.)
Any pliable twig or rod; (Mbr, Ḳ;) any piece of wood that is pliable. (AHeyth.) [Often applied in the present day to the osier; as well as to the rattan: n. un. with p {xayozuraAnapN}.]
The rod which kings hold in their hands, and with which they amuse themselves (yataEab-avuwna) and make signs. (Ḥam p. 710.)
The pole with which a ship, or boat, is pushed or propelled, (Mbr, Ḳ,) when pliable, or bending; as also xayozaArapN↓. (Mbr, TA.)

Also, (AO, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and with p {xayozuraAnapN}, (Ṣ, TA,) The suk-aAn (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) of a ship, (Ḳ,) i. e. its kawoval [meaning the rudder]: (TA:) or, accord. to ʼAmr Ibn-Bahr, the lijaAm [lit. the bridle and bit, app. meaning the tiller] of a ship, by means of which the suk-aAn, which is the canab, is directed. (TA: [but instead of AltI bhA yqwm Als-uk-Anu whw fI Alcnb, I read AlcI bh yuqaw-amu Als-uk-aAnu whwAlc-anabu.]) En-Nábighah says, describing the Euphrates in the time of its increase, or fulness,
yaZal-u mino xawfihi Almal-aAHu muEotaSimFA
biAloxayozuraAnapi baEoda AlOayoni waAln-ajadi
[By reason of his fear, the sailor becomes in a state of cleaving, or laying fast hold, upon the xyzrAnp, (which may here mean the pole above mentioned, or the rudder, or the tiller,) after fatigue and distress]. (Ṣ, TA.) In a trad. it is said that the devil, when he had been commanded by Noah to go forth from the ark, mounted upon the xyzrAn of the ark, i. e. its suk-aAn. (TA.)
xayozuwrN: see the last paragraph above.
xayozaArapN: see the last paragraph above.

Oaxozaru A man having narrow and small eyes: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or having eyes of which the sight is contracted, naturally: (Ḳ:) or who looks from the outer angle of his eye: (A:) or who is as though he so looked: (Ṣ:) or who looks as though on one side: or who opens and closes his eyes; (Ḳ;) or, his eye: (M:) or who has a distortion (HawalN) of one of his eyes: (Ḳ:) or whose eyes look towards his nose: (TA:) [or whose eyes look towards their outer angles: (see xurorapN:)] and Oaxozaru AlEayoni one who looks askew, or sideways; as also xaziru↓ AlEayoni, an epithet applied to an enemy: (TA:) the fem. of Oaxozaru is xazoraMCu: (A, Mṣb:) and the pl. is xuzorN. (Ḳ.) You say also OaEoyunN xuzorN [meaning Eyes that are narrow and small:, &c.]. (TA.)
xazaEobalN Stories that are held to be clever, ingenious, or elegant, (IDrd, Ḳ,) and at which one laughs. (IDrd.)
xuzaEobalapN or xuzaEobilapN (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ) A wonderful thing. (IAạr, Ḳ.) And [the pls.] xuzaEobilaAtN and xuzaEobalaAtN False, or vain, stories. (Ḥar p. 16.)
xuzaEobiylN: see xuzaEobalN.
xuzaEobiylapN A laughable thing; a thing that makes people laugh. (Ṣ, Ḳ) One says, haAti baEoDa xuzaEobiylaAtika [Give me some of thy laughable thingsor stories]. (Ṣ.)

xazafN Pottery; jars; or earthern vessels; syn. jar-N; (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ; [and so in the present day;]) and anything made of clay, and baked, so that it becomes fax-aAr: (IDrd, Ḳ:) or clay made into vessels, before it is baked; i. q. SaloSaAlN: when baked, it is called fax-aAr. (Mṣb.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce Uino, p. 107.]
xazafiI-N [Of, or relating to, pottery, or jars,, &c.;] rel. n. of xazafN. (TA.)
See also what follows.
xaz-aAfN and xazafiI-N↓ A seller [or maker] of xazaf [or pottery, jars,, &c.]. (TA.)

1. xazaqa, aor. _i {yaxoziqu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. xazoqN and xuzuwqN, (TA,) It (an arrow) hit the target; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or the object at which it was shot; (ISd, TA;) as also xasaqa↓ [q. v.]: (TA:) or transpierced, or passed through, or its extremity passed through, (Mgh, TA,) making the blood to flow: (TA:) [and app. also it stuck fast therein: (see xazoqN, below:)] or xazaqa AlqiroTaAsa it (an arrow) transpierced, or passed through, the target; or pierced it so that its extremity passed through. (Mṣb.)

xazaqahu, aor. _i {yaxoziqu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xazoqN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He pierced him [with a spear or the like]. (Ṣ Mṣb, Ḳ.) And He pierced him slightly with a spear. (TA.) And It (an arrow) hit him. (JK.)
And xazaqotuhumo biAln-aboli I hit them with the arrows. (Ṣ.) [Whence,] xazaqahu biEayonihi ‡ He looked sharply at him; and cast his eye at him, or smote him with his eye: (Lḥ, TA:) or he wounded him with his eye. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Z, TA.)
Also He stuck it (i. e. anything sharp) into the ground (Lth, JK, TA), &c. (Lth, TA.)
7. Anxzq He became pierced [with a spear or the like]. (Ḳ.)
It (anything sharp, JK) became stuck into the ground [&c.]. (JK, TA.)
Also, or Axtzq↓, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, the latter in the CK,) It (a sword) became drawn from its scabbard. (Ḳ, TA.)
8: see what next precedes {7}.
xazoqN inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ,* Mṣb, TA.)

[I also find in the TA, Alxzq mA yvbt wAlxzq mAynfc, as though meaning that xazoqN signifies A thing that becomes fixed or fast: and also a thing that transpierces, or passes through: but these may be loose explanations, intended to mean that xazoqN is said of that which becomes fixed or fast (as an arrow in the body pierced by it), and also of that which transpierces, or passes through: see xasaqa, of which the inf. n., xasoqN, is said to be used in these two senses.]
xazuwqN A she-camel that pierces the ground with her toes, (Ḳ, TA,) making marks upon it: (TA:) or that furrows the ground with her toe turned up, as she goes. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also xasuwqN.]

xaAziqN, applied to an arrow, Hitting, or that hits, the target; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) and (Mgh, TA) transpiercing, or passing through, or that transpierces or passes through, or piercing, or that pierces, so that its extremity passes through, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the target [or the object shot at]; (Mṣb;) as also xaAsiqN: (TA:) pl. xawaAziqu. (Mṣb.) And [hence, used as a subst.,] A spear-head: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the iron head or blade of an arrow, &c. (TA.) One says, huwa OamoDaI mino xaAziqK [He is more penetrating than a spear-head]: (Ṣ:) and Oanofadu mino xaAziqK, which means the same; (JK, Meyd;) or more penetrating than a transpiercing arrow: (TA:) the latter is a prov.; (Meyd, TA;) applied to him who is penetrating in affairs. (Meyd.) And Uin-ahu laxaAziqu waraqapK [lit. Verily he is a piercer, or transpiercer, of a leaf]; meaning laA yuTomaEu fiyhi [i. e. † he is a person whom one may not hope to overcome]: (IAạr, Ḳ:) or † he is bold and skilful. (Ḳ.)
[xaAzuwqN A stake for impaling a man: but this I believe to be post-classical: pl. xawaAziyqu.]

mixozaqN A small stick, (JK, Ḳ,) with a pointed end, (JK,) or having at its end a sharp nail, (Ḳ,) that is with the seller of full-grown unripe dates for date-stones [which are used as food for camels]: (JK, Ḳ:) he has many maxaAziq [pl. of mixozaqN]; and a boy comes to him with date-stones, which he takes from him on the condition that he shall strike with the mxzq a certain number of times and have as many of the dates as become thus transfixed for him, whether many or few, but nothing if he miss. (Ḳ.)
mixozaqapN A dart, or javelin. (TA.)
muxotazaqN Chase, or game; i. e. an object of the chase or the like. (JK, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xazalahu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxozulu}, (Mṣb,) or _i, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xazolN, (Mṣb,) He cut it off. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See also 8.]
xazalahu Eano HaAjatihi, aor. _i {yaxozilu}, † He impeded, hindered, prevented, or withheld, him from attaining the object of his want. (Ḳ,* TA.)
xazila, aor. _a {yaxozalu}, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. xazalN, (JK,) He had a fracture in his back. (JK, Ḳ.)
Also, (TḲ,) inf. n. as above; (Ḳ;) and txz-l↓ and Anxzl↓; He walked in a heavy, or sluggish, manner: (Ḳ:) or, as in the ʼEyn, with a looseness of the joints. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1.
[Hence,] txz-l Als-aHaAbu The clouds appeared as though they were retreating, by reason of the heaviness, or sluggishness, of their motion. (M, Ḳ,* TA.)
7. Anxzl It became cut off. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
[Hence,] Anxzl fiI kalaAmihi † He became cut short, or stopped, in his speech. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
Anxzl Eano jawaAbiI He cared not for my answer, or reply. (M, Ḳ.)
See also 1.

hom.sense: 8. Axtzlhu He cut it off for himself. (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ.*) One says, Axtzl AlmaAla He cut off for himself the property. (TA.) And Axtzlhu Eani Alqawomi He cut him off from the people, or party. (Ṣ.)

And hence, Aixotazalotu AlwadiyEapa † I was unfaithful in respect of the trust, or deposit; even if meaning I refused to restore it: because the doing so is a cutting off, for one's self, of the property of the owner. (Mṣb.)

Accord. to Sb and the Ḳ, AlAixotizaAlu is also syn. with AlHacofu [The cutting off a thing; or cutting it so as to lessen it at its extremity;, &c.]: but ISd says, I know not this on the authority of any other than Sb. (TA.)
AlxtzAl also signifies The being alone (Ḳ, TA) in opinion; with none to share therein. (TA.)
And Axtzl, He (a man) became lame; or walked lamely. (TA.)

entry.sense: xazolN: see what next follows.
xazolapN: see what next follows.
xuzolapN, (JK, Ḳ,) or, as in the M, xazolapN↓ and xazolN↓, (TA,) A fracture in the back. (JK, M, Ḳ.)
xuzalapN One who impedes, hinders, prevents, or withholds, another from that which he desires to do. (Az, Ḳ,* TA.)
xayozalN: see xawozlaI.
xawozalapN i. q. UiEoyaMCN [Fatigue: or a fatiguing]. (TA.)

xawozalaI and xayozalaI↓ A certain mode of walking, with a looseness of the joints; like xawozaraI and xayozaraI: (Ṣ:) or a heavy, or sluggish, manner of walking; as also xayozalN↓: (Ḳ:) the dual of xawozalaI [to which that of xayozalaI is similar] is xawozalaAni. (IAmb, TA in art. qhqr.) Accord. to the T, one says, huwa yamoXiI AlxayozalaI↓ and AlxawozalaI, meaning He walks with an elegant, and a proud and self-conceited, gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: or as though thorns pricked his feet. (TA.)
xayozalaI: see what next precedes, in two places.
And A camel whose hump has entirely gone away: (Ḳ:) so says Lth; but Az thinks that this may be a mistranscription for Oajozalu; or x and j may be interchangeable in this case. (TA.)
Also Lame. (AA, TA.)
maxozuwlN: see what next precedes, in two places.

1. xazamahu, aor. _i {yaxozimu}, (Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. xazomN, (JK, TA,) He pierced it, or perforated it; (JK, Mgh, Ḳ;) namely, a thing of any kind: for instance, the nose of a camel, for the [ring called] xizaAmap [to which the rein is attached]: and the letter of a Kádee to another Kádee; for such a letter is pierced for the siHaMCap [or strip of paper with which it is bound], and is then sealed [upon this strip]; and when this is done, the letter is said to be maxozuwmN↓. (Mgh.) You say, xazama AlbaEiyra, aor. as above, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and so the inf. n., (Mṣb,) He pierced the nose of the camel (Mgh, Mṣb) for the xizaAmap: (Mgh:) or xazama AlbaEiyra (Ṣ, Ḳ) biAlxizaAmapi, (Ṣ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) he put the xzAmp in the side of the nostril, (Ḳ,) or in the partition between the nostrils, (Ṣ,) [but the former is the more common practice,] of the camel; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xz-mhu↓; (Ḳ;) [or] this signifies the doing so much, or often. (TA.) [Hence,] xazama Oanofahu † He brought him under, or into, subjection; rendered him submissive, tractable, or manageable. (TA.) And xazamotu AljaraAda fiI AlEuwdi I spitted the locusts in a series upon the [skewer, or] piece of stick or wood. (Ṣ.) And xazama XiraAka naEolihi He pierced and tied the [thong called] XarAk [q. v.] of his sandal [app. so as to attach to it the two branches (EaDudaA AlX-iraAki) of the strap that encompasses the heel]. (TA, [See also xizaAmapN.])

[Also He cut it. for] Alxazomu is syn. with AlqaToEu. (Ḥam p. 166. [It is there also said to be syn. with AlXd; i. e. AlX-ad-u; but this is app. a mistake for AlX-ak-u, a meaning assigned to it in the JK, agreeably with the Ḳ.])
2: see 1.

3. xAzmhu, (Ṣ,) or xAzimhu AlT-ariyqa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaAzamapN (Ṣ in art. xSr) [and xizaAmN], He (a man, Ṣ) took a different way from his (another's) until they both met in one place: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the doing so is also termed muxaASarapN: (Ṣ in art. xSr, and TA:) it is as though it were a rivalling, or imitating, in travelling. (TA.) Ibn-Fesweh says,
UicaA huwa naH-aAhaA Eani AlqaSodi xaAzamato
bihi Aljawora Hat-aI tasotaqiymu DuHaI Algadi
i. e. When he turns her, meaning his she-camel, from the right way, she pursues with him a way different from the wrong, so that she overcomes him, and takes the right way, in the early daytime of the morrow. (TA.) muxaAzamapN also signifies The act of rivalling, or imitating. (JK, TA.) And one says, laqiytuhu xizaAmFA (JK, TA) and maxaAzamapF, (JK,) meaning I met him face to face: (TA:) or suddenly, or unexpectedly, and face to face. (JK.)
5. txz-m AlX-awoku fiI rijolihi The thorns pierced his foot, or leg, and entered into it. (Ḳ,* TA.)
6. txAzm AljayoXaAni The two armies rivalled, or imitated, each other; or opposed each other; syn. taEaAraDaA. (TA.)

hom.sense: xazamN A certain kind of tree, (JK, T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the bark of which ropes are made: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) it is like the dawom [or Theban palm]; (Ḳ;) having branches with small dates, which become black when ripe, bitter, astringent, or disagreeable and choking; not eaten by men; but the crows are greedy of them, and come to them time after time: so says AḤn.: (TA:) n. un. with p {xazamapN}. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
See also xazuwmapN.

entry.sense: xuzamN: see xuzaAmaI.
xuzumN [a pl. of which the sing is not mentioned] Sewers of skins or hides or boots and the like; syn. xar-aAzuwna. (TA.)
xazamapN n. un. of xazamN, explained above. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
Also The leaves (xuwS) of the muqol [or Theban palm]; (JK, Ḳ;) of which are made women's OaHofaAX [i. e. receptacles for their perfumes and other similar things, pl. of HifoXN]. (TA.)
UibilN xazomaI: see maxozuwmN.
xizaAmN: see xiraAmapN, in two places.
xazuwmN: see xazuwmapN.

xizaAmapN A ring of [goat's] hair, which is put [in the side of the nostril (see 1) or] in the partition between the nostrils of the camel, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* TA,) and to which is tied the rein; (Ṣ, TA;) as also xizaAmN↓: (TA, and Ḥar p. 73:) or a burap in the nose of a she-camel: (JK:) or, accord. to the Ḳ, a burap which is put in the side of the nostril of the camel: but Lth says that when it is of brass it is termed burap; and when of [goat's] hair, xizaAmap: (TA:) pl. xazaAYimu (JK, Mṣb, TA) and xizaAmaAtN. (Mṣb.) [Hence,] OaEoTaI AlquroMna xazaAYimahu: from a trad. of Abu-d-Dardà, in which it is said, murohumo Oano yuEoTuwA AlquroMna bixazaAtimihimo ‡ Command ye them that they submit themselves to the judgment, or decision, of the Ḳur-án; xzAYm being here pl. of xizaAmapN: (IAth, TA:) or OaEoTuwA AlquroMna xazaAYimahu † Render ye to the Ḳur-án its due. (JK.) [In the present day, xizaAmN↓, vulgarly pronounced xuzaAm, is applied to A woman's nose-ring, of gold or other metal.]
The xizaAmap of the sandal is A slender thong which is pierced and tied between [the two thongs called] the XiraAkaAni [app. here meaning the EaDudaAni of the XiraAk: see 1]. (Ḳ,* TA.)

xuzaAmaI A certain plant, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) called also xuzamN↓, (JK,) of sweet odour: (TA:) or i. q. xiyriI-u Albar-i [q. v.]; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) accord. to El-Fárábee: one of the plants of the desert: said by Az to be a certain herb of sweet odour, having a flower like that of the violet: (Mṣb:) [accord. to the book entitled maA laA yasaEu AlT-abiyba jaholahu, as stated by Golius, a certain wild herb, having a long stalk, small leaves, red flower, and very sweet odour:] its flower is the sweetest of flowers in odour; the fumigation therewith dispels every fetid odour; the use thereof as a suppository in the vagina promotes pregnancy; and the taking it internally restores to a right state the liver and the spleen, and the brain affected with cold: (Ḳ:) [in the present day, applied to the common lavender; lavandula spica:] n. un. xuzaAmaApN. (TA.)

xazuwmapN i. q. baqarapN [app. as meaning both A bull and a cow], (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the dial. of Hudheyl; (Ṣ;) or such as is advanced in age, and short: (M, Ḳ:) pl. xazuwmN↓, [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [the pl. is] xazaAYimu (JK, Ḳ) and xazuwmaAtN (Ṣ) and [quasi-pl. n.] xazamN↓. (TA.)
xaz-aAmN A maker of ropes of the bark of the tree called xazam. (JK, Ṣ.*) [Accord. to the Ḳ, A seller of the kind of tree called xazam: but this is a mistake, app. caused by an omission in the Ḳ.]
AryHN xaAzimN † A cold wind; as though it pierced through the extremities: so says Kr: AʼObeyd says xaArimN: accord. to the Ḳ, both signify the same. (TA.)

maxozuwmN Anything pierced or perforated: (Ṣ, Mgh:) applied in this sense, (JK,) or as meaning pierced and tied, (TA, [see 1,]) to the [thong, of a sandal, called] XiraAk; (JK, TA;) or, thus applied, it means cut. (Ḥam p. 166.) See also 1, first sentence, for its meaning as applied to a letter.

Any animal having the nose pierced. (Mṣb.) And UibilN xazomaI↓ means Camels having rings such as are termed xazaAYim ( pl. of xizaAmap) in their nostrils; (IAạr, Ḳ, TA;) as also muxaz-amapN↓. (IAạr, TA.) All birds, also, are said to be maxozuwmap, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and muxaz-amap↓; (Ḳ;) because perforated in the partition between the nostrils: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and particularly the ostrich is said to be maxozuwm (Ṣ, Ḳ *) and muxaz-am↓. (JK, Ḳ.*) One says, maAhumo Uil-aA kaQloOanoEaAmi Almuxaz-amapi↓, meaning ‡ They are none others than stupid, or foolish, persons. (TA. [But kaQloOanoEaAmi is app., here, a mistranscription for kaQln-aEaAmi; for the ostrich is proverbial for stupidity: one says OaHomaqu mino naEaAmapK “More stupid than an ostrich:” because, as Meyd says, when an ostrich happens to see the eggs of another ostrich, it will sit upon them, and forget its own eggs.])

hom.sense: 1. xazanahu, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxozunu}, (JK, Mṣb,) inf. n. xazanN, (Mṣb,) He reposited it, stowed it, or put it, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) laid it up, kept it, preserved it, or guarded it, (JK, Ḳ,) in a xizaAnap, (JK, Ṣ,) or in a maxozin [or maxozan]; (Mṣb;) namely, a thing, (JK, Mṣb,) or property; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Axtznhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Astxznhu↓: or ↓the second of these signifies he did so for himself. (TA.)
And [hence] the first (Ṣ, Mṣb) and ↓the second, (Ṣ,) † He concealed it; namely, a secret. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
And xazana Eanohu EaTaMCahu † He withheld from him his gift. (TA.)

xazina, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) formed by transposition from xaniza, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yaxozanu}, inf. n. xazanN; (Mṣb;) and xazuna; and xazana, [aor. _u {yaxozunu},] inf. n. xazonN and xuzuwnN; (Ḳ;) said of flesh-meat, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It became altered [for the worse] (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ) in odour, (Mṣb,) or stinking: (Ṣ, TA:) or, accord. to Z, xazuna, said of flesh-meat, means it became stinking in consequence of its being laid up, or stored: and Er-Rághib says that xazonN, in relation to flesh-meat, means the laying up, or storing: and hence is metonymically used as meaning its becoming stinking. (TA.) Tarafeh says,
vum-a laA yaxozanu fiynaA laHomuhaA
Uin-amaA yaxozanu laHomu Almud-axiro
[Then the flesh thereof will not become stinking among us: only the flesh-meat of him who lays it up becomes stinking]. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Axzn He became rich, or in a state of competence or sufficiency, after poverty. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 8: see 1, in three places.
Axtzn TariyqFA He took the nearest road, or way. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: xazonapN: see xaziynapN:
and see also xizaAnapN.
xaziynN A thing reposited, stowed, or put, [laid up, kept, preserved, or guarded,] in a maxozin [or maxozan or xizaAnap]. (Mṣb.)
Flesh-meat altered [for the worse in odour]; (Ḳ;) stinking. (TA.)

hom.sense: xizaAnapN A small chamber within a large chamber; (TA in art. xdE;) [a closet; also called in the present day xazonapN↓: and a cupboard:] a place in which things are reposited, stowed, laid up, kept, preserved, or guarded; a repository; [a magazine; a store-room;] (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and so maxozanN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with fet-ḥ to the z, (Ṣ,) like maqoEadN, (Ḳ,) or maxozinN↓, like majolisN, [which is irreg., as the aor. of xazana is yaxozunu:] (Mṣb:) the former should not be pronounced with fet-ḥ [i. e. xazaAnap], (Ḳ,) as the vulgar are given to pronounce it: (TA:) the pl. of the former is xazaAYinu; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and that of mxzn is maxaAzinu. (Mṣb, TA.) [Hence, xizaAnapu kutubK A library; and a bookcase. And xizaAnapu silaAHK An armoury.]
And ‡ The heart; (Ḳ, TA;) because the secret is concealed in it. (TA.) See an ex. voce xaAzinN.
Also The occupation, (JK, TA,) and act, (Ḳ, TA,) of the xaAzin. (JK, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: xaziynapN and xazonapN↓ Wealth, or property, reposited, stowed, laid up, kept, preserved, or guarded. (TA.) [In the present day, both signify also A treasury. The pl. of the former is xazaAYinu.]

[Hence,] xazaAYinu Qll-ehi [in the Ḳur. vi. 50 and xi. 33, accord. to some,] means † The hidden things that are known of God: (TA:) or † the events decreed by God: (Bḍ in vi. 50:) or † the treasures of the means of subsistence that are supplied by God. (Bḍ and Jel * ibid.)

hom.sense: xaz-aAnN One who stores up wheat, or food: of the dial. of Egypt. (TA.)
See also xaAzinN.
Also, as a subst, like jab-aAnN, (AḤn,) Ripe dates becoming black in the interior by reason of some bane: (AḤn, Ḳ:) n. un. with p {xaz-aAnapN}. (AḤn.)

entry.sense: xaAzinN [One who reposits, stows, lays up, keeps, preserves, or guards, property, &c.; a treasurer]: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. xaAzinuwna and xazanapN. (TA.) [The latter of these pls. is applied in the Ḳur. xxxix. 73 to The keepers, or guardians, of Paradise: and in xxxix. 71 and xl. 52 and lxvii. 8 to those of Hell.] maA Oanotumo lahu bixaAziniyna, in the Ḳur [xv. 22, accord. to some], means † Ye are not bearing it in mind with thankfulness. (TA.)

‡ The tongue; as also xaz-aAnN↓. (Ḳ, TA.) Hence the saying of Lukmán to his son, UicaA kaAna xaAzinuka HafiyZFA waxizaAnatuka↓ OamiynapF raXadota fiI Oamorayoka dunoyaAka waMxiratika, i. e. ‡ [When] thy tongue [is such as keeps the secret confided to thee], and thy heart [is trustworthy, thou wilt follow the right way in respect of thy two states, thy state in the present world and thy state in the world to come]. (TA.)
maxozanN and maxozinN: see xizaAnapN.
maxaAzinu AlT-ariyqi The nearest roads, or ways. (Ḳ,* TA. [In the CK, maHASiruhu is erroneously put for maxaASiruhu.])
1. xazaAhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yaxozuwhu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. xazowN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He ruled, or governed, him; and subdued him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And xazaA Ald-aAb-apa He broke, or trained, the beast. (Ḳ.)

Also He withheld, or restrained, him from [indulging] his natural desire. (Ḳ.) And xazaA Aln-afosa, inf. n. as above, He withheld, or restrained, the soul from its purpose, or intention. (JK.) One says, Auxozu fiI TaAEapi Qll-ehi nafosaka Withhold thou, or restrain thou, thy soul from its purpose, or intention, and make it to endure patiently the right course of events, in obedience to God. (TA.)
And He slit his tongue [to prevent his sucking]; namely, a young camel's. (Ḳ.)
He possessed him, or it. (Ḳ.)
He treated him, or regarded him, with enmity, or hostility. (Ḳ.)
And xazowN (JK, TA) and xizaAyapN (JK) signify The act of piercing, or thrusting, (JK, TA,) with spears. (JK.)

hom.sense: 1. xaziIa, aor. yaxozaI, inf. n. xizoIN (Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and xazFI (Sb, Ḳ) and xizoyapN and maxozaApN, (MA, [or these two are simple substs.,]) He was, or became, base, abased, abject, vile, despicable, or ignominious: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:) or, accord. to ISk, he fell into trial, or affliction: (Ṣ:) or he fell into trial, or affliction, (Ḳ, TA,) and evil, (TA,) and a thing that exposed him to disgrace, and thereby became base, abased, abject, vile, despicable, or ignominious; as also AixozawaI↓, (Ḳ, TA,) like AiroEawaI: (TA:) or xizoIN signifies disgrace, or ignominy: so in the Ḳur v. 37 [&c.]: (Sh, TA:) or its primary signification is a state of abasement, vileness, or ignominy, of which one is ashamed: so accord. to Er-Rághib and Bḍ and the Ksh: (MF, TA:) or the manifesting foul actions or qualities, for the manifesting of which one deserves punishment: (El-Harállee, TA:) or xaziIa signifies he became disgraced, and was confounded, or perplexed, by reason of disgrace. (TA.)

And xaziIa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ṣ, Mgh,) inf. n. xazaAyapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xazFI, (Ḳ,) He was, or became, moved, or affected, with shame; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [as also AstxzI↓: see the part. n. of this latter below:] or xazaAyapN signifies the being moved, or affected, with much, or intense, shame. (JK.)
xaAzaAniI faxazayotuhu: see the next paragraph {3}.
xizaAyapN: see art. xzw.

entry.sense: 3. xaAzaAniI, inf. n. muxaAzaApN, He vied, or contended, with me in mutual abasing; or rendering base, abject, vile, despicable, or ignominious. (TḲ.) You say, xaAzaAniI faxazayotuhu↓, (Ks, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. of the latter Oaxoziyhi, (Ks, JK, Ṣ,) [inf. n. app. xazoIN,] I vied, or contended, with him (JK, TḲ) in mutual abasing,, &c., (TḲ,) and I surpassed, or overcame, him [therein]: (JK:) [or it may signify, in abasement,, &c.; for] the meaning [of the latter verb with its pronoun] is kunotu OaXad-a xazoyFA minohu. (Ḳ: in the CK, xizoyFA: but in a MṢ copy of the Ḳ, xizoyFA.)

4. AxzAhu He (God) abased him; or rendered him base, abject, vile, despicable, or ignominious: or may He abase him;, &c.: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or He disgraced him, or put him to shame: or may He disgrace him,, &c. (Ḳ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xi. 80], the saying of Lot to his people, walaA tuxozuwni fiI DayofiI (TA) And disgrace ye not me in respect of my guests: (Bḍ, Jel, TA:) or make not me ashamed, &c. (Bḍ.) One says also, of him who has done or said that which is approved, maAlahu OxozaAhu Qll-ehu [What aileth him? May God abase him, or disgrace him!]; and so without mA lh: (Ḳ:) it is like maA lahu qaAtalahu Qll-ehu, said of a man whose action pleases: (Ṣ in art. nfr:) it is used in lieu of praise, to charm a person against the evil eye; and means a prayer for him, not an imprecation against him. (TA.) See also muxozK, below.
Also He made him to be ashamed for himself (Ḥam pp. 114 and 397, and TA) in respect of him, for his shortcoming. (TA.) [See the citation from the Ḳur above.]
He compelled him, or constrained him, to admit an evidence, or a proof, whereby he abased him, or disgraced him. (TA.)
And He aided him in, and made him to keep to, a maxozaAp [i. e. a thing that was a cause of shame, or of abasement or disgrace]. (TA.)
9. AixozawaI: see 1.
xazK [part. n. of xaziIa] Base, abased, abject, rile, despicable, or ignominious. (MA.) [See also xazoyaAnu and muxozFI.]

xazoyapN A habit, a quality, a practice, or an action, (JK,) or a crime, a sin, or an offence, or act of disobedience, (TA,) of which one is, or should be, ashamed: (JK, TA: [and maxozaApN↓, which is coupled therewith in the JK, app. as syn. with it, properly signifies a thing, or an action,, &c., that is a cause of shame, or of abasement or disgrace; being a noun of the class of maboxalapN and majobanapN; originally maxozayapN: see 4, last sentence:]) and muxoziyapN↓, of the form of an act. part. n., from OaxozaI, signifies [the same; or] a bad, an evil, or a foul, habit, quality, practice, or action: the pl. of this last is muxoziyaAtN, and of the same [and of maxozaApN also] maxaAzK. (Mṣb.) Or the first signifies A habit, a practice, or an action, in which one becomes base, despicable, or ignominious. (Mgh.)
Also A trial, or an affliction, (Ḳ, TA,) into which one is made to fall; (TA;) and so xizoyapN↓. (Ḳ.)
xizoyapN: see what next precedes.

xazoyaAnu Moved, or affected, with shame; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 36;) as also musotaxozK↓: (Ḥar p. 482:) or, with much shame, (Lth, JK, TA,) on account of a bad, or foul, deed that he has done: (Lth, TA:) or it may signify [like xazK] base, abased, abject, vile, despicable, or ignominious: (Ḥam ubi suprà:) fem. xazoyaA (Lth, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and xazoyaAnapN, which is irreg.: (TA:) pl. xazaAyaA. (Lth, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
muxozFI Rendered base, abject, vile, despicable, or ignominious, by a thing proved against him. (TA.) [See also xazK and xazoyaAnu.]

kalaAmN muxozK Speech, or language, that is approved, so that one says of its author, OaxozaAhu Qll-ehu. (TA.) They relate that El-Farezdaḳ gave utterance to an excellent verse, and said, hecaA bayotN muxoziI-a, i. e. [This is a verse such as that,] when it is recited, people will say, [or rather, such as will make it to be said of me,] OaxozaI↓ Qll-ehu qaAYilahu maA OaXoEarahu [May God abase, or disgrace, the sayer thereof! How good, or excellent, a poet is he!]. (TA. [See 4.]) [Hence,] qaSiydapN muxoziyapN [An ode] that is extremely good. (TA.)
maxozaApN, said in the MA to be an inf. n. of xaziIa: see xazoyapN.
muxoziyapN: see xazoyapN.
musotaxozK: see xazoyaAnu.

hom.sense:
1. xas-a, (Mṣb, TA,) sec. pers. xasisota, (Fr, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaxas-u; (A, Mṣb, TA;)
and xas-a, sec. pers. xasasota, aor. yaxis-u; (Mṣb, TA;) inf. n. xis-apN (Fr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and xasaAsapN (Fr, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xusuwsN, (TA,) He (a man) was, or became, low or ignoble, base, vile, mean or sordid, weak; (Fr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) [or, more commonly,] contemptible: (Fr,* Ṣ,* A, Ḳ:) and it (a thing) was, or became, base, vile, or mean; (TA;) or contemptible, paltry, or inconsiderable; (Mṣb,* TA;) and bad, corrupt, abominable, or disapproved. (TA.)
xas-a fiEoluhu, and qawoluhu, and raOoyuhu, and HaZ-uhu, ‡ [His action, and his saying, and his opinion, and his fortune, was, or became, low or ignoble,, &c.] (A.)
xas-a, aor. yaxis-u, It was, or became, light of weight, not equal to what corresponded with it. (Mṣb.)

xas-a, aor. yaxus-u; (Mṣb;) and Axs-↓, (ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UixosaAsN; (ISk, Ṣ;) ‡ He did what was low or ignoble, base, vile, mean or sordid, weak; [or, more commonly,] contemptible: (ISk,* Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ:) or ↓the latter signifies he did something low or ignoble,, &c., in actions. (TA.)

xas-a naSiybahu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh,* Ḳ,) aor. yaxus-u; (Ṣ, TA;) and Axs-hu↓; (Mgh;) He made his lot, portion, or share, to be low or ignoble, base, vile, mean; [or, more commonly,] contemptible: (Ṣ,* A, Mgh,* Ḳ:) and xas-a AlHaZ-a, and Axs-hu↓, He made the lot, portion, or share, little, and incomplete. (TA.)

Also xas-a HaZ-ahu, [and Axs-hu↓,] ‡ [He made his fortune to be low or ignoble,, &c.; or contemptible; differing from the signification immediately preceding, being said to be tropical.] (A.) The Arabs say of a man without any good fortune in the present life, Oaxas-a↓ Qll-ehu HaZ-ahu † [God made his fortune mean, or contemptible]; as also Oaxat-ahu. (AM, TA.)
4. Axs-: see xas-a, in two places.
Axs-hu: see xas-a naSiybahu and what follows it, in four places.
Also He found him to be low or ignoble, base, vile, mean or sordid, weak; [or, more commonly,] contemptible. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6. taxaAs-uwhu They did it by turns: or they hastened together, or vied in hastening, to do it. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
10. Astxs-hu He reckoned, accounted, or esteemed, him low or ignoble, base, vile, mean or sordid, weak; [or, more commonly,] contemptible. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)
Astxs- HaZ-ahu ‡ [He accounted his fortune low or ignoble,, &c.]. (A.)

xas-N [Lettuce; lactuca;] a certain plant, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the kind called baqol, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) well known, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the description termed OaHoraAr, [i. e., that are eaten without being cooked, or that are slender and succulent, or slender and soft,] with broad leaves: it increases the blood: the wild kind has the property of the black poppy: the best is the garden-kind, [lactuca sativa,] which is succulent, yellow, and broad [in the leaf]: it is cold and moist in temperament: the most nutritious is that which is cooked; and it is useful for counteracting contrariety of the fluids; but the eating it constantly weakens the sight, and is injurious to the venereal faculty: (TA:) n. un. with p {xas-apN}. (Mṣb.)
xusaAsN: see xasiysN.
hecihi AlOumuwru xisaAsN bayonahumo These things, or affairs, are done by them by turns. (JF, Ḳ.)

xasiysN, applied to a man, and to a lot or portion or share, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or a thing, (Mṣb, TA,) Low or ignoble, base, vile, mean or sordid, weak; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) [or, more commonly,] contemptible; (A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also musotaxis-N↓ and musotaxas-N↓; (Ḳ;) and, applied to a thing, also, paltry, or inconsiderable; and so xusaAsN↓ and maxosuwsN↓; bad, corrupt, abominable, or disapproved: (TA:) fem. with p {xasiysapN}: (Mgh, Mṣb:) pl. masc. Oaxis-aMCu and xisaAsN (Mṣb, TA) and Oaxis-apN; (A;) pl. fem. xasaAYisu. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
HaZ-N xasiysN, and maxosuwsN↓, ‡ A low, or mean, fortune, that is not held in any estimation. (A.)
huwa laA yadoxulu fiI xisaAsi AlOumuwri ‡ [He will not enter into low, mean, or contemptible, affairs]. (A.)
xasiysN is also applied to A disbeliever, an unbeliever, or infidel. (TA.)

hom.sense: xasiysapN fem. of xasiysN. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

You say also, rafaEa Qll-ehu xasiysapa fulaAnK God raised the condition of such a one after it had been low: (Az, TA:) or rafaEotu mino xasiysatihi I did to him a deed whereby he became raised to a high condition. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

The teeth of a she-camel within the period of the shedding of the central incisors: you say, jaAwazati Aln-aAqapu xasiysatahaA [The she-camel passed beyond the period of her xasiysap]: this is in the sixth year, when she sheds her central incisor: she is then such as is allowable for sacrifice. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
xas-aMCu The state of him, or it, that is xasiys [i. e. low or ignoble,, &c.]. (TA.)
A foul, or an ugly, woman. (TA.) [See also musotaxis-N.]

entry.sense: Oaxas-u [More, and most, xasiys, i. e., low or ignoble,, &c.]. You say, maA raOayotu Oaxas-a minohu [I have not seen any more low or ignoble, or, more commonly, contemptible, than he, or it]. (A.)
maxosuwsN A man made, or rendered, low or ignoble,, &c., and weak. (TA.)
See also xasiysN, in two places.
musotaxis-N and musotaxas-N: see xasiysN.
Also, both words, A foul, or an ugly, face: fem. with p {musotaxis-apN or musotaxas-apN}. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also xas-aMCu.]

hom.sense: 1. xasaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxosaOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xasoCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xusuwoCN, (Ḳ,) He drove away a dog: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he chid him. (Lth.)
It is also intrans., (Ṣ,) and signifies He (a dog) went away, to a distance; (Ṣ,* Ḳ;) [being driven away, or chidden;] as also xasiYa, (Ḳ,) and AnxsO↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] tropically, said to a man, AixosaOo Uilayoka, meaning AixosaOo Ean-iI ‡ [Go thou away: or go thou away from me]. (TA.) AixosaWuwA fiyhaA walaA tukal-imuwni, in the Ḳur [xxiii. 110], is expressive of removal to a distance with anger; [meaning † Go ye away into it, (i. e. the fire of Hell,) and speak not unto Me.] (Zj.)

[And hence, † He was, or became, vile and despised and hated: so says Golius, as on the authority of the KL; but this meaning is not in my copy of that work: it agrees, however, with a signification of the part. n. xaAsiYN, q. v.]
Also, inf. n. xasoCN and xusuwoCN [as above], said of the sight, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) ‡ It was, or became, dazzled, or confused, (AZ, Ṣ, TA,) and dim. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 3. xaAsaWuwA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaAsaOapN, (Ṣ,) ‡ They threw stones, one at another; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also txAsWwA↓, (Ḳ,) or txAsWwA biAlHijaArapi. (Ṣ.) And kaAnato bayonahumo muxaAsaOapN ‡ [There was between them a contending in throwing, or throwing of stones]. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also art. xsI.]
And huwa yuxaAsiYu means yuqaAmiru [He contends in a game of hazard]. (IB, TA in art. xsw.)
6: see 3.
7: see 1.
xasiIoCN Bad wool. (O, Ḳ.)
xaAsiYN, applied to a dog, and to a swine, (Ḳ,) and to a devil, (TA,) Driven away, repelled, and not suffered to come near to men. (Ḳ, TA.)
And [hence,] † Contemptible, despicable, vile, or abject. (TA.)

Applied to the sight, ‡ Dazzled, or confused, (Ṣ, TA,) and dim. (TA.) So in the words of the Ḳur [lxvii. 4], yanoqalibu Uilayoka AlbaSaru xaAsiYFA ‡ [The sight will recoil to thee dazzled, or confused, or dim]: (Ṣ, TA:) or the meaning here is † contemptible: or withdrawing far away: or it is of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, [meaning repelled far away,] like EiyXapK raADiyapK, in the Ḳur [lxix. 21 and ci. 5], for maroDiy-apK. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. xasira, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _a {yaxosaru}; (Ḳ;) and xasara, aor. _i {yaxosiru}; (Ḳ;) but the latter is an unusual form [except in the sense of Oaxosara]; (B, TA;) inf. n. xusoraAnN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xusorN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xasaArapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) [which are the only forms assigned in the TA to the verb when used with reference to traffic] and xusurN and xasorN and xasarN and xasaArN; (Ḳ;) He lost, or suffered loss or diminution: or he was deceived, cheated, beguiled, or circumvented: (Ḳ:) fiI AlbayoEi in selling; (Ṣ;) or fiI bayaEihi in his selling; (A;) or fiI tijaAratihi in his traffic: (Mṣb, Ḳ: [see also 4:]) the former is the original signification: (TA:) he suffered diminution of his capital; he lost part thereof: (B, TA:) and he lost his capital altogether. (Bḍ in iv. 118;, &c.) xusoraAnN is also attributed to an action, as well as to a man: (B, TA:) you say, (but in this case the verb is used tropically, A,) xasirato tijaAratuhu ‡ [His traffic was losing; or an occasion of loss]; (A, B;) opposed to rabiHato. (A.)
It is also used in relation to personal acquisitions; such as health, and safety, and intellect, and faith, and the recompense or reward of obedience [to God], which God has declared [Ḳur xxii. 11 and xxxix. 17] to be manifest xusoraAn, (B,) since there is none like it. (Bḍ.) For instance, you say, xasira Eaqolahu, and maAlahu, He lost his intellect, and his property. (IAạr.) [In a phrase of this kind, the noun which immediately follows the verb may be considered as put in the accus. case on account of the rejection of a prep., namely fiI: for] it is said that xasira is never used otherwise than intransitively: though this has been contradicted, on the ground of the following phrase in the Ḳur [xxii. 11], xasira Qld-unoyaA waQloMxirapa [He hath lost, or he loseth, the things of the present life and of the latter life]; and the like; as Ql-aciyna xasiruwA Oanofusahumo waOaholiyhimo [Who shall have lost themselves, or their own souls, and their families, or their wives; Ḳur xxxix. 17 and xlii. 44]; (MF, TA;) i. e., themselves, or their own souls, by their having erred, and their families by their having caused them to err, or by being separated from them for ever; (Bḍ;) or by being themselves made to remain for ever in Hell, and by their not gaining access to the Huwr prepared in Paradise [as wives] for the believers: (Jel:) or the meaning is, accord. to Fr, who shall be deceived of their own souls, &c.: or, accord. to others, who shall have destroyed their own souls, &c. (TA.)
Also [He experienced, or saw, that he was loser; or] his having lost became manifest to him: so in the Ḳur xl. [78 and] last verse. (TA.)

Also (with all the forms of the inf. n. above mentioned, Ḳ,) He erred; went astray; deviated from, or lost, or missed, the right way: or he became lost; he perished; or he died: syn. Dal-a, (Ḳ,) and halaka. (Mṣb.)

xasarahu, (AʼObeyd, IAạr, Zj, Ṣ, A, &c.,) aor. _i {yaxosiru} (Zj, Mṣb) and _u {yaxosuru}, (Bḍ in lv. 8,) inf. n. xasorN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and xusoraAnN; (Ḳ;) and Axsrhu↓, (AʼObeyd, Zj, Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. UixosaArN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and xs-rhu↓; (A;) He made it defective, or deficient; (AʼObeyd, IAạr, Zj, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, the weight, and the measure; (Zj, TA;) and the thing weighed; (TA;) and the balance, (AʼObeyd, IAạr, Zj, A, Mṣb,) by diminishing the weight. (Mṣb.) ↓The second of these forms is more common, in this sense, than the first (Zj, TA) [and than the third]. For walaA tuxosiruwA↓ QlomiyzaAna, in the Ḳur lv. 8, there are three other readings; namely taxosuruwA and taxosurwA and taxosaruwA; in the last of which, the prep. fiI is omitted after the verb. (Bḍ.)
[And He, or it, made him to lose, or suffer loss; to err, or go astray; to become lost, or to perish.]

entry.sense: 2. xs-rhu, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxosiyrN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. q. xasarahu, q. v.: (A:) [and particularly] He, or it, destroyed him; caused him to perish. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, xs-rhu suwoCu Eamalihi ‡ The evilness of his conduct caused him to perish. (A.)
He put him away, or far away; removed, alienated, or estranged, him; (IAạr, Mṣb;) from good, or prosperity. (IAạr.)
He attributed, or imputed, to him xusoraAn [i. e. loss; or error, or deviation from the right way]: like kac-abahu meaning “he attributed, or imputed, to him lying,”, &c. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 4. Axsrhu i. q. xasarahu, which see in three places: (AʼObeyd, Zj, Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) [and particularly] He made him to lose, or suffer loss, in his traffic; contr. of OarobaHahu. (A.)
And Axsr He fell into loss; (A;) he met with loss in his traffic. (TA. [See also 1.])

entry.sense: xusorN an inf. n. of xasira. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) In the Ḳur ciii. 2, accord. to some, it means Punishment for sin. (TA.)
xasirN: see xaAsirN.

xusoraAnN an inf. n. of xasira. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [For particular usages thereof, see 1. As a simple subst., it generally signifies Loss, or the state of suffering loss or diminution: the state of being deceived or cheated: error, or deviation from the right way: (see also xasaArN:) or the state of becoming lost, of perishing, or of dying.]
It is also an inf. n. of xasarahu. (Ḳ.)
xusorawiI-N: see what next follows.

xusorawaAniI-N, (A, Ḳ,) or xusoruwaAniI-N, (TA, [but the former is the better known,]) A certain kind of garment or cloth; (A, Ḳ;) so called in relation to Khusrow Sháh, one of the [kings of Persia called] OakaAsirap [pl. of kisoraI or kasoraI]; as also xusorawiI-N↓. (A, TA.)
And A certain wine or beverage. (Ḳ.)

xasaArN and xasaArapN↓, [both inf. ns. of xasira, q. v.,] (Ṣ,) and xayosaraI↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, in some copies of the Ḳ written xanosaraI, with n, TA,) Error; or deviation from the right way: [like xusoraAnN:] (Ṣ:) and perdition; or death; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xanaAsiyru↓, (Ṣ, and Ḳ in art. xnsr,) which last [is of a pl. form, but] has no sing. (Ṣ.)

And all the foregoing words, including xnAsyr↓, Baseness, ignobleness, ungenerousness, or meanness; (Ḳ;) the last, in poetry, shortened to xanaAsiru↓: (TA:) and xayosaraI↓, (Ḳ,) and, as some say, xanaAsiyru↓, (TA,) perfidy, unfaithfulness, or treachery. (Ḳ, TA.)
xasiyrN: see xaAsirN.
xasaArapN: see xasaArN.

xaAsirN Losing, or suffering loss, in his traffic. (Lth.) And [hence,] tijaArapN xaAsirapN ‡ [Losing traffic; traffic which is an occasion of loss]; opposed to raAbiHapN. (A.) And SafoqapN xaAsirapN † A bargain that does not bring gain [but on the contrary occasions loss]. (TA.) And kar-apN xaAsirapN † An unprofitable charge or assault. (Ḳ.)
One who has lost his property, and his intellect. (IAạr.)

Erring; going astray; deviating from, or losing, or missing, the right way: or becoming lost; perishing; or dying: syn. DaAl-N: (Ḳ:) and so xasirN↓ (TA) and xasiyrN↓ and xayosaraI↓, (Ḳ, TA, but the last written in the CK xayosariI-N,) or xayosarN↓, for it is said to occur [as an epithet] only in the following saying, in which xayosaraI is said to be put for xayosarN to assimilate it to preceding words: bifiyhi AlbaraI waHum-aI xayobaraI waXar-N maA yaraI faUin-ahu xayosaraI [In his mouth be dust, and may the fever of Kheyber befall him, and evil be that which he shall see, for he is one who goeth astray: but in the TA, in art. wrI, is another reading; for bfyh AlbrI, substituting bihi AlwaraI, meaning a certain disease]. (TA.) [Hence,] OaHomaqu xaAsirN daAbirN daAmirN [Foolish, or stupid, erring, and utterly perishing]. (T in art. bt. [See baAt-N: and see also daAmirN.])
Also One who makes the measure, and the balance, defective, or deficient, when he gives, and demands excess when he receives. (AA.)
xaAsirapN: see the next paragraph.
xanosarN and xanosariI-N↓ A man in a place [or condition] of xusoraAn [or loss,, &c.]: (Ḳ in the present art. and in art. xnsr:) pl. xanaAsirapN. (Ḳ in art. xnsr.)

And [the pl.] AlxanaAsirapu, in several copies of the Ḳ, in other copies of the Ḳ AlxaAsirapu↓, but correctly AlxanaAsiru↓, (TA,) The weak of mankind; (Ḳ, TA;) and the small, or little, of them; (TA;) as also AlxanaAsiyru↓, in the former sense, (Ḳ and TA in art. xnsr,) and in the latter sense also: (TA in that art.:) and Oaholu AlxiyaAnapi; (Ḳ and TA in this art.; and Ḳ in art. xnsr, accord. to several copies;) i. e. The people of perfidy, unfaithfulness, or treachery; and of baseness, ignobleness, ungenerousness, or meanness: (TA in the present art.:) or Ahl AljbAnp; because of their weakness; (TA in art. xnsr;) [as though meaning the people of cowardice (AljabaAnap): or it may mean the people of the burial-ground (Aljab-aAnap)]; for, accord. to AḤát, AlxnAsyr↓ signifies those who conduct [to the burial-ground] the corpse or the bier with the corpse; perhaps from xanaAsiru meaning “small, or little, and weak men.” (TA.)

hom.sense: xinosirN, (Ḳ in art. xnsr, [in the CK, erroneously, xinosar,]) or xinosiyrN↓, (Ibn-ʼOsfoor, AḤei, and Ḳ in the present art.,) Base, ignoble, ungenerous, or mean: (Ḳ:) and perfidious, unfaithful, or treacherous. (TA in explanation of the latter.)

Also (the former accord. to the Ḳ in art. xnsr, and the latter likewise accord. to the TA in the present art.,) A calamity, or misfortune: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. [of the latter] in this sense xanaAsiyru, like xanaAviyru. (IAạr, TA.)

entry.sense: xayosarN: see xaAsirN.

hom.sense: xayosaraI: see xasaArN, in two places:
and see also xaAsirN.
Also One who will not accept an invitation to partake of food, lest he should be required to make a requital: so in a trad. of ʼOmar. (TA.)

entry.sense: xanosariI-N: see xanosarN.
xinosiyrN: see xinosirN.

hom.sense: xanaAsiru: see xasaArN:
and see also xanosarN.
xanaAsiyru a word [of a pl. form] having no sing.: (Ṣ:) see xasaArN, in three places.
[Also pl. of xinosiyrN, q. v.]
See also xanosarN, in two places.
Also The urine of the mountain-goats upon the herbage and the trees [or shrubs]: (Ḳ in this art. and in art. xnsr:) in which sense, also, it has no singular. (TA in the present art.)

entry.sense: Oaxosaru sing. of Oaxosaruwna, which occurs in the Ḳur [xi. 24 and] xviii. 103 [and xxi. 70 and xxvii. 5], (Akh, Ṣ,) and signifies The greatest losers; those who suffer, or shall suffer, the greatest loss. (Bḍ.)

[maxosarapN An occasion, or a cause, of loss; or of error, or going astray; or of being lost, of perishing, or of dying: a word of the same class as maboxalapN and majobanapN, &c.: pl. maxaAsiru. Hence the saying,] AlmasaAxiru maxaAsiru ‡ [Occasions, or causes, of mockery, or derision, or ridicule, are occasions, or causes, of loss,, &c.]. (A.)

hom.sense: 1. xasafa, aor. _i {yaxosifu}, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xasofN, (JK,) or xusuwfN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or both; (Mṣb;) [and Anxsf↓;] It (a place) sank, (JK, Mṣb,) or went away, into the ground, or earth, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with what was upon it. (JK.) You say, Anxsf↓ AlOaroDu, [and xasafat,] The ground sank [into the earth] with what was upon it. (TA.) And Anxsft↓ bihi AlOaroDu, (JK,) or Anxsf↓ bh AlArD, and xusifa bh AlArD, (TA,) and xasafato, (Mṣb in art. swx,) The ground sank with him, or it: (JK:) or the ground, or earth, [swallowed up him, or it; or] took and enclosed him, or it. (TA.) And Anxsft↓ AlbiYoru The well [sank and collapsed; or] went away into the earth with its casing of stones and wood. (Mgh.) And xasafa fiI AlOaroDi and xusifa bihi [He, or it, sank into the ground, or earth, and became swallowed up, or enclosed, or concealed, therein]. (Ṣ.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxviii. 82], accord. to one reading, laxusifa binaA [We had been swallowed up by the earth]: (Ṣ:) accord. to another reading, (that of ʼAbd-Allah, Ṣ, i. e. Ibn-Mesʼood, TA,) laQnoxusifa↓ bnA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the pass. form; (Ḳ;) [meaning the same;] like as one says, AunoTuliqa bnA. (Ṣ.) You say also, xasafato Eayonu AlmaMCi The spring of water sank, or went away, into the earth. (Mṣb, Ḳ.*) And Anxsft↓ AlEayonu The eye sank, or became depressed, in the head; syn. gaArato; (Mṣb in art. gwr;) [and so xasafat, inf. n. xusuwfN; for] xusuwfu AlEayoni signifies The eye's going away into the head: (Ṣ:) or Anxsft↓ signifies its black, or part surrounded by the white, disappeared in the head: (Mgh:) or this last, (Ḳ,) as quasi-pass. of the trans. v. xasafa, (TA,) ‡ it (the eye) became blind; as also Oaxosafat↓; (Ḳ, TA;) and [in like manner] xasafat † it (the eye) lost its light [or sight]. (Mṣb.)

[Hence, app.,] xasafa Alqamaru, inf. n. xusuwfN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and xusifa; (TA;) † The moon [suffered eclipse, or became eclipsed, or] lost its light, or part of its light; (Mṣb;) i. q. kasafa: (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ:) and xasafati AlX-amosu and kasafat both signify the same [i. e. the sun suffered eclipse,, &c.]: (Mgh:) or one says kasafat of the sun, and xasafa of the moon, (Th, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) accord. to the more approved usage: (Th, Ṣ, Mṣb:) or, in the common conventional language, Alkusuwfu is the partial loss of the light of the sun, and Alxusuwfu is the total loss of the light thereof: (AḤát, Mṣb:) or Alxswf is the partial loss of the light of the sun, and Alkswf is the total loss thereof, (Ḳ, TA,) accord. to AḤát: (TA:) Alxswf often occurs in the trads., as said of the sun; though the term commonly known in the classical language is Alkswf [in this case]: and it is said in a trad., Uin-a AlX-amosa waAlqamara laAyaxosifaAni limawoti OaHadK Oawo liHayaAtihi [Verily the sun and the moon suffer not eclipse for the death of any one or for his life]; predominance being in this instance attributed to the moon, as being masc., over the sun, which is fem. (IAth.)
Also, inf. n. xasofN, † It (a thing) became defective or deficient; suffered loss or diminution. (Ḳ.)

‡ It (the body) became lean, or emaciated. (TA.) And xasafato, said of camels and of sheep or goats, ‡ They became lean, or emaciated. (TA. [This meaning is there indicated, but not clearly expressed. See xasofapN. Accord. to the KL, the inf. n. xasofN signifies The being vile, abject, or contemptible: and also the being lean, or emaciated: and hence Golius, on that authority, has rendered the verb as meaning vilis et macer fuit.])
Also † It (the colour, or complexion, of a person) became altered, or altered for the worse. (TA.)
And ‡ It (a thing, Ḳ, as, for instance, a roof, TA) became pierced with a hole, or rent; (Ḳ, TA;) as also Anxsf↓. (TA.)
And, xasafat, said of a she-camel, ‡ She, after yielding abundant milk, soon stopped [its flow] in winter. (Ḳ, TA.)
And, said of a well, It was, or became, such as is termed xasiyfN [q. v.]. (TA.)
And xasafa, said of a man, ‡ He recovered from a disease. (IDrd, Ḳ, TA.)

xasafa, (JK, Mṣb, TA,) aor. _i {yaxosifu}, (Ḳur xvi. 47, &c.,) inf. n. xasofN, He (God) made a place, (JK, Mṣb,) or the ground, (TA,) to sink, (JK, Mṣb, TA,) or go away, into the earth, (Mṣb,) with what was upon it. (JK, TA.) And xasafa bihi AlOaroDa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xasofN, (Ṣ,) He (God) made him, or it, to disappear in the earth, or ground: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or made the earth, or ground, to sink with, and swallow up, him, or it:] whence, in the Ḳur [xxviii. 81], faxasafonaA bihi wabidaArihi AlOaroDa [And we made the ground to sink with, and swallow up, him and his mansion]. (Ṣ.) And xasafotu Eayona AlmaMCi I made the spring of water to sink, or go away, into the earth. (Mṣb.)

xasafa Eayona fulaAnK, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. _i {yaxosifu}, inf. n. xasofN, (TA,) ‡ He put out, or blinded, the eye of such a one, (Ḳ,* TA,) so that the black, or part surrounded by the white, disappeared in the head. (TA.)
xasafa AlX-aIoCa, (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He made a hole in, or rent, the thing. (Ḳ, TA.)
And † He cut, or cut off, the thing. (Ḳ.)

xasafa AlbiYora, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) † He dug the well in stones, so that it yielded an abundant and unceasing flow of water: (Ḳ, TA:) or he dug the well by piercing through its mountain [or rock] to the water beneath so that it would never become exhausted: or he dug the well so as to reach an unceasing, or a copious, source of water. (TA.) Hence the saying of ʼOmar, in reply to a question of El-ʼAbbás respecting the poets, AimoraOu Alqayosi saAbiquhumo xasafa lahumo Eayona AlX-iEori, i. e. † [Imra-el-Ḳeys is he who has the precedence of them:] he has made the source of poetry to well forth abundantly to them. (TA.)
xasafa Aln-aAqapa, inf. n. as above, ‡ He (God) made the she-camel, after yielding abundant milk, soon to stop [its flow] in winter. (Ḳ, TA.)

xasofN also signifies The confining a beast without fodder: (Ḳ, TA:) or making a beast to pass the night without fodder: (Ḥam p. 290:) and (hence, TA) ‡ the constraining a man to do that which he dislikes, or hates; (JK, Ḥam ibid., Ḳ, TA;) as also xusofN: (JK:) and (hence, Ḥam) ‡ the lowering, humbling, or abasing, another: (Ḥam,* Ḳ, TA:) whence, sumotuhu Alxasofa, (Ḥam,) or saAmahu xasofFA, &c.: [explained below: see xasofN:] (TA:) and the verb of xasofN in these three senses is xasafa. (T, Ḳ.)
4. Oaxosafati AlEayonu: see 1.
Axsf, said of a well-sinker, † He found his well to be such as is termed xasiyf [q. v.]: (JK:) or he produced an abundant flow of water. (TA.)

entry.sense: 7: see 1, in nine places.
