hom.sense: xasofN [an inf. n. of 1: and hence several of the significations here following.] Deep places in the ground (Eumuwqu ZaAhiri AlOaroDi; in the CK Eumuwqu mACi AlArDi); as also xusofN↓. (Ḳ, TA.)

The place whence the water of a well issues. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.) In the following saying of Sá'ideh El-Hudhalee,
OalaA yaA fataI maA Eabodu XamosK bimivolihi
yubal-u EalaI AlEaAdiI watuWobiI AlmaxaAsifu
the last word is pl. of xasofN [app. as signifying A source of water], after the manner of maXaAbihu and malaAmiHu: (TA:) the meaning is, [Truly, O young man, what is ʼAbd-Shems? i. e.] how great a person is ʼAbd-Shems! by the like of him the enemy is overcome [and the sources of water become difficult of access]. (M in art. bl.)

A cloud, or collection of clouds, that has risen and appeared from the direction of the extreme west, [as North-western Africa is called by the Arabs,] from [the quarter of] the right of the Kibleh [to one who is on the north-east of Mekkeh, towards El-'Irák]: (Lth, Ḳ:) or it signifies, (JK, TA,) [and] so xisofN↓ and xasiyfN↓, (Ḳ,) a cloud, or collection of clouds, that has risen and appeared mino qibali AlEayoni, bearing much water; (JK, Ḳ, TA;) i. e., from [the quarter of] the right of the Kibleh [as explained above]. (TA.)

‡ Deficiency, or imperfection; a fault; or a low, or base, quality; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also xasiyfapN↓. (TA.) One says, raDiIa fulaAnN biAlxasofi ‡ Such a one was content with deficiency, or imperfection;, &c. (Ṣ, TA.)
† Leanness, or emaciation; (TA;) as also xasiyfapN↓. (JK.)
[See also 1, last sentence.]

[Hence,] baAta Alqawomu EalaI Alxasofi ‡ The party passed the night in a state of hunger, not having anything wherewith to feed themselves: (TA:) and baAta fulaAnN Alxasofa ‡ Such a one passed the night hungry: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:)
and XaribonaA EalaIe Alxasofi ‡ We drank without eating. (IAạr, IDrd, Ḳ, TA.) A poet says,
batonaA EalaI Alxasofi laA risolN nuqaAtu bihi
Hat-aI jaEalonaA HibaAla Alr-aHoli fuSolaAnaA
[We passed the night in a state of hunger: there was no milk wherewith we might be fed, until we made the ropes of the camel's saddle to serve as young camels]: i. e. we had no food until we bound the she-camels with ropes in order that they might yield us milk [as though they had young ones to suckle], and we might feed ourselves with their milk. (O, TA.) [See also another ex., in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh, cited voce Uil-aA, p. 78.]

[Hence, also,] saAmahu xasofFA and xusofFA↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and saAmahu Alxasofa, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) ‡ He brought upon him abasement, or ignominy: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he required, or constrained, him to do an affair of difficulty; and to become in a state of abasement, or ignominy. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also two similar phrases voce xuT-apN.]
[And hence,] xasofN signifies also † Wrong, wrongdoing, injustice, injuriousness, or tyranny. (TA.) [And saAmahu xasofFA, or Alxasofa, sometimes means † He brought upon him wrong,, &c.]
See also the next paragraph.
xusofN: [see 1, last sentence: and] see xasofN, in two places.
daEi AlOamora bixusofK means † Leave thou the thing, or affair, as it is. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

The [fruit called] jawoz, which is eaten; [i. e. the walnut, or walnuts;] (AA, AḤn, Ḳ;) of the dial. of the people of Esh-Shihr; (AA;) as also xasofN↓: (AA, Ḳ:) accord. to ISd, the former is the correct word: (TA:) n. un. with p {xusofapN}. (JK.)

entry.sense: xisofN: see xasofN.

hom.sense: xasofapN [app. A leanness, or an emaciation: see 1, and see also xasofN]: this befalls camels, and sheep or goats, in the heat and in the cold. (A, TA.)

Also sing. of OaxaAsiyfu↓, (JK,) which signifies Soft tracts of land: (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:) or level lands: (JK:) and one says also OaxaAsifu↓ [and thus the word is written in the CK]. (Fr, TA.) One says, waqaEuwA fiI OaxaAsiyfa↓ mina AlOaroDi They became in soft tracts of land. (Ṣ.) [See also OaxaAXifu, in art. xXf.]

entry.sense: xasawfN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: xasiyfN ‡ A spring, or source, (EayonN, [shown in the TA to have this meaning here,]) sinking, or going away [into the earth]; as also xaAsifN↓; (Ḳ, TA;) in like manner without p. (TA.)

† A well (biYorN) dug in stones, so that it yields an abundant and unceasing flow of water; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xasiyfapN and xasuwfN↓ and maxosuwfapN↓; (Ḳ;) or, as some say, xasiyfN only: (TA:) or this signifies a well pierced through its mountain [or rock] to the water beneath so that it never becomes exhausted; (JK, TA;) as also maxosuwfapN↓: (JK:) or a well dug so as to reach an unceasing, or a copious, source of water: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxosifapN (JK, Ḳ) and [of mult.] xusufN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
‡ A she-camel that yields abundant milk, but soon stops [its flow] in winter. (Ḳ, TA.) [And] with p {xasiyfapN}, † A she-camel that yields abundant milk. (JK.)
See also xasofN.
EayonN xasiyfapN (Mgh, Ḳ, TA) and xaAsifapN↓ (JK, Mgh) ‡ An eye put out, or blinded; (JK, Ḳ, TA;) of which the black, or part surrounded by the white, has disappeared in the head. (JK, Mgh, TA.)

AlxasiyfaAn, thus correctly written, as in the L, and so in the Nawádir of Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee, and in the Tedhkireh of Aboo-ʼAlee El-Hejeree, who asserts that the n is the n of the dual, and in one dial. with damm, [so that the word is written AlxasiyfaAni and AlxasiyfaAnu,] and on whose authority is mentioned the saying humaA xaliylaAnu, with damm to the n, [so that each is a dual in form, though not in signification,] but in the O and the Ḳ AlxayosafaAnu↓, [in the CK AlxiysafaAnu,] with fet-ḥ to the s, and [AlxayosufaAnu↓,] with damm to that letter, (TA,) Bad dates: (O, Ḳ:) so in the Nawádir and Tedhkireh above mentioned: (TA:) or a palm-tree that bears a small quantity of fruit, and of which the unripe dates turn bad. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xasiyfapN [as an epithet, fem. of xasiyfN, q. v.:] as a subst.: see xasofN, in two places.
xaAsifN, and its fem. with p {xaAsifapN}: see xasiyfN, in two places.
Also ‡ Lean, or emaciated. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
† A body altered, or altered for the worse. (A, TA.) † A man (JK) altered, or altered for the worse, in colour, or complexion, (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) and in aspect. (JK.)
‡ Hungry. (AHeyth, TA.)
† A boy light, or active, (Ḳ, TA,) and brisk, lively, or sprightly; as also xaAXifN. (TA.)
† A man convalescent; or recovering from disease; syn. naAqihN: (AA, Ḳ: [see 1:]) pl. xusufN. (Ḳ.)
AlxayosafaAnu and AlxayosufaAnu: see xasiyfN.
OaxaAsifu and OaxaAsiyfu: see xasofapN, in three places.
Almuxas-afu The lion. (TṢ, Ḳ.)
maxosuwfapN, applied to a well: see xasiyfN, in two places.
AlmaxaAsifu: see xasofN.

1. xasaqa, aor. _i {yaxosiqu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xasoqN and xusuwqN, (Mṣb, TA,) It (an arrow) hit the target: (Ḳ:) or passed through the object at which it was shot; or penetrated into its inside, and its extremity went forth from the other side, the rest. remaining therein: (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb:) or stuck fast therein: (IF, Mṣb:) or xasaqa Alhadafa (Mṣb, TA) it hit the object at which it was shot, and passed through, or its extremity passed through; like xazaqa: (TA:) or passed through, or pierced so that its extremity passed through, not with vehemence. (Mṣb.) And ramaI faxasaqa He shot, or cast, and clave the skin. (Az, TA.) IF says that it is not a primitive; that the s is substituted for z; and that the word is altered because of the alteration of the meaning. (TA.)
xasuwqN, applied to a she-camel, i. q. HazuwqN; (Ḳ;) or Evil in disposition; that pierces the ground with her toes, as she goes; (JK, TA;) furrowing the ground with her toe turned up. (TA.)
xaAsiqN i. q. xaAziqN [q. v.]. (Ṣ.)

2. xs-I, (so in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA,) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ txs-I, but the former is the right, (TA,) inf. n. taxosiyapN, He played with walnuts at the game of odd or even; (Ḳ, TA;) as also AxsI↓: and xAsAhu↓, (inf. n. muxaAsaApN, TA,) He played with him at that game: (Ḳ:) or you say, huwa yuxas-iI wayuzak-iI He plays, and says, “Is it even or odd?” (TA.)
3: see above {2}.
4: see above {2}.
6. taxaAsaA They (two men) played together at the game of odd or even. (JK,* TA.)

xasaA, (JK, Ḳ,* and TA in art. zkw,) without tenween, and accord. to some with tenween, and not having the article Al prefixed to it; and in like manner zakaA, which is coupled with the former, is without tenween, and accord. to some with tenween, and not having the article Al prefixed to it; (TA in that art.;) [but each has Al prefixed to it in the Ḳ;] accord. to Fr, some make it quasi-coordinate to fatFI [i. e. with tenween, and masc.]; some, to zfr [app. meaning the proper name zufaru i. e. without tenween, and masc.]; and some, to sakoraI [app. meaning without tenween, and fem.]: (TA:) a word that is said in playing with walnuts; (JK;) An odd number: (Lth, Fr, Ḳ, TA:) and zkA signifies an even number: (Lth, Fr, TA:) accord. to IB, its final letter is hemzeh, for one says, yuxaAsiYu meaning yuqaAmiru [he contends in a game of hazard]; but it is pronounced without C to assimilate it to zkA: (TA:) the pl. is OaxaAsK, (Ḳ, TA,) accord. to the M, maxaAsK, like masaAwK, (TA, [but the former pl. occurs in a verse cited in the TA,]) which is anomalous. (Ḳ.) One says, xasFA Oawo zakFA, [so in my copies of the Ṣ, with tenween,] i. e. Odd or even? (Ṣ:) [or xasaA Oawo zakaA, as shown above:] and some say, xasaA zakaA, like xamosapa EaXara. (IB, TA.) And it is said in a trad., maA OadoriI kamo Had-avaniI OabiI Eino rasuwli Qll-ehi Sal-aI Qll-ehu Ealayohi wasal-ama OaxosaA Oamo zakaA, or OaxosFA Oamo zakFA, [for the vowel-signs are not written in my original,] meaning farodFA Oamo zawojFA [i. e. I know not how many times my father told me, from the Apostle of God, God bless and save him; whether an odd or an even number: or, perhaps, once or twice]. (TA.)

6. Alt-axaAsiI The throwing of pebbles, one at another. (Ḳ.) You say, taxaAsato qawaAYimu Ald-aAb-api biAlHaSaA The legs of the beast threw the pebbles, one at another. (TA.) [See also 3 in art. xsO.]
xasiI-N The like of a [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, or of a [tent such as is called] xibaMC, woven of wool. (JK, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. xaX-a fiyhi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoXiXu}, (JM,) [vulgarly, and irregularly, _u,] inf. n. xaX-N, (TA,) He (a man) entered into it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, a thing; (Ṣ;) as also AnxX-↓; (Ḳ, A, TA;) and xaXoxaXa↓, (TA,) inf. n. xaXoxaXapN; (Ḳ, TA;) and in like manner, into a collection of trees, and a company of people: (A,* TA:) or xaXoxaXa↓ fiyhi, (IDrd,) and taxaXoxaXa↓ fyh, (IDrd, Ḳ,) he entered into it, (namely, a thing, IDrd, or a collection of trees, Ḳ, and in like manner a company of men, TA,) so as to become hidden, or concealed: (IDrd, Ḳ:) and xaX-a, he (a man) went, or went away, or advanced, [into a thing,] and penetrated. (TA.)

Hence, (TA,) xaX-a AlbaEiyra (Ṣ, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yaxoXuXu}, [agreeably with general rule in this case,] inf. n. xaX-N, (Ṣ,) He put into the camel's nose the thing termed xiXaAX; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also OaxaX-a↓. (Zj, Ḳ.)

And hence the saying in a trad., xuX-uwA bayona kalaAmikumo laA Uileha Uil-aA Qll-ehu, meaning, † Introduce ye, or insert ye, in your speech the words There is no deity but God. (TA.) And xaXoxaXahu↓ likewise signifies He introduced, or inserted, him or it. (TA.)
Also xaX-ahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, He pierced him, or stabbed him. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see xaX-a AlbaEiyra.
7: see xaX-a fiyhi.
8. AxtX- mina AlOaroDi He ate of the xiXaAX of the earth. (TA.)

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. xaXoxaXa: see xaX-a fiyhi, in two places.
xaXoxaXahu: see 1, last signification but one.
Also He caused it to make a sound such as is described below, voce xaXoxaXapN. (Ṣ, TA.*) See an ex. in the next paragraph.
R. Q. 2. taxaXoxaXa: see xaX-a fiyhi.

Also It made a sound (Ṣ, Ḳ) such as is described below, voce xaXoxaXapN. (Ṣ.) 'Alkameh Ibn-'Abadeh says,
taxaXoxaXa OabodaAnu AlHadiydi Ealayohimu
kamaA xaXoxaXatu↓ yabosa AlHaSaAdi januwbu
[The short coats of mail of iron rustled upon them, like as when a south wind has caused to rustle the dry reaped corn]. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: xaX-N: see maxoXuwXN.
xaXaAXN: see xiXaAXN; for the former, in three places.
xuXaAXN: see xiXaAXN; for the former, in three places.

hom.sense: xiXaAXN The wooden thing that is inserted in the bone of the nose of the camel, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) to which the nose-rein is tied, in order that he may be quickly submissive: (TA:) the burap is of brass, (Ṣ, TA,) or of silver; (TA;) and the xizaAmap is of hair: (Ṣ:) or the thing that is put in the nose; and the brp is the thing that is put in the flesh: (Lḥ:) or what is in the bone, when it is wood, or a stick; and the EiraAn is what is in the flesh, above the nose: (Aṣ:) a wooden thing, or stick, that is put in the bone of the nose of the camel: (Mṣb:) n. un. with p {xiXaAXapN}: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. OaxiX-apN. (A, Mṣb.) [Hence the saying,] jaEala AlxiXaAXa fiI Oanofihi waqaAdahu UilaI AlT-aAEapi biEunofihi ‡ [He put the xXAX in his nose, and drew him to obedience by his violence]. (A, TA.) [And hence, also,] it signifies gaDabN, (IAạr, Ḳ,) as used in the saying, Har-aka xiXaAXahu, [lit., He put in motion his xiXaAX: meaning, † he roused, or excited, his anger; or] he made him angry. (IAạr.)

AlxiXaAXu, and AlxaXaAXu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latter form being sometimes used, (Ṣ,) which indicates that the former is the more chaste, but, accord. to MF, several authorities say the contrary, (TA,) and AlxuXaAXu↓, (Ḳ,) or xaXaAXu↓ AlOaroDi, (AʼObeyd, Mṣb,) and xiXaAXu AlOaroDi, (Mṣb,) The creeping things of the earth: n. un. with p {xiXaAXapN}, which is syn. with AlHaXarapu and AlhaAm-apu: (Mṣb:) the HaXaraAt (A' Obeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ) of the earth, (A' Obeyd, Ḳ,) and its hawaAm-, and [other] creeping things, (AʼObeyd,) such as sparrows and the like: (AʼObeyd, Ḳ:*) or xiXaAXu AlOaroDi, and AlT-ayori, signify the small ones of beasts or creeping things [of the earth], and of birds: (A:) IAạr is related to have said that it is xiXoxaAXN↓, contr. to what is said by the lexicologists in general: and these things are said to have their appellation from their entering into the earth and concealing themselves; but this assertion is not valid: (ISd:) in a trad., for mn xXAX AlArD, one relation substitutes mino xaXiyXihaA↓, which has the same meaning: and some say that it is xuXayoX↓, a contracted dim. of xXAX; or xuXay-iX↓, without contraction: (TA:) and AlxaXaAXu↓ signifies the bad [meaning ignoble] kinds of birds; this being with fet-ḥ only: (Aṣ:) or birds that do not prey: (IAạr, TA voce EuqaAbN:) xiXaAXN, with kesr, also signifies the serpent of the mountain; which does not suffer one to survive; and the OafoEaI is the serpent of the plain; (El-Fak'asee, Ḳ;) which like wise does not suffer one to survive: (Ḳ:) or a great and abominable vuEobaAn: or a serpent like the Oaroqam, but smaller: or a small, tawny serpent, smaller than the Arqm: (TA:) or a white serpent, which seldom hurts, between the Huf-aAv and the Arqm: (Aboo-Kheyreh:) or such as is light, or active, and small in the head, of serpents: explained also as signifying the serpent, without restriction: (TA:) and, (Ḳ,) or as some say, (TA,) such as has no power of defence, [maA laA difaAEa lahu, as in the CK and a MṢ copy of the Ḳ, for which we find in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA, mA lA dimaAga lahu such as has no brains, which is doubtless a mistake,] of beasts or creeping things of the earth, and of birds, (Ḳ,) such as the ostrich, and the [bustard called] HubaAraI, and the karawaAn [or stonecurlew], and [the bird called] mulaAEibu Zil-ihi, and the [harmless kinds of] serpent: (TA:) or what is small in the head, and slender, of beasts or creeping things: and the kite; and [the bird called] mulaAEibu Zil-ihi: (Aboo-Muslim:) the pl. is xX-MC [app. xuX-aMCu, originally xuXaXaMCu, unless a mistake for OaxiX-aMCu, originally OaxoXiXaMCu]. (TA.)

entry.sense: xaXiyXN, and xuXayoXN, and xuXay-iXN: see xiXaAXN.

xuX-aMCN The bone which is protuberant behind the ear, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and which is thin, and bare of hair: (TA:) originally xuXaXaMCu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the measure fuEalaMCu; (Ṣ;) [but masc., and perfectly decl., as being quasi-coordinate to quroTaAsN, whereas the original is fem., and imperfectly decl.; (see quwabaMCu;)] like quwobaMCN, which is originally quwabaMCu; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and these two words are the only instances of their kind: (ISk, Mṣb:) dual xuXaXaAwaAn. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

xaXoxaXapN The [clashing, clattering, chinking, jingling, rattling, or rustling,] sound of arms, or weapons, (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ,) and the like; (Ṣ;) as also XaxoXaxapN, but this latter is a dial. var. of weak authority: (TA:) and of any dry or hard thing rubbing against another such thing: (Ḳ:) accord. to IDrd, such [sound or thing (for his words are ambiguous)] is termed xaXoxaAXN↓: (TA:) and the [rustling] sound of a new garment or piece of cloth, when it is put in motion; as also naXonaXapN: (IAạr:) and [a confused sound] such as is heard to proceed from the inside of an animal on its being hit by an arrow: (JK in art. xXf:) and a motion having a sound like the sound of arms, or weapons; (TA;) or an audible motion. (Mgh in art. xXf.)

hom.sense: xaXoxaAXN A company: (ISd, TA:) or a numerous company of men: (Az, TA:) or a company (Ṣ, Ḳ) in, (Ḳ,) or having upon them, (Ṣ,) arms, or weapons, and coats of mail. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also xaXoxaXapN.

Also A certain plant, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) well known; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [namely, the poppy;] which is of several species; (Ḳ;) i. e., four; (TA;) yusotaAniI-N [or garden-poppy,] (Ḳ,) which is the white, and this is the most fit for eating, and the best thereof is the fresh and heavy; (TA;) and manovuwrN, (Ḳ,) which is the wild Egyptian; (TA;) and muqar-anN, [app. the horned poppy,] (Ḳ,) the produce of which has an elongated extremity like the horn of the bull; (TA;) and zubodiI-N, [app. the spattling poppy,] (Ḳ,) which is known by the name of blbs [a word which I have not been able to find elsewhere]: (TA:) every one of these is soporiferous, and produces torpidness, and cools: (Ḳ:) used as a suppository, it produces sleep: and the integument [of the capsule] has a stronger power of producing sleep than the seeds: (TA:) [or rather the seeds have no narcotic power:] from half a drachm of the integument, with cold water, as a draught, taken early in the morning, and the like at sleep, has a wonderful effect in stopping a looseness characterized by a mixture of humours and by blood, when accompanied by heat and inflammation: (Ḳ:) it is wonderful also that its solid part confines, and its juice relaxes: and when the root, or lower part, is taken with water, [and boiled] so that the water is reduced to half its quantity, it is beneficial as a remedy for diseases of the liver arising from thick humour: so says the author of the Minháj: (TA:) the n. un. is with p {xaXoxaAXapN}: (Mṣb:) and the pl. is xaXaAxiXu [app. a mistake for xaXaAxiyXu]. (TA.) [See also OafoyuwnN.]

entry.sense: xiXoxaAXN: see xiXaAXN.
maxoXuwXN A camel having a xiXaAX put in his nose; as also xaXN↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. xaXaba, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoXibu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaXobN, (TA,) He mixed a thing (Ṣ, Ḳ) with (bi) another thing. (Ṣ.)
And He picked out, chose out, or selected, a thing: the verb thus having two contr. significations. (Ḳ, TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) He polished a sword, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) by laying on it a broad and smooth spearhead and rubbing it therewith: so accord. to El-Ahmar, who relates that an Arab of the desert said to him, I said to a sword-polisher, “Hast thou finished my sword?” and he answered, naEamo Uil-aA Oan-iI lamo OaxoXibohu [Yes, except that I have not polished it]. (Ṣ.) And [or, as in the TA, “or”] He sharpened it. (Ḳ, TA.)

And He forged a sword: (Ḳ:) or fashioned it with the file, without polishing it: (TA:) or he made it imperfectly, not thoroughly, or not well: (A:) thus, again, the verb has two contr. significations: (Ḳ:) also he thus made an arrow: (A:) or he shaped out a bow, (AḤn, Ḳ,) and an arrow, (TA,) [in a rough manner, or] by the first operation, (AḤn, Ḳ, TA,) without perfecting it, or making it smooth, or even. (TA.) You say of a sword, before it has been filed, maA OaHosana maA xuXiba [How well has it been forged!]: and in like manner one says of an arrow, when it has been filed, before the safan [with which it is smoothed] has been applied to it. (Skr, on a verse of Sakhr, cited below, voce xaXiybapN.)

[Hence,] xaXaba AlX-iEora, (ISk, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (A,) ‡ He said, spoke, or uttered, the poetry (ISk, Ṣ, A, Ḳ) as it came, (ISk, Ṣ,) [unpolished, and unstudied,] without affecting nicety, or refinement, therein, (ISk, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and without study, or labour: (A, Ḳ:) Jereer did thus, and Farezdaḳ trimmed his verses; but the verses of Jereer thus produced are better than the trimmed verses of Farezdaḳ: (A, TA:) and AxtXbhu↓ signifies the same. (A, Ḳ.) You say also, humo yaxoXibuwna AlkalaAma waAlEamala ‡ [They say, speak, or utter, words, and do work, without affecting nicety, or refinement, and without study, or labour]: (A:) or imperfectly, or not thoroughly; inelegantly, or not well. (TA.) And Ait-axaca Als-ayofa xaXabFA: see 8.
5. txX-b: see 8.
txX-bti AlUibilu The camels ate thick branches: (Ḳ:) or ate dry herbage. (Ṣ.) And tataxaX-abu EiydaAna AlX-ajari They take with the mouth, and eat, the branches of the trees. (TA.)

entry.sense: 8. AxtXb Als-ayofi signifies Ait-axacahu xaXobFA↓; He took the sword without choosing the best by taking it from this place or that; (L, TA;) as also tHX-bhu↓. (TA.)
See also 1, near the end.

12. AxXwXb He [a man or a camel (see xaXibN)] was, or became, tall, and gross, rude, or coarse, with bones uncovered by flesh, and hard, or hardy. (Ḳ.) He (an ostrich) was, or became, rough, or coarse. (Ṣ.)

† He (a man) became hard, or hardy, and rough, or coarse, in his religion, clothing, food, and in all respects. (TA.) † He employed himself in work, and in walking barefoot, in order that his body might become thick, gross, or coarse. (Ṣ, TA.) And AxXwXb fiI EayoXihi † He endured with patience a life of hardship, or difficulty: or he subjected himself to a life of hardship, or difficulty, in order to render himself the more able to bear it. (Ḳ, TA.) AixoXawoXibuwA is thus used in a trad. of ʼOmar: (Ṣ, TA:) or, as some relate it, the word is [AjXwXbwA,] with j; or, accord. to some, AxXwXnwA, with x and n. (TA.)

rajulN qiXobN xiXobN A man in whom is no good: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or with whom is no good: (TA:) [in some copies of the Ḳ, xiXobN waqiXobN; but this, as is said in the TA, is incorrect:] xiXobN being an imitative sequent to qiXobN. (Ṣ, TA.)

xaXabN [Wood, such as is used in carpentry and the like; timber;] thick wood: (A, Ḳ:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. xaXabapN [signifying a piece of wood or timber]: (Mṣb:) the pl. of the latter, (Ṣ, Mṣb,*) or of the former, (Ḳ,) is xaXabN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, [i. e., accord. to the Ḳ, the pl. is the same as the sing., but properly speaking, as said above, this is a coll. gen. n.,]) and xuXubN and xuXobN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xuXobaAnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [which last is agreeable with analogy as pl. of xaXabN,] or xuXobaAnN is pl. of xuXobN, and xuXobN is pl. of xaXabapN. (JK.) The hypocrites are described in a trad. as xuXubN biAll-ayoli SuxubN biAln-ahaAri Like timbers, or pieces of wood, in the night; [clamorous in the day;] meaning that they pass the night in sleep, without prayer. (TA.)

maAlN xaXabN † Cattle that are lean, or emaciated, syn. hazolaI, (Ḳ,) in consequence of their feeding upon dry herbage. (TA.) [And it seems that xaXabN↓ signifies the same: for I find in the TA, and in a copy of the A which I believe to have been used by the author of the TA, mentioned as tropical, maAlN xaXabN waHaTibN jazolN, app. meaning that maAlN xaXibN and HaTibN signify jazolN; but jazolN, I think, is here evidently a mistranscription for hazolaI; as HaTibN is explained in the Ṣ and Ḳ as signifying “very lean or meagre.”]

xaXibN Rough, or coarse; as also OaxoXabuxaXiybN↓: (Ḳ:) the former applied in this sense to a male ostrich: (Ṣ:) and both signify anything gross, or big, and rough, or coarse; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ;) as also xaXiybN↓: (TA:) and the first, (Ḳ,) applied to a man and to a camel, (TA,) tall, and gross, rude, or coarse, with bones uncovered by flesh, and hard, or hardy, and strong; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also xaXiybN↓ and xaXiybiI-N↓: (Ḳ:) or these three signify, or signify also, dry, or rigid, or tough: (Kr, ISd:) and xaXibN, a man hard, or hardy, strong, and vigorous, in body: (A, TA:) and the same, (JK,) or xaXiybN↓, (TA,) a man whose bones are uncovered by flesh, and whose sinews are apparent; (JK, TA;) hard, or hardy, and strong: (JK:) and the last, a gross, big, or coarse, camel: (Ṣ, TA:) a camel gross, coarse, or rude, in make, and ugly: (TA:) and a horse thick, or big, in the bones. (Ḥam p. 207.) See also xaXabN. And see OaxoXabu, in two places.
Also † Life in which one is not dainty, nice, or scrupulous. (Ḳ.)
xaXobapN The first filing of a sword, before the polishing. (TA.)
xuXobaAnN: see OaxoXabu.
xaXaAbN: see OaxoXabu.
xuXaAbN, from the Persian xuwXo Mbo, [The beverage properly called in Arabic] nabiyc. (TA.)

hom.sense: xaXiybN and maxoXuwbN↓ Mixed. (TA.)
And the former, (Ḳ,) or both, (TA,) Picked out, chosen, or selected: (Ḳ, TA:) both words thus having two contr. significations. (TA.)
Also the former (Ṣ, Ḳ) and latter, (Ḳ,) A sword polished: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) this is [said to be] the prevailing signification: (TA:) or both signify a sharpened sword. (JK, TA.)

And the former, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or both, (JK, A,) A sword of which the forging is commenced; thus [again] having two contr. significations: (Ṣ:) or forged, (Ḳ,* TA,) or fashioned with the file, but not yet polished: (Aṣ, TA:) or newly made: (TA:) or imperfectly, not thoroughly, or not well, wrought; (JK, A;) and thus both words applied to an arrow: (A:) or the former, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or both, (TA,) applied to an arrow, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to a bow, (Ḳ,) shaped out (Ṣ, Ḳ) [in a rough manner,] by the first operation, (Ṣ, TA,) not yet perfected, or made smooth, or even: (TA:) pl. of the former (accord. to the TA as applied to a bow [but I see no reason for this restriction]) xuXubN and xaXaAYibu. (Ḳ.) maxoXuwbN↓ lamo yunaq-aHo [Rough hewn, not yet trimmed,] is a prov., mentioned by Meyd and Z. (MF, TA.)

[Hence,] XiEorN xaXiybN and maxoXuwbN↓ ‡ Poetry said, spoken, or uttered, as it has come to the speaker, [unpolished, and unstudied,] without his affecting nicety, or refinement, therein, and without study, or labour. (A,* TA.) And jaMCa bilmaxoXuwbi↓ ‡ [He said, or uttered, that which came to him, as it came, unpolished, and unstudied]. (A, TA.)
See also xaXiybN voce xaXibN, in three places.
It also signifies Bad, corrupt, or vile. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense:
xaXiybapN The natural quality [of the metal] of a sword, (Skr on the verse here following, Ṣ, TA,) before the making thereof is completed: (Skr:) or its blade, or iron: (A:) or its edge: or its polish. (JK.) Sakhr says,
waSaArimN OuxoliSato xaXiybatuhu
OaboyaDu mahowN fiI matonihi zubadu
And a sharp sword of which the natural quality [of the metal] before the completion of the making thereof has been refined, [white, or a sword,] thin in the two edges or sides, having [in its broad side] diversified marks. (Skr.)
xaXiybiI-N: see xaXibN.
xaX-aAbN: see what next follows.

hom.sense: xaX-aAbapN [a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is xaX-aAbN↓,] Sellers of xaXab [i. e. wood, or timber]. (TA.)

Accord. to El-Hejeree, xXAbp [so in the TA, without any syll. sign,] signifies A slender [implement of the kind called] mTrq [i. e. miToraq, q. v.,] which the polisher, when he has finished the polishing of a sword, passes over it, in consequence of which the scabbard does not alter its state. (TA.)

entry.sense: xaAXibN: see muxotaXibN.

OaxoXabu: see xaXibN. Also A great mountain: (A:) or a rugged, or rough, and great mountain; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so jabalN xaXibN↓: or such as is not to be ascended: (TA:) an elevated place, rugged, with rough stones: (JK:) a tract of the kind termed quf-, rugged and stony: (TA:) pl. OaxaAXibu, (A, TA,) because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it: and the fem. xaXobaMCu is also sometimes used in the same sense; or as syn. with gayoDapN [i. e. a thicket,, &c.]; but the former meaning is better known: and this [likewise] is thought to be rather a subst. than an epithet, because of the pl., mentioned above: (TA:) and xuXobaAnN↓ [also seems to be a pl. of OaxoXabu, or of xaXibN; for it is said that it] signifies rugged, or rough, mountains, neither great nor small: (Ḳ:) and rugged ground. (TA in art. cnb.) xaXobaMCu also signifies Hard land or ground; (Ḳ,* TA;) land, or ground, in which are stones and pebbles and earth or clay. (IAmb, TA.) And OaroDN xaXaAbN↓ (Ḳ, TA) Hard land or ground, like xaXobaMCu, (TA,) that flows with the least rain. (Ḳ, TA.) And OakamapN xaXobaMCu (Ṣ, TA) A hill of which the stones are scattered, but near together. (TA.) And jabohapN xaXobaMCu A displeasing forehead; as also xaXibapN↓: (TA:) or a displeasing, rigid forehead; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;*) not even. (JK.) And OaxoXabu Aljabohapi A man having a displeasing and rigid forehead. (TA.)
bayotN muxaX-abN [so in the present day, but written in the TA without any syll. sign,] A house having xaXab [i. e. wood, or timber, employed in its construction]. (TA.)
maxoXuwbN: see xaXiybN, in four places.
It is applied to a horse, by El-Aạshà; (Ṣ, TA;) meaning Of mixed pedigree: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or not broken; not well trained; from what next follows; and thus used only by El-Aạshà. (IKh, TA.)
jafonapN maxoXuwbapN A wooden bowl imperfectly made. (IKh, TA.)

TaEaAmN maxoXuwbN [Food imperfectly prepared; i. e.], if flesh-meat, not thoroughly cooked; and if not flesh-meat, (but grain, TA,) without any seasoning, or condiment, to render it pleasant, or savoury. (Ḳ,* TA.)
muxotaXibN One who eats what he can; as also xaAXibN↓. (JK.)

hom.sense: 1. xaXarahu, aor. _i {yaxoXiru}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaXorN, (Ṣ,) He picked it, (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) namely, a collection of goods, or commodities, (Lḥ,) removing from it what was bad. (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And xaXara, aor. (and inf. n., TA) as above, He left upon the table refuse of food: thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (Ḳ.)
Also xaXarahu He rendered it (a thing) bad, or vile. (TA.)

entry.sense: xuXaArN (Ḳ) and xuXaArapN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) The bad part or parts [or the refuse] (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ) of goods, or commodities, (Lḥ,) or of anything. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And the latter, The worst kind, syn. XiyS, of lates. (A.)
What contains no lub- [or heart], of barley. (A, Ḳ.)
And the latter, The refuse of food remaining upon a table; that in which is no good. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.*)

Also the latter, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and the former, (Ḳ,) and xuX-aArN↓, (IAạr,) ‡ The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, of mankind, or of people; (IAạr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also xaAXirN↓, accord. to the Ḳ, but correctly xaAXirapN↓, as related by AA from IAạr. (TA.) El-Hotei-ah says,
wabaAEa baniyhi baEoDuhumo bixuXaArapF
wabiEota licuboyaAna AlEalaMCa bimaAliki
[And some of them have sold their sons for the refuse of mankind; but] thou hast purchased eminence for Dhubyán with Málik: in the Ṣ we find bimaAlikaA [with thy property]: but it is correctly as above: Málik was a son of 'Oyeyneh Ibn-Hisn: the Benoo-'Ámir slew him: wherefore 'Oyeyneh made war upon them, and obtained his blood-revenge, and spoil: and to this event El-Hotei-ah refers in the verse above. (IB, TA.)
xuXaArapN: see the paragraph next preceding.
xuX-aArN: see the paragraph next preceding.
xaAXirN: see the paragraph next preceding.
xaAXirapN: see the paragraph next preceding.

hom.sense: 1. xaXaEa, aor. _a {yaxoXaEu}, inf. n. xuXuwEN, He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AxtXE↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and txX-E↓; (Abu-lFet-h, Ḥam pp. 24 and 127;) xuXuwEN being syn. with xuDuwEN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or xXwE is nearly the same as xDwE: (Lth, Ḳ:) or the former is mostly used as meaning in the voice; and the latter, in the necks: (Mṣb:) or the latter is in the body; and the former is in the voice and in the eyes: (Ḳ:) or, as we read in the ʼEyn, the former is nearly the same as the latter, except that the latter is in the body, and signifies the acknowledging of humility and submission, and the former is in the voice and in the eyes; and the like is said in the Nh [and in the Mṣb in art. xDE]. (TA.) You say, xaXaEati AlOaSowaAtu The voices were [or shall be (as in the Ḳur xx. 107)] still and low: (Mṣb:) or low: or, as some say, still. (TA.) And xaXaEa bibaSarihi He lowered his eye. (Ṣ.) And AxtXE↓ and txX-E↓ He cast his eye towards the ground, and lowered his voice. (TA.) Lth says that you say, AxtXE↓ fulaAnN, but not AxtXE bibaSarihi. (TA.) And xaXaEa baSaruhu His eye became contracted. (TA.) And xaXaEato duwnahu AlOaboSaAru ‡ [meaning The eyes were cast down before him, or it]. (TA.) xuXuwEN also signifies The being, or becoming, still: and the abasing oneself; or lowering oneself. (Ḳ, TA.) And AxtXE↓, He lowered, or stooped, or bent down, his breast. (TA.)

Also, inf. n. as above, He feared; for instance, in prayer: (TA:) or xaXaEa fiI SalaAtihi and fiI duEaAYihi signifies He applied himself with his heart to [or in] his prayer, and his supplication. (Mṣb.)

xaXaEati AlkawaAkibu, (Aboo-ʼAdnán,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) ‡ The stars approached to the place of setting; (Aboo-ʼAdnán;) or approached to setting: (Ḳ:) or sank, and nearly disappeared in their setting-place. (Aboo-Sálih El-Kilábee.) [The corresponding phrase in Hebrew, occurring in Gen. xxxvii. 9, probably has the same meaning.]
xaXaEati AlX-amosu ‡ The sun became eclipsed. (TA.)
xaXaEa Als-anaAmu ‡ The hump for the most part went away; (O, Ḳ;) i. e. the hump of the camel: (TA:) or became lean; its fat going away, and its height becoming lowered. (L.)
fulaAnN jicolN HikaAkN xaXaEati Eanohu AlOubanu is a saying of the Arabs, explained in art. Hk. (TA in that art.)
xaXaEa Alwaraqu ‡ The leaves withered. (TA.)
xaXaEati AlOaroDu ‡ The earth, or land, dried up, not being rained upon. (TA.)
xaXaEa fulaAnN xaraAXiI-N Sadorihi Such a one ejected the viscous saliva [or phlegm of his chest]. (O, Ḳ.)
And xaXaEato xaraAXiI-N Sarihi The viscous saliva [or phlegm of his chest] became ejected. (O, Ḳ.) The verb is thus intrans., as well as trans. (O.)

entry.sense: 5. txX-E He lowered, humbled, or abased, himself: (Lth, Ḳ:) or he constrained himself to be, or to become, lowly, humble, or submissive; or to be so, or to become so, in voice, or in the eyes. (Ṣ.) See also 1, in two places.
6. txAXE [He feigned lowliness, humility, or submissiveness, in demeanour, or in voice, or in the eyes]. (TA in art. mwt;, &c.)
8: see 1, in four places.

xuXoEapN A low hill: (Ṣ:) or a hill cleaving to the ground: (IAạr, Ḳ:) and a piece of rugged ground: (IDrd, Ḳ:) or [elevated ground such as is termed] quf- that is for the most part soft, i. e. neither stone nor clay: (Lth:) and a rock growing in the sea: (TA:) pl. xuXaEN. (Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., kaAnati AlOaroDu xuXoEapF EalaI AlmaMCi vum-a duHiyato [The earth was a low hill,, &c., upon the water: then it was spread out]: (Ṣ:) but this trad. is variously related. (TA.)

xaAXiEN Lowly, humble, or submissive, (Ḳ, TA,) and still: (TA:) [or so in the voice and in the eyes: (see 1:)] pl. xaAXiEuwna and xuX-aEN; the latter also signifying men lowering, humbling, or abasing, themselves: or constraining themselves to be, or to become, lowly, humble, or submissive; or to be so, or to become so, in voice, or in the eyes: or casting their eyes towards the ground, and lowering their voices. (TA.)
Hence, in the Kur [lxviii. 43, and lxx. 44], accord. to different readings, xaAXiEapF OaboSaAruhumo and xaAXiEFA OaboSaAruhumo [Having their eyes cast down]: the accus. case being used as denotative of state. (Zj, TA.)
Bowing; or bending down the head and body. (Ḳ.)
Fearing. (TA.)
‡ A camel's foot (xuf-N) cleaving to the ground. (TA.)
‡ A wall that has cracked, and given notice of its falling, and [then] become even with the ground. (TA.)
‡ A herb dried up, and falling down upon the ground. (TA.)

Applied to a place, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and, with p {xaAXiEapN}, to a balodap [or portion of country], (Ṣ,) ‡ Overspread with dust, [in the CK AlmuEanobaru is erroneously put for Almugab-aru,] and having in it no place of alighting, or of abiding: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and to land (OaroDN), meaning of which the wind raises the surface, by reason of its softness, so as to efface its traces, or tracks: (L:) or in this case it is with p {xaAXiEapN}, as in the Ḳur xli. 39, and means altered (mutagay-irap [probably a mistranscription for mutagab-irap overspread with dust]), and having its herbage broken in pieces: (Zj,* TA:) or dried up, and containing no herbage: (Jel:) or containing no green herbage: or low, or depressed, and still: (TA:) and, without p, applied to a place, to which one finds not his way: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) pl. xuX-aEN. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. xaXafa, aor. _i {yaxoXifu} (Ṣ, Ṣgh, L, Ḳ) and _u {yaxoXufu}, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaXofN, (Ṣ,) He, or it, made a sound, (L, Ḳ,) or what is termed His- [i. e. a low, faint, gentle, or soft, sound], (Ṣ,) and an audible motion: (Ṣ, L:) said of a man: and said also of snow, as meaning it caused one to hear a [sound such as is termed] xaXofap in walking [upon it]; as is the case in intense cold. (Ṣ.) And xaXafa, aor. _i {yaxoXifu}, inf. n. xuXuwfN, said of snow, It was rough, so that it caused one to hear a xaXofap in walking [upon it]: and in like manner said of ice; i. e. it was soft, or yielding [to the feet, crackling], or easily broken. (TA.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely, El-Katámee, (TA,)
UicaA kab-ada Aln-ajomu Als-amaMCa biXatowapK
EalaIHiyna har-a Alkalobu wAlv-aloju xaAXifu
[When the asterism of the Pleiades culminates in winter, at the time when the dog whines by reason of the cold, and the snow causes one to hear a slight sound in walking upon it]: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to IB, the right reading is, bisuHorapK [a little before daybreak, or in the last third of the night]: (TA:) Hyn is here mansoob because ElI is made to be redundant, and because it is prefixed to a verbal proposition: (Ṣ:) this is the more approved way in a case of this kind, when the verb commencing the proposition is a pret.; but some say ElI Hiyni. (I’Aḳ p. 199.)
xaXafa said of water, It froze. (Ḳ.)
Said of cold, It was, or became, intense. (Ḳ.)

xaXafa iI Als-ayori, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaXafaAnN, (JK,) He hastened, made haste, or sped, [app. so as to cause a slight sound to be heard,] in going, journeying, or pace. (JK,* Ḳ.) And mar-a yaxoXifu He passed along hastening. (TA.)

xaXafa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxoXufu} (Ṣ, TA) and _i {yaxoXifu}, (TA,) inf. n. xuXuwfN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xaXafaAnN, (Ḳ,) He went away in, or into, the land, or country. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And xaXafa fulaAnN Such a one journeyed away, went away, or departed, or became hidden or concealed, syn. tagay-aba, (Ḳ, TA,) in the land, or country. (TA.)
xaXafa, inf. n. xaXafaAnN, He (a man) went, or travelled, by night. (Ḳ.)

And He was bold, or daring, in night-journeying: or he went about, or round about, by night; (L, Ḳ, TḲ; but in the first and second, only the inf. n. is mentioned in this case;) and journeyed much by night. (L.) And xaXafa biAlqawomi, aor. _i {yaxoXifu}, said of a guide of the way, He went about, or round about, by night, and hastened, or sped, with the party: (JK:) or xaXafa bihimo, inf. n. xaXaAfapN, he (a guide of the way) acted with a penetrative energy, or with sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, with them [in conducting them]; as also xX-f↓, inf. n. taxoXiyfN. (Ḳ,* TA.)
xaXafato biwaladihaA She (a woman) cast forth her child [from the womb]. (Ḳ.) And xuXifa bihi He, or it, was cast, or thrown; as also xufiXa bh, and HufiXa bh. (TA.)
xaXafa raOosahu biAlHajari He (a man, Ṣ) broke his head with the stone. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

3. xAXf, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaAXafapN, (JK, TA,) It (an arrow) caused a [sound such as is termed] HaXofap to be heard on its hitting the object aimed at: (Ḳ,* TA:) or it (an arrow) caused a [confused sound such as is termed] xaXoxaXap to be heard from the inside of the animal hit thereby. (JK.)
xAXf fiI AlX-ar-i, and UilaI AlX-ar-i, He hastened in doing, and to do, evil, or mischief. (TA.)
xAXf fiI cim-atihi He hastened in breaking, or violating, his compact, covenant, or promise of protection or safeguard, or of security or safety. (Ḳ,* TA.)
xAXf AlUibila layolatahu He went, or kept pace, with the camels during his night; syn. saAyarahaA. (Ḳ.)
7: see 1.

hom.sense: xuXofN: see xaXofapN, in two places:
and xiXofN:
and xaAXifN.

entry.sense: xuXofN: see what next follows.

xiXofN (Aṣ, JK, IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xuXofN↓ and xaXofN↓, (Ḳ,) the second of which is said by MF to be the most common, and then the first, (TA,) [but this is a mistake, for the first is the only form commonly occurring,] The young one of the gazelle; (JK, Mṣb;) applied to the male and the female; (Mṣb;) or the female is termed xXfp [i. e. xiXofapN and xiXofapi and xaXofapN]: (Ḳ:) or the young one of the gazelle in the first stage after its birth: (Ḳ:) or after it is termed TalFA; for it is called by the latter appellation when just born: (Aṣ, TA: [see XaSarN:]) or after it is termed jadaAyap: (TA:) or when it first walks: or she that flees, or goes away, from, or of, (mino,) her young ones: (Ḳ: [a strange (as well as an ambiguous) explanation, seeing that the fem. is said in the Ḳ to be with p {xiXofapN}:]) pl. xuXuwfN, (Mṣb,) or xiXafapN. (Ḳ.)

xaXafN and xaXiyfN↓ Rough snow, (JK, Ḳ,) that causes one to hear a [sound such as is termed] xaXofap in walking [upon it]: (TA:) and (in like manner, TA) ice that is soft, or yielding [to the feet, crackling], or easily broken: (Ḳ:) or the latter signifies [simply] snow. (Ṣ.) One says, OaSabaHa AlmaMCu xaXiyfFA↓ [The water became ice such as was soft,, &c.]. (JK, TA.) [See also xaAXifN.]

hom.sense: xaXofapN (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and xaXafapN↓ (Mgh, Ḳ) and xaXofN↓ (Ḳ) A sound: (Ḳ:) or such as is termed His-N; (Ṣ;) [i. e.] a low, faint, gentle, or soft, sound: (JK:) and a motion: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a low, faint, gentle, or soft, His-: or the first signifies the sound of the creeping of serpents; and the sound of the hyena: (Ḳ:) or a sound that is not loud, or vehement; (AʼObeyd;) and so ↓the second: (Mgh:) or a single sound; so accord. to Fr: (Az, TA:) and ↓the last signifies the sound of a sword falling upon flesh, and upon a weapon or weapons: and the sound of feet, such as is not loud, or vehement. (TA.)
Also the first, A [tract of high ground such as is termed] quf- that is mostly soft. (L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xaXafapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
xaXuwfN A quick, or swift, man. (Ṣ.)

Also and xaAXifN↓ and xaAXifapN↓ sings. of xuX-afN, which signifies Camels that journey by night: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to IB, the sing. of this pl. is xaAXifN only: and the pl. of xuXuwfN is xuX-afN [a mistranscription for xuXufN]. (L.)
See also mixoXafN:
and the paragraph here next following.

hom.sense: xaXiyfN: see xaXafN, in two places:
and xaXuwfN also, in two places.
And Water that runs in a [watercourse such as is termed] baToHaMC, beneath the pebbles, two or three days, and then goes away. (TA.)

entry.sense: AlxaX-aAfu: see mixoXafN.
Oum-u xaX-aAfK Calamity, or misfortune; (JK, Ḳ;) as also xaX-aAfN, without Oum-. (TA.)

xuX-aAfN A certain nocturnal flying thing; (Mṣb;) the xuf-aAX [or bat], (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb,) that flies by night: so says El-Fárábee, in section X: (Mṣb:) formed by transposition from the latter word, which is the more chaste: (Ṣgh, Mṣb, TA:) or rather so called because of its xafaXaAn,
i. e. its going about, or round about, by night: (Lth, TA:) or a certain flying thing, having two small eyes: (TA:) as some say, (Ṣ,) and thus also says El-Fárábee, (Mṣb,) the xuT-aAf [or swallow]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) he who says xuf-aAXN derives its name from the smallness of its eyes. (Lth, TA.)
[xaAXifN act. part. n. of 1; fem. with p {xaAXifapN}]: see 1.
Water freezing, or in a state of congelation, and so xaXofN↓. (TA.) [See xaXafN.]
See also xaXuwfN, in four places:
and see xaXiyfN.
Also A boy light, or active, and brisk, lively, or sprightly; like xaAsifN. (TA in art. xsf.)
OaxaAXifu Hard tracts of land: with s, it signifies such as are soft. (Fr, Ḳ.)

maxoXafN A place of ice; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) [an icehouse;] this is the meaning of the term by which Lth explains it, namely, yaxadaAn, (Ṣgh, TA,) [or yaxodaAno,] which is Persian, and which the author of the L has mistranscribed najoraAn, adding thereto AlcI yjrI Elyh AlbAb. (TA.)
ZaboyapN muxoXifN A she-gazelle having a xiXof. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
mixoXafN: see xaXuwfN, in two places.

Also A guide of the way (Lth, JK, Ḳ) who travels, or goes about, with people by night: (Lth, JK:) or who acts with a penetrative energy, and with sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness. (Ḳ.) A man (AA, Ṣ) bold, or daring, (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ,) to encounter the night, (Ṣ,) or to encounter the terror of the night, (AA,) or in night-journeying: (Ḳ:) or who goes about, or round about, by night; as also xaXuwfN↓: (Ḳ:) or this last, one who fears not by night: (JK:) or who goes away boldly in the night or in any case. (AA, IB.)
AlmixoXafu The lion; (Ḳ;) because of his boldness in going about: (TA:) and so AlxaX-aAfu↓. (JK.)

hom.sense: 1. xaXamahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoXimu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaXomN, (JK, Ṣ,) He broke his xayoXuwmN [q. v.]. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

xaXima, aor. _a {yaxoXamu}, inf. n. xaXamN, (Ḳ, TA,) agreeably with rule, (TA, [accord. to the CK xaXomN,]) and xuXuwmN, (Ḳ,) which is irreg., (TA,) He (a man, TA) was, or became, wide in the nose. (Ḳ.)

And It (the nose) became altered for the worse in odour, or stinking, by reason of a disease therein; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e., by reason of a stoppage therein, affecting the passage of the breath, and preventing respiration: or had one of its three bones broken. (TA.)

And xaXima, (JK, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxoXamu}, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaXomN, (JK, Mgh, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or xaXamN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, and so in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) and xuXaAmN, (Ḳ, [but mentioned in the JK as though a simple subst.,]) said of a man, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) He became affected with a certain disease in the nose, (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) which stopped the passage of the breath; (JK;) or which caused it to become altered for the worse in odour, or stinking; (Zj, Mgh;) or which rendered it corrupt, or unsound, so that the person could not smell: (Mṣb:) or his [cartilages of the nose called the] xayaAXiym [pl. of xayoXuwmN q. v.] delapsed, (Ḳ, TA,) and the passage of his breath became stopped. (TA.)

And xaXima, (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxoXamu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaXamN; (TA;) and AxXm↓; (JK, Ḳ;) and xX-m↓, (Ṣ, JM, TA,) inf. n. taxoXiymN; (JM;) for which last, the Ḳ erroneously substitutes txX-m↓; (TA;) It (flesh-meat) became altered for the worse in odour, or stinking: (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ:) or became very stinking; stank much. (JK.)

2. xX-mhu AlX-araAbu, inf. n. taxoXiymN, The odour of the wine rose into his xayoXuwm, and intoxicated him: (M, Ḳ:) or the odour of the wine rose into his xyXwm, and became infused in his brain, and so dispelled his reason. (T, TA.)
See also 1, last sentence.

entry.sense: 4: see 1, last sentence.
5. txX-m His reason became dispelled by the rising of the odour of wine into his xayoXuwm and its becoming infused in his brain. (T, TA.)
See also 1, last sentence.

hom.sense: xaXomN The nose: [see also xayoXuwmN:] and the mucus that flows from it. (TA, from a trad.: and the latter signification is mentioned in the TA voce salata; as well as in the present article.)
[In modern Arabic, it signifies The mouth: and hence, a spout.]
In Persian, it signifies Anger: and this meaning is with probability deducible from the literal root of this art.; for he who is angry raises his nose and makes it pointed. (TA.)

entry.sense: xuXomapN [Intoxication produced by the odour of wine rising into the xayoXuwm;] a subst. from xaX-amahu AlX-araAbu. (Ḳ.)
xaXimN, applied to flesh-meat, [Stinking: (see 1, last sentence:) or] stinking much. (JK.)

hom.sense: xuXaAmN A certain disease in the nose, and a stoppage of the passage of the breath [therein]. (JK. [See also 1.])
A man having a large nose: (Ṣ:) [or] a large nose; (Zj, JK, Ḳ;) and so though not elevated, or prominent. (Zj, TA.)
And † A mountain having a thick prominence: (Ṣ:) or a long mountain, (AA, JK, TA,) having a prominence, (AA, TA,) or having a thick prominence: (TA:) or a great mountain. (Ḳ.)
And AlxuXaAmu The lion: (JK, Ḳ:) because of the greatness of his nose. (TA.)

entry.sense: xuXaAmapN Refuse; anything remaining after the good has been picked out. (JK.)

xayoXuwmN The extreme, or most remote, [meaning innermost,] part of the nose: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or the interior of the nose: (MA:) or the upper part of the interior of the nose: and the bone of the nose: (KL:) or the part that is above the nuxorap [which here seems to mean the end, or tip, or flexible part,] of the nose, of the bone thereof: and what is beneath this [is] of [the thin cartilages called] the xaXaArim of the head: (M, Ḳ:) and the nose [altogether] (Mṣb, KL) is so called by some: (Mṣb:) the word is of the measure fayoEuwlN: (Mṣb, TA:) and its pl. is xayaAXiym: (Mṣb:) which [also] signifies certain cartilages in the extreme [or inmost] part of the nose, between it and the brain: or certain ducts, (Euruwq, [meaning, or including, the air-passages, see juX-apN, and naxara, &c.,]) in the interior (baATin M, or baTon Ḳ) of the nose. (M, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] the pl. signifies also ‡ Prominences, or projecting parts, of mountains. (JK, Ṣ, TA.)
And the sing., [as a coll. gen. n.,] Small, thin, black things, resembling flesh; and morbose nodes; upon a bone. (TA.)
OaxoXamu Wide in the nose: (Ḳ:) applied to a man. (TA.)

And, so applied, Having a certain disease in the nose, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) whereby it is rendered corrupt, or unsound, so that he cannot smell: (Mṣb:) or whose xayoXuwmN has a fetid odour; (Mgh, Mṣb;) from xaXima said of flesh-meat, explained above: (Mṣb:) or that cannot smell anything, (JK, Az, Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) whether sweet or stinking, (Az, Mgh, TA,) by reason of a stoppage in his xayaAXiym, from having one of the three bones broken: (TA:) and maxoXuwmN↓ [in like manner] signifies having his nose altered for the worse in odour, or stinking, his nose altered for the worse in affecting the passage of the breath, and preventing respiration; or having one of its three bones broken: (TA:) fem. of the former xaXomaMCu. (Mṣb.)

And, applied to the nose, Altered for the worse in odour, or stinking, by reason of a disease therein, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e., by a stoppage therein, affecting the passage of the breath, and preventing respiration: or having one of its three bones broken. (TA.)
muxaX-amN Intoxicated; as also maxoXuwmN↓ and mutaxaX-imN↓: (Ḳ:) or much intoxicated. (Ṣ, TA.)
And Broken in pieces. (TA.)
maxoXuwmN: see OaxoXamu:
and see also muxaX-amN.
mutaxaX-imN: see muxaX-amN.

1. xaXuna, aor _u, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xuXuwnapN and xuXonapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL) and xaXaAnapN (CK, TA, but omitted in some copies of the Ḳ) and xaXonN and maxoXanapN, (Ḳ,) It was, or became, rough, harsh, or coarse; (Ḳ,* KL, PṢ;) contr. of laAna, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of naEuma; (Mṣb;) as also txX-n↓. (Ḳ.)

[Hence,] huwa cuw xaXonapK and xuXuwnapK (Ḳ) and maxoXanapK (TA) ‡ He is difficult, refractory, or stubborn; not to be coped with. (Ḳ, TA. [See also xaXinN.]) And xaXuna Ealayohi Sadorihi and AxXwXn↓ Elyh Sdrh † He was, or became, angry with him. (Sh, TA.) See also 3.
2. [xX-nhu He made it rough, harsh, or coarse.]

[Hence,] xX-n Sadorahu, inf. n. taxoXiynN, ‡ He exasperated him; made him to be affected with wrath, or rage. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) A poet says,
waxaX-anato SadorFA jayobuhu laka naASiHu
[explained in art. jyb]. (Ṣ.)
5: see 1:
and see also 12.

hom.sense: 10. AstxXnhu He found it [or esteemed it] rough, harsh, or coarse. (Ḳ.)

Hence, in a trad. of ʼAlee, making mention of pious men of learning, QsotalaAnuwA maA QsotaxoXana Almutorafuwna † [And they esteemed, or esteem, soft, or smooth, what those leading a life of ease and plenty esteemed, or esteem, rough, harsh, or coarse]. (TA.) And AstxXn AlmaqaAma fiI maHal-i kacaA † [He esteemed unpleasant, or uncomfortable, the remaining in such a place of abode]. (TA in art. bXE.)

entry.sense: 12. AxXwXn (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and txX-n↓ (Ḳ) It was, or became, very rough, harsh, or coarse: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or (Ḳ.) he wore rough, harsh, or coarse, clothes: (JK, Ḳ:) or the former signifies also he accustomed himself to the wearing of such clothes: (Ṣ:) or each, he ate rough, harsh, or coarse, food: (TA:) or the former, (JK,) or each, (Ḳ,) † he said what was rough, harsh, or coarse: (JK, Ḳ, TA:) or † he lived a rough, or coarse, life. (Ḳ.) The former verb is more intensive in all its senses (Ḳ, TA) than xaXuna and txX-n, because of the repetition of the medial radical and the addition of the w; and the same is the case of every verb of this class, as AEXwXb and the like, as is indicated in the Ṣ. (TA.)
See also 1.

xaXinN Rough, harsh, or coarse; (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ, KL, PṢ;) applied to a thing (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) of any kind; (Ḳ;) as also OaxoXanu↓: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) in relation to a stone, they seldom or never say otherwise than OaxoXanu: (Mṣb:) the fem. of the former is with p {xaXinapN}; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and the pl. is xuXunN, (Mṣb,) [also said to be a pl. by poetic license of OaxoXanu, for xuXonN, as will be seen below,] or xiXaAnN, (Ḳ,) which is applied in the sense explained above to land [or lands]: (TA:) the fem. of OaxoXanu↓ is xaXonaMCu; (Ḳ;) and the pl. is xuXonN. (Ṣ.) You say OaroDN xaXinapN Rough, or rugged, ground or land. (Mṣb.) And OaroDN xXonaMCu↓ Rugged ground or land, (JK, TA,) in which are stones and sand. (TA.) And mulaMCapN xaXonaMCu↓ [A wrapper for the body] in which is roughness, harshness, or coarseness, either from newness or from make. (TA.)

[Hence,] † A strong man. (Mṣb.) And huwa xaXinu AljaAnibi and OaxoXanuhu↓ ‡ He is difficult, refractory, or stubborn; not to be coped with. (Ḳ, TA. [See also 1.]) And EaAXa EayoXFA xaXinFA † He lived a rough, or coarse, life. (Ḳ.) See also OaxoXanu.

xuXayonaMCu [dim. of xaXonaMCu] A certain small herb, or leguminous plant, green, found in meadows, and plains; so called because of its roughness, or harshness, or coarseness. (TA.) See also xaXnaMCu at the end of the next paragraph.

OaxoXanu, and its fem. xaXonaMCu: see xaXinN, in five places. You say also katiybapN xaXonaMCu ‡ [An army, or a portion thereof, bristling with weapons: or] having many weapons: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) [and in like manner, jayoXN xaXinN↓, occurring in the TA in art. xms:] and maEoXarN xuXonN and xuXunN; the latter allowable in poetry: (Ṣ: [it is there implied that this has a similar meaning:]) or the last signifies † [a company of men] who resist harm, or injury. (Ḥam p. 5.) And Ouvofiy-apN xaXonaMCu † A great number [of people]. (Ṣ in art. vafI.)

Also, (Ḳ, TA,) or OuxayoXinu↓, (JK,) ‡ A man whose state, or condition, is discommended. (JK, Ḳ, TA. [See also muxaX-anapN.]) And the fem., † A she-camel lean, or emaciated. (JK, Ḳ.) And sanapN xaXonaMCu † A year of drought or distress. (JK.)

A rájiz says,
mino yavoribiy-aAtK xuXoni
meaning [Of the fabric of Yethrib,] new [unfeathered arrows]. (Ṣ, TA.)

xaXonaMCu also signifies A certain green herb, or leguminous plant, (AḤn, JK, Ḳ,) having short leaves, (JK,) that spreads upon the ground, (AḤn,) rough to the feel, but soft in the mouth, viscous like purslane; (AḤn, Ḳ;) its blossom is yellow, and it is eaten [by men], and is like wise a pasture: (AḤn:) also called xuXayonaMCu↓. (TA.)

OuxayoXinu dim. of OaxoXanu as syn. with xaXinN. (TA.) OuxayoXinu fiI caAti Qll-ehi is a phrase occurring in a trad. [app. as meaning † Somewhat rough or coarse in clothing, or in mode of living, for the sake, or to obtain the approbation, of God]. (Ṣ, TA.) See also OaxoXanu.
muxaX-anapN A she-camel whose Tiroq [or condition in respect of fatness] is discommended. (JK, Ḳ. [See also OaxoXanu.])
1. xaXati Aln-axolapu, aor. taxoXuw, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. aXowN, (JK, TA,) The palm-tree bore dates such as are termed xaXow, i. e. HaXaf: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) so says El-Umawee, (Ṣ,) or IAạr. (TA.)
xaXFA Black wheat. (IAạr, Ḳ,* TA.)

xaXowN Dates such as are termed HaXaf: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) so says El-Umawee, (Ṣ,) or IAạr, who adds, i. e., of which the lower portion has become bad and rotten, while in its place: he says that it is of the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xaXiIa, aor. yaxoXaI, inf. n. xaXoyapN (JK, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xaXoIN (JK, M, Ḳ) and xiXoIN (Ṣgh, Ḳ) [the second and third erroneously written in the CK xaXFA and (by indication) xiXFA] and xaXaApN (M, Ḳ) and xaXoyaAnN, (JK, M, Ḳ,) though it has been said that the only instances of this kind are XanoMnN and lay-aAnN, [see the former of these two,] but in one copy of the M found written xiXoyaAnN, (TA,) and maxoXaApN (JK, M, Ḳ) and maxoXiyapN, (M, Ḳ,) He feared; syn. xaAfa: (JK, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib and others, he dreaded; or feared with reverence, veneration, respect, honour, or awe. (TA.) You say, xaXiyahu He feared him, or it; [or he dreaded him, or it; i. e. feared him, or it, with reverence,, &c.;] as also txX-Ahu↓. (Ḳ.) [And xaXiIa minohu, meaning the same: or He feared, or dreaded, what might happen to him from him, or it. And xaXiIa Ealayohi XayoYFA He feared, or dreaded, for him a thing.] And faEalotu celika xaXaApa Oano yakuwna kacaA [I did that in fear, or dread, that such a thing might happen]. (IAạr, TA.)

xaXayotuhu also signifies Hope. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And the saying of Ibn-ʼAbbás to ʼOmar, laqado Oakovarota mina Ald-uEaMCi biAlmawoti Hat-aI xaXiytu Oano yakuwna celika Oasohala laka Einoda nuzuwlihi, is explained as meaning [Verily thou hast prayed much for death, so that] I hope [that it may be easier to thee when it happens]. (TA.)

And sometimes xaXiytu means Ealimotu [I knew, or know]. (Mṣb.) So it is said to mean in the saying of the poet.
walaqado xaXiytu biOa mano tabiEa AlhudaI
skana AljinaAna maEa Aln-abiI-i muHam-adi
[And I know assuredly that he who follows the right direction shall dwell in the gardens of Paradise with the Prophet Moḥammad]: (Ṣ, TA:) or the meaning may be, I hope. (TA.)

In the saying in the Ḳur [xviii. 79], faxaXiynaA Oano yurohiqahumaA TugoyaAnFA wakuforFA, the meaning is said, by Akh, to be And we disapproved [that he should make excessive disobedience, and ingratitude, to come upon them twain]; (Ṣ;) and so says Zj, explaining it as the saying of El-Khidr: or, accord. to Fr, the meaning is, and we knew. (TA. [See also Oazohaqa.])
xaAXaAniI faxaXayotuhu: see 3.

entry.sense: 2. xX-Ahu, inf. n. taxoXiyapN, He frightened him, or made him to fear; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [or he made him to dread; or to fear with reverence,, &c.; (see 1;)] biAlOamori [with the thing, or event]. (TA.) One says, xaX-i cuWaAlapa biAlHibaAlapi, meaning [Frighten thou] the wolf [with the snare]. (Ṣ. [See art. cOl.]) And laqado kunotu wamaA OuxaX-aI biAlc-iYobi [Verily I used to be in a state when I was not frightened by the wolf]: a prov. (JK, TA.)
3. xaAXaAniI faxaXayotuhu↓, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. of the latter OaxoXiyhi, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ,) [I vied with him in fear or dread, and] I was more fearful [or dreading] than he. (A'Obeyed, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
xaAXaI fulaAnFA, (JK, TA,) inf. n. muxaAXaApN, (TA,) He left, forsook, relinquished, or abandoned, such a one, being left,, &c., by him. (JK, TA.)
xAXI bihimo He guarded himself against them in an extraordinary degree, and was cautious, or wary, (JK, TA,) and therefore turned away, or withdrew. (TA.)
5: see 1, second sentence.
xaXK: see what next follows.

xaXoyaAnu Fearful, or fearing; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) [or dreading; i. e. fearing with reverence,, &c.: (see 1:)] as also xaAXK↓ and xaXK↓: (Ḳ:) fem. xaXoyaA, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, [in the CK, erroneously, xaXoyaMCu,]) like gaDobaI fem, of gaDobaAnu, (Mṣb,) accord. to rule, (TA,)
and xaXoyaAnapN, mentioned by El-Marzooḳee, and thought by MF to be of the dial. of Asad; (TA;) or this signifies a wo man who fears, or dreads, (taxoXaI,) everything; (JK, TA;) so in the Tekmileh: (TA:) pl. xaXaAyaA, (Ḳ,) pluralized in a similar manner to epithets significant of diseases, like HayaATaI, &c., because AlxaXoyap is like a disease. (TA.)
xaXaMCN Land such as is termed jahaAdN [i. e. hard; or having no herbage; or hard, and having no herbage; or level; or rugged,, &c.]. (JK, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

xaXiI-N Dry; (Aṣ, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) like HaXiI-N; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) applied to herbage; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) or to herbs and trees: (JK:) or dry and rotten. (IAạr, TA.) A rájiz says, (Ṣ,) namely, Sakhr, (TA,)
sam-u caraAriyHa riTaAbK waxaXiIo
[Poison of moist cantharides, and dry]; (Ṣ, TA;) meaning waxaXiI-K, suppressing one of the two I s by poetic license. (IB, TA.)
xaAXK: see xaXoyaAnu.

OaxoXaI meaning More [and most] fearful, or feared, [or dreaded,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) is anomalous, (Ḳ,) being from the pass. [verb, like its syn. Oaxowafu]. (TA.) You say, hecaA AlmakaAnu OaxoXaI mino caAka This place is more fearful, or feared, [or dreaded,] than that. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
maxaAXK [pl. of maxoXaApN, originally maxoXayapN,] Causes of fear [or dread]; syn. maxaAwifu [pl. of maxaAfapN: like which, maxoXaApN is also an inf. n.]. (Ḥar p. 138.)

hom.sense:
1. xaS-ahu biAlX-aIoCi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or bikacaA, (A, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaxoSuSu}, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. xaS-N (Ḳ) and xuSuwSN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xaSuwSN (TA) and xaSuwSiy-apN and xuSuwSiy-apN, (Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) of which last two the former is the more chaste, (Ṣ, TA,) and is the form mentioned in the Fṣ and its Exposi tions, and the I in it is said to be the relative I, and the I which is characteristic of an inf. n., whereas in the latter it is said to be a characteristic of intensiveness, but MF thinks that this requires consideration, because the I is also said to be, and by some more commonly, without teshdeed, as in karaAhiyapN and EalaAniyapN, (TA,) and xiS-iySaI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like mik-iyvaI, which is said to be the only other instance of this measure, (TA,) [but some others might be added, as dil-iylaI and fix-iyraI and qit-iytaI,] and xiS-iySaMCu, (IAạr, Kr, Ḳ,) [like mik-iyvaMCu,] the former of which last two [each of which has an intensive signification] is the chaste, and com monly known, form, (TA,) and xuS-iy-apN, or xiS-iy-apN, or xaSiy-apN, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) written by Ṣgh with damm, (TA,) and taxiS-apN, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) or, as some say, xaSuwSiy-apN and xiS-iy-apN [or xuS-iy-apN or xaS-iy-apN] are each a quasi-inf. n., as also xaAS-apN, (TA,) He distinguished him particularly, peculiarly, or specially, i. e., above, or from, or exclusively of, others, by the thing, or by such a thing; he particularized him, or particularly or peculiarly or specially characterized him, thereby; syn. faD-alahu (A, Ḳ, TA) duwna gayorihi, and may-azahu; (TA;) he appropriated, or assigned, [the thing or] such a thing, or made it to belong, to him alone, or in particular, or peculiarly, or specially, exclusively of others; (Mṣb;) and AxtS-hu↓ bihi signifies the same; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AxS-hu↓, (A, [but for this I know not any other authority,]) and xS-Shu↓; (A;) or this last has an intensive signification. (Mṣb.) You say, xaS-ahu biAluwd-i He distinguished him, &c. by love, or affection; or favoured him in preference to another, or others, thereby. (Ḳ, TA.) As to the saying of AZ,
Uini QmoraON xaS-aniI EamodFA mawad-atahu
EalaI Alt-anaAniI laEinodiI gayoru makofuwri
[If a man distinguish me above, or from, or exclusively of, others, purposely, by his love, or because of his love of me, notwithstanding distance of each from the other, it will not be disacknowledged with me,] the meaning is, xaS-aniI bimawad-atihi; or it may be xaS-aniI limawad-atihi Uiy-aAIa [in the TA bimawad-atihi, which is evidently a mistranscription]; for, says ISd, we have not heard xaS-ahu [or rather xaS-a] doubly transitive. (TA.) And [hence] xaS-ahu bikacaA also signifies He gave him such a thing in large quantity, or abundantly. (TA.) [You say also, xaS-ahu biAlc-ikori He distinguished,, &c., or singled out, him, or it, by mention: or he particularized, peculiarized, or specified, him, or it, thereby; he particularly, peculiarly, or specially, mentioned him, or it. And xaS-ahu, alone, He pointed particularly, or peculiarly, to him, or it, in what he said; or he meant particularly, or peculiarly, him, or it. And xaS-a minohu kacaA He distinguished, particularized, peculiarized, or specified, thereof such a thing: and he distinguished therefrom such a thing; he particularly, peculiarly, or specially, excepted therefrom such a thing.] You also say, xaS-ahu linafosihi (TA) and AxtS-hu↓ linafosihi (T, A, TA) [He appropriated, or took, or chose, him, or it, particularly, or specially, to, or for, himself; as also xaS-a bihi nafosahu and AxtS-↓ bihi nafosahu]. And huwa yasotaxiS-u↓ fulaAnFA and yasotaxoliSuhu (A, TA) [He appropriates such a one purely to himself, exclusively of any partner; (see the latter verb;)] he chooses such a one for himself; he appropriates him to himself as his particular, or special, intimate; (TA in art. xlS;) both signify the same. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. xlS.) [And AxtS-hu↓ He treated him, or behaved towards him, with partiality; was partial towards him: a signification implied by the first explanation in this art.: and in this sense it is often used.]

xaS-a,, aor. _u {yaxoSuSu}, [contr. to general rule, by which it should be _i, for it is intrans., and of the measure faEala, accord. to the Mṣb,] inf. n. xuSuwSN, [and app. xaSuwSiy-apN and xuSuwSiy-apN, accord. to modern usage,] It was, or became, particular, peculiar, or special; restricted, or confined, to one or more of persons, places, or things; distinct, or distinguished, from others; not common, or general; contr. of Eam-a; as also AxtS-↓: (Mṣb:) [each, also, followed by lahu, signifies He, or it, belonged, pertained, or appertained, to him, or it, particularly, peculiarly, specially, or exclusively; it so related to him, or it; it was, or became, peculiar to him, or it: see also the latter verb below.]
xaS-a, sec. pers. xaSiSota, (in the CK xuSiSotu,) [inf. n., app., xaSaASapN and xaSaASN and xaSaASaMCu,] ‡ He was, or became, poor; in a state of poverty; (Fr, Ṣgh, Ḳ;) as also AxtS-↓. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. xS-Shu, inf. n. taxoSiySN, He made it, or rendered it, particular, peculiar, or special; distinct, or distinguished, from others; not common, or general; he individuated it; particularized it; distinguished it from the generality; singled it out; taxoSiySN being the contr. of taEomiymN. (Ḳ. [But only the inf. n. is there mentioned.])
See also 1, first sentence.
4: see 1, first sentence.
See also 8, in two places.
It is also said to mean † He was, or became, in a peculiar, unparticipated state of pressing want and poverty. (Ḥar p. 94.)

hom.sense: 8. AxtS-hu: see 1, in four places.
AxtS- as an intrans. v.: see 1, last sentence but one.

AxtS- biAlX-aIoCi, (Ḳ,) or bikacaA, (A, Mṣb,) quasi-pass. of xaS-ahu bihi; (A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He was, or became, distinguished particularly, peculiarly, or specially, i. e., above, or from, or exclusively of, others, by the thing, or by such a thing; he was, or became, particularized, or particularly or peculiarly or specially characterized, thereby; (A,* Ḳ * TA;) he had [the thing or] such a thing appropriated, or assigned, or made to belong, to him alone, or in particular, or peculiarly, or specially, exclusively of others; (Mṣb;) and txS-S↓ signifies the same. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, AxtS- fulaAnN biAlOamori, and txS-S↓ lahu, [or bihi, accord. to general usage,] Such a one was, or became, alone, with none to share or participate with him, in the affair; syn. Ainofarada. (TA.)
See also 1, last sentence.

entry.sense: 10: see 1, latter half.

xuS-N A booth of reeds, or canes, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or of [boughs of] trees: (TA:) or a house roofed with a piece of wood, in the form of the [oblong vaulted structure called] Oazoj: (JK, Ḳ:) so called because of the xaSaAS, or “narrow interstices,” which are in it; (T, TA;) or because one sees what is in it through its xaSaAS, or “interstices:” (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxoSaASN (JK, Mṣb, TA) and [of mult.] xiSaASN (JK, L, Ḳ [in the CK xaSaASN, which is wrong,]) and xuSuwSN (JK, Ḳ) and xuSuwSapN. (JK.)
Also The shop of a vintner, (Aṣ, Ḳ,) although it be not of reeds, or canes. (Ḳ.)
xaSaASN: see xaSaASapN, from the beginning to the last sentence but two.
xuSuwSN an inf. n. of 1, trans. and intrans.

[Used as a simple subst., Particularity; peculiarity; speciality, or specialty; as also the inf. ns. xaSuwSiy-apN↓, and xuSuwSiy-apN↓.] You say, lahu xuSuwSN and xuSuwSiy-apN↓ [To him belongs a particularity,, &c.], and biI [in me is, &c.]. (A.) [Hence xuSuwSFA Particularly; specially; as also xaAS-apF↓.] Th was heard to say, UicaA cukira AlS-aAliHuwna fabaxaAS-apK↓ Oabuw bakorK waUicaA cukira AlOaXoraAfu fabixaAS-apK EaliI-N [meaning faxuSuwSFA, i. e., When the righteous are mentioned, then in particular, or peculiarly, Aboo-Bekr is virtually mentioned; and when the shereefs are mentioned, then in particular, or peculiarly, ʼAlee]. (L, TA.)

hom.sense: xaSaASapN An interstice, interval, or intervening space or opening; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xaSaASN↓ [which is commonly used as a coll. gen. n.] and xaSaASaMCu↓: (Ḳ:) or an interstice,, &c., in the vagor [app. meaning the front teeth]; as also ↓the second of these words: (TA:) or the first and ↓second, (TA,) or ↓all, (Ḳ,) any interstice,, &c., or hole or perforation, in a door, and sieve, and [veil of the kind called] buroquE, and the like, (Ḳ, TA,) such as a cloud, and a strainer,, &c.: (TA:) [a crevice, cranny, chink, or fissure:] or the first, (TA,) or ↓all, (Ḳ,) a small hole or perforation: (Ḳ, TA:) or the first has this signification as well as the signification first mentioned: (Ṣ:) or ↓the second, the like of a kaw-ap [or mural aperture] in a [structure of the kind called] qub-ap, or the like, when as wide as the face; or, accord. to some, whether wide or narrow: (TA:) and the same, interstices, intervals, or intervening spaces or openings, in a xuS-; (TA;) or narrow interstices,, &c., therein: (T, TA:) and the same, (TA,) or ↓all, (Ḳ,) the intervening spaces between the three stones upon which a cooking-pot is placed; (Ḳ, TA;) and between the fingers: (TA:) and the first, the intervening spaces between the feathers of an arrow: (IAạr, TA:) pl. [of the first,] xaSaASaAtN. (TA.) You say of the moon, badaA mino xaSaASapi Algayomi [It appeared from the gap of the cloud, or clouds]. (Ṣ, A.)
Also A cloud itself; or clouds; syn. gayomN. (TA.)

Also the first, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and ↓second, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and ↓third, (IDrd, Ḳ,) ‡ Poverty; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) need; (A, Mṣb, TA;) straitness, or difficulty; (Mgh;) an evil state or condition: (TA:) from xaSaASaAt meaning the “holes” of a sieve: whence a saying cited voce tajam-ala: (Mgh:) or from the first of the senses explained in this paragraph; because a thing, when it opens so as to form an interstice, becomes weak and unsound. (TA.) You say also, sadadotu xuSaASapa↓ fulaAnK, with damm, meaning, ‡ I repaired the broken fortune of such a one. (A, TA.)
Also the first, ‡ Thirst; as in camels when they return from water without having satisfied themselves with drink: and hunger; as in a man when he has not satisfied himself with food. (TA.)

entry.sense: xuSaASapN: see xaSaASapN, last sentence but one.
xaSaASaMCu: see xaSaASapN, from the beginning to the last sentence but two.
xaSwuSiy-apN and xuSuwSiy-apN: see xuSuwSN, in three places.
xiS-aAnN and xuS-aAnN: see the next paragraph, in three places.
xaAS-N Particular; peculiar; special; distinct, or distinguished, from others; contr. of EaAm-N. (Mṣb, TA.)
[And hence, Choice; select.]
[And Pare; unmixed; unadulterated.]

[Used as a subst.,] it is syn. with xaAS-apN↓; (Ks, Mṣb, Ḳ;) in which the p is a corroborative; (Mṣb;) and which signifies Distinguished people; persons of distinction; the distinguished sort; contr. of EaAm-apN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the former is contr. of EaAm-N, and ↓the latter is contr. of EaAm-apN: (TA:) [the pl. of both is xawaAS-N and xiS-aAnN↓ and xuS-aAnN↓: or, accord. to rule, the first of these is pl. only of xaAS-apN; and judging from other instances, we should regard the second and third as more probably pls. of xaAS-N: but however the case may be,] xiS-aAnN is syn. with xawaAS-u, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and so is xuS-aAnN. (Ḳ.) [You say, AlxaAS-u waAlEaAm-u, and AlxaAS-apu↓ waAlEam-apu, The distinguished and the common people; the persons of distinction and the vulgar.] You also say, Uin-amaA yafoEalu hecaA xiS-aAnN↓ mina Aln-aAsi meaning xawaAS-u minohumo [Only distinguished persons of mankind do this]. (Ṣ.)

[It seems to be also, in some instances, syn. with xaAS-apN↓ as signifying A particular, peculiar, or special, friend, intimate, familiar, companion, associate, attendant, dependent, or servant:] the latter is explained in the T [and JK] as meaning a person whom thou hast appropriated, particularly distinguished, taken, or chosen, (AixotaSaSotahu,) [as a friend,, &c.,] to, or for, thyself: (TA:) [and it is used as a sing. and as a pl.: for] you say, hecaA xaAS-atiI [This is my particular, or special, or choice, or choicest, friend,, &c.]: and humo xaAS-atiI [They are my particular, or peculiar, or special, or choice, or choicest, friends,, &c.]. (A.) You say also, fulaAnN xaAS-N lifulaAnK, (Kull p. 174,) or bifulaAnK, (so in the L,) [app. meaning lifulaAnK, unless it be mistranscribed, and the latter be the correct reading, which I think much the more probable;] i. e., Such a one belongs exclusively [as a particular, or peculiar, or special, friend,, &c.,] to such a one; (Kull;) and muxaS-N↓ signifies the same. (L.)
See the dim. of xaAS-apN, (namely xuwayoS-apN,) below.
xaAS-apN: see xaAS-N, in four places.

It also signifies A property of a thing, not found, or not existing, either wholly or partly, in another thing: and xaAS-iy-apN↓ [thus correctly written, and thus I have always found it written except by Golius and those who have probably imitated him, who write it without the sheddeh to the I,] is used as denoting [a property, or particular or peculiar virtue, which is] an unknown cause of a known effect; as that by which a medicine operates: the former differs from the latter in being conventionally applied to an effect, [or effective property,] whether the cause of its existence be known or not: [the pl. of the former is xawaAS-u, agreeably with analogy and usage, like as EawaAm-u is pl. of EaAm-apN:] the pl. of the latter is xaAS-iy-aAtN [and xaSaAYiSu]; and xawaAS-u is a quasi-pl. n., not a pl., of the same. (Kull p. 174. [All the abovementioned words here cited from that work are there without syll. signs, as being well known. Both xAS-p and xAS-y-p↓, as here explained, are perhaps post-classical; but of this I am not certain: and both are sometimes used as meaning The peculiar nature of a thing; also termed its essence.])
xaAS-apF and bixaAS-apK: see xuSuwSN.
xaAS-iy-apN: see xaAS-apN, in two places.

xuwayoS-apN dim. of xaAS-apN; (A, Ḳ;) [like duwayob-apN, q. v., dim. of daAb-apN;] originally xuwayoSiSapN; (TA;) the I being quiescent because the I of the dim. cannot be movent; (A, Ḳ;) [properly signifying A little, or young, particular, or peculiar, or special, friend, companion, associate, attendant, or servant; and used in other senses, like other diminutives; implying littleness of estimation; and also affection, and awe.] It is said in a trad., (TA,) Ealayoka bixuwayoS-api nafosika [Keep thou to the little, or dear, particular friend of thine own self: so it seems to mean accord. to Z, being mentioned by him among the proper expressions belonging to this art.: but accord. to the TḲ, it appears to be tropical; for the meaning is there said to be, † thine own particular state, or condition]. (A, TA.) In another trad., xwyS-p is used as signifying A little, young, particular, or peculiar, or special, servant. (TA.) And in another trad. it is said, baAdiruwA biAlOaEomaAli sit-FA Ald-aj-aAli wakacaA wakacaA waxuwayoS-apa OaHadikumo, i. e. † Strive ye to be before six things with [good] works; Antichrist, and such and such things, and the event of death which is specially, or peculiarly, appointed to any one of you: [or, I would rather say, the awful special awaiter of any one of you; though it is asserted that] the diminutive form is here used to denote low estimation of that which it signifies in comparison with what follows it, namely, the resurrection, &c. (TA.)
muxaS-N: see xaAS-N, last sentence but one.
1. xaSiba and xaSaba: see 4.
[2. xS-b, inf. n. taxoSiybN, It rendered fruitful; it fecundated: so in the present day: see an instance voce baAqil-aI.]

hom.sense:
4. AxSb, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UixoSaAbN; (TA;) [and some add xiSobN, as another inf. n.; but ISd holds this to be a simple subst.; (see 4 in art. ryf;)] and xaSiba↓, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxoSabu}; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and xaSaba↓, aor. _i {yaxoSibu}, inf. n. xiSobN; (Ḳ;) It (a place) abounded, or became abundant, with herbage [or with the produce of the earth], and with the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; (A, Ḳ;) [was, or became, fruitful;] had increase; had plenty, or abundance; (Mṣb;) [contr. of Oajodaba and jadiba or jadaba and jaduba:]
and AxSbt AlOaroDu [the land, or earth, abounded, or became abundant, with herbage, &c.]. (JK, Ṣ.) UixoSaAbN and AixotiSaAbN↓ are both from AlxiSobu [but the precise meaning of the latter is not explained]. (Lth, JK, TA.) In the saying of the rájiz,
laqado xaXiytu Oano OaraI jadib-aA
fiI EaAminaA caA baEoda Oano OaxoSab-aA
[Verily I feared to see drought, or barrenness, or dearth, in this our year, after it had been abundant in herbage, &c.], OaxoSab-aA is put for OaxoSabaA: but accord. to one reading, it is AixoSab-aA↓, of the measure AifoEal-a, though this is generally employed for colours; and the incipient A is rendered disjunctive of necessity, for the sake of the metre. (L. [Respecting jidab-aA, see jadobN.]) You say also, AxSb janaAbu Alqawomi, meaning The tract surrounding the people [became abundant with herbage, &c.]. (Ṣ, TA.)

AxSbwA They attained, obtained, had, or became in the condition of having, abundance of herbage [or of the produce of the earth], and of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.) [They became in the condition of persons whose food and milk, and the pasture of whose land, were abundant. (See the part. n., muxoSibN, below.)] And AxSbt AlX-aApu The ewe, or she-goat, obtained abundance of herbage. (TA.)
AxSb Qll-ehu AlmawoDiEi God caused the place to produce herbs and pasture. (Mṣb.)
AxSbt AlEiDaAhu, mentioned as on the authority of Lth, [and in the Ḳ,] is, accord. to Az, a gross mistranscription, for AxSbt [q. v.]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 8: see 1.
9: see 1.
xaSobN: see xaSobapN, in two places.

hom.sense: xiSobN Abundance of herbage [or of the produce of the earth], and of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; (A, Ḳ;) contr. of jadobN; (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb;) [fruitfulness;] increase; plenty, or abundance; (Mṣb:) abundance of good, or of good things: (Ḳ:) [abundant herbage, and the like:] truffles are included in the term xiSobN; and also locusts, when they come after the herbage has dried up and the people are secure from being injured by them. (AḤn.)

baladN xiSobN and OaxoSaAbN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like baladN sabosabN and sabaAsibu, &c., the sing. being used [in bld AxSAb] as a pl., as though made to consist of parts, or portions, [each termed xiSobN,] (Ṣ, TA,) A country, or region, abounding with herbage [or with the produce of the earth], or with the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; [fruitful; or plentiful;] (Ṣ,* Ḳ;) as also muxoSibN↓ (Ṣ,* A, Mṣb,* Ḳ) and xaSiybN↓ (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ) and xaSibN↓. (A, Mṣb.*) And OaroDN xaSibN and xaSiybapN↓, (AḤn, TA,) and OaroDuwna xiSobN [because xiSobN is originally an inf. n.] and xiSobapN and xaSobapN↓, which last word is either an inf. n. used as an epithet, or a contraction of xaSibapN↓, (Ḳ,) A land, and lands, abounding with herbage, &c. (Ḳ, TA.)
