And EayoXN xiSobN and muxoSibN↓ [A life of abundance or plenty]. (TA.)

entry.sense: xaSobapN: see xiSobN.

Also, [app. as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] A palm-tree having much fruit: pl. xiSaAbN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xaSobN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) or xaSobN [is properly a coll. gen. n., and] signifies palm-trees [absolutely:] (Ḳ:) and xaSobapN signifies a palmtree of the kind called naxolapu Ald-aqali, in the dial. of the people of El-Bahreyn, (Az, TA,) or of Nejd; (TA;) and its pl. is xiSaAbN. (Az, TA.)

It is said that xaSobN↓ signifies also The spadix of the palm-tree: so in the Ḳ: and accord. to Lth, xaSobapN signifies a single spadix of a palm-tree: but [it is probably a mistranscription for xaDobapN, with the pointed D:] Az says that he who assigns to it this meaning errs. (TA.)

rajulN xaSiybN A man abounding with good, or with good things; (Ḳ;) i. e., whose abode abounds therewith; (TA;) as also xaSiybu Alr-aHoli (A, TA) and xaSiybu AljanaAbi: (TA:) or this last means one whose region, or quarter, is xaSiyb: (Ṣ:) or it is tropical, (A in art. jnb,) as is also the expression immediately preceding, (A in the present art.,) and means ‡ Generous or bountiful [or hospitable]. (A in art. jnb.)
[OaxoSabu More, and most, abundant with herbage, &c.]
muxoSibN: see xiSobN, in two places.
qawomN muxoSibuwna A people, or party, whose food and with, and the pasture of whose land, have become abundant. (TA.)
mxSbp [so in the TA, either maxoSabapN (like maboqalapN, &c.) or muxoSibapN,] A land (OaroDN) abounding with pasture or herbage. (TA.)
baladN mixoSaAbN (Ḳ) A country, or region, scarcely ever, or never, sterile, barren, unfruitful, or afflicted with dearth or scarcity or drought. (TA.)
And qawomN maxaASiybu [A people, or party, scarcely ever, or never, without abundance of herbage, &c.]. (TA in art. rtE.)

1. xaSra, (Ṣ, A,) aor. _a {yaxoSaru}, inf. n. xaSarN, (TḲ,) It (a day) was, or became, intensely cold. (Ṣ, A.) He (a man) suffered pain from the cold in his extremities. (Ṣ.) And xaSirato yadiI, (Ṣ, TA,) and OanaAmiliI, (TA,) My arm, or hand, and my fingers' ends, were pained by the cold. (Ṣ,* TA.)
2. taxoSiyrN [an inf. n. of which the verb, if it have one, is xuS-ira]: see muxaS-arN.
3. xASr AlmaroOapa, (A,) inf. n. muxaASarapN, (TA,) He laid hold upon the woman's xaASirap [or flank], (A,) or put his hand to her xaSor [or waist], (TA,) in compressing her. (A, TA.)

And xASrhu He took his hand in walking, or walked with him hand in hand, (Ṣ, A, IAth, Ḳ,) so that the hand of each was by the waist (xaSor) of the other: (IAth:) and, (so in the Ṣ, but in the Ḳ “or,”) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) he took a different way from his (another's) until he met him in a place: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) mxASrp as the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is syn. with muxaAzamapN: (Ṣ:) or xASrhu signifies he walked with him, and then parted from him, and so continued until he met him at a time, or place, at which they had not appointed to meet: (IAạr:) or he walked by his side. (Ḳ.)
4. AxSr It (cold) pained a man's arms, or hands, and his fingers' ends. (A,* TA.)

hom.sense: 5: see 8, in the first sentence:
and again {8}, in the last two sentences.

entry.sense: 6. txASr: see 8.
txASrwA They took one another by the hand in walking, or walked together hand in hand [so that the hand of each was by the waist (xaSor) of another: see 3]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

hom.sense: 8. AxtSr (A, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and txS-r↓, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or txASr↓, (A, L,) He put his hand upon his xaSor [or waist], (A, Mgh, L, Mṣb,) or upon his xaASirap [or flank], (Mgh, Ḳ,) in prayer. (Mgh, L, Mṣb.) The doing this in prayer [except in the night, when tired, (see AlmutaxaS-iruwna,)] is forbidden, or disapproved. (Mgh, TA.)
AxtSr AlT-ariyqa He went the nearest way. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

And hence, (Mṣb, TA,) AxtSr AlkalaAma ‡ He abridged the language, or the discourse; syn. Oawojazahu: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) [and in like manner, AlkitaAba the book, or writing:] or, accord. to some, the latter (Awjzhu) signifies “he expressed its correct meaning concisely, without regard to the original words;” and the former, he curtailed its words, preserving the meaning: (MF:) or properly, he abridged the expressions, making the words fewer, but preserving the entire meaning: (Mṣb:) or he abridged the language by omitting superfluities, and choosing from it concise expressions which conveyed the meaning. (L.) [You say, AxtSrhu EalaI Alr-uboEi † He reduced it by abridgment to the fourth of its original bulk.] And AxtSr Als-ajodapa † He recited the chapter in which a prostration should be performed, omitting the verse requiring prostration, in order that he might not prostrate himself: or he recited only the verse requiring a prostration, to prostrate himself in so doing: both which practices are forbidden. (T,* Mgh,* Mṣb,* Ḳ.) And the verb alone † He recited a verse, or two verses, of the last part of the chapter, in prayer; (Ḳ;) not the whole chapter. (TA.)
Also, the verb alone, He curtailed a thing of its superfluities, (Ḳ,) in a general sense. (TA.)

And AxtSr fiI Aljaz-i, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) in some copies of the Ḳ fiI AlHaz-i, with H, (TA,) or AxtSr Aljaz-a, (A,) He did not extirpate in cutting; did not cut off entirely, or utterly: (A, Ḳ:) or he extirpated in cutting; cut off utterly. (JK.)

AxtSr also signifies He took a mixoSarap [in his hand]: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) and txS-r↓ bihaA he took it in his hand; namely, a mxSrp: (Ḥar p. 122:)
or the former, he leaned upon it in walking: (TA:) or he took a mxSrp or a staff in his hand, to lean upon it. (Mgh.) You say also, AxtSr AlEanazapa [He took in his hand the Enzp: or he leaned upon the Enzp in walking]: it is a thing [i. e. a kind of staff, or short spear,] like the Euk-aAzap: and in like manner, txS-r↓; as in the L, &c.: (TA:) and AxtSr biAlEaSaA He leaned upon the staff in walking. (A.)

entry.sense: xaSorN The middle, or waist, of a man or woman: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e. the slender part above the hips or haunches: (Mṣb:) pl. xuSuwrN. (A, Ḳ.) See also AlxaASirapu, in two places.
‡ The hollow part of the sole of the foot, which does not touch the ground: (A, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)

‡ The narrow part of a sandal, before the OucunaAni [which are the two loops whereto is attached the strap that passes behind the wearer's heel]: (TA:) or xaSoraAni [the dual] signifies the narrow part of a sandal. (IAạr, TA.)
‡ The part which is between the base of the notch and the feathers of an arrow: (AḤn, A,* Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
‡ A way between the upper and lower parts of a heap of sand; (Ḳ, TA:) or ‡ the lower part of a heap of sand; the thin part thereof; as also muxaS-arN↓: (A, TA:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
† The place of the buyuwt [or tents] of the Arabs of the desert: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, of such bywt, a clean place: (TA:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
xaSarN Cold (Ṣ, Ḳ) which a man feels in his extremities. (TA.)
xaSirN, applied to a day, Painfully cold. (A, TA.)
Cold, as an epithet, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) applied to water, (Ṣ,) and to anything. (TA.)
A man feeling cold [especially in his extremities: see 1]: to signify cold and hungry, the epithet xariSN is used. (AʼObeyd.)
vagorN xaSirN [A mouth, or front teeth,] cold, or cool, in the place that is hissed. (A, TA. [See also muxaS-arN.])

xuSayoraI, (Ḳ, TA,) in some copies of the Ḳ xuSayoriI-N, (TA,) [but the former is shown to be the right reading by a verse cited in the TA,] The curtailment of the superfluities of a thing; like AixotiSaArN. (Ḳ,* TA.)

AlxaASirapu [The flank; i. e. each of the ilia;] i. q. AlX-aAkilapu; (Zj, in his “Khalk el-Insán;” Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. the TafoTafap [or quivering flesh] of the side, that reaches to the extremities of the ribs: (Zj, ibid.:) and [so in the Ḳ, but more properly “or,”] AlxaASirapu, (Ḳ,) or AlxaASiraAtaAni (JK, TA) and AlxaSoraAni↓, (TA,) what is between the Haroqafap [or crest of the hip] and the lowest rib; (JK, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. the part from which retires each of the lowest ribs, and in advance of which projects each of the HajabataAni: [explained by the words mA qlS Enh AlquSayorayaAni wtqd-m mn AlHjbtyn: but for mn AlHjbtyn, I read minohu AlHajabataAni; referring, for corroboration, to explanations of this last word; and therefore I have rendered the passage as above: the meaning seems evidently to be the part between the lowest rib and the crest of the hip, on each side:] the thin skin which is above the xaSor is called the TafoTafap: so in the M, agreeably with the saying of Ibn-El-Ajdábee, that AlxaSoru↓ and AlxaASirapu are syn.; i. e., in this sense: [this assertion, however, requires consideration; for all the explanations of AlxASrp are easily reconcileable:] pl. xawaASiru [which is also used in the sense of the sing. or dual]. (TA.) You say rajulN Daxomu AlxawASiri [A man large in the flank or flanks]: and Lḥ mentions the phrase Uin-ahaA lamunotafixapu AlxawaSiri [Verily she is inflated, or swollen, in the flank or flanks]; as though the term xASrp were applicable to every portion [of the flank]. (TA.)
Also A pain in the xaASirap [or flank]: or in the kidneys. (TA.)
And it is also said to signify A certain vein (Eiroq) in the kidney, which occasions pain to the person when it is in motion. (TA.)
xinoSirN: see art xnSr.

OaxoSaru [Shorter: and shortest]. You say, hecaA OaxoSaru mino caAka This [road] is shorter than that. (A.) But this is irregular; OaxoSaru being formed from AuxotuSira, a verb of more than three letters. (I’Aḳ p. 237.)

mixoSarapN A thing like a whip: and anything that a man takes (yaxotaSiru) with his hand, and holds, such as a staff and the like: (Ṣ:) a thing which a man takes in his hand, and upon which he leans, such as a staff and the like: (Ḳ,* TA:) a rod [or sceptre] which a king used to take in his hand, with which he made signs, or pointed, in holding a discourse, or addressing, (A, Ḳ,*) and accompanied what he said, (A,) and in like manner the xaTiyb in reciting a xuTobap: (Ḳ,* TA:) it was one of the insignia of kings: (TA:) a rod, or what is termed Eanazap, or the like, with which the xaTiyb makes signs, or points, in addressing the people: (Mṣb:) a thing which a man holds in his hand, such as any of the things termed EaSFA and miqoraEapN and EanazapN and Euk-aAzapN and qaDiybN, or the like; and upon which he sometimes leans: (AʼObeyd:) pl. maxaASiru. (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: muxaS-arN, applied to a man, (TA,) Slender (Ḳ, TA) in the waist: (TA:) lean, or lank in the belly: (Ḳ:) or, in the xaASirap [or flank]: (TA:) and maxoSuwrN↓ AlbaToni is also applied to a man [as meaning lank in the belly]. (A, TA.)
kaXoHN muxaS-arN A thin [flank or rather waist: see a verse of Imra-el-Ḳeys cited voce mucal-alN]. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

qadamN muxaS-arapN (JK, A, TA) and maxoSuwrapN↓ (JK, TA) ‡ [A foot that touches the ground with its fore part and heel; the middle of the sole being hollow and narrow: this meaning, or a meaning similar to that of yadN muxaS-arapN explained below, seems to be indicated in the TA: the latter is the meaning accord. to the JK; but this I think doubtful, on account of what here follows]. muxaS-aru Alqadamayoni means ‡ A man whose feet touch the ground with the fore part and the heel; the middle of the sole being hollow and narrow: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and you say also maxoSuwru↓ Alqadamayoni. (A, TA.)

yadN muxaS-arapN, or maxoSuwrapN↓, (as in different copies of the Ḳ,) or both, (TA,) ‡ An arm, or a hand, in the wrist of which is what is termed taxoSiyrN↓, as though it were bound: or which has an encircling groove-like depression. (Ḳ, TA.)
naEolN muxaS-arapN ‡ A sandal narrow in the middle. (Ṣ,* A,* Ḳ, TA.)
See also xaSorN.
vagorN baAridu AlmuxaS-ari [A mouth, or front teeth,] cold, or cool, in the place that is kissed. (TA. [See also xaSirN.])

entry.sense: maxoSuwrN A man having a complaint of, or a pain in, his xaSor [or waist], or his xaASirap [or flank]. (TA.)
See also the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

hom.sense: maxaASiru pl. of mixoSarapN. (Ṣ, TA.)

maxaASiru AlT-ariyqi The nearest roads or ways; (Ḳ;) as also AlmuxotaSaraAtu↓: (TA:) or muxotaSaraAtu AlT-uruqi signifies The roads, or ways, that are near, notwithstanding their ruggedness, but not so easy as those that are longer. (L.)

entry.sense: AlmuxotaSaraAtu, or muxotaSaraAtu AlT-uruqi: see the paragraph next preceding.

AlmutaxaS-iruwna, (Ḳ,) or AlmutaxaS-iruwna fiI AlS-alaApi, (Mgh,) Those who, in praying in the night, becoming tired thereby, put their hands upon their xawaASir [or flanks]: of such it is said (in a trad., IAth, Ḳ) that light shall be [seen] on their faces (IAth, Mgh, Ḳ) on the day of resurrection: (IAth, Ḳ:) [in other cases, this action is forbidden, or disapproved: see 8:] or, in the instance mentioned above, it may mean those who shall rest upon their righteous works on the day of resurrection: (IAth, Mgh, TA:) this latter is apparently the right meaning: otherwise, two trads. contradict each other. (MF.)

hom.sense: 1. xaSofN [inf. n. of xaSafa] signifies The act of adjoining, and putting together. (TA.)

Hence, (TA,) xaSafa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) aor. _i {yaxoSifu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaSofN, (Mṣb,) He sewed a sole (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) [so as to make it double], covering, or facing, one piece with another: (TA:) or he patched a sole; mended it by sewing on another piece. (Mṣb.) And He made anything double, putting one piece upon another; he faced it. (TA.)

And [hence,] xaSafa EalaI nafosihi, (JK,) or xaSafa Alwaraqa EalaI badanihi, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ṣ, TA,) and so the inf. n.; (TA;) and AxtSf↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and AxSf↓; (Ḳ;) and xS-f↓, inf. n. taxoSiyfN; (TA;) ‡ He stuck [or sewed] the leaves together, one to another, (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) and covered his person with them, leaf by leaf, (Ḳ,) to conceal therewith his pudenda: (Ṣ, TA:) or the first phrase, (JK,) as also AxtSf↓, (Lth, JK,) signifies he (a naked man) put upon his pudenda wide leaves, (Lth, JK,) or the like: (Lth:) you say, AxtSf↓ bikacaA [he covered his pudenda with such a thing]. (Lth, JK.)
It is said in the Ḳur [vii. 21 and xx. 119], waTafiqaA yaxoSifaAni EalayohimaA mino waraqi Aljan-api; and yaxiS-ifaAni↓, originally yaxotaSifaAni, by some pronounced yaxaS-ifaAni↓, (Ṣ, TA,) and by some, yaxoS-ifaAni↓, with two quiescent letters together; (TA; [but this appears to be incorrect; see 8 in art. xSm;]) and yuxoSifaAni↓, from OaxoSafa; and yuxaS-ifaAni↓, from xaS-afa; (Ksh and Bḍ in vii. 21, and TA;) thus accord. to different readings; i. e. ‡ And they betook themselves to sticking [or sewing] together, one to another, of the leaves of Paradise, to conceal therewith their pudenda. (Ṣ, TA.) And hence, also, the saying, in a trad., UicaA daxala OaHadukumu AlHam-aAma faEalayohi biAln-aXiyriwalaA yuxaS-ifo↓, i. e. ‡ [When any one of you enters the bath,] let him take the waist-wrapper, and not put his hand upon his pudendum: and like this in meaning is txS-fh [app. a mistranscription for yataxaS-afu↓, or yaxiS-ifu↓ or the like, for yaxotaSifu: if not, it must be taxaS-afahu↓, meaning he put his hand upon it]. (TA.)

[Hence also the saying,] famaA zaAluwA yaxoSifuwna OaxofaAfa AlmaTiI-i biHawaAfiri Alxayoli Hat-aI liHiquwhumo ‡ And they ceased not to make the prints of the feet of the camels to be covered by the prints of the hoofs of the horses [until they overtook them]; as though they sewed these upon the others, like as one sews a sole by covering, or facing, one piece with another. (TA.)
And xuSifati Alkatiybapu mino waraAYihaA bixayolK, i. e. † [The body of troops] was followed [by horsemen]. (Ṣ.)
And xaSafa, aor. _i {yaxoSifu}, inf. n. xaSofN, † He lied. (Munjid of Kr. [See xaS-aAfN.])
And xaSafotu fulaAnFA ‡ I exceeded such a one in reviling [as though adding reviling upon reviling]. (TA.)

xaSafato, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoSifu}, (AZ, Ṣ,) inf. n. xiSaAfN, said of a she-camel, She cast her young one in the ninth month: (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) the epithet applied to her in this case is xaSuwfN↓: (AZ, Ṣ:) or, as some say, (Ṣ,) this epithet signifies one that brings forth a year and a month, (Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ a year and two months, which is wrong, (TA,) after the time when she was covered: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) jaruwrN is applied to one that brings forth a year and two months after that time: (Ṣ, TA:) or ↓the former epithet signifies one that brings forth on the completion of the year: (IAạr, TA:) or one of the camels termed maraAbiyE [pl. of mirobaAEN q. v.] that brings forth at the completion of the year; or one of such camels that brings forth when she comes to the time of the year in which she was covered, completely: (TA:) and AxtSft↓ signifies she (a camel) became such as is termed xaSuwf. (JK, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in three places.

[From the primary signification of the verb is derived the phrase,] xaS-afahu AlX-ayobu, inf. n. taxoSiyfN, ‡ Hoariness rendered his hair white and black in equal proportions; (IAạr,* Ḳ,* TA;) syn. with xaw-aSahu, inf. n. taxowiySN; and vaq-aba fiyhi, inf. n. tavoquybN. (IAạr.) And xaS-afa AlX-ayobu lim-atahu ‡ Hoariness rendered xaSiyf↓ [i. e. white and black] his lm-p [or hair hanging down below his ears]. (A, TA.)
4: see 1, in two places.
5: see 1, in two places.

hom.sense: 8. AxtSf, and three variations of the aor.: see 1, in seven places:
and AxtSf said of a she-camel: see 1, last sentence.

entry.sense: xaSofN A sole having another sole sewed upon it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so naEolN xaSiyfN↓, (Ṣ,* TA,) i. q. maxoSuwfapN↓. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: xaSafN † A mixed colour, black and white. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)
See also xaSafapN, in two places.
Also a dial. var. of xazafN [q. v.]. (Lth, TA.)

entry.sense: xaSofapN Any sole, or matching piece, that is sewed upon a sole [so as to make it double]; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xaSiyfapN↓. (Ṣ;* and Ḳ voce TiraAqN.)
xuSofapN A puncture, or stitch-hole, in a skin; syn. xurozapN. (Ḳ.)
And [hence,] † The anus, or orifice of the rectum: and † the orifice of the vagina. (TA voce xurobapN.)

xaSafapN A receptacle for dates, such as is termed jul-ap, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) made of palm-leaves; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) wherein they are stored: of the dial. of El-Bahreyn: (TA:) and a mat upon which OaqiT &c. are put to dry: (TA in art. Xr:) and [it is said to signify] a very thick kind of cloth: (Lth, Ḳ:) pl. xaSafN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [the pl. properly speaking is] xiSaAfN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) Lth says that a certain Tubba' [a king of El-Yemen] clothed the House [i. e. the Kaabeh] with xaSaf↓, meaning very thick cloths; so called as being likened to the xaSaf of woven palm-leaves: but Az says that this is wrong; and that it means pieces of matting made of palm-leaves woven together, oblong pieces of which were used as coverings for the tents of the Arabs of the desert, and sometimes made into jilaAl [pl. of jul-apN] for dates: (TA:) xuS-aAfN↓, also, signifies a piece of matting of palm-leaves; and its pl. is xaSaASiyfu. (JK.)
xaSuwfN: see 1, last sentence, in two places. Applied to a woman, One who brings forth in the ninth [month], not entering upon the tenth. (TA.)
xaSiyfN: see xaSofN.

† A thing in which are united any two colours. (Ṣ, TA.) See also 2. And see OaxoSafu in two places. [Hence,] † Ashes; (Ḳ;) because there are two colours therein, blackness and whiteness: but one says more commonly ramaAdN xaSiyfN, using the latter word as an epithet. (TA.) And katiybapN xaSiyfN, (Ṣ,) or ktybp xaSiyfapN, (Ḳ,) † [A body of troops] having two colours, (Ḳ,) having the colour of iron (Ṣ, Ḳ) and another colour: (Ḳ:) or so called because of the rust of the iron, &c.: (L:) or the former phrase means, as some say, followed by horsemen; and therefore the epithet is without p, because it has the signification of a pass. part. n.: for were it to denote the colour of the iron, they had said xaSiyfapN, because it would in this latter case have the signification of an act. part. n. (Ṣ.)
Also † Fresh milk upon which is poured raAYib [i.e. curdled, or thick, or churned, milk]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) if dates and clarified butter are put into it, it is [termed] EawobavaAniI-N. (Ṣ.)
xaSiyfapN [fem. of xaSiyfN, q. v.]
[And also a simple subst.]: see xaSofapN.
xaS-aAfN One who sews soles [so as to make them double, covering, or facing, one piece with another: see 1]: (Kr, Ḳ:) or one who patches soles; who mends them by sewing on other pieces. (Mṣb.)
‡ One who covers his pudendum with his hand: on the authority of Seer. (TA. [See 1.])
‡ A liar: (Kr, Ḳ, TA:) as though he sewed one saying upon another, and [thus] embellished it. (TA.)
xiS-aAfN: see xaSafapN.

OaxoSafu † Of a colour like that of ashes, in which are blackness and whiteness; (JK, Ṣ;) as also xaSiyfN↓. (JK.) In this sense, (TA,) applied to a mountain, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also xaSiyfN↓, (TA,) and to a male ostrich, meaning † In which are blackness and whiteness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) fem. xaSofaMCu. (TA.) † A rope, or cord, of two colours, having one strand black and another strand white. (JK.) † A horse, and a sheep, white in the flanks; (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the rest being of any colour: and sometimes in one side: (TA:) or whose balaq [or blackness and whiteness] extends from his belly to his sides: (Ṣ, TA:) or a horse white in the side. (Mgh.)
mixoSabN The awl; or instrument for boring, or perforating; (JK, TA;) use in the sewing of soles [and the like;] (JK;) i. q. UiXofFI [q. v.]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) [pl. maxaASifu.]
maxoSuwfapN, applied to a sole: see xaSofN.
Applied to a ewe or she-goat, † Smooth: or of two colours, black and white: (Ḳ, TA:) so in the O. (TA.)
1. xaSala, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaSolN, (TA,) He cut, or cut off, a thing; (Ḳ;) as also qaSala. (TA.) [Accord. to the TA, this is the proper, or primary signification.]
xaSalahumo, [aor., accord. to rule, _u,] inf. n. xaSolN and xiSaAlN, He overcame them, or surpassed them, in shooting. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [In the CK, faDalahumo is erroneously put for naDlahumo.]) See also 3.
2. xS-lhu, inf. n. taxoSiylN, He cut it, or divided it, in pieces. (M, Ḳ.)

xS-l AlXajara, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He lopped the branches of the trees: (Ḳ, TA:) or taxoSiylN signifies the cutting off slender extremities and branches from the [species of mimosa called] EurofuT, in the interior parts thereof. (JK.)
xS-l AlbaEiyra He cut off, for the camel, the xuSolap, (Ḳ,) i. e. the soft and tender branch of a tree. (TA.)
3. xaASalotuhumo faxaSalotuhumo↓, inf. n. of the former muxaASalapN, I vied, competed, or contended for superiority, with them in shooting, and I overcame them, or surpassed them, therein. (TA.)
4. AxSl He (a shooter) hit the target: (Ḳ, TA:) or made his arrow to fall close by the side of the target. (JK, Ḳ.)
6. txASlwA They vied, competed, or contended for superiority, in shooting: (Az, TA:) or they contended together for stakes, or wagers, laid by them to be taken by the winner in shooting. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

xaSolN A stake, or wager, laid in a shootingmatch. (Ṣ, TA.) One says, OaHozara xaSolahu and OaSaAba xaSolahu [He won his stake, or wager;] he overcame (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) in the case of laying stakes or wagers [in a shooting-match]. (TA.)
And A thing for which persons contend together in a game of hazard. (Ḥar p. 640.)
See also xaSolapN, in two places.
xaSilN [One who overcomes much, or often, in shooting-matches: occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees: expl. by Freytag as meaning multum vincens in ludo alearum].

hom.sense: xaSolapN i. q. xal-apN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) i. e. A property, quality, nature, or disposition: and a habit, or custom: (KL, PṢ, TḲ:) [and a practice, or an action: it is used in these various senses in different trads.: in one trad., avarice is termed a xaSolap; and so is evilness of nature: in another, fasting, and praying: in another, the inflicting of castigation, and the executing of retaliation, in a mosque:] it signifies an excellent quality or the like; and a low, base, or mean, quality or the like; (Ḳ, TA;) in a man: (TA:) or its predominant application is to an excellent quality or the like: (Ḳ:) so in the M: (TA:) [it is said that] it is used only in commendation; whereas xal-apN is used in relation to good and evil: (Ḥam p. 525:) [but this is a mistake, as I have shown above:] accord. to Az, it signifies the states, or conditions, of things or affairs: (TA:) [or this is a signification of the pl.:] the pl. is xiSaAlN (Ḳ) and xaSalaAtN; (TA;) [and xaSaAYilu↓ is a pl. pl., i. e. pl. of xiSaAlN, with which it is explained in the KL as syn.: see an ex. in a verse cited voce dafiYN.]

A hitting of the target; (Ḳ;) in shooting: (TA:) or, (Ḳ,) as also xaSolN↓, (JK, Ḳ,) in a shooting-match, (JK,) it is [a shot] in the case in which the arrow goes close by the target: (JK, Ḳ:*) thus accord. to Lth, who says that the former explanation is erroneous; (TA;) [as appears also from the assertion that] what are termed xaSolataAni, in a shooting-match, are reckoned as equivalent to a shot that goes right to the target. (T, Ḳ, TA.)
And accord. to Ṣgh, A single act of overcoming in a shooting-match. (TA.)
Also, and xuSolapN↓, A raceme, or bunch, of grapes or the like; syn. EunoquwdN. (Ḳ.)
And (both words) A stick, branch, or twig, (EuwdN,) in which are thorns. (Ḳ.)

And xaSolapN and xaSalapN↓, or this latter only, The extremity of a fresh, pliant, soft, or tender, twig, or rod: (Ḳ,* TA:) and (some say, TA) a soft and tender twig or rod, of the [species of mimosa called] EurofuT: (Ḳ, TA:) and xaSolN↓ [of which xaSolapN is the n. un.] signifies the slender extremities and branches of the EurofuT: (JK:) and xuSolapN↓, a soft and tender branch of any tree: (T, TA:) and [its pl.] xuSalN, the pendent extremities of trees. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: See also xaSolapN, in two places.
Also A portion of flesh forming a distinct limb or member or organ (EuDowN mina All-aHomi). (Ḳ.)
xaSalapN: see xaSolapN.

hom.sense: xaSiylN: see xaSiylapN, in two places.
Also Overcome [in a shooting-match, or] in a contest for stakes or wagers. (JK, Ḳ.)
And A tail; (Ḳ, TA;) as, for instance, of a [wild] bull. (TA.)

entry.sense: xuSaAlapN a dial. var. of HuSaAlapN, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) meaning The remains of wheat in the sieve, after the sifting, with what are mixed therewith: but the latter word is the more known. (JK, TA.)

hom.sense: xaSiylapN A piece, or portion, of flesh, (M, Ḳ,) small or large: (M, TA:) or the flesh of the thighs and of the upper arms and of the fore arms: (Ḳ:) or any portion of flesh, by itself, of the flesh of the thighs and of the upper arms (JK, T, Ṣ, TA) and of the shanks and of the fore arms: (JK, T, TA:) or the portion of flesh of the thigh: (TA:) or any compact and long portion of flesh, in the arm or elsewhere; also called xabiybapN: (AO, TA in art. xb:) or (Ḳ, TA, but in the CK “and”) [any muscle, of those that are termed voluntary muscles; as also EaDalapN and EaDiylapN; i. e.] any tendon, or sinew, upon which is thick flesh: (Ḳ:) or any portion of flesh that is oblong, and intermixed with tendons, or sinews: (O, TA:) or, as some say, the TafoTafap [or flank,, &c.]: (TA:) pl. xSiylu↓ [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.] and [the pl. is] xaSaAYilu. (Ḳ.) A certain person has described a horse as being saboTu AlxaSiyli↓ [app. meaning Lank in the muscles; or long and even therein]: and sometimes xaSaAYil is used in relation to a man. (TA.)
See also xuSolapN.
And for the pl. xaSaAYilu see also xaSolapN.

entry.sense: mixoSalN A very sharp sword (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ), &c.: (M:) a dial. var. of miqoSalN. (Ṣ.) mixoDalN is said by AʼObeyd to be a mistranscription for mixoSalN; but AḤei and others authorise it. (TA.)
mixoSaAlN A minojal [or reaping-hook]: (Ḳ:) or an instrument with which the branches of trees are lopped, (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA,) like the faOos. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)
1. xaSima, aor. _a {yaxoSamu}, [inf. n., app., xaSamN,] He contended in an altercation, disputed, or litigated, in a valid, or sound, manner. (Mṣb.)
See also 3:
and 8.

hom.sense: 3. xASmhu, inf. n. muxaASamapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xiSaAmN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and [quasi-inf. n.] xuSuwmapN, (Ḳ,) the last said in the Ṣ to be a simple subst., (TA,) He contended with him in an altercation, disputed with him, or litigated with him; (Ḳ, TA;) i. q. naAzaEahu: (Mgh and Mṣb and Ḳ in art. nzE:) accord. to El-Harállee, AlxiSaAmu signifies the saying which the listener is made to hear, and which is made to enter his ear-hole, such as may cause him to refrain, or desist, from his assertion, and his plea, or claim. (TA.) You say, xaASamotuhu faxaSamotuhu↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) aor. of the latter OaxoSimuhu, with kesr, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or OaxoSumuhu, with damm, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or not with damm, (Ṣ,) or both these forms of the aor. are used, accord. to AḤei; the latter agreeable with analogy; (MF;) the former anomalous; for the regular aor. of an unaugmented sound verb in a case of this kind is with damm, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as in the instance of EaAlamotuhu faEalamotuhu, aor. OaEolumuhu; (Ṣ;) if it has not a faucial letter (Ṣ, Ḳ) for its medial radical, (Ḳ,) in which case it is with fet-ḥ, as in the instance of faAxarotuhu fafaxarotuhu, aor. Oafoxaruhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) accord. to the opinion of Ks, but this is contr. to the opinion generally held: (MF:) the inf. n. of xaSamotuhu is xaSomN: (Ṣ,* TA:) and the meaning is, [I contended with him in an altercation, or I disputed, or litigated, with him, and] I overcame him in the altercation,, &c. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
xASmhu also signifies He put it in, or by, the xuSom, i. e. edge, or side, of the bed. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AxSmhu He dictated to him his plea against his adversary in an altercation or a dispute or litigation, (JK, TA,) whereby he might overcome the latter. (JK.)
6: see the next paragraph {8}, in two places.

hom.sense: 8. AxtSmwA They contended in altercation, disputed, or litigated, one with another; (Mṣb, TA;) i. q. txASmwA↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) both signifying as above. (TA.) He who reads yaxaS-imuwna [in the Ḳur xxxvi. 49] means yaxotaSimuwna; changing the t into S, and incorporating [it into the other S], and transferring its vowel to the x: some read yaxiS-imuwna, without transferring that vowel; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because a quiescent letter, when it is made movent, is [regularly] made so with kesr: (Ṣ:) AA slurred the vowel of the x: the pronunciation [yaxoS-imuwna] with two quiescent letters together is incorrect: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) Hamzeh read yaxoSimuwna↓, (Ṣ,) i. e., with the x quiescent and with kesr to the S. (TA.)

AixotaSamaA Uilayohi They two applied to him for the decision of a cause, each of them claiming the right. (TA in art. qmT.) And tuxuwSima↓ Uilayohi [An application was made to him by litigants for the decision of a cause]. (Mgh in art. dlw.)
Als-ayofu yaxotaSimu jafonahu, said by J to signify The sword cuts (lit. eats) its scabbard, by reason of its sharpness, is a mistake; the verb being correctly with D, (Ḳ,* TA,) dotted. (TA.)

entry.sense:
xaSomN An adversary in contention or altercation, in dispute, or in litigation; an antagonist; a litigant: (JK, Ḳ, TA:) as also xaSiymN↓: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:)
the former is used alike as masc. and fem. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and sing. (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dual (Mṣb, Ḳ) and pl.; (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because it is originally an inf. n.: (Ṣ, TA:) [see an ex. of its use in a pl. sense in a verse cited voce janafN:] but it also has the dual form, xaSomaAni; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and the pl. xuSuwmN (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xiSaAmN (Mṣb) and perhaps OaxoSaAmN, [which is a pl. of pauc.,] or this may be pl. of xaSimN: (TA:) the pl. of xaSiymN↓ is xuSamaMCu (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and xuSomaAnN. (Ḳ.)

xuSomN The side (Ṣ, Ḳ) of anything; (Ṣ, TA;) as, for instance, of a load such as is called Eidol; (Ṣ;) and of a bed; and the edge thereof: (TA:) written by Aboo-Moosà with D; but IAth says that it is correctly with S: (TA in art. xDm:) a lateral part or portion (Ṣ, Ḳ) of anything: (Ṣ:) a corner, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as well as a side, (Ṣ,) of an Eidol, and of a receptacle, such as a xuroj or a juwaAliq or an Eayobap: (Ṣ:) and the [anterior lower] extremity of a [water-bag of the kind termed] raAwiyap, that is opposite to the EazolaMC; (JK, Ḳ, TA; [in the CK, Alz-Awiyapi and AlgazolACi are erroneously put for Alr-aAwiyapi and AlEazolaMCi;]) the upper extremity [correctly extremities, at which are the loops whereby it is suspended upon the side of the camel,] being called the ESm [i. e. EuSom, pl. of EiSaAmN]: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxoSaAmN and [of mult.] xuSuwmN: (Ḳ:) but some say that the OaxoSaAm of the [water-bag termed] mazaAdap, and its xuSuwm, are its corners: the xuSuwm of a cloud are its sides: (TA:) and OaxoSaAmu AlEayoni signifies the part, or parts, of the eye upon which the edges of the lids close together. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

[Also A gap, or an intervening space: it is said in the TA that] AlOaxoSaAmu [pl. of AlxuSomu] signifies Alfrj [i. e. Alfuraju, pl. of Alfurojapu: and it is added,] one says, of an unsound, a corrupt, or a disordered, affair, laA yus-adu minohu xuSomN Uil-aA QnofataHa xuSomN Mxaru ‡ [A gap of it will not be stopped up but another gap will open]; occurring in a trad., meaning, the state of affairs is disordered and distressing, and not to be rectified and repaired. (TA.)
[The pl.] xuSuwmN also signifies The mouths of valleys. (JK, Ḳ.)
And The lower parts, or stocks, syn. OuSuwlN, (JK, Ḳ,) of [trees of the kind called] saraHaAt [pl. of saroHapN]; used in this sense by Et-Tirimmáh. (JK.)

xaSimN Vehement in altercation or dispute or litigation; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) as also xaSuwmN↓: (Ḥam p. 628:) [or each signifies contentious, disputatious, or litigious:] or the former, knowing, or skilled, in altercation, &c., though not practising it: (IB, TA:) or valid, or sound, therein; as also xaSiymN↓: (Mṣb:) or this last signifies one who contends with another in an altercation, disputes with him, or litigates with him: (IB, TA:) the pl. of the first is xaSimuwna, (Ḳ,) occurring in the Ḳur xliii. 58; and perhaps OaxoSaAmN, or this may be a pl. of xaSomN. (TA.)

xaSomapN A certain bead, or gem, or the like, used by men [as an amulet], in the Ḳ, mino Huruwzi Alr-ijaAli, but correctly, as in the M, mino xazari Alr-ijaAli, (TA,) worn on the occasion of contending in an altercation, or disputing, or litigating, or on going into the presence of the Sultán; (Ḳ, TA;) and sometimes it is beneath the gem of the man's signetring, when it is small; and it may be in his button; and sometimes they put it in the cuWaAbap [or cord by which the hilt is occasionally attached to the guard] of the sword: (TA:) also called xaDomapN. (Ḳ and TA in art. xDm.)
xuSomapN: see xuSuwmapN.
xuSomaAniy-apN: see xuSuwmapN.
xaSuwmN: see xaSimN.

xuSuwmapN Contention or altercation; disputation; litigation; (Ḳ, TA;) a subst. from 3 (Ṣ, TA) or 8 (JK,* TA) and 6, as also xuSomapN↓ and xuSomaAniy-apN↓. (TA.) faSolu AlxuSuwmapi: see art. fSl. [See also an ex. voce HukomN.]

OuxoSuwmN The loop of the [sack called] juwaAliq, (JK, TA,) and of the [load called] Eidol; (TA;) i. q. OuxosuwmN; (Ḳ;) but the latter is a dial. var. of weak authority, and disapproved. (TA in art. xsm.)
xuSowapN a dial. var. of xuSoyapN, q. v. (Sh, TA.)

1. xaSaAhu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaxoSiyhi, (JK, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. xiSaMCN (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xaSaMCN, mentioned, by MF, from Expositions of the Fṣ, (TA,) and xaSoIN, agreeably with analogy, occurs in a trad. of Esh-Shaabee, though we have not heard it, (Mgh,) He drew forth, or extracted, his testicles; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [he gelded, or castrated, him;] namely, a stallion, (Ṣ,) a sheep or goat, or a horse or similar beast, (Lth, JK, TA,) and a man or boy, (TA,) or a slave. (Mṣb.) One says, bariYotu Uilayoka mina AlxiSaMCi [I am irresponsible to thee for castration]. (Ṣ.)
[Hence,] kaAna jawaAdFA faxuSiIa [lit. He was a fleet and excellent horse, and he was gelded]; meaning ‡ he was rich, and he became poor. (TA.)

The poets term satire, and the act of overcoming, xiSaMC: one of them says,
xaSayotuka yaA Qbona Hamozapa biAlqawaAfiI
kamaA yuxoSaI mina AlHalaqi AlHimaAru
[‡ I have emasculated thee, O son of Hamzeh, with rhymes, like as the he-ass is emasculated in consequence of the disease termed Halaq; for which, it is asserted, (as is said in the TA, art. Hlq,) there is no remedy but gelding]. (IB, TA.)
4. AxSI [as though meaning † He did away with that which rendered him like one emasculated; the A, app., having a privative property;] ‡ he learned one science. (Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA.)
The use of UixoSaMCN [its inf. n.] in the sense of xiSaMCN inf. n. of xaSaI is a mistake. (Mgh.)
8. AxtSI He castrated himself; or made himself a eunuch. (KL.)
xaSK Having a complaint of his xuSaI [or testicles]. (Ḳ.)
xiSoIN: see what next follows.

xuSoyapN A testicle; (El-Umawee, Ṣ;) sing. of xuSFI; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) it is [one] of the organs of generation; (Ḳ;) well known; (Mṣb;) and xiSoyapN↓ signifies the same, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and so does xuSoIN↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and xiSoIN↓; (Ḳ;) and xuSowapN is a dial. var., occurring in a trad., but is extr.: (Sh, TA:) accord. to some, (Mṣb,) the sing. is xuSoyapN [alone], (T, Mṣb,) of the fem. gender; (T, TA;) and the dual is xuSoyaAni↓, (El-Umawee, T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the masc. gender, (T, TA,) without t, (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) irreg., (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Mṣb,) like OaloyaAni dual of OaloyapN, (El-Umawee, Ṣ,) and xuSoyataAni also, (T, Mgh, Ḳ,) this latter being sometimes used, (T, Mgh,) though rarely, (MF on the authority of the Expositions of the Fṣ,) both mentioned by ISh: (T, TA:) AO says, I have heard xuSoyap, with damm, but I have not heard xiSoyap↓, with kesr; and I have heard xuSoyaAhu↓ [as the dual], though they did not use xuSoIN↓ as the sing.; (Ṣ;) IB, however, cites exs. of this last as a sing.: (TA:) AA says that AlxuSoyataAni signifies the two testicles; and AaxuSoyaAni↓, the two skins [which compose the scrotum, i. e.,] in which are the two testicles; citing an ex. in which the latter dual is used in this sense; (Ṣ;) and ISk says the like; whereas IḲooṭ makes AlxuSoyapu to signify [the scrotum, i. e.] the skin containing the testicle. (Mṣb.)
Also ‡ An earring (quroTN) in the ear: (JK, Ṣgh, Ḳ:) thus called by way of comparison: (TA:) pl. xuSFI. (JK.)
xiSoyapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

xaSiI-N Whose testicles have been drawn forth, or extracted; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [gelded, or castrated; a eunuch;] applied to a sheep or goat, and a horse or similar beast, (TA,) and a man (Ṣ, TA) or boy, (TA,) or a slave; (Mṣb;) as also maxoSiI-N↓: (Ḳ:) pl. xiSoyaAnN (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and xiSoyapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in giving it the former pl., they liken it to a subst., like ZaliymN, of which the pl. is ZilomaAnN: so says Sb; meaning that fiEolaAnN is generally the pl. of faEiylN as a subst. (TA.) One says also xaSiI-N naSiI-N; using the latter word as an imitative sequent. (Lḥ, TA.)
Also ‡ Poetry in which is no amatory effusion. (Ḳ, TA.)

xaASK [act. part. n. of 1]. They say, jaMCa kaxaASiI AlEayori [lit. He came like the gelder of the ass], meaning he came ashamed: (JK, and TA in art. jwj:) and also, disappointed, or unsuccessful. (TA in that art.)
maxoSFI The place of cutting [or gelding or castration]. (Ṣ.)
maxoSiI-N: see xaSiI-N.

R. Q. 1. xaDoxaDapN, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. xaDoxaDapN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) He agitated it; moved it about; stirred it; shook it; namely, water, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and the like, (Ṣ, O,) and sawiyq, and the like. (O, Ḳ.) You say also, xaDoxaDotu dalowiI fiI AlmaMCi [I agitated, or dashed about, my bucket in the water]. (O, TA.) Sakhr-el-Gheí El-Hudhalee says, describing a water to which he had come for drink,
faxaDoxaDotu DufoniIa fiI jam-ihi
xiyaADa AlmudaAbiri qidoHFA EaTuwfaA , (O, TA,) i. e. [And I dashed about my leathern bucket in the main body thereof,] as he who is overcome in the game of el-meysir introduces among the other arrows a borrowed arrow [that comes forth winning], in the luck of which he has confidence. (TA in art. xwD.) This verb, though mentioned here, is [said to be] from xaADa, aor. yaxuwDu; not from xaD-a; therefore the poet here uses xayiAD for its inf. n. (O, TA.) You also say, jaMCahu biAlxanojari faxaDoxaDa bihi baTonahu [He came to him with the dagger, and stirred about with it his belly]. (TA.)
R. Q. 2. taxaDoxaDa It (water, and the like, Ṣ) became agitated, moved about, stirred, or shaken. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. xaDaba, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoDibu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaDobN (Ṣ, Mṣb) [and accord. to MF xiDaAbN and xuDuwbN, but respecting these two inf. ns. (the latter of which seems to be peculiar to the intrans. verb xaDaba) see what follows], He coloured, or tinged, (A, Ḳ,) a thing; (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ;*) or changed it in colour to red, or yellow, &c.; (TA;) and xD-b↓ signifies the same, [but app. in an intensive sense, or as applying to a number of objects, (see its pass. part. n. voce xaDiybN,)] (Ḳ,) inf. n. taxoDiybN: (TA:) and the former, particularly, he tinged, or dyed, his white hair, (TA,) or the hand, &c., (Mṣb,) with hinnà: (Mṣb, TA:) but when a man has dyed his hair with any other dye than hinnà, you say, Sabaga XaEarahu: (Mṣb, TA:) or you say also, xaDaba biAls-awaAdi [He dyed his hair with black]. (Suh, TA.) When one does not mention the hair (Mṣb, TA) or the white hair [&c.], (Mṣb,) he says xaDaba, inf. n. xiDaAbN; (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb;) and AxtDb↓, (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, Mṣb, TA,) and txD-b↓; (A, TA;) [meaning He dyed his hair,, &c.,] with hinnà, (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, Mṣb, TA,) and the like: (Ṣ, TA:) and in like manner one says of a woman, xaDabato, aor. _i {yaxoDibu}; and AxtDb↓: (TA:) which last also signifies [particularly] She dyed her hands with hinnà. (T, TṢ, TA, in art. gms.)

Hence, in a trad., bakaI Hat-aI xaDaba damoEuhu AlHaSaI ‡ He wept so that his tears wetted the pebbles: or, more probably, so that his tears became red, and dyed the pebbles: (IAth, TA:) [or most probably, so that his tears caused the pebbles to appear of a reddish colour; for such is commonly the case when pebbles are wetted.]

xaDaba, aor. _i {yaxoDibu}; and xaDiba, aor. _a {yaxoDabu}; and xuDiba; inf. n. of each xuDuwbN; and AxDwDb↓; ‡ It (a tree) became green. (Ḳ, TA.) And xaDaba, inf. n. xuDuwbN, † Its small leaves came forth in the spring, and its twigs lengthened; said of the qataAd, at the commencement of its vegetation; and likewise of the Earofaj and Eawosaj; but of no other tree of the kind called EiDaAh: or said also of the EurofuT and samur; meaning † it dropped its leaves, and became red and yellow: (TA:) and you say also, xaDabati AlEiDaAhu ‡ the EDAh became green, and broke forth; (A;) or the sap of the EDAh flowed in their branches, and they became green; as also OaxoDabato↓, (TA,) for which AxSbt, with the unpointed S, is said by Az to be a gross mistranscription; explained by Lth, on whose authority it is written with S, [as also in the Ḳ in art. xSb,] as meaning the sap flowed in the branches of the EDAh so as to reach the roots. (T and TA in art. xSb.) And xaSaba Aln-axolu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaDobN, (Ḳ,) The palm-trees, (Ṣ,) or the spadices of the palm-trees, (Ḳ,) became green. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And xaDabati AlOaroDu, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaDobN; (TA;) and AxDbt↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UixoDaAbN; (TA;) or AxtDbt↓; and txD-bt↓; (A;) The earth, or land, exposed to view, (A,) or produced, (Ḳ,) its herbage, (A, Ḳ,) and it (the latter) became green. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.
4: see 1, each in two places.
5: see 1, each in two places.
8: see 1, in three places.
xaDobN The colour of a tree, or of the spadix of a palm-tree, when it becomes green: pl. xuDuwbN. (Ḳ.)

A plant fresh, or new, and green in consequence of rain; as also xaDuwbN↓: (Ḳ:) or watered by rain, and imparting a colour to the ordure: (TA:) or the green colour that appears in trees when they begin to put forth their leaves: (Ḳ:) pl. xuDuwbN. (TA.)
xaDobapN A spadix of a palm-tree: xaSobapN, [q. v.,] with the unpointed S, is erroneously said to have this signification. (TA.)
xuDabapN A woman who uses xiDaAb for herself [i. e. for dyeing her hair or hands, &c.] much, or often. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
xiDaAbN Hinnà (Hin-aMC), and the like: (Mṣb:) or the thing with which one dyes, or tinges, his, or her, hair, &c.; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) such as Hin-aMC and katam and the like. (TA.)
xaDuwbN: see xaDobN.

xaDiybN Anything dyed, tinged, or changed in colour; [generally, with hinnà;] as also maxoDuwbN↓: the former is both masc. and fem.: and its pl. is xuDubN. (TA.) You say kaf-N xaDiybN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and xaADibN↓ (TA voce DaAribN) [A hand dyed with hinnà]: and banaAnN xaDiybN and maxoDuwbN↓ (Ḳ) and muxaD-abN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) [fingers, or fingers' ends, dyed with hinnà]; but the last of these has an intensive signification. (Ṣ.)

And hence, (TA,) Alkaf-u AlxaDiybu † A certain star; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) the star β of Cassiopeia; (so in the Egyptian almanacs;) [i. e.] the bright star of the constel-lation called caAtu AlkurosiI-i; which star is [termed] the extended right h and of Alv-uray-aA [or the Pleiades; corresponding to the star called Alkaf-u AljacomaMCu]. (Ḳzw. [See Oajocamu.])
And AimoraOapN xaDiybN [A woman having her hands, or feet, or hair, &c., dyed with hinnà or the like]. (Ḳ.)
xaADibN A man dyeing, or who dyes, his hair with hinnà. (Mṣb.)
See also xaDiybN.

Also ‡ A male ostrich (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.) whose shanks (A, Ḳ) and legs (A) have become red, (A, Ḳ,) or green, [app. meaning of a dark, or an ashy, dustcolour,] or yellow, (A,) in consequence of his lusting after the female, (A, Ḳ,) or in consequence of his having eaten the [herbage termed] rabiyE: (A:) or the front edges of whose shanks have become red, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or green, (Ḳ,) or yellow, in consequence of his having eaten the [herbage termed] rbyE: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or whose beak and shanks have become red from his having eaten the [herbage termed] rbyE: in the summer (AlS-ayof) he becomes bald (yqrE), and his shanks become white: (L:) or whose shanks have become green by reason of lust in the [season termed] rbyE: (ADk:) accord. to some, (TA,) it is applied only to the male ostrich: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but some explain it without this restriction; and Lth mentions [the fem.] xaADibapN as applied to an ostrich: [it is said that] the skin of the neck, and that of the breast, and that of the thighs, of the male ostrich, but not his feathers, become intensely red when he lusts after the female: or, as some say, xADb signifies an ostrich that has eaten green food: (TA:) or the extremities of whose feathers are dyed by [the eating of] blossoms, and the slender parts of whose legs have become red by the same cause: accord. to an Arab of the desert, supposed to be Aboo-Kheyreh, in the [season termed] rbyE, when it eats OasaAriyE [app. meaning certain worms so called], its legs and beak assume the red hue of the EuSofur [or safflower]: (AḤn, L:) or xADb is applied to a male ostrich the slender parts of whose legs become red when the dates begin to become red, and cease to be so when the redness of the dates ceases: (AḤn, Ḳ:) so that it is not from eating AsAryE, which, it is said, no ostrich is known to eat: accord. to Aṣ, the cause [of the redness above mentioned] is only the dye of blossoms; but were it so, the bird would also become yellow, and green, &c., [and some assert that it partially does, as has been shown above,] accord. to the colours of the blossoms and herbs; and the green colour would predominate: [but, as the Arabs say, this requires consideration:]
whatever be the cause, the bird, it is said, is termed xADb on account of the redness that affects its shanks: and this word is [said to be] an epithet used as a proper name of the bird: (AḤn, L:) but this is a mistake, unless it mean that, because of its prevailing application, it is used in the same manner as AlHerivu and AlEab-aAsu, not that it may be used [in a determinate sense] without the article Al: (L:) the pl. is xawaADibu. (TA.) It is also said to be applied as an epithet to Any animal that eats xaDob [q. v.]: (TA:) and particularly to [the species of bovine antelope called] the wild bull (Alv-aworu AlwaHoXiI-u). (L.)
[See also a saying of Dukeyn cited voce raAwuwqN.]
mixoDabN I. q. mirokanN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Uij-aAnapN: (A:) or a vessel resembling that called Uij-aAnapN, in which clothes are washed. (TA.)

maxaADibu [is its pl.; and also] signifies The rags of the xiDaAb [or hudot;innà or the like]: (A:) [or] of the HyD [or catamenia]. (TA.) [If these two significations be correct, the latter is app. tropical: but HyD may be a mistranscription for xDAb.]
muxaD-abN: see xaDiybN.
maxoDuwbN: see xaDiybN, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. xaDada, aor. _i {yaxoDidu}, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaDodN, (L,) He broke wood, or a branch, or twig, whether moist or dry, (L, Ḳ,) or a soft thing, (L,) so that its parts did not separate. (L, Ḳ.)
It (carriage) broke in pieces fruit. (A.)

He bent, (Ṣ, A, L,) without breaking, (Ṣ, L,) wood, or a branch, or twig. (Ṣ, A, L.) You say also, xaDada AlbaEiyru Eunuqa Mxara (L, Ḳ) The camel broke, (L,) or bent, (Ḳ,) the neck of another camel: (L, Ḳ:) or ‡ the camel fought another camel. (Lth, A.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) He cut, or cut off, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) anything moist, or soft, or supple; and so xD-d↓, inf. n. taxoDiydN. (Ṣ.) And xaDada AlX-ajara He cut off, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or pulled off, or removed, (Fr, Zj,) the thorns of the trees. (Fr, Zj, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

Also, (A, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) ‡ He (a man, Ḳ) ate vehemently: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or [he craunched a thing;] he ate something moist, or soft, or supple; as a cucumber, and a carrot, (Ḳ,) and the like: (TA:) and † he (a horse) ate in the manner termed xaDomN, (L,) or qaDomN. (TA.) An Arab of the desert, who liked the cucumber, being asked what pleased him therein, answered, xaDoduhu [app. meaning The craunching thereof]: (Ṣ, L:) or he was asked what pleased him thereof, and answered, xaDaduhu, meaning what is broken in pieces, thereof. (A.)
xaDida, [aor. _a {yaxoDadu},] (TA,) inf. n. xaDadN, (Ḳ,) It (fruit) became shrunk and shrivelled. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
5: see 7, in two places.

[Also, app., † He affected an inclining of his body, or a bending, or he inclined his body, or bent, from side to side, by reason of languor; syn. tavan-aI: (see its part. n., voce OaxoDadu:) as said of a drunken man, in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, Freytag renders it fractus fuit et quasi fractus corruit.]
It (fruit, A, Ḳ, fresh, or moist, TA, being carried from one place to another, A, TA) became broken in pieces, (A, Ḳ,) or crushed; (Ḳ;) and so txD-d↓. (A.)
It (wood, or a branch, or twig,) bent without breaking (AZ, Ṣ, L) asunder. (AZ, L.)

hom.sense: xaDadN Feebleness and weakness in a plant. (Ḳ.)
† A malady (L, Ḳ) in a man, (L,) affecting the limbs, not amounting to a fracture; as also xaDaAdN↓. (L, Ḳ.)
† Languor and pain of the body, with laziness. (L.)
xaDadu Als-afari ‡ The fatigue and weariness that are occasioned to a man by travel. (TA.)

Whatever is cut off from wood, or a branch, or twig, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) that is moist, or soft, or supple: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or what breaks in pieces, or broken pieces, of trees; as also yaxoDuwdN↓: (Ḳ:) or what is cut off, and removed, of trees: and broken pieces, heaped up, of the papyrus, and of any pieces of wood, or of branches, or twigs, that are moist, or soft, or supple: (L:) and broken pieces of cucumbers [&c.]. (A.)
A certain plant: (Ḳ:) or a-certain soft, or flaccid, kind of tree, without thorns. (L.) [See also xaDaAdN.]

entry.sense: xaDidN † Lacking power to rise, (Ḳ, TA,) from languor of the body, and pain, with laziness; (TA;) as also maxoDuwdN↓. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: xaDaAdN: see xaDadN.

Also A certain kind of tree, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) soft, or flaccid, and without thorns: (Ṣ:) [see also xaDadN:] or, of the kind of trees called janobap, the leaves of which have edges like those of the HalofaMC, which are pulled with the hand like HlfAC. (L.)

entry.sense: xaDuwdN A horse that eats in the manner termed qaDomN. (TA. [See 1.])
xaDiydN, applied to wood, or a branch, or twig, whether moist or dry, Broken so that its parts are not separated; as also maxoDuwdN↓. (L.)

Also, and maxoDuwdN↓ (Ṣ, A) and muxaD-adN↓, (A,) A tree, (Ṣ,) or lote-tree, (A,) having its thorns cut off, (Ṣ, A,) or pulled off, or removed: (Fr and Zj in explanation of the second word as occurring in the Ḳur lvi. 27:) or the second, in the Ḳur (ubi suprà), may mean having the branches bent by reason of the abundance of the fruit. (Bḍ.)

OaxoDadu and mutaxaD-idN↓ i. q. mutavan-K [app. as meaning † Affecting an inclining of the body, or a bending, or inclining the body, or bending, from side to side, by reason of languor: see 5; and see also xaDadN and xaDidN]. (Ḳ.)
mixoDadN ‡ A vehement eater: (A, L, Ḳ:) one who eats with coarseness, or rudeness, and quickness. (L.)
muxaD-adN: see aDiydN.
maxoDuwdN: see xaDiydN, in two places:
and xaDidN.
mutaxaD-idN: see OaxoDadu.
yaxoDuwdN: see xaDadN.

hom.sense: 1. xaDira: see 9, in two places.
xaDara: see 8, in two places.

entry.sense: 2. xD-rhu, [inf. n. taxoDiyrN,] He rendered it OaxoDar [i. e. green,, &c.]. (Ṣ.)

[Hence,] it is said in a trad., UicaA OaraAda Qll-ehu biEabodK Xar-FA xaD-ara lahu fiI All-abini waAlT-iyni Hat-aI yaboniIa, (TA,) i. e. † [When God desires evil to befall a man,] He makes him to have pleasure in unburnt bricks and clay, so that he may build, and thus be diverted from the things of the world to come, if his building be beyond his need, or not such a structure as a mosque or the like. (Marginal note in a copy of the “Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer” of Es-Suyootee.) [Hence also,] xuD-ira lahu fiyhi, inf. n. as above, ‡ He was blessed in it. (L, Ḳ.) You say, mano xuD-ira lahu fiI XaIoCK faloyalozamohu, (L,) or mano xuD-ira mino XaIoCK flylzmh, (so in a copy of the Mgh,) i. e. † Whosoever is blessed in a thing, (Mgh, L,) meaning an art or a trade or traffic, or a means of subsistence, let him keep to it. (L.)

3. xADrhu, (TḲ,) inf. n. muxaADarapN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He sold to him fruits before they were in a good, or sound, state: (A:) or before their goodness, or soundness, became apparent: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TḲ:) the doing of which is forbidden: (Ṣ:) accord. to some, (TA,) the prohibition includes the sale of fresh ripe dates, [app. if not fully ripe,] and herbs, or leguminous plants, and the like; and therefore some disapprove of selling a greater quantity of fresh ripe dates than is cut at once. (Ṣ.)
4. AxDr It (plenty of moisture) rendered seedproduce soft, or tender. (TA.)

8. AxtDr He cut herbage, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a tree, (A,) while it was green; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also xaDara↓, (A, TA,) aor. _u {yaxoDuru}, inf. n. xaDorN. (TA.) And AuxotuDira It (herbage, TA) was taken, (Ḳ,) and pastured upon, (TA,) while fresh and juicy, (Ḳ,) and green, before it had attained its full height. (TA.) See also 9, last sentence.

Hence, (Ṣ, TA,) the pass. form, † He died in his youth; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) in his fresh and flourishing state. (Ṣ.) Young men used to say to an old man, Oajozarotu yaA Xayoxu † [Thou hast attained to the time for dying, (lit. for being cut,) O old man]: and he replied, OaIo baniI-a watuxotaDaruwna † [O my sons, and ye shall be cut off, or die, in your youth]. (Ṣ. [See also Oajozara.])

Also, the act. v., He cut off the green branches of a palm-tree with his mixolab; (TA;) and so xaDara↓, (Ḳ,* TA,) aor. _u {yaxoDuru}, inf. n. xaDorN: (TA:) and he cut off a thing, as a man's nose, entirely: (TA:) or, simply, he cut off a man's nose. (IAạr.)
And He ate fruit [while it was green, or] before it was ripe. (A.)
And hence, (TA,) ‡ He deflowered a girl: (Ḳ, TA:) or, before she had attained to puberty; (Mṣb in art. qD, and Ḳ;) as also Aibotasara and Aibotakara. (TA.)
Also † He took a camel in a refractory state, not trained, and attached the nose-rein to him, and drove him. (TA.)
And † He took up a load, or burden. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 9. AxDr-, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. AixoDiraArN; (Ṣ, A;) and AxDwDr↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [inf. n. AixoDiyDaArN, in the TA written by mistake AixoDiyraArN;] and HaDira↓, aor. _a {yaxoDaru}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaDarN; (Mṣb;) It (a colour, Mṣb, or seed-produce, Ḳ) was, or became, of the colour termed xuDorap [i. e. green: and he, (a camel, and a horse, and an ass, and sometimes a bird,) and it, (a garment of the kind called kisaMC, and the like, or any other thing,) was, or became, of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour; or dingy ash-colour; or dark dust-colour: and he, (a man,) or it, (a thing,) was, or became, of a tawny, or brownish, colour; or blackish; or of a blackish hue inclining to green; or black; or intensely black: see xuDorapN and OaxoDaru]. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [Hence,] AxDr- UizaAraI (The place of) my AzAr became black: or, rather, became of a [blackish] hue inclining to green: because the hair when it first grows is of that hue. (Ḥar p. 494.) And AxDr- XaAribuhu [His mustache grew so as to appear dark]; said of a boy; a phrase similar to baqala wajohuhu. (Mgh in art. bql.) And AxDr-All-ayolu ‡ The night became dark and black. (Ḳ,* TA.) And AxDr-t AlZ-ulomapu ‡ The darkness became intensely black. (A.)
AxDr- jilodatuhu [properly His skin became green from carrying the produce of his land; meaning] ‡ he became in a state of plenty. (TA. [See humo xuDoru AlmanaAkibi, voce OaxoDaru.])
AxDr- and AixotaDara↓, (Ḳ,) or this may be of the pass. form, [AuxotuDira,] so as to agree with what occurs before, [see 8,] (TA,) It (herbage, TA) was, or became, cut. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: 12: see 9, first sentence:
and {9} last sentence but one.
xaDorN Trees (XajarN) that are soft, or tender, when cut; as also maxoDuwrN↓. (TA.)
xuDorN: see xuDaArapN.

xiDorN [i. q. xaDirN]. You say, Oaxacahu xiDorFA miDorFA, and xaDirFA↓ maDirFA, He took it without price: or in its fresh, or juicy, state: (Ḳ:) mDrA being an imitative sequent. (TA.) Whence the saying, Ald-unoyaA xaDirapN↓ maDirapN [in the Ṣ HulowapN xaDirapN] The goods of this world are delicate, fresh, and pleasant: or pleasing. (TA.) And Algazowu HulowN xaDirN↓ [Predatory warfare is sweet and] fresh [or refreshing] and loved; because of the victory and spoil attending it. (TA, from a trad. of Ibn-ʼOmar [which see fully quoted voce vumaAmN].)
You say also, huwalaka xiDorFA miDorFA It is thine, or for thee: may it be attended with enjoyment and a wholesome result. (Ḳ.)

And cahaba damahu xiDorFA miDorFA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and xaDirFA↓ maDirFA, (Ḳ,) His blood went unrevenged, or unretaliated, or unexpiated by a mulet: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) mDrA being an imitative sequent [here as in the former instance]. (TA.)

hom.sense: xaDarN inf. n. of xaDira: [see 9, first sentence:]
[and {9} last sentence but one; and] see also xuDorapN.
Also Green palm-branches with the leaves upon them: and green palm-branches stripped of their leaves: (Fr, Ḳ:) pl. OaxoDaArN. (AḤn.)

entry.sense: xaDirN: see OaxoDaru.

Also A place having much verdure; and so yaxoDuwrN↓ and maxoDarapN↓. (Ḳ.) And OaroDN xaDirapN and yaxoDuwrN↓ Land in which is much verdure: and ArD maxoDarapN↓, as in the Ḳur xxii. 62, accord. to one reading, verdant land. (TA.)
See also xiDorN, in four places.

Also, [as a subst.,] What is green: (Akh, Ṣ, and Bḍ in vi. 99:) seed-produce; (Lth, Bḍ, Ḳ;) and so xuD-aAraI↓: (Ṣ:) so the former in the Ḳur ubi suprà: (Lth, Bḍ:) or goodly green herbage: (A:) and a branch: (Ḳ:) any branch. (TA.)

And AlxaDiru The plant called Albaqolapu AlxaDoraMCu↓; as also AlxaDirapu↓ and AlxaDiyru↓ (Ḳ) and AlxuDorapu↓: (TA:) it is a green and rough herb or leguminous plant, the leaves and fruit of which are like those of millet; it rises to the height of a cubit; and fills the mouth of the camel. (TA.) Also A species of plant of the kind called janobap; (Ḳ;) which latter term is applied to herbage whereof the root is deep in the earth, like the naSiI- and Sil-iyaAn: (TA:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {xaDirapN}: (Ḳ:) it is not of the slender and succulent herbs or leguminous plants, which dry up in summer. (TA.) Hence Mkilapu AlxaDiri, occurring in a trad., [properly signifying A she-camel that eats the plant above mentioned,] applied to a man who acts justly and moderately with respect to worldly enjoyments: for the xDr is not of the slender and succulent herbs, as above observed, nor of those excellent plants which the spring produces by its consecutive rains, and which therefore become goodly and soft or tender; but of those upon which beasts pasture after others have dried up, because they find no others, and which the Arabs call janobap; and the beasts do not eat much of it, nor do they find it wholesome. (IAth, TA.)
xaDorapN [if not a mistranscription for xuDorapN] Fresh cut herbage, to be eaten quickly. (TA.)

xuDorapN [Greenness; a green colour; verdure;] a certain colour, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) well known; (Ḳ;) [and] a colour between black and white: it is in plants and in animals, &c., and, accord. to IAạr, in water also: (TA:) in camels, (Ṣ,) and horses, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [and asses, and sometimes in birds, and in a garment of the kind called kisaMC, and the like, and in other things, a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour; or dingy ash-colour; or dark dustcolour;] a dust-colour intermixed with duhomap [i. e. blackness or deep ash-colour]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in men, [and in other things,] a tawny, or brownish, colour; syn. sumorapN: (Ṣ:) [and a blackish hue: and a blackish hue inclining to green:] and blackness: (TA:) [and intense blackness: see 9; and see also OaxoDaru:] pl. xuDarN and xuDorN. (Ḳ.)
And A green plant: pl. xuDarN: (TA:) or the latter signifies herbs, or leguminous plants; as though pl. of the former. (Mṣb.) [See xaDaArN: and xaDorapN.]
See also xaDirN.
Also Softness, or tenderness, (IAạr, Ḳ,) of seed-produce [and the like]; (TA;) and so xaDarN↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. of xaDira. (TA.)
And What is soft, or tender; fresh, or juicy; and pleasant to the eater. (TA, from a xuTobap of ʼAlee, delivered at El-Koofeh.)
AlxaDirapN: see xaDirN.
xuDoriy-apN A palm-tree (naxolapN) that bears good green dates. (Az, Ḳ.)
A kind of dates, green, resembling glass, of a colour that is admired. (AḤn.)
xaDaArN Herbs, or leguminous plants, in the first state of their growth. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.) [See also xuDorapN.]

Also Milk mixed with much water: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) AZ says that it is like samaArN, meaning as above, diluted so as to be of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour (Hat-aI QxoDar-a): like as the rájiz says,
jaAWuwA biDayoHK halo raOayota Alc-iYoba qaTo
[They brought milk mixed with much water. Hast thou ever seen the wolf?]: meaning that the milk was of an ash-colour (Oaworaq), like the colour of the wolf, by reason of the great quantity of the water: or, as some say, milk and water in the proportion of one third of the former to two thirds of the latter: it is of any milk, that has been kept in a skin or that is fresh, and from any beast: some say that the word is a pl., [or rather a coll. gen. n.,] and that the sing., or n. un., is with p {xaDaArapN}. (TA.)
xaDuwrN: see OaxoDaru.
xaDiyrN: see OaxoDaru:
and see also xaDirN.
xuDayorN: see what next follows.
xuDaArapN: see OaxoDaru, in the latter half of the paragraph.

xuDaArapN, determinate, and imperfectly decl., (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) because it has the quality of a proper name and the fem. gender with p, like OusaAmapN, &c., (TA,) ‡ The sea; (ISk, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also AlOaxoDaru↓, and xuDayorN↓, (A, TA,) or xuDorN↓. (So in a copy of the A.) [But it is used as a masc. proper name; for] you say, hecaA xuDaArapu TaAmiyFA [This is the sea, in a state of rising, or becoming full, or becoming high and full]. (Ṣ, TA. [In one copy of the Ṣ, I find hecihi; but in others, hecaA; and in all, TaAmiyFA.])
xaDiyrapN A palm-tree (naxolapN) of which the dates fall while unripe and green; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also mixoDaArN↓. (TA.)

hom.sense: xuDayorapN dim. of xuDorapN.
Also ‡ A woman who scarcely ever, or never, completes the fruit of her womb, so that she casts it. (TA.)

entry.sense:
xuDaAriI-N A certain bird; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) also called the Oaxoyal; (Ṣ;) regarded as of evil omen when it alighted upon the back of a camel: it is OaxoDar [i. e. green, or of a dark or an ashy dust-colour], with redness in the Hanak [or part beneath the beak], and is larger than the qaTaA: or certain green, or dark or ashy dust-coloured, birds, (TayorN xuDorN,) also called qaAriyap: AʼObeyd asserts that the Arabs loved them, and likened to them a liberal, or bountiful, man:
but ISd says, on the authority of the ʼEyn, that they regarded them as of evil omen: (TA:) [Golius states, on the authority of Meyd, that the xDArI- is a bird of a blackish colour, called in Persian karAyaho. See Bochart's Hieroz. p. ii. col. 61; referred to by Freytag.]
Also The [tree, or shrub, called] rimov, when it has grown tall. (TA.)
xuD-aArN A certain bird, (Ḳ,) green or of a dark or an ashy dust-colour (OaxoDaru). (TA.)
xuD-aAraI: see xaDirN.
Also A certain plant. (Ḳ.)

OaxoDaru [Green; verdant;] of the colour termed xuD-aAraI; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also xaDirN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and xaDiyrN↓ and xaDuwrN↓ and yaxoDuwrN↓ and yaxoDiyrN↓: (Ḳ, TA: the last two written in the CK taxoDuwrN and taxoDiyrN:) applied to a horse, [and to a camel, (see xuDorapN,) and to an ass, and sometimes to a bird, and to a garment of the kind called kisaMC, and the like, and to various other things, of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour; or dingy ash-colour; or dark dust-colour;] of a dust-colour intermixed with duhomap [i. e. blackness or deep ash-colour]; which is the same as dayozajN; (Ṣ;) in horses being distinguished as OaxoDaru Oadogamu and OaxoDaru OaToHalu and OaxoDaru Oaworaqu: (TA: [see the latter epithet in each of these cases:]) applied to a man, [and to other things,] tawny, or brownish: (Ṣ:) [and blackish: and of a blackish hue inclining to green:] and black; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) black-complexioned: (TA:) [and intensely black: it is said in the Mṣb, art. Htm, that AlOaxoDaru is, with the Arabs, Oasowadu; which may mean either that green is, with the Arabs, termed Aswd, or that AlAxDr is, with the Arabs, black: but the truth is, that each of the epithets OaxoDaru and Oasowadu is sometimes used for the other: see what here follows, and see Oasowadu: in Ḥar p. 495, it is erroneously said, on the authority of Er-Rázee, that the Aswd is not termed by the Arabs AxDr, although the AxDr is termed by them Aswd because of its intense xuDorap and riI-:] the fem. is xaDoraMCu: and the pl. is xuDorN. (Mṣb, TA.) You say XajarapN xaDoraMCu A green, and fresh, or juicy, tree. (TA.) And maMCN OaxoDaru Water inclining to a green colour, by reason of its clearness. (TA.) And OaxoDaru Aljilodapi [lit. Tawny of skin:] meaning † of pure race; because the complexions of the Arabs are tawny; (Ṣ;) of genuine Arab race: (IB:) as in the saying of El-Lahabee, (Ṣ, TA,) El-Fadl Ibn-ʼAbbás, (TA,)
waOanaA AlOaxoDaru mano yaEorifuniI
OaxoDaru Aljilodapi fiI bayoti AlEarabo
[And I am the tawny: who knows me? the tawny of skin (or pure of race), of the family that comprises the nobility of the Arabs]. (Ṣ, IB.) And fulaAnN OaxoDaru AlqafaA [lit. Such a one is blackish, or black, in the back of the neck:] meaning ‡ such a one is the son of a black woman: (Az, A:) or ‡ one who is slapped on the back of his neck: (A:) or ‡ a freedman, or an emancipated slave. (TA.) And OaxoDaru AlbaToni ‡ A weaver: (A, TA:) because his belly, being stuck close to his loom, becomes blackened by it. (TA.) And OaxoDaru Aln-awaAjici ‡ An eater of onions and leeks: or a tiller, or cultivator, of the ground; because he eats herbs, or leguminous plants. (A.) And humo xuDoru AlmanaAkibi [lit. They are green in the shoulders, from carrying the produce of their land:] meaning ‡ they are in a state of great plenty. (Ḳ, TA.) And [hence, perhaps,] fulaAnN OaxoDaru ‡ Such a one possesses abundant xayor [or wealth, or prosperity]: (A, TA:) [or it may mean goodness: for] AlOaxoDaru, applied to a man, is an epithet of praise, whereby he may be likened to the sea, because it is described as green, or to the [rain or herbage called] rabiyE; in both cases meaning † liberal, or bountiful; and it is so applied because xuDorapN is of the colours of the Arabs: and it is also an epithet of dispraise, as meaning † black by reason of baseness, ignobleness, or meanness. (Ḥam p. 282.) And XaAb-N OaxoDaru ‡ A young man whose hair has begun to grow upon the sides of his face. (TA.) And katiybapN xaDoraMCu ‡ An army, or a troop of horse, overspread with the blackness of iron: (Ṣ, TA:) or a great army or troop of horse (Ḳ, TA) of which most of the men are clad in iron; like jaOowaMCu: (TA:) because of the xuDorap of the iron: (A:) [i. e.] because of the blackness thereof. (TA.) And All-ayolu OaxoDaru ‡ Night is black. (TA.) And [hence,] jan-a Ealayohi OaxoDaru AljanaAHayoni ‡ Night [lit. the black-winged] veiled him, concealed him, or covered him with its darkness. (A.) mudohaAm-ataAni, in the Ḳur [lv. 64, relating to two gardens of Paradise], is explained by xaDoraAwaAni because it means Inclining to blackness, by reason of abundance of moisture, or irrigation. (Ṣ.)
AlOaxoDaru used as a subst.: see xuDaArapN.

The fem. xaDoraMCu [is also used as a subst., and] signifies Gree herbs or leguminous plants; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also xuDaArapN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. xaDoraAwaAtN: by rule it should be xuDorN; but as the quality of a subst. predominates in it, it has a pl. like the pl. of a subst., like SaHoraAwaAtN pl. of SaHoraMCN: (Mṣb:) this pl. occurs in the saying (in a trad., TA) layosa fiI AlxaDoraAwaAti SadaqapN There is no poor-rate in the case of green herbs or leguminous plants; (Mṣb;) or fresh fruits and herbs or leguminous plants; (TA;) or fruits, such as the apple and the pear, &c.; or herbs or leguminous plants, such as leeks and smallage and rue and the like; and xuDarN, pl. of xuDorapN, is sometimes substituted for it. (Mgh.) [Hence,] Uiy-aAkumo waxaDoraMCu Ald-imani, meaning ‡ Avoid ye the beautiful woman that is of bad origin: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) because what grows in a dimonap [or place which men have blackened by their cooking, and where their camels or other beasts have staled and dunged], though it may be beautiful and bright, does not bear fruit [because it is neglected, and left unwatered], (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and soon becomes corrupt, or bad. (Mṣb. [See also dimonapN: and see EuXobapN Ald-aAri, in art. EXb.])

And AlxaDoraMCu, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, (TA,) ‡ The sky, or heaven; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) because of its greenness; like as the earth is called AlgaboraMCu. (TA.) You say, maA taHota AlxaDoraMCi Oakorahu minohu ‡ [There is not under the sky one more hateful than he]. (A.)
And xaDoraMCu ‡ A bucket (A, Ḳ) with which water has been drawn long, so that it has become green or blackish, &c. (Hat-aI QxoDar-ato). (Ḳ.)

And † The congregated or collective body, and mass, or bulk, of a people. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the saying, OabaAda Qll-ehu xaDoraMCahumo † [May God destroy the congregated or collective body, mass, or bulk, of them]: (Ṣ:) or this means, ‡ their stock (Xajarap) from which they have branched off; (A;) [for] xaDoraMCu signifies the origin of anything: (TA:) or, their life in this present world: (Fr, TA:) or, as some say, their enjoyment and plenty; (TA;) [for] xaDoraMCu signifies prosperity, and plenty, and enjoyment: (TA in a later part of this art.:) or the right reading is gaDoraMCahumo, meaning “their prosperity, and their pleasantness of life, or plenty and prosperity.” (Ṣ. [See art. gDr.])
Albaqolapu AlxaDoraMCu: see xaDirN.

AlxuDoru, (T,) or AlxaDoraMCu, (Ḳ,) The domestic pigeons; (T, Ḳ;) so called although of various colours, because their predominant colour is wuroqap [or ash-colour], or xuDorap [meaning a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour]: the xuDor and the numor [or spotted with white and black, &c.,] are especially characterized by the faculty of rightly directing their course. (T, TA.)
AlOaxaASiru [a pl. of AlOaxoDaru used as a subst.] ‡ Gold and flesh-meat and wine; as also AlOaHaAmirapu [as some explain this latter]. (TA.)

OaxoDaru also signifies ‡ Fresh, or recent: so in the saying, AlOamoru bayonanaA OaxoDaru ‡ [The affair between us is fresh, or recent]: and in like manner you say, Almawad-apu bayonanaA xaDoraMCu ‡ Love, or affection, between us is fresh. (A.) And Soft, or tender; applied to herbage, or seed-produce. (TA.)
[Hence,] EiyXapN xaDoraMCu † A mode of life soft, or delicate, and plentiful and pleasant. (Ḥar p. 639.)

AlOaxoDaru is also the name of [A certain star, or asterism; most probably either α of Piscis Australis or ε of Pegasus, or some star or asterism nearly in a line with those two;] one of the three OanowaMC of the rain called Alxariyf; namely, the middle nawoC of those three AnwMC; the first being the nasoraAni; and the last, the foremost of the farogaAni: see nawoCN. (AZ, T and TA in art. nwO.)

hom.sense: AlOuxayoDiru dim. [of AlOaxoDaru], (TA,) [Cantharides;] a kind of fly, (Ḳ,) green, of a dark or an ashy dust-colour, (OaxoDaru,) of the size of the black fly, and called the Indian fly [as cantharides are by the Arabs in the present day]; having properties and uses mentioned in medical books. (TA.)
Also A certain disease in the eye. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: maxoDarapN: see xaDirN, in two places.
mixoDaArN: see xaDiyrapN.
maxoDuwrN: see xaDorN.
yaxoDuwrN: see xaDirN, in two places: and see also OaxoDaru, first sentence.
yaxoDiyrN: see OaxoDaru, first sentence.

Q. 1. xaDorama AlOucun-, inf. n. xaDoramapN, He cut somewhat of the extremity of the ear of a camel, and left it dangling: or he cut the ear in halves: and you say also, xaDoramuwA naEamahumo [They so cut the ears of their camels]: (TA:) or xaDoramapN signifies the cutting one of the ears only. (JK.)
And xaDorama He mixed [a thing or things]: (IKh, TA:) [and so HaDorama, as is indicated in the Ḳ in art. HDrm, by an explanation of the inf. n.]
And xaDoramapN signifies also The making a thing to be of an intermediate, or a middling, kind or quality. (TA.)
Q. 2. taxaDorama, said of butter [in the process of formation], It became dissundered, or separated [into clots], by reason of intense cold; and did not coalesce; as also tHSrm. (TA in art. HSrm.)

xiDorimN A well having much water; (JK, Ḳ;) and so, [as some say,] a sea, or great river; but its application as an epithet to a sea, or great river, is disallowed by Aṣ: (Ṣ:) or a great sea: (Ḳ:) accord. to some, so called because of its greenness; and if so, the m is augmentative: (MF:) or water copious and wide in the utmost degree: (Mz 49th nwE:) and anything much in quantity, or copious, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and wide, or ample: (Ṣ:) or it signifies also wide, or ample, (Ḳ,) applied to anything: (TA:) pl. xaDaArimu: (Ṣ:) and muxaDoramN↓ and xuDaArimN↓, also, signify much in quantity, or copious, applied to water: (TA:) and xiDorimN is applied in this sense as an epithet to nabiyc. (Ṣ,* TA.)

‡ Bountiful, or munificent; (JK, Ḳ;) who gives many gifts: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) said to be likened to the sea, or great river, to which this epithet is applied; though Aṣ disallowed its application to a sea, or great river: (Ṣ:) or likened to the well to which the same epithet is applied: (JK:) and a forbearing, or clement, lord, or chief; as also xuDaArimN↓: pl. xaDaArimu and xaDaArimapN and xiDorimuwna: all applied peculiarly to men: (Ḳ:) not to women. (TḲ.)

hom.sense: xuDarimN Sweet water: or water between sweet and bitter: (Ḳ:) on the authority of Yaạḳoob. (TA.)

The young of the [kind of lizard called] Dab-: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to IDrd, in its first stage it is called HisolN; [after which he should have said, then, gayodaAqN;] then it is called muTab-ixN [q. v.]; then, xuDarimN; and then, Dab-N: he does not mention the term gayodaAqN, but AZ mentions it. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: xiDorimiI-N: see AlxaDaArimapu.
xuDaArimN: see xiDorimN, in two places.

AlxaDaArimapu A certain people of the Eajam [i. e. Persians], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the sons of Fáris, (Ṣ,) who went forth [from their country] in the beginning of El-Islám, and dwelt in Syria: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) i. e., those people who went forth at that period dispersed themselves in the countries of the Arabs; some of them settling in El-Basrah, and these are the OasaAwirap; and some of them, in El-Koofeh, and these are the OaHaAmirap; and some of them, in Syria, and they are the xaDaArimap; and some of them, in El-Jezeereh, and they are the jaraAjimap; and some of them, in El-Yemen, and they are the OabonaMC; and some of them, in El-Mowsil, and they are the jaraAmiqap: (Ṣ, TA:) the n. un. is xiDorimiI-N↓. (Ḳ.)
muxaDoramN [pass. part. n. of xaDorama]. You say naAqapN muxaDoramapN A she-camel having the extremity of her ear cut. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And OucunN muxaDoramapN An ear cut. (Mz 49th nwE.)

Hence, as some say, (Mz ubi suprá,) A man, (Ḳ, Mz,) or a poet, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) who lived in the Time of Ignorance and in that of El-Islám; (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Mz ubi suprà) as though he were cut off from paganism to El-Islám; (Mz ubi suprà;) or from infidelity; (IB, TA;) as Lebeed, (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Mz 20th nwE,) and Hassán Ibn-Thábit, and Nábighah of the BenooJaadeh, and Aboo-Zubeyd, and ʼAmr Ibn-Sha-s, and Ez-Zibrikán Ibn-Bedr, and ʼAmr Ibn-MaadeeKerib, and Kaab Ibn-Zuheyr, and Maan Ibn-Ows: (Mz 20th nwE: [see also UisolaAmiI-N, and XaAhidN:]) or a person who passed half of his life in the Time of Ignorance, and half thereof in that of El-Islám: (Ḳ:) [I have generally found the word thus written;] but IB says that, accord. to most of the lexicologists, it is muxaDorimN↓, with kesr to the r; for the pagans, when they became Muslims, cut somewhat of the extremities of the ears of their camels (xaDoramuwA McaAna Uibilihimo) as a sign of their being Muslims in case of their being attacked and plundered, or their being made war with; (IB, TA;) and this they were ordered to do in a manner different from that of the pagans: (TA:) accord. to some, the epithet applied to a poet of the class above mentioned is mHDrm, with the unpointed H, [i. e. muHaDorimN,] from AlHaDoramapN signifying AlxaloTu, [like AlxaDoramapu, as shown above,] because of his mixing paganism with El-Islám: (Mz 49th nwE:) or muHaDoramN: (Ḳ in art. HDrm:) and in like manner IKh explains the epithet muxaDorimN↓. (TA.)
Also A black man whose father is white. (IKh, Ḳ.*)
And Deficient in respect of AlHasab; (Ḳ;) meaning not of generous parentage. (TA.)

And One whose origin is suspected; or who claims for his father one who is not: (Ḳ:) and so muxaDoramu Aln-asabi: (Ṣ, TA:) or muxaDoramN fiI nasabihi means of mixed parentage. (TA.) One whose father is unknown: [or, app., accord. to the TA, whose parents are unknown:] or one sprung from [a succession of] concubines. (Ḳ.)
Uncircumcised. (Ḳ.) And, with p {muxaDoramapN}, applied to a woman, Circumcised: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as some say, cut, by a mistake of the woman operating, in a place not that of circumcision. (TA.)
Flesh-meat such that one knows not whether it be from a male or a female. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Accord. to IAạr, who does not explain it, (ISd, TA,) it is applied also to food, (ISd, Ḳ,) ISd thinks (TA) as meaning Insipid; (ISd, Ḳ;) neither sweet nor bitter. (ISd.)
And Water between heavy and light: (T, Ḳ, TA:) or not sweet. (TA.)
See also xiDorimN.
muxaDorimN: see muxaDoramN, in two places.
mutaxaDorimN, applied to butter, [as also mutaHaSorimN and muHaSoramN,] Dissundered, or separated [into clots]; not coalescing; by reason of cold. (Ḳ. [See Q. 2.])

hom.sense: 1. xaDaEa, aor. _a {yaxoDaEu}, inf. n. xuDuwEN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xaDoEN and xuDoEaAnN, or xiDoEaAnN, (TA,) He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) lahu to him, (Mṣb, TA,) [for instance,] to his creditor, (Mṣb,) or to God; (TA;) as also AxtDE↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [and AnxDE↓, (Ḳ in art. xcO,)] and AixoDawoDaEa↓: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) xuDuwEN is nearly the same as xuXuwEN, except that the latter is mostly used in relation to the voice [or the eyes]; but the former is used as meaning in the necks: (Mṣb:) or the former is in the body, (ʼEyn and Ḳ in art. xXE,) and signifies the acknowledgment of humility and submission; (ʼEyn;) and the latter is in the voice and in the eyes. (ʼEyn and Ḳ ubi suprà.) It is said in a trad. respecting the [devils'] hearing [the words of the angels] by stealth, xuDoEaAnFA liqawolihi [With submissiveness to his saying, or to what he said]; or, accord. to one relation, xiDoEaAnFA; but it may be a pl. of xaADiEN; and accord. to another relation, it is xuD-aEFA, which is a pl. of xaADiEN. (TA.)
He was, or became, still, (Ḳ, TA,) and tractable, or submissive. (TA.)

He made his words soft to a woman; as also AxDE↓: (L:) or the latter signifies his speech was soft to a woman. (O, Ḳ.)
