It is said in the Ḳur [xxxiii. 32], falaA taxoDaEona biAlqawoli Then be ye not soft in speech. (TA.) And you say, xaDaEa lahaA bikalaAmihi waxaDaEato lahu wataTam-aEa fiyhaA [He was soft to her in speech, and she was soft to him, and he became excited to feel an eager desire for her, or to lust after her]; (TA;) and in like manner, xaADaEahA↓, (Ḳ,* TA,) inf. n. muxaADaEapN, (TA,) [he was soft in his speech to her, she being soft in her speech to him.] And xaDaEaA bayonahumaA HadiyvFA They two (a man and a woman) made soft discourse together, saying that which excited each to feel an eager desire for, or to lust after, the other. (TA from a trad.)

xaDaEa, aor. _a {yaxoDaEu}, inf. n. xaDoEN, [or, as in two copies of the Ṣ, xaDaEN, though it seems that the verb is correctly xaDaEa, not xaDiEa,] He had a natural stooping of the neck: (TA:) and he bent himself, or became bent; as also AxDE↓. (Zj.) And AxtDE↓, said of a hawk, He lowered his head to make a stoop, or to pounce down. (Z, TA.)

[Hence,] xaDaEati AlUibilu ‡ The camels strove, or exerted themselves, or hastened, in their pace, or going; (Ḳ;) because, when they do so, they lower their necks. (TA.) And AxtDE↓, (Ḳ,) said of a horse, (IAạr,) [for the same reason,] † He went quickly, or swiftly. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

xaDaEa Aln-ajomu ‡ The star, or asterism, inclined (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) to the place of setting, (Ṣ, TA,) or to setting: (Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner, xaDaEati AlX-amosu ‡ the sun inclined, &c.; like xadaEat: (TA:)
and xaDaEato OayodiI AlkawaAkibi ‡ the stars inclined to setting. (Aboo-ʼAdnán, TA in art. xXE.)
xaDaEahu He, or it, rendered him still (Ḳ, TA) [and submissive: see 1]: the verb being both intrans. and trans. (TA.) [See also 4.]

Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaDoEN and xuDuwEN, (TA,) He, or it, caused him to have a stooping neck; as also AxDEhu↓; (Ḳ;) i. e., bent him: (TA:) said of old age. (TḲ.) Jereer says,
OaEad-a Qll-ehu lilX-uEaraMCi min-iI
SawaAEiqa yaxoDaEuwna lahu Alr-iqaAbaA
[God hath prepared, for the poets, from me, thunderbolts which make the necks to stoop to Him]. (TA.)
xaDaEa fulaAnFA UilaI Als-awoCapi; in the Ḳ AlI Als-uwCi, but the former is the right; inf. n. xuDuwEN; (TA;) He, or it, invited such a one to that which was foul, abominable, or evil. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 4.
3: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph.

hom.sense: 4. AxDE, intrans.: see 1, in two places.

AxDEhu It (poverty) lowered, humbled, or abased, him; (Mṣb;) [as also xD-Ehu↓; for its inf. n.] taxoDyEN signifies the rendering lowly, humble, or submissive; in Persian, faruwtano karodaAniydano. (KL. [But Golius, from the same source, explains the verb as signifying “Submissum humilemque se commonstravit.”]) [Hence,] OaxoDaEataniI Uilayoka AlHaAjapu (Zj, Ṣ, TA) Want, or need, [made me lowly, humble, or submissive, to thee; or] constrained me to have recourse to thee, and to require thine aid. (TA.)
See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.

entry.sense: 7: see 1, first sentence.
8: see 1, in three places.
12. AxDwDE: see 1, first sentence.

xaDiEN A plant bending by reason of softness, or tenderness: ISd holds it to be formed after the manner of a relative, or possessive, noun, because there is no verb [of the measure xaDiEa] to which it may be referred. (TA.) [The regular form, if it were a part. n., would be xaADiEN, q. v.]
xaDoEapN, or xaDaEapN↓: see baDaEapN and baADiEN.
xaDaEapN: see what next precedes.
xuDaEapN A man (Ṣ) who is lowly, humble, or submissive, to everyone. (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ,)
And One who overcomes, or subdues, his adversaries, or opponents, (Ḳ, TA,) and humbles and abases them. (TA.)
xaDuwEN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

hom.sense: xaADiEN Lowly, humble, or submissive; (Mṣb;) and xaDuwEN↓ signifies the same: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or rather the latter is an intensive epithet, signifying very lowly,, &c.:] the pl. of the former is xaADiEuwna and xuD-aEN and xuDoEaAnN, or xiDoEaAnN: (TA:) [respecting the last two of which, see 1, second sentence:] and the pl. of xaDuwEN↓ is xuDuEN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as in the phrase qawomN xuDuEu Alr-iqaAbi [A people, or company of men, very submissive in the necks]. (Ṣ.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxvi. 3], faZal-ato OaEonaAquhumo lahaA xaADiEiyna And their necks shall continue, the pret. being used in the sense of the aor., meaning taduwmu, (Jel,) submissive to it: (Jel,* TA:) the original of the phrase is faZal-uwA lahaA xaADiEiyna; and AEnAq is redundantly inserted to show the place of xuDuwE, and the predicate is left in its original state: (Bḍ:) or as the xDwE is only that of the AEnAq, it is allowable to make the predicate relate to [the pronoun hm, which is] the complement of the latter word: (Sb, Kh:) or since the xDwE is ascribed to the necks but really belongs to the persons, the epithet has that form of pl. which is proper to rational beings: (Jel: [and the like is said by Bḍ:]) or AEnAqhm means their chiefs: or their companies: but there is another reading [which is literally grammatical], namely xaADiEapF. (Bḍ.)
The pl. xuD-aEN is also applied to Women who have been [ or who are] soft in speech, and still. (IAạr.) [See 1.]
naEaAmN xawaADiEu [pl. of xaADiEapN] Ostriches inclining their heads towards the ground in their places of pasture; and in like manner, ZibaMCN [gazelles]. (TA.)
UibilN xawaADiEu ‡ Camels striving, or exerting themselves, or hastening, in their pace, or going; because, when they do so, they lower their necks. (TA.)
manokibN xaADiEN and OaxoDaEu↓ A low, or depressed, shoulder-joint. (TA.)
nujuwmN xawaADiEu ‡ Stars inclining to setting, or to their places of setting. (A, TA.)
Inviting to that which is foul, abominable, or evil. (TA.)

entry.sense: OaxoDaEu Content with abasement; fem. xaDoEaMCu. (Lth, Ḳ.)
Having a natural stooping of the neck; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a man, (TA,) and to a horse, (Ṣ, TA,) and a camel, and an ostrich, and a gazelle. (TA.)
See also xaADiEN, near the end of the paragraph.
1. xaDila, aor. _a {yaxoDalu}, inf. n. xaDalN: see 9, in two places.
2: see the next paragraph {4}.

hom.sense: 4. AxDlhu He moistened it; or wetted it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xD-lhu↓, inf. n. taxoDiylN. (TA.) You say, OaxoDalato dumuwEuhu liHoyatahu His tears moistened, or wetted, his beard. (JK,* TA.) And OaxoDalotuhu Als-amaMCu The rain wetted him: (TA:) or wetted him much. (JK.)
See also 9.

entry.sense: 8. AxtDl biSaAHibihi He (a man) became united with his companion. (Fr, TA.)

9. AxDl-, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. AixoDilaAlN, (Ṣ,) It was, or became, moistened, or wetted; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also OaxoDala↓, (Ḳ, TA, [but not in the CK,]) inf. n. UixoDaAlN; (TA; [perhaps a mistranscription for AxDAl-↓, inf. n. AixoDiylaAlN; but said by Freytag to occur in the Deewán of the Hudhalees;]) and AxDwDl↓, (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. AixoDiyDaAlN; (Ṣ;) and xaDila↓: (Ḳ: [but see what follows:]) it is said of a garment, and of the beard: (TA:) and the first of these verbs signifies also it was, or became, moist, so that its moisture became sprinkled, or scattered in drops; (Ḳ,* TA; [accord. to the explanation of the part. n. xaDilN (q. v.) in the JK and M;]) and so AxDAl-↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. AixoDiylaAlN; (TA;) and xaDila↓, aor. _a {yaxoDalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaDalN; but Lth says, I have not heard them say xaDila. (TA.)
AxDl- All-ayolu The night became dark: (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) or the pleasant coolness of the night came. (T, TA.)
11: see 9, in two places.

Also AixaDaAl-ati AlX-ajarapu, inf. n. AixoDiylalN; (Ṣ;) or AxDAl- AlX-ajaru, and AixoDaOal-a↓; (IDrd, Ḳ;) The tree, or trees, had many branches and leaves: (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or became green, and fresh, or sappy, in the branches thereof. (TA.)
12. AixoDawoDala: see 9.
Q. Q. 4. AixoDaOal-a: see 11.

hom.sense: xaDolN Moisture. (TA. [But perhaps this may be a mistranscription for xaDalN, inf. n. of xaDila.])
Also, (JK, T, Ḳ,) and xaDalN↓, (ISd, Ḳ,) Pearls: (JK, Ḳ:) or clear large pearls: (Ḳ:) or good, clear, lustrous, large pearls: of the dial. of Yethrib. (TA.)
And A well-known kind of beads: (ISk, Ḳ:) or a red bead: or a bead of ivory: (TA:) n. un. with p {xaDolapN}. (Ḳ.)
And dur-apN xaDolapN, (TA,) or xaADilapN↓, (JK,) A clear large pearl. (JK, TA.)

entry.sense: xaDalN: see the next preceding paragraph.

xaDilN A thing, (Ṣ,) or roasted meat, (JK, T, M, Ḳ,) moist, or juicy, (JK, T, Ṣ,) and well cooked: (T:) or dripping with its gravy; or succulent, and dripping with its juice: (M, Ḳ:) and anything moist so that its moisture becomes sprinkled, or scattered in drops; (JK, M, Ḳ;*) as also xaADilN↓. (Ḳ: in the copies of which we find yataraX-afu in the place of yataraX-aXu; the latter being the reading in the [JK and] M, TA.)
Applied to a plant, or herbage, Soft, or tender. (Ṣ, TA.)
And hence metaphorically applied to life: you say EayoXN xaDilN, (Ḥar pp. 54-55,) and muxoDilN↓, and muxoDil-N↓, (Ḳ,) ‡ A soft and delicate life. (Ḳ, and Ḥar ubi suprà.)

xuDul-apN A plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, state of life. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, Aln-iEomapu is erroneously put for Aln-aEomapu.]) You say, humo fiI xuDul-apK mina AlEayoXi They are in a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, state of life. (TA.) And yawomu xuDul-apK A day of plenty, and pleasure or ease, and softness or delicacy; (JK, Ḳ;) or a day of plenty; or of abundance of herbage, or of the goods or conveniences or comforts of life; and of pleasantness and easiness of life. (Ṣ, TA.) And nazalonaA fiI xuDul-apK mina AlEuXobi We alighted among green, soft or tender, fresh herbage. (TA.)
Also A wife: (Ḳ:) or a name for a woman: (Ḳ,* TA:) and a soft, or tender, woman. (JK, Ḳ.)
And The rainbow. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) And A halo round the moon. (AA, TA.)
One says also, daEoniI mino xuDul-aAtika, meaning Let me alone, and cease from thy vain, or false, sayings or actions. (TA.)
xaDiylapN A rawoDap [or meadow] (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ) that is luxuriant and moist. (IDrd.)
xaADilN: see xaDilN.
dur-apN xaADilapN: see xaDolN.
muxoDilN: see xaDilN.
mixoDalN: see mixoDalN.
muxoDil-N: see xaDilN.

1. xaDima, aor. _a {yaxoDamu}; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and xaDama, aor. _i {yaxoDimu}; (JK, Ḳ;) inf. n. xaDomN; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) He (a man) ate a thing with the whole of the mouth: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or he ate, (Ḳ,) in a general sense: (TA:) or he ate with the more remote of the teeth: (Ḳ:) qaDomN signifies the “eating with the nearer of the teeth;” (TA;) [i. e., “with the teeth of the fore part of the mouth:” or the “eating with the extremities of the teeth:” see art. qDm:] or [he ate so that] he filled his mouth with that which he ate: or it relates peculiarly to the thing that is moist, or juicy, as the cucumber, (Ḳ,) and the like: (TA:) or he ate in the enjoyment of a plentiful and pleasant life: (JK, TA:) or xaDomN referring to a man is like qaDomN referring to a beast. (TA.)
And xaDamahu, aor. _i {yaxoDimu}, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and AxtDmhu↓; (JK, Ḳ;) He cut it; or cut it off: (Ḳ:) or he cut it in pieces. (JK.)

xaDama lahu mino maAlihi, (Ḳ,) accord. to IAạr, (TA,) signifies He gave him of his property; (Ḳ;) [as though he cut off for him a portion thereof;] but Th rejects this, and says that it is haDama. (TA.)
8: see 1.

[Hence,] Als-ayofu yaxotaDimu jafonahu The sword cuts, and eats, its scabbard, (Ḳ,) by reason of its sharpness; mentioned by J as a meaning of yaxotaDimu: [see 8 in art. xSm:] and yaxotaSimu AlEaZoma cuts the bone: and Alc-iraAEa [the fore arm]. (TA.)
And AxtDm AlT-ariyqa He stopped the way, robbing and slaying passengers. (Ḳ.)
xuDomN: see xuSomN.
xaDomapN i. q. xaSomapN, (Ḳ,) i. e. A certain bead, or gem, mentioned before. (TA.)
xuDaAmN: see what next follows.

xuDaAmapN A thing that is eaten in the manner termed xaDomN; [see 1;] (Ḳ;) as also xuDaAmN↓ [expressly said to be like guraAbN, otherwise it would seem to be xaDaAmN, like qaDaAmN, to which it is opposed,] (TA,) [and maxoDamN↓, as is indicated in the Ḳ in art. qDm, opposed to maqoDamN in that art. (q. v.) in the Ṣ and Ḳ.]
maxoDamN: see what next precedes.

1. xaT-a, aor. _u {yaxoTuTu}, inf. n. xaT-N, He made [a line, or lines, or] a mark, EalaI AlOaroDi, upon the ground. (Mṣb.) You say, xaT-a Alz-aAjiru fiI AlOaroDi, aor. and inf. n. as above, The diviner made a line, or a mark, or lines, or marks, upon the ground, and then divined. (TA.) And Alz-aAjiru yaxuT-u biUiSobaEihi fiI Alr-amoli wayazojuru [The diviner makes lines, or marks, with his finger upon the sand, and divines]. (Ṣ.) Th says, on the authority of IAạr, that Eilomu AlxaT-i is Eilomu Alr-amoli [or geomancy]: I 'Ab says that it is an ancient science, which men have relinquished: but Lth says that it is practised to the present time; [to which I may add, that it has not even now ceased; being still practised on sand and the like, and also on paper;] and they have conventional terms which they employ in it, and they elicit thereby the secret thoughts, &c., and often hit upon the right therein: the diviner comes to a piece of soft ground, and he has a boy, with whom is a style; and the master makes many lines, or marks, in haste, that they may not be counted; then he returns, and obliterates leisurely lines, or marks, two by two; and if there remain two lines, or marks, they are a sign of success, and of the attainment of the thing wanted: while he obliterates, his boy says, for the sake of auguring well, AibonaIo EiyaAno OasoriEaA AlbayaAno [O two sons of 'Iyán (meaning two lines or marks), hasten ye the manifestation]: I 'Ab says that when he has obliterated the lines, or marks, and one remains, it is the sign of disappointment: and AZ and Lth relate the like of this. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh Ibn-El-Hakam Es-Sulamee, traced up by him to its author, kaAna nabiI-N mina AlOanobiyaMCi yaxuT-u famano xaT-ahu Ealima mivola Eilomihi [A prophet of the prophets used to practise geomancy; and he who matches his geomancy knows the like of his knowledge]. (TA.) You say also, when a man is meditating upon his affair, and considering what may be its issue, or result, fulaAnN yaxuT-u fiI AlOaroDi ‡ [Such a one makes lines, or marks, upon the ground]. (TA.) [See also nakata: and see St. John's Gospel, ch. viii. verses 6 and 8.] And xaT-a birijolihi AlOaroDa means ‡ He walked, or went along. (TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. as above, (Mṣb,) and so the inf. n., (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He wrote (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) a writing, or book, (Mṣb,) or a thing, (TA,) with the reed prepared for that purpose, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or with some other thing; (Ḳ, TA;) [and so xT-T↓, for] taxoTiyTN is syn. with tasoTiyrN, or, as in the T, like tsTyr; whence the saying, xuT-iTato Ealayohi cunuwbuhu His sins were written [or registered] against him. (TA.)
xaT-a AlxiT-apa, and xaT-ahaA linafosihi: see 8; for the latter, in two places.
[Hence,] xaT-a Ealayohi † He prohibited it; or took it for himself; relating to anything. (Ḳ, TA.)
xuT-u waHohuhu: or xaT-a: see 8.
xaT-a AlgulaAmu: see 8.

xaTaTotu biAls-ayofi wajohahu wawasaTahu ‡ [I cut, or clave, with the sword his face and his waist]. (TA.) And xaT-ahu biAls-ayofi niSofayoni ‡ [He clave him, or it, in halves with the sword]. (TA.) And jaAraAhu famaA xaT-a gubaArahu ‡ He contended with him in running, and did not cleave his dust. (JK, Ṣ,* A, L.)

xaT-a Qll-ehu nawoCahaA [God made its (a land's) rain-giving star or asterism (see nawoCN) to pass it over: or may God make, &c.]: from xaTiyTapN signifying “a land not rained upon between two lands that have been rained upon:” (Ṣ, TA:*) it was said by I’Ab [in a tropical sense, by way of imprecation, with reference to a woman], when he was asked respecting a man who had put the affair of his wife in her own hand and she had in consequence divorced him by a triple sentence: (Ṣ:) accord. to one relation, it is xaT-aOa; the meaning being “may he make its rain to miss it:” (Ṣ, TA:) and accord. to another, xaT-aI↓, originally xaT-aTa, like taqaD-aI AlbaAziI: the former, or first, is the weaker, or weakest, in authority, of these relations. (TA. [See also 2 in art. xTO.])
2. xT-T, inf. n. taxoTiyTN, [He marked with lines, streaks, or stripes. Also] He wove a piece of cloth with lines, streaks, or stripes. (KL.) And He drew lines well and elegantly. (KL.)
See also 1, in two places, in the latter half of the paragraph.
4: see 8, in three places.

8. AxtT- AlxiT-apa, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or AxtT-hA linafosihi, (Ṣ,) He took the xiT-ap [q. v.] to himself, and (Ḳ) made a mark upon it, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in order to its being known that he had chosen it to build there a house; (Ṣ, TA;) as also xaT-ahaA↓; (as in some copies of the Ḳ;) or AxT-hA↓; (as in other copies of the Ḳ, and as in the TA;) and xaT-ahaA↓ linafosihi: (TA:) and he alighted and took up his abode in the xiT-ap, none having done so before him; as also xaT-ahaA↓ linafosihi. (Ḳ.) [And hence, AxtT- signifies also He founded a town or the like.]

AxtT- wajohuhu ‡ His face became marked with lines [app. by the growth of his beard]; (Ḳ, TA;) as also xaT-a↓; (Ḳ, L, TA;) or xuT-a↓; (JK;) or AxT-↓: (CK:) or ‡ the hair of his beard extended [so as to form lines] upon the two sides of his face. (A, TA.)
AxtT- AlgulaAmu ‡ The two sides of the boy's, or young man's, beard grew forth; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, TA;) as also xaT-a↓; or AxT-↓. (Ḳ, accord. to different copies.)

xaT-N A line, streak, or stripe; in, or upon, a thing: (Ḳ:) pl. xuTuwTN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OaxoTaATN; (Ḳ;) the latter, [a pl. of pauc.,] used by El-ʼAjjáj: (TA:) and xuT-apN↓ is [syn. with xaT-N as explained above, being] a subst. form [the inf. n.] AlxaT-u, like as nuqoTapN is from Aln-aqoTu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) you say, EalaI Zahori AlHimaAri xuT-ataAni↓ Upon the back of the ass are two lines, or streaks, differing in colour from the rest of the body. (TA.)
[In mathematics, A line. And hence, xaT-u AlAisotiwaMCi The equinoctial line.]

A slight track, or path, or road, in plain, or smooth, or soft, ground: pl. as above. (Ḳ.) And A road, or path: (Th, Ḳ:) as in the saying, Ailozamo celika AlxaT-a walaA taZolimo minohu XayoYFA [Keep thou to that road, or path, and do not deviate from it at all]:
or in this sense the word is xuT-N↓. (TA.) Also A road, or way, or street, that is a common thoroughfare; and so xuT-N↓. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
‡ [A streak, or stripe, of herbage.] You say, AlkalaOu xuTuwTN fiI AlOaroDi ‡ The herbage consists of streaks, or stripes, upon the ground; the rain not having watered the country in common. (L, TA.)
Writing, and the like. (TA.) [Handwriting. Character; or particular form of letters.]
[See also 1.]
xuT-N: see xaT-N, in two places.
The place of the tribe. (AA, Ḳ.)
xiT-N: see xiT-apN:
and see also xaTiyTN, in two places.
xuT-apN: see xaT-N, in two places.

Also An affair: a matter: a case: an event: a state, or condition: syn. OamorN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and qiS-apN: (Ṣ:) or the like of qiS-apN: (JK, Ḳ:) and xaTobN: and HaAlN: (TA:) or HaAlapN: (Mṣb:) or, as some say, a dubious affair, of great magnitude or moment, to accomplish which, or to perform which, one finds not the way: (Ḥar p. 436:) and a quality, or property. (Mṣb.) You say, sumotuhu xuT-apa xasofK [I required, or constrained, him to do an affair of difficulty; or to become in a state of abasement, or ignominy]: and xuT-apa suwoCK [an evil affair]. (L.) And huwayukal-ifuniI xuT-apF mina Alxasofi [He requires, or constrains, me to do an affair of difficulty;, &c.]. (JK. [See also xasofN.]) And it is said in a trad., of Keyleh, OayulaAmu Qbonu hecihi Oano yafoSila AlxuT-apa wayanotaSira mino waraMCi AlHajazapi [Is the son of this woman to be blamed for deciding the affair, or matter, or case,, &c., and defending himself in the absence of the wrongdoers who would prevent his obtaining his right; or, of those who defend men, one from another, and decide between them justly?]: i. e., when a dubious event, to the encountering of which he does not find the right way, befalls him, that he should not care for it, but decide it so as to settle it and extricate himself from it. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also HaAjizN.] Also, in a trad. respecting El-Hodeybiyeh, laAyasoOluwniI xuT-apF yuEaZ-imuwna fiyhaA HurumaAti Qll-ehi taEaAlaI Uil-aA OaEoTiyotuhumo Uiy-aAhaA [They shall not ask of me a matter wherein they honour the sacred things of God, (exalted be He,) but I will grant it to them]. (TA.) And in the same, qado EaraDa Ealayokumo xuT-apa ruXodK faQqobaluwhaA He hath proposed to you a case of evident rectitude; therefore do ye accept it. (TA.) And Taäbbatasharrà says,
humaA xaT-ataA Uim-aA UisaArN wamin-apN
waUim-aA damN waAlqatolu biAlHur-i Oajodaru
[They are two case; either bondage and reproach, or else blood; and slaughter is more befitting to the free, or ingenuous]: he means xuT-ataAni. (Ṣ. [See Ḥam p. 34.])

Also A course: as in the phrase xuT-apN naAYiyapN A distant, or far-extending, course. (Ṣ, TA.) You say also, xuco xuT-apF, i. e. xuco xuT-apa AlAinotiSaAfi [Take thou the course of exacting thy right, or due, with equity]; meaning AinotaSifo [exact thou thy right, or due, with equity]. (Ṣ.)

A proof; an evidence; a testimony; an argument; a plea; or an allegation; syn. Huj-apN. (O, TA.) So in the phrase, Oaqimo EalaI hecaA AlOamori bixuT-apK [app. Establish thou a proof,, &c., against this thing, or case]; as is said in the “Nawádir.” (TA.)

An object of want which one has determined to accomplish: as in the saying, jaMCa wafiI raOosihi xuT-apN He came having in his mind [lit. his head] an object of want, &c.: [but see the last sentence in this paragraph:] the vulgar say xuTobapN: (Ṣ, L:) the former is the word used by the Arabs: (L:) the latter, however, occurs in the “Nawádir” of AZ; therefore the attribution of it to the vulgar demands consideration. (TA.)
Boldness to undertake affairs. (Ḳ.)
Ignorance. (Ḳ.) You say, fiI raOosihi xuT-apN In his head is ignorance: or, as some say, some affair: and it has another meaning explained above. (TA.)
[Hence,] fulaAnN bay-inN xiTaTi AlmakaArimi ‡ [Such a one exhibits in himself the marks of generous, or honourable, qualities]. (TA.)
xaTuwTN A wild bull, (Ṣ, L,) and any beast, (L,) that marks the ground with the extremities of his hoofs. (Ṣ, L.)

waAdN xaTiyTN [A valley not rained upon]. (AO, TA voce xaTowapN, q. v.) And xaTiyTapN [or OaroDN xaTiyTapN] Land not rained upon; (TA;) as also xiT-N↓: (Ḳ:) or land not rained upon between two lands that have been rained upon: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or land of which part has been rained upon, (Ḳ, TA,) and part has not: (TA:) or land not rained upon surrounded by land that has been rained upon; (ISh;) as also ↓the latter word: (AḤn:) pl. of the former, xaTaAYiTu. (Ṣ.)

Hence the saying of a certain Arab, to his son, Ailozamo xaTiyTapa Alc-ul-i maxaAfapa maA huwa OaXad-u minohu ‡ [Keep thou to the condition of abasement in fear of what is more grievous than it]. (IAạr, M.)
xaTiyTapN also signifies A strip of ground differing in roughness and smoothness from what is on either side of it: pl. as above. (L.)
xaT-aATN A practiser of what is termed Eilomu AlxaT-i [or geomancy]. (Lth.)
[Also A practiser of the art of writing:] a caligraphist. (KL.)

rimaAHN xaT-iy-apN Spears of El-Khatt; so called from AlxaT-u, a place in El-Yemámeh, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) also called xaT-u hajarK, (Ṣ,) because they are brought thither (Ṣ, Mṣb) from India, (Ṣ,) and straightened in that place, (Ṣ, Mṣb,*) which is a coast for ships; not that the canes grow there: (Mṣb:) or they are so called from AlxaT-u which is the station for ships in El-Bahreyn, because they are sold there; not that it is the place of their growth: this place is also called AlxiT-u: (Ḳ:) but this demands consideration; for it is said [in the ʼEyn, i. e.] by Lth, (TA,) or by Kh, (Mṣb,) that when you convert the rel. n. into a subst., you say xiTiy-apN↓, (Mṣb, TA,) with kesr to the x, (Mṣb,) without rmAH, like as you say, viyaAbN qiboTiy-apN, (Mṣb, TA,) with kesr, (Mṣb,) but when you convert the rel. n. into a subst., you say, quboTiy-apN, (Mṣb, TA,) with damm, to distinguish the subst. from the rel. n., without vyAb: (Mṣb:) a single spear of this kind is called rumoHN xaT-iI-N: (TA:) AḤn says that AlxaT-iI-u signifies the spears; and that it is a rel. n. used in the manner of a proper name; being a rel. n. from AlxaT-u, which is xaT-u AlbaHorayoni, where ships moor when they come from India. (TA.)
xiT-iy-apN: see the next preceding paragraph.
OaxaT-u † Delicate in beauties. (IAạr.) [See also muxaT-aTN.]
maxaT-N [A place marked with a line or lines, with a streak or streaks, or with a stripe or stripes]. (TA in art. Tr.)

mixaT-N A wooden instrument with which one makes lines or marks or the like: (Ṣ:) or the wooden instrument with which the weaver makes lines or marks or the like, in, or upon, a piece of cloth. (L, Ḳ.)
muxaT-aTN A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, (Ṣ, TA,) and a date, and a wild animal, (TA,) or anything, (Ḳ, TA,) marked with lines, streaks, or stripes. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
‡ Beautiful; (Ḳ, TA;) applied to a boy [whose hair of his beard has appeared upon the sides of his face, forming lines]; as also muxotaT-N↓ [originally muxotaTiTN: see 8]. (TA.)
mixoTaATN [A wooden ruler;] an instrument of wood by means of which lines are made even. (Ṣ, O.)
maxoTuwTN A book or the like written in, or upon. (TA.)
muxotaT-N: see muxaT-aTN.

hom.sense: 1. xaTiYa is syn. with AxTO↓, inf. n. UixoTaMCN and xaATiYapN↓, (Ḳ,) which latter, mentioned by AAF, on the authority of AZ, is extr. in the case of a triliteral [unaugmented] verb, and more so in the case of a quadriliteral [i. e. a triliteral augmented by one letter]; (TA;) and with txT-O↓; signifying He did wrong; or committed a mistake, or an error: (Ḳ:) [and if this and similar explanations be correct, xaTaOo may be an inf. n. of the first of these verbs, and a quasi-inf. n. of the second and third:] or AxTO↓ and txT-O↓ have this signification: (Ṣ:) and xaTiYa, aor. _a {yaxoTaOu}, inf. n. xiToCN and xiToOapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) signifies he committed a sin, a crime, or an act of disobedience for which he deserved punishment: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or he committed a fault or an offence or an act of disobe dience [in an absolute sense]: (Ḳ,* TA:) or, accord. to AO, (Mṣb,) or A' Obeyd, (TA,) xaTiYa, inf. n. xiToCN, signifies he committed a fault, an offence, or an act of disobedience, unintentionally; as also AxTO↓: (Mṣb, TA:) or, as others say, xaTiYa means [he committed a fault,, &c.,] in religion; and AxTO↓, in anything; intentionally or unintentionally: (Mṣb:) xaTiYa, in religion; and AxTO↓, in calculation [&c.]: (Aṣ, M, TA:) or, accord. to Ibn-ʼArafeh, (TA,) you say, xaTiYa fiI diynihi, (Ḳ, TA, [in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ and in the CK,* fI canobihi,]) and AxTO↓, meaning he pursued a wrong way in his religion, intentionally or otherwise: (Ḳ, TA:) or xaTiYa signifies he committed an act of disobedience intentionally; (Mṣb, TA;) so accord. to the 'Ináyeh, and the like is said in the A; (TA;) and AxTO↓, he did wrong, meaning to do right: (Az, Mṣb, TA:) [and this distinction is agreeable with general usage:] accord. to AHeyth, you say, xaTiYota bimaA SanaEotuhu [Thou didst wrong, in that which thou didst,] intentionally; and OaxoTaOota maA SanaEotahu↓ [or bimaA SnEtp or fiymaA SnEth Thou didst wrong, in that which thou didst,] unintentionally. (TA.)
See also 4, in two places.
xaTaOati Alqidoru bizabadihaA, aor. _a {yaxoTaOu}, ‡ The cooking-pot threw up its froth, or foam, or scum, (Ḳ, TA,) in boiling. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. xT-Ohu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxoTiYapN and taxoTiIoCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He said to him, OaxoTaOota [meaning Thou hast done wrong, or committed a mistake or an error]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he pronounced him, or asserted him, to be doing wrong, or committing a mistake or an error. (Mṣb.) You say, Uino OaxoTaOotu faxaT-iYoniI [If I do wrong,, &c., tell me that I have done so]. (Ṣ.)

Also He made it to miss: so in the saying, xaT-aOa Qll-ehu nawoCahaA God made, or may God make, its [i. e. a land's] star, or asterism, to miss; so that the rain which the star or asterism should have brought did not, or shall not, fall upon it. (TA.) This was [also] said by I’Ab [in a tropical sense] with reference to a woman, as an imprecation, in disapproval of her conduct. (Mgh.) As some relate this saying, the verb is xaT-aI, (Mgh, TA,) and the meaning, God made, or may God make, its [rain-giving] star or asterism, to pass it over, and not send rain upon it: and in this case it may be, (TA,) or it is, (Mgh,) from xaTiyTapN, signifying “a land not rained upon (Mgh, TA) between two lands that have been rained upon;” (Mgh;) the verb being originally xaT-aTa, and the final T being changed into I. (Mgh, TA. [See art xT.]) nawoC is [here] the sing. of OanowaMCN meaning the “Mansions of the Moon,” also called the “stars, or asterisms, of rain.” (Mgh.) [See more in the first paragraph of art. xT: and see also 4 in the present art.] Accord. to Fr, xaT-aI Als-ahoma and xaT-aOahu are syn. [as meaning He made the arrow to pass over, or to miss, the mark]. (TA.) One says also, xuT-iYu Eanoka Als-uwoCu [May evil be made to miss thee;] i. e. may evil be repelled from thee. (ISk.) And xaT-aOa Eanoka Als-uwoCu [app. for taxaT-aOa↓] Evil missed thee, or may evil miss thee. (AZ.)

hom.sense: 4. AxTO, inf. n. UixoTaMCN and xaATiYapN: see 1, in eight places. OaxoTayotu, for OaxoTaOotu, should not be said: (Ṣ:) it is a word of weak authority; or a mispronunciation: (Ḳ:) but some use it; (Ṣ, Ṣgh, TA;) because a change of this kind is generally allowed by some of the writers on inflection. (TA.) See also 5.

AxTOhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which signifies, He [or it] missed, or failed of hitting, it [or him], (TA,) and txATOhu↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and txT-Ohu↓ (Ḳ) and txT-O↓ lahu (TA) [and xaTiYahu↓, as will be seen from what follows,] are syn. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) [See also 2, last sentence.] You say, AxTO Alr-aAmiI AlgaraDa The archer, or thrower, missed the mark; or failed of hitting it. (TA.) And AxTOhu Als-ahomu The arrow [missed it, or him, or] passed beyond it, or him: and you may also say, OaxoTaAhu, suppressing the C (Mṣb.) And AxTO AlT-ariyqa [He missed the way; or] he deviated from the way. (TA.) And AxTO nawoWuhu [† His star, or asterism, missed]; said of him who has sought an object of want and not succeeded in attaining it: (TA:) and to a person in this case one says, AxTO nawoWuka [† Thy star, or asterism, has missed]. (Mgh. [See also 2.]) And AxTOhu The right, or due, was, or became, [out of his reach,] or far from him. (Mṣb.) Owfà Ibn-Matar El-Mázinee says,
taxaATaOati↓ Aln-abolu OaHoXaMCahu
[meaning The arrows missed his bowels]. (Ṣ.) And AO, (Ṣ,) or A' Obeyd, (TA,) says that xaTiYa↓ and AxTO are syn.; citing, as an ex., the saying of Imra-el-Ḳeys,
yaA lahofa hinodK Uico xaTiYona kaAhilaA , (Ṣ, TA,) meaning [O the grief of Hind,] when they (the troop of horse) missed the sons of Káhil; (TA;) xTYn being here used in the sense of OaxoTaOona, (Ṣ, TA,) which latter, accord. to Az, is the more proper in this case. (TA.)
maA OaxoTaOahu is an expression of wonder [meaning How sinful, or criminal, or intentionally-disobedient, or intentionally-wrongdoing, is he!] from xaTiYa, not from OaxoTaOa. (Ṣ.)
5: see 1, in two places:
and see also 2, last sentence; and 4, in two places.
txT-O lahu fiI AlmasoOalapi He addressed to him the question with the desire of causing him to make a mistake: (TA:) or i. q. OaxoTaOa↓. (Ṣ.)
taxaT-uWN also signifies The feigning a wrong action, a mistake, or an error. (KL. [See also 6.])
And The charging another with a wrong action, a mistake, or an error. (KL. [See also 2.])
6. txATO He imputed to himself a wrong action, a mistake, or an error, not having committed any. (KL. [See also 5.])
See also 4, in two places.

entry.sense: 10. AstxTOt She (a camel) did not conceive, or become pregnant. (TA. [See also the part. n., below.])
xaToCN: see xaTaON.
xiToCN: see xaTiyoYapN.

xaTaON A wrong action; a mistake, or an error; contr. of SawaAbN; as also xaTaMCN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xaToCN↓: (Ḳ:) accord. to some, it is syn. with xaTiyoYapN and xiToCN; and is an inf. n. used as a simple subst; but accord. to others, (TA,) it signifies an unintentional fault or offence or disobedience; (Ḳ, TA;) a subst. from OaxoTaOa: (M, Mṣb: [see 1, first sentence:]) and accord. to the M, xaTaMCN↓ is a subst. from xaTiY [and therefore syn. with xaTiyoYapN accord. to the general acceptation of xaTiYa]. (TA.)
xTOp [so in the TA, app. xaToOapN,] A land which the rain misses, while it falls upon another near it. (TA. [See 2.])
xaTaMCN: see xaTaON, in two places.

xaTiyoYapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xaTiy-apN, a change of this kind being allowable in this and in similar cases, (Ṣ, TA,) A fault, an offence, or an act of disobedience; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or such as is intentional; (Ḳ;) like xiToCN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which is an inf. n., thus used as a subst.; (Mṣb;) meaning a sin, a crime, or an act of disobedience for which one deserves punishment: (Ṣ:) pl. xaTaAyaA, (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) originally xaTaAYiYu; (Lth, Ṣ;) and xaTaAYiI also, (Ḳ, TA, [in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ xaTaAYiYu,]) or this is [anomalous and] incorrect, unless with the art. Al, being otherwise xaTaMCN; (MF;) and xaTaAYiI-u, [an anomalous pl.,] of which Th gives an ex. in the following verse, related to him by IAạr;
likul-i QmoriYK maA qad-amato nafosuhu lahu
xaTaAYiy-uhaA Uino OaxoTaOato waSawaAbuhaA
[For every man is appointed, in the world to come, the recompense of what his soul has prepared, or laid up in store, for him, its wrong actions, if it have done wrong; and its right action]. (L.)

xaTiyoYapN yawomN and xaTiyoYapN layolapN are expressions like TiylN yawomN and TiylN layolapN: you say, xaTiyoYapN yawomN yamur-u biI Uil-aA OaraI fiyhi fulaAnFA [app. meaning It were a crime that a day should pass with me without my seeing in it such a one; or perhaps, it is a rare event that a day passes with me, &c.: see what follows]. (TA.)

A little, or small quantity; or a few, or small number; of anything. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, EalaI Aln-xolapi xaTiyoYapN mino waHoXK [Upon the palm-tree are a few fresh ripe dates]: and xaT-aMCN [In the land of the sons of such a one is] a small number of wild animals that have missed their [wonted] places and are in what are not their accustomed places. (TA.)
xaATiYN A man who constantly adheres to faults, offences, sins, crimes, or acts of disobedience for which he deserves punishment. (TA.)

xaATiYN Intentionally doing that which is not right; (El-Umawee, Ṣ;) intentionally pursuing a wrong way in his religion; (Ḳ;) intentionally doing that which he is forbidden to do. (Mṣb.) [See xaTiYa, of which it is the part. n.]

[Also Missing the mark. Hence the saying,] maEa AlxawaATiYi sahomN SaAYibN [With those that miss is an arrow that goes right, or hits the mark]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) xawaATiYu being pl. of xaATiYapN, meaning that misses the butt: (Ḥar p. 481:) a prov., (Ṣ,) applied to him who frequently errs, but sometimes does right; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or to the niggard who sometimes gives notwithstanding his niggardliness. (AʼObeyd.)
xaATiYapN: see 1, first sentence.
muxoTiYN [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.;] One who does wrong, meaning to do right. (El-Umawee, Ṣ.)

[mataxaT-iIN signifies the same as mutaxaT-K, or nearly so: and hence the saying,] naAqatuka mina AlmutaxaT-iYaAti Aljyf, (TA in the present art.,) or naAqatuka hecihi mina AlmutaxaT-iyaAti Aljyf, [the last word being app. Aljiyafa, and the lit. meaning, Thy she-camel, or this thy she-camel, is of those that step over the carcasses;] i. e. she is hardy and strong, such as will go on, and leave behind [others that have fallen down and died] (txlf [so in the TA, app.tuxal-ifu,]) until she [herself] has fallen down (AlI mO sqTt). (AZ, TA in art. xTw.)
musotaxoTiYapN, applied to a she-camel, ‡ i. q. HaAYilN [i. e. Not conceiving, or not becoming pregnant during a year, or two years, or some years;, &c.: see its verb, 10]. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xaTaba, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or xaTaba xuTobapF, (A,) aor. _u {yaxoTubu}, (TA,) inf. n. xuTobapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or this, accord. to some, is a subst. used as an inf. n., (TA,) and xaTaAbapN, (Ḳ,) said of a xaTiyb (A) or xaATib, (Ḳ,) [He recited a xuTobap (q. v. infrà),] EalaI Alminobari [upon the pulpit]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AxtTb↓. (Ṣ.) And xaTaba Alqawoma, (Mṣb,) and EalaI Alqawomi, (Th, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaxoTubu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xuTobapN, (Th, Mṣb,) [He recited a xuTobap to the people, and over the people, i. e. on the pulpit, beneath which they sat: or] he delivered an exhortation, or admonition, to the people. (Mṣb.)

xaTaba AlmaroOapa, (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. xiTobapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and xaTobN (Lḥ, Ḳ) and xiT-iybaI; (T, Ṣ,* Ḳ;) and AxtTbhA↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He asked, or demanded, the woman in marriage. (Mṣb.) In the following verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, respecting Jedheemeh El-Abrash, and his asking in marriage Ez-Zebbà,
lixiT-iybaI Al-atiI gadarato waxaAnato
wahun-a cawaAtu gaAYilapK luHiynaA
[For the asking in marriage of her who acted perfidiously and treacherously: for they (i. e. women) are possessed of secret malevolence: may they be disgraced and accursed:] xT-ybI is syn. with xiTobap: (Ṣ:) accord. to Lth, it is a simple subst.; but AM says that he is in error, and that it is an inf. n. (TA.) You say also, xaTaba AlmaroOapa UilaI Alqawomi He asked, or demanded, the woman in marriage, of the people. (Mṣb.) And xaTaba UilaI fulaAnK [He asked, or demanded, a woman in marriage, of such a one]. (TA.) And xaTaba EalaI xiTobapi Oaxiyhi He asked, or demanded, a woman in marriage, when another had done so, and she had inclined to the latter, and he and she had agreed to a certain dowry, and had approved each other, and nothing remained but to conclude the contract; the doing of which is forbidden: but it is not forbidden to ask in marriage a woman when another has done so if she and the latter have not agreed, nor approved each other, nor has either of them inclined to the other. (TA.)
fulaAnN yaxoTubu Eamala kacaA ‡ Such a one seeks, or desires, to do such a thing. (A, TA.)
xaTuba, [aor. _u {yaxoTubu},] inf. n. xaTaAbapN, He became a xaTiyb (Ṣ.)
xaTiba, aor. _a {yaxoTabu}, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaTabN, (Ṣ, TA,) He, or it, was, or became, of the colour termed xuTobapN: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) or his, or its, colour was, or became, what is thus termed. (JK.)

entry.sense: 3. xATbhu, (A, Mṣb, TA,) or xATbhu biAlkalaAmi, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. muxaATabapN and xiTaAbN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He talked, spoke, conversed, or discoursed, with him; held a colloquy, dialogue, conversation, or discourse, with him: (Mṣb, TA:) he talked to him, spoke to him, or addressed him, face to face; accosted him with speech or words. (A.) [Hence,] Harofu xiTaAbK [A particle of allocution]: such is the t in Oanota and Oanoti, (Mughnee and Ḳ on the letter t,) and such is the k in caAka, &c. (I’Aḳ p. 36;, &c.)
He consulted with him. (TA.)

faSolu AlxiTaAbi [as used in the Ḳur xxxviii. 19] means The deciding a case, or passing sentence, or judging, with evident demonstration, or proof; or by testimony confirmed by oath: (Ḳ, TA:) or the deciding between truth and falsehood, and distinguishing between just judgment and the contrary thereof: (TA:) or understanding, intelligence, sagacity, or knowledge, in judging or passing sentence: or the pronouncing the phrase Oam-aA baEodu, (Ḳ, TA,) which David [it is said] was the first to utter, and which means, accord. to Abu-l- ʼAbbás, Now, after these preliminary words, [I proceed to say] thus and thus; (TA;) or this last phrase means after my prayer for thee; (Ḳ in art. bEd;) or after praising God. (TA in art. bEd [See also art. fSl.])

hom.sense: 4: see 2.
[Accord. to the KL, UixoTaAbN signifies The inviting one for the purpose of marriage: but I think it is only AixotiTaAbN that has this signification.]

OaxoTabaka AlS-ayodu ‡ The game, or object of the chase, has become within thy power, or reach; (Ṣ, A;) and has become near thee; (Ṣ;) faQromihi [therefore shoot it, or cast at it]. (A.) And AxTbk AlOamoru ‡ The thing, or affair, has become within thy power, or reach. (JK, A.*)
AxTb, said of the colocynth, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) It became striped with green: (JK, Ḳ:) or it became yellow, with green stripes. (Ṣ.) And AxTbti AlHinoTapu The wheat became coloured. (TA.)

entry.sense: 6. txATbA They two talked, spoke, conversed, or discoursed, each with the other; held a colloquy, dialogue, conversation, or discourse, each with the other. (TA.) [Hence, Eurofu Alt-axaATubi The generally-known, generally-received, or conventional, language of conversation.]
8: see 1, in two places.
AixotaTabuwhu They invited him to marry a woman of their family: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or they invited him to ask, or demand, in marriage, a woman of their family. (AZ,* A. [See also 4.])

xaTobN ‡ A thing, an affair, or a business, (A, Ḳ, MF,) small or great, (Ḳ,) that one seeks, or desires, to do, (A,) syn. OamorN maxoTuwbN, (Ḥam p. 33,) or that is, or may be, a subject of discourse: this is the primary signification: (MF:) or a great thing or affair: or a thing, or an affair, that is disliked; not one that is liked: or that is liked also: (Ḥam p.127:) or the cause, or occasion, of a thing or an event: (JK, Ṣ:) or an affliction; a calamity: (Mṣb:) [often used in this last sense in the present day:] and a state, or condition: (TA:) pl. xuTuwbN; (A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) for which xuTub is used in a verse below. (TA.) You say, maAxaTobuka ‡ What is the thing, or affair, or business, that thou seekest, or desirest, to do? (A:) or what is thy cause [of coming, &c.]? (Ṣ.) xaTobN yasiyrN and jaliylN ‡ [A little, or an unimportant, and a great, or an important, thing or affair]. (A.) And huwa yuqaAsiI xuTuwba Ald-ahori ‡ [He endures, or he contends, or struggles, with, or against, the afflictions, or calamities, of fortune]. (A.) El-Akhtal says,
kalamoEi OayodiI mavaAkiyla musal-ibapK
yanodubona Darosa banaAti Ald-ahori waAlxuTubi
† [Like the wavings of the hands of mothers bereft of many children, in mourning on account of them, bewailing the biting cruelty of the daughters of misfortune and afflictions]: using AlxuTubi for AlxuTuwbi. (L.)
xuTobN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

xiTobN A man who asks, or demands, a woman in marriage; (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ;*) as also xuTobN↓ (MF) and xaATibN↓ (A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xiT-iybN↓: pl. of the first OaxoTaAbN, (Ḳ,) and of the second xuT-aAbN, (A,) and of the last xiT-iybuwna. (Ḳ.) You say, huwaxiTobuhaA [and xaATibuhaA↓] and xiT-iybuhaA↓ He is her asker, or demander, in marriage. (Ḳ,* TA.) It was a custom, in the Time of Ignorance, for a man to stand up and to say xiTobN, (A, Ḳ,*) and xuTobN↓, (Ḳ,) meaning I am an asker, or demander, in marriage; (MF;) and he who desired to give to him in marriage would reply nikoHN, (A, Ḳ,*) and nukoHN, (Ḳ,) [meaning I am “a giver in marriage,”] and thus marriage was effected: there was a woman among them, called Umm-Khárijeh, and the man who asked her in marriage used to stand at the door of her tent, and say, xiTobN; and she used to reply, nikoHN; (Ṣ,* TA;) and hence the prov, OasoraEu mino nikaAHi Oum-i xaArijapa [Quicker than the marriage of Umm-Khárijeh]. (TA.)

Also A woman asked, or demanded, in marriage; (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ;*) and so xiTobapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xuTobapN↓ (Kr, Ḳ) and xiT-iybapN↓ (A, Ḳ) and xiT-iybaI↓ [which is also an inf. n.: see 1]: (Ḳ:) or this last signifies a woman often asked, or demanded, in marriage. (JK.) You say, hiIa xiTobuhu and xiTobatuhu↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ), &c. (Ḳ) She is the person asked, or demanded, in marriage by him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

hom.sense: xuTobapN, a word of the measure fuEolapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN, like nusoxapN in the sense of manosuwxapN, and gurofapN mina AlmaMCi in the sense of magoruwfapN; meaning An exhortation or admonition [recited by a xaTiyb]: (Mṣb:) a form of words, a discourse, a sermon, a speech, an oration, or a harangue, which the xaTiyb recites on the pulpit: (Ḳ,* TA:) [in the noon-service of the congregational mosque on Friday, the xTyb recites two forms of words, each of which is thus termed: the former chiefly consists of expressions of praise to God, blessings on Moḥammad and his family and companions, and exhortation to the congregation; and is termed xuTobapu AlwaEoZi: the latter, of praise to God, exhortation, blessings on Moḥammad and his family and companions, and prayer for the Muslims in general, and especially for the Sovereign; and is termed xuTobapu Aln-aEoti: (see my “Modern Egyptians,” ch. iii.:)] or, [accord. to its original signification,] with the [Pagan] Arabs, a discourse, a speech, an oration, or a harangue, [generally applied to one delivered in public,] in rhyming prose; and the like: (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, Ḳ:) or the old Arabian xuTobap, in the Pagan and the early Muslim ages, was, in most instances, not in rhyming prose; and the term “prose,” as here used, does not exclude what contains poetry introduced by way of testimony and the like: (MF:) or [a tract, or small treatise or discourse,] like a risaAlap, which [is complete in itself, or, in other words,] has a beginning and an end: (T, TA:) the pl. is xuTabN: (Mṣb:) and maxaATibu↓, occurring in the following words of a trad., mino Oaholi AlmaHaAXidi waAlmaxaATibi, meaning of those who congregate, and harangue people, exciting them to go forth and assemble for seditious purposes, is said to be used in the same sense as xuTab, and to be a pl. [of xuTobapN], contr. to rule, like maXaAbihu [pl. of XabahN] and malaAmiHu [pl. of lamoHapN]: or it is pl. of maxoTabapN↓, which is syn. with xuTobapN: (TA:) or it [is pl. of maxoTabN↓, and] signifies places of haranguing. (L in art. HXd.) You say, xaTaba AlxaTiybu↓ xuTobapF HasanapF [The xTyb recited a beautiful xTbp]. (A.)

Also A turbid, or dusky, colour, (Ḳ,) or a colour inclining to turbidness or duskiness, (TA,) mixed with yellowish red; (Ḳ, TA;) like the colour of wheat before it dries, and that of some wild asses: (TA:) and a green [app. here meaning a dark, or an ashy, dust-] colour: (TA:) or a dust-colour suffused with xuDorap: [or a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour: see OaxoTabu:] (A, Ḳ:) or xuDorap mixed with black. (TA.)

The saying, Oanota AlOaxoTabu↓ Albay-inu AlxuTobapi, which might be imagined to ascribe to the person addressed perspicuity, or eloquence, in his xuTobap, really means Thou art [the asinine;] he who bears evidence of AlHimaAriy-ap [i. e. asinineness]. (A.)
xiTobapN an inf. n. of xaTaba AlmaroOapa: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or a simple subst. (Mṣb.)
See also xiTobN, in two places.

entry.sense: xuTobaAnN, and xuTobaAnapN: see OaxoTabu, in four places.

The former is also the name of A certain plant, (Ḳ,) of the most bitter of herbs, (TA,) resembling the hiloyawon [or asparagus], (Ḳ,) or like the tails of serpents, with thin extremities resembling [in colour] the violet, or blacker; the part next below being green; and the part next below that, to the roots, white: whence the saying, Oamar-u mina AlxuTobaAni [More bitter than the xTbAn]; in which xTbAn has been erroneously said to be pl. of OaxoTabu, like as suwdaAnN is pl. of Oasowadu (TA.)
xiTobaAnN: see OaxoTabu
Oaworaqu xuTobaAniI-N [Of a dusky colour, inclining to black, in a great degree; or very dusky]: the latter word is added to give intensiveness to the signification. (Ḳ.)

xaTiyb-N [A speaker; generally a public speaker; an orator; a preacher;] a reciter of a xuTobap, (A, Mṣb, TA,) [and particularly] on the pulpit; (TA;) i. q. xaATibN↓ [in these senses; but the latter is generally used in another sense, explained above, voce xiTobN]: (Ṣ, TA:) or one who recites a xuTobap well; (Ḳ, TA;) [a good speaker or orator:] pl. xuTabaMCu. (Mṣb, TA.) See xuTobapN. You say also, huwa xaTiybu Alqawomi, meaning He is the speaker for the people or party. (Mṣb.)
xiTaAbapN The office of a xaTiyb of a mosque. (TA.)
xaT-aAbN A man practised in, or accustomed to, the asking, or demanding, women in marriage. (Ḳ,* Mṣb, TA.)
xiT-iybN: see xiTobN, in two places.
xiT-iybapN: see xiTobN.
xiT-iybaI: see xiTobN.
xaATibN: see xiTobN, in two places:
and see also xaTiybN.
OaxoTabu Of the colour termed xuTobapN. (Ḳ.)

An ass, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) i. e. a wild ass, (TA,) of a colour tinged with xuDorap [here meaning a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or of a dustcolour suffused with xuDorap: (A:) or having a black line, or stripe, along the middle of the back: (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) fem. xaTobaMCu, applied to a she-ass; (Fr, Ṣ;) and likewise to a she-camel. (Ṣ, A.)
See also xuTobapN.
HamaAmapN xaTobaMCu AlqamiySi [A pigeon of the colour termed xuTobapN]. (A.)

yadN xaTobaMCu, (Ḳ,) and OanaAmilu xuTobN, (TA, [xuTobN being the pl.,]) [A hand, and fingers' ends,] of which the darkness of the dye imparted by Hin-aMC has faded: (Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner the epithet [OaxoTabu] is sometimes applied to the hair. (TA.) One says also AimoraOapN xaTobaMCu AlX-afatayoni [A woman pale in the lips; whose lips have lost their deep red hue]. (A.)

HanoZalN OaxoTabu, (Ḳ,) or xuTobaAnN↓, (Ṣ,) Colocynths that are yellow, (Ṣ,) with green stripes: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) fem. (applied to a single colocynth, which is termed HanoZalapN, TA) xaTobaMCu, with which xuTobaAnapN↓ is syn.: the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of this last [or pl. of OaxoTabu] is xuTobaAnN↓, and xiTobaAnN↓, which is extr. [with respect to rule]. (Ḳ.) And xuTobaAnN↓ ( a pl. of OaxoTabu, JK) also signifies Green leaves of the samur. (JK, Ḳ.)

AlOaxoTabu The [bird called] Xaqir-aAq; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) called in Persian, accord. to a marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ, kaAsokiynapo: (TA:) or the [bird called] Surad; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because it has a mixture of black and white. (TA.)
And The Saqor [or hawk]. (Ḳ.)
And A certain creeping thing (duwayob-ap) of a green colour, longer than the locust, having six legs; called in Persian XX PAyh, and sbwXknk. (Mgh.)
OaxoTabaAnu a [proper] name of A certain bird; (Ḳ, TA;) so called because of a xuTobap, i. e. xuDorap, in its wings. (TA.)
maxoTabN: see xuTobapN.
maxoTabapN: see xuTobapN.
maxaATibu: see xuTobapN.

hom.sense:
1. xaTara bicanabihi, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) aor. _i {yaxoTiru} [in the CK, erroneously, _u,] inf. n. xaTorN and xaTaraAnN (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and xaTiyrN, (JK, Ḳ,) He (a camel, Ṣ, Mgh, or a stallion [camel], A, Ḳ) raised his tail time after time, and struck his thighs with it: (Ṣ:)
or lashed with it to the right and left: (Ḳ:) or moved about his tail: (A,* Mgh, TA:) the stallion does so in threatening, through pride; (T, TA;) or in fighting with others, as though threatening; (A;) or by reason of emaciation occasioned by severe drought; or by reason of sprightliness: but a she-camel, to inform the stallion that she has become pregnant. (TA.) You say also, gaTara bcnbh, aor. _i {yaxoTiru}: the g being a substitute for the x: (TA:) or each form may be original; but the latter is the less used. (IJ, TA.)

[Hence,] xaTara birumoHihi, (A,* Ḳ,) and bisayofihi, (Ḳ,) and biqaDiybihi, and bisawoTihi, (TA,) inf. n. xaTaraAnN, (Ḳ,) ‡ He moved his spear up and down, and his sword, (Ḳ, TA,) and his rod, and his whip. (TA.) A man does so with the spear when he walks between the two [opposing] ranks. (A.)

And xaTara biyadihi fiI maXoyihi ‡ [He moved his arm up and down in his walking]. (A.) And xaTara fiI miXoyatihi, (Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoTiru}, (TA,) inf. n. xaTaraAnN (Ḳ) and xaTiyrN, (TA,) † He moved his arms up and down in his mode of walking, (Ḳ, TA,) inclining his body from side to side at the same time. (TA.) And xaTara, aor. _i {yaxoTiru}, (TA,) inf. n. xaTaraAnN, (Ṣ,) † He (a man) shook himself in walking; (Ṣ;) and walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (Ṣ, TA.) Aljunodu yaxoTiruwna Hawola qaAYidihimo † [The troops strut around their leader] is said when they show their energy to their leader; and in like manner, when they assemble and equip themselves in war. (TA.)

And xaTara, aor. _i {yaxoTiru}, inf. n. xaTorN, † He (a man) raised his arm, or hand, with a stone which he lifted for the purpose of trying his strength, to cast, or throw, and shook the stone in lifting it. (TA.)

And xaTara biUiSobaEihi UilaI Als-amaMCi ‡ He moved his finger, [or raised it towards the sky,] in supplication. (A.) [This one does in the ordinary prayers, in uttering the profession of belief in the unity of God; raising the first finger only (of the right hand, which is placed on the thigh, while sitting on the left foot), and not the hand itself.]
And xaTara, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoTiru}, inf. n. xaTaraAnN, (Ṣ,) † It (a spear) quivered, vibrated, or shook: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or moved up and down previously to a thrusting with it. (Ṣ.)

xaTara bibaAliI, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and EalaI baAliI, (JK, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxoTuru} (Ṣ, ISd, IḲṭṭ, Mgh, Ḳ) and _i {yaxoTiru}, (ISd, IḲṭṭ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xuTuwrN, (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or xaTarN, (Mṣb,) and xaTaraAnN, (JK,) or this last is a mistranscription, (Mgh,) ‡ It bestirred itself in my mind: (A: [see xaATirN:]) or it moved my mind: (Mṣb:) or it occurred to my mind [absolutely, or] after I had forgotten it. (Ḳ.)

xaTara AlX-ayoTaAnu bayonahu wabayona qalobihi † The devil put vain suggestions into his mind. (TA.) xaTara Ald-ahoru xaTaraAnahu, (Ṣ,) or mino xaTaraAnihi, (TA,) ‡ [Fortune, or time, produced, or brought to pass, its events, or among its events such and such things]: a phrase like Darba Ald-ahoru DarabaAnahu, (Ṣ,) or mino DarabaAnihi. (T, A. [See art. Drb.])

xaTura, aor. _u {yaxoTuru}, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xuTuwrapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or xaTarN, (Mṣb,) ‡ He (a man, Ṣ, &c.) was, or became, eminent, noble, or of high rank, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or characterized by rank or station. (Ṣ, A.) And xaTara, [or this is probably a mistranscription for xaTura,] aor. _u {yaxoTuru}, inf. n. xaTarN and xuTuwrN, [or, more probably, xuTuwrapN,] † He was, or became, great in estimation, rank, or dignity, after having been little in respect thereof. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. xT-r, inf. n. taxoTiyrN, † He took, got, or won, a bet, wager, or stake. (L in art. ndb, and TA.)

3. xATr binafosihi, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and biqawomihi, (A,) inf. n. muxaATarapN; (TḲ;) and AxTr↓ bqwmh; (A;) He placed himself at the point of, or near to, destruction; perilled, imperilled, endangered, jeoparded, hazarded, or risked, himself; (Ṣ, A;) and his people or party: (A:) or xATr bnfsh signifies he did that in which fear predominated: (Mṣb:) or he caused himself to be on the brink of destruction or of attaining dominion. (Ḳ.) And xATr binafosihi wamaAlihi He threw himself and his property into destruction. (TA.) And AxTr↓ lahu kacaA He hazarded, or risked, to him such a thing. (L.) [See also 4, below.]
xAZrhu EalaI kacaA, (Ṣ, A,) or EalaI maAlK, (Mṣb,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He laid a bet, wager, or stake, with him, (Ṣ,* A, Mṣb,) for such a thing, (Ṣ, A,) or for property. (Mṣb.) [See, again, 4.]

hom.sense: 4. AxTrhu Qll-ehu bibaAliI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [and EalaI baAliI, (see 1,)] ‡ God caused it [to bestir itself in my mind: or to move my mind: or] to occur to my mind after I had forgotten it. (Ḳ.)
See also 3, in two places.

AxTrAlmaAla, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. UixoTaArN, (Mṣb,) ‡ He made the property a stake (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) between the parties betting. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And OaxoTara liI waOaxoTarotu lahu ‡ [He laid me a bet and I laid him a bet;] we laid bets, wagers, or stakes, one to another. (Ḳ. [See also 3.]) And AxTr Almawota nafosahu ‡ He made his soul a stake to death [by exposing it to be taken by death, like as a stake is taken by one of two parties who have betted]. (TA.) And AxTr [alone] ‡ He made himself, or his soul, a stake to his adversary, and sallied forth against him. (Ḳ.)
OaxoTarahumo xaTarFA and AxTr lahumo xaTarFA † He gave them liberally, or freely, a lot, portion, or share, or a compensation, such as contented them. (TA.)
AxTrhu He (God) made him to be characterized by rank, or station. (A.)

AxTr fulaAnN fulaAnFA † Such a one became like in rank, or station, to such a one. (Ḳ.) And OuxoTirotu lifulaAnK † I was made like to such a one in rank, or station. (Lth, TA.) And OuxoTira bihi He was made equal. (TA. [See OunoZira bihi.])
6. taxaATarati AlfuHuwlu biOaconaAbihaA [The stallions of the camels lashed with their tails] previously to their attacking one another. (A.)
txATrwA ‡ They laid bets, wagers, or stakes, one with another, (Ḳ, TA,) EalaI OamorK for a thing. (TA.) And txATrA Ealayohi ‡ They two laid bets, wagers, or stakes, for it. (A.)
xaTorN: see xiTorN:
and xaTarN, in two places:
and xaATirN.

xiTorN A large number of camels: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or forty: (Ḳ:) or two hundred; (AḤát, Ḳ;) and the like of sheep or goats: (TA:) or a thousand thereof: (Ḳ:) and more: (TA:) and xaTorN↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ:) pl. OaxoTaArN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

A certain plant, with which one dyes or tinges, himself or his hair, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) its leaves being put into black dye: (TA:) it resembles the plant called katam, with which it often grows; and old men dye their hair with it: (AḤn:) or [the plant called] wasomap: (Ḳ:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {xiTorapN}. (AḤn, Ḳ.)
Hence, (Ṣ,) ‡ Milk mixed with much water: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) as though it were tinged [with the plant so called]. (TA.)
And A branch (Ḳ) of a tree: pl. xiTarapN, which is extr.; or as though the p were imagined to be elided. (TA.)

xaTarN The being at the point of, or near to, destruction; (JK, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [imminent danger; peril; jeopardy; risk; hazard;] and fear of perishing: (Mṣb:) pl. OaxoTaArN. (A.) You say, huwa EalaI xaTarK EaZiymK He is [in a state of great peril, or] on the brink of destruction. (A.) And rakobuwA AlOaxoTaAra [They embarked in perilous undertakings; or braved perils]. (A.) [And Oamoru lahu xaTarN and cuw xaTarK A perilous affair or event or case: and hence, a momentous, or an important, affair or event or case; an affair, or event,. or a case, of moment or importance or magnitude: see also xaTiyrN.] And xaTarN [alone] signifies A thing, or an affair,, &c., of great magnitude: and a trial, or an affliction: pl. as above. (Ḥar p. 264.)

‡ A bet, wager, stake, or thing wagered; a thing staked at a shooting-match or a race, and taken by the winner: (T, Ṣ,* A,* Mgh,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA:) [accord. to the TA, this is the primary signification; but accord. to the A, it is tropical:] pl. as above; (Mṣb;) or xiTaArN; and pl. pl. xuTurN: (Ḳ: [but in some copies of the Ḳ, the last is written OaxoTaArN; and so in the TA, where it is added that some say it is pl. of xaTarN, like as OasobaAbN is of sababN, and OanodaAbN of nadabN:]) xaTarN and sabaqN and nadabN all signify the same. (TA.) You say, waDaEuwA xaTarFA ‡ [They laid a bet]. (A.) And OaHoraza fulaAnN AlxaTara ‡ [Such a one won the bet]. (A.)

Hence, [app. as being likened to a stake won,] (TA,) ‡ Eminence; nobility; as also xaTorN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) in which sense it has become so much used as to be, in this acceptation, conventionally regarded as proper: (TA:) also excellence: (TA:) and (as also xaTorN↓, TA) rank; degree of dignity; station; of a man: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA:) and highness of rank or account or estimation: and wealth: (TA:) pl. OaxoTaArN: (A:) accord. to some, it is only used to signify high rank: but accord. to others, you say, Uin-ahu laEaZiymu AlxaTari ‡ [Verily he is of great dignity] with respect to his good actions and his nobility, and Sagiyru AlxaTari ‡ [of little rank] with respect to his evil actions and his ignobleness. (TA.) Also † A lot, or portion, or share. (TA.)
And † A compensation. (TA.)

† A like, or fellow, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in rank or station, (Ṣ,) or in eminence; (Ḳ;) as also xaTiyrN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
You say, hecaA xaTarN lihecaA, and xaTiyrN↓, † This is like to that. (Ṣ.) And Aljan-apu laA xaTara lahaA † Paradise has not its like. (TA.) And fulaAnN layosa lahu xaTiyrN↓ † Such a one has not his like or fellow. (TA.)
Also [an inf. n. of xaTara in the phrase xaTara bibaAliI and EalaI baAliI, accord. to the Mṣb And hence,] † A vain suggestion of the devil. (JK.) [See xaATirN.]

entry.sense: xaTirN: see xaATirN.
xaTorapN [inf. n. of un. of xaTara: and hence,] † A going away; and walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (Ḥar p. 35.)
See also xaATirN.

maA laqiytuhu UilaA xaTorapF ‡ [I met him not save] sometime; (A;) or sometimes. (Ḳ.) And maA cakarotuhu Uil-aA xaTorapF baEoda xaTorapK ‡ [I remembered not, or mentioned not, him, or it, save sometime after sometime; i. e., save] sometimes. (A.)
OaSaAbatohu xaTorapN mina Aljin-i † A touch, or stroke, from the jinn, or genii, befell him; or madness, or insanity, [proceeding] from the jinn; syn. mas-N. (Ḳ,* TA.)
bayoniI wabayonahu xaTorapu raHimK (IAạr, TA) app. means † Between me and him is a tie of relationship. (TA.)
raEayonaA xaTaraAti AlwasomiI-i † We pastured [our beasts] upon the patches of herbage produced by the [rain called] wsmI-. (Ḳ,* TA.)
xaTorapN also signifies † A small quantity [or shower] of rain: pl. xiTaArN (JK) [and probably xaTaraAtN also].

And one says, laA jaEalahaA Qll-ehu xaToratahu walaA jaEalahaA Mxira maxoTarK minohu↓ [app. referring to rain, and meaning † May God not make it to be the only shower, or fall, thereof, or the only time thereof; nor make it to be the last time thereof]; (TA;) Mxira maxoTarK meaning Mxira EahodK. (Ḳ,* TA.)
xTAr: see what next follows.

hom.sense: A camel's nose-rein; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a nose-rein by which a she-camel is led: (Kr:) a rope: (Sh, Ḳ:) these, says Meyd, are one and the same thing. (TA.) It is related in a trad. of ʼAlee that he said to [a mistake for “respecting”] 'Ammár, jur-uwA lahu AlxaTiyra maA Qnojar-a lakumo [Pull ye his noserein as long as it will be pulled by you]: or, as some relate the saying, maA jar-ahu lakumo [as long as he pulls it to you]: meaning follow him as long as there is ground for doing so: or, accord. to some, as Sh says, act patiently towards 'Ammar as long as he acts patiently towards you: Meyd mentions it as a proverb. (TA.)

‡ Eminent; noble; of high rank: (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) characterized by rank or station: (Ṣ, A:) pl. xuTorN (Ḳ) and xaTiyruwna. (A.) And † Anything excellent. (TA.) You say OamorN xaTiyrN † A thing, or an affair, of high account or estimation. (TA.)
Also † Ignoble; of low rank; (AZ, TA;) contemptible. (AZ, Mṣb.)
See also xaTarN, in three places.

entry.sense: xaT-aArN [is probably applied to a he-camel in a sense like that of the fem., here following]. xaT-aArapN, applied to a she-camel, That lashes with the tail to the right and left: (Ḳ:) or that moves about her tail, when going, in a brisk, or sprightly, manner: (A:) or that raises her tail, in going along, by reason of briskness, and exceeding sprightliness. (Ḥar p. 557.) [See 1, first sentence.]
[Hence,] ‡ A spear that quivers, vibrates, or shakes: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or that does so much: and in like manner, a man. (TA.) And xaT-aArN biAlr-umoHi ‡ A man who thrusts much with the spear. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
† A man who raises his arm, or hand, (Ḳ, TA,) with a stone which he lifts for the purpose of trying his strength, (TA,) to cast, or throw, (Ḳ, TA,) and who shakes the stone in lifting it. (TA.)
† A sling. (Ḳ.) † The [engine of war called] manojaniyq; (Ḳ;) as also xaT-aArapN↓: its casting being likened to the action termed xaTaraAnN [inf. n. of 1, q. v.], of the stallion-camel. (TA.)
AlxaT-aAru † The lion: (Ḳ:) because of his proud walk, and self-admiration: or because of his shaking himself in his walk. (TA.)
misokN xaT-aArN ‡ Musk that diffuses much odour or fragrance. (A.)
xaT-aArapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: xaATirN [part. n. of 1, q. v.:] ‡ Walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side; (Ḳ;) as also xaTirN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or xaTorN↓. (So in the CK and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ.)

‡ An opinion, or an idea, or object of thought, bestirring itself in the mind; (A and Kull p. 179;) i. q. haAjisu, (M, Ḳ,) i. e. a thing coming at random into the mind: (Ṣ in art. hjs:) or a cogitation which bestirs itself, or occurs, (yaxoTuru,) in the mind, with a view to the end, issue, or result, of a thing: (Mṣb:) pl. xawaATiru: (A, Ḳ:) [and xaTorapN↓ signifies the same; for] xaTaraAtN [which is its pl.] is syn. with xawaATiru; (A;) [whence the phrase,] xaTaraAtu AlX-ayaATiyni † The vain suggestions of the devils. (Ṣ and TA in art. hmz, &c.) [See also xaTarN, last sentence]
Hence it is applied to † The mind itself. (Kull p. 179.)

entry.sense: maxoTarN: see xaTorapN.
baAdiyapN muxoTirapN † [A perilous, or dangerous, desert;] as though it made the traveller a stake between safety and perdition. (Mṣb.)
muxaATirN [act. part. n. of 3, q. v.:] † One who contends with another in shooting or casting [app. for a wager]. (JK, TA.)

1. xaTifahu, aor. _a {yaxoTafu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaTofN; (Ṣ, TA;) this is the approved form of the verb; (T, Ṣ;) and xaTafahu, aor. _i {yaxoTifu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above; (Mṣb;) a form of the verb mentioned by Akh, (Ṣ,) but this is rare, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or (Ḳ) bad, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) scarcely, or not at all, known; (Ṣ;) and AxtTfhu↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) and txT-fhu↓; (Ṣ Mṣb, TA;) He seized it; or took it, or carried it off, by force: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he did so quickly; snatched it away: (Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) and xT-f↓ has been said to imply repetition of the action [unless it be a variation of AxtTf as in a case mentioned below]; but this is strange, and not known on any other authority than that of the “Akáneem et-Taaleem” by El-Khuweiyee, a disciple of El-Fakhr Er-Rázee. (MF, TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xxix. 67], wayutaxaT-afu↓ Aln-aAsu mino Hawolihimo [And men are carried off by force from around them]. (TA.)
[And hence,] hecaA sayofN yaxoTafu Alr-aOosa ‡ [This is a sword that will strike off the head]. (TA.)

And xaTifa AlbaSara and xaTafahu, said of lightning, (Ḳ,) and of a ray of light, and of a [glistening] sword, and of any polished body, (TA,) ‡ It took away the sight: (Ḳ, TA:) and AuxotuTifa baSaruhu↓ ‡ His sight was suddenly taken away. (M and Ḳ in art. mls.) It is said in the Ḳur [ii. 19], yakaAdu Albaroqu yaxoTafu OaboSaArahumo ‡ [The lightning almost taketh away their sight, lit. sights]: (TA:) You read yaxoTifu AbSArhm; (Ṣ, TA;) and so did Aboo-Rejà and Mujáhid: and some read yixiT-ifu↓, and yaxaT-ifu↓, originally yaxotaTifu, accord. to the opinion of the Basrees, disputed by Fr, but confirmed by Zj. (TA.)

And xaTifa Als-amoEa, (Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxoTafu}, (Ṣ,) said of a devil, ‡ He stole [an opportunity of] hearing [the speech of the angels, from the confines of the lowest Heaven; or snatched it]; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also AxtTfhu↓: (Ḳ:) the two verbs being like nazaEahu and AinotazaEahu. (Sb, TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xxxvii. 10], Uil-aA mano xaTifa AlxaTofapa↓ ‡ Except him who steals the [opportunity of] hearing: (TA:) or who snatches unawares and by stealth, (Bḍ,) or hears and snatches, (Jel,) the speech of the angels: (Bḍ, Jel:) El-Ḥasan read Al-A mn xaT-afa↓ AlxTfp, originally QxotaTafa: (Ṣ, TA:) and another reading, ascribed to him and others, is xiT-ifa↓; but this is very weak. (TA.)

xaTifa, aor. _a {yaxoTafu}; and xaTafa, aor. _i {yaxoTifu}; inf. n. xaTafaAnN; (Ḳ;) thus in all the copies of the Ḳ, but correctly xaTofN, as in the L; (TA;) said of a camel, † He went along quickly. (Ḳ, TA.) And mar-a yaxoTafu xaTofFA munokarFA † He went along at a quick rate [such as was deemed strange, or disapproved]. (TA.) And xaTifati Als-afiynapu, and xaTafat, † The ship sailed, or voyaged: you say, xaTifati Alyawoma mino EumaAna † She sailed,. or voyaged, to-day, from 'Omán. (TA.)
2: see 1, first sentence.

hom.sense: 4. AxTf biAlOamori He said, Seize thou this [thing], O man; or take it, or carry it off, by force; or snatch it away. (Ṣgh.)

OaxoTafa liI mino Hadiyvihi XayoYFA vum-a sakata, inf. n. UixoTaAfN, † He cut short somewhat of his discourse, or narrative, which he had begun to me, on some other thing's occurring to his mind, and was silent. (TA.)
OaxoTafatohu AlHum-aI, (Lḥ, O, TA,) or OaxoTafato Eanohu, (JK,) or
AixotaTafatohu, (Ḳ,) † The fever left him, or quitted him. (Lḥ, JK, O, Ḳ.)

AxTfhu Almawotu † [Death missed him by a little;] he escaped death by a little. (JK.)
And AxTf Alr-amiy-apa † He missed the animal at which he shot or cast, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) nearly hitting it: (JK:) and in like manner, AlX-aIoCa the thing. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) And He captured, or caught, the animal at which he shot or cast; expl. by UicaA kaAna yaSiyduhaA [perhaps a mistranscription for yuSiybuhaA, and, if so, meaning he hit]. (JK.) And AxTf said of an arrow, † [It missed: or it fell upon the ground, and then glided along upon the ground to the butt, or object of aim: (see xaATifN:) and] it went straight. (TA.)
AxTf said of a man, † He became affected with a slight sickness, and then speedily recovered. (TA.)

OixoTaAfu AlHaXaA i. q. AinoTiwaMWuhu [meaning † The state of being lean, or lank, in the belly: see muxoTafN]. (Ṣ, TA.) AlOixoTaAfu in horses is a fault: it is † The contr. of AlAinotifaAxu: AHeyth says that it is, in horses, † smallness of the jawof [here meaning the belly, or abdomen]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in two places.
6. txATfwA Alkurapa bayonahumo [They contended together in snatching away the ball] with the goffsticks. (Ḳ * and TA in art. jHf.)

hom.sense: 8. AxtTf; and its variations xaT-afa and xiT-ifa; and yixiT-ifu and yaxiT-ifu, variations of its aor.: see 1, in seven places.
kaOan-ahu yaxotaTifu fiI maXoyihi Eunuqahu, said of a swift camel, means As though he were straining, or stretching, (yajotacibu,) in his going along, his neck. (Ṣ.)
See also 4.

entry.sense: maA mino maraDK Uil-aA walahu xuTofN † There is no disease but there is for it a cure. (JK, Ḳ.)
xuTofN and xuTufN↓ † Leanness; or lankness of the belly: and † lightness of the flesh of the side. (TA)
xuTufN: see what next precedes.
bihi xuTufN † In him (namely, a man, JK) is madness, or diabolical possession; (JK, TA;) as also xuT-afN↓: but this latter may be either a pl., like Dur-abN [pl. of DaAribN], or a sing. (TA.)

xaTofapN A single act of seizing; or, of taking, or carrying off, by force: (TA:) or, of doing so quickly; of snatching away. (Mgh, Mṣb, TA.) Hence, [in a trad.,] accord. to one reading, nahaI Eano kul-i ciI xaTofapK, meaning He prohibited the prey of whatever snatches away the prey, and goes away with it, not withholding it for its owner: or, as some say, what snatches away with its talon, or claw: but the reading commonly known is, nahaI Eani AlxaTofapi: (Mgh:) and AlxaTofapu signifies what the wolf, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) or the like, (Mṣb,) snatches away, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) of the limbs, or members, of a living sheep or goat, (Mgh, TA,) or of a living animal; (Mṣb;) or what the dog snatches away from the limbs, or members, of the animal of the chase, of flesh, &c., while the animal is alive: (Mgh, TA:) or the limb, or member, which the beast or bird of prey seizes, or carries off by force, or which a man cuts off, from the beast that is alive: (Ḳ, TA:) for whatever is separated from the living animal, (Mgh, TA,) of flesh or fat, (TA,) is carrion, (Mgh, TA,) unlawful to be eaten: the prohibition originated from the Prophet's finding, when he came to El-Medeeneh, that the people loved and ate the humps of camels and the tails of sheep: (TA:) the reading AlxaTafap, of the measure faEalap, with fet-ḥ to the medial radical letter, as pl. of xaATifN, is a mistake. (Mgh.)
Also † A single suck of a small quantity of milk quickly taken by a child from the breast. (TA.)
For its meaning in the Ḳur xxxvii. 10, see 1.
See also xuTofN.
xaTafaI † Quickness in pace or going, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of a camel, as though he were straining, or stretching, his neck, in going along; (Ṣ; [see 8;]) as also xayoTafaI↓, (Ḳ,) and xayoTafN↓. (JK, TA.)
See also the last of these words below.
xaTiyfN: see xayoTafN.

hom.sense: xaTiyfapN The act of seizing, or carrying off by force; or, of snatching away at unawares. (TA.)

Flour sprinkled upon milk, (Ṣ,) or flour upon which milk is sprinkled, (JK, Ḳ,) then cooked, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and licked, or eaten with the finger, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and snatched up with spoons: (Ḳ:) IAạr says that it is [what is called] jabuwlaMCu [a word I have not found in any other instance]: (Ṣ:) or, with the Arabs, it is a food made with milk (labaniy-apN), which is heated, then flour is sprinkled upon it, and then it is cooked, and people lick it, or eat it with the finger, snatching it up hastily. (Az, TA.)

entry.sense: xuT-afN: see xuTufN.

AlxaT-aAfu [lit. He that is wont to seize,, &c.: and particularly † he that is wont to snatch, or steal, opportunities of hearing the speech of the angels, from the confines of the lowest Heaven: and hence.] applied in a trad. to † the Devil, or Satan: (Ṣ, TA:) or, as some say, it is in this instance AlxuT-aAfu↓, as pl. of xaATifN, [and therefore meaning † the devils,] or as being likened to the hooked iron called xuT-aAf. (TA.)
Oabuw AlxaT-aAfi a surname of The HidaOap [or kite]. (TA in art. HdO.)

hom.sense: xuT-aAfN [The swallow; thus called in the present day;] a certain bird, (JK, Ṣ, Mgh,) well known; (JK, Mgh;) a certain black bird; (Ḳ;) the EuSofuwr [or passerine bird] which the common people call EuSofuwru Aljan-api [the ESfwr of Paradise]: pl. xaTaATiyfu. (ISd, TA.) [See also xuX-aAfN.]

The bent, or crooked, piece of iron which is on each side of the sheave of a pulley, and in which is the pin whereon the sheave turns: (Aṣ,* JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) it confines the sheave on each side: (TA:) that which is of wood is termed qaEowN. (Aṣ, TA.) Also (Ṣ [in the Ḳ “or”]) Any crooked, or hooked, iron: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) [An iron hook: a grapple: a grapnel: and the like.] The xuT-aAfaAni of a bit are The two bent pieces of iron in the misoHal and the Xakiymap, on the right and left. (IDrd in his “Book on the Saddle and Bridle.”) And xaTaATiyfu signifies ‡ The claws, or talons, of a beast or bird of prey; (Ṣ, TA;) as being likened to a hooked iron. (TA.)

† A wicked thief: so in the saying of Abu-nNejm,
waQsotaSoHabuwA kul-a EimK Oum-iI-i
mino kul-i xuT-aAfK waOaEoraAbiI-i
† [And they took as companions every blind illiterate man, of every wicked thief and Arab of the desert]. (TA.) yaA Qbona xuT-aAfK [app. meaning † O son of a wicked thief] was said by a woman to Jereer, in derision. (TA.)
See also the paragraph next preceding this.
† A mark made with a hot iron upon a camel, like the xuT-aAf of the sheave of a pulley. (JK, L, Ḳ.*)
† The part, of a horse, which is the place of the heel of the rider. (JK.)
Also pl. of xaATifN. (TA. See AlxaT-aAfu.)

entry.sense: xaATifN [act. part. n. of 1, Seizing,, &c.]: pl. xuT-aAfN. (TA.)
AlxaATifu The wolf; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) because he seizes, or carries off by force, his prey. (TA.)

xaATifu Zil-ihi A certain bird, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) said by Ibn-Selemeh to be called Alr-aforaAfu; (Ṣ, [so in three copies, not raqoraAq as in Freytag's Lex.,] TA;) that sees its shadow, and thinks it to be a bird; (JK;) or when it sees its shadow in the water, it advances to it to seize it, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) thinking it to be a prey: (L, TA:) [see xayaAlN:] it is one of the birds of the deserts, and is [said to be] thus called because of the swiftness with which it pounces down; it is green, or of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, (OaxoDaru,) in the back; white in the belly; long in the wings, and short in the neck: (Mṣb in art. lEb:) also called mulaAEibu Zil-ihi. (Ṣ and Mṣb in that art.)
baroqN xaATifN ‡ Lightning that takes away the sight. (JK, Ṣ,* TA.*)

sahomN xaATifN † An arrow that falls upon the ground, and then glides along upon the ground to the butt, or object of aim; as though snatching something from the ground: pl. xawaATifu: (Ḥam p. 573:) or xawaATifu signifies arrows that miss; for muxoTifaAtN. (TA.)

xayoTafN, (Ḳ,) or xaTiyfN↓, (Ṣ, [so in my copies,]) † A quick, or swift, camel; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as though he strained, or stretched, his neck, in going along: (Ṣ: [see 8:]) and the former, † a camel of the [excellent and swift] kind called mahaAriI-: pl. xayaATifu. (TA.)
xayoTafN, (TA,) or xaTafaI↓, (JK,) [as meaning † Quick,] is also applied to [the pace termed] EanaqN; (JK, TA;) and so xayoTafaI↓. (JK.)
See also xaTafaI.
xayoTafaI: see xaTafaI:
and see also xayoTafN.
xaATuwfN A thing like a reaping-hook, which is tied to a snare, and by which the gazelle is caught. (JK, O, L, Ḳ.)
OaxoTafu AlHaXaA: see what next follows.

muxoTafu AlHaXaA, applied to a horse, † Lean, or lank, in the part of the belly that is behind the place of the girth: (Ṣ:) and muxoTafN [alone] is applied to a man [in a similar sense];
as also maxoTuwfN↓: (TA:) and muxoTafu AlbaToni † lean, or lank, in the belly; syn. munoTawiyhi; (Lth, Ḳ;) applied to a camel, and to an ass: (Lth, TA:) and OaxoTafu↓ AlHaXaA and maxoTuwfuhu↓, applied to a man, [signify the same,] ‡ i. q. DaAmiruhu. (TA.)
mixoTafN ‡ A sword that takes away the sight by its glistening. (TA.)

hom.sense: maxoTuwfN: see muxoTafu AlHaXaA, in two places.
Also † A camel branded with a mark like the xuT-aAf of the sheave of a pulley. (JK, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 1. xaTilati AlOucunu, aor. _a {yaxoTalu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xaTalN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) The ear was, or became, flaccid, flabby, or pendulous. (Ṣ,* Mṣb.) [In like manner, also,] xaTalN in flesh signifies The being flaccid, flabby, or pendulous. (KL.) And in a man, and a horse or a bow, (faras or qawos, accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, the former being the reading in the TA,) and a spear, (Ḳ,) and the like, (TA,) The being tall, or long, and shaky, or quivering. (Ḳ.)
xaTalN, as an inf. n. [of xaTila], also signifies The being unsteady, or restless. (KL.)
And xaTila, aor. _a {yaxoTalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaTalN, (JK, Ḳ,) He was, or became, light, and quick. (JK, Ḳ. [In the former it seems to be implied that it is said of a stupid man.])

And xaTila, (JK, Ḳ,) or xaTila fiI kalaAmihi, (Ṣ,) aor. _a {yaxoTalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaTalN, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) He was foul, and obscene, in his speech; (JK, Ṣ;) as also AxTl↓, (JK,) or AxTl fI klAmh: (Ṣ, TA:) or he was corrupt in his speech, and loquacious: (Ḳ:) or xaTila, aor. and inf. n. as above, he erred, or was wrong, in his speech; as also AxTl↓; and in his opinion, or judgment. (Mṣb.) [See also xaTalN below.]
4: see 1, in two places.

5. txT-l fiI miXoyatihi He twisted himself in his gait, and walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (Ḳ. [See also xaTalN, an inf. n. of which the verb (xaTila) is not mentioned as having this meaning.])
xaTalN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, &c.)
A twisting of one's self, and walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side (Ḳ. [See 5.])

Corrupt speech: or loquacity: (TA:) or corrupt and conflicting speech: (Ṣ, O:) or corrupt speech with loquacity. (Ḳ.) In a woman, Foul, or obscene, speech; and conduct that induces doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: xaTilN Long and quivering; applied to a spear. (Ṣ, TA.)
And simply Long: so in the phrase, rajulN xaTilu AlqawaAYimi [A man having long legs]. (TA.)
And, applied to a garment, That drags upon the ground by reason of its length. (T, O, Ḳ.)
Also, applied to a garment, (JK, Ḳ,) and a badan [app. here meaning a short coat of mail], (Ḳ,) Rough and thick: (JK, Ḳ:) pl. OaxoTaAlN. (TA.)
Also Stupid, or foolish, (Ḳ, TA,) and hasty. (TA.)
Light and quick; (JK, Ḳ;) applied to a stupid, or foolish person; (JK;) and OaxoTalu↓ signifies the same. (Ḳ.)
A fighting man (JK) quick in thrusting or piercing. (JK, Ḳ.)

‡ One who gives, or bestows, quickly; (Ṣ;) or so xaTilu Alyadayoni; (JK;) or so xaTilu Alyadayoni biAlmaEoruwfi: (Ḳ, TA:) a tropical phrase. (TA.) And xaTilu Alyadayoni A man having rough arms or hands. (Ḳ.)
Also Corrupt in speech, and loquacious; and so OaxoTalu↓: (Ḳ:) or erring, or wrong, in speech, and in opinion, or judgment. (Mṣb.)
An arrow (JK, Ḳ) that goes to the right and left; (JK;) that does not take a direct course towards the butt. (Ḳ.)
The cord of the sportsman [who catches, or snares, game therewith]. (Ḳ.)
And The border, or extremity, of a [tent of the kind called] fusoTaAT: (Ḳ:) pl. as above: so in the O. (TA.)

entry.sense: xaT-aAlapN A woman very foul, or obscene, in speech: (JK,* Ḳ:) or whose conduct induces doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion: (Ḳ:) so in the M and O. (TA.)
