OaxoTalu Having [flaccid, or flabby, or pendulous, or] long, and flaccid or flabby or pendulous, ears: (Mgh:) xaTolaMCu [is its fem., and therefore signifies the same; or this], applied to a ewe or she-goat, (JK, Ḳ,) signifies having broad ears; (Ḳ;) or having very broad ears; (JK, TA;) or long-eared: (Ḥam p. 741:) pl. xuTulN (Ḳ) and xuTolN. (TA.) You say val-apN xuTulN (Ṣ) or xuTolN (TA) A flock of sheep, or goats, having flaccid, or flabby, or pendulous, ears: and the same epithet is applied to dogs: (Ṣ, TA:) all dogs of the chase have such ears. (TA.) And OucunN xaTolaMCu A flaccid, or flabby, or pendulous, ear: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a long ear, that shakes about: (TA:) or a very broad ear. (JK.)
Also, the fem., A woman thick, coarse, or rude, (T, Ḳ,) of make: (T, TA:) or, as some say, (TA,) long in the breasts. (Ḳ, TA.)
See also xaTilN, in two places.
rajulN OaxoTalu All-isaAni A man having a wagging tongue; able in speech. (TA.)
baEiyrN OaxoTalu AlqawaYimi A camel that does not put his legs in their proper places. (JK.)
dahorN OaxoTalu A time, or fortune, that brings calamities. (JK.)

1. xaTamahu, aor. _i {yaxoTimu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaTomN, (TA,) He struck his xaTom, i. e. his nose. (Ḳ,* TA.) And He struck the very middle of his nose with a sword. (TA.) And xuTima Oanofuhu His nose was broken. (Ḥam p. 528.)

† He branded him [i. e. a camel] on his nose with the mark called xaTomN [or xiTaAmN]. (TA.) [Hence,] xaTama Oanofahu ‡ [He branded him with disgrace;] he made disgrace to cleave to him manifestly. (TA.) And xaTamahu biAll-awomi ‡ [He branded him with blame]; and Eacarahu [i. e. bAllwm signifies the same]. (TA.)

He attached the zimaAm [or xiTaAm, q. v.,] to him; namely, a camel: (Ṣ:) or xaTamahu biAlxiTaAmi, (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) he put the xiTaAm upon his nose; as also xT-mhu↓ bihi: (Ḳ:) [but the latter verb seems to be more properly used in relation to a number of camels:] or the former, (Ḳ,) or simply xaTamahu, and xT-mhu↓, (TA,) he made a cut, or notch, in his nose, (Haz-aOanofahu, so in the Ḳ accord. to the TA,) not deep, (TA,) or he drew his nose [down], (jar-a Oanofahu, so in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ and in the CK,) in order to put upon it the xiTaAm. (Ḳ, TA.)

[Hence,] † He withheld him, or prevented him, from going forth [&c.]. (TA.) And xaTamahu biAlkalaAmi ‡ He overcame him, or subdued him, by speech, and prevented him from speaking, (Ḳ, TA,) and from answering, or replying. (TA.)
xaTama Alkalimapa, inf. n. as above, ‡ He made the word, or saying, valid and strong; alluding to prudence and precaution as to what one utters. (TA.)
xaTama OumuwrFA ‡ He conducted, or managed, affairs. (TA.)

xaTama Alqawosa biAlwatari, inf. n. xaTomN and xiTaAmN, ‡ He suspended the bow by the suspensory called watarN and xiTaAmN. (AḤn, Ḳ, TA.) And xaTama Alqawosa bixiTaAmihaA † He strung the bow with its string. (TA.)
xaTama AlOadiyma, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaTomN, (TA,) ‡ He sewed the edges of the skin, or hide. (Kr, Ḳ, TA.)
xuTima biliHoyatihi, and xaTamatohu liHoyatuhu, ‡ His beard grew upon his two cheeks. (TA.)
xaTama Oanofa Alr-amoli ‡ He passed over, or crossed, the extremity, or prominent portion, of the tract of sand: (Aṣ, TA:) or he faced it, crossing it. (TA.)
2: see 1, in two places.
taxoTiymN, [as inf. n. of xuT-ima or xaT-ama, (see the part. ns. below,)] said of unripe dates, signifies † The putting forth colours. (KL.)
8. AxtTm Alv-awoba He bound the garment over the maxoTim, i. e. the nose; or over the xaTom, i. e. the fore part of the nose: and AxtTm bilivaAmK [he so bound a lvAm, q. v.]. (Ḥar p. 433.)

hom.sense: xaTomN The muzzle, i. e. the fore part of the nose and mouth, of a dAb-ap [i. e. beast], (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) whatever it be, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) as a dog, and a camel, but originally of a beast of prey, and of a sheep or goat: (TA:) or, of a beast of prey, i. q. xuroTuwmN: (IAạr, TA:) or, as some say, of a beast of prey, [the lip, i. e.] what corresponds to the jaHofalap of the horse: (TA:) or of a camel, the nose. (Mgh.) And ‡ The bill, or beak, of a bird, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) whatever it be, (JK, Ṣ,) as a hawk, or falcon, (JK,) and a qaTaAp. (TA.) And of a man, ‡ The nose; (Ḳ;) as also maxoTimN↓ (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and mixoTamN↓; (Ḳ, TA;) pl. maxaATimu: (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the fore part of the nose: (Ḥar p. 433:) and the mxTm↓ is also of a camel. (IAth, TA.) Also, of a man, ‡ The fore part of the face. (TA.)
xaTomu All-ayoli ‡ The first approach of night: like as one says Oanofu All-ayoli. (TA.)
See also xiTaAmN.

entry.sense: xuTomapN ‡ A prominent portion of a mountain. (Ṣ, TA.)

xiTomiI-N (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xaTomiI-N, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or, accord. to Az, the latter only, the former being incorrect, (TA,) but the former is the more common, (Mṣb,) [Althæa; the althæa officinalis of Linn.; i. e. marsh-mallow;] a certain plant (JK, Ḳ) with which, (Ṣ, TA,) or with a preparation of which, (JK,) the head is washed; (JK, Ṣ, TA;) a well-known preparation for washing the head: (Mṣb:) it is a dissolvent, suppurative, lenitive; good for dysury, and the stone, and sciatica, and ulcer of the bowels, and tremour, and for the suppuration of wounds, and the allaying of pain; and, with vinegar, for the [species of leprosy termed] bahaq; and for toothache, used as a gargle; and for the sting or bite of venomous reptiles and the like, and for burns; the mixing of its seed with water, or its bruised stem or root, causes it to congeal; and its mucilage, extracted by hot water, is beneficial to the sterile woman. (Ḳ.)

xiTaAmN [A kind of halter for a camel; a cord of which one end is fastened round the nose and jaws of a camel; accord. to J,] i. q. zimaAmN: (Ṣ:) [but the following explanations are more correct:] a certain thing well known; so called because [a portion of] it lies upon [or surrounds] the fore part of the nose and the nouth of the camel: (Mṣb:) or anything that is put upon the nose of the camel in order that he may be led thereby: (M, Ḳ:) or a cord, or rope, which is put upon the neck of the camel, and folded [for yusam-aI, in my copy of the work from which this is taken, I read yuvonaI, as in another explanation, below,] upon, or over, his nose: (Mgh:) or a cord, or rope, which is attached to an iron that surrounds the nose and jaws [of the camel]: (JK:) or any cord, or rope, that is suspended upon the throat of the camel and then tied upon, or over, his nose, whether of skin or of wool or of fibres of the palm-tree or of hemp: (ISh, TA:) but if of plaited leather, it is said to be called jariyrN: (TA:) or the xTAm of the camel is a cord, or rope, of fibres of the palm-tree, or of [goats'] hair, or of flax, at one end of which is put a ring, then the other end is tied to it, [i. e. to the rope, as the relative pronoun in the original shows, or to some part of it,] so that it becomes like a ring [or loop], then it is put upon the neck of the camel, and then it is folded upon, or over, his nose: what is put in the nose, [attached to a ring, or the like, therein,] and is slender, is termed zimaAmN: (IAth, TA:) pl. xuTumN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) manaEa xiTaAmahu, said of a camel, means He refused to have his xTAm put upon him. (TA.) And tazaw-aja EalaI xiTaAmK means † He married two wives, so that they became like a xiTaAm to him. (TA.)
† The rope of a bucket. (TA.)
‡ The suspensory of a bow. (AḤn, Ḳ, TA.) And † The string of a bow. (Ḳ, TA.)
xaTiymN Struck upon the nose. (Ḳ.) Having the nose broken. (Ḥam p. 528.)

misokN xaT-aAmN (like Xad-aAdN, TA, in the CK [erroneously] without teshdeed,) ‡ Musk that fills with its odour the innermost parts of the nose: (Aṣ, Ḳ:) or musk sharp, or pungent, in odour; as though striking the nose (kaOan-ahu yaxoTimu AlOanofa). (Z, TA.)
fulaAnN xaATimu Oamori baniI fulaAnK ‡ Such a one is the leader, and the conductor, or manager, of the affairs, of the sons of such a one. (TA.)
OaxoTamu A man (Ṣ) having a long nose. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And Black. (JK, Ḳ.)
maxoTamN A woman. (Ḳ.)
maxoTimN and mixoTamN: see xaTomN, in three places.

hom.sense: muxaT-amN: see maxoTuwmN.

† A horse having a whiteness extending from the fore part of his nose and his mouth to the part beneath his lower jaw, (ISd, Ḳ, TA,) so as to resemble the xiTaAm: in which sense it has no verb. (ISd, TA.)
Full-grown unripe dates (busor) upon which are lines (Ṣ, Ḳ) and streaks [of colour]; (Ṣ;) as also muxaT-imN↓. (Kr, Ḳ.) [See 2: and see also busorN.]
The part of the nose of the camel which is the place of the xiTaAm. (TA.)

entry.sense: muxaT-imN: see the next preceding paragraph.
maxoTuwmN [pass. part. n. of 1]. You say naAqapN maxoTuwmapN A she-camel having a xiTaAm put upon her: and nuwqN muxaT-amapN↓ she-camels having xuTum put upon them. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also xiTaAmN.

1. xaTaA, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. yaxoTuw, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xaTowN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AxtTI↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) said of a man (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) [and of a beast]; both signify the same; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He stepped, paced, or walked; (MA, KL;) i. q. maXaI; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AixotaATa, [which see in art. xyT,] formed by transposition. (Ḳ.) You say, xaTawotu xaTowapF waAHidapF [I stepped one step]. (JK.) [And was-aEa AlxaTowa He stepped wide.] See also the last sentence of the next paragraph.

hom.sense: 2. xT-I He made to pass over: so in the saying, xaT-aI Qll-ehu nawoCahaA God made, or may God make, its (a land's) [rain-giving] star or asterism to pass it over, and not send rain upon it: (TA in art. xTO:) but in this case the verb is, (Mgh in that art.,) or may be, (TA ibid.,) originally xaT-aTa, the final T being changed into I. (Mgh and TA ibid. [See 2 in art. xTO.]) Accord. to Fr, xaT-aI Als-ahoma and xTO are syn. [as meaning He made the arrow to pass over, or to miss, the mark]. (TA in art. xTO.) One says also, in praying for a man, xuT-iIa Eanohu Als-uwoCu [May evil be made to pass him; or] may evil be repelled from him: and one says also xuT-iIa Eanoka May it be removed, or put away, from thee: (Ṣ, TA:) or xuT-iYa Eanoka Als-uwoCu. (ISk, TA in art. xTO.)

The vulgar say [to a she-ass and to a she-camel or other beast in a slippery or difficult place] xaT-iI, meaning AimoXiI [for AimoXiI ruwayadFA Step thou leisurely]: but the correct word is AuxoTiI↓ [imperative fem. of xaTaA]. (TA.)
4. AxTAhu He (a man) made him (another man) to step, pace, or walk. (Ṣ, TA.)
OaxoTayotu for OaxoTaOotu: see the latter.

entry.sense: 5. taxaT-ayotuhu I stepped, or walked, over him, or it: (Mṣb:) or I passed over and beyond him, or it: (Ṣ:) or txT-I Aln-aAsa He went over the people, (rakibahumo,) and passed beyond them; and so AixotaTaAhumo↓. (Ḳ.) One says, taxaT-ayotu riqaAba Aln-aAsi [I stepped over, walked over, passed over and beyond, or went over and passed beyond, the necks of the people]. (Ṣ, TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting Friday, [of one who came too late to the Friday-prayers, as is shown in the TA in art. AnI,] raOaI rajulFA yataxaT-aI riqaAba Aln-aAsi He saw a man passing step by step [over the necks of the people who were already in their ranks in the mosque]. (TA. [See also Ḥar p. 83.]) One says also, fulaAnN laA yataxaT-aI Eani AlT-unubi [Such a one will not step over, or beyond, or from, the tent-rope], meaning, will not go far from the tent for the purpose of voiding his excrement, by reason of his foulness and vileness and uncleanness. (TA.) And taxaT-ayotu kacaA (Ṣ, TA) I passed over [to such a thing or place or person]: (TA:) one should not say taxaT-aOotu [in this sense], with C. (Ṣ, TA.) [Hence the following tropical phrases.] txT-Ahu Almakoruwhu ‡ [What was disliked or hated, or evil, passed over him; not alighting upon him]. (TA.) And taxaT-ayotu Uilayohi biAlmakoruwhi ‡ [I passed over others to him with that which was disliked or hated, or evil; i. q. tajaAwazotu]. (TA.) And txT-I Ean-iI baSaruka † [Thine eye, or thy sight, passed me over]. (Aboo-Turáb, TA in art. tyh.)
[Also † I overstepped it, or transgressed it; namely, a limit prescribed to me, &c.]

hom.sense: 8: see 1:
and see also 5.

entry.sense:
xaTowapN A step, or pace, as meaning a single act of stepping or pacing or walking: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb:) pl. [of pauc.] xaTawaAtN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of mult.] xiTaMCN. (Ṣ.) Imra-el-Ḳeys says,
lahaA wavabaAtN kawavobi AlX-ibaMCi
fawaAdK xiTaMCN wawaAdK maTiro
[She has bounds like the bounding of gazelles; and a valley is stepped over by her with leisurely steps, and a valley is trampled over by her rapidly as though it were rained upon]: (Ṣ:) i. e., one time she steps, and refrains from running; and one time she runs with a running resembling rain: but AO relates it otherwise, saying, fawaAdK xaTiyTN [lit. and a valley is not rained upon]: and some substitute kaSawobi Alxariyfi [like the pouring rain of the autumn]. (IB, TA.) [See also what next follows.]

xuTowapN A step, or pace, as meaning the space between the two feet [in walking or running]: pl. (of pauc., Ṣ) xuTowaAtN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xuTuwaAtN and xuTawaAtN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and (of mult., Ṣ) xuTFI. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One says, qar-aba Qll-ehu Ealayoka AlxuTowapa, meaning May God make short to thee the space, or distance. (TA.) And bayona Alqawolayoni xuTKI yasiyrapN † Between the two sayings is little difference. (TA.) laA tat-abiEuwA xuTuwaAti AlX-ayoTaAni, in the Ḳur [ii. 163, &c.], means [Follow not ye] the ways of the Devil: (TA:) or the footsteps of the Devil: (JK:) here some read xuTowaAt; and some, accord. to Lth, xuTuWaAt, which Az pronounces to have no meaning. (TA.)
xaTiy-apN for xaTiyoYapN: see the latter, in art. xTO. [Freytag, evidently from his having found it incorrectly written for HaZiy-apN, has assigned to it the meaning of “amica,” and “amata.”]

naAqatuka hecihi mina AlmutaxaT-iyaAti Aljyf [the last word being app. Aljiyafa] is a saying mentioned by AZ: (TA in the present art.:) or mn AlmutaxaT-iYaAti Aljyf. (TA in art. xTO, where see the explanation.)

hom.sense: 1. xaZaA laHomuhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yaxoZuw, (Ṣ,) inf. n. xuZuw-N, (Ḳ,) His flesh was, or became, compact; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xaZiI, (Ḳ in art. xZI,) mentioned, as well as the former, by IF, and also by Ḳz, who does not mention the former, (TA,) aor. yaxoZaI, inf. n. xaZFI; (Ḳ;) or xaZiIa should not be said; (Ṣ;) or xaZaA is more common. (IF.) See also xaZaA and xaZataA voce xaAZK, below.
xaZaAhu Qll-ehu God made him, or it, (namely, flesh,) big, or large; (Ḳ accord. to the TA;) or big and thick; (CK;) as also AxZAhu↓. (Ḳ.)

4. AxZAhu: see what immediately precedes {1}. [Freytag also mentions AxZI, on the authority of the “Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen,” as signifying He, or it, caused the flesh in the arm to become prominent, so that the muscles appeared.] And AxZI also signifies He, or it, fattened, or rendered fat, (Ḳ and TA in art. xZI,) the body. (TA.)
AxZI [as an intrans. v.] (said of a man, IAạr) He became fat. (IAạr, Ḳ in art. xZI.)

entry.sense: xaZaA, followed by baZaA; and the fem. xaZaApN; and xaZaAtaA: see xaAZK.
xaZK, followed by baZK; and the fem. xaZiyapN, followed by baZiyapN: see xaAZK.
xaZawaAnN One whose flesh is such [in thickness, or abundance, or brawniness,] that one part overlies another. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

xaAZK Compact, applied to flesh; (TA;) and so xaZaA↓ baZaA, (Ṣ, TA,) likewise applied to flesh, (TA,) and to a horse, (AHeyth, TA,) [each] originally a verb, (Ṣ, TA,) and the latter an imitative sequent; and the fem. xaZaApN↓, applied to anything; (TA;) and xaZaApN baZaApN, applied to a woman, the [radical] I being changed into A accord. to the dial. of Teiyi; (AHeyth, TA;) and xaZK↓ baZK, applied to a horse; and xaZiyapN↓ baZiyapN, applied to a woman. (AHeyth, Ḳ in art. xZI.) The Saadee says, (accord. to the TA, 'Ámir Ibn-Et-Tufeyl,)
riqaAbN kaAlmawaAjini xaAZiyaAtN
waOasotaAhN EalaI AlOakowaAri kuwmu
[Compact necks like the bleachers' beating implements, and rumps elevated upon the camels' saddles]. (Ṣ.) In the saying of Imra-el-Ḳeys,
lahaA matonataAni xaZaAtaA↓ kama
Oakab-a EalaI saAEidayohi Aln-amiro
[She has two compact portions of flesh and sinew confining her back-bone, like as appear when the leopard falls prostrate upon his fore shanks], he means xaZaAtaAni, suppressing the n for the purpose of alleviation of the utterance: (Fr, Ṣ:) or, as some say, he means xaZataA↓, restoring the A that fell out on account of the concurrence of two quiescent letters in the sing. [i. e. xaZaAto, for xaZato is formed from xaZaAto, which is from xaZawato,] when the t has become movent. (Ṣ.)

xaAZK also signifies Thick, and hard, firm, or rigid: (TA:) and [so, or simply] thick, applied to an arrow. (AḤn, TA.) And one says saAEidN xaAZiI AlbaDiyEi [A fore arm, or an upper arm,] full of flesh. (IB, TA in art. bDE.) And rajulN xaAZiI AlbaDiyEi (Aṣ, Ṣ in art. bDE) A fat man. (TA in that art.)
1. xaZiIa laHomuhu: see 1 in art. xZw.
4: see 4 in art. xZw.
xaZK baZK, and xaZiyapN baZiyapN: see xaAZK, in art. xZw.

1. xaf-a, aor. _i {yaxofifu}, inf. n. xif-apN (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and xaf-N (Mṣb, Ḳ) and xaf-apN and taxaw-ufN, but this last belongs to art. xwf, (Ḳ,) contr. of vaqula [both properly and tropically]; (Mṣb;) properly, (TA,) It (a thing, Ṣ, Mṣb) was, or became, xafiyf [i. e. light] (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) of weight, (JK,) in body, or material substance. (TA.) Hence the saying of ʼAṭà, in a trad., xif-uwA EalaI AlOaroDi, meaning [Be ye, or bear ye, lightly upon the ground] in prostration: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or, as some relate it, xaf-ifuwA↓: i. e. prostrate yourselves [lightly upon the ground;] not heavily, so as to make marks, or impressions, upon your foreheads: and in another trad. it is said, UicaA sajadota fataxaAf-a↓ When thou prostratest thyself, put thy forehead upon the ground lightly: but AʼObeyd says that some say fatujaAfi, [i. e. fatujaAfi EaDudayoka Eano janobayoka,] with j. (TA [See 3 in art. jfw.]) [Hence also,] xaf-a AlmiyzaAnu The balance had one of its two scales light, so that it rose. (TA.)
[Used tropically, it means † It, or he, was, or became, light in estimation, lightly esteemed, or of little account.]

And ‡ He was, or became, xafiyf [i. e. light as meaning active, agile,, &c.,] in work: (TA:) he was, or became, brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, and quick; syn. naXiTa. (Mṣb and TA in art. nXT.) You say, xaf-a fiI Eamalihi waxidomatihi ‡ He was, or became, [brisk,, &c., or] obedient and submissive, in his work and his service: (TA:) and xaf-a lahu fiI Alxidomapi ‡ [He was, or became, brisk,, &c., to him in service], aor. yaxif-u, inf. n. xif-apN: (Ṣ:) and in like manner, xaf-a lifulaAnK ‡ He was, or became, [promptly] obedient and submissive, to such a one. (TA.) [Hence,] xafafotu UilaI fulaAnK † [I was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly, in behaviour to such a one]. (Ṣ in art. hX.) And xaf-ati AlOunovaI lilofaHoli ‡ The female was, or became, submissive to the male. (A, TA.) And xaf-ati AlOutunu liEayorihaA ‡ The she-asses obeyed their he-ass. (Ḳ, TA.) And xuf-a UilaI AlEaduw-i, inf. n. xufuwfN, † He hastened to the enemy. (Mṣb.) And xaf-a Alqawomu Eano waTanihimo, (Ḳ,* TA,) inf. n. xufuwfN, (TA,) ‡ The people, or party, removed, or departed, or journeyed, quickly from their home: or, as some say, simply removed, or departed, or journeyed, from it. (TA.)

‡ He was, or became, xafiyf [or light] in intellect, or understanding: (TA:) [and in conduct, or behaviour: generally meaning] † he was, or became, light, inconstant, unsteady, irresolute, or fickle; or light of intellect; lightwitted; syn. TaAXa: (Mṣb:) the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is xif-apN. (Mṣb and Ḳ, &c. in art. TyX, and TA in the present art.) [But sometimes, when relating to the intellect, or understanding, it means, † He was, or became, quick, acute, or sharp; and clever, or ingenious: see xafiyfN.] And you say of him whose hearing is good, fiI Oucunihi xif-apN ‡ [In his ear is quickness, acuteness, or sharpness, of hearing]. (TA in art. vql.)
[† He was, or became, flurried, agitated, or excited, by reason of fear, and by anger, or the like: see 10.]

[† He was, or became, lighthearted, or cheerful; one whose company, or converse, was acceptable and cheering.] You say, xaf-a fulaAnN EalaI Almaliki † Such a one was, or became, acceptable and cheering to the king. (TA.)

[† It (an action, or an affair, and a case, or the like,) was, or became, light, or easy: and it become alleviated.] You say, xaf-ato Ealayohi AlHarakapu † [Motion, or moving, was, or became, easy to him]; opposed to vaqulato. (TA.) And xaf-ato HaAluhu: see 4.
[† It (a word) was light, or easy, of utterance: and in like manner said of a sound, † it was, or became, light to the ear; or slight.]
[† It (food) was, or became, light to the stomach; easy of digestion.]
[Said of the hair of the head, and of the beard, † It was, or became, light, thin, or scanty.]
Said of a people, or company of men, (qawomN,) inf. n. xufuwfN, it means qal-uwA waqado xaf-ato zaHomatuhumo [i. e. † They became few in number, their crowding having diminished]. (Ṣ.)
Said of rain, [&c.,] † It diminished; decreased; or was, or became, [light, or] deficient. (TA.)
[Said of a blow, a disease, an affection of the mind, &c., It was, or became, light, slight, or inconsiderable.]
xaf-ato manaAziluhumo minohumo wamaDawoA † [means Their abodes became clear of them, and they went away]. (Ḳ * and TA in art. Xwl.)

2. xf-fhu He made it, or rendered it, xafiyf [i. e. light, both properly and tropically: the tropical significations are shown by the preceding paragraph, and by explanations of xafiyfN; and some by what here follows]: (Mṣb:) taxofiyfN is the contr. of tavoqiylN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Hence, in the Ḳur [ii. 174], celika taxofiyfN mino rab-ikumo † [That is an alleviation from your Lord]. (TA.) Hence also, in a trad. [respecting the estimates to be made by the collectors of the poor-rate], xaf-ifuwA AlxaroSa † [Make ye the conjectural computation of the quantity of the fruit upon palm-trees, &c. light to the owners, or moderate;] go not to the utmost length in the xrS. (TA.) [And xf-f Eanohu † He made light, or alleviated, his burden, suffering, distress, uneasiness, or the like, by removing from him somewhat thereof; he alleviated him; he relieved him: see Ḳur iv. 32 and viii. 67, &c.] And xaf-ifuwA EalaI AlOaroDi: see 1; second sentence. [And xf-f fiI Eamalihi † He relaxed, or remitted, in his work.]

[taxofiyfN also signifies † The making a word light, or easy, of utterance, by the suppression of hemzeh, or by its conversion into A or I or tavoqiylN; opposed to taHoqiyqN and taHoqiyqN: and by making a double consonant single; opposed to tavoqiylN and taXodiydN: and by making a movent consonant quiescent; opposed to tavoqiylN and taHoriykN: each of these changes in a word is said to be lilt-axofiyfi for the purpose of alleviating the utterance. Also, in like manner, † The making a sound light to the ear, or slight; opposed to tavoqiylN. And † The suppressing of hemzeh; opposed to taHoqiyqN.]

hom.sense: 4. AHf- He made an arrow light, by scraping or paring it. (L in art. Hwc.)
See also 10.

He was, or became, unburdened, or unencumbered, or without anything that burdened him heavily: (Mṣb:) or he was, or became, little burdened or encumbered, in journeying, (JK, TA,) or in his residence at home. (TA.)

And i. q. xaf-ato↓ HaAluhu [i. e. ‡ His state, or condition, was, or became, light, little encumbered, easy, or alleviated: or it was, or became, that of one having a small family to maintain: or that of having little property: or that of having little property and a small family to maintain]: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA: [see HaAlN:]) and, as some add, raq-ato [i. e., † it was, or became, narrow in its circumstances, or evil: it is used in contr. senses: though raq-ato seems to be here intended as explanatory of xaf-ato]. (TA.)
Axf- Alqawomu † The people's beasts were, or became, xifaAf [i. e. light as meaning active, agile, or brisk]: (AZ, Ṣ:) or the people had such beasts. (Ḳ.)
5. txf-f [He lightened his clothing; or clad himself lightly: but for this I know no other authority than modern usage].
txf-f minohu: see 10.

Also He put on, or wore, a xuf- [i. e. boot], or xifaAf [i. e. boots]: (Ḳ, accord. to different copies:) or txf-f biAlxuf-i, (JK,) or txf-f Alxuf-a, (TA,) he put on, or wore, the xuf- (JK, TA) on the foot. (TA.)

entry.sense: 6. txAf- He pressed, or bore, lightly [upon a thing]; contr. of tvAql. (Ḳ,* TA.) Hence the saying, in a trad., UicaA sajadota fataxaAf-a explained above: see 1, second sentence. (TA.)

10. Astxf-hu contr. of Aisotavoqalahu; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) He deemed it, or him, xafiyf [i. e. light, properly and tropically]. (TA.) He found it light, or easy, to carry, (Bḍ in xvi. 82, and TA,) and to remove. (Bḍ ibid.)

Astxf- bihi † He held him, or it, (namely, a man's right, or due, or just claim, Mṣb, TA,) in light, or little, estimation or account, or in contempt; he contemned, or despised, him, or it. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)
Astxf- Alhamozapa † [He deemed the hemzeh light, or easy, of utterance]. (TA.)

Astxf-hu also signifies † He demanded, or desired, his xif-ap [i. e. briskness, or promptness]; as also taxaf-afa↓ minohu: (TA:) and † it (a thing) incited him, or excited him, to briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness; syn. AisotahaX-ahu; (JK and Ḳ and TA in art. hX;) and OaTorabahu: (Ḥar p. 139:) and † he incited him, or excited him, to lightness, levity, or unsteadiness, so as to induce him to follow him in his error: (TA:) [and simply] ‡ he excited him to lightness, levity, or unsteadiness; (Ksh and Bḍ and Jel in the Ḳur xxx. last verse;) flurried him, or disquieted him: (Ksh and Bḍ ibid.:) and ‡ it flurried him, so that he became unsteady; said of impatience; and of a lively emotion of the heart or mind; (TA;) and of fear; (MA;) and of anger: (T in art. Hml:) and Axf-hu↓ † he angered him, (TA,) and deprived him of his forbearance, moderation, patience, staidness, or calmness, and incited him, or excited him, to levity, or unsteadiness. (Ḳ,* TA.) faQsotaxaf-a qawomahu, in the Ḳur xliii. 54, means † And he demanded, or desired, of his people, briskness, or promptness, in obeying him: or fAstxf- OaHolaAmahumo [and he held in light estimation their qualities of forbearance, moderation, patience, or staidness]: (Bḍ:) or he incited, or excited, his people to be promptly obedient and submissive (Oano yaxif-uwA) to him and to that which he desired of them; like Aisotafaz-a: (Ksh:) or he incited, or excited, his people to levity, or unsteadiness, (Alxif-ap,) and ignorance, foolishness, or wrong conduct. (Mṣb.) And you say, Astxf- fulaAnFA Eano raOoyihi † He incited, or excited, such a one to ignorance, foolishness, or wrong conduct, and levity, or unsteadiness, so as to make him swerve from his right sentiment, opinion, or judgment; (Az, Ḳ, TA;) as also Astfz-hu En rOyh. (Az, TA.)

xuf-N A boot; (KL, PṢ, &c.;) a certain thing that is worn (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) upon the foot: (TA:) pl. xifaAfN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OaxofaAfN [which is a pl. of pauc.]. (L, TA.) Hence, rajaEa bixuf-aIo HunayonK [He returned with the two boots of Honeyn]; a saying which originated thus: (AʼObeyd, TA:) an Arab of the desert bargained with Honeyn the UisokaAf [or maker of shoes and boots], (Ḳ,) who was of the people of El-Heereh, (TA,) for a pair of boots, until he angered him, (Ḳ,) and Honeyn desired to anger the Arab: (TA:) so when the Arab of the desert departed, Honeyn took one of his two boots and threw it down in the way, and then he threw down the other in another place; and when the Arab passed by one of them, he said, “How like is this to the boot of Honeyn! and if the other were with it, I would take it:” and he went on: and when he came to the other, he repented of having left the former: and Honeyn had lain in wait for him: therefore when the Arab went away in search of the former [boot], Honeyn betook himself to the camel that he rode, and what was upon it, and went away therewith; and the Arab came, having with him nothing but a pair of boots; and it was said, (Ḳ,) i. e. his people said to him, (TA,) “What hast thou brought from thy journey?” and he answered, jiYotukumo bixuf-aIo HunayonK [“I have brought you the two boots of Honeyn”]: and this became a prov., applied on the occasion of one's despairing of an object of want, and returning disappointed: (Ḳ:) thus the case is related by AʼObeyd, and by most others after him. (TA.) Accord. to ISk, Honeyn was a strong man, who asserted his relationship to Asad Ibn-Háshim Ibn-ʼAbd-Menáf, and came to ʼAbd-El-Muttalib, wearing a pair of red boots, [formerly distinctive of kings and men of high rank,] and said, “O my paternal uncle, I am the son of Asad the son of Háshim the son of ʼAbd-Menáf:” but ʼAbd-El-Muttalib said, “No, by the garments of my father Háshim, I know not in thee the natural qualities of Háshim; therefore return thou:” so he returned: and it was said, rajaEa HunayonN bixuf-ayohi [Honeyn returned with his pair of boots]. (O, Ḳ, &c.) As to the saying of the rájiz,
yaHomilu fiI saHoqK mina AlxifaAfi
tawaAdiyFA suw-iyna mino xilaAfi
he means thereby [He carries, in] a pastor's bag (kinof) made of the leg of a xuf- [or boot, wooden implements to be tied upon the dugs of she-camels, made of different trees]. (Ṣ. See xilaAfN.)

The foot (KL, PṢ) of the camel; (Ṣ, Mṣb, KL, PṢ;) the whole (majomaE) of the firosin of the camel; (JK, Ḳ, TA;) of the male and of the female; corresponding to the HaAfir [or hoof] of the horse: (TA:) and sometimes of the ostrich, (Ḳ,) because resembling that of the camel: (TA:) but of no other than these two: (Ḳ:) of the masc. gender; whereas firosinN [its syn.] is fem.: (TA:) pl. OaxofaAfN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

[And hence, by a synecdoche, for cawaAtu xuf-K,] ‡ Camels; coupled with HaAfirN as meaning horses, [and sometimes asses or mules], (Mgh, TA,*) and ZilofN [as meaning sheep or goats or other cloven-hoofed beasts]. (TA.) You say, maAlahu xuf-N walaAHaAfirN walaA ZilofN ‡ [meaning He possesses not camels, nor horses or asses or mules, nor sheep or goats or other cloven-hoofed beasts]. (TA.) You say also, jaMCati AlUibilu EalaIxuf-K waAHidK, meaning ‡ The camels came following one another, the head of each [except the first] being at the tail of the next [before it], whether tied together in a file or not. (L.)

An aged camel: (Ḳ:) [and a weak camel:] or, as some say, a bulky camel: pl. OaxofaAfN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., yuHomaI mina AlOarAaki maA lamo tanalohu OaxofaAfu AlUibili [Of the trees called ArAk, what the aged and weak of camels cannot reach may be prohibited]: i. e. what is near, thereof, to the place of pasturage is not to be prohibited, but is to be left for the aged and weak camels, that cannot go far in search of pasture: (Aṣ, O, Mṣb:) or what camels cannot reach (Mṣb, TA) by means of their AxfAf, (Mṣb,) by walking thereto, (TA,) may be prohibited: (Mṣb, TA:) or it means, what camels cannot reach with their heads may be prohibited [to be shaken or beaten off for them]. (Mgh.)
‡ The sole, or part that touches the ground, of the foot of a man. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
‡ A tract of ground (Ṣ, A, O, L) more rugged, (Ṣ, O, L,) or longer, (A,) than such as is termed naEolN: (Ṣ, A, O, L:) or a rugged piece of ground. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: xif-N: see xafiyfN, in four places.
Also A company consisting of few persons. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, xaraja fulaAnN fiI xif-K mino OaSoHaAbihi Such a one went forth among a company consisting of few persons of his companions. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: xif-apN an inf. n. of 1 [in almost all of its senses, proper and tropical; and much used as a simple subst., signifying Lightness: † levity:, &c.]. (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.)
xufaAfN: see what next follows, in four places.

xafiyfN a part. n. of 1 [in all its senses, proper and tropical, signifying Light:, &c.]: (JK, Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA:) as also xif-N↓ [in the proper sense] (JK,* Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA) and xufaAfN↓: (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA:) the first is applied to a thing; as also ↓the second, (Mṣb,) which signifies anything light to carry, (TA,) [as also the first;] and light in weight but heavy in price, not incommoding the bearer: (Ḥar p. 139:) and the first and ↓third are also applied to a man: (Ṣ, TA:) but, as some say, the first means [light] in body [as well as in tropical senses]; and ↓the third, † [light] in [the sense of possessing] quickness or acuteness or sharpness, and cleverness or ingeniousness: and [in like manner] xafiyfu Alqalobi signifies † quick, acute, or sharp, in intellect; and xafiyfu Alr-uwHi, the same; or clever, or ingenious: the pl. of the first is xifaAfN and OaxofaAfN and Oaxif-aMCu; the first of which three pls. is also pl. of xufaAfN↓: and hence, in the Ḳur [ix. 41], AinofiruwA xifaAfFA waviqaAlFA [explained in art. vql]. (TA.) xif-N↓ is also applied to a boy, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning Light to carry; (TA;) as in the saying of Imra-el-Ḳeys,
yazil-u AlgulaAmu Alxif-u Eano SahawaAtihi
[The boy that is light to carry slips from the parts of his (the horse's) back whereon the rider sits]: (Ṣ: so in my copies:) or yuzil-u AlgulaAma Alxif-a [he makes the boy that is light to carry to slip]: and [it is said that] it means also † the hardy, strong, or sturdy, boy. (TA.) And xafiyfN signifies also Little burdened or encumbered in journeying, or in residence at home; like xif-N↓ and muxif-N↓. (TA.) [Hence,] rajulN xafiyfu caAti Alyadi † A poor man. (TA.)
[† Brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, and quick. Hence,] xafiyfN UilaI Alxayori [† Prompt, or quick, to do good]. (TA in art. hX.)

[† Light, or easy, of utterance: and † light to the ear; light in sound. Hence,] Aln-uwnu Alxafiyfapu [† The lightsounding n; as in yafoEalano, &c.]; contr. of Alv-aqiylapu: and also applied to the tenween. (TA.)

[† Light, thin, or scanty; applied to the hair of the head, &c. Hence,] huwa xafiyfu AlEaAriDayoni [† He is light, thin, or scanty,] in the hair of the two sides of the cheeks, (Ṣ and O and Mṣb in art. ErD,) and of the beard. (O in that art.)
xaf-aAfu [A maker, or seller, of boots (xifaAfN, pl. of xuf-N).] (TA.)
muxif-N: see xafiyfN.
[AlEaworapu Almuxaf-afapu † The part, or parts, of the person which it is improper, but not grossly indecent, to expose: so in the law-books: see art. Ewr.]

1. xafata, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxofitu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xufuwtN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and xafotN (Mṣb, TA) and xufaAtN, (TA,) It (the voice, Ṣ, A, Mṣb) was, or became, still, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or silent; (A;) was, or became, low, (Mṣb,) or soft, or gentle, or slender; and became weak, by reason of vehement hunger. (TA.)
Hence, said of a dying man, He ceased speaking; (Ṣ;) he was, or became, silent; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) he spoke not. (A.)

And [hence,] xafata, (A, TA,) inf. n. xufuwtN. † He died: (A, TA:) and xafata, inf. n. xufaAtN, ‡ he died suddenly; (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also maAta xufaAtFA. (A.) And the latter, i. e. xafata inf. n. xufaAtN, accord. to AM, † He was, or became, weak, and abject, or abased. (TA.)

xafotN also signifies The speaking with a suppressed voice; and so taxaAfutN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and muxaAfatapN↓. (Ḳ, TA.) And you say, xafata biSawotihi, (Mṣb,) and xAft↓ bihi, (TA,) He lowered his voice; spoke with a low voice. (Mṣb, TA.) And xafata biqiraMCatihi; (TA;) and xAft↓ bihaA, (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. muxaAfatapN; (Mṣb;) and qaraOamuxaAfatapF↓; (TA;) He lowered his voice in his reading or reciting; read, or recited, with a low voice: (A, Mṣb, TA:) or the second of these signifies he read, or recited, indistinctly, not with raised voice. (Lth, TA.)
xafata, said of seed-produce, † It was, or became, such as is termed xaAfitN [explained below]. (Mṣb.)
2. xf-t [app. It silenced, or killed: said of a smiting with a sword or the like: see faw-aArN]. (TA.)
3. xAft, inf. n. muxaAfatapN: see 1, in four places.
[Hence,] AlUibilu tuxaAfitu AlmaDoga The camels ruminate. (TA.)
4. Axftt She (a camel) brought forth on the day [of the year] in which she was impregnated [or just a year after she was covered]. (Ḳ.)
6. txAftwA They consulted together secretly. (TA.) See also 1.
And txAft † He feigned, or made a false show of, weakness and stillness. (TA.)

hom.sense: xafotN (Ṣ) and xufaAtN↓, (A,) applied to speech, (Ṣ, A,) Uttered with a low, or suppressed, voice. (Ṣ,* A.) [See also xaAfitN.]

The former is also syn. with xabotN [A low, or depressed, tract of ground:, &c.]. (Ḳ. [So accord. to my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, and accord. to the TA: but in the CK this signification is omitted; for instead of wAlxabotu wabiAlD-am-i Als-acaAbu, we find waAlxafotu biAlfatoHi wabiAlD-am-i Als-acaAbu, meaning that HafotN and xufotN signify the same as sacaAbN.])

entry.sense: xufotN [and accord. to the CK xafotN, but this is app. a mistake, (see what next precedes,)] i. q. sacaAbN [i. e. Rue]; (Ḳ;) as also xutofN. (T, TA.)
xufaAtN [an inf. n. of 1, q. v.]
[And also used as an epithet; for cuw xufaAtK]: see xafotN.
Also Weak hearing. (TA, from a trad.)
lasotu xufaAtFA [I am not weak, and abject, or abased]. (T, from a verse of El-Jaadee.)

xafuwtN ‡ A lean, or an emaciated, woman: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) or a woman who is scarcely seen distinctly, by reason of leanness, or emaciation: (TA:) or a woman who is deemed goodly, or beautiful, (Ḳ,) whom the eye regards as worthy of notice, (A, TA,) as long as she is alone, not when she is among other women. (A, Ḳ, TA.) You say AimoraOapN xafowtN lafuwtN: (Lth, A, TA:) lfwt meaning wont to calumniate, or slander. (A.) But AM says, I have not heard xfwt as an epithet applied to a woman on any authority but that of Lth. (TA.)
xafiytN: see what follows, in two places.
One whose voice is still, or silent, by reason of his weakness. (Ḥar p. 76.) Applied to a dying man, Ceasing to speak; silent. (Ṣ.)

saHaAbN xaAfitN Clouds in which is no water. (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ.) A cloud like these does not move from its place: only that which contains water travels along: that which sends forth a slightly-flashing lightning scarcely ever, or never, does so. (Aboo-Saʼeed.)

zaroEN xaAfitN ‡ Dying, or dead, seedproduce: (A:) or seed-produce that has not grown tall: (Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA:) or that has not attained the full height. (TA.) The weak believer is likened, in a trad., to xaAfitu Alz-aroEi, (A, TA,) which at one time inclines, and at another time stands straight; accord. to AʼObeyd, xAft meaning what is fresh, or juicy, and soft, or tender: or, accord. to one reading, to xaAfitapu Alz-aroEi, meaning fresh, or juicy, seed-produce, that is soft, or tender, and weak; the p being added in xAfth as though by zrE were meant sunobulap. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xafarahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and xafarabihi, and xafaraEalayohi, (A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxofiru} (Ṣ, Ḳ) and _u {yaxofuru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaforN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and xf-rhu↓, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxofiyrN; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) and txf-r↓ bihi; (Ḳ;) He protected him; granted him refuge; preserved, saved, rescued, or liberated, him; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) from him who sought or pursued him. (Mṣb.) And xafaraAlqawoma, inf. n. xufaArapN, He protected the people and became responsible for their safety. (TA.)
And xafarahu He received from him hire for protecting him (Ḳ) and being responsible for his safety. (TA.)

And xafara, (TḲ,) inf. n. xifaArapN, (Ḳ,) He guarded palm-trees from injury: and seed-produce from the birds: syn. of the inf. n. of the verb in the latter sense, XiraAHapN. (Ḳ, TA: in the CK XaraAjapN, with fet-ḥ to the X, and with j in the place of H.)
See also 5.

xafara biAlEahodi, (Mgh, Mṣb) and biEahodiI, (A,) aor. _i {yaxofiru} (Mgh, Mṣb) and _u {yaxofuru}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xifaArapN, (Mgh,) He fulfilled the covenant, or engagement, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and my covenant, or engagement. (A.)
See also 4, in two places.
riyHuhu taxofuru Xahowapa Aln-isaMCi Its odour puts a stop to the carnal desire of women. (R, TA.)

xafira, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or xafirato, (Ḳ,) for most assert that this verb is only used in relation to a woman, and it seems to be seldom, if ever, otherwise used, (MF,) aor. _a {yaxofaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xafarN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xafaArapN, (Ḳ, TA,) or the latter is a simple subst; (Mṣb;) and txf-r↓, (Ḳ,) or txf-rt; (M, L;) He, or she, was bashful; or felt, or had a sense of, or was affected with, shame, shyness, or bashfulness; (Mṣb, TA;) and was grave, staid, or sedate: (Mṣb:) or was very bashful;, &c. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.)
2: see 1.

taxofiyrN [its inf. n.] is also syn. with taXowiyrN [The doing an action of which one should be ashamed]: (Ṣ, and some copies of the Ḳ, and so in the CK:) or tasowiyrN [the act of walling a town]: (so in other copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA:) and taHoSiynN [the act of fortifying]. (TA.)
4. Axfrhu He sent, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or appointed, (A,) with him a xafiyr [or protector], (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) to defend and guard him. (Abu-l-Jarráh El-'Okeylee, TA.)

He broke, or violated, his covenant, or engagement, with him; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the O having a privative effect; (TA;) he behaved perfidiously, treacherously, or unfaithfully, to him; as also xafara↓ bihi, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxofiru}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xaforN (Ḳ, TA, in the CK xafarN) and xufuwrN: (Ḳ, TA:) or xufuwrN is an inf. n. syn. with UixofaArN as inf. n. of Axfr in the sense above explained, but having no verb, such as xafara, belonging to it: (TA:) or you say, xafarato↓ cim-apu fulaAnK, inf. n. xufuwrN, such a one's compact, covenant, or obligation, by which he had become responsible for the safety, or safe-keeping, of a person or thing, or the like, was unfulfilled: and AxfrhAAlr-ajulu the man broke, or violated, or failed of performing, it: (Sh, TA:) and AxfrAlEahoda he broke, or violated, the covenant, or engagement: (Mgh:) and Axfr alone signifies the same. (IAth.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in two places.

taxf-rbihi also signifies He had recourse to him for refuge, protection, or preservation; sought his protection; asked him to be his xafiyr [or protector]; (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ;) and so xafarahu↓; (TA;) [and Astxfrhu↓, occurring in the Ṣ, in art. qwb:] he protected, or defended, himself by means of him; syn. AiHotamaI bihi. (Mṣb.)
xafarN: see xifaArapN.

xafirN, applied to a man; (Mṣb;) and the same, (Ḳ,) without p, (TA,) and xafirapN and mutaxaf-irapN↓, applied to a female, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also mixofaArN↓, (Ḳ,) as a possessive or an intensive epithet; (TA;) Bashful; or feeling, having a sense of, or affected with, shame, shyness, or bashfulness; (Mṣb, TA;) and grave, staid, or sedate: (Mṣb:) or very bashful,, &c.; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xafiyrN↓ applied to a man: (TA, from a trad.:) pl. [of the first, applied to a female, and of the second,] xafaAYiru. (Ḳ.)

xuforapN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and xufaArapN↓ (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) [both, in Ḥam p. 677, said to be inf. ns., but they are rather to be regarded as quasi-inf. ns.,] and xifaArapN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xafaArapN↓ (Ḳ) Protection, refuge, preservation, rescue, or liberation, (Ṣ,* A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from one seeking or pursuing: (Mṣb:) a compact, a covenant, or an obligation, by which one becomes responsible for the safety, or safe-keeping, of a person or thing; or the like; or simply responsibility, or suretiship; syn. cim-apN: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. of the first, xufarN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., mano Sal-aI AlS-uboHa fahowa fiI xuforapi Qll-ehi Whoso performeth the prayer of daybreak, he is in the protection of God. (TA.) And in another trad., Ald-umuwEu xufaru AlEuyuwni Tears are the protections of the eyes from Hell-fire when they weep from the fear of God. (TA.) And wafato, (Ṣ, A,) and xufaAratuka↓, (A,) May thy compact, covenant, or obligation, which hath made thee responsible for my safety, be fulfilled, (Ṣ,) is said by the object of protection to his protector when he has not as yet preserved him in safety. (A.)
xufarapN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

xafiyrN A protector; one who protects, grants refuge, preserves, saves, rescues, or liberates; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) from one who seeks or pursues; (Mṣb;) as also xufarapN↓: (A, Ḳ, TA:) a protector of a people, in whose safeguard they are as long as they remain in his district: (Lth:) pl. xufaraMCu. (A.) One who guards seed-produce from the birds. (TA.)
Oae who is protected, to whom refuge is granted, who is preserved, saved, rescued, or liberated. (Ḳ.) The Ḳ might be thought to imply that xufarapN↓ is also used in this sense; but it is not. (TA.)
See also xafirN.
xifaArapN (A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xufaArapN and xafaArapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) The hire, or pay, of a xafiyr [or protector]: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the vulgar say xafarN↓: and some erroneously change the x into g. (TA.)
See also xuforapN, first and last sentences.

xaAfuwrN A certain plant, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which ants collect in their habitations, (TA,) resembling tares, or darnel, (zuwaAn,) (Ḳ,) i. e., in form; said to be so called because its odour puts a stop to the carnal desire of women; also called marowN and zagobarN: so says Suh in the R. (TA.)
mixofaArN: see xafirN
mutaxaf-irapN: see xafirN

1. xafiXa, aor. _a {yaxofaXu}, inf. n. xafaXN, He had that quality of the eyes, or sight, which is termed xafaXN as this word is explained below. (Mṣb.) And xafiXato Eayonuhu His eye had that quality. (A.)

xafaXN Smallness of the eye, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or of the eyes, (Mṣb,) and weakness in the sight, by nature: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a natural narrowness in the eye: (TA:) and sometimes it is a disease: (Ṣ, Mṣb:*) or a corrupt state in the eyelids, (Kh, A, Ḳ,) and redness, which causes the eyes to become narrow, (Kh,) without pain, (Kh, A, Ḳ,) and without ulceration: (Kh:) and (so in the Ṣ and A and Mṣb, but in the Ḳ “or”) nyctalopia; or the seeing by night, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) but not by day: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the seeing by night more than by day: (Mṣb:) and in a cloudy day, but not in a clear one: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and sometimes, ‡ the being affected with ophthalmia, or inflammation of the eye with pain and swelling. (Mṣb.) kaOan-ahumo miEozaI HaZiyrapK fiI xafaXK [As though they were the goats of a pen, in respect of weakness of sight,] is a prov., applied to him who falls into blindness or perplexity or the darkness of night; because goats are the weakest of the ganam in rain and cold: originally said by ʼÁïsheh. (TA.)

xuf-aAXN The bat; syn. waTowaATN; (Ḳ;) a certain flying thing; (Mṣb;) that flies by night: (Ṣ:) so called because it can scarcely see by day; (Mṣb;) or because of the smallness of its eyes and the weakness of its sight (Ḳ, TA) by day: (TA:) its brain, if the hollows of the soles of the feet be anointed with it, excites the venereal passion: and if burnt, and used as a collyrium, it removes, or stops, (according to different copies of the Ḳ,) whiteness of the eye, (Ḳ, TA,) and sharpens the sight: (TA:) its blood, if smeared upon the pubes of one who has nearly attained the age of puberty, prevents the growth of hair; (El-Minháj, Ḳ;) as some say; but this is not true: (El-Minháj:) and if the pudendum of her who has difficulty in bringing forth, be rubbed gently with its gall-bladder, she brings forth immediately: (Ḳ,* TA:) the pl. is xafaAfiyXu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also xuX-aAfN.]

OaxofaXu One who has that quality of the eyes, or sight, which is termed xafaXN as this word is explained above: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) and one who contracts his eyes when he looks: (TA:) and one who has in his eyes white fluid matter, or motes, or the like: (AZ:) fem. xafoXaMCu. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 1. xafaDahu, [aor. _i {yaxofiDu},] inf. n. xafoDN, He lowered it; depressed it; namely, a thing; contr. of rafaEahu. (A.)
He (God) abased him; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) namely, an unbeliever. (Mṣb.) You say, Aall-ehu yaxofiDu mano yaXaMCu wayorfaEu † God abaseth whom He will, and exalteth.. (Ṣ.)
xafaDa janaAHahu He (a bird) [lowered or] relaxed his wing, and contracted it to his side, in order that he might rest, or cease, from his flying. (TA.)

And the same phrase, ‡ He made himself gentle, easy to deal with, compliant, or obsequious. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [xv. 88], waQxofiDo xanaMHaka lilomuWominiyna ‡ And make thyself gentle,, &c., to the believers: (Jel, TA:) or be thou condescending to the believers, and treat them with gentleness. (Bḍ.) And again, in the same [xvii. 25], (TA,) waQxofiDo lahumaA janaAHa Alc-ul-i mina Alr-aHomapi ‡ And humble, or abase, thou thyself to them both, from compassion: (Bḍ, Ḳ, TA:) or make thyself submissively gentle to them both, from compassion: (Bḍ,* Jel:) or there is a transposition in the sentence, and the meaning is wAxfD lhmA jnAH AlrHmp mn Alcl- [and make thyself compassionately gentle to them both, from submissiveness]. (O, Ḳ.)

Uin-a Qll-eha yaxofiDu AlqisoTa wayarofaEuhu, in a trad., means Verily God, at one time, bringeth down to the ground the just, or equitable; and, at another time, exalteth him: (ISh:) or maketh ample [the means of subsistence, &c.] to whom He will, and maketh scanty to whom He will: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) or maketh little the portion of the means of subsistence which is the share of any created being, and maketh it much. (TA in art. qsT, q. v.). xafoDu AlEadoli warafoEuhu is also explained as signifying The just's being overcome by the unjust, when men act corruptly, and the just's overcoming the unjust, when they repent, and act righteously. (TA.) [See also art. rfE.]

maAzaAlato taxofiDuniI OaroDN watarofaEuniI OuxoraI Hat-aI waSalotu Uilayokumo ‡ [app. means One land ceased not to make me go a gentle pace, and another to make me go a vehement pace, until I came unto you: for xafaDa as relating to pace is probably not only intrans., as it will be seen to be below, but also trans., like its contr. rafaEa: or it may mean one land ceased not to make me go down, and another to make me go up,, &c.; though its being tropical if having this meaning may be doubted]. (A, TA.)

xafaDa Sawotahu, (A, Mṣb,) aor. _i {yaxofiDu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xafoDN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) ‡ He (a man, Mṣb) lowered his voice; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) did not raise his voice; (Mṣb;) [contr. of rafaEahu, as is indicated in the A.]
[In most of the above-mentioned senses, xaf-aDa↓ is nearly; if not exactly, syn. with xafaDa.]

xafaDa AlHarofa fiI AlUiEoraAbi † He made the [final] letter to have kesreh, in inflection. (Mṣb.) xafoDN is syn. with jar-N [q. v.] (Ṣ, Ḳ) in the inflection of words: (Ḳ:) these two terms, in the inflection of words, are like kasorN in the non-inflection, in the conventional language of the grammarians. (Ṣ.)
xafuDa EayoXuhu, aor. _u {yaxofuDu}, [inf. n., app., xafoDN, q. v. infrà,] † His life was, or became, easy; free from trouble or inconvenience, and toil or fatigue; tranquil; and plentiful. (JK, Ḳ.*)
xafuDa SawotuhaA † Her (a woman's) voice was, or became, [low, soft,] gentle and easy. (TA.)
xafaDato † She (a woman) was, or became, low, soft, or gentle, in voice. (TA.)
xafaDati AlUibilu, [inf. n. xafoDN and maxofuwDN, like the contr. rafoEN and marofuwEN, (see xafoDN below,)] ‡ The camels went a gentle pace; (A, TA;) contr. of rafaEat. (A.)

xafaDa biAlmakaAni, aor. _i {yaxofiDu}, † He remained, stayed, or abode, in the place. (Ḳ.) [See also xaAfiDN.] A poet says, [app. using the verb in this sense,]
Uin-a XakoliI waUin-a Xakolaki Xat-aI
faQlozamiI AlxuS-a waQxofiDiI taboyaDiD-iI
[Verily the like of me, and verily the like of thee, are different: therefore keep thou to the booth which is our home, and remain at rest: thou wilt become fair]: the last word is for taboyaD-iI; a D being added. (Ṣ.)
xafaDa, inf. n. xufuwDN, also signifies † He died; said of a man. (TA.)

xafaDati AljaAriyapa, [aor. and inf. n. as below,] She circumcised the girl: [see baZorN:] (Mṣb:) xafaDotu AljaAriyapa, (Ṣ,) or xufiDati AljaAriyapu, (A, Ḳ,) is like xatanotu AlgulaAma, (Ṣ,) or, xutina AlgulaAmu: (A, Ḳ:) the former verb applies only to a girl: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or you say sometimes, xfaDa AlS-abiI-a, aor. _i {yaxofiDu}, inf. n. xafoDN, meaning he circumcised the boy. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
xaf-iDo raOosa AlbaEiyri Draw thou the camel's head towards the ground, that thou mayest mount him. (Lth, Ḳ.)
xf-Dhu † He weakened, and lowered, or abased, his state, and his rank. (TA.)
† He quieted him, or tranquillized him, and rendered the affair, or case, or state, easy to him. (TA, from a trad.)
xaf-iDo Ealayoka jaAXaka † Quiet, or calm, thy heart. (TA.)
xaf-iDi Alqawola yaA fulaAnu ‡ Make thou thy words (lit. the saying) gentle, or soft, O such a one: (Ḳ, TA:) and xaf-iDo Ealayoka Alqawola [signifies the same]. (Ṣ.)

xaf-iDo Ealayoka AlOamora, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or [simply] xaf-iDo Ealayoka, (A,) ‡ Make thou the case, or affair, light, or easy, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) to thyself: (A:) [i. e. regard it lightly: for] xaf-iDiI Ealayoki, occurring in a trad., as said by Aboo-Bekr to ʼÁïsheh, means make thou the case, or affair, light, or easy; and do not grieve for it. (TA.)
OuSiyba bimaSaAYiba taxaf-iDu Almawota † He was smitten by afflictions which brought near to him death, and from which he could not escape. (IAạr, L.)
3. raAfaEaniI waxaAfaDaniI: see art. rfE.
5: see what next follows {7}.

7. AnxfD, (JK, Ṣ, Ṣgh,) or AxtfD↓, (Ḳ,) or both, (TA,) [but the latter seems to be very rare, whereas the former is of very frequent occurrence,] and txf-D↓, (A,) It was, or became, lowered, or low, or depressed (JK, Ṣ, A, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 8. AxtfD: see 7.
AxtfDt She (a girl) was, or became, circumcised. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See 1, last signification.]

entry.sense: xafoDN: [see xafaDa, (of which it is the inf. n.,) throughout.]

A state of abatement, or remissness, or the like: (A, TA:) † ease; repose; freedom from trouble or inconvenience, and toil or fatigue; tranquillity; quietness; quietude; stillness; syn. daEapN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and raAHapN; (Mṣb;) and sukuwnN; (TA;) of life: (Mṣb:) or ampleness of the circumstances of life; (El-Marzookee, Mṣb;) plentifulness and pleasantness thereof: (El-Marzookee:) softness, delicateness, or easiness: (A, TA:) pleasant life: (L:) and [in like manner] xafiyDapN↓, softness, delicateness, or easiness, of life; and ampleness of the circumstances thereof: (TA:) and the former, † gentleness and easiness of voice. (TA.) You say, humo fiI xafoDK mina AlEayoXi † They are in an easy, or a tranquil, [or a plentiful and pleasant, or a soft or delicate,] state of life. (Ṣ.) [This phrase is said in the A to be tropical; but why, I do not see; since xafoDN in the sense of daEapN is proper accord. to the same authority.] And huwa fiI xafoDi AlEayoXi † He is in an ample, and an easy, or a tranquil, state of life. (Mṣb.) And a poet says,
laA yamonaEan-aka xafoDa AlEayoXi fiIdaEapK
nuzuwEu nafosK UilaI OaholK waOawoTaAni
taloqaI bikul-i bilaAdK Uino Halalota bihaA
OaholFA biOaholK wajiyraAnFA bijiyraAni ; (Ḥam p. 137, and Ṣgh;) i. e. † [Let not yearning of soul for family and homes prevent thee from enjoying] ampleness of the circumstances of life, or plentifulness and pleasantness thereof, in ease and tranquillity: [thou wilt find in every country, if thou take up thine abode in it, a family for a family, and neighbours for neighbours:] (El-Marzookee, MF:) another reading, which is preferable, though each is allowable, is nizaAEu in the place of nuzuwEu. (Ḥam ubi suprà.)

[It is also used as an epithet; app. for cuw xfoDK.] You say, EayoXN xafoDN, (JK, TA,) and xaAfiDN↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and xafiyDN↓, and maxofuwDN↓, (TA,) † An easy, or a tranquil, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and plentiful, (JK, TA,) and soft, or delicate, (TA,) life: (JK, Ṣ, &c.:) and maxofiDN↓ signifies the same as xafoDN. (TA: there mentioned in the same place as here.) [It is said in the A, that EyX xAfD↓ is like EiyXapN raADiyapN, (meaning that it is for EayoXN maxofuwDN,) and that it is tropical.]
Also ‡ A gentle pace; contr. of rafoEN; (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ;) and so maxofuwDN↓; (Ṣ,* A;) contr. of marofuwEN. (A, TA.) [See xafaDati AlUibilu.]

Also Low, or depressed, land: (TA:) and [in like manner] xaAfiDapN↓ a low, or depressed, tract (taloEapN muTomaYin-apN) of land: (ISh, Ḳ:) raAfiEapN signifying [the contr., i. e.] a hard and elevated tract of land. (ISh.)

huwa fiI HaAli xafoDapK and HaAli rifoEapK [He is in a state of abasement and in a state of elevation: or perhaps the word xfDp should be written xifoDp, to agree in form with rifoEap, and because in itself denoting a state]. (A.)
SawotN xafiyDN ‡ A low, soft, or gentle, voice. (TA.) And kalaAmN xafiyDN and maxofuwDN↓ ‡ [Low, soft, or gentle, speech]. (A, TA.) See also xaAfiDN.
EayoXN xafiyDN: see xafoDN.
xafiyDapN, as a subst.: see xafoDN, near the beginning of the paragraph.

hom.sense: AlxaAfiDu, one of the names of God called AlOasomaMCu AlHusonaI, The Abaser of the proud, haughty, or insolent: (Ḳ:) the Abaser of everything which He desireth to abase. (TA.)

xaAfiDapN raAfiEapN in the Ḳur [lvi. 3, applied to the resurrection, (AlqiyaAmap,)] means Abasing certain persons to Hell: exalting certain persons to Paradise: (O, Ḳ:) or abasing the disobedient: exalting the obedient. (Zj.)

A rájiz [of the tribe of Asad (Ṣ in arts. Xwl and Sn)] says, censuring a collector of the poor-rate,
OaUibiliI taOokuluhaA muSin-aA
xaAfiDa sin-K wamuXiylFA sin-aA
[Dost thou devour my camels, elevating the nose with pride, lowering age in one case and raising age in another?]: or, accord. to IAạr, this was a man addressing his wife, and censuring her father, who had required as her dowry twenty camels, all to be banaAt labuwn, and demanded them of him; and when he saw among his camels a fat Hiq-ap, he said “This is a binot labuwn,” that he might take her; and when he saw a lean bnt lbwn, he said “This is a binot maxaAD,” that he might leave her. (Ṣ.)
huwa xaAfiDu AljanaAHi ‡ He is gentle, easy to deal with, compliant, or obsequious: (A, TA:) ‡ he is grave, staid, sedate, or calm; (TA;) and so huwaxaAfiDu AlT-ayori. (Ḳ, TA.)
AimoraOapN xaAfiDapu AlS-awoti, and xafiyDapu↓ AlS-awoti, † A woman low, soft, or gentle, in voice: (TA:) not clamorous and foul-tongued. (T, TA.)
EayoXN xaAfiDN: see xafoDN, in two places.
OaroDN xaAfiDapu Als-uqoyaA † Land easy of irrigation. (Ḳ.) The contr. is termed raAfiEapu AlsqyA. (TA.)
bayoniI wabayonaka layolapN xaAfiDapN ‡ Between me and thee is a night of easy journeying. (Ṣ, TA.)
qawomN xaAfiDuwna † A people, or company of men, remaining at a water: when going in search of pasture and of the places where rain has fallen, they are not so called. (IAạr.)
xaAfiDapN A woman who circumcises girls. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.*) And xaAfiDN is sometimes applied to A man who circumcises boys. (TA.)

entry.sense: xaAfiDapN, as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: see xafoDN, last signification.

hom.sense: maxofiDu qawomK A place where a people are in a state of ease, or tranquillity; or in a plentiful and pleasant state of life. (TA.)
See also xafoDN, in the latter part of the paragraph.
maxofiDN also signifies The place of a girl where the operation of circumcision is performed. (Lḥ and Az, in TA, voce Eucorap.)
maxofuwDN: see xafoDN, in two places, in the latter part of the paragraph: and see xafiyDN.
maxofuwDpN A girl circumcised. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

entry.sense: AlHuruwfu AlmunoxafiDapu All the letters of the alphabet except g Z T D S x, and q; (Ḳ;) which latter are called AlmusotaEoliyapu. (TA.)

1. xafoqN signifies The striking, or slapping, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) a thing, [so as to make a slight sound,] with a dir-ap [q. v.], (JK, Ḳ,) or with something broad. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, xafaqahu, (Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _i {yaxofiqu} [and _u,] inf. n. xafoqN, (Mṣb,) He struck, or slapped, him, or it, [so as to make a slight sound,] with something broad, (Mgh, Mṣb,) such as a dir-ap. (Mṣb.) And xafaqahu, aor. _i {yaxofiqu} and _u {yaxofuqu}, He struck him slightly, [or so as to make a slight sound,] with a sword, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and with a whip, and with a dir-ap. (TA.) And xafaqa AlOaroDa binaEolihi He struck the ground [so as to make a sound] with his sandal. (Ṣ, TA.)

And hence, i. e. from xafaqahu as first explained above, (Mgh,) The sounding [of the patting, or pattering,] (JK, Mgh, Ḳ) of the sandal, (JK, Ḳ,) or of the sandals, (Mgh,) and the like: (TA:) and xafoqu AlOaqodaAmi EalaI AlOaroDi [the sounding of the patting, or pattering, of the feet upon the ground]. (Az, in TA, art. hms.) You say, xafaqa Aln-aEolu The sandal made a sound, or sounds. (Mṣb.)

And xafaqati Alr-aAyapu, aor. _i {yaxofiqu} and _u {yaxofuqu}, inf. n. xafoqN and xafaqaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xufuwqN, (TA,) The banner, or standard, was, or became, in a state of commotion; moved, or went, to and fro; trembled; fluttered; or quivered; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Axtfqt↓: (JK, Ḳ:) and in the same sense the former verb is used in speaking of the heart; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) xafaqaAnu Alqalobi signifying the fluttering, or palpitating, of the heart; (JK, T, Ḳ;) and in like manner xafaqaAnu AljinaAHi the fluttering, or flapping, of the wing: (JK:) so, too, the former verb is used in speaking of the mirage; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and ↓the latter verb likewise; (Lth, Ḳ;) and Ru-beh, by poetic license, makes the f of [the inf. n.] Alxafoq to be with fet-ḥ, in his saying,
muXotabihi AlOaEolaAmi lam-aAEi Alxafaqo
[Indistinct in respect of the signs of the way, glistening much in the quivering, or fluttering]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in like manner, also, the former verb is used in speaking of lightning, (Ṣ,* TA,) inf. n. xafoqN; (Ṣ;) and of a sword, and of the wind, and the like: and Axfq↓, said of the heart, and of lightning, and of a sword, and [Axfqt said] of a banner, or standard, and of the wind, signifies the same: (TA:) or xafaqati Alr-iyHu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. xafaqaAnN, (Ṣ, TA,) signifies The wind made a rustling, or murmuring, or confused and continued, sound. (Ṣ, TA.*) And xafaqati Aln-aAqapu The she-camel broke wind, with a sound. (Ḳ.)

xafaqa said of a bird, [because of the flapping, or sound, of its wings,] It flew. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also 4, first sentence. And said of an arrow, [because of its whizzing,] It went swiftly. (TA.) And xafaqa fiI AlbilaAdi, inf. n. xufuwqN, He went away into, or in, the countries, or lands,, &c. (TA.)

Also, said of a man, [in the CK, fulaAnFA is erroneously put for fulaAnN,] He moved, or shook, his head, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or bent [down] his head, (TA,) [or nodded,] being drowsy, or dozing; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also Axfq↓: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) or he drowsed, or dozed: (Mgh:) or he had a fit of drowsiness, or dozing, and then awoke: (TA:) or he slept; (JK, TA;) so says Ibn-Háni; (TA;) aor. _i {yaxofiqu} and _u {yaxofuqu}, (JK,) inf. n. xufuwqN. (TA.) And xafaqa biraOosihi xafoqapF↓ Oawo xafoqatayoni, (Mgh, Mṣb,) occurring in a trad., (Mgh,) He bent [down] his head, without the rest of his body, [or nodded,] once, or twice, being taken by a fit of drowsiness, or dozing. (Mṣb.) It is said in another trad., kaAnato ruWuwsuhumo taxofiqu xafoqapF↓ Oawo xafoqatayoni [Their heads used to nod by reason of drowsiness, or dozing, once or twice]. (Ṣ.) And in another, kaAnuwA yanotaZiruwna AlEiXaMCa Hat-aI taxofiqu ruWuwsuhumo, i. e. [They used to wait for nightfall until] they slept so that their chins dropped upon their breasts. (TA.)

xafaqati Aln-ujuwmu, inf. n. xufuwqN, The stars set, or disappeared. (Ṣ.) And xafaqa Aln-axomu, (JK, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxofiqu}, inf. n. xufuwqN, (Ḳ,) The star, or the asterism, [or the Pleiades,] set, or disappeared; (JK, Mgh, Ḳ;) as also Axfq↓: (JK:) or the former signifies the star,, &c., went down in the place of setting; and in like manner the verb is used in speaking of the moon; (TA;) and of the sun: (IAạr, TA:) and Axfqt↓ Aln-ujuwmu signifies the stars retired to the place of setting: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as some say, shone with a flickering light, or glistened, or shone brightly: [because of their twinkling, or apparent quivering: or] as though the A in the verb had a privative effect. (TA.) One says, waradotu xufuwqa Aln-ajomi, meaning [I came] at the time of the setting of the Pleiades; making the inf. n. an adv. n. [of time]. (Ṣ, TA.)

Hence, (Mgh, TA,) or, as some say, from the same word as signifying “the act of striking [or slapping],” (TA,) Alxafoqu signifies The act of inserting; (Mgh;) [i. e.] the causing the penis to become concealed in the vulva; (Ḳ;) or the act of copulation: (JK:) or [rather] the penis' becoming concealed in the vulva. (Az, TA.)
xafaqa All-ayolu The night for the most part passed away: (JK, Ḳ:) [and in like manner the verb is said of the day:] see xaAfiqN.
xafaqa AlmakaAnu The place was, or became, void, or unoccupied. (TA.)
xufuwqN in a horse is The being slender, or lean, in the belly. (AO, Ḳ. [See xafiqN.])

hom.sense: 4. Axfq, said of a bird, It beat with [or flapped] its wings: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and xafaqa↓ bijinaAHayohi [signifies the same]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. rnq.) And Axfq bivawobihi He (a man) made a sign with his garment, by raising it, and waving it. (Ṣ, Z, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
Said of the heart, and of lightning, and of a sword, &c.: see 1.
And said of a drowsy, or dozing, man: see 1.

Also He (a man who had gone on a warring and plundering expedition) failed of obtaining any spoil: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 157, and Ḥar p. 26:) because he becomes in a shaky, or unsteady, condition, at that time: or because his travelling-bags become unsteady, or shake about, by reason of their lightness and emptiness: so that the verb is of the same category as OaEoTaXa [meaning “his camels thirsted”] and Oajoraba [meaning “he had his camels affected with the mange, or scab]: (Ḥar ubi suprà:) or the proper signification is, he found the spoil to be not stationary: (TA:) or it means he returned disappointed of spoil, or of predatory warfare: (JK:) or he was disappointed of that for which he hoped. (Ḥam p. 157.) And He (a hunter or fowler) returned without having taken any game. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And His property became little. (TA.) You say also, Axfq fiI zaAdihi He (a man) had his travelling-provisions all spent, or consumed, [so that his provision-bags, being empty, shook about.] (JK.) and Talaba HaAjapF faOaxofaqa (Ṣ, Ḳ) He sought an object of want, and failed of obtaining it. (Ḳ.)
Axfq Aln-ajomu, and Axfqt Aln-ujuwmu: see 1.
Axfq fulaAnFA He threw down, or prostrated, such a one on the ground. (AA, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8: see 1, in two places.
miXofarN xafiqN A camel's lip flaccid, or pendulous. (JK.)

farasN xafiqN and xafiqapN and xufaqN↓ and xufaqapN A horse, or mare, slender, or lean, in the belly: sometimes the animal is so by nature; sometimes, by reason of loss of flesh; and sometimes, by being jaded: (AO, Ḳ:) sometimes, also, they said xafiqu AlOaHoXaMCi; at other times using the epithet by itself: (AO, TA:) pl. [masc.] xifaAqN and [fem.] xafiqaAtN and xufaqaAtN. (AO, Ḳ.)
xufaqN and [its fem.] xufaqapN: see xafiqN.

hom.sense: xafoqapN [A single nodding of the head, by reason of drowsiness, or dozing]: see 1, in two places: (Mgh, Mṣb:) a slight, or light, sleep. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting Ed-Dejjál [or Antichrist], yaxoruju fiI xafoqapK mina Ald-iyni, explained as meaning [He will come forth] in a time when religion will be drowsy, or dozing, by reason of weakness. (TA.)
maDaI xafoqapN mina All-ayoli means A period (saAEapN) of the night passed. (JK.)

And one says, sayoru All-ayoli AlxafoqataAni wasayoru Aln-ahaAri AlbarodaAni [The time of] the journeying of the night is the first part thereof and the last part thereof, and [that of] the journeying of the day is the morning, between daybreak and sunrise, and the evening, between sunset and nightfall. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph, in two places.
xifoqapN, (Ḳ,) or, as in the Tekmileh, xafoqapN↓, (TA,) A thing with which one strikes, or beats, such as a thong, or strap, or a dir-ap [q. v.]. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also mixofaqapN.]
And the former, (Ḳ,) or ↓the latter, (JK,) A smooth desert in which is [the kind of mirage termed] Ml: (JK, Ḳ:) so says Lth. (TA.) [See also maxofaqN.]

entry.sense: xifaAqN A garment with which one makes a sign, by raising it, and waving it. (JK.)
xafuwqN: see xaAfiqN.
Also A she-camel that breaks wind [often], with a sound. (Ḳ.)
xaf-aAqN [Flapping, or flapping much;] applied to a wing. (TA.) And applied to a bird, [because of the sound of its wings,] meaning Flying. (TA.)
OaroDN xaf-aAqapN A land in which the saraAbi [or mirage] quivers. (TA.)

xaf-aAqu Alqadami A man broad in the fore part of the foot: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or broad in the under part, or sole, of the foot: (JK, TA:) or having the foot light upon the ground; not heavy, nor slow: (IAạr, TA:) or quick in step, beating the ground much with the foot so that it makes a sound of flapping to be heard by reason of the vehemence of his tread. (Ḥam p. 173.)
xaf-aAqapu AlHaXaI A woman lank in the belly. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, TA.)
xaf-aAqapN fem. of xaf-aAqN [q. v.].
[Hence,] Alxaf-aAqapu The anus. (IDrd, Ḳ.)

xaAfiqN [act. part. n. of xafaqa in all its senses]. It is applied as an epithet to the saraAb [or mirage, as meaning Quivering]: and so xafuwqN↓ [but with an intensive signification]. (JK.) And [the fem. pls.] xawaAfiqu and xaAfiqaAtN are used as [substs.] signifying Banners, or standards, [because of their fluttering.] (TA.)
Applied to a man, Moving, or shaking, his head, or bending it [down, or nodding], when drowsy, or dozing. (TA.)
[Hence, app.,] raOayotu fulaAnFA xaAfiqa AlEayoni ‡ I saw such a one with the eye cast down, and depressed in the head [as though drowsy]. (TA.)

Oay-aAmu AlxaAfiqaAti Certain days in which the stars [in great number] became scattered (tanaAvarato [in the CK, erroneously, tanASarato]), [causing a belief that the day of judgment was at hand, (see Ḳur lxxxii. 2,)] in the time of Abu-l-ʼAbbás and Aboo-Jaạfar, (Ḳ, TA,) the 'Abbásees. (TA.)

AlxaAfiqaAni is a term applied to The place of sunrise and the place of sunset, (AHeyth, JK, Mgh, Ḳ,) by the attribution of predominance to the latter; for AlxaAfiqu, meaning the disappearing, is applied to the place of sunset: (AHeyth, TA:) or the horizon (Oufuq) of the place of sunrise and that of the place of sunset; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) accord. to Lth (TA) and ISk, (Ṣ, TA,) because the night and the day for the most part pass away (yaxofiqaAni↓, so in the T and Ṣ, but in the Ḳ, erroneously, yaxotalifaAni, TA) between them, (T, TA,) or in them: (Ṣ, TA:) or the two [opposite] extremities of the heaven and the earth: (Aṣ, Sh, Ḳ:) or the end of the heaven and earth: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, Ḳ:) or two vacant spaces (hawaAMni) next to the two [opposite] sides of the earth: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, TA:) and xawaAfiqu Als-amaMCi signifies The regions of the heaven from which issue the four [cardinal] winds. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, Ḳ.) One says, maAbayona AlxaAfiqayoni mivoluhu There is not between the place of sunrise and the place of sunset the like of him. (TA.) And OaloHaqahu Qll-ehu biAlxaAfiqi and biAlxawaAfiqi [May God remove him to the place of sunset and to the four cardinal regions of the heaven or earth]. (TA.)
xaAfiqN also signifies A place void of, or unoccupied by, any one to cheer by his presence. (TA.)
xayofaqN, applied to a desert (falaApN), Wide, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which the saraAb [or mirage] quivers. (Ṣ.)

Applied to a horse or mare, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) mostly to a female, (IDrd, TA,) and a she-camel, (IDrd, JK, Ḳ,) and a male ostrich, (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ,) Quick, or swift: (Ḳ:) or very quick or swift: (JK, Ṣ:) and xanofaqiyqN↓, (so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or xayofaqiyqN↓, (so in other copies of the Ḳ and in the JK and O, and so written by AʼObeyd,) each correct, the n in the former and the I in the latter augmentative, (MF, TA,) is applied to a she-camel and a male ostrich, (JK, Ḳ,) in the former sense, as is also xayofaqN, (JK,) or in the latter sense. (AʼObeyd, Ḳ.) Accord. to some, applied to a she-camel, it signifies Lean, or lank, in the belly; having little flesh. (TA.) And, applied to a woman, Long in the rufogaAni [app. here meaning the two inguinal creases], slender in the bones, and wide in step. (El-Kilábee, Ḳ.) Also, applied to a woman, Quick and bold; and so xanofaqiyqN↓: (TA:) or the latter, so applied, signifies light, active, or agile, and bold: and Sb says that the n in it is augmentative; deriving it from xafoqu Alr-iyHi [explained above: see 1]. (Ṣ.)

Also i. q. daAhiyapN [meaning either A calamity, or, as an epithet, very cunning]; (AA, Ḳ;) and so xanofaqiyqN↓; which latter occurs in a verse, variously related, applied to a child brought forth by a woman who had been in labour a whole night; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) meaning dAhyp; or, as some explain it, in this instance, meaning imperfectly formed; (TA;) [and is also used as a corroborative of dAhyp; for] one says daAhiyapN xanofaqiyqN↓ [a great, or severe, calamity; or extremely cunning]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: xanofaqiyqN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

Also, (as in some copies of the Ḳ,) or xayofaqiyqN↓, (as in other copies of the Ḳ and in the JK, and thus written by Lth,) a word imitative of The sound of the running of horses (JK, Ḳ) in which is a quivering, or convulsive, motion. (Ḳ.)
xayofaqiyqN: see xayofaqN:
and see also xanofaqiyqN.

entry.sense: maxofaqN A place, (TA,) or a level land, (Aṣ, TA,) in which the saraAb [or mirage] quivers. (Aṣ, TA.) [See also xifoqapN.]
And [the pl.] maxaAfiqu signifies The places of setting [of stars]: and is used as [a sing.,] meaning the place of setting of a star. (Ḥam p. 152.) [See also xaAfiqN.]
mixofaqN A broad sword: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or anything broad with which one strikes. (Mgh.)
mixofaqapN A dir-ap [q. v.] (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) with which one strikes [or flogs]: (Ṣ:) or (so in the Ḳ, but in the JK “and”) a whip of wood: (JK, Ḳ:) so says Lth. (TA.)
maxofuwqN A man (T) having a fluttering, or palpitation, of the heart. (IDrd,* T, Ḳ.*)
And Possessed, bereft of reason, or insane; syn. majonuwnN: (AA, Ḳ:) fem. with p {maxofuwqapN}. (AA.)

1. xafaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yaxofuw, (Ṣ,) inf. n. xafowN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xufuw-N; (ISd, Ḳ;) and xafaI, aor. yaxofiI, inf. n. xFfoIN; (Ṣ, TA;) and xafiIa, aor. yaxofaI, inf. n. xafoIN; (Kr, TA;) said of lightning, It flashed, gleamed, or shone, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) faintly, extending sideways in the adjacent tracts of cloud: when it flashes, gleams, or shines, a little, and then ceases, not extending sideways, it is termed wamiyDN; and when it cleaves the clouds, and extends high, into the midst of the sky, without going to the right and left, it is termed EaqiyqapN: (Ṣ, TA:) accord. to AʼObeyd, xafowN signifies the extending of lightning sideways in the tracts of the sky. (TA.)
And xafaA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xafowN, (TA,) It (a thing) appeared. (Ḳ, TA. [See also xafiIa, in art. xfI.])
xifowapN i. q. xifoyapN, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, xafiy-ap,]) an inf. n. of xafiytu lahu as syn. with Aixotafayotu, (Ḳ * and TA in art. xfI, q. v.,) the w and I being interchangeable. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xafiIa, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaxofaI, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xafaMCN, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) has two contr. significations: (Mgh, Mṣb:) It was, or became, unperceived or imperceptible, [or hardly perceived or perceptible, by any of the senses, or only by the eye or ear, or by the mind; mostly] unapparent, or not apparent; (Ḳ;) [latent; obscure;] hidden, concealed, or covered; (Mgh, Mṣb;) [or unconspicuous; but also faint, or dim, to the sight; suppressed, or stifled, said of the voice; or low, faint, gentle, or soft, to the ear; and obscure to the mind, abstruse, recondite, occult, or covert; and secret, private, or clandestine:] and the contr., i. e. it appeared; it was, or became, apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident; (Mgh, Mṣb;) [as also AstxfI↓: (see musotaxofK, below:)] or, accord. to some, the particle that connects it with its subject distinguishes one meaning from the other: (Mṣb:) you say, xafiI Ealayohi, aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) it (a thing, or an affair, Mgh) was, or became, unperceived or imperceptible, [&c., by him;] unapparent, or not apparent, [or obscure,, &c., to him;] (TA;) or hidden, or concealed, from him: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and xafiIa lahu it appeared to him; it was, or became, perceptible, apparent, open,, &c., to him: [but see what follows:] (Mgh, Mṣb:) whence the sayings of Moḥammad, [app. the Hanafee Imám,] referring to spoils, faxafiI lahumo Oano yacohabuwA bihaA wayakotumuwhaA Oahola AlX-iroki, i. e. It appeared [to them that they should go away with them, or take them away, and conceal them from the believers in a plurality of gods], and xafiIa lahumo Oano yuxorijuwhaA UilaI daAri AlUisolaAmi [It appeared to them that they should take them forth to the territory of El-Islám]: but this is said only in relation to that which appears from a state of concealment or from a hidden quarter. (Mgh.) [Hence,] bariHa AlxafaMCu The affair, or case, became manifest: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the state of concealment departed, or ceased; but the former explanation is better: or, as some say, AlxafaMCu↓ here signifies the secret; and the meaning is, the secret became apparent: (TA:) or, lit., the low ground became high and apparent; meaning † what was concealed became revealed. (Ḥar pp. 133-4. [See also art. brH.]) [And EalaI xafaMCK means Covertly, secretly, privately, stealthily, or clandestinely. (See also what follows.)]

xafiytu lahu, aor. _a {yaxofaIu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xufoyapN and xifoyapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and xifowapN, (Ḳ,) the I and w being interchangeable, (TA,) signifies Aixotafayotu↓ [i. e. I made myself unapparent to him, lurked, or lay hid or in ambush, for him; cloaked, or disguised, myself to him; hid, or concealed, myself from him]: (Ḳ:) [for] AxtfI signifies he hid, or concealed, himself, (Fr,* El-Fárábee, JK,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) minohu from him; (TA;) as also AstxfI↓, (Fr,* JK,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AxfI↓, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and txf-I↓ also is syn. with AxtfI [in this sense]: (Z, TA:) or you say, Aisotaxofayotu↓ minoka, meaning I hid, or concealed, myself from thee; but not Aixotafayotu↓: (IḲt, Th, Ṣ, Mṣb:) or AxtfI↓ in the sense of xafiIa is not of high authority, nor is it disallowed, (Az, Mṣb, TA,) but AstxfI↓ is more usual. (Az, TA.) You say, faEalotuhu xufoyapF and xifoyapF [I did it covertly, secretly, privately, stealthily, or clandestinely]. (Mṣb) And qutila xfoyapF and xifowapF [He was slain covertly, secretly,, &c.]. (JK.) And yaOokuluhu xifowapF [lit. He eats it covertly,, &c.,] means he steals it. (Ḳ.) In the saying in the Ḳur [vii. 53], AudoEuw rab-akumo taDar-uEFA waxufoyapF, the meaning [of the last word] is, Submissively, devoting yourselves to his service: or, accord. to Zj, adhering to his service in your minds: or, accord. to Th, celebrating Him in your minds: or, accord. to Lḥ, in quietness, and stillness: (TA:) or secretly; and so in the similar passage in the Ḳur vi. 63. (Jel, and so Bḍ on this latter passage.) xufoyapN is from Oaxofayotu AlS-awota [explained below in this paragraph]: (JK:) the intrans. v. whereof is AxtfI↓ [signifying It (the voice) was, or became, suppressed, or stifled; or low, faint, gentle, or soft; like xafiIa, which is more common]. (Lth, TA.)

xafaAhu, aor. yaxofiyhi, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xafoIN (JK, Mṣb,* Ḳ) and xufiI-N, (Ḳ,) also has two contr. significations: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) He made it perceptible, apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident: (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and he hid, or concealed, or covered, it; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ; [in this latter sense, erroneously written in the CK xaf-Ahu;]) as also AxfAhu↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, this latter has the latter meaning; and the former verb has [only] the former meaning: but accord. to other, the reverse is the case: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to Aboo-ʼAlee El-Ḳálee, the former verb has the former meaning only; and ↓the latter verb has both meanings: (IB, TA:) ↓the latter is also explained as signifying he removed its xifaMC, i. e. its covering: (TA:) and the former, as meaning he made it to come forth from a state of concealment: (JK:) and he drew it forth; (Ḳ;) as also AxtfAhu↓. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One says, xafaI AlmaTaru AlfaOora The rain made the rats, or mice, to come forth from their holes. (Ṣ.) It is said in the Ḳur [xx. 15], Uin-a Als-aAEapa MtiyapN OakaAdu OaxofiyhaA, (JK, TA,) or OuxofiyhaA↓, (JK, Ṣ, TA,) accord. to different readers: (TA:) the former means [Verily the hour of the resurrection is coming:] I am almost making it to appear: (JK, TA:) and the latter, I am almost removing that which conceals it: (Ṣ, IJ, TA:) or I almost conceal it: (JK, TA:) or, as Ubeí reads it, OakaAdu OuxofiyhaA mino nafosiI [I almost conceal it from Myself]: and Fr says [that the meaning is], I almost conceal it from Myself, and how then should I acquaint you therewith? (TA.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the flight [from Mekkeh], AxfI Ean-aA xabaraka [written without the vowel-signs, so that it may be AixofiI or OaxofiI↓,] i. e. Conceal thou thine information from such as may ask thee respecting us. (TA.)
