And in another trad., kaAna yaxofiI Sawotahu biOaniynK, thus with fet-ḥ to the I, meaning He used to make his voice perceptible [or audible, with moaning]. (TA.) And you say, Oaxofayotu↓ AlS-awota [meaning I suppressed, or stifled, the voice; or made it low, faint, gentle, or soft]. (Lth, JK, TA.) [And AxfI↓ AlkalaAma He uttered speech, or the speech, in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, tone; he spoke in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner; lit. he made speech, or the speech, to be low,, &c.]
xafaI, aor. yaxofiI; and xafiIa, aor. yaxofiI; inf. n. of each xafoIN; said of lightning: see xafaA, in art. xfw.
4. as an intrans. v.: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, near the middle.
As a trans. v.: see 1, in seven places, in the latter half of the paragraph.

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, near the middle.

hom.sense: 8. as an intrans. v.: see 1, in four places.
AixotafaI, said of a man, [if it be not a mistranscription for AuxotufiIa, like AuxotufiIa damuhu,] signifies also He was slain covertly, secretly, or clandestinely. (JK.)
As a trans. v.: see 1.
You say also AxtfI may-itFA He drew forth a dead body from the grave, to steal the grave-clothes. (TA.)
And AxtfI AlbiYora He dug, or cleared out, the well. (Mṣb.)
And AxtfI damahu He slew him without its being known. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 10: see 1, in four places, in the former half of the paragraph.

xafFA [more properly written xafFI] A thing that is unperceived or imperceptible, [or hardly perceived or perceptible,] unapparent, or not apparent; [latent; obscure;, &c.; (see 1, first sentence;)] (JK, Ḳ;) as also xaAfiyapN↓ and xaAfK↓ [for XaIoCN xaAfK, the explanation in the JK]. (Ḳ.) [See also xafaMCN.]
xafiI AlbaToni A man lank in the belly. (IAạr, TA.)
xafaMCN inf. n. of xafiIa. (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Also A thing that is unperceived or imperceptible [&c. (see xafFA)] by one; unapparent, or not apparent. [latent, or obscure,,] to one; or hidden, or concealed, from one. (TA.) A secret: so, accord. to some, in the phrase bariHa AlxafaMCu mentioned above: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph. (TA.) And [in the same phrase, accord. to some,] Low, or depressed, ground. (TA.)

xifaMCN A [garment of the kind called] ridaMC, which a woman wears over her other clothes: (Lth, JK:) or a [garment of the kind called] kisaMC: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and any covering of a thing, (Lth, JK,*) whatever it be with which one covers a thing, such as a ksAC and the like: (Lth:) pl. OaxofiyapN. (Lth, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] Oaxofiyapu Aln-awori The calyxes of flowers: (Ḳ:) sing. as above. (TA.)
And Oaxofiyapu AlkaraA [The coverings of drowsiness; meaning] the eyes. (Ḳ.)

xafiI-N i. q. xaAfK↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a thing; (Ṣ;) i. e. Unperceived or imperceptible, [or hardly perceived or perceptible, by any of the senses, or only by the eye or ear, or by the mind; mostly] unapparent, or not apparent; (Ḳ;) [latent; obscure; hidden, or concealed; or unconspicuous; but also faint, or dim, to the sight; suppressed, or stifled, applied to the voice; or low, faint, gentle, or soft, to the ear; and obscure to the mind, abstruse, recondite, occult, or covert; and secret, private, or clandestine: see 1, first sentence:] pl. xafaAyaA. (Ṣ.) [You say najomN xafiI-N A dim star or asterism. And makaAnN xafiI-N An obscure, or a concealed, place. And SawotN xafiI-N A low, faint, gentle, or soft, voice or sound.] And AimoraOapN xafiy-apu AlS-awoti A woman having a low, faint, gentle, or soft, voice. (TA in art. xfD.) And Aln-uwnu Alxafiy-apu i. q. Alxafiyfapu [q. v.]. (Ḳ.) And some of the Arabs say, (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ,) UicaA Hasuna mina AlmaroOapi xafiy-aAhaA Hasuna saAYiruhaA, meaning [When] the voice and the foot-mark of the woman [are good, or pleasing, the rest, or the whole, of what pertains to her is good, or pleasing]: (Yaạḳoob, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) for when her voice is soft, or gentle, this indicates her being bashful, or shy; and when her foot-marks are near together, and firmly impressed, they indicate that she has [large] buttocks and haunches. (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ.) One says also, laqiytuhu xafiy-FA I met him covertly, secretly, privately, or clandestinely. (TA.) [And maXaI miXoyapF xafiy-apF He walked with a soft, or stealthy, gait.]
Also One who secludes himself from [other] men; whose place is concealed from them. (TA.)

hom.sense: xafiy-apN A well: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a deep well; because its water is not perceived, or not apparent: (TA:) or a well of ancient times, that has become filled up and then dug again: (JK, TA:) or any well that has been dug and then left until it has become filled up, then dug again, and cleared out: (ISk, Ṣ:) [opposed to badiIoCN:] accord. to AʼObeyd, it is so called because it is made to appear: (Ṣ:) pl. xafaAyaA and xafiy-aAtN. (JK, TA)

And A tangled, or luxuriant, or dense, thicket, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) which the lion takes as his covert: (JK, TA:) or xafiy-ap is the name of a certain place frequented by lions; (Ṣ, IB;) and is properly imperfectly decl., so that you say Ousuwdu xafiy-apa; but it may be perfectly decl. in poetry. (IB.)
Also A slight taint, or infection, or a touch, or stroke, of insanity: so in the phrase bihi xafiy-apN In him is a slight taint,, &c., of insanity. (Ibn-Menádhir, Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: xaAfK: see xafiI-N:
and see also xafFA.

AlxaAfiI The jinn, or genii; (Aṣ, Lḥ, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) because they conceal themselves from the eyes [of men]; (TA;) as also AlxaAfiyaMCu↓ (JK, Ḳ) and AxaAfiyapu↓: (Ḳ:) or this last signifies what conceals itself in the body, of the jinn, or genii: (Ibn-Menádhir, Ṣ:) the pl. (of the first, Lḥ, JK, [and of the second and third also accord. to analogy,]) is xawaAfK; (Lḥ, JK, Ḳ;) [and of the first, xaAfuwna also, like qaADuwna; for] the bare piece of ground amid herbage is said, in a trad., to be muSal-aI AlxaAfiyna, i. e. [The praying-place] of the jinn, or genii. (TA.) The first (AlxaAfiI) also signifies Mankind; thus bearing two contr. [or rather opposite] meanings. (TA.) And one says, maA OadoriI OaI-u xaAfiyapa↓ huwa, (Ḳ and TA voce xaAlifap, q. v.,) or xaAfiyapK↓, (CK ibid.,) I know not what one of mankind he is. (Ḳ ibid.)

OaroDN xaAfiyapN [and OaroDu xaAfiyapK↓, the latter word in the former case being an epithet, fem. of xaAfK, and in the latter case a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst is predominant,] A land in which are jinn, or genii. (Ḳ.)
xaAfiI AlguraAbi: see the last sentence but one in the next paragraph.

xaAfiyapN contr. of EalaAniyapN [app. meaning that it signifies A state of being unapparent or not apparent, covert, secret, private, or clandestine: though explained in the TḲ (followed by Freytag) as an epithet applied to a man, meaning whose actions are always covert]. (Ḳ.)
See also xafFA.
And see xaAfK, in four places.

Also One, i. e. a single feather, of the feathers called AlxawaAfiI: (TA:) AlxawaAfiI signifies the feathers below the ten that are in the fore part of the wing: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or certain feathers that are concealed when the bird contracts its wing: (Ḳ:) or the four feathers that are [next] after those called AlmanaAkib, (Lḥ, Ḳ,*) and next before those called AlOabaAhir: (Ṣ in art. bhr, and L in art. nkb:) or seven feathers in the wing, after the seven foremost: (Ḳ,* TA:) but the people [generally] mention them as four: or they are the small feathers in the wing of a bird. (TA.) xanojarN mivolu xaAfiyapi Aln-asori [A dagger like the xAfyp of the vulture], occurring in a trad., means a small xnjr. (TA.) One says also xaAfiyapu AlguraAbi [The xAfyp of the crow]: and the pl. is [sometimes expressed by using the coll. gen. n., saying] xaAfiI↓ AlguraAbi. (JK.)

AlxawaAfiI also signifies The palm-branches [next] below the qilabap [which latter are the branches that grow forth from the heart of the tree]: (Ṣ, TA:) thus called in the dial. of Nejd: (TA:) in the dial. of El-Ḥijáz called AlEawaAhinu. (Ṣ, TA.)
AlxaAfiyaMCu: see xaAfK.

muxotafK A rifler of graves: (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) because he extracts the grave-clothes; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) or because he steals covertly: a word of the dial. of the people of El-Medeeneh: fem. muxotafiyapN. (TA.)

musotaxofK Hiding, or concealing, himself: and accord. to Akh, appearing: in both of which senses it is said to be used in the words of the Ḳur [xiii. 11], musotaxofK biAll-ayoli wasaAribN biAln-ahaAri [Hiding himself by night, and appearing by day: or appearing by night, and hiding himself by day: see art. srb]. (TA.)

Alyadu Almusotaxofiyapu The hand of the thief, and of the rifler of graves: opposed to Alyadu AlmusotaEoliyapu, which is the hand of him who takes by force, and of the plunderer, and the like: the Sunneh ordains that the former shall be cut off [except in certain cases], but not the latter. (TA.)

hom.sense: You say also xalilotu mino kacaA I missed such a thing. (JK.) And xal-a AlbaEiyru mina Alr-abiyEi The camel missed the [herbage called] rbyE, and became lean in consequence thereof. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)

And xal-a, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xal-N; (TA;) and Oaxal-a↓, (JK, Mṣb, TA,) or Ouxil-a↓, (Ḳ,) and Ouxil-a↓ bihi; (Ṣ, TA;) and Axtl-↓; (MA, KL;) said of a man, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb,) He was, or became, poor, or in want or need. (JK, Ṣ, MA, KL, Mṣb, Ḳ, AT.)

xal-a AlX-aIoCa, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxolulu}, inf. n. xal-N, (TA,) He, or it, perforated the thing; transpierced it, or pierced it through; as also txl-lhu↓: (Ḳ:) so in the M. (TA.) You say, xalalotu AlX-aIoCa biAlxilaAli, aor. _u {yaxolulu}, I transfixed, or transpierced, the thing with the [pin called] xlAl. (JK,) [And xal-a All-aHoma He skewered the flesh-meat.] And xalalotuhu biAlr-umoHi I pierced him with the spear. (JK.) And Axtl-hu↓ biAlr-umoHi He transpierced him, or transfixed him, with the spear; (T, M, Ḳ, TA;) and so biAls-ahomi with the arrow: (Ṣ:) or the former signifies he pierced him with the spear and transfixed his heart: (TA:) accord. to AZ, AlAixotilaAlu relates to the heart and the liver. (M in art. nZm.) And yaxotal-F↓ Alv-aworu Alkaloba biqaronihi [The bull pierces the dog with his horn]. (JK. [It is there vaguely indicated that xil-apN↓ signifies The act, or perhaps the effect, of a bull's piercing a dog with his horn.]) And txl-lhu↓ biAlr-umoHi He pierced him time after time with the spear. (M, Ḳ.)

And xal-a AlfaSiyla, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xal-N, (TA,) He slit the tongue of the young camel, and inserted into it a wooden pin called xilaAl, in order that he might not such: (Ḳ:) or [simply] he slit the tongue of the young camel, in order that he might not be able to such [any longer], so that he became lean; as also xal-a lisaAna AlfaSiyli: (Ṣ:) or Alxal-u signifies the fixing a xilaAl above the nose of the young camel, to prevent his sucking. (TA in art. lhj.)

And xal-apu, (T, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) aor. _u {yaxolulu}, inf. n. xal-N, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) namely, a thing, (TA,) a garment, (T, TA,) a [garment such as is called] kisaMC (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) or radaMC (Mgh, Mṣb), &c., (TA,) and a [tent such as is called] xibaMC, (Ṣ, TA,) He pinned it with the [pin called] xilaAl; (T, TA;) he conjoined (Mgh, Mṣb, TA) its two edges, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or its edges, (TA,) or he fastened it, (Ḳ,) with a xilaAl: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) and xl-lhu↓ has a similar, but intensive, signification. (Mṣb) A poet says,
samiEona bimawotihi faZaharona nawoHFA
qiyaAmFA maA yuxal-u lahun-a Euwdu
meaning, laA yuxal-u lahun-a vawobN biEuwdK [i. e. They (the women) heard of his death, and appeared, wailing, standing; no garment of theirs having its edges fastened together with a pointed piece of wood]. (TA.)

xal-a AlUibila, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxolulu}, inf. n. xal-N, (TA,) He removed, transferred, or shifted, the camels to what is termed xul-ap [after they had been pasturing upon HamoD]; as also Oaxal-ahaA↓: (Ḳ:) or the latter signifies he pastured them upon xul-ap. (Ṣ.)

xal-a, (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) [aor. _u {yaxolulu},] inf. n. xal-N, (TA,) is also syn. with xaS-a [He particularized, or specified]; (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) contr. of Eam-a; (Ḳ;) and so xl-l↓: (JK, Ṣ, TA:) thus in the phrase, Eam-a fiI duEaAYihi waxal-a (Ṣ, TA) and waxal-ala (JK, Ṣ, TA) [He included, or comprehended, persons or things in common, or in general, in his prayer or supplication, &c., and particularized, or specified, some person or thing, or some persons or things].

2. xl-l OasonaAnahu, inf. n. taxoliylN, [He picked his teeth;] he extracted the remains of food between his teeth with a xilaAl [or toothpick]; (Mṣb, Ḳ,* in which latter the pass. form of the verb is mentioned;) and so txl-l↓, alone; (T, Ṣ,* O, TA;) but accord. to the Ḳ, you say, txl-lhu [he extracted it], meaning the remains of food between the teeth. (TA.)
xl-l AlX-aEara biAlmuXoTi [He separated the hair with the comb; he combed the hair]. (Mgh voce taXoriyHN.)

xl-l liHoyatahu, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) and OaSaAbiEahu, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) He made the water to flow into the interstices of his beard, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of his fingers or toes, (Ḳ,) in the ablution termed wuDuwoC; (Ṣ, TA;) and txl-l↓, alone, signifies the same. (Ṣ.) It (the former) is as though it were taken from taxal-alotu Alqawoma meaning “I entered amid the breaks, or interspaces, of the people.” (Mṣb.) Hence the trad., xal-iluwA OaSaAbiEakumo laA tuxal-alahaA naArN qaliylN buqoyaAhaA [Make ye the water to flow into the interstices of your fingers or toes, lest fire that shall spare little be made to flow into their interstices]. (TA.)
xl-lhu kilosFA He put SaAruwj [or kilos, i. e. quick lime,, &c.,] into the interstices of its (a building's) stones. (TA in art. kls.)

xl-l Alqiv-aMCa, and AlbiT-iyxa, inf. n. as above, He investigated the state of the cucumbers, and the melons, or water-melons, so as to see every one that had not grown, and put another in its place. (AA, TA.)
See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
And see 1 again, last sentence.

xl-l, inf. n. taxoliylN, said of wine and of other beverages, It became acid, or sour; and spoiled: (Ḳ:) or, said of XaraAb [i. e. wine and the like], (Mgh,) or of nabiyc [i. e. must and the like], (Mṣb,) or of expressed juice, (Ḳ,) it became vinegar; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Axtl-↓; (Lth, Ḳ;) but this is disallowed by Az; (TA;) and txl-l↓; but this is of the language of the lawyers; (Mgh;) or, said of nbyc, this last signifies it was made into vinegar: (Mṣb:) or xl-l, said of XrAb, signifies it spoiled, (JK, T,) and became vinegar. (T.)

taxoliylN also signifies The making vinegar; (Ṣ;) and so AixotilaAlN↓; (Ḳ;) i. e. of the expressed juice of grapes and of dates. (TA.) You say, xl-l Alxamora, (Ḳ,) or AlX-araAba, (Mgh,) or Aln-abiyc, inf. n. as above, (Mṣb,) the verb being trans. as well as intrans., (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and txl-l↓ Aln-abiyca, (TA,) He made the wine, or beverage, or must or the like, into vinegar. (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.)

And xl-l Albusora He put the full-grown unripe dates in the sun, and then sprinkled them (naDaHahu, in some copies of the Ḳ nDjh,) with vinegar, and placed them in a jar: (Ḳ:) so in the M: and in like manner, other things than busor; as cucumbers, and cabbage, and baAcanojaAn [q. v.], and onions. (TA.) [Accord. to modern usage, the verb signifies He pickled.]

entry.sense: 3. xAl-hu, (JK, Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaAl-apN and xilaAlN (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and [quasi-inf. n.] xul-apN↓, (JK,) He acted, or associated, with him as a friend, or as a true, or sincere, friend. (JK, Ṣ,* Mgh, Ḳ.) laA bayoEN fiyhi walaA xilaAlN, in the Ḳur [xiv. 36], is said to mean [Wherein shall be no buying or selling] nor mutual befriending: or [and no friends, or true friends, for], as some say, xilaAlN is here pl. of xul-apN↓, like as jilaAlN is pl. of jul-apN. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Oaxal-a and Ouxil-a and Ouxil-a bihi: see 1, near the beginning.

Oxal-a bihi He (a man) fell, or stopped, short in it; fell short of accomplishing it; fell short of doing what was requisite, or due, or what he ought to have done, in it, or with respect to it; or flagged, or was remiss, in it; namely, a thing; syn. qaS-ara fiyhi; (Mṣb;) as, for instance, in belief, and in confession thereof, and in works: (Ksh and Bḍ in ii. 2:) he left it, neglected it, omitted it; or left it undone: (Ḥar p. 402:) or i. q. OajoHafa bihi [app. as meaning he was near to falling short of accomplishing it, or of doing what was requisite in it; or was near to being remiss in it]; namely, a thing. (Ḳ.)
He failed of fulfilling his compact with him, or his promise to him. (Ḳ.)

He became absent, or he absented himself, from it; he left, abandoned, or quitted, it; namely, a place, &c. (Ḳ.) You say, Axl- bimarokazihi He (a man, Ṣ, or a horseman, Mgh) left, abandoned, or quitted, his station (Ṣ, Mgh) which the commander had appointed him. (Mgh.) And Axl- bihimo He became absent, or he absented himself, from them. (JK.)
Axl- AlwaAliI biAlv-uguwri The prefect made the frontiers to be kept by a small body of troops. (Ḳ.)
Oaxal-a Uilayohi: see 8.

Axl-hu He made him, or caused him, to want, or be in need. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, maA Oaxal-aka UilaI hecaA What has made thee, or caused thee, to want, or be in need of, this? (Ṣ.) And maA Oaxal-aka Qll-ehu Uilayohi What has God made thee, or caused thee, to want, or be in need of? (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
Axl- AlOibila: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.
Axl-wA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UixolaAlN, (TA,) Their camels pastured upon what is termed xul-ap. (Ḳ.)
Hence, Axl- said of a man signifies † Oaxaca mino qubulK [i. e. He took frontways]: opposed to OaHomaDa [and Ham-aDa, q. v.], meaning Oaxaca mino duburK. (TA.)
Axl-t Aln-axolapu The palmtree produced bad fruit. (A' Obeyd, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And The palm-tree produced dates such as are termed xalaAl: [like OabolaHat from balaHN:] thus it bears two contr. significations. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense:
5. txl-l [primarily signifies It entered, or penetrated, or passed through, the xilaAl, i. e. interstices,, &c., of a thing]. You say, taxal-alotu Alqawoma I entered amid the breaks, or interspaces, of the people. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.*) And taxal-aluwA Ald-iyaAra [They went through the midst of the houses]. (Ṣ in art. jws.) And txl-l Alr-amola He passed through the sands. (Az, TA.)
And txl-l Alqaloba † [It penetrated the heart]; said of admonition. (TA in art. bhm.) And txl-l AlAX-aIoCu The thing [i. e. anything] went, or passed, through. (JK,* Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[Hence, It intervened; said of a time, &c. And hence the phrase mino gayori taxal-uli Without interruption.]
And txl-l AlmaTaru The rain was confined to a particular place, or to particular places; was not general. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 1, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph.

txl-l Alr-uTaba He sought out the fresh ripe dates in the interstices of the roots of the branches (M, Ḳ) after the cutting off of the racemes of fruit. (M.) And txl-l Aln-axolapa He picked the dates that were among the roots of the branches of the palm-tree; as also takar-abahaA. (AḤn, TA.)
For other significations, see 2, in four places.
6. taxaAl-N [said of several persons] The being friendly, one with another. (KL.) [You say, taxaAl-uwA They acted together, or associated, as friends, or as true friends.]

hom.sense: 8. Axtl- [primarily signifies] It had interstices, breaks, chinks, or the like. (MA. [See xalalN.])

[And hence,] It was, or became, shaky, loose, lax, uncompact, disordered, unsound, corrupt, (Mṣb,) faulty, or defective, (KL, Mṣb,) [and weak, or infirm, (see xalalN and muxotal-N,)] said of a thing or an affair; (KL;) it became altered for the worse. (Mṣb.) [You say, Axtl- mizaAjuhu His constitution, or temperament, became in a corrupt or disordered state. And Axtl- alone He was, or became, disordered in temper; (see taHam-aDa;) but this seems to be from the same verb said of a camel; (see Axtl-t AlOibilu, below;) for the camel becomes disordered in his stomach by pasturing long upon xul-ap, without shifting to HamoD. And Axtl- Eaqolahu His mind, or intellect, was, or became, unsound, or disordered.] And Axtl- Oamoruhu [His affair, or state, was, or became, unsound, corrupt, or disordered]; (Ṣ, voce AiDoTaraba;) i. e. waqaEa fiyhi Alxalalu. (JM.)
He was, or became, lean, meagre, or emaciated; (KL;) and so Axtl- jisomuhu. (Ṣ.) See 1, first sentence.

See also xal-a as syn. with Oaxal-a or Ouxil-a, &c., near the beginning of the first paragraph. [Hence,] Axtl- Uilayohi He wanted it, or needed it; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a thing; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also Oaxal-a↓ Alyh: (TA:) whence the saying of Ibn-Mesʼood, Ealayokumo biAlEilomi faUin-a OaHadakumo laAyadoriI mataI yuxotal-u Uilayohi [Keep ye to the pursuit of knowledge, or science; for any one of you knows not, or will not know, when it will be wanted, or needed]; i. e., when men will want, or need, that [knowledge] which he possesses. (Ṣ.) You say also, Auxotul-a UilaI fulaAnK Such a one was wanted, or needed. (JK.)
See also 2, in two places.
Axtl-hu biAlr-umoHi, and biAls-ahomi: and yaxotal-u Alv-aworu Alkaloba biqaronihi: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph.
Axtl- also signifies He served together. (KL.)
Auxotul-a said of herbage: see xul-apN, near the end of the paragraph.
Axtl- AlmakaAnu The place had in it xul-ap [q. v.]. (MA.)
And Axtl-t AlUibilu The camels were confined in [pasturage such as is termed] xul-ap. (Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1. xaloxalahaA He attired her with the xiloxaAl [or anklet, or pair of anklets]. (TA.)
xlxl AlEaZoma He took the flesh that was upon the bone. (Ḳ.)
R. Q. 2. taxaloxalato She attired herself with the xaloxaAl [or anklet, or pair of anklets]. (Ḳ.)
txlxl It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was, or became, old, and worn out. (JK.)

xal-N a word of well-known meaning, (Ṣ, Mṣb.) Vinegar; i. e. expressed juice of grapes (JK, Mgh, Ḳ) and of dates (JK) &c. (Ḳ) that has become acid, or sour: (JK,* Mgh, Ḳ:) so called because its sweet flavour has become altered for the worse (Aixotal-a): (Mṣb:) a genuine Arabic word: (IDrd, Ḳ:) the best is that of wine: it is composed of two constituents (Ḳ) of subtile natures, (TA,) hot and cold, (Ḳ,) the cold being predominant: (TA:) and is good for the stomach; and for the gums, (Ḳ,) which it strengthens, when one rinses the mouth with it; (TA;) and for foul ulcers or sores; and for the itch; and for the bite, or sting, of venomous reptiles; and as an antidote for the eating of opium; and for burns; and for toothache; and its hot vapour is good for the dropsy, and for difficulty of hearing, and for ringing in the ears: (Ḳ: [various other properties, &c. are assigned to it in the TA:]) xal-apN↓ signifies somewhat (lit. a portion) thereof; [being the n. un.:] (Aboo-Ziyád, Ḳ;) or it may be a dial. var. thereof, like as xamorapN is [said by some to be] of xamorN: (Aboo-Ziyád, TA:) see also xal-apN: the pl. is xuluwlN [meaning sorts, or kinds, of vinegar]. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., niEoma AlUidaAmu Alxal-u [Excellent, or most excellent, is the seasoning, vinegar!]. (TA.)
[Hence,] Oum-u Alxal-i [The mother of vinegar; meaning] wine. (JK, TA.)

[Hence also the saying,] maA fulaAnN bixal-K walaA xamorK, (AʼObeyd, JK, Ṣ,) or maA lahu xal-N walaA xamorN, (Ḳ,) or maA Einoda fulaAnK xal-N walaA xamorN, (Ṣ, in art. xmr,) Such a one, or he, possesses neither good nor evil: (AʼObeyd, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or neither evil nor good: for] AA says that some of the Arabs make Alxamoru to be good, and Alxal-u to be evil; [and thus the latter is explained in one place, in this art., in the Ḳ;] and some of them make Alxmr to be evil, and Alxl- to be good. (Ḥar p. 153.)

I. q. HamoDN [i. e. A kind of plants in which is saltness: or salt and bitter plants: or salt, or sour, plants or trees:, &c.: opposed to xul-apN]. (Ḳ.) A poet says,
layosato mina Alxal-i walaA AlximaATi
[She is not, or they are not, of the plants or trees called xl-, nor of the kind called xmAT ( pl. of xamoTN)]. (TA.)

A road in sands: (Ṣ:) or a road passing through sands: or a road between two tracts of sand: (Ḳ:) or a road passing through heaped-up sands: (JK, Ḳ:) masc. and fem. [like TariyqN]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] Oaxol-N and [of mult.] xilaAlN. (Ḳ.) One says Hay-apu xal-K [A serpent of a road in sands,, &c.]; like as one says OafoEaI SariymapK. (Ṣ.)
An oblong tract of sand. (Ḥam p. 709.)
A vein in the neck (JK, Ḳ) and in the back, (Ḳ,) communicating with the head. (JK, TA.)
A slit, or rent, in a garment, or piece of cloth. (Ḳ.)

An old and worn-out garment, or piece of cloth, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in which are streaks: (TA:) [or so vawobN xal-N:] and xaloxalN↓ and xaloxalN↓, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (JK, Ḳ,) signify old and worn out, (JK,) or thin, (Ḳ,) like halohalN and halohaAlN. (TA.)
A bird having no feathers: (JK:) or having few feathers. (Ḳ.)

A man (JK, Ṣ) lean, meagre, or emaciated; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xaliylN↓ (Ḳ) [a meaning said in the TA to be tropical] and maxoluwlN↓ and muxotal-N↓: (TA:) or light in body: (IDrd, TA:) and [the fem.] xal-apN, applied to a woman, light (Ḳ, TA) in body, lean, or spare: (TA:) the pl. of xal-N is xuluwlN. (JK.) Also Fat: thus bearing two contr. significations: (Ḳ:) and so maxoluwlN↓. (TA.) It is applied to a man and a camel. (TA.) Accord. to the Ḳ, it also signifies A [young camel such as is termed] faSiyl: (TA:) but it means such as is lean, or emaciated: (TA:) and so maxoluwlN↓, applied to a fSyl as an epithet, for a reason mentioned above, in an explanation of the phrase xal-a AlfaSiyla. (Ṣ, TA.)

Also i. q. Aibonu maxaADK [i. e. A male camel in his second year]; (JK, Ḳ;) and so xal-apN↓; which is also applied to the female: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and i. q. Aibonu labuwnK [i. e. a male camel in, or entering upon, his third year]; and in like manner xal-apN↓ is applied to the female; (JK;) or, as in the M, to a she-camel; (TA;) and, as some say, (JK,) a large she-camel: (JK, TA:) and Aibonu Alxal-api↓ signifies the same as Aibonu All-abuwni (T in art. bnI) or Aibonu maxaADK [or Abn AlmaxaADi]. (TA in that art.) You say, OataAhumo biquroSK kaOan-ahu firosinu xal-apK↓, (Ṣ, TA,) or kaOan-ahu xuf-u xal-apK, (JK,) [They brought them a round cake of bread as though it were the foot of a camel in its second, or third, year,] meaning small. (JK. [In the TA, meaning samiynap (i. e. fat); but this seems to be a mistranscription.])
A cautery. (TA.)

entry.sense: xul-N: see xaliylN, in two places.
xil-N: see xul-apN, in two places:
and see xaliylN, in four places.

hom.sense: xal-apN A road between two roads. (TA.)
A hole, perforation, or bore, that penetrates, or passes through, a thing, and is small: or, in a general sense: (Ḳ:) or a gap, or breach, in a booth of reeds or canes. (T, TA.) [See also xalalN.]

[And hence,] The gap that is left by a person who has died: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, TA:) or the place, of a man, that is left vacant after his death. (Ḳ.) One says, of him who has lost a person by death, Aall-ehum-a Qxolufo EalaI Oaholihi bixayorK waQsodudo xal-atahu, i. e. [O God, supply to his family, with that which is good, the place of him whom they have lost,] and fill up the gap which he has left by his death. (Aṣ, T, Ṣ,* TA.)
And The interval, or intervening space, between the piercer, or thruster, and the pierced, or thrust: whence the saying, raqaEa xal-apa AlfaArisi, explained in art. rqE. (O and Ḳ and TA in that art.)

[Hence also,] Want, or a want: poverty; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) need, straitness, or difficulty. (Lḥ, Ḳ.) One says, bihi xal-apN XadiydapN He has pressing, or severe, need or straitness or difficulty. (Lḥ, TA.) And sad-a Qll-ehu xal-atahu May God supply his want. (TA.) And it is said in a prov., Alxal-apu tadoEuw UilaI Als-al-api Want invites to theft. (Ḳ,* TA.)

I. q. xaSolapN; (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) both signify A property, quality, nature, or disposition: and a habit, or custom: (KL, PṢ, TḲ:) [and app. also a practice, or an action:] in a man: (TA: [see the latter word:]) pl. xilaAlN. (JK, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One says, fulaAnN xal-atuhu HasanapN [Such a one, his nature, or disposition, is good]. (IDrd, TA.) And hence, xayoru xilaAli AlS-aAYimi Als-iwaAku [The best of the habits, or customs, of the faster is the use of the tooth-stick]. (Mgh.)
See also xul-apN.
An isolated tract of sand, (Fr, Ḳ,) separate from other sands. (Fr, TA.)
And i. q. haDobapN [which signifies An elevated tract of sand: but more commonly a hill; or a spreading mountain;, &c.]. (JK, TA.)

Wine, (Ḳ,) in a general sense: (TA:) or acid, or sour, wine: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or wine altered for the worse, (Ḳ, TA,) in flavour, (TA,) without acidity, or sourness: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] xal-N↓. (Ḳ.)
See also xal-N, first sentence.
And see this last word near the end of the paragraph, in four places.

xul-apN an inf. n. [or rather quasi-inf. n.] of xaAl-ahu, q. v.: (JK:) True, or sincere, friendship, love, or affection; as also xuluwlapN↓ and xulaAlapN↓ and xalaAlapN↓ and xilaAlapN↓: (Ṣ:) or all these signify a particular true or sincere friendship, or love, or affection, in which is no unsoundness, or defect, and which may be chaste and may be vitious: (Ḳ: [in which all are said to be substs., except xul-apN, as though this were properly speaking an inf. n., though having a pl., as shown below:]) [and sometimes simply friendship: see an ex. in a verse cited voce maroHabN, in art. rHb:] or xul-apN and xal-apN↓, (Mṣb,) or xil-N↓ and xil-apN↓, each with kesr, (Ḳ,) signify true, or sincere, friendship, or love, or affection, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and brotherly conduct: the last two as used in the phrases, Uinahu lakariymu Alxil-i↓ and Alxil-api↓ [Verily he is generous in respect of true, or sincere, friendship,, &c.]: (Ḳ:) the pl. of xul-apN in the sense explained above is xilaAlN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also xaliylN, in three places.

A kind of plants or herbage [or trees]; (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, the sweet kind thereof; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) not HamoD: (JK:) or any pasture, or herbage, that is not HamoD; all pasture, or herbage, consisting of HamoD and xul-ap, and HamoD being such as has in it saltness [or sourness]: (TA:) the [kind of plant, or tree, called] Earofaj; and every tree that remains in winter: (JK:) accord. to Lḥ, it is [applied to certain kinds] of trees, &c.: accord. to IAạr, peculiarly of trees: but accord. to AʼObeyd, [shrubs, i. e.] not including any great trees: (TA:) and a certain thorny tree: also a place of growth, and a place in which is a collection, of [the plants, or trees, called] Earofaj: (Ḳ:) and any land not containing [the kind of plants, or herbage, or trees, called] HamoD; (AḤn, Ḳ;) even though containing no plants, or herbage: (AḤn, TA:) the pl. is xulalN: (Ḳ:) one says OaroDN xul-apN and OaraDuwna xulalN: ISh says that OaroDN xal-apN and xulalu AlOaroDi mean land, and lands, in which is no HamoD, sometimes containing [thorny trees such as are called] EiDaAh, and sometimes not containing such; and that xul-apN is also applied to land in which are no trees nor any herbage: (TA:) some say that xul-apN, as meaning the pasture, or herbage, which is the contrary of HamoD, has for a pl. xilaAlN, and then, from xilaAl is formed the pl. Oaxil-apN: and some say that this last means herbage that is cut (Auxotul-↓ waQjotuz- [in which the latter verb seems to be an explicative adjunct to the former]) while green. (Ḥam p. 662, q. v.) They say that the xul-ap is the bread of camels, and the HamoD is their fruit, (JK, T, Sudot;, TA,) or their flesh-meat, (Ṣ, TA,) or their xabiyS. (TA.)

Hence, by way of comparison, it is applied to ‡ Ease, or repose; freedom from trouble or inconvenience, and toil or fatigue; or tranquillity; and ampleness of circumstances: and HamoD, to evil, and war: (T, TA:) and the former, to life: and the latter, to death. (Ḥam p. 315.)
Also Acid, or sour, leaven or ferment. (IAạr, TA.)
xil-apN: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph:
and see also xulaAlpN, in four places:
and xul-apN, first sentence, in two places:
and xaliylN, in two places.

Also The jafon [i. e. the scabbard, or the case,] of a sword, covered with leather: (Ḳ:) or a lining with which the jafon of a sword is covered, (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Ḥam pp. 330 et seq.,) variegated, or embellished, with gold, &c.; (Ṣ;) but the pl. is also used as meaning scabbards: (Ḥam p. 331:) and a thong that is fixed upon the outer side of the curved extremity of a bow: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in the T it is explained as meaning the inner side of the thong of the jafon, which is seen from without, and is an ornament, or a decoration: (TA:) and any piece of skin that is variegated, or embellished: (M, Ḳ:) the pl. is xilalN (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 330) and xilaAlN, and pl. pl. Oaxil-apN, (Ḳ,) i. e. pl. of xilaAlN. (TA.)

entry.sense: xalalN An interstice, an interspace or intervening space, a break, a breach, a chink, or a gap, between two things; (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) pl. xilaAlN: (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb:) and particularly the places, (Ḳ,) or interstices, (Ṣ,) of the clouds, from which the rain issues; as also xilaAlN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) both occurring in this sense, accord. to different readings, in the Ḳur xxiv. 43 and xxx. 47: (Ṣ, TA:) the latter may be [grammatically] a sing. [syn. with the former], or it may be pl. of the former: (MF, TA:) and xilaAlu↓ Ald-aAri signifies what is around the limits of the house; (JK, Ḳ;) or around the walls thereof; thus in the M; (TA;) and what is between the chambers thereof. (Ḳ.) You say, daxalotu bayona xalali Alqawomi and xilaAlihimo↓ [I entered amid the breaks, or interspaces, of the people]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) And huwa xalalahumo and xilaAlahumo↓ (M, Ḳ) and xalaAlahumo↓ (Ḳ [but in the CK these words are with damm to the second l]) He is amid them. (M, Ḳ.) And jusonaA xilaAla↓ buyuwti AlH-I, and xilaAla↓ duwri Alqawomi, i. e. [We went, or went to and fro, or went round about, &c.,] amid the tents of the tribe, and in the midst of the houses of the people; like a phrase in the Ḳur xvii. 5. (TA.)

And [hence] Shakiness, looseness, laxness, or want of compactness, and disorder, or want of order, of a thing; (Mṣb;) unsoundness, or corruptness, (Ṣ, Mṣb,*) in an affair or a thing, (Ṣ,) or of a thing; (Mṣb;) [a flaw in a thing;] defect, imperfection, or deficiency; (Ḥam p. 300;) weakness, or infirmity, in an affair, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) as though some place thereof were left uncompact, or unsound, (TA,) and in war, (JK,) and in men: (JK, Ḳ:*) and ‡ unsettledness in an opinion. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Alxalalu The night. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád.)
xulalN: see xulaAlapN, in two places.
xilalN: see xulaAlapN, in three places.
xilalapN: see xulaAlapN, in two places.

hom.sense: xalaAlN [Dates in the state in which they are termed] balaHN, (JK, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the dial. of the people of El-Basrah; (T, TA;) i. e. green dates: (JK:) [but see balaHN and busorN:] n. un. with p {xalaAlapN}. (JK, TA.)
huwa xalaAlahumo: see xalalN.
xulaAlN: see xulaAlapN.
Also An accident that happens in anything sweet so as to change its flavour to acidity, or sourness. (Ḳ.)
xilaAlN A thing with which one perforates, or transpierces, a thing, (JK, Ḳ,) either of iron or of wood: (JK:) pl. Oaxil-apN. (Ḳ.)

A wooden thing [or pin] (Ṣ, Mṣb,) with which one pins a garment, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) conjoining its two edges: (Mgh, Mṣb:) pl. as above: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) which also signifies the small pieces of wood with which one pins together the edges of the oblong pieces of cloth of a tent. (TA.)
[A skewer for flesh-meat.]
A wooden pin which is inserted into the tongue of a young camel, in order that he may not such: (Ḳ:) or which is fixed above the nose of a young camel, for that purpose. (TA in art. lhj.)
[A toothpick;] a thing (of wood, Ṣ, Mṣb) with which one extracts the remains of food between his teeth; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also xilaAlapN↓. (Ḥar p. 101.)
[A long thorn or prickle: such being often used as a pin and as a toothpick.]
See also xulaAlapN.
And see xalalN, in six places.

entry.sense: See also xal-N, in the latter half of the paragraph.

Poor; needy; in want; (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also muxil-N↓, (so in some copies of the Ḳ and in the M,) or muxal-N↓, (so in other copies of the Ḳ,)
and muxotal-N↓ and Oaxal-u↓ (Ḳ:) and Oaxil-apN may be a pl. of xaliylN in this sense. (Ḥam p. 662.)

A friend; or a true, or sincere, friend; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) as also xil-N↓, and xul-apN↓, which is used alike as masc. and fem., because originally an inf. n., [or a quasi-inf. n., i. e. of 3, q. v.,] (Ṣ,) or xil-apN↓, [thus in the copies of the Ḳ, but what precedes it, though not immediately, seems to show that the author perhaps meant xul-apN,] used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl.: (Ḳ:) or a special, or particular, friend or true or sincere friend; as also xil-N↓ and xul-N↓; or this latter is only used in conjunction with wud-N, as when you say, kaAna liI wud-FA waxul-FA [He was to me an an object of love and a friend, &c.]; (Ḳ;) or, as ISd says, xil-N↓ is the more common, and is applied also to a female; (TA;) as is also xul-apN↓, (Ḳ,) and xil-apN↓: (TA:) xaliylN also signifies veracious; (Ḳ;) thus accord. to IAạr: (TA:) or a friend in whose friendship is no xalal [i. e. unsoundness, or defect, or imperfection]: (Zj, TA:) or one who is pure and sound in friendship, or love: (IDrd, Ḳ:) the pl. is Oaxil-aMCu (Mṣb, Ḳ) and xul-aAnN (JK, Ḳ) and Oaxil-apN: (Ḥam p. 662, and MA:) the fem. is xaliylapN; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) of which the pl. is xaliylaAtN and xalaAYilu: (M, Ḳ:) the pl. of xil-N↓ or xul-N↓ is OaxolaAlN: (Ḳ:) and the pl. of xul-apN↓ is xilaAlN, (Ṣ,) mentioned before, see 3, second sentence. It is applied in the Ḳur iv. 124 to Abraham; who is called xaliylu Qll-eh, (TA,) and Alxaliylu. (Ḳ.) And it is said that the pl. Oaxil-apN means also Pastors; because they act to their beasts like Oaxil-aMC [or friends, &c.], in labouring to do good to them. (Ḥam p. 662.)
Also One who advises, or counsels, or acts, sincerely, honestly, or faithfully. (IAạr, TA.)
And Alxaliylu also signifies The heart. (IAạr, JK, Ḳ.)
And The liver. (JK, TA.)
And The nose. (JK, Ḳ.)
And The sword. (IAạr, TA.) [And] A sword of Saʼeed Ibn-Zeyd Ibn-ʼAmr Ibn-Nufeyl. (Ḳ.)
And The spear. (IAạr, TA.)
xalaAlapN: see xul-apN, first sentence.

hom.sense: Also What comes forth from the teeth when they are picked; (JK, Ṣ,* Mṣb;) as also xilalN↓ (JK, Ṣ) and xulalN↓ (Ṣ) and xil-apN↓: (JK:) or xilalN↓ and xilaAlN↓ and xulaAlapN (Ḳ) and xil-apN↓ (Ṣ) and xaAl-N↓ (TA) signify the remains of food between the teeth; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and the sing. [of xilalN] is xil-apN↓ and [the n. un. of the same] xilalapN↓. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, for xilalapN is erroneously put xal-alahu.]) You say, fulaAnN yaOokulu xulaAlatahu and xalalahu↓ (JK, Ṣ) and xulalahu↓ (Ṣ) and xil-atahu↓ (JK) and xilalatahu↓ (TA) Such a one eats what comes forth from his teeth when they are picked. (JK, Ṣ,* TA.)
See also xul-apN, first sentence.
xilaAlapN: see xul-apN, first sentence:
and see also xilaAlN.

entry.sense: xuluwlapN: see xul-apN, first sentence.
xal-aAlN A seller of vinegar. (Ḳ,* TA.)

xul-iI-N a rel. n. from xul-apN as meaning the “sweet kind of plants or herbage.” (Ṣ.) You say baEiyrN xul-iI-N, (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ,) and UibilN xul-iy-apN (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Ḳ) and muxol-apN↓ and muxotal-apN↓, (Ḳ,) meaning [A camel, and camels,] pasturing upon xul-ap. (Ḳ.) And hence the prov., Uin-aka muxotal-N↓ fataHam-aDo † [meaning Verily thou art disordered in temper, therefore sooth thyself; or] shift from one state, or condition, to another: accord. to IDrd, said to him who is threatening: (TA. [See also 5 in art. HmD:]) [or it may mean verily thou art weary of life, therefore submit to death: see Ḥam p. 315.] And the saying of El-ʼAjjáj,
kaAnuw muxal-iyna↓ falaAqawoA HamoDaA
[lit. They were pasturing upon xul-ap, and they found HamoD; meaning † they were seeking to do mischief, and found him who did them worse mischief]: applied to him who threatens, and finds one stronger than he. (TA. [See also HamoDN.])

hom.sense: xaloxalN: see xal-N, in the latter half of the paragraph:
and see also xaloxaAlN.

entry.sense: xuloxulN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: xaloxaAlN: see xal-N, in the latter half of the paragraph.
ramolN xaloxaAlN Rough sand. (TA.)

Also, and HaloxalN↓, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is a dial. var. of the former, or a contraction thereof, (Ṣ,) and xuloxulN↓, (JK, Ḳ,) A well-known ornament (Ḳ) of women; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) i. e. an anklet: (KL:) [or a pair of anklets; for you say,] fiI saAqayohaA xaloxaAlN [Upon her legs is a pair of anklets]: (TA in art. Hjl:) pl. (of the first, Ṣ) xalaAxiylu (Ṣ, TA) and [of the second and third] xalaAxilu. (TA.)

xaAl-N (Ḳ) and mutaxaloxilN↓ (Mgh, Ḳ) [and muxotal-N↓ all signify Having interstices, breaks, chinks, or the like:] uncompact, or incoherent: (Mgh, Ḳ:) the first and second applied in this sense to an army. (Ḳ.)
For the first, see also xaAlN, in art. xyl.
And see xulaAlapN.

entry.sense: Oaxal-u More, and most, poor, or needy: (Ḳ, TA:) from Oaxal-a Uilayohi signifying “he wanted it,” or “needed it.” (TA.) Hence the phrase Oaxal-u Uilayohi [meaning More, or most, in need of him, or it]. (TA.)
See also xaliylN.
muxal-N: see xaliylN.

hom.sense: muxil-N: see xaliylN:
and see also xul-iI-N, in two places:
and what here follows.

entry.sense: OaroDN maxal-apN, or muxil-apN↓, (accord. to different copies of the Ṣ,) A land abounding with xul-ap, not containing any HamoD. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: maxoluwlN: see xaliylN, first sentence:
and see also xal-N, in the latter half of the paragraph, in three places.

entry.sense: muxaloxalN The part, of the leg, which is the place of the xaloxaAl [or anklet]; (JK, Ḳ;) i. e., of the leg of a woman. (TA.)

hom.sense: muxotal-N: see xaAl-N:
and see xal-N, in the latter half of the paragraph:
and xaliylN.
Also Vehemently thirsty. (ISd, Ḳ.)
OamorN muxotal-N An affair in a weak, or an unsound, state. (Ḳ.)
See also xul-iI-N, in two places.

entry.sense: mutaxaloxilN: see xaAl-N.

1. xalaOato, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxolaOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaloCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in an expos. of the Moʼallaḳát written xiloCN, (TA,) and xilaMCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with kesr and medd, (Ṣ,) so accord. to IḲooṭ and IḲṭṭ and ʼIyáḍ and IAth and Z and Hr, but in some copies of the Ḳ xalaMCN, and so many assert it to be, (TA,) and xuluwoCN, (Ḳ,) said of a she-camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) She lay down, or kneeled and lay down, upon her breast: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) or she was, or became, refractory, or stopped and was refractory, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and lay down, or kneeled and lay down, upon her breast, without disease or other like cause, (Ṣ,) and would not move from her place: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) like OalaH-a said of a he-camel, and Harana said of a horse: (Ṣ:) the epithet applied to her that does thus is xaAliYN↓, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) without p; (Lḥ;) and [app. to her that does so much, or often,] xaluwoCN↓. (Ḳ.) And in like manner xalaOa is said of a he-camel; (Ḳ;) accord. to ISh, only of a he-camel: (TA:) or the verb is used only in speaking of a female [when relating to a camel]: (Ḳ:) one should not say of a he-camel xalaOa: (Az, Ṣ, Z, Ṣgh:) but it is also said of a man, (Ḳ,) tropically, (TA,) inf. n. xuluwoCN, meaning ‡ He moved not from his place. (Ḳ, TA.)
[See also what next follows {3}.]
3. xAlO Alqawomu [in the CK xalaOa] The people, or party, or company of men, left one thing, and betook themselves to another. (Th, Ḳ, TA.) [xaAlaI (see 3 in art. xlw) has a similar meaning.]
xaluwoCN: see 1.
xaAliYN: see 1.

1. xalabahu, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxolubu}, (A, Mṣb,) or _i, (Mgh,) or _i and _u, (Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. xalobN, (Lth, Mgh, TA,) He wounded him, or scratched him, or cut him, with his nail; (A, Ḳ;) as also Astxlbhu↓: (Ḳ:) he (a beast or bird of prey, TA) seized him, i. e. the prey, with his claw or talon: (Ḳ:) or he (a beast of prey) rent his skin with his dog-tooth: (TA:) or he rent it (the skin) with his dog-tooth: (Lth, Mgh, TA:)
or he (a bird) cut and rent it (i. e. the skin) bimixolabihi with his talon: (Mṣb:) he rent it, or slit it. (Ḳ.) One says of a woman, qalabato qalobiI waxalabato xilotiI↓ [She smote, or overturned, my heart, and rent my midriff, or, more probably, liver, which is regarded as a seat of passion]. (A, TA.) And xalabato fulaAnFA She (a woman) smote the xilob↓ [app. here, also, meaning liver] of such a one. (Ḥam p. 343.)
Also It (a venomous or noxious reptile or the like, TA) bit him. (Ḳ.)
And xalaba Aln-abaAta, aor. _u {yaxolubu}, inf. n. xalobN, He cut the plants, or herbage; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also Astxlbhu↓. (Ṣ.)
And xalaba biAlmixolabi He worked, and cut, with the reaping-hook. (TA.)
The root denotes the making a thing to incline: for AlT-aAYiru yaxolibu bimixolabihi AlX-aIoCa UilaI nafosihi [The bird makes to incline, with its talon, the thing towards himself]. (IF, Mgh.)

[Hence,] xalaba fulaAnFA Eaqolahu, aor. _i {yaxolibu} and _u {yaxolubu}, He despoiled, or deprived, such a one of his reason: (Ḳ:) or xalaba AlmaroOapa EaqolahaA, inf. n. xalobN, he despoiled, or deprived, the woman of her reason: and xalabato Eaqolahu, inf. n. as above, she took away his reason; as also Axtlbthu↓. (L.)

And [hence,] xilaAbapN↓ signifies The endeavouring to deceive or beguile (IF, IAth, Mgh) with blandishing speech: (IAth:) or deceiving with the tongue: (Ṣ:) or a woman's captivating the heart of a man by the most blandishing and deceiving speech. (Lth.) You say, xalabahu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxolubu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or _u and _i, (Mgh,) inf. n. xalobN (Mṣb,* Ḳ) and xilaAbapN, (A, Ḳ,) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and xilaAbN; (Ḳ;) and Axtlbhu↓; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and xAlbhu↓; (Ḳ;) He deceived him (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) with his tongue: (Ṣ:) or he despoiled, or deprived, him of his reason, bimanoTiqihi [by his speech]: (A:) or, followed by bimanoTiqihi, he made his heart to incline [to him] by the most blandishing speech. (Mgh.) It is said in a prov., UicaA lamo tagolibo faQxolubo, (Ṣ, TA,) or faQxolibo; accord. to the former reading, which is that of Aṣ, (TA,) When thou dost not overcome, use deceit: (Ṣ, IAth, TA:) accord. to the latter reading, [it is said to mean when thou dost not overcome,] grasp little after little; as though it were taken from mixolabN signifying “a claw” or “talon.” (TA.)
3: see 1.
8: see 1, in two places.
10: see 1, in two places. Astxlb also signifies He cut, (Ṣ, TA,) with the reaping-hook, (TA in art. xbr,) and craunched (xaDada, TA) and ate, plants, or herbage. (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: xilobN i. q. ZufurN, (Ḳ,) used in a general sense [as meaning The nail of a man, and the talon of a bird, and the claw of a beast: see also mixolabN]: pl. OaxolaAbN only. (TA.)

The diaphragm, or midriff; syn. HijaAbu Alqalobi; (JK, L;) or HijaAbu Alkabidi; (A, Ḳ;) the partition intervening between the heart and the liver; (IAạr, Ṣ;) the partition between the heart and the belly; (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán;”) or a small and thin piece of flesh forming a connection between the ribs [app. of one side and those of the other]: or the liver [itself]: (Ḳ:) or its ziyaAdap [or zaAYidap]: (A, Ḳ:) or a white thin thing adhering to the liver: (Ḳ:) or a certain thing in, or upon, the liver, like a gud-ap: (JK:) or a small bone, resembling a man's nail, adhering to one side of the midriff, next the liver. (TA.) See 1, in two places.
A friend; [app. because he cleaves to another;] as also xilomN. (JK.)

[And hence, app.,] xilobu nisaMCK, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) a phrase like Hidovu nisaMCK and ziyru nisaMCK, (TA,) A man whom women love: (Ṣ:) or one who loves women for the sake of discourse, or for the sake of vitious or immoral conduct, or adultery, or fornication, (A, Ḳ,) and whom they love (Ḳ) in like manner: (TA:) and one who endeavours to deceive, or beguile, women [with blandishing speech: see 1]: (TA:) pl. OaxolaAbu nisaMCK and xulabaMCu↓ nisaMCK: (Ḳ, TA:) the latter [in the CK xilobACu] extr. [with respect to rule]. (TA.)
I. q. waXoIN [app. as meaning A kind of variegated, or figured, cloth or garment]. (TA.) [See also muxal-abN.]
The radish. (Ḳ, TA.) In a copy of the Ḳ, AlfaHolu is erroneously put for Alfijolu. (TA.)
The leaves, (Ḳ,) or broad leaves, (Lth,) of the grape-vine. (Lth, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xalibapN: see xaAlibN.
xalobaMCu: see xaAlibN.
xulabaMCu nisaMCK: see xilobN.
xalabuwbN: see xaAlibN.
xalabuwtN: see xaAlibN, for each in two places.
xaluwbN: see xaAlibN, for each in two places.
xilaAbapN: see 1. [And see also xil-iybaI.]

xul-abN † Clouds (saHaAbN, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) that thunder and lighten, (TA,) containing no rain: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or whereof the lightning flashes slightly, so that one hopes for their raining, but which deceive the expectation, and become dispersed: as though derived from xilaAbapN, the “deceiving with blandishing speech.” (IAth.) And Albaroqu Alxul-abi and baroqu xul-abK (Ṣ, Ḳ) and baroqu Alxul-abi (Ḳ) and baroqN xul-abN (A) ‡ Lightning with which is no rain; (Ṣ, A;) as though deceiving: (Ṣ:) that excites hope [of rain] and breaks its promise. (Ḳ.) Hence the saying, to him who promises and does not fulfil his promise, Uin-amaA Oanota kabaroqK xul-abK † [Thou art only like lightning with which is no rain] (Ṣ.). And fulaAnN xul-abN qul-abN † Such a one is sharp in intellect, clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent. (JK.)
xal-aAbN and xal-aAbapN: see xaAlibN.
xil-iybaI Deceit, or guile. (Ḳ.) [See also xalaAbapN, in the first paragraph.]

xaAlibN, applied to a man, Deceiving: (Ḳ:) and in like manner, [but in an intensive sense,] xal-aAbN↓ (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ) and xaluwbN↓ (Kr, Mṣb, TA) and xalabuwtN↓ (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ) and xalabuwbN↓ (Ḳ) Very deceitful (ISk, Ṣ, Kr, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA) and lying: (ISk, Ṣ:) and so, applied to a woman, xal-aAbapN↓ and xaluwbN↓ (A, Ḳ) and xalibapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xalabuwtN↓ (Ḳ) and xalobaMCu↓ (TA) very deceitful: (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ,* TA:) xalabapN is a pl. [of xaAlibN], and means men who deceive women. (Ṣ.) You say also AimoraOapN xaAlibapN lilofuWaAdi [meaning A woman who captivates the heart by the most blandishing and deceitful speech]. (TA.)

Oaxolabu [More, and most, deceiving or deceitful]. You say of a woman, taxolubu qaloba Alr-ajuli biOaloTafi Alqawoli waOaxolabihi [She captivates the heart of the man by the most blandishing and deceiving speech]. (Lth.)

mixolabN [The talon, or claw, of a bird or beast of prey; a tearing talon or claw;] the same to the bird (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) and to the beast of prey (Ṣ, Mṣb) as the Zufur to man; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) because the bird [or beast] cuts and rends with it the skin: (Mṣb:) the Zufur [or nail] (A, Ḳ) of any beast or bird of prey: or it is of a bird of prey; and the Zfr is of a bird that does not prey: (Ḳ:) pl. maxaAlibu. (A.) [See also xilobN.] You say, OanoXaba fiyhi maxaAlibahu, meaning ‡ He clung, or caught, to him, or it. (A.)
Also A minojal [or reaping-hook] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) in a general sense: or (TA) that has no teeth. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)
EuqaAbN muxolibapN An eagle with sharp talons. (JK.)
muxal-abN, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (Ṣ, TA,) means kaviyru AlwaXoIi, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) i. e. [Much variegated or figured; or] of many colours. (TA.) [See also xilobN.]

1. xalaja, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoliju}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or _u, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xalojN; and Axtlj↓; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, TA;) and txl-j↓; (L, TA;) He drew, dragged, pulled, strained, stretched, extended, lengthened, or protracted, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) a thing: (Ṣ,* L, TA:) and he pulled out or up, displaced, removed, or took away, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a thing, (Ṣ,* A, Mṣb, TA,) and a person. (A.) Thus in the saying, Oaxaca biyadihi faxalajahu bayoni SaHobihi [He took his hand, and pulled him out from amid his companions]: and xalaja rumoHahu mina AlmaToEuwni [He pulled out his spear from the person pierced]: and Axtlj↓ rumoHFA marokuwzFA [He pulled out a spear stuck in the ground]. (A, TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce maTorabN.] El-ʼAjjáj says,
faUino yakuno hecaA Alz-amaAnu xalajaA
faqado labisonaA EayoXahu AlmuxarofajaA
meaning † And if this time has taken away, and exchanged for another, a state [in which we were, we have long enjoyed its plentiful life]. (Ṣ.)

[Hence,] xulija, said of a stallion-camel, He was taken away from the females that had passed seven or eight months since the period when they last brought forth, before he had become too languid to cover any longer. (Lth, A, L.)
And xalaja, aor. _i {yaxoliju}, † He weaned his offspring, or the offspring of his she-camel: (Ḳ:) ‡ he separated a young camel from the mother. (A.) And xalajato waladahaA ‡ She (a mother) weaned her offspring: (M, A:) so accord. to Lḥ, who does not particularize any kind [of animal]. (M.) And xalaja naAqapF † He weaned the offspring of a she-camel. (Ṣ.) And Auxotulija↓ mino bayonihimo ‡ [He was taken away from among them]: said of the dead. (A, TA.)

xalajaniI kacaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) aor. _i {yaxoliju}, (Ḳ,) † Such a thing occupied me; busied me; or diverted me, by employing my attention, from other things. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.) You say, xalajatohu Oumuwru Ald-unoyaA † [The affairs of the world occupied him,, &c.]. (Ṣ, TA.) And xalajatohu AlxawaAliju↓ † Busying [or distracting] affairs busied [or distracted] him. (Lth.) And a poet says,
waOabiytu taxolijuniI Alhumuwmu kaOan-aniI
dalowu Als-uqaApi tumad-u biAlOaXoTaAni
[And I pass the night,] anxieties busying me [as though I were the bucket of the waterers, drawn from the well by the ropes]. (IAạr.)
taxoliju Als-ayora, said of a fleet she-camel, (L, Ḳ,) † She goes, journeys, or travels, quickly. (L.) And xalaja fiI miXoyatihi: see 5.

xalaja, aor. _i {yaxoliju}, also signifies † He put (a thing, TA) in motion, or into a state of commotion. (A, Ḳ, TA.) You say, xalaja HaAjibayohi, and Eayonayohi, ‡ He put in motion, or into a state of commotion, his eyebrows, and his eyes. (A.)

And xalaja, aor. _i {yaxoliju} (L, Ḳ) and _u {yaxoluju}, inf. n. xalojN, (L, TA,) † He made a sign [by a motion] (L, Ḳ, TA) biEayonihi with his eye, and biHaAjibayohi with his eyebrows. (L, TA.) And xalajahu biHaAjibihi, aor. and inf. n. as above, † He made a sign to him with his eyebrow. (L.) And xalajahu biEayonihi † He made a sign to him with his eye; winked to him. (Ṣ, L.) And xalajatoniI biEayonihaA ‡ She made a sign to me with her eye, or winked to me, to indicate a time or place of appointment, or something that she desired. (A, TA.)
See also 8, in two places.

3. xAljhu, (A, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. muxaAlajapN, (Mgh,) He contended with him, (A, Mgh,* Mṣb, TA,) [as though drawing, or pulling, him, (see 6,)] namely, a man. (TA.) You say, xAljhu AlX-aIoCa He contended with him for the thing. (A.) And xaAlajaniI AlqiraMCapa † He vied with me in reciting the words of prayer, (Mgh,* TA,) uttering aloud what I uttered aloud, so that he took from my tongue what I was reciting, and I did not [or could not] continue to do so. (TA, from a trad.) And xAlj qalobiI OamorN ‡ A thing, or an affair, troubled my heart with contending thoughts. (Ḳ, TA.) And maA yuxaAlijuniI fiI celika AlOamori Xak-N ‡ [Doubt does not contend with me respecting that affair], meaning I doubt not respecting that affair. (Sh, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Axlj HaAjibayohi Eano Eayonayohi † [He drew up his eyebrows from his eyes]. (Lth.)
Axlj is also quasi-pass. of xalaja, though this is extr. with respect to analogy, like AbXr [q. v.], &c.; (TA;) signifying It was, or became, drawn, dragged, pulled,, &c. (L, TA.)
5. txl-j: see 1, first sentence.

[Hence,] txl-j fiI miXoyatihi He (a paralytic, Ṣ, Ḳ, or an insane, or a possessed, man, A) walked in a loose manner, as though disjointed, and inclined from side to side, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) as one dragging a thing: (A, TA:) it is similar to txl-E: (TA:) and signifies also he (an insane, or a possessed, man) inclined from side to side in his gait, (Mgh,* TA,) as though he were drawing along, now to the right and now to the left; and so xalaja↓ fI mXyth, aor. _i {yaxoliju}, inf. n. xalajaAnN. (TA.)
See also 8, in two places.
And see 6.
[It branched off, like a xaliyj, from a large river: occurring in this sense in art. djl of the T and TA; where dujayol is described as nahorN SagiyrN yataxal-aju mino dijolapa.]

entry.sense: 6. taxaAlajatohu Alhumuwmu ‡ Anxieties contended with him, one on one side and another on another side, as though each were drawing him to it. (A, L.) And txAlj fiI SadoriI XaIoCN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and Axtlj↓ (TA) ‡ A thing was, or became, unsettled in my bosom, or mind; (TA;) meaning I was in doubt [respecting a thing]; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also txl-j↓ and tHl-j, (Lth,* Aṣ, TA in art. Hlj,) or these two mean nearly the same. (Sh, TA in that art; in which see 5, in three places.) [See also 8.]

hom.sense: 8. Axtlj, as a trans. v.: see 1, in three places.

Also ‡ It (a thing) was, or became, in a state of commotion, or agitation; it quivered, quaked, or throbbed; (Sh, TA;) and so txl-j↓ (Sh, Ḳ) [and xalaja↓, as will be seen from what follows]. You say Axtlj HaAjibaAhu † His eyebrows quivered, or were in a state of commotion. (Lth.) And Axtljt Eayonuhu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and txl-jt↓; (TA;) and xalajato↓, aor. _i {yaxoliju} and _u {yaxoluju}, inf. n. xuluwjN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xalajaAnN; (Sh;) † His eye quivered, throbbed, or was in a state of commotion; (Sh, L;) i. q. TaArato, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., throbbed. (PṢ, TḲ.) And Axtlj AlEuDowu † The member (i. e. any member, L) quivered,, &c. (Mgh, L, Mṣb.)
† He trembled, quivered, or quaked. (TA.) And Axtlj biwajohihi † He moved about his lips and his chin, mocking and imitating a person talking. (TA, from a trad.)
Axtlj fiI SadoriI ham-N ‡ [Anxious thought fluttered in my bosom]. (TA.) See also 6.

entry.sense: xilojN: see xaluwjN.
xulujN † Persons trembling in the bodies. (Ḳ.)
† Persons tired, or fatigued. (IAạr.)
† A people whose lineage, or origin, is doubted, (T, Ḳ,) so that different persons dispute, one with another, respecting it. (T.) See also muxotalajN.
xalanojN: see art. xlnj.

xaluwjN Clouds (saHaAb) separated, or scattered, (Ḳ, TA,) as though drawn away from the mass; of the dial. of Hudheyl: (TA:) or clouds, (sHAb, Ḳ,) and a cloud, (saHaAbap, TA,) abounding with water, (Ḳ, TA,) and lightening vehemently. (TA.)
And hence, † A she-camel abounding with milk, and yearning towards her young one. (T, TA.)

Also † A she-camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or other female, (TA,) whose young one has been taken from her (Ṣ, Ḳ) by slaughter or death, and that yearns towards it. (TA,) and whose milk in consequence has become little in quantity. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Accord. to some, (L,) † A she-camel that goes, journeys, or travels, quickly, by reason of her [natural, not forced,] fleetness. (L, Ḳ.*) Pl. xilojN↓ [or, rather, this is a quasi-pl. n., like as libonN is of labuwnN,] and xilaAjN. (L.)

xaliyjN A canal, or cut, from a large river; syn. XaromN mino baHorK: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) what is cut off from the main mass of water; so called because it is drawn from it: (ISd, TA:) a river cut off from a larger river, extending to a place where use is made of it: a river on one side of a larger river: (TA:) and [simply] a river: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) and xaliyjaA nahorK is said to signify the two sides of a river: (Ṣ:) or the two wings thereof: and some explain the sing. (xlyj) as meaning a branch from a valley, conveying its water to another place: (TA:) pl. xulojaAnN (A, TA) and xulujN. (TA.)
xaAlijN [act. part. n. of 1].

It is said in a trad. of ʼAlee, respecting life (AlHayaAp), Uin-a Qll-eha jaEala Almawota xaAlijFA liOaXoTaAnihaA, meaning † Verily God has made death to be quick in seizing its cords; i. e. the cords of life. (L.)
[Hence,] AlxaAliju is applied to † Death; because it draws away mankind. (TA.)
[jaAlijapN † A busying, or distracting, affair: pl. xawaAliju. Hence,] xalajatohu AlxawaAliju: see 1.
maxal-ajN † Fat, so that his flesh quivers. (TA.)

muxotalajN ‡ A man whose name has been transferred from the register of his own people to that of another people, to whom his lineage, or origin, is consequently ascribed, (A, TA,) and respecting whose lineage, or origin, people differ and dispute: (TA:) accord. to some, i. q. xulujN↓ as meaning a people whose reputed origin is transferred so as to be ascribed to another people: and the former signifies also a man whose lineage, or origin, is disputed; as though he were drawn, and pulled away, from his people. (TA.)
† One whose flesh and strength are taken away. (TA.)
† A face (Lth, ISd, Ḳ) lean, (Lth, ISd,) having little flesh. (Ḳ.)

1. xalada, aor. _u {yaxoludu}, inf. n. xuluwdN (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xulodN, (Ṣ,* A, L, Ḳ,* [but the latter is not said to be an inf. n. in the first nor in the last of these lexicons, and is perhaps a simple subst.,]) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode; syn. OaqaAma: (L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, long;
syn. OaTaAla AlUiqaAmapa: (A:) bimakaAnK (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and UilaI makaAnK (Ḳ) [in a place]; as also Axld↓ (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xl-d↓: (Ḳ:) and he remained, or continued, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;*) syn. baqiIa, (A, L, Ḳ,) and daAma, (Ḳ,) or daAma baqaAWuhu; (Ṣ, L;) fiI daArK in a house, or an abode, not going forth from it: (L:) he remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, for ever, or perpetually, in Paradise, (A, L,) or in Hell. (A.)

[Hence,] xalada, (L, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxolidu} and _u {yaxoludu}, (Ḥam p. 70, and L,) inf. n. xalodN, (Ḳ,) or xaladN, (thus in the L,) and xuluwdN; (L, Ḳ;) and Axld↓; (Ḥam ubi suprà;) ‡ He was slow in becoming hoary, (Ḥam, L, Ḳ,) when advanced in years; (Ḳ;) as though he were created to continue for ever. (L.)
See also 4, in two places.

hom.sense: 2. xl-d, as a trans. v.: see 4.
Also He adorned a girl [with bracelets, or other ornaments (see the pass. part. n.), or] with earrings. (AA.)
As an intrans. v.: see 1:
and see also 4.

4. Axldhu, (Ṣ, A, L,) inf. n. UixolaAdN; (Ṣ, L;) and xl-dhu↓, (Ṣ, A, L,) inf. n. taxoliydN; (Ṣ, L;) He (God, Ṣ, L) caused him to remain, stay, dwell, or abide: (L:) or caused him to remain, stay, dwell, or abide, long, in a place: (A:) or caused him to remain, or continue, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever, (Ṣ, L,) in a house, or an abode, not going forth from it: (L:) or caused him to remain, stay, dwell, or abide, for ever, or perpetually, in Paradise, (A, L,) or in Hell. (A.) yaHosabu Oan-a maAlahu Oaxoladahu, in the Ḳur civ. 3, means He thinketh that his wealth hath made him to be one that shall continue for ever; that he shall not die: (Jel:) i. e. he acteth as one that thinketh, with his opulence, he shall not die. (L.)
As an intrans. v.: see 1, in two places.
You say also, Axld bihi, (inf. n. as above, AA,) He kept, or clave, to him; (AA, AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., to his companion. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And Axld Uilayohi ‡ He inclined, or propended, to him, (L, Ḳ, TA,) and liked him: (L, TA:) he inclined to, and relied upon, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) him, (Ṣ, A,) or it; (Mṣb;) as also xalada↓. (Mṣb.) Axld UilaI AlOaroDi, in the Ḳur [vii. 175], (Ks, Ṣ, A, L,) as also xalada↓, and xl-d↓, but this last is rare, (Ks, L,) and so is the second, (L,) means ‡ He inclined to, and relied upon, the earth: (Ṣ, A:) or he inclined, or propended, to the world; (Bḍ, Jel;) and relied thereon: (Jel:) or he inclined, or propended, to lowness, baseness, or meanness. (Bḍ.)

entry.sense: xalodN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: xulodN an inf. n. of xalada, (A, L,) [or a simple subst.] syn. with [the inf. n.] xuluwdN. (Ḳ.)
[Hence,] Alxulodu, (T, Ḳ,) or daAru Alxulodi, (L,) [the latter signifying The abode of the state of perpetual existence;] Paradise: (Ḳ:) or the Paradises: (T:) or the world to come. (L.)

A bracelet: and an earring; as also xaladapN↓: pl. xiladapN: (Ḳ:) which last signifies [also] ornaments for the person, collectively; (TA;) and so xulodapN↓ [if this be not a mistranscription for xiladapN]. (L.)

[The mole;] the blind rat; (L, Ḳ;) as also xalodN↓, (Ḳ,) and julocN [q. v.]: (Ḳ in art. jlc:) or a species of rat; as also xilodN↓: (L:) or one of the names of the faOor [or rat]: (IAạr:) or a species of the [kind of rats called] jirocaAn, blind (Lth, Ṣ, L, Mṣb) by nature, (Lth, L, Mṣb,) having no eyes, (Lth, L,) inhabiting the deserts: (Mṣb:) Lth says that the sing. is xilodN↓, and the pl. xilodaAnN: in the T it is said that the sing. is xilodapN↓, and the pl. xilodaAnN; which is very strange: (L:) or a blind beast [that lives] beneath the ground. (Ḳ,) having no eyes, (TA,) that likes the smell of onions and leeks; so that if either of these be put over its hole, it comes forth and is caught: if its upper lip be hung upon a person affected with a quartan fever, it cures him; and its brain, mixed, or moistened, with oil of roses, and used as an ointment, dispels the maladies termed AlbaraS and Albahaq and AlqawaAbiI and Aljarab and Alkalaf and AlxanaAziyr, and every eruption upon the body: (Ḳ:) manaAjicu, (L, Ḳ,) or, as in some copies of the Ḳ, manaAjidu, with the unpointed d, (TA,) is used as its pl, like as maxaADN is used as pl. of xalifapN. (L, Ḳ.)
Also A species of the qub-arap [or lark]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xilodN: see xulodN, in two places.
xaladN The mind: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) the heart: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. OaxolaAdN. (TA.) You say, waqaEa celika fiI xaladiI That came into my mind, or heart. (Ṣ.)
xulodapN: see xulodN.
xilodapN: see xulodN.
xaladapN: see xulodN.

hom.sense: xaAlidN [Remaining, staying,, &c.].

[Hence,] AlxawaAlidu [as though pl. of AlxaAlidapu] † The three pieces, or portions, of stone, or rock, called AlOavaAfiI, upon which the cooking-pot is placed, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) remaining in their places: (L:) so called because of their remaining (Ṣ, L) a long time (L) after the standing relies of a house have become effaced. (Ṣ, L.) [See an ex., from a poem of El-Mukhabbal Es-Saadee, voce Uil-aA, p. 78; where xwAld is with tenween for the sake of the metre.]
Also ‡ The mountains: and the stones: (L. Ḳ:) and the rocks: so called for the same reason. (L.)
[As a proper name, xaAlidN is often written xelidN.]

entry.sense: muxoladN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

muxolidN ‡ Slow in becoming hoary; (A;) as also muxoladN↓ and muxal-adN↓: (Ḥar p. 588:) whose teeth do not fall out (T, A) by reason of extreme old age: (T:) or, as some say, it is muxoladN↓; as though [meaning] made by God to continue for ever in such a state: (A:) a man who is not hoary when advanced in age: (ISk, Ṣ:) whose hair of his head and beard remains black in old age. (T.)
Also † Still; motionless. (TA in art. xmd.)

hom.sense: muxal-adN: see the paragraph next preceding.

muxal-aduwna in the Ḳur [lvi. 17 and lxxvi. 19] means Always of the same age; never altering in age: (Fr:) or [endowed with perpetual vigour;] that never become decrepit: (Ḳ:) or that never exceed the fit age for service: (L, Ḳ:)
or it means adorned with earrings: (L, Ḳ:) or, with bracelets; (AO, L, Ḳ;) accord. to the dial. of El-Yemen: (L:) or, with ornaments. (Zj.)

entry.sense: 1. xalasahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) aor. _i {yaxolisu}, (Mṣb, MṢ,) inf. n. xalosN (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xil-iysaI; (Ḳ;) and Axtlshu↓; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and txl-shu↓; (Ṣ, TA;) He seized it, or carried it off, by force; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) mino yadihi from his hand: (A:) he took it at an opportunity, with deceit, guile, or circumvention: (TA:) or he took it hastily and openly: (Mgh:) or he snatched it at unawares; seized it hastily when its owner was unaware: (Mṣb:) or AixotilaAsN↓ denotes a quicker action than xalosN. (Lth, Ḳ.) You say also, xalasahu Uiy-aAhu [He seized it, or carried it off, from him by force;, &c.]: (TA:) and xaAlasotuhu↓ AlX-aIoCa I seized the thing, or snatched it away, from him. (Ḥar p. 139.) And Oaxacahu xil-iysaI, i. e. AixotilaAsFA↓ [He took it by forcible seizure;, &c.]. (TA.) xalosN is also in fighting and prostrating: and you say, Axtls↓ TaEonapF [He seized an opportunity to inflict a thrust, or wound, with a spear or the like]. (TA.) And Auxotulisa↓ baSaruhu † His sight was suddenly taken away. (A * and TA in art. mls.)

3. xAlshu AlX-aIoCa, (A, TA,*) inf. n. muxaAlasapN and xilaAsN, (TA,) [He contended with him in a mutual endeavouring to seize, or carry off, the thing by force; or to take it at an opportunity, with deceit, guile, or circumvention; or to take it hastily and openly; or to snatch it at unawares: see 1 and 6.] A poet says, [app. using the verb tropically,]
naZarotu UilaImaI-K xilaAsFA EaXiy-apF
EalaI EajalK waQlokaAXiHuwna HuDuwru
[I looked at Mei, vying with her in snatching glances, in the evening, in haste, while the secret enemies were present]. (Th, TA.)
See also 1.

4. Axls It (the hair, A, TA, and the head, [meaning the hair of the head,] AZ, Ṣ, TA) became a mixture of black and white, (Ṣ, A, TA,) in equal proportions: or more black than white: (TA:) [or mostly white: (see xaliysN:)] or partly white. (AZ.)

[Hence,] ‡ It (herbage) became a mixture of fresh and dry: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or partly green and partly white, in drying up. (Az, TA.) † It (HaliI- [q. v.]) put forth fresh verdure. (IAạr, TA.) And Axlst AlOaroDu † The land put forth somewhat of herbage. (TA.)
5: see 1.

6. taxaAlasaA AlX-aIoCa [They both contended together, each endeavouring to seize, or carry off, the thing by force; or to take it an opportunity, with deceit, guile, or circumvention; or to take it hastily and openly; or to snatch it at unawares: see 1 and 3]: (A:) the inf. n., taxaAlusN, signifies i. q. tasaAlubN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
txAls AlqironaAni, and txAlsA nafosayohimaA, The two opponents sought to seize each other by force;, &c. (T, TA.)
8: see 1, in five places.
[Axtls also signifies † He slurred a vowel; i. e., pronounced it slightly: and he suppressed it altogether.]
xalosN: see xaliysN.
xulosN: see xaliysN.

hom.sense: xalosapN inf. n. of un. of xalasahu [A single act of seizing, or carrying off, by force;, &c.]. (Mṣb.)
It also occurs in a trad., where, if correctly related, it is syn. with xalosapN. (Mgh.)

xulosapN a subst. from xalasahu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [which may perhaps mean that it has the abstract sense of the inf. n.: and] A thing that is [seized, or carried off, by force; or taken at an opportunity, with deceit, guile, or circumvention; or] taken hastily and openly; (Mgh;) or snatched at unawares: (Mṣb:) or spoil; plunder; booty; a thing taken by spoliation and force; as also xaliysapN↓; which last also signifies an animal that is snatched from a beast or bird of prey and dies before it has been legally slaughtered; in consequence of which it is forbidden [to be eaten]. (TA.) Hence, laA qaToEa fiI Alxulosapi [There shall be no amputation (of the right hand) in the case of a thing seized, or carried off, by force;, &c.]. (Mgh, Mṣb.) [See also an ex. voce Hucay-aA, in art. HcI.]
An opportunity. (Ṣ,* A, TA.) You say, hecihi xulosapN faQnotahizohaA This is an opportunity, therefore do thou take it, or seize it. (A, TA.)
A mixture of whiteness with blackness in the hair, (Ṣ, Ḥam p. 387, TA,) in equal proportions: or of more blackness than whiteness: (TA:) [or a predominance of whiteness: see xaliysN.]
[Hence,] ‡ A mixture of fresh and dry portions [or green and white (see 4)] in herbage. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: xalosaMCu: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: xaliysN [an epithet having the sense of the pass. part. n. of xalasahu; i.e., Seized, or carried off, by force;, &c.]. [Hence,] TaEonapN xaliysN A thrust, or wound, with a spear or the like, which one has seized an opportunity to inflict, by means of his skill. (TA.)

Also, and muxolisN↓, Hair having whiteness mixed with its blackness, (A, TA,) in equal proportions: or with more blackness than whiteness: (TA:) or mostly white: (Mgh:) or partly white. (AZ, TA.) And the former, Having a mixture of whiteness with the blackness of his hair. (Ṣ, Ḳ,)

Also † White (OaHomaru [q. v.]) whose whiteness is mixed with blackness: and so, applied to women, xulosN↓, (syn. sumorN, TA,) of which the sing. may be xalosaMCu↓; or xaliysN; or xilaAsy-apN↓, supposing the two augments (yp TA) to be elided. (Ḳ.)
Also † i. q. xaliyTN [q. v.]. (TA.)
And † The young one of a she-camel begotten by a stallion not prepared for her. (Ṣgh, TA.)

entry.sense: xaliysapN: see xulosapN.

xilaAsiI-N ‡ A boy whose mother is black, and his father a white, or tawny, Arab, and who is born of a colour between those of his two parents; fem. with p {xilaAsiI-apN}: (Az, TA:) or ‡ a child whose parents are (one) white and (the other) black, (A, Ḳ, TA,) a white man and a black woman, or a black man and a white woman. (TA.) See also xaliysN.
And ‡ A domestic fowl, (A,) or cock, (Ḳ,) begotten between an Indian and a Persian fowl. (A, Ḳ.)
xal-aAsN: see xaAlisN:
and see xaliysN.

xaAlisN One who seizes, or carries off, a thing by force: who takes it at an opportunity, with deceit, guile, or circumvention: [or who takes it hastily and openly: or who snatches at unawares:] as also xal-aAsN↓: [or this latter has an intensive signification:] and [in like manner] muxotalisN↓ one who seizes, or carries off, a thing at a time of inadvertence. (TA.)
[Hence,] AlxaAlisu Death: because it seizes people unawares. (TA.)
muxolisN: see xaliysN, in two places.
muxaAlisN: see xaliysN.
muxotalisN: see xaAlisN.

hom.sense: 1. xalaSa, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yaxoluSu}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. xuluwSN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and xalaASN (TA) and xaAliSapN, (Ḳ,) or the second and third of these are simple substs. [used as inf. ns., i. e., quasi-inf. ns.]; (TA;) and xaluSa also; (Et-Towsheeh, TA;) but the former is that which is commonly known; (TA;) It (a thing, Ṣ, TA) was, or became, xaAliS, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) which signifies [here] clear, pure, sheer, free from admixture, unmingled, unmixed, or genuine; (B, TA;) and white. (Ḳ.) You say, xalaSa AnmaMCu mina Alkadari The water became clear from turbidness. (Mṣb.) And xalaSa Alz-ubodu mina Alv-ufoli [The butter became clear from the dregs, or sediment,] in being cooked. (Ṣ.)

xalaSa mina AlwaroTapi, (A,) or Alt-alafi, aor. _u {yaxoluSu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xalaASN (A, Mṣb) and xuluwSN and maxolaSN, (Mṣb,) ‡ He became safe, or secure, or free, from embarrassment or difficulty, or from destruction, (A, Mṣb,) like as a thing becomes clear from its turbidness. (A.) [See also 5.]

xalaSa mina Alqawomi ‡ He withdrew, retired, or went away or apart, from the people, or company of men. (A, TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [xii. 80], xalaSuwA najiy-FA ‡ They retired, conferring privately together. (Bḍ, Jel, TA.)

xalaSa Uilayohi, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and bihi (TA,) inf. n. xuluwSN, (Ḳ,) ‡ He, or it, (a thing, Ṣ, and grief, and happiness, A, TA,) came to, or reached, him: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA:) he came to, reached, or arrived at, it; namely, a place. (TA.)
Also xalaSuwA Uilayohi They came to him (namely a judge or governor) and referred to him their cause, or suit, for judgment. (T and L in art. nfc.)

xalaSa, inf. n. xalaASN and xuluwSN; (TA;) or xl-S↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taxoliySN; (TA;) but the former is that which is found in the correct lexicons; (TA;) He took the xulaASap [q. v.] (Ḳ, TA) of, or from, clarified butter; (TA;) and AxlS↓, inf. n. UixolaASN, signifies the same. (TA.) [See also this last below.]

2. xl-Shu, (A,) inf. n. taxoliySN, (TA,) He made, or rendered, it clear or pure [&c. (see 1, first signification)]; he cleared, clarified, purified, or refined, it; (A, Mgh, TA;) [as also AxlShu↓, q. v.]
† He separated it from another thing or other things. (Mṣb.) You say also xl-S bayonahumaA [He separated them, each from the other]. (M in art. qlS.)

‡ He (God, A, TA, or a man, Ṣ) saved, secured, or freed, him, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) mino kacaA from such a thing, (Ṣ,) [as, for instance, a snare, and embarrassment or difficulty, or destruction, like as one renders a thing clear from its turbidness, (see 1,)] after he had become caught, or entangled; (TA;) as also AxlShu↓. (TA.) Also † [He disentangled it; unravelled it:] said of spun thread that has become entangled. (Lth and Az and Ṣgh, in TA, art. Esr.)
† He made it clear; or explained, expounded, or interpreted, it; as also lax-aSahu. (A in art. lxS.)

xl-S, inf. n. as above, also signifies † He gave [a man (for the verb in this case, as in others, is trans, accord. to the TḲ,)] the xalaAS, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e., the equivalent of a thing, or requital, or hire for work. (TA.)
See also 1, last signification.

entry.sense: 3. xaAlShu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaAlaSapN, (TḲ,) † [He regarded him, or acted towards him, with reciprocal purity of mind, or sincerity: and particularly, as also xAlShu Alwud-a, mentioned in this art. in the A, but not explained,] ‡ he regarded him, or acted towards him, with reciprocal purity, or sincerity, of love, or affection; syn. SaAfaAhu (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and waAdadahu; (TA;) fiI AlEiXorapi [in social intercourse]. (Ṣ, TA.) You say also, xAlS Qll-eha diynahu ‡ [He acted with reciprocal purity, or sincerity, towards God, in his religion]. (A.) And one says, xaAliSi AlmuWomina waxaAlifi AlkaAfira ‡ [Act thou with reciprocal purity, or sincerity, towards the believer, and act thou with contrariety to the unbeliever]. (A. [See 3 in art. xlq, where a similar saying is mentioned.]) [See also the next paragraph {4}.]

4. AxlShu: see 2, first signification. You say, AxlS Als-amona, inf. n. UixolaASu, He clarified the cooked butter by throwing into it somewhat of the meal of parched barley or wheat (sawiyq), or dates, or globules of gazelles' dung: (Ṣ,* L:) or he took the xulaASap [q. v.] of the cooked, or clarified, butter. (Fr, Ḳ.) See also 1, last signification.
And OaxolaSatohu Aln-aAru [The fire clarified it, or purified it,] namely, butter, and gold, and silver. (Ḳ.)

You say also, AxlSwA Aln-aSiyHapa and AlHub-a ‡ [lit. They made good advice or counsel, and love, pure, or sincere; meaning, they were pure, or sincere, in giving good advice, and in love]. (TA.) And AxlS lahu Almawad-apa ‡ [He was pure, or sincere, to him in love, or affection]. (A.) And AxlS lil-ehi AlEamala † [He was pure, or sincere, towards God in works]. (Mṣb.) And AxlS lil-ehi Ald-iyna, (Ṣ, TA,) or diynahu, (A,) ‡ He was pure, or sincere, towards God in religion, [or in his religion;] without hypocrisy. (Ṣ,* TA.) And AxlS lil-ehi, [elliptically,] † He was without hypocrisy [towards God]. (Ḳ.) or UixolaASN properly signifies † The asserting oneself to be clear, or quit, of [believing in] any beside God. (B, TA.) [Hence.] suwrapu AlUixolaASi is † a title of The [112th] chapter of the Ḳur-án commencing with the words qulo huwa Qll-ehu OaHadN: (IAth, Mṣb:) and suwrataA AlUixolaASi † the same together with the [109th] chapter commencing with the words yaA Oay-uhaA QlokaAfiruwna. (Mṣb.) And kalimapu AlOixolaASi is applied to ‡ The sentence which declares belief in the unity of God. (A,* TA.) OaxolaSonaAhumo bixaAliSapK: see below, voce xaAliSapN.
See also 2, third signification.
And see 10.

5. txl-S ‡ He became saved, secured, or freed; he escaped, or freed himself; or became safe, secure, free, or in a state of freedom or immunity; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) from a thing; (Ṣ;) as, for instance, a gazelle, and a bird, from a snare, (A,) [and a man from embarrassment or difficulty, or destruction, like as a thing becomes cleared from its turbidness, (see 1,) or] like spun thread when it has been entangled. (TA.)
[See also nasaba biAlomaroOapi.]
6. txAlSwA ‡ They regarded one another, or acted reciprocally, [with purity, or sincerity: and particularly,] with purity, or sincerity, of love, or affection. (A,* TA.)
10. AstxlS Alz-uboda mina All-abani He extracted the butter from the milk. (ADk, A, L.)

AstxlShu linafosihi He appropriated him [or it] purely to himself, (Bḍ and Jel in xii. 54,) exclusively of any partner: (Jel:) he chose him [or it] for himself; took him [or it] in preference for himself; (IAạr, in L, art. qrH; and TA in the present art.;) he appropriated him to himself as his particular, or special, intimate; (TA;) syn. AisotaxaS-ahu; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and AxlShu↓ signifies the same. (TA.)

xiloSN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and xuloSaAnN↓ (Ṣ, A, TA) and xaAliSapN↓ (Ṣ, TA) ‡ A man's friend; [or his sincere, or true,] or his secret, or private, friend; or his companion, or associate, who converses, or talks, with him; syn. xidonN; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) his particular, or special, friend: (TA:) ↓the second is also used in a pl. sense: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. of the first, xulaSaMCu. (Ḳ.)

xalaSN A kind of tree like the grape-vine (Ḳ) in its manner of growth, (TA,) that clings to other trees, and rises high; (Ḳ;) having leaves of a dust-colour, thin, round, and wide; and a blossom like that of the mr [?]; and tinged in the lower parts of its stems; (TA;) sweet in odour; and having berries (Ḳ) like those of [the plant called] EinabN Alv-aEolabi, [see art. vElb,] three and four together, red, (TA,) like the beads of Eaqiyq [q. v.]; (Ḳ;) not eaten [by men], but depastured: (TA:) n. un. with p {xalaSapN}: (Ḳ:) thus described by [AḤn] Ed-Deenawaree, on the authority of an Arab of the desert. (TA.) See the end of the next paragraph.
