cuw AlxalaSapi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and cw AlxuluSapi, (Hishám, Ḳ,) and cw AlxaloSapi, accord. to IDrd, and some write it cw AlxaluSapi, but the first is the form commonly obtaining with the relaters of trads., (TA,) A certain temple, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) called kaEobapu AlyamaAmapi, (Ṣ,) or AlkaEobapu AlyamaAniy-apu, (El-Háfidh Ibn-Hajar, Ḳ,) and also AlkaEobapu AlX-aAmiy-apu, because its door faced Syria, (TA,) belonging to the tribe of Khath'am, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Dows and Bejeeleh and others, (TA,) in which was an idol called AlxalaSapu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which was demolished (Ṣ, TA) by command of Moḥammad: (TA:) or cuw AlxalaSapi was the idol itself, as some say; but, says IAth, this requires consideration, because [it is asserted that] cw is not prefixed to any but generic names: (TA: [but see cuw:]) or the temple was so called because it was the place of growth of a tree of a kind called xalaS↓. (Ḳ,* TA.)
xuloSaAnN: see xiloSN, in two places.

hom.sense: xalaASN an inf. n. of 1.
yawomu AlxalaASi is The day of the coming forth of Ald-aj-aAl [or Antichrist]; because then the believers will be distinguished. (TA.)
Also † An equivalent; a requital, or compensation; hire, pay, or wages, for work: pl. OaxolaASN. (TA.)
See also xulaASap.

entry.sense: xulaASN: see xulaASap, in two places.
xilaASN: see xulaASap, throughout.
xuluwSN: see xulaASap, in three places.
Also an inf. n. of 1.
xulayoSN: see xaAliSN.

xulaASapu Als-amoni (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xilaASatuhu (Fr, Ṣgh, Ḳ) What has become clear, of cooked butter; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) or cooked butter into which some dates have been thrown, or into which some sawiyq [i. e. meal of parched barley or wheat] has been thrown, in order that thereby it may become clear from the remains of the milk: (Mṣb:) for when they cook fresh butter, to make it samon, they throw into it somewhat of swyq, or dates, or globules of gazelles' dung; and when it becomes good, and clear from the dregs, or sediment, that smn is called AlxulaASapu, and AlxilaASu↓ also, (Ṣ, L,) mentioned by AʼObeyd, (Ṣ,) and this, namely the xilaAS, is the Uivor: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) and the terms xuluwSN↓ (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and qilodapN (Ṣ, L) and qiXodapN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and kudaAdapN (Ṣ, L) are applied to the dregs, or sediment, remaining at the bottom; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also xulaASapN: (AHeyth, L in art. qXd:) the inf. n. is UixolaASN; and you say, OaxolaSotu Als-amona: (Ṣ, L:) or xulaASapN and xilaASN↓ signify dates and swyq that are thrown into smn; and AxlS Als-amona signifies “he threw dates and swyq into the smn [and so clarified it]:” and xulaASN↓ [thus I find it written] signifies what has become clear, of smn, when it is cooked: and xilaASN also signifies, and so UixolaASN↓, and OixolaASapN↓, butter when clear from the dregs, or sediment: and xuluwSN↓, the dregs, or sediment, at the bottom of the milk: (L:) UixolaASN↓ and UixolaASapN↓ are syn. with UicowaAbN and UicowaAbapN: (TA:) or, accord. to AZ, the latter two terms are applied to butter when it is put into the cooking-pot to be cooked into smn; and when it has become good, and the milk has become clear from the dregs, or sediment, that milk is called UivorN and UixolaADN↓: Az says, I have heard the Arabs apply the term xilaASN↓ to that with which smn is cleared, in the cookingpot, from the water and milk and dregs; for when it is not clear, and the milk is mixed with the butter, they take dates, or flour, or swyq, which they throw therein, that the smn may become clear from the remains of the milk mixed with it: this is the xilaAS: but the xlASp [i. e. xulaASap] is what remains, of the xilaAS and dregs or milk, &c., in the bottom of the cooking-pot: (L, TA:) [or] xilaASN↓ (Ḳ) [accord. to some, xalaASN↓, but this is app. wrong, (see Ḥar p. 311,)] and xulaASapN (Hr, TA) also signify what fire has clarified, or purified, (maA OaxolaSatohu Aln-aAru,) of butter, and of gold, and of silver: (Hr, Ḳ, TA:) or xilaASu↓ All-abani, means what is extracted from milk; i. e. butter; (ADk, L, TA;) and so does xulaASapu All-abani: (A: [but there mentioned among tropical expressions:]) xulaASapN being applied in the manner first mentioned in this paragraph, by a secondary application is made to signify what is clear, or pure, of other things; (Mṣb;) [as also xaAliSN↓: and hence both of them often signify † the choice, best, or most excellent, part of anything; and so, probably, does xilaASN↓:] and xulaASapN and xulaASN↓ also signify Inspissated juice (rub-) made from dates; (JK;) or this is called xuluwSN↓. (TA.)

xaAliSN Clear; pure; sheer; free from admixture; unmingled; unmixed; genuine: (B, TA:) clear, or pure, applied to any colour: (Lḥ, TA:) ‡ white; as also xulayoSN↓; [which latter appears to me doubtful, though I know not why Freytag has substituted for this, or for the former word, xaloSN;] both applied to anything. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, vawobN xaAliSN ‡ A garment, or piece of cloth, of a clear, or pure, white: and qabaMCN Oazoraqu xaAliSu AlbiTaAnapi ‡ A garment of the kind called qbAC blue with a white lining. (A.)
[Also † Pure, or sincere, love, religion, &c.]
See also xulaASap, near the end of the paragraph.

hom.sense:
xaAliSapN [fem. of xaAliSN: used as a subst.,] † A pure property, or quality. (Bḍ in xxxviii. 46; and Ḳ. [In the CK, xul-ap is erroneously put for xal-ap: the corresponding word in Bḍ is xaSolap.])
So in the Ḳur [xxxviii. 46], OaxolaSonaAhumo↓ bixaAliSapK cikoraI Ald-aAri † We have rendered them pure by a pure quality, (Bḍ, Ḳ,* TA,) the keeping in memory the final abode: (Bḍ, TA:) ckrI AldAr being a substitute for xAlSp: or it may mean [by] their keeping in memory much the final abode and the return to God: (TA:) some also, (TA,) namely Náfi' and Hishám, (Bḍ,) read bixaAliSapi, making it a prefix to ckrI (Bḍ, TA) as an explicative; or an inf. n., in the sense of xuluwS, prefixed to its agent. (Bḍ.)

You say also, hecaA AlX-aIoCu xaAliSapN laka † This thing is a property of thine: (so in a copy of the Ṣ, and so the phrase is written in the TA:) or is a thing purely thine, exclusively of others: (TA:) or hcA AlXIC xaAliSapF laka this thing is particularly, or specially, thine, or for thee. (So accord. to other copies of the Ṣ, and a copy of the JK.)
See also xiloSN.
xaAliSapN is also syn. with UixolaASN [in some sense not pointed out: see the latter below; and see also 4]. (TA.)

entry.sense: UixolaASN [inf. n. of 4, used as a subst.]: see xulaASap, in three places.
UixolaASapN: see xulaASap, in two places.
[maxolaSN ‡ A place of safety, or security, or escape from an event.]
muxolaSN Chosen: (JK:) chosen by God, and pure from pollution; applied to a man. (Zj, TA.) [It is implied in the A and TA that it is also syn. with muxoliSN in the sense explained below.]
muxoliSN ‡ Pure, or sincere, towards God in religion; without hypocrisy: (TA:) or purely believing in the unity of God. (Zj, TA.)
yaAquwtN mutaxal-iSN Picked [sapphires]. (A, TA.)

1. xalaTahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxoliTu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaloTN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He mixed it; mingled it; incorporated, or blended, it; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) or put it together; (Mṣb;) bigayorihi with another thing; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) inseparably, as in the case of fluids; and separably, as in the case of animals, (Mṣb, TA,) and grains; (TA;) as also xl-Thu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taxoliyTN: (TA:) [or the latter relates to many, or several, objects; or signifies he mixed it much:] El-Marzookee says that the primary signification of xaloTN is the intermingling of the particles of a thing, one with another. (Mṣb, TA.) [And hence, † He confused, confounded, or disordered, it.]
xalaTa Alqawoma; and xaliTa: see 3, near the end of the paragraph.
2: see 1.
[Its inf. n. is pluralized: you say,] jamaEa maAlahu mino taxaAliyTa [He collected together his property, or camels,, &c., from states of confusion]. (TA.)

Alt-axoliyTu fiI AlOamori signifies The creating confusion, or disorder, (AlUifosaAdu,) in the affair, or case. (Ṣ.) And you say, huwa fiI taxoliyTK fiI Oamorihi [and mino Amrh, He is in a state of confusion, or disorder, in, or with respect to, his affair, or case]. (TA.) [And xl-T Ealayohi AlOamori He rendered the affair, or state, or case, confused, or disordered, or perplexed, to him. And xl-T bayona Alqawomi He created confusion, or disorder, or disturbance, among the people, or company of men.]

3. xAlThu, inf. n. muxaAlaTapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and xilaATN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) It mixed, mingled, commingled, intermixed, or intermingled, with it; it became incorporated, or blended, with it; syn. maAzajahu; (Mgh, Ḳ;) and xaAmarahu; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, all in art. xmr;) [as, for instance,] water with milk. (A in art. xmr, and Mgh in the present art.) xilaATN in relation to camels, and men, and beasts, also signifies Their being mixed together. (Ḳ.) A poet says,
yaxorujona mino buEokuwkapi AlxilaATi
[They come forth from the crowding and dust (of the beasts) occasioned by the being mixed together]. (Th, TA.) And it is said in a trad., laA xilaATa walaA wiraATa (Ṣ, Mgh,) There shall be no putting together what is separate, nor separating what is put together, from fear of the poor-rate: (Ṣ:) for the Prophet made it incumbent on a person having possessed forty sheep or goats a whole year to give one sheep or goat; and so on one having possessed more thereof to the number of a hundred and twenty, to give one sheep or goat; but if they exceeded a hundred and twenty by one, two sheep or goats were to be given of them: (Az, TA:) i. e. there shall be no putting together what is separate; as, for instance, when three persons possess a hundred and twenty sheep or goats, every one of them having forty, they not having been partners for a whole year, and it being incumbent on every one of them to give a sheep or goat; and when the collector of the poorrate comes to them, they put them together, assigning them to one pastor, in order that they may not be obliged to give for them more than one sheep or goat: (Ḳ,* TA:) accord. to IAth, this is termed UixolaATN [app. a mistake for xilaATN]: nor shall there be any separating of what is put together; i. e., when there are two partners, each of them having a hundred and one sheep or goats, for which together they are bound to give three sheep or goats; and when the collector of the poorrate comes to them, they separate their sheep or goats, so that each of them shall not have to give more than one sheep or goat: [see also art. wrT:] (TA:) or xlAT signifies a man's mixing his sheep or goats when they are eighty in number with those of another which are forty in number, both together being bound to give two sheep or goats while they are separate, in order that one [only] may be taken: and wrAT, a man's giving to another the half of his sheep or goats when they are forty in number, in order that the collector of the poor-rate may not take anything: (Mgh:) or xlAT is, when there are, between two partners, a hundred and twenty sheep or goats, one of them having eighty and the other forty, and the collector of the poor-rate has taken two of these sheep or goats, the former partner's restoring to the latter the third of a sheep or goat; so that the former has had to give a sheep or goat and a third; and the latter, two thirds of one: and if the collector have taken, from the hundred and twenty, one sheep or goat, the former partner's restoring to the latter one third [in some copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, two thirds] of a sheep or goat; so that the former has had to give two thirds of a sheep or goat; and the latter, one third of one: (ISd, Ḳ,* TA:) and wrAT is deceiving, and acting dishonestly: (ISd, L, TA:) in the place of wrAT, we find, accord. to one relation, XinaAq, followed by fiI AlS-adaqapi. (TA.)

El-ʼAjjáj contended with Homeyd El-Arkat in two poems of the metre termed rajaz ending with T, and Homeyd said, AlxilaATa yaA OabaA AlX-aEovaMCi, i. e. [Beware thou of mixing; or] do not thou mix my Ourojuwzap with thine [O father of her with the shaggy hair]; to which El-ʼAjjáj replied, AlfijaAju OawosaEu mino celika yaA Qbona OaxiI [The roads are wider than to require my doing that, O son of my brother]. (AO, Ṣ.)
xAlT Alc-iYobu Alganama [lit. signifying The wolf mixed with the sheep, or goats,] means ‡ the wolf fell upon the sheep, or goats: (Ḳ, TA:) the inf. n. is xilaATN. (TA.)

xAlThA, (Az, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xilaATN and muxaAlaTapN, (Az, Mṣb,) ‡ He had carnal intercourse with her; (Az, Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e., a man with his wife, (Az, Mṣb,) or with a woman: (Ḳ:) the lawyers say, xAlThA muxaAlaTapa AlAizodiwaAji: (Mṣb:) Th explains the inf. n. xilaATN by rafavN, q. v. (TA.) Also, in like manner, with the same inf. ns., ‡ a stallion-camel with the female. (Lth, Ḳ, TA.) [See also 4.] IAar explains xilaATN in relation to camels as signifying † A man's coming to the nightly resting-place of another's camels, and taking thence a male camel, and making him to cover his she-camel without his owner's knowledge. (TA.)
xAlThu Als-ahomu † [The arrow penetrated into him]. (TA.)
xAlThu AlX-ayobu [Hoariness, or whiteness, became intermixed in his hair]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wxT;, &c.)
xAlThu Ald-aMCu ‡ The disease infected, or pervaded, him; [as though commingling with him;] syn. xaAmarahu: (Sh, Ḳ:) or infected, or pervaded, his inside. (Lth, Ṣ.)

xaAlaTa qalobahu ham-N EaZiymN ‡ [Great anxiety, or disquietude of mind, infected, or pervaded, his heart]. (TA.) It is said in a trad., warajaEa AlX-ayoTaAnu yalotamisu AlxilaATa ‡ And the devil returned seeking to infect (yuxaAliT) the heart of the man praying by suggesting what was vain. (TA.)

Alxamoru tuxaAliTu AlEaqola ‡ [Wine infects the intellect]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. xmr.) And xuwliTa fiI Eaqolihi, inf. n. xilaATN, ‡ [He became infected, corrupted, disordered, or confused, in his intellect.] (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And xuwliTa Eaqoluhu, and AixotalaTa↓ Eaqoluhu, ‡ His intellect became corrupted, or disordered; (TA; [in which only the latter phrase is thus explained, though both are mentioned;]) and so AixotalaTa↓ alone: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and AixotalaTato↓ nafosuhu † [His soul, or stomach, became disordered]: (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. xvr:) and OaxolaTa↓, said of a man, signifies the same as AxtlT. (TA.)

xAlT Alqawoma † He mixed with the people, or company of men, in familiar, or social, intercourse; conversed with them; or became intimate with them; or mixed with them in, or entered with them into, their affairs; syn. daAxalahumo; as also xalaTahumo↓, inf. n. xaloTN; (TA;) and xaliTa↓, like fariHa, is used in a similar manner, in the sense of xaAlaTa: (IAạr, TA:) and you say also AxtlT↓ biAln-aAsi † [he mixed, or associated, or conversed, with men]. (TA.) And xaAlaTotu fulaAnFA † I mixed with such a one in familiar, or social, intercourse; conversed with him; or became intimate with him; syn. xaAmarotuhu, (A in art. xmr,) and EaAXarotuhu. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, all in art. EXr.) And xAlThu fiI Oamori † [He mixed, or joined, with him in an affair]. (Mgh.) And hence xAlThu signifies † He was, or became, copartner with him; he shared with him. (Mgh.) xaAlaTahumo also signifies xaAlafahumo [evidently a mistranscription, for HaAlafahumo † He entered into a confederacy, league, compact, or covenant, with them]. (TA.) And you say also xAlT AlOumuwra † [He mixed in, engaged in, or entered into, affairs]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4. AxlThu, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AxlT lahu, (IAạr, Ḳ,) He put, (Ṣ,) or inserted, (AZ,) or directed (Ḳ, TA) and inserted, (TA,) his (a camel's) qaDiyb into the HayaMC, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) he having missed it; (AZ, Ḳ;) as also OaloTafahu: (AZ:) IF makes UixolaATN and AisotixolaATN↓ to be the same. (TA.)
AxlT [intrans.] ‡ He (a stallion) covered the female. (Ḳ.) [This seems to be taken from IF, who, as shown above, makes it syn. with AstxlT. See also 3.]
As syn. with AxtlT, see 3, near the end of the paragraph.
Said of a horse, He fell short, or flagged, in his running; as also AxtlT↓. (IDrd, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: txAlTwA also signifies † They commingled, or mixed together, in familiar, or social, intercourse; [conversed together; or became intimate, one with another; or they mixed, one in another's affairs; see 3, near the end;] syn. tEAXrwA. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, all in art. EXr.)

8. AxtlT It was, or became, mixed, mingled, commingled, incorporated or blended together, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) or put together. (Mṣb.) [And hence, † It was, or became, confused, confounded, indiscriminate, promiscuous, without order, disordered, or perplexed.]

AxtlT All-ayolu biAlt-uraAbi † [The night became confused, or confounded, with the dust, or earth]: (AZ, Ḳ:) and AlHaAbilu biAln-aAbili (Ḳ) † the setter of the snare with the shooter of arrows; or the warp with the woof: (TA:) and AlmaroEaI biAlhamali † [the place of pasturage with the camels left to pasture by themselves]: (AZ, Ḳ:) and AlxaAviru biAlz-ubaAdi (as in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA) † the thick milk with the butter that had become bad, or spoiled, in the churning; or, as some say, with the thin milk; (TA;) or biAlz-ab-aAdi (as in other copies of the Ḳ and in the TA) with the herb [so called], which, when it falls into the raAYib [or milk that is thick, and fit for churning, &c.], is with difficulty separated from it: (TA:) [but see art. zbd:] proverbs, alluding to the dubiousness and confusedness of an affair or a case: (Ḳ:) or the first, to the dubiousness of an affair or case; and the second, to its confusedness; and the third is applied when a people's affair or case is confused or perplexed to them; and the last relates to the confusedness of truth with falsity; and to a people whose affair or case is dubious to them, so that they do not decide upon anything. (TA.)
[AxtlT AlZ-alaAmu † The darkness, or the beginning of night, became confused, is a phrase of frequent occurrence. And so AixotilaATu AlZ-alaAmi † The confusedness of the darkness,, &c.]
AxtlT Ealayohimo Oamoruhumo † [Their affair, or case, became confused, or perplexed, to them]. (Ṣ.)
See also 3, in four places, near the end of the paragraph: and see 6.
Said of a camel, ‡ He became fat; (ISh, Ḳ;) his fat and flesh becoming mixed together. (ISh.)
Said of a horse: see 4, last sentence.
10. AstxlT He (a camel) inserted, (AZ,) or directed (Ḳ, TA) and inserted, (TA,) his qaDiyb into the HayaMC, by himself: (AZ, Ḳ, TA:) or he leaped the female; syn. qaEaA. (Ṣ.) See also 4.
xaloTN: see the next paragraph.

xiloTN Anything that mixes, mingles, commingles, or becomes incorporated or blended, with a thing; an admixture; (Ḳ, TA;) any kind of mixture; as a medicinal mixture; and the like: pl. OaxolaATN. (TA.)
A kind of [mixed] perfume, (Ṣ,* Mṣb,) well known: (Mṣb:) pl. as above. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

[Sing. of AxlAT in the term] OaxolaATu AlUinosaAni The four humours of man, (Ḳ, TA,) which are the constituents of his composition; (TA;) namely, Almir-ataAni [the black bile and the yellow bile] and Albalogamu [the phlegm] and Ald-amu [the blood]. (TA in art. mzj.)
Mixed dates of various sorts: pl. as above. (Ḳ.)

‡ A man who mixes with others, and manifests love to them; (TA;) and xiloTapN a woman who does so: (Ḳ,* TA:) and the former, (IAạr, TA,) or xaloTN↓, (Ḳ,) or this signifies [simply] muxaAliTN, [see 3,] and is an inf. n. used in that sense, (TA,) and xaliTN↓, (Lth, Ḳ,) and xuluTN↓, (Ḳ,) which is mentioned by Sb and explained by Seer, (TA,) ‡ a man who mixes with others, (Ḳ, TA,) and manifests love to them, (TA,) and behaves in a blandishing manner to them, and one who casts his women and goods among men; (Ḳ, TA;) and xaliTapN↓ in like manner, applied to a female. (TA.)

† A man of mixed race: or a bastard. (Aṣ.) You say rajulN xiloTN miloTN † A man of mixed race: (Ḳ,* TA:) or of faulty race: (O, TA:) or miloT N signifies one whose race and father are unknown. (Aṣ, TA.) And OaxolaATN mina Aln-aAsi † A medley, or mixed or promiscuous multitude or collection, of men, or people; or of the lowest or basest or meanest sort, or refuse, or riffraff, thereof; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also xaliyTN↓, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) and xul-ayoTaI↓, (Ḳ,) and xulayoTaI↓: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) to these (lahun-a [in the CK lahum]) there is no sing.: (Ḳ, TA:) but xaliyTN is also a sing., and has pls., as will be seen below. (TA.)
‡ Stupid; foolish; having little sense; (IAạr, Ḳ;) as also xaliTN↓: (IAạr, Ṣgh, Ḳ:) pl. of the former OaxolaATN; (IAạr, TA;) with which xuluTN↓ is syn. (TA.)

A crooked bow, and arrow; (Ḳ;) an arrow of which the wood has grown crookedly, and which ceases not to be crooked even if it have been straightened; (Ṣ;) as also xiliTN↓, applied to either of these. (Ḳ.) And in like manner, † a man; he being likened to such an arrow: and † a people, or company of men. (TA.)
Also † Good in disposition; good-natured. (TA.)
xuluTN: see xiloTN, in two places:
[and see xaliyTN, of which it is a pl.]
xiliTN: see xiloTN, last sentence but one.
xuloTapN [A state of mixing, or mingling, together;] a subst. from AxtlT. (Mṣb.)
[And hence,] † Copartnership. (Ṣ, Mgh, TA.) You say bayonahumaA xuloTapN † Between them two is a copartnership. (Mgh.) [See also what next follows.]
xiloTapN † Social, or familiar, intercourse. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.) [See also what next precedes.]

xaliyTN [Mixed; mingled; incorporated, or blended: of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; like qatiylN, &c. And hence,] (Ḳ,) or EalafN xaliyTN, (Ṣ, TA,) [The kind of trefoil called] qat- and cut straw (Ṣ, TA) mixed together: (TA:) or clay mixed with cut straw: (Ḳ, TA:) or with qat-. (Ḳ.) Also, (Ḳ,) or labanN xaliyTN, (TA,) Sweet milk mixed with sour or such as bites the tongue. (Ḳ, TA.) Also, (Ḳ,) or samonN xaliyTN, (TA,) Clarified butter in which are fat and flesh-meat. (Ḳ, TA.) [Hence also,] it is said in a trad. respecting [the beverage called] nabiyc, (TA,) nuhiIa Eani AlxaliyTayoni (Ṣ, Ḳ) fiI AlOanobicapi (Ṣ) or Oano yunobacaA (Ḳ) [Two sorts of things mixed together are forbidden in the beverages of the kind called nbyc, or that nbyc should be made of them]; i. e. it is forbidden to mix together [for making nbyc] two sorts of things; (Ṣ, TA;) meaning dried dates and raisins; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) or fresh grapes and fresh ripe dates; (Ṣ;) or dried dates and full-grown unripe dates, (T, Mgh, Ḳ,) thoroughly cooked by fire; (Mgh;) or fresh grapes and raisins; (T, Ḳ;) and the like; because such nbyc quickly alters, and becomes intoxicating: (Ḳ:) and some hold that nbyc so made is forbidden even if it do not intoxicate. (TA.)
See also OaxolaATN mina Aln-aAsi, voce xiloTN.

† One who mixes much with men: (Mṣb, TA:) [see also mixolaATN:] † one who mixes with others in familiar, or social, intercourse; or becomes intimate with them; or mixes with them in, or enters with them into, their affairs; syn. with muxaAliTN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like as nadiymN is syn. with munaAdimN, and jaliysN with mujaAlisN: (Ṣ:) pl. xulaTaMCu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xuluTN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:)
it sometimes has these pls., but is itself both sing. and pl.: (Ṣ, TA:) and as a pl. signifies † a people, or company of men, whose affair, or case, or state, is one: (Ḳ, TA:) it occurs frequently in the poems of the Arabs because they used to assemble in the days of the fresh herbage, sundry tribes of them congregating in one place, and familiar intercourse took place between them, and when they separated and returned to their homes, it grieved them: (Ṣ, TA:) or, accord. to some, it relates only to partnership: (TA:) it signifies † a partner, copartner, or sharer; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as, for instance, in merchandise, and sheep or goats: (Mgh:) or † one who has mixed his property with that of his copartner: (Bḍ in xxxviii. 23:) or † one who shares in merchandise, or in a debt, or in commerce, or in neighbourship: (Ibn-ʼArafeh, TA:) and † a sharer in the rights of possession, or property; such as water, and a road: (Ḳ:) the pl. is xulaTaMCu; (Mgh, TA;) occurring in the Ḳur xxxviii. 23: (TA:) and the sing. also signifies † a neighbour; syn. jaArN [which has also other significations here assigned to xaliyTN]; (TA;) and mujaAwirN: (Mṣb:) and † a husband: and † the son of a paternal uncle: (Ḳ:) and [the pl.] xuluTN is also explained by IAạr as † i. q. mawaAlK [pl. of mawolFI, which has several of the significations here assigned to xaliyTN]: and as signifying also † neighbours of sincere friendly conduct. (TA.) It is said in a trad. (Ḳ, TA) respecting [the right termed] AlX-ufoEap, (TA,) AlX-ariyku OawolaI mina AlxaliyTu OawolaI mina AljaAri † The sharer in what is not divided is more deserving than the sharer in the rights of possession, or property; [and the sharer in the rights of possession, or property, is more deserving than the neighbour:] (Ḳ, TA:) [or the trad. is as follows:] AlxaliyTu mina AlX-ariyki waAlX-ariyku OaHaq-u mina AljaAri OaHaq-u mino gayorihi † the sharer in the thing itself that is sold has more right than the sharer in the rights thereof; and the sharer in the rights thereof has more right than the adjoining neighbour; and the adjoining neighbour has more right than another: or the meaning here is, he between whom and thyself are acts of receiving and giving, and affairs of debt and credit; not the sharer, or partner. (Mgh.) And in another trad., maA kaAna mino xaliyTayoni faUUin-ahumaA yataraAjaEaAni bayonahumaA biAls-awiy-api † Whatever two copartners there be that have not divided the beasts [belonging to them], they shall make claim for restitution, one of the other, with equality; i. e., if they be copartners in camels for which it is incumbent to give sheep or goats, and the camels be found in the possession of one of them, and the poor-rate for them be taken from him, he shall make a claim for restitution [of what he has given above his own share] upon his copartner, with equality: (Esh-Sháfiʼee, Ḳ, TA:) the two persons are not xaliyTaAni unless they be such as drive back their beasts to the nightly resting-place, and drive them forth in the morning to the pasturage, and water them, together, and have their stallions mixed together, and have been copartners for a year; and if so, they give the poor-rate as one: otherwise, they are not xlyTAn; and they give the poor-rate as two: (Esh-Sháfiʼee, TA:) the trad. applies, for instance, to the case of two copartners who have mixed their property together; one of them having forty bulls or cows or of both kinds; and the other, thirty; and the collector of the poor-rates takes from the forty a musin-ap [q. v.], and from the thirty a tabiyE [q. v.]; then the giver of the msn-p makes a claim for restitution of three sevenths thereof upon his copartner; and the giver of the tbyE, of four sevenths thereof upon his copartner; for it is incumbent to give the beasts of these two ages [the msn-p and the tbyE] when the property is not divided, as though it were the property of one: and the saying bAls-wyp shows that if the collector of the poor-rate wrong one of them, and take from him more than the law imposes upon him, he cannot make a claim for restitution thereof upon his copartner, who is only responsible to him for the value of what falls upon him in particular, of what is incumbent by the law: and the making claim for [just] restitution, by one upon the other, shows that the partnership holds good notwithstanding the distinction of the things which compose the possessions, with such as hold this to be the case. (IAth, TA.)
xalaATapN ‡ Stupidity; foolishness; paucity of sense. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
xaliyTapN Camel's milk milked upon that of sheep or goats: or sheep's milk upon that of goats: and the reverse. (Ḳ.)
xulayoTaI: see xiloTN:
and see what next follows, in two places.
xul-ayoTaI: see xiloTN.

waqaEuwA fiI xul-ayoTaI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and xulayoTaI↓, (Ḳ,) † They fell into a state of confusion: (Ḳ:) their affair, or case, became confused, or perplexed, (AixotalaTa,) to them. (Ṣ.) And kun-aA xulayoTaI↓ † [We were in a state of confusion]: cited by Az, from an Arab of the desert. (TA.) [xul-ayoTaMCu↓, which probably signifies the same, is mentioned in the TA, voce lugazN, on the authority of Sb.]
xil-iyTaI The creating confusion, or disorder, (UifosaAdN,) in an affair, or a case. (TA.) [See also 2.]
maAluhumo xil-iyTaI-N [in the CK mAlahumo] Their possessions, or camels, &c., are mixed together. (Ḳ,* TA.)
xul-ayoTaMCu: see xul-ayoTaI.
OaxolaTu mina AlHum-aI ‡ [More insinuating than fever]; a saying of the Arabs; meaning that it manifests an affection for a person by its access to him, like the lover and blandisher. (TA.)
mixolaTN † One who renders things confused, or dubious, to the hearers and beholders. (TA.)

† One who mixes in, or enters into, (yuxaAliTu,) affairs, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and relinquishes them; (TA; [but this addition seems rather to apply to mizoyalN in what follows;]) as also mixolaATN↓: (Ḳ:) or this latter signifies † one who mixes much with men. (Ṣgh, TA.) [See also xaliyTN.] You say, huwa mixolaTN mizoyalN † [He is one who mixes in, or enters into, affairs; (and, accord. to an explanation of mizoyalN in the TA, in art. zyl, on the authority of IAth,) one who is vehement in altercation, or litigation, relinquishing one plea, or argument, and taking to another]; like as you say, huwa raAtiqN faAtiqN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mixolaATN: see mixolaTN.
muxaAliTN: see xaliyTN.
muxotaliTN: see muxaAlaTN.
Also ‡ A camel that has become fat, so that the fat is mixed with the flesh: fem. with p {muxotaliTapN}, applied to a she-camel. (ISh, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. xalaEahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yaxolaEu}, (TA,) inf. n. xaloEN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He pulled it off; syn. nazaEahu; (Mgh, Mṣb;) or stripped it off; or took it off; (TA;) or put it, or threw it, or cast it, off from him; (IAth;) namely, his garment, (Ṣ, IAth, Mgh, Mṣb,) Eano badanihi from his body; (Mgh;) and his sandal, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) Eano rijolihi from his foot; (Mgh;), &c.; (Mṣb, TA;) [as also AxtlEhu↓, as appears from its being said that] AixotilaAEN is syn. with xaloEN: (TA:) accord. to some, xaloEN is syn. with nazoEN; but accord. to Lth, (TA,) the former is like the latter, except that the former is a somewhat leisurely action. (Ḳ, TA.) The phrase in the Ḳur [xx. 12], faQxolaEo naEolayoka is said to be used in its proper sense, [And do thou pull off, or put off, thy sandals,] because his sandals were of the skin of a dead ass: or, as the Soofees say, it is a command to stay; like as you say to him whom you desire to stay, “Pull off thy garment and thy boots,” and the like; and is tropical: (TA:) or, accord. to some, † make thy heart vacant from [care for] family and property. (Bḍ.)

It is said in a trad. respecting ʼOthmán, Uin-a Qll-eha sayuqam-iSuka qamiySFA waUin-aka tulaASu EalaI xaloEihi, (L,) meaning ‡ Verily God will invest thee with the apparel of the office of Khaleefeh, (Ḳ and TA in art. qmS,) and thou wilt be urged with enticement, and solicited, to divest thyself of it. (TA in art. lwS.)
xalaEa Alfarasu EicaArahu † The horse threw off his head-stall, or halter, and wandered about at random. (Mgh.)
[And hence,] xalaEa EicaArahu [said of a man,] ‡ ‡ He threw off from himself his EcAr, [meaning restraint,] and acted in a wrongful and evil manner towards others, with none to repress him. (TA.)
xalaEa OawoSaAlahu He removed its AwSAl [meaning the bones so called, as is indicated by the context]. (TA.)
xalaEa maAla SaAHibihi ‡ [He took away the property of his companion]; said of a person gambling with another. (A, TA.)
xalaEa qaloba Aln-aAZiri Uilayohi † [It drew away the heart of the beholder towards it]; said of the best of property. (Aboo-Saʼeed.)
xalaEa qayodahu ‡ [He took off his shackles; or] he released him from his shackles: and in like manner, xalaEa daAb-atahu, and xl-EhaA↓, he released his beast from its shackles. (TA.)
xalaEa Alr-iboqapa Eano Eunuqihi ‡ He annulled his compact, or covenant. (TA.)

xalaEa yadFA mino TaAEapK ‡ He [threw off his allegiance, or] forsook obedience to his Sultán, and acted in a wrongful and evil manner towards him: (TA:) obedience being likened to a garment which a man puts off, or throws off, from him. (IAth, TA.)
yuxolaEu Almay-itu [for yuxolaEu Alkafanu Eani Almay-iti, like xalaEa Ald-aAb-apa (mentioned above) for xalaEa qayoda Ald-aAb-api,] The corpse shall have its grave-clothes pulled off from it. (Mgh.)

[In like manner you say,] xalaEotu AlwaAliI Eano Eamalihi ‡ I removed the ruler, or governor, or the like, from his office; or deposed him. (Mṣb.) And xuliEa AlwaAliI ‡ [The ruler, or governor, or the like, was divested of his authority; or] was removed from his office; or was deposed; (Ṣ, TA;) and so AlEaAmilu [the agent, or the exactor of the poor-rates]; and Alxaliyfapu [the Khaleefeh]. (TA.) And xalaEa qaAYidahu ‡ [He divested his leader of his authority; or removed him from his office; or dismissed him]. (Ṣ, TA.) But IF says, This is scarcely, or never, said, except of an inferior who forsakes, or relinquishes, his superior; so that [xalaEahu signifies, in a case of this kind, ‡ He threw off his allegiance to him; or forsook obedience to him; like another phrase, mentioned above; and] one does not say, [or seldom says,] xalaEa AlOamiyru waAliyahu EalaI baladi kacaA [as meaning † The prince deposed his ruler over such a province, or the like]; but only, [or rather,] Eazalahu. (TA.)

xalaEa QmoraOatahu, (Az, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. xuloEN, with damm, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or this is a simple subst., (Az, Mgh, Mṣb,) and the inf. n. is xaloEN, (Az, Mṣb, TA,) and some add xilaAEN; (TA;) and xAlEhA↓, (Az, TA,) inf. n. muxaAlaEapN; (Ḳ;) [and xilaAEN seems to be another inf. n. of this latter verb, rather than of the former;] ‡ He divorced his wife (Az, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) for a ransom given by her, (Mṣb,) or for her property given by her as a ransom to release herself from him, (Az, Mgh, TA,) or for a gift, or a compensation, from her, (Ḳ, accord. to different copies; some having bibacolK; and others, bibabadalK;) or from another: (Ḳ:) because the wife is [as] a garment to the husband, and the husband to the wife, (Az, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) as is said in the Ḳur ii. 183: (Az, TA:) [it is also said that] taxaAluEN↓ is syn. with xuloEN: (Ḳ:) [but see 6, below:] and AixolaEohaA, occurring in a trad., is explained as signifying Divorce thou her, and quit her. (TA.)

xalaEahu Oaholuhu ‡ [His family cast him off, repudiated him, or renounced him;] so that if he committed a crime, or an offence rendering liable to punishment, they should not be prosecuted for it. (Ṣ, TA.) In the Time of Ignorance, when one said, (Ḳ, TA,) proclaiming in the fair, or festival, (TA,) yaA Oay-uhaA Aln-aAsu hecaA QbonaI qado xalaEotuhu, (Ḳ,* TA,) meaning [O men, this, my son, I cast off, repudiate, or renounce, him, or] I declare myself to be clear of him; so that if he commit a crime, or an offence rendering him liable to punishment, I am not responsible; and if a crime, or an offence rendering liable to punishment, be committed against him, I will not pursue [for redress, or retaliation]; (TA;) he was not punished afterwards for any such act committed by him: (Ḳ, TA:) this was when the person doing so feared some foul action or treachery from his son: and in like manner, they said, Uin-aA qado xalaEonaA fulaAnFA [Verily we cast off,, &c., such a one]. (TA.) In like manner, also, xalaEuwhu, inf. n. xaloEN, signifies ‡ [They cast him off, repudiated him, or renounced him, or] they declared themselves to be clear of him; meaning a confederate; so that they should not be punished for a crime, or an offence rendering liable to punishment, committed by him, nor should he be punished for such an act committed by them. (IAth, L.) In the same sense the verb is used in the saying, naxolaEu wanatoruku mano yafojuruka [We repudiate, or renounce, or] we declare ourselves clear of, and forsake, him who disobeys, or opposes, Thee: (Mgh, TA:) or naxolaEu wanahojuru mano yakofuruka we hate, and [repudiate, or renounce, or] declare ourselves clear of, [and forsake,] him who denies, or disacknowledges, thy favour, or who is ungrateful, or unthankful, for it. (Mṣb.)

xaluEa, aor. _u {yaxoluEu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xalaAEapN, (Ṣ,* TA,) ‡ He became cast off, repudiated, or renounced, by his family; (SaAra xaliyEFA; TA; i. e. xalaEahu Oaholuhu; Ṣ, TA;) so that if he committed a crime, or an offence rendering liable to punishment, they were not prosecuted for it: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) he became alienated or estranged [from his family]; syn. tabaAEada: (TA:) [he became vitious, or immoral; notorious for drinking and play; a gambler; or the like: see xalaAEapN, below; and see xaliyEN.]
xuliEa He became affected with what is termed xaAliEN, i. e., a twisting of the EuroquwbN [or hock-tendon]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. xl-E daAb-atahu: see 1.
taxoliyEN as signifying a certain manner of walking: see 5.

3. xaAlaEato baEolahaA, (Ṣ,) or taxoliyEN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. muxaAlaEapN, (Mṣb,) † She incited, urged, or induced, her husband to divorce her for a gift, or a compensation, (bibacolK, or bibadalK, accord. to different copies of the Ṣ,) from her to him: (Ṣ, Mgh:*) or † she ransomed herself from him, and he divorced her for the ransom. (Mṣb.)
xAlE QmoraOatahu: see 1.
xAlEhu ‡ He contended with him in a game of hazard: because he who does so takes away the property of his companion. (TA.)
5. txl-E It (a bond, or chain,) came off, or fell off, from the hand or foot. (KL.) [See also 7.]
txl-Et Als-afiynapu The ship parted asunder; became disjointed; became separated in its places of joining. (Mgh.)

txl-E, in walking, i. q. tafak-aka; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. ‡ [He was, or became, loose in the joints; or] he shook his shoulder-joints and his arms, and made signs with them: (TA:) and taxoliyEN↓ also signifies a certain manner of walking, (so in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA,) in which one shakes his shoulder-joints and his arms, and makes signs with them: (TA:) or the walking of him whose buttocks are apart, or parted. (CK, and so in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ.) [See also taxal-aja.]
txl-E fiI AlX-araAbi † He persisted in the drinking of intoxicating beverage, (Ḳ,* TA,) or became intoxicated, so that his joints became lax, or loose. (TA.)
txl-E Alqawomu † The people, or company of men, stole away, slipped away, or went away secretly. (IAạr.)
6. txAlEwA ‡ They annulled, dissolved, or broke, the confederacy, league, compact, or covenant, that was between them. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.)

taxaAlaEaA ‡ They divorced themselves, namely, a husband and his wife, for a gift, or a compensation, (bibacolK, or bibadalK, accord. to different copies of the Ṣ,) from the wife to the husband. (Ṣ.) See also xalaEa QmoraOatahu.
7. AnxlE It became pulled off, stripped off, taken off, or removed, from its place; it became displaced. (Mgh.) [See also 5.]

Hence, AinoxalaEa qinaAEu qalobihi mino Xid-api AlfazaEi ‡ [He became as though] the integument of his heart became pulled off, in consequence of violence of fear, or fright. (Mgh.) And hence also, AinoxalaEa fuWaAdu Alr-ajuli ‡ [The heart of the man became removed from its place; meaning] the man became frightened. (Mgh.)
[AnxlE AlEuDowu, or AlEaZomu, The limb, or the bone, became dislocated. See Ainoxaraja.]
[AnxlE Eano Eamalihi ‡ He (a ruler, or governor, or the like,) became removed from his office; became deposed. See 1.]
AnxlE mino maAlihi ‡ He became stripped of his property, like as a man is stripped of his garment. (TA.)

hom.sense: 8. AixotalaEato (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) mino zawojihaA, (Mgh,) ‡ She became divorced from her husband (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) for a gift, or a compensation, from her, (Ṣ, Ḳ, accord. to different copies; some having bibacolK; and others, bibabadK;) or from another, (Ḳ,) or for her property given by her as a ransom to release her from him. (Mgh.)
AxtlEhu: see 1, first sentence.
AxtlEwhu ‡ They took his property: (Ḳ, TA:) from the “Nawá- dir el-Aaráb.” (TA.)

xaloEN Flesh-meat cooked with seeds that are used for seasoning, then put into a receptacle of skin, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) which is called qarofN: (Ṣ:) or flesh-meat cut into strips or oblong pieces, and dried, or salted, and dried in the sun, roasted, (Ḳ, TA,) and, as Lth says, (TA,) put into a receptacle with its melted grease: (Ḳ,* TA:) or flesh-meat having its bones pulled out, then cooked, and seasoned with seeds, and put into a skin, and used as provision for travelling: (Z, TA:)
and xaliyEN↓, also, signifies flesh-meat of which the bones have been pulled out, and which is seasoned with seeds, and laid up (yurofaEu) [for future use]: (TA:) and xawolaEN↓, flesh-meat which is boiled in vinegar, and then carried in journeys. (TA.)
A state of dislocation of the joint, of the arm or hand, or of the leg or foot; its becoming displaced, without separation; as also xalaEN↓. (TA.)

entry.sense: xuloEN [accord. to the Ṣ, and app. accord. to the Ḳ, and inf. n., (see xalaEa QmoraOatahu,) or] a simple subst., signifying ‡ The act of divorcing a wife (Az, Mgh, Mṣb) for a ransom given by her, (Mṣb,) or for her property given by her as a ransom to release her from her husband, (Az, Mgh, TA,) or for a gift, or a compensation, from her; or from another: (Ḳ: see 1:) IAth says that it annuls the return to the wife unless by means of a new contract: accord. to EshSháfi'ee, there is a difference of opinion respecting it; whether it be an annulment of the marriage, or a divorcement: [if the latter, it is not irrevocable unless preceded by two divorcements:] sometimes it is called by the latter term. (TA.) [See also xuloEapN.]
xalaEN: see xaloEN.

hom.sense: xuloEapN A state of divorcement [for a ransom given by the wife, or for her property given by her as a ransom to release her from her husband, or] for a gift, or a compensation, from the wife, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) or from another. (Ḳ.) [See 8: and see also xuloEN.] You say, waqaEato bayonahumaA AlxuloEapu [Divorcement, or] separation, [for a ransom,, &c. or] for [a gift, or] a compensation, took place between them two. (TḲ.)

† The best, or choice part, of property, or of camels or the like; (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ṣ Ṣgh, Ḳ;) so called because it takes away the heart of him who looks at it; (Aboo-Saʼeed;) as also xiloEapN↓. (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
† Weakness in a man. (TA.)

entry.sense: xiloEapN Any garment which one pulls off, or takes off, from himself: (TA:) and particularly, (TA,) a garment which is bestowed upon a man, [generally meaning a robe of honour,] (Ḳ,* TA,) whether it be put upon him or not: (TA:) or a gift, or free gift, [of any kind,] which a man bestows upon another: (Mṣb:) or a sewed garment: (KL:) pl. xilaEN. (Mṣb, TA.) You say, xalaEa Ealayohi xiloEapF [explained above]: see 1, near the beginning. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also xuloEapN.
xuloEiI-N, with damm, One who sells [cast-off or] old garments. (Ibn-Nuktah, TA.)
xiloEiI-N, with kesr to the x, and with the l quiescent, One who sells the garments bestowed by kings. (TA.)

xulaAEN † An affection resembling what is termed xabalN [q. v.], (Ḳ, TA,) and insanity, or diabolical possession, (TA,) which befalls a man: (Ḳ, TA:) or weakness, and fear or fright: (TA:) and xawolaEN↓ and xayolaEN↓ [in like manner] signify ‡ fear, or fright, affecting the heart, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) occasioning evil imagination, and weakness, (TA.) as though it were a touch of insanity, or of diabolical possession, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in a man, and in the heart. (Ṣ.)
xaliyEN Pulled off; stripped, or taken, off; put, or thrown, or cast, off; i. q. maxoluwEN↓; applied [to a garment, and a sandal, or the like, or], accord. to some, to anything. (TA.)
[Hence, used as a subst., A cast-off, or] an old, and wornout, garment. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, huwayakosuwhu mino xaliyEihi [He clothes him with some of his cast-off, or old, and worn-out, apparel]. (TA.)
See also xaloEN.
† A person whose property is won from him in a game of hazard; as also maxoluwEN↓. (L.)

xaliyEu AlEicaAri † † A man who does and says what he pleases; not caring, nor fearing God nor the blame of men; like the beast that has no halter on its head. (Ḥar p. 676.) Also applied to a woman in a state of estrangement [from her husband; lit., Having her headstall, or halter, pulled off, or thrown off; she being likened to a mare; meaning, † † without restraint]; having none to command or forbid her: [see 1:] incorrectly written xaliyEapu AlEicaAri; for xlyE is here of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: or you say xaliyfapN without mentioning the EcAr, from xalaEapN, like ZariyfapN and laTiyfapN [from ZaraAfapN and laTaAfapN]. (Mgh.) [See also xaAliEN.]

xaliyEN is also applied to a Khaleefeh, and a prince or the like, meaning ‡ Divested of his authority; removed from his office; deposed; (L;) as also maxoluwEN↓: and it is a strange thing, noticed by Dmr and others, that every sixth is mxlwE. (TA.)

Also ‡ A young man, (Ṣ,) or a son, (Ḳ,) and a confederate, (IAth, L,) cast off, repudiated, or renounced, (Ṣ, IAth, L, Ḳ,) by his family, (Ṣ,) or father, (Ḳ,) or confederates, (IAth, Ḳ,) so that if he commit a crime, or an offence rendering liable to punishment, they, i. e. his family, or he, i. e. his father, or they, i. e. his confederates, shall not be prosecuted, or punished, for it; (Ṣ, IAth, L, Ḳ;) as also maxoluwEN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former, xulaEaMCu: (Ḳ:) and ‡ a young man (Ḳ, TA) thus cast off by his family, (TA,) who commits, or has committed, many crimes, or offences rendering him liable to punishment; as also xawolaEN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) † one alienated or estranged [from his family]: (TA:) ‡ one who has broken off from his family, and disagreed with them, and wearied them by his wickedness and baseness and guile; (Mgh, Ḳ,* TA;*) as though he had thrown off his headstall or halter, [i. e., restraint,] and who does what he will; or because his family have cast him off, and declared themselves clear of him; (Mgh;) or because he has cast off his kinsfolk, and they have declared themselves clear of him; or because he is divested of religion and shame; (TA;) fem. with p {xulaAEapN}: (Ḳ: [indicating that it is a part. n. of xaluEa; not of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, as is implied by some portions of the explanations here given:]) † bad, evil, wicked, or mischievous: (TA:) ‡ [vitious, or immoral: (see xalaAEapN, whence it is derived:)] † notorious for drinking and play: (TA:) [in the present day commonly used in this sense; and as signifying † waggish; or a way:] † a player, with another, at a game of hazard, or for stakes laid by both of them to be taken by the winner; (IDrd, Ḳ;) as also muxaAliEN↓; because the best, or choice part, of his property (xuloEatuhu) is [often] won from him: (Ṣ:) † one who applies himself constantly to games of that kind: (TA:) and xawolaEN↓ signifies ‡ a player at games of that kind, who has had the punishment termed Had-N inflicted upon him, and is always overcome in such games, or who is fortunate, and always overcomes in such games. (Ḳ, accord. to different copies; in some of which we read AlmuqaAmiru AlmaHoduwdu Al-aciI yuqomaru OabadFA; and in others, AlmqASr Almajoduwdu AlcI yaqomuru AbdA.)
† A hunter, fowler, or fisherman; (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ;) so called because he is alone. (Ṣgh.)
‡ A [demon, or devil,, &c., of the kind called] guwl; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) because of its evil nature; (TA;) as also xawolaEN↓ (Ḳ) and xayolaEN↓. (TA.)
† A wolf; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xawolaEN↓ (Ḳ) and xayolaEN↓. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
† The gaming-arrow that does not win (Ṣ, Kr, Ḳ) at first: (Ṣ, Kr:) or, accord. to some, the gaming-arrow that wins at first; as is said by Ṣgh and in the L: (TA:) pl. xilaEapN. (Kr.)

xalaAEapN: [see xaluEa:] it is syn. with daEaArapN [i. e. ‡ Vice, or immorality; or vitious, or immoral, conduct;, &c.]; as also xaraAEapN, a dial. var. thereof; (Ṣ in art. xrE;) and xaliyEapN↓ signifies the same. (TA.)
xaliyEapN: see what next precedes.
xaliEu AlEicaAri [† A horse throwing off his headstall, or halter, and wandering about at random.]
[And hence, † † A man throwing off from himself restraint, and acting in a wrongful and an evil manner towards others, with none to repress him. See also xaliyEN.]
[And hence,] † † † A beardless youth, or young man; or one whose mustache has grown forth, but not his beard. (TA.)
xaAliEN † A kid. (TA.) [App. because of its playful disposition.]

† A woman who incites, urges, or induces, her husband to divorce her for a gift, or a compensation, from her to him: [see 3:] (Ṣ:) or who causes herself to be divorced for a gift, or a compensation, from her to her husband: [see 6:] and in like manner, a husband who divorces his wife for a gift, or a compensation, from her. (Ḳ.)

ruTabN xaAliEN Dates that are all ripe, or ripe throughout, or soft; syn. munosabitN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because their skins strip off by reason of their succulency: (TA:) and busorapN xaAliEN, (Ḳ, TA,) and xaAliEapN, (TA,) a date that has become wholly fit to be eaten. (Ḳ,* TA.) [See busorN]

xaAliEN also signifies A twisting of the Euroquwb [or hocktendon]: (Ḳ:) or a certain disease that attacks the Euroquwb of a she-camel. (TA.) And you say, baEiyrN bihi xaAliEN, (Ṣ,) or baEiyrN xaAliEN, (Ḳ,) A camel that is unable to rise (Ṣ, Ḳ) when a man sits upon the part called guraAb [q. v.] of its haunch, (Ṣ) in consequence, as some say, of a dislocation of the tendon of the hock. (TA.)

jubonN xaAliEN ‡ Vehement cowardice; as though the vehemence of the man's fear removed his heart from its place; accord. to IAth, an affection arising from yearning thoughts, and weakness of the heart, on an occasion of fear. (TA.)

hom.sense: xawolaEN: see xaloEN.

It also signifies habiyd [i. e. Colocynth, or its pulp, or seed,] when it is cooked until its samon [or decocted juice] comes forth, whereupon it is cleared, and put aside; and bruised dates of which the stones have been taken out are put upon it, and flour, and it is stirred about and beaten until it becomes mixed; then it is left, and put down; and when it becomes cold, its smn is restored to it: or, as some say, colocynth (HanoZal) bruised, moistened with something to sweeten it, and then eaten; also called mubas-alN. (TA.) [See habiydN.]
See also xulaAEN:
and xaliyEN, in four places.
Also Stupid; (Ḳ;) applied to a man. (TA.)
And A skilful guide. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
xayolaEN: see xulaAEN:
and see xaliyEN, in two places, near the end.
Also † A weak man. (TA.) [See also muxal-aEN.]

entry.sense: muxal-aEN AlOaloyatayoni A man (Ṣ) having the buttocks apart, or parted. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And muxal-aEN A weak, and soft, or flabby, man. (Lth, Ḳ.) [See also xayolaEN.]
‡ A man (TA) in whom is what resembles a loss of reason, or a touch of insanity or of diabolical possession: (Ḳ,* TA:) and ‡ a man insane, or possessed by a jinnee. (TA.)
maxoluwEN: see xaliyEN, in four places.
rajulN maxoluwEu AlfuWaAdi ‡ A man frightened, or terrified; as though his heart were removed from its place. (TA.)
muxaAliEN: see xaliyEN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

muxotaliEapN ‡ A woman divorced from her husband for a gift, or a compensation, from him, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or from another: (Ḳ:) [see 8:] and [the pl.] muxotaliEaAtN [is explained as signifying] ‡ women who incite, urge, or induce, their husbands to divorce them for a gift, or a compensation, without any injurious conduct from the latter. (TA.)
† A woman affected with lust. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. xalafa, aor. _u {yaxolufu}, inf. n. xalofN, He came after, followed, succeeded, or remained after, another, or another that had perished or died. (TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [vii. 168 and xix. 60], faxalafa mino baEodihimo xalofN (TA) And there hath succeeded them, or come after them, [a posterity, or] an evil posterity. (Bḍ in xix. 60.) And xalafahu He came after him, (Ṣ, A in art. dbr, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) or behind him, (A ubi suprà, Mgh,) or following him nearly; (A ubi suprà;) inf. n. as above, (Mgh, TA,) and xilofapN also: (Mgh:) or he remained after him: (Ḳ:) and jaMCa xilaAfahu↓ likewise signifies [the same as jMC xalofahu; an inf. n. of xaAlafa being thus used as an adv. n.; i. e.] he came after him. (TA.) You say also, xalafa All-ayolu Aln-ahaAra, inf. n. xalofN and xilofapN, The night followed, or came after, the day. (MA.)

[Hence,] xalafotuhu, [aor. as above,] inf. n. xalofN, [perhaps a mistranscription for xalafa,] I was, after him, a substitute for him: (TA:) [I supplied his place: and I superseded him.] And xalafahu, (aor. as above, TA,) inf. n. xilaAfapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and xalafN (TA) and xil-iyqaI, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) which last is an inf. n. of the intensive kind, (Ṣgh, MF, TA,) He was, or became, his xaliyfap [i. e. successor, or vice-agent,, &c.], (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or his substitute; (TA;) fiI qawomihi [among, or in respect of, his people], (Ṣ, TA,) and Oaholihi [his family]; relating to good and to evil; wherefore one says, OawoSaI lahu biAlxilaAfapi [he charged him by his will with the being his successor, or vice-agent,, &c.]; (TA;) or EalaI Oaholihi wamaAlihi [over his family and his property]: (Mṣb:) and Axtflhu↓ signifies the same; (Lḥ, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) he was, or became, his xaliyfap (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA) after him. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.) And xalafa fulaAnFA [alone] He was, or became, the xaliyfapN of such a one among, or in respect of, his family (Ḳ, TA) and his children. (TA.) And xalafahu rab-uhu fiI Oaholihi (Ḳ, TA) and waladihi, (TA,) inf. n. xilaAfapN, (Ḳ,) His Lord was [for him] a xaliyfap [or supplier of his place] to his family (Ḳ, TA) and his children. (TA. [In the CK, Axlf is made to signify the same; but this is in consequence of an omission.]) And one says, xalafa Qll-ehu Ealayoka May God be to to thee a xaliyfap [or supplier of the place] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) of thy father; (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or of the one whom thou hast lost: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) thus one says to one who has lost by death his father (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) or mother (Ḳ) or paternal uncle (Ṣ, Mṣb) or any other who cannot be replaced: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) and xalafa Qll-ehu Ealayoka xayorFA, (Ḳ,) or bixayorK, (AZ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or both, (L,) and xalafa Qll-ehu laka bixayorK, (AZ, Mṣb,) and Oaxolafa↓ Qll-ehu Ealayoka xayorFA and laka xayorFA: (Ḳ: [in which it is implied that these phrases mean May God supply to thee well the place of him whom thou hast lost: but it is implied in the Mṣb that the two of them there mentioned mean May God restore to thee good in the place of that which has gone from thee: and it appears from what here follows that all of these phrases have the latter meaning, whether or not they have the former meaning also:]) to him who has lost property or a child or a thing [of any other kind] of which the replacement may be asked, (Ṣ,) or to him of whom that which may be replaced has perished, or died, (Ḳ,) one says, Oaxolafa↓ Qll-ehu Ealayoka (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) May God restore to thee the like of that which has gone from thee, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or may God restore to thee what has gone from thee; (Ḳ in a later part of the art.;) and Axlf↓ Qll-eh laka; and xalafa Qll-eh lk: or xalafa Qll-eh Ealayoka is allowable in relation to property and the like; and yaxolafu, like yamonaEu is allowable as its aor., though extr., (Ḳ,) as it has no faucial letter to occasion the fet-ḥ: (TA:) and one says also, xalafa Qll-ehu laka bixayorK meaning May God give thee good in the place of that which has gone from thee; (TA;) and Axlf↓ Ealayoka xayorFA, (Mṣb, TA,) meaning the same; (TA;) and [so] Axlf↓ laka xayorFA and bixayorK: and Axlf↓ Qll-ehu Ealayoka maAlaka and laka maAlaka [May God restore, or replace, to thee thy property]. (Mṣb.) xalafa OabaAhu, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxolufu}, (TA,) means He became behind his father; (Ḳ;) and if so, its inf. n. is xalofN: (TA:) or it means he became in the place of his father; (Ḳ;) and if so, its inf. n. is xalafN: (TA:) and xalafa makaAna Oabiyhi, inf. n. xilaAfapN (Ḳ) and xalafN, (TA,) he became in the place of his father, exclusively of every other. (Ḳ.) You say also, xalafati AlfaAkihapi baEoDuhaA baEoDFA, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. xalofN, (JK, TA,) or xalafN, (TA, [the former being there altered to the latter (which is the more probably correct), or the latter to the former,]) and xilofapN, (JK, TA,) The fruit replaced other fruit; or became substituted for other fruit. (JK,* Ḳ,* TA. [In the CK, SaAra xalofFA is erroneously put for SaArato xalafFA.]) And xalafa fulaAnN EalaI fulaAnapa, inf. n. xilaAfapN, [like Eaqaba EalayohaA,] Such a man took as his wife such a woman after another husband [and thus supplied his place]. (Z, TA.)

xalafa ulaAnFA, (aor. _u {yaxolufu} TA,) He took, or seized, such a one from behind him; (JK,* Ḳ;) as also Axtlfhu↓. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) xalafa lahu biAls-ayofi (JK, TA) He came to him from behind him, and smote his neck, or struck off his head, with the sword. (TA.)
xalafa fulaAnN biEaqibiI [is explained as meaning] Such a one stayed, or abode, after me. (Mṣb in art. Eqb) [But]

xalafa biEaqabi fulaAnK is said by some to mean xaAlafahu↓ UilaI Oaholihi [q. v.]: accord. to Aṣ, however, it means He parted with such a one on the condition of doing a certain thing, and then came behind him [or behind his back] and did another thing after parting with him: and Az says that this is a more correct explanation than the former one. (TA.) [Hence, app.,] one says also, Uin-a QmoraOapa fulaAnK taxolufu zawojahaA biAln-izaAEi UilaI gayorihi UicaA gaAba EanohaA [Verily the wife of such a one is unfaithful to her husband by yearning towards another when he is absent from her: or deceives her husband behind his back by yearning towards another; for it is implied, by an ex. given, that AcA gAb EnhA is added by way of explanation]. (TA.) xalafahu also signifies He spoke of him, or mentioned him, [behind his back, or] when he was not present: so in the phrase, xalafahu bixayorK or biXar-K [He spoke of him behind his back well or ill]. (TA.) And one says, yaxolufu Aln-aAsa mino waraAYihimo [meaning He defames men behind their backs]: the action signified hereby is like giybapN, and may be [by making signs] with the side of the mouth, and with the eye, and with the head. (TA in art. hmz.)

xalafa Eano OaSoHaAbihi, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. _u {yaxolufu}, He remained behind, or after, his companions; did not go forth with them; as also qaEada xilaAfa↓ OaSoHaAbihi [similar to a phrase mentioned near the beginning of this art.]; (TA;)
i. q. txl-f↓; (Ḳ in explanation of the former phrase;) which is syn. with taOax-ara; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as in the phrase txl-f Ean-iI [which means He remained behind me, or after me]; (Ṣ;) [for] txl-f Eanohu means baqiIa xalofahu; (Mgh;) and [in like manner] you say, txl-f Eani lAqawomi He remained behind, or after, the people, or party, not going with them; [he held back, or hung back, from them;] and qaEadotu xilaAfahu↓ [i. e. I remained] behind him, or after him; (Mṣb;) and xAlf↓ Ean-aA He remained behind us, or after us; syn. txl-f↓. (TA, from a trad.) It is said in the Ḳur [xvii. 78], waUicaA laA yalobavuwna xilaAfaka↓ Uil-aA qaliylFA, i. e. [But in that case they should not have remained] after thee [save a little while]: (JK, TA:*) so accord. to one reading [instead of xalofaka, which means the same]. (TA.) And in like manner, fariHa Almuxal-afuwna bimaqoEadihimo xilaAfa↓ rasuwli Qll-ehi, in the Ḳur [ix. 82], means [Those who were left behind rejoiced in their remaining] behind the Apostle of God: (Ṣ, TA:) or the meaning here is, muxaAlafapa rswl Qll-eh [i. e. in disagreement with the Apostle of God]: (JK, Ṣ:) thus says Lḥ; but IB disagrees with him; saying that xlAf here means baEoda; and cites six exs. in which it has this meaning, from poets. (TA.)

[Hence,] xalafa fulaAnN Eano kul-i xayorK † [Such a one was, or became, kept back from all good; i. e.,] did not prosper, or was not successful. (TA. [It is there added, that it is explained in the A as tropical, and as meaning tagay-ara wafasada: but this is perhaps a mistake, occasioned by the accidental omission of waxalafa All-abanu or the like, of which this is a correct explanation: or the phrase thus explained in the TA, as from the A, may correctly mean He became altered for the worse, and corrupt; agreeably with other explanations of the verb below.])

xalafa, aor. _u {yaxolufu}, also signifies He (a man) retired, withdrew, or went away or apart. (JK.) And xalafato nafosahu Eani AlT-aEaAmi, aor. _u {yaxolufu}, inf. n. xuluwfN, † His soul turned away from, avoided, or shunned, the food, in consequence of disease. (JK, TA.)
And He fled. (Ḥam p. 411.)
And He (a man, Ṣgh) ascended a mountain. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
See also 2, first sentence.

xalafa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. xuluwfN, (Lḥ, Mṣb, TA, and Ḥam p. 679,) [inf. n. xuluwfN,] said of the taste of water, It was, or became, different from, or contrary to, what it was thought to be: and [hence,] it was, or became, altered [for the worse]: (Ḥam ubi suprà:) [and] said of milk, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of food, (Lḥ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and the like, (Lḥ, TA,) and some say xalufa, (TA,) aor. _u {yaxolufu}, inf. n. xuluwfN, (Lḥ, TA,) of both verbs, (TA,) it was, or became, altered [for the worse] (Lḥ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) in taste, or in odour; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Axlf↓: or, said of milk, the first signifies it became bad from being long kept; or, as in the A, ‡ what was good thereof became mixed (xulifa, i. e. xuliTa,) with other milk: and Axlf↓, said of milk, signifies also it was, or became, sour: (TA:) and the first, said of [the beverage called] nabiyc, it became bad. (Ḳ.) Also, inf. n. xuluwfN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xuluwfapN (Ḳ) and xilofapN, (L, TA,) said of the mouth (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) of a person fasting, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It was, or became, altered [for the worse] in odour; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Axlf↓. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad. that the xuluwf of the mouth of one who is fasting is sweeter in the estimation of God than the odour of musk: or, accord. to some of the lawyers and of the relaters of traditions, xaluwf; but [SM says,] I think this to be a mistake, as several affirm it to be, while others say that it is of a bad dial.: accord. to one reading, it is xilofap. (TA.)
[Hence,] xalafa Eano xuluqi Oabiyhi, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxolufu}, inf. n. xuluwfN, (TA,) † He was, or became, altered [for the worse] from the natural disposition of his father. (Ḳ, TA.)
And xalafa, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xalofN [or xuluwfN]; or xalofa, aor. _u {yaxolufu}, inf. n. xalaAfapN and xuluwfN; (TA;) † He (a man) was, or became, bad, or corrupt. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

And xalafa, (Ḳ) inf. n. xalaAfapN (IAth, Ḳ) and xuluwfN, (Ḳ,) † He (a man) was, or became, stupid, or foolish; or one who had little, or no, intellect or understanding: (Ḳ,* TA:) or unprofitable: or a frequent promise-breaker: (IAth:) or xalafa and Axlf↓, said of a slave, he was, or became, idiotic, deficient in intellect, or bereft of his intellect. (JK.)

xalafa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xalofN; (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA;) and Axlf↓, and Astxlf↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He drew water, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) liOaholihi for his family: [app. because he who does so leaves his family behind him: see 2, first sentence:] (Ḳ, TA:) [or] Astxlf↓, said of a man, signifies AisotaEocaba AlmaMC [app. as meaning he sought, or drew, or brought, sweet water: see art. Ecb]: and, accord. to IAạr, you say, Oaxolafotu↓ Alqawoma, meaning properly I carried sweet water to the people, or party, when they were in the [season, or herbage, called] rabiyE and without sweet water, or when they were by salt water: UixolaAfN [as meaning the carrying, or drawing, of water,] being [properly] only in the rbyE: in other cases, metaphorically applied. (TA.) El-Hoteíäh says,
lizugobK kaOawolaAdi AlqaTaA raAva xalofuhaA↓
EalaI EaAjizaAti Aln-ahoDi HumorK HawaASiluho
† [To, or for, downy ones, like the young ones of the katà, whose procurer of water has been slow in coming to those lacking the power of spreading their wings for flight, red in their crops]: he means mixolifuhaA↓ [or xaAlifuhaA], and has put in the place of this the inf. n.: and by HwASlh, accord. to Ks, he means HawaASilu maA cakaronaA [the crops of what we have mentioned]: but Fr says that the h relates to the zgb, exclusively of the EAjzAt, which [latter] has the sign of the pl.; for every pl. that has the form of a sing. may be imagined to be a sing., as in the saying of the poet,
mivolu AlfiraAxi nutifato HawaASiluho
[meaning “like the young birds of which the crops have been plucked”]; for AlfrAx has not the sign of the pl., but has the form of a sing., like AlkitaAb and AlHijaAb: another says, [but this is very far-fetched,] that the h relates to AlnhD, which [sometimes] means a place in the shoulderblade of the camel; and that the poet has used it metaphorically as belonging to the qTA. (Ṣ.)

xalafa Alv-awoba, (Ṣ,) or AlqamiySa, aor. _u {yaxolufu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xalofN (Kr, TA) and xulofapN, in some copies of the Ḳ xalofapN, [so in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, and so in the TḲ,] and [in some] xulafN also, but these require consideration, (TA,) He took out from the garment, or shirt, the part that was worn out, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) that is, the middle part, which was worn out, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and then sewed the [cut] edges together. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And Axlf↓ Alv-awoba signifies the same as xalafahu, i. e. He repaired the garment [app. in any manner, or, as is implied in the Ṣ and TA, by substituting one piece for another]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

The saying, in a trad. of Hamneh, faUicaA xalafato celika falotagotasilo, meaning † And when she has discriminated that period of days and nights during which she has been HaAYiD, [she shall perform a complete ablution of herself,] is from xalafa AlqamiyS signifying as explained above. (Mṣb.)
xalafa signifies also He mixed [a thing with another thing; as, for instance, (see xulifa in a passage above,) milk with other milk]: and he mixed saffron, and medicine, with water. (TA.)
xalafa bayotahu He put to, or made for, his tent, a pole, (Ḳ, TA,) termed a xaAlifap, (TA,) in the hinder part thereof. (Ḳ TA.)
xalifa, aor. _a {yaxolafu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xalafN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He (a camel) inclined towards one side. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
xalafN is also an inf. n. (of xalifa, said of a man, TḲ) signifying The being Oaxolaf as meaning contrarious, hard in disposition, as though going with a leaning towards one side:
and the being left-handed:
and the being OaHowal [or squint-eyed]. (Ḳ.)
xalifato, aor. _a {yaxolafu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xalafN, (Mṣb, TA,) She (a camel) was, or became, pregnant. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

2. xl-fhu, (Mṣb,) and xl-fhu waraMCahu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. taxoliyfN, (TA,) He left him behind him; (Mṣb;) namely, a man: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) and xalafahu↓ [signifies the same: or] he made him to be behind him; as also Axlfhu↓ [q.v.], and Axtlfhu↓: (TA:) [whence the saying,] OaloHaHotu EalaI fulaAnK fiI AlAitibaAEi Hat-aI Qxotalafotuhu↓ i. e. [I pressed upon such a one in following] until I made him to be behind me. (ISk, TA.) You say also, xal-afahumo, inf. n. as above, meaning He was, or became, or went, before them; and left them behind him. (TA.) And xl-fwA OavoqAlahum, inf. n. as above, They left their loads, or baggage, &c., behind their backs; (O, Ḳ;) when they went away to draw water. (TA.)

[Hence,] xl-fhu He made him, or appointed him, his xaliyfap [i. e. successor, or vice-agent,, &c.]; (Ḳ;) and so Astxlfhu↓. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) So in the Ḳur [xxiv. 54], layasotaxilafan-ahumo↓ fiI QloOaroDi kamaA Qsotaxolafa Ql-aciyna mino qabolihimo [That He will assuredly make them to be successors in the earth, like as He made to be successors those who were before them]. (TA.)
xl-f binaAqatihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) He bound one of the teats of his she-camel with the thing termed SiraAr [in order that her young one might not suck it]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) from Yaạḳoob. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense:
3. xAlfhu, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. xilaAfN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and muxaAlafapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) He [or it] disagreed with, or differed from, him [or it]; or he dissented from him; (Mgh, Mṣb;) contr. of waAfaqahu; fiI kacaA [in, or in respect of, such a thing]: (Mgh:) and he, or it, was contrary, opposed, or repugnant, to him, or it: (TA:) [and he acted contrarily, contrariously, adversely, or in opposition, to him, or it; he, or it, contravened, or opposed, him, or it:] and he [or it] contradicted him [or it]. (M in art. nqD.) It is said in a prov., Uin-amaA Oanota xilaAfa AlD-abuEi Alr-aAkiba, i. e. tuxaAlifu xilaAfa AlD-abuEi [Verily thou art one who acts with the contrariousness of the hyena towards the rider]: for the hyena [attacks a man on foot, but], when it sees the rider, flees from him. (IAạr, TA.) You say also, xaAlafaniI Eano kacaA He turned away from such a thing [in opposition to me, or] when I betook myself to it: [see also the last sentence but one of the first paragraph {1} of art. bht:] and xAlfnI UilaI kacaA He betook himself to such a thing [in opposition to me, or] when I turned away from it: (Mgh:) or xAlfhu UilaI AlX-aIoCi means he disobeyed him by betaking himself to the thing; or betook himself to the thing after he had forbidden him it. (TA.) And hence, (Mgh,) huwa yuxaAlifu UilaI QmoraOapi fulaAnK, (Ṣ, Mgh,*) or UilaI fulaAnapa, (O, L, TA,) in the Ḳ erroneously, hw yxAlf fulaAnapa, (TA,) He comes to the wife of such a one when he [the latter] is absent from her, (Ṣ,) or to such a woman when her husband is absent from her: (Mgh,* O, L, Ḳ, TA:) and xAlfhu UilaI Oaholihi [he came to his (another's) wife in his (the husband's) absence]: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph. (Az, TA.) And xAlfhu Uilayohimo He watched to see him, and, when he was absent from them, namely, his family, he went in to them: (Jm, O, TA:) and, accord. to AZ, Axlf↓ fulaAnN SaAHibahu Such a one watched to see his companion, and, when he was absent, he came, and went in to him [or rather to his wife or to his family]: (TA:) [or] xAlf↓ SaAHibahu he watched to see his companion, and, when he was absent, went in to his wife: (Ḳ, and the like is said in the JK:) thus says IDrd, on the authority of AZ. (TA.) And xAlf UilaI qawomK He came to a party, or company of men, from behind them [or behind their backs]: or he feigned to them the contrary of that which he conceived in his mind, and took them unawares. (TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, [describing a collector of wild honey,]
UicaA lasaEatohu Aln-aHolu lamo yaroju lasoEahaA
waxaAlafahaA fiI bayoti nuwbK EawaAsili , (Ṣ in the present art., in which only the former hemistich is cited, and in art. rjw,) i. e. [When the bees sting him,] he fears not nor minds [their stinging], (Ṣ in art. rjw) [but comes, during their absence, to the hiving-place of bees occupied in gathering honey:] meaning, he comes to their honey, (Ṣ, TA, [in the latter of which, in the place of AlnHl, is put Ald-aboru “the swarm of bees,”]) and takes it, (TA,) while they are feeding; (Ṣ, TA;) or, as AA says, he comes behind them to the honey while they are absent: AO explains it by xaAlafahaA UilaI mawoDiEK Mxara which [he says] means he keeps with them [to another place]; syn. laAzamahaA; [and thus this phrase (which is strangely misinterpreted in the TḲ and in Freytag's Lexicon) is explained in the Ḳ, but without any reference to the verse;] as also HaAlafahaA, with the unpointed H: (TA:) and some read the verse thus; but this reading is said to be a mistake. (TA in art. Hlf.)
jaMCa xilaAfahu: see 1, near the beginning of the paragraph. And see also five other exs. in the middle portion of the same paragraph.

xAlf bayona rijolayohi He put one of his legs forward and the other backward: and [hence,] AlmuxaAlafapu bayona Alr-ijolayoni [as signifying the alternate shifting of the legs to and fro] is metonymically used as meaning the act of dancing. (Ḥar p. 108.) [And xAlf bayona AlX-ayoYayoni He put, or placed, the two things contrariwise; or on contrary sides; or in contrary directions. Hence,] Oawo tuqaT-aEa Oayodiyhimo waOarojuluhumo mino xilaAfK, in the Ḳur v. 37, [Or that their hands and their feet shall be cut off on contrary sides,] means that their right hands and left feet shall be cut off. (Bḍ, Jel. [See also similar exs. in the Ḳur vii. 121 and xx. 74 and xxvi. 49.]) [Hence also,] farasN bihi XikaAlN mino xilaAfK, (JK,) or cuw xadamataAni mino xilaAfK, (TA,) A horse having a whiteness in his right fore leg and his left hind leg [or the reverse]: (JK, TA:) and some say, lahu xadamataAni mino xilaAfK when he has a whiteness [or rather a ring of white a little above the hoof] in his fore leg [or right fore leg] and another in his left fore leg [probably a mistake of a copyist for his left hind leg]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Axlfhu: see 2, first sentence. Also He put him, turned him, or made him to go back or stand back, behind him. (Ḳ, TA.) And Axlf yadahu He put his hand behind him. (Az, TA.) And also, (Fr, TA,) or Axlf biyadihi UilaI Als-ayofi, (JK,) or simply Axlf [used elliptically], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He put [back] his hand to his sword, (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in order to draw it, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) it being hung behind him. (Fr,* TA.) And Axlf Als-ayofa [He hung the sword behind him; or kept it hung behind him]: said, in a trad., of a man on the day of Bedr. (TA.) And Axlf Eani AlbaEiyri [for Axlf Eanohu AlHaqaba] He shifted [backwards] the hind girth of the camel, putting it next to his testicles, on account of its hurting the sheath of his penis, and causing a suppression of his urine; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Axlf AlbaEiyra: (TA:) or you say only, Oaxolifi AlHaqaba, meaning remove thou the hind girth from the sheath of the penis. (Lḥ, TA.) And Axlf Ald-aAb-apa biAls-awoTi He struck the beast on the hinder part with the whip. (JK.)

Axlf AlbaAzila [He (a camel) exceeded in age the bAzl, which is generally one that has entered his ninth year: as though he made the bAzl to be behind him: and so, app., Axlf alone; AlbaAzila being understood: see muxolifN]. El-Jaadee says,
Oaxolafa AlbaAzila EaAmFA Oawo bazalo
Oay-idi AlkaAhili jalodK baAzilK
[Strong in the withers, hardy, a bAzl; that has exceeded in age him who has just become a bAzl by a year, or that has himself just become a bAzl]. (Ṣ, TA.) Some say that AlUixolaAfu is [a term denoting] the last of the ages [that have words to signify them] with respect to all beasts. (TA.)
Axlf fulaAnN SaAHibahu: see 3, near the middle of the paragraph.

Axlfhu maA waEadahu, (Ṣ,) or mawoEidahu, (Mgh,) or waEodahu, (Mṣb,) or AlwaEoda, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UixolaAfN, (Mgh,) He broke, (Mgh,) or failed to perform, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) his promise, or the promise, to him: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) restricted to future time: (Mṣb:) AlUixolaAfu is, in respect of the future, like Alkacibu in respect of the past: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the making a promise and not fulfilling it: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) and some say that it signifies one's seeking an object of want, or water, and not finding it. (TA.) It is said in a trad., UicaA waEada Oaxolafa, i. e. When he promises, he does not fulfil his promise, and is not true [to it]. (TA.) [Hence,] Oaxolafati Aln-ujuwmu, i. e. ‡ [The stars broke their promise; meaning,] were attended with drought, not attended with rain: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) a saying of the people in the Time of Ignorance: (Ṣ, TA:) and so Aixotalafato↓ Eano OanowaAYihaA: for they used to believe and say that they were rained upon by such and such a nawoC. (TA. [See nawoCN.]) Hence also, Oaxolafati AlHum-aI † The fever, being tertian or quartan, came not in its time, or turn. (Mgh.) And Oaxolafato said of a she-camel, † She, having been covered by the stallion, did not become pregnant: (JK, TA:) and † she proved to be not pregnant when thought to be pregnant. (JK.) And in like manner said of a palm-tree; (JK;) ‡ It bore not one year: and ‡ it (a tree) bore no fruit: or lost the fruit that it had. (L, TA. [The verb, said of trees, has also another meaning, which see below.])
Axlfhu is also said, by El-Fárábee, to occur as meaning He acted according to his promise [or fulfilled his promise] to him; thus bearing two contr. significations: but this is strange. (MF.)
Also He found him to be a breaker of his promise; (JK;) or he found his promise to be broken, or unfulfilled. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Axlf Ealayoka and laka, each with an objective complement (xayorFA or maAlaka) expressed or understood: see 1, in six places, in the former half of the paragraph. You say also, Axlf fulaAnN linafosihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or ligayorihi, (TA,) Such a one replaced to himself, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or to another, (TA,) a thing that had gone from him, with another thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Ibn-Mukbil says,
faOaxolifo waOatolifo Uin-amaA AlmaAlu EaArapN
wakulohu maEa Ald-ahori Al-aciI huwa Mkiluho
[Then replace thou, and consume: wealth is but a loan: and devour it with time, which is a devourer thereof]: he means, gain a substitute for what thou hast consumed. (Ṣ, TA.) And the Arabs say to him who has put on a new garment, Oaboli waOaxolifo waQHomadi AlkaAsiI [Wear out thy garment, and replace it with another, and praise the Clother, meaning God]. (TA.)
And Oaboli wayuxolifu Qll-ehu [Wear out thy garment, and God will replace it with another; or, may God replace, &c.]. (Ṣ in art. blw)
See also Axlf Alv-awoba near the end of the first paragraph.

Axlf said of a plant, or of herbage, It put forth the xilofap, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) meaning leaves that come forth after the first leaves, in the [season called] Sayof; (TA;) and in like manner said of trees: (Mṣb, TA:) or Axlf AlX-ajaru means the trees put forth fruit after other fruit. (JK.) And, said of fruit, It came forth, some thereof after other thereof. (TA.) And Axlft AlOaroDu The land became affected by the cold of the latter part of the [season called] Sayof, and some of its trees consequently become green. (TA.)
Also, said of a bird, ‡ It put forth feathers after the first feathers: (Ḳ, TA:) from the same verb said of a plant, or of herbage. (TA.)
And, said of a boy, † He nearly attained to puberty. (JK, Az. Ḳ, TA.)
And, said of a solid-hoofed beast, † He completed a year after the quruwH [or finishing teething, or shedding the corner-nipper]. (JK.)
Axlfhu said of medicine, It weakened him (Ḳ, TA) by causing him to go frequently to the privy. (TA.)
And AlUixolaAfu also signifies The bringing the stallion again to the she-camel when she has not conceived at once. (Ḳ.)
See also 1, in six places, in the latter half of the paragraph.

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in two places, in the middle of the paragraph. [Hence, txl-fani AlOamori He held back from, or fell short of, doing the thing.]
6: see the next paragraph {8}, in three places.

hom.sense: 8. AixotilaAfN signifies The following reciprocally; or alternating. (Mgh.) So in the phrase in the Ḳur [ii. 159 and iii. 187 and xlv. 4], waQxotilaAfi All-ayolu waAln-ahaAri And the alternating of the night and the day. (Mgh) [And in a verse of El-ʼAjjáj cited voce OabolaI, in art. blw.] And hence the phrase, AixotalafaA DarobapF Each of them beat, or struck the other in turn. (Mgh.) And the saying, in a trad. of ʼAlee, faQxotalafato bayona Eubayodapa boni AlHerivi waAlwaliydi boni Euqobapa DarobataAni [And two blows were interchanged between ʼObeydeh Ibn-El-Hárith and El-Weleed Ibn-'Okbeh]. (Mgh.) And the saying, in a trad. of Umm-Sabeeyeh, Aixotalafato yadiI waydu rasuwli Qll-ehi fiI UinaMCK waAHidK, meaning My hand and the hand of the Apostle of God were both put [by turns] into one vessel. (Mgh.) And AixotalafuwA signifies They followed, or succeeded, one another; whenever one went, another coming after him. (TA in art. Ewr.)

Also The going, or moving, repeatedly, to and fro; so coming and going; or reciprocating; syn. tarad-udN [in this sense, as is shown in this art. in the Ḳ and TA, and in the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. rwd, &c.: and also as mean ing the returning, or repairing, time after time, or repeatedly, or frequently, to a person or place; because it implies coming and going: and sometimes it means simply the returning; because this cannot be without a previous going]. (Ḳ.) You say, huwa yaxotalifu UilaI fulaAnK, i. e. yatarad-adu [He returns, or repairs, time after time, repeatedly, or frequently, to such a one]: and Aixotalafa Uilayohi QxotilaAfapF waAHidapF [He returned to him once]. (TA.) And huwa yaxotalifu UilaI majaAlisi AlEilomi He repairs frequently to, or frequents, the assemblies of science; syn. yatarad-adu. (A in art. rd.) And Aixotalafa UilaI AlmutawaD-aOi [He returned, or repaired, time after time,, &c., to the privy]. (Ṣ.) And Aixotalafa UilaI AlxalMCi [properly signifies the same: and hence, † He had a looseness of the bowels, or a diarrhœa]. (Ḳ.) And [perhaps as implying coming and going,] Axtlf also signifies He supplied, or gave, or offered, water. (TA.)
