[Also The disagreeing, differing, or varying, in state or condition or quality, &c.; being dissimilar, different, diverse, various, incongruous, discordant, or dissentient:] Axtlf is the contr. of Ait-afaqa; (Ḳ, TA;) and is said of anything that is dissimilar [in the parts or members, &c. of which it is composed]; as also txAlf↓. (TA.) You say, txAlf↓ AlOamoraAni [and Axtlf AlAmrAn], i. e. lamo yat-afiqaA [The two things, or affairs, or cases, were, or became, dissimilar,, &c.]. (TA.) And AxtlfwA and txAlfwA↓ (Mgh, Mṣb) [They disagreed,, &c., fiI OamorK in a thing or an affair or a case;] every one of them took to, or held, a way, or an opinion, different from, or contrary to, that of another: (Mṣb:) both signify the same. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., saw-uwA Sufuwfakumo walaA taxotalifuwA fataxotalifa quluwbukumo [Make ye your ranks even when ye place yourselves to pray together, and be not dissimilar in your positions, for in that case your hearts would disagree]; meaning, when one of you advances, or stands, before another in the ranks, your hearts will be affected, and disagreement in respect of friendship and amity will arise among you: or, as some say, it means, your hearts will be made to recoil: or the Suwrap [or specific character] of your hearts will become changed into another Swrp. (TA.) [Hence,] Aixotalafato Eano OanowaAYihaA, said of stars: see 4, near the middle of the paragraph.

Also The being complicated, intricate, or confused. (KL.) [You say, Axtlf AlOamoru bayonahumo The affair, or case, was, or became, complicated, intricate, or confused, so as to be a subject of disagreement, or difference, between them: a phrase of frequent occurrence.]
Axtlfhu: see 1, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph.
See also 2, in two places.
Axtlf SaAHibahu: see 3, near the middle of the paragraph.
10. Astxlfhu: see 2, in two places.
Also He took it (a thing) as a substitute, or in exchange, for another thing; or in the place of another thing; syn. AisotaEowaDahu and Aisotabodalahu. (TA.)
Astxlfti AlOaroDu The land produced the herbage of the [season called] Aisotabodalahu. (TA.)
See also 1, in the middle of the latter half of the paragraph, in two places.

xalofN [meaning The location, or quarter, that is behind; and the time past;] (Ḳ; [so in my MṢ. copy, and thus it should be written as a simple noun; but in the CK xalofu;]) or Alxalofu; (Lth, Ḳ;) contr. of qud-aAmN [or Alqud-aAmu]: (Lth, Ḳ:) [and] xalofa [Behind; and after;] contr. of qud-aAma: (Ṣ: [thus in my tow copies; and said in the margin of one of them to be thus in the copy of IB, and in that of El-Jawáleeḳee:]) a simple noun: and an adv. n.: of the fem. gender [as meaning the jihap; but otherwise it seems to be masc.]. (TA.) You say, jaMCa xalofahu [and mino xalofihi, both meaning He came behind him, and after him]. (Mgh.) And jalasotu xalofa fulaAnK I sat after, or behind, such a one; syn. baEodahu (Ṣ.) And labiva xalofahu He remained after him. (Ḳ.) Some read, in the Ḳur [xvii. 78], waUicFA laAyalobavuwna xalofaka: others read xilaAfaka [which means the same, as mentioned above: see the middle of the first paragraph of this art.]. (TA.)

xalofN signifies also The back (Ḳ, TA) itself: so says IAạr: and particularly, of a house; the side corresponding to, or over against, that in which is the door; and as a house may have two doors, [in two different sides,] it may be said to have two backs, each of which may be thus termed; and the dual of this word seems to be used as meaning two backs in a trad. [respecting the building of the Kaabeh]. (TA.)

And One who comes after another; (Ṣ, TA;) as also xalafN↓, or, accord. to some, there is a difference between these two, as will be shown in what follows; (Ṣ;) and xaAlifN↓ and xaAlifapN↓: it is originally an inf. n.: (TA:) and signifies one who remains after another, whether this other be dead or living: and one remaining after another who is dead; his follower, or successor; the follower, or successor, of one who has gone: used in praise and in dispraise: pl. xuluwfN: and the sing. also signifies [like the pl.] persons remaining after others; accord. to some: (IB, TA:) a remnant of people: (Lḥ, TA:) and a generation after a generation; (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xalafN↓: (Lth, TA:) but Lth says that the former is applied to the evil, and ↓the latter to the good, (Ḳ, TA,) whether meaning a generation or a son: (TA:) the latter means a good son (Ḳ, TA) remaining after his father: (TA:) and the former, a bad son: (Ḳ, TA:) [therefore] one says, huwa xalofu sawoCK mino Oabiyhi [He is a bad son] who has taken the place of his father, and xalafu↓ SidoqK mn Abyh [a good son], &c.: (Ṣ:) but sometimes each is used in the place of the other; so that one says, hw xalofu SidoqK mn Abyh: (Ḳ:) or both signify the same: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so says Akh: some, he says, use the former; and some, the latter: but some say xalafu↓ SidoqK and xalofu sawoCK, meaning thus to distinguish between them: (Ṣ:) accord. to IB, xalafN↓ correctly signifies a man's successor who is a substitute for him, good and bad: and is originally an inf. n.: (TA:) and the pl. of this is OaxolaAfN: (AZ, IB, TA:) accord. to IAth, xalafu SidoqK means a good generation: and xalofu sawoCK, an evil generation: (TA:) and xalofN likewise signifies progeny [without restriction]. (Ḳ.) One says also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of a people following people more in number than they, (Ṣ,) heWulaMCi xalofu sawoCK [These are a bad generation.] (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And baqiynaA fiI xalofi sawoCK We remained among an evil remnant. (Lḥ, TA.) And faxalafa mino baEodihimo xalofN, in the Ḳur [vii. 168 and xix. 60], is explained as meaning And there remained after them a remnant. (TA.)
[Hence,] ‡ One in whom is no good. (IB, Ḳ.) [And app. also Persons in whom is no good..]

And ‡ A thing in which is no good: (IB, TA:) [and particularly] † a bad saying; (ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a wrong, bad saying, like the xalof of mankind. (AʼObeyd, Mṣb.) See also xulofN. It is said in a prov., sakata OalofFA wanaTaqa xalofFA † He held his tongue from a thousand words (sakata Eano Oalofi kalimap), and then uttered what was wrong. (ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb.) An Arab of the desert, who had been guilty of a breach of manners (Habaqa HaboqapF), pointed with his thumb towards his Aisot, and said, Uin-ahaA xalofN naTaqato xalofFA [which may be rendered, Verily it is a thing in which is no good: it uttered a thing in which was no good: but it obviously admits of being rendered otherwise]. (IAạr, Ṣ.)

Also People who have gone away from the tribe (T, Ḳ) to draw water, and have left their baggage, &c. behind them: (T, TA:) and such as are present, [remaining behind,] of the tribe: thus bearing two contr. significations: pl. xuluwfN. (Ḳ.) You say HaI-N xuluwfN A tribe who are absent; none of them remaining behind: (Ṣ, TA:) or a tribe of which the men are absent and the women remaining: (TA:) and xuluwfN also signifies the contr., i. e. such as are present, (Ṣ, TA,) remaining behind. (Ṣ.) It is said of Moḥammad, in a trad., lamo yatoruko Oaholahu xuluwfFA, i. e. He did not leave his family neglected, with no pastor nor protector. (TA.) See also a verse of El-Hoteíäh in the latter part of the first paragraph of this article.
Old and worn out; applied to a waTob [or skin for milk, or for clarified butter and milk: as though it were a remnant thereof]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
A mirobad; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. a place of confinement for camels: (TA:) or such as is behind the tent or house. (JK, Ṣ,* Ḳ.)

A large faOos [i. e. hoe or adze or axe]: or such as has one head: and the edge of a fOs: or the head thereof: (Ḳ:) you say faOosN caAtu xaloqayoni a two-headed fOs: (Ṣ, TA:) or caAtu xaloqayoni and caAtu xiloqayoni↓ are names of the fOs (Ḳ, TA) when two-headed: (TA:) and the pl. is cawaAtu Alxaloqayoni: (Ḳ:) pl. xuluwfN. (JK.)
And The head of a razor. (Ḳ.)

And The [pointed] head of a minoqaAr, [an iron instrument like the faOos, (A and Ḳ in art. nqr,) with which mill-stones, &c. are pecked, or wrought into shape, (see minoqaArN,) and] with which wood is cut. (TA.)
See also xilofN.

xulofN a subst. from UixolaAfN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) relating to a promise, and restricted to future time; (Mṣb;) i. e. a subst. used in the place of UixolaAfN; (Lḥ, TA;) meaning The breach, or non-fulfilment, of a promise; as also xulufN↓, which is said to be the original form of the word, and xuluwfN↓: (TA:) it is, in respect of the future, like kacibN in respect of the past: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) some say that it signifies a false, or wrong, saying; which is a meaning of xalofN↓, with fet-ḥ, before mentioned: but perhaps these two words may be syn. dial. vars. (MF, TA.)

Also, (Mṣb,) or xulofapN↓, and xilofapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) Disagreement, difference, dissension, contrariety, contrariousness, or opposition, (Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) in opinions or the like, (Mṣb,) or in respect of friendship and amity, (TA in explanation of the second of these words,) or in natural disposition; (Ḳ;) as also xilafonapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xilafonaApN↓ and xaAlifN↓ and xaAlifapN↓. (Ḳ.)
It is also pl. of xaliyfN, in its various senses.
xilofN: see xilofapN, in the latter half of the paragraph, in seven places.
Also, applied to a man, (Ṣgh,) i. q. lajuwjN [app. as meaning One who perseveres much in opposition or contention or the like]; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) as also xaAlifapN↓. (TA.)

The teat (Halamap) of the udder of the she-camel: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the two fore ones, and the two hinder ones: (Ṣ:) or the part of the udder upon which the milker lays hold: (TA:) or the extremity of the udder of the she-camel: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the hinder of the OaTobaMC [or teats]: (Ḳ:) or the udder itself; (Lth, TA;) [i. e.] it is, to the she-camel, (Mṣb,* Ḳ,) like the vadoI to the human being, (Mṣb,) or like the DaroE to the ewe or she-goat: (Ḳ:) or the xilof is of the camel and of the cloven-hoofed animal; and the TuboI, of the solid-hoofed animal and of the animal that has a claw: (Lḥ, TA:) the pl. [properly of pauc.] is OaxolaAfN (Mṣb, TA) and [of mult.] xuluwfN. (TA.) One says, dar-ato lahu OaxolaAfu Ald-unoyaA ‡ [The world yielded him abundance of its good things]. (TA.)

The shortest of the ribs of the side; (Ṣ;) [and] so xalofN↓; (Ḳ;) likewise called DilaEN Alxilofi and Alxalofi; it is the furthest and thinnest of the ribs; (TA;) [i. e.] the xilof is that next to the belly, of the small ribs; their quSayoraI: (Ḳ: [see AlquSoraI:]) pl. of the former (Ṣ) [and] of the latter (Ḳ) xuluwfN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
caAtu xilofayoni: see xalofN, near the end of the paragraph.

entry.sense: xalafN A substitute; a thing given, or received, or put, or done, instead of, in place of, or in exchange for, another thing. (AʼObeyd, Th, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) You say, AijoEalo hecaA xalofFA mino hecaA Make thou this to be a substitute for this. (Mṣb.) And hecaA xalafN mim-aA Ouxica laka This is a substitute for what has been taken to thee. (IB.) And fiI heWulaMCi Alqawomi xalafN mim-ano maDaI In these people are such as supply the place of those who have gone. (TA.) And fiI fulaAnK xalafN mino fulaAnK [In such a one is a substitute for such a one]. (TA.) And huwa mino Oabiyhi xalafN He is a substitute for his father. (IB.) See also xalofN, in six places, in the former half of the paragraph.

xalifN, applied to she-camels, i. q. maxaADN, i. e. Pregnant: n. un. with p {xalifapN}: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to some, (TA,) the pl. of xalifapN, which signifies a pregnant camel, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) or, as some say, one that has completed a year after bringing forth and has then been covered and has conceived, until she enters upon the term called Alt-aEoXiyr, (TA, [from-the time when her pregnancy has become manifest, (see qaAriHN and laAqiHN,)]) is maxaADN, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) like as the pl. of AimoraOapN is nisaMCN; (Mṣb, TA;) and sometimes xalifaAtN (Mgh, Mṣb, TA) and xilaAfN: (TA:) but xalifN occurs in the saying of the rájiz,
maA laka tarogiyna walaA taroguwA Alxalifo
[What aileth thee that thou utterest a grumbling cry, when the pregnant camels utter not that cry?]. (IB.)
xulafN: see xulofapN.
xulufN: see xulofN.
xalofapN: see the next paragraph, in two places.
xulofapN: see xulofN.

Also The last taste of food; (Ḳ;) as in the saying, Uin-ahu laTay-ibu Alxulofapi [Verily it is good, or sweet, in respect of the last taste]; (TA;) and so xalofapN↓: pl. xulafN: and it (xulofapN) signifies also loss of appetite for food, in consequence of disease: (so accord. to the CK:) [or,] accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, xalofapN↓ has this latter signification; and so xulafN↓: accord. to other copies, xulafN is pl of xalofapN in this sense: but both these readings require consideration: what is found in the Lexicons is, xalafato nafosuhu Eani AlT-aEaAmi, aor. _u {yaxolufu}, inf. n. xuluwfN; meaning as explained above, in the latter half of the first paragraph. (TA.)

hom.sense: xilofapN a subst. signifying A mode, or manner, of coming after [or behind]; like qiEodapN signifying “a mode, or manner, of sitting.” (Mṣb.)
See also xulofN.

It signifies also Difference [of any kind]: (Ḳ,* TA:) or the coming and going of the night and the day; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) and likewise of wild animals. (Ḳ.) Hence the saying in the Ḳur [xxv. 63], wahuwa Ql-aciI jaEala Qll-ayola waQln-ahaAra xilofapF, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) meaning cawaI xilofapK, (Bḍ,) i. e. [And He it is who hath made the night and the day] so that each replaces the other: or each follows the other: (Ḳ,* TA:) or so that he who is unable to accomplish a thing in the night may do it in the day, and the reverse. (Fr, L, Ḳ.) Zuheyr says, of wild animals, yamoXiyna xilofapF, meaning They go to and fro. (Ṣ, TA. [See Em p. 109.])
And one says, Oaxacatohu xilofapN, meaning He was taken with [an affection causing] a frequent going to and from the privy. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [And hence,] xilofapN signifies also, A discharging of the bowels; or a purging and vomiting together; (Ḳ;) or a disordered state of the stomach arising from [unwholesome] food; (TA;) a looseness, or diarrhœa. (JK, TA.)
See also xilofN.
Also The bringing of camels to the watering-place in the evening, after the people have gone away. (L, Ḳ.)

And A man's watching to see another, (Oano yunaAZira in some copies of the Ḳ, and An yunaASira in other copies, being put for An yubaASiru, which is the right reading, agreeably with an explanation of Aixotalafa SaAHibahu, [for which see 3, near the middle of the paragraph,] TA,) and when he is absent from his family, going in to them, (Ḳ, TA,) or [rather], when he is absent from his wife, going in to her. (TA, after the explanation of the phrase above mentioned.)
A thing that is suspended behind the rider; (JK, Ḳ;) such as is suspended behind the [kind of vehicle called] maHomil. (TA.)
Remains of water in a trough or tank. (TA.)
What remains, of food, between the teeth. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

A plant, or herbage, that comes forth after another plant, or other herbage, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which has become dry, and broken in pieces: (Ṣ, TA:) or that comes forth not from rain, but by reason of the cold of the latter part of the night. (Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilábee, Ḳ. [See also rabolN.])

What the trees disclose in the beginning of the cold, (Ḳ, TA,) by reason of the [rain called] Safariy-ap [q. v.]: (TA:) or fruit that comes forth after other fruit: (Ḳ:) or fruit that comes forth after abundant fruit; (Ṣ, Mgh, TA;) this being termed the xilofap of trees: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or a growth of leaves after the falling away of other leaves: (Ḳ,* TA: duwna in the Ḳ is a mistake for baEoda: TA:) or leaves that come forth after the first leaves, in the [season called] Sayof. (Nh, TA.)

What grows in the Sayof [or summer]; so says AʼObeyd: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, (JK, Mgh, Ḳ,) as also xilofN↓, (Ḳ,) the herbage produced by the Syf, (JK, Ḳ,) or in the Syf, (Mgh,) after the springherbage has dried up. (JK, Mgh.)

A produce of grape-vines after the grapes have turned black; the grapes being gathered while it is fresh and green, it then ripens: and so other fruits: or a new produce, by the vine, of fresh sour grapes. (Ḳ.)
Grain that is sown (JK,* Mgh, Ḳ *) after the former has come to maturity: (Mgh, TA:) because taken as a substitute for wheat and barley: (Ḳ:) pl. xilafN. (Mgh.)
A piece with which a garment is patched (Ḳ) when it is old and worn out. (TA.)
A time after a time. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

Differing [one from another or others]; as also xilofN↓: (Ḳ:) it is applied in this sense to a people, or company of men: (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and to beasts, or horses or the like, as meaning differing (Ḳ, TA) in their colours and appearances: (TA:) and xilofataAni is applied to any two things that are different; (Ks, TA;) as also xilofaAni↓: (Ks, Mṣb, TA:) and xilofapN, (Ḳ,) or xilofataAni, (Ks, TA,) to any two colours that are combined [because different]. (Ks, Ḳ, TA.) AZ cites, as an ex., the saying [of a rájiz],
dalowaAIo xilofaAni↓ wasaAqiyaAhumaA
[My two buckets are different, and their two suppliers with water]; (Ṣ, TA;) meaning that one of them [i. e. of the buckets] is ascending and full, and the other is descending and empty; or that one of them is new, and the other is old and worn out. (TA, in two places.) And one says of two children, or two male slaves; or two female slaves, that they are xilofataAni, (Ks, Ḳ,) and xilofaAni↓, (Ḳ,) applying to the male and the female, (TA,) meaning One tall and the other short: or one white and the other black. (Ks, Ḳ.) One says also, banuw fulaAnK xilofapN, meaning The children of such a one are half males and half females. (Ṣ.) And nitaAju fulaAnK xilofapN The offspring of the beasts of such a one are one year male and another year female. (JK, TA.) And waladato xilofayoni↓, said of ewe or goat, (Ḳ,) or of a camel, (L,) She brought forth one year a male and another year a female. (L, Ḳ.) The pl. [of xilofN↓] (Ḳ, TA) in all its senses (TA) is OaxolaAfN and xilafapN; (Ḳ,* TA;) the latter, [in the CK xilofapN,] like qiradapN as pl. of qirodN. (TA.)

entry.sense: xulofufN and xulofafN and xulofufapN and xulofafapN: see xaAlifN, in the latter half of the paragraph.
Oum-u xulofufK (Ṣgh, Ḳ) and xulofafN Calamity, or misfortune: or the greatest calamity or misfortune. (Ḳ.)
xilafonapN and xilafonaApN: see xulofN:
and see also xaAlifN, in the middle of the paragraph.

hom.sense: xilaAfN an inf. n. of 3 [q. v. passim]. (Ṣ, &c.)

Also The contrary, or opposite, of a thing; syn. Did-N. (Mṣb in art. Dd. [Very often used in this sense.]) You say, AlAixotilaAfu xilaAfu AlAit-ifaAqi [i. e. AlAxtlAf is the contrary of AlAt-fAq] (TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) by the vulgar (O, Mṣb, TA) incorrectly pronounced with teshdeed (O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and fet-ḥ [to the x, i. e. xal-aAfN], (TA,) A well-known kind of tree; (Ṣ;) the [kind of tree called] SafoSaAf: (Mṣb:) or a species of the SfSAf, but not the SfSAf itself: (Ḳ:) [the salix Aegyptia of Linnæus; called by this name in the present day; and by some, improperly, baAnN, q. v.:] it abounds in the land of the Arabs; and is [also] called sawojarN [or sawoHarN]; and there are many varieties thereof; all of them soft and weak; (TA;) but it is seldom, or never, found in the desert: (Mṣb:) they assert that it is thus called because the torrent brings it from one locality to another, so that it grows in a place different from that of its origin; (AḤn, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA;) but this is not a valid assertion: (TA:) [it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {xilaAfapN}. (Mṣb, TA.) suw-iyna mino xilaAfi, in the saying of the rájiz cited voce xuf-N, means Made of different trees: it does not mean of the tree called xilaAf; because this is seldom, or never, found in the desert. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also The sleeve of a shirt. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
xuluwfN: see xulofN.
It is also, as stated above, pl. of xalofN: (IB, Ḳ, TA:)
and a pl. of xilofN. (TA.)
xaliyfN: see xaliyfapN, in three places.
Also One who holds back from the place, or time, of promise: and one who breaks a promise. (TA.)
And A woman that has let down her hair behind her. (JK, O, Ḳ.)
And A woman that has attained to the period of one day, or two days, after her having brought forth. (IAạr.) [Perhaps from the signification next following.]

A she-camel in the second day after her having brought forth: pl. xulufN and xulofN: (Ḳ, TA:) these two pls. are mentioned in the Ḳ in different places in this art., but both are correct, like rusulN and rusolN. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) one says, rakibahaA yawoma xaliyfihaA [He rode her on the second day after she had brought forth]. (Ḳ.)

And The milk that is after the biestings: (AA, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.) One says also, HalabahaA xaliyfa libaYihaA He drew from her the milk that came after the biestings had passed away. (JK.) And AiytinaA bilabani naAqatika yawoma xaliyfihaA, i. e. [Bring thou to us the milk of thy she-camel of the day] after the cessation of her biestings; i. e., of the milking that is after her bringing forth by a day or two days. (AA, TA.)

Applied to a garment, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a shirt, (Mṣb,) Having the middle, wornout part taken out, and the [cut] edges then sewed together: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ *:) and maxoluwfN↓ signifies the same; (JK;) or a garment composed of two pieces sewed together: or, as some say, this signifies a garment pledged. (TA.)

Also, accord. to AʼObeyd, The part beneath the armpit: and the xaliyfaAni of the camel are like the UiboTaAni of man: accord. to the Ṣ and the O, xaliyfaA Aln-aAqapi signifies the two armpits of the she-camel (UiboTaAhaA): but the author of the Ḳ, following the [first] explanation given by AʼObeyd, says that this is wrong, and that the meaning is the parts beneath the two armpits of the she-camel. (TA.)
And A sharp arrow: (AḤn, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Skr, the word in this sense is HaliyfN, with the unpointed H; and this is more probably correct. (TA.)

entry.sense: xalaAfapN: see xulofapN.
xilaAfapN inf. n. of xalafahu as meaning “he was, or became, his xaliyfap” [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
[And hence, as a simple subst., The office of xaliyfap.]

xaliyfapN A successor: and a vice-agent, vicegerent, lieutenant, substitute, proxy, or deputy: (KL:) one who has been made, or appointed, to take the place of him who has been before him: (JK:) an act. part. n. of xalafahu, inf. n. xalafN and xilaAfapN; as also xaliyfN↓: (TA:) or it may have the meaning of an act. part. n. or that of a pass. part. n.: and so in the sense next following: (Mṣb:) the supreme, or greatest, ruler or sovereign, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) who supplies the place of him who has been before him; (TA;) [particularly the successor of the Prophet; whence “Caliph,” commonly used by English writers for “Khaleefeh;”] as also xaliyfN↓, (Ḳ,) which is the original form, (Mṣb,) without p; (Mṣb, TA;) disapproved by some, but mentioned by AḤát and Ibn-ʼAbbád and IB, and occurring in a verse of Ows Ibn-Hajar cited by IB: (TA:) the p in the former is to denote intensiveness of signification, (Nh, Mṣb, TA,) as in Eal-aAmapN and nas-aAbapN: (Mṣb:) or, as some say, liln-aqoli [i. e. for the transference of the word from the category of epithets to that of substs.]: (TA:) it is also said that the word may be an epithet of which the subst. qualified thereby is suppressed, for nafosN xaliyfapN; but this requires consideration: (MF, TA:) it is an epithet applied to a man peculiarly: (Mṣb:) some make it fem.; (Fr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) saying hecaA xaliyfapN OuxoraI [This is another Khaleefeh]; though the proper way is to make it masc.: (Mṣb:) a poet says,
Oabuwka xaliyfapN waladatohu OuxoraI
waOanota xaliyfapN caAka AlkamaAlu
[Thy father was a Khaleefeh, whom another Khaleefeh begat; and thou art a Khaleefeh: that is perfection]: (Fr, Ṣ:) the pl. is xalaAYifu [generally applied to any people that have succeeded others, and supplied their places, as in the Ḳur x. 15], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like as karaAYimu is pl. of kariymapN; (Ṣ;) and xulafaMCu [generally applied to successors of the Prophet], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) because, as it applies only to the male, and has p added, the p is dropped in forming the pl., which is thus like ZurafaMCu as pl. of ZariyfN: (Ṣ:) thus says ISk, and the like is said in the O: but what AḤát and Ibn-ʼAbbád say requires not this straining: (TA:) [i. e.] xalaAYifu is pl. of xaliyfapN; and xulafaMCu, of xaliyfN↓: (JK:) or some, having regard to the original, make the pl. to be xulafaMCu, like as XurafaMCu is pl. of XariyfN; (Mṣb;) and this pl. is masc. only, so that you say valaAvapN xulafaMCa: (ISk, Mṣb, TA:) and some, having regard to the word itself [in its altered and used state], make the pl. to be xalaAYifu; (Mṣb;) and this pl. may have prefixed to it either a masc. or a fem. n. of number, so that you say valaAvapN xalaAYifa and valaAvu xalaAYifa; (ISk, Mṣb, TA;) both of which are chaste. (Mṣb.) You say, kaAna Qll-ehu xaliyfapa waAlidika Ealayoka [May God be to thee a supplier of the place of thy father]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:*) and in like manner you say, to a person, of any one whom he has lost by death, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and who cannot be replaced; as the paternal uncle; (Mṣb;) or the mother. (Ḳ.) Some say that the application of the title xaliyfapu Qll-ehi [The Vicegerent of God] is not allowable, except to Adam and David because there is express authority in these instances [in the Ḳur ii. 28 and xxxviii. 25]; but others allow it in other cases, like suloTaAnu Qll-ehi and junuwdu Qll-ehi and Hizobu Qll-ehi and xayolu Qll-ehi; all of which have been heard: (Mṣb:) and Zj says that it is allowable to say of the Imáms that they are xulafaMCu Qll-ehi fiI OaroDihi [The Vicegerents of God in his earth]. (TA.)
xil-iyfapN: see the middle of the next paragraph.

hom.sense: xaAlifN: see xalofN, in the former half of the paragraph.

Also One who remains behind, or after, another, (Yz, Ḳ, TA,) or others, in the case of a war, or a warring and plundering expedition, and in other cases: (TA:) pl. xaAlifuwna (Yz, Ḳ, TA) and xawaAlifu, which latter is extr. [in this case], but is also said to be a [reg.] pl. of xaAlifapN↓, and as such to signify persons who do not go forth on a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition: and xaAlifapu↓ AlgaAziI signifies he who remains behind, or after, him who goes forth on such an expedition, being of his family. (TA.) faQqoEuduwA maEa AlxaAlifiyna, in the Ḳur [ix. 84], means Then stay ye with those who remain behind. (Yz, Ḳ.*) xawaAlifu is also pl. of xaAlifapN↓ [as fem. of xaAlifN], (TA,) and signifies Women (Ḳ, TA) remaining behind in the houses or tents: but some assign to it the first of the meanings explained above: and some say that it means the children remaining behind. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [ix. 88 and 94], raDuwA biOano yakuwnuwA maEa AlxawaAlifi↓, i. e. [They chose to be] with the women: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) thus it is explained by Ibn-ʼArafeh: but some say that the meaning is, with the bad, or corrupt, persons; and that xwAlf is here a pl. [of xaAlifN,] like fawaArisu. (TA.) For

xaAlifN is applied to a man [as meaning Bad, or corrupt]; and xaAlifapN↓ to a woman as meaning bad, or corrupt, and remaining behind in her abode: and the former to a slave as meaning bad, or corrupt: and also contrarious: and in this last sense it is likewise applied to a companion: and some of the grammarians say that there is no word of the measure faAEilN having its pl. of the measure fawaAEilu, except xaAlifN and haAlikN and faArisN: but see this last: (TA:) and xil-iyfapN↓, also, has this last signification; (JK, TA;) or [rather] signifies very contrarious; (Ḳ;) as also xaAlifapN↓; (JK;) and so xilafonapN↓, and xilafonaApN↓, (Lḥ, JK, Ḳ,) in each of which the n is augmentative, and each of which is applied to a man and to a woman and to a pl. number; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) but xilafonayaAtN has been mentioned as pl. [of xlfnAp], and as applied to males and females: (TA:) and xaAlifuwna is likewise used in this sense applied to a number of men. (JK.)

Also, applied to a slave, [and app. to any man, but in this latter case I find it written xlf, which I believe to be a mistranscription,] One who has withdrawn from the people of his house: so says Lḥ. (TA.)

Also Stupid; foolish; or having little, or no, intellect or understanding; as also xaAlifapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) but in an intensive sense, and also applied to a woman; (TA;) and Oaxolafu↓, (JK, Ḳ,) of which the fem. is xalofaMCu; (JK, TA;) and xulofufN↓, (Ḳ,) or xulofafN↓, (L,) or both, (JK,) likewise applied to a woman, as also xulofufapN↓, (Ḳ,) or xulofafapN↓: (JK:) or, as some say, xaAlifN signifies one in whom is no good: and, as also xaAlifapN↓, one who has not what suffices: or who often breaks his promises: (TA:) or both of these mean one who has not what suffices, and in whom is no good: or very contrarious. (JM.) One says that a man is xaAlifapu↓ Oaholi bayotihi and xaAlifu Ahl byth, meaning The one in whom is no good, of the people of his house: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the ungenerous: (Ḳ:) or the stupid, or foolish: or the bad, or corrupt, and the evil: and it is [said to be] tropical. (TA.) And qawomN xawaAlifN↓ Persons in whom is no good. (JK.)

And, [app. because he leaves his family behind him,] A drawer of water; (Ṣ, TA;) as also musotaxolifN↓ [q. v.]: both mentioned in the Ḳ; but Als-aq-aMCu is there erroneously put for AlmusotaqiI. (TA.)
And Weak, without appetite for food. (TA.)
And Flesh-meat from which a slight smell is perceived, but in the chewing of which is no harm. (Lth, TA.)
See also xulofN.

xaAlifapN: see xalofN, in the former half of the paragraph. Also, particularly, [or perhaps Oum-apN xaAlifapN only in this sense,] A nation, people, or race, remaining after another that has gone before. (I'Abbád, Ḳ.) And One who comes to the water after him who has returned [from it]: whence Aboo-Bekr applied this appellation to himself, from a motive of humility, when asked if he were the Khaleefeh of the Apostle of God. (IAth, TA.) See also xaAlifN, in eight places: and see its pl., xawaAlifu, in the same paragraph, in two places.
Also, applied to a man, [like xil-iyfapN as explained in the Ḳ,] Very contrarious, or adverse, and inimical. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.) See also xilofN.

maA OadoriI OaI-u xaAlifapa huwa, the word xAlfp being here imperfectly decl., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) because of the fem. gender and determinate, being explained by Aln-aAsi, (Ṣ,) or because determinate and occupying the place of a pl., like as one says OaI-u tamiyma and OaI-u Oasada, [or rather, I think, because used as a proper name, as MF, says, (though SM disputes this,) and with the sign of the fem. gender,] means I know not what one of mankind he is; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also OaI-u xaAlifapK, perfectly decl.; and OaI-u AlxaAlifapi; and OaI-u AlxawaAlifi; (Ḳ;) and so OaI-u xaAfiyapa; (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK AI- xaAlifapK again,]) imperfectly decl. (TA.) Lḥ says that AlxaAlifapu, writing it thus with Al, signifies Aln-aAsu. (TA.)
xawaAlifu, (Yz, Ḳ,) or xawaAlifu mina AlOaroDi, (TA,) Lands that produce not plants, or herbage, save among the last of lands. (Yz, Ḳ,* TA.)
See also xulofN.
Oaxolafu: see xaAlifN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

Also Contrarious, hard in disposition, as though going with a leaning towards one side: (Ḳ:) and [simply] leaning towards one side; applied to a camel: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so says AʼObeyd; (Ṣ, TA;) and so Aṣ. (TA.)

Also A camel that has the sheath of his penis slit, and that will not remain stationary, by reason of pain: (TA:) and maxoluwfN↓ signifies a camel having the sheath of his penis slit in the hinder part, (JK, TA,) when suffering suppression of his urine in consequence of the pressure of his hind girth upon his sheath: so says El-Fezáree. (TA.)
And Left-handed. (JK, Ḳ.)
And Squinteyed; syn. OaHowalu. (Ḳ.)
Accord. to some, (TA,) A torrent: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as some say, a river. (Skr, TA.)

And A male serpent. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) [All these meanings seem to have been assigned to the word as occurring in a verse of Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhalee, in which he likens the course of a wolf in a narrow road to the course of the Oaxolaf.]

[Also More, and most, wont to break promises. Hence the prov., mentioned by Meyd, Oaxolafu mino EuroquwbK More wont to break promises than 'Orkoob: a certain man who rendered himself notorious for breaking his promises. See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 454.]
[And More, and most, disagreeing, differing, dissentient, contrary, contrarious, or opposing. See an ex. in a prov. cited voce viylN.]
[And app. More, and most, offensive in the odour of the mouth. See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ubi suprà.]

entry.sense: taxaAliyfu Different colours. (TA.)
maxolafN: see maxolafapN.

muxolifN A camel that has exceeded in age the baAzil; [which latter is generally one that has entered the ninth year;] (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) beyond which there is no age [having an epithet to denote it]; therefore, (TA,) one says muxolifu EaAmK and muxolifu EaAmayoni [that has exceeded in age the bAzl by a year and by two years]; (Ṣ, TA; [see 4;]) applied alike to the male and the female; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and the female is also termed muxolafapN: (Ḳ:) or this latter signifies ‡ a she-camel that appears, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or is thought, (A,) to be pregnant, and is not pregnant: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) and the pl. is maxaAliyfu. (TA.)
See also mixolaAfN.
Also A man whose cattle have not obtained the [herbage termed] rabiyE. (JK.)
rajulN muxolifN mutolifN, or mixolafN↓ mitolafN, and mixolaAfN↓ mitolaAfN: see art. tlf.

nawomapu AlD-uHaI muxolifapN lilofami, (Ḳ, TA,) also written maxolafapN↓, and in some copies nawomu AlD-uHaI, [which requires the reading maxolafapN,] (TA,) i. e. [The sleep, or sleeping, in the period of the morning when the sun is yet low is] a cause of the mouth's becoming altered [for the worse] in odour. (Ḳ, TA.)
muxolifu janobK Having one half of his face and of his mouth turning sideways. (JK.)
See also the explanation of the verse of El-Hoteiäh cited in the last quarter of the first paragraph. The qaTaA are termed muxolifaAtN because they draw water for their young ones. (JK.)
mixolafN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: maxolafapN: see muxolifN.

See also xaliyfN, near the end of the paragraph. Almaxolafu↓ [as a coll. gen. n.] signifies The roads along which the people pass in Minè; (Ḳ) which are three: one says, AuTolabohu biAlmaxolafapi AlwusoTaI mino minFI [Seek thou him in the middle road of Minè]. (TA.) And maxolafapN baniI fulaAnK The place of alighting, or descending and stopping or sojourning or abiding or lodging or settling, of the sons of such a one. (Ḳ,* TA.) And maxolafapu minFI The place of alighting, or descending and stopping, &c., of the people in Minè. (Ḳ.)
A place in which are trees of the kind called xilaAf. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

mixolaAfN A man who often breaks his promises; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also muxolifN↓: (TA:) [whence the latter (which properly signifies simply breaking a promise) is applied to a star, or an asterism, as meaning ‡ Unattended with rain: (see 4:) and in the same sense to clouds (saHaAb): or, accord. to Freytag's Lex., in this or in the contr. sense.]
See also muxolifN.
And see maxolafaAn.

Also A kuwrap [i. e. province, district, or region] (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) pertaining to the people of El-Yemen, (Ṣ,) or in the dial. of El-Yemen; (Mgh, Mṣb;) pl. maxaAliyfu; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) every mxlAf thereof having a [distinctive] name whereby it is known; (Ṣ;) the mxAlyf of the people of El-Yemen being like the Oajonad of the people of Syria and the kuwar of the people of El-'Irák and the rasaAtiyq of the people of El-Jibál and the TasaAsiyj of the people of El-Ahwáz: (IB:) or mixolaAfN signifies a kuwrap (JK, M, Ḳ) to which a man comes; (M;) [in any country;] and hence the mxAlyf of El-Yemen, (Ḳ,) i. e. its kuwar: (TA:) some say that there is a mxlAf in every country; (Mṣb;) so says Khálid Ibn-Jembeh; (TA;) i. e. a naAHiyap [as meaning a district, &c.]; (Mṣb;) and thus one says the mxlAf of El-Medeeneh, and of El-Yemámeh, (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, TA,) and the mxAlyf of Et-Táïf: (AA, Mṣb, TA:) but properly it is peculiar to the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

Also i. q. bnkrd [a foreign word, and perhaps mistranscribed], i. e. The poor-rate of any particular people or party, which is given by them to [the poor of] their own community: so says Aboo-Mo'ádh: (L:) and maxaAlifu↓ [is its pl., as also, app., maxaAliyfu, agreeably with rule, and] signifies the poor-rates of the Arabs; (JK, TA;) [as in the saying,] AusotuEomila fulaAnN EalaI maxaAlifi baniI fulaAnK [Such a one was employed as collector of the poor-rates of the sons of such a one]. (JK.)
maxoluwfN: see xaliyfN:
and Oaxolafu.
Also A man affected with a looseness, or diarrhœa. (JK, TA.)

entry.sense: maxaAlifu: see mixolaAfN, last sentence.

hom.sense: maxaAliyfu: pl. of mixolaAfN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.)
Also Camels that have pastured upon fresh herbs, or leguminous plants, and have not fed upon dry herbage, and to which their pasturing upon the former has been of no avail. (IAạr, TA.)

entry.sense: qawolN muxotalifN [Discordant speech;] speech expressing different opinions. (Bḍ and Jel in li. 8.)
[TuruqN muxotalifapN Roads leading in different directions.]
musotaxolifN: see xaAlifN, near the end of the paragraph.
cahaba Almusotaxolifuwna yasotaquwna a saying mentioned by Lḥ as meaning Those going before [or leaving others in their places] went away to draw water. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. xaloqN signifies The act of measuring; or determining the measure, proportion, or the like, of a thing; and the making a thing by measure, or according to the measure of another thing; or proportioning a thing to another thing; syn. taqodiyrN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA, and Bḍ in ii. 19:) this is the primary meaning. (Mṣb, TA, and Bḍ ubi suprà.) You say, xalaqa AlOadiymi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxoluqu}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. xaloqN (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xaloqapN, (Ḳ,) He measured, or proportioned, (qad-ara,) the hide, and sewed it: (Ḳ:) or he measured, or proportioned, (qd-r,) the hide, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) limaA yuriydu [for, or to, that which he desired to make of it], (JK,* TA,) or lils-iqaMCi [for, or to, the skin for water or milk that he desired to make], (Mṣb,) before cutting it; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) he measured it (qaAsahu) to cut from it a water-bag, or a water-skin, or a boot: (TA:) and in like manner, xalaqa Aln-iTaEa he measured,, &c., the nTE [q. v.]: when one cuts it, one says, faraAhu. (Ḳ.) And xalaqa Aln-aEola He determined the measure of the sandal, or proportioned it; (qad-arahaA;) and made it by measure. (Ksh and Bḍ in ii. 19.) Hence the saying of Zuheyr, (Ṣ,) praising Herim Ibn-Sinán, (TA,)
walaOanota taforiI maA xalaqota wabaEoDu
Alqawomi yaxoluqu vum-a laA yaforiI
[† And thou indeed cuttest what thou hast measured; but some of the people measure, then will not cut]: (Ṣ, TA:) i. e., when thou determinest upon a thing thou executest it; but others determine upon that which they do not execute. (TA.) And El-Hajjáj said, maA xalaqotu Uil-aA qarayotu waEadotu Uil-aA wafayotu [† I have not measured unless I have afterwards cut, and I have not promised unless I have afterwards performed]. (Ṣ.) Oaxoluqu lakumo mina AlT-iyni kahayoYapi AlT-ayori, in the Ḳur iii. 43, means I will form for you, (Jel,) or I will make according to its proper measure (Ouqad-iru) for you, (Ksh, Bḍ,) and will form, (Bḍ,) of clay, a thing like the form of the bird, or of birds. (Ksh, Bḍ, Jel.)

[Hence,] it signifies also The bringing a thing into existence according to a certain measure, or proportion, and so as to make it equal [to another thing], or uniform [therewith]: (Ksh and Bḍ in ii. 19:) or the originating, or producing, [a thing] after a pattern, or model, which one has devised, not after the similitude of anything preexisting: this is another meaning which it has in the [classical] language of the Arabs. (TA.) As the act of God, it signifies The originating, or bringing into being or existence, anything, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing: (TA:) [and the creating a thing; and thus it is generally best rendered; as meaning the bringing into existence from a state of non-existence: for] xalaqa Qll-ehu AlX-aIoCa, inf. n. xaloqN, means God brought the thing into existence (Mgh,* TA) after it had not been: (TA:) [or xaloqN, as the act of God, signifies the creating out of nothing: for it is said that] OuEobuduwA rab-akumu Ql-aciI xalaqakumo, in the Ḳur ii. 19, means [Serve ye your Lord] who brought you into existence when ye were nothing. (Jel. [But in other passages of the Ḳur (vi. 2, &c.) it is said that God created (xalaqa) mankind of clay.]) Accord. to the A, xalaqa Qll-ehu Alxaloqa is a tropical phrase, meaning ‡ God brought into existence the creation, or created beings, or mankind, according to a predetermination (taqodiyr) required by wisdom. (TA.) You say, hecihi xaliyqatuhu Al-atiI xuliqa EalayohaA and xuliqahaA and Al-atiI xuliqa: see xuluqN. (Lḥ.)

[Hence, also,] xalaqa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. xaloqN, (TA,) ‡ He fabricated speech, or a saying or sentence, &c.: (Ḳ,* TA:) ‡ he forged (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) a saying, (Mṣb,) or a lie, or a falsehood; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also Axtlq↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and txl-q↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The Arabs say, Had-avanaA fulaAnN biOaHaAdiyvi Alxaloqi ‡ Such a one related to us fictitious tales or stories, such as are deemed pretty, or such as are told by night [for entertainment]. (TA.) And it is said in the Ḳur [xxvi. 137], accord. to one reading, Uino hecaA Uil-aA xaloqu AlOaw-aliyna, meaning ‡ This is nought but the lying, and forging, of the ancients. (TA.) And in the same [xxxviii. 6], Uino hecaA Uil-aA QxotilaAqN↓ ‡ This is nought but forging, and lying. (TA.)

xaluqato, inf. n. xalaAqapN, said of a woman, (JK, Ḳ,) She had [a goodly] body and make: (JK:) or she was, or became, goodly in make, or well made. (Ḳ. [In the CK, instead of Hasuna xaloquhaA, is put Hasuna xuluquhA, meaning She was, or became, good in nature,, &c.])

And xaliqa, aor. _a {yaxolaqu}, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. xalaqN; (JK, Ṣ;*) and xaluqa, aor. _u {yaxoluqu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xuluwqapN (TA) [and xalaAqapN, and perhaps xuloqapN q. v. infrà]; It (a thing) was, or became, smooth, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) and equable, or even. (TA.) [See also 12. And it seems that one says, xaliqati AlS-axorapu, inf. n. xalaqN, q. v. infrà, meaning The rock was free from crack or fracture.]

And xaluqa, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxoluqu}; (Ḳ;) and xaliqa, aor. _a {yaxolaqu}; and xalaqa, aor. _u {yaxoluqu}; (Ḳ;) inf. n. (of the first, JK, Ṣ) xuluwqapN (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and xalaAqapN (JK, TA) and [of the second] xalaqN (Ḳ) and [of the third] xuluwqN; (JK, TA;) It (a garment) was, or became, old, and worn out; as also Axlq↓, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. UixolaAqN; (JK, TA;) and Axlwlq↓. (TA.) [Hence,] Axlq↓ diybaAjuhu [lit.] His face became worn out; meaning ‡ it became used for mean service [so that it lost its grace, or was disgraced,] by his begging. (Ḥar p. 476. [See also 4 below.]) [Hence also,] Axlq↓ XabaAbahu † His youth declined, or departed. (TA.)

And xaluqa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxoluqu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xalAqapN, (Ḥam p. 522,) He was, or became, xaliyq, i. e. jadiyr [meaning adapted or disposed by nature, apt, meet,, &c.: see xaliyqN, below]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, xaluqa lcelika [and bicelika (see xaliyqN) He was, or became, adapted, disposed,, &c., for that]; as though he were one of those in whom that was reckoned to be, and in whom the symptoms, signs, or tokens, thereof were seen. (Ṣ.) [And xaluqa Oano yafoEala celika and biOano yfEl clk and liOano yfEl clk and mano Oano yfEl clk He was, or became, adapted,, &c., to do that: see xaliyqN. And xaluqa may signify also It was, or became, probable; or likely to happen or be, or to have happened or been: see, again, xaliyqN.]
2. xl-qhu: see 1, latter half, in two places.

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxoliyqN, (Ḳ,) He rubbed him over with xaluwq [q. v.]: (Ṣ:) or he perfumed him: (Ḳ:) or xl-qhu bixaluwqK he perfumed him with xlwq (TA.) And xal-aqotu AlmaroOapa biAlxaluwqi [I perfumed the woman, or rubbed her over, with the xlwq]. (Mṣb.) And xal-aqato jisomahaA She (a woman) rubbed her body and limbs over with xlwq. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. xaAlaqahumo, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaAlaqapN, (TA,) He consorted [or comported himself] with them (Ḳ, TA) according to their natures, or moral characters or qualities; (TA;) or with good nature, or moral character or qualities: (Ḳ:) or xAlqhm bixuluqK HasanK has this latter meaning. (TA.) One says, xaAliSi AlmuWomina waxaAliqi AlfaAjira, (Ṣ,) or wxAlq AlkaAfira, (TA,) [Act thou with reciprocal sincerity towards the believer, and comport thyself with the vitious, or the unbeliever, according to his nature,, &c. See also 3 in art. xlS, where a similar saying is mentioned.]

hom.sense: 4. Axlq: see 1, latter part, in three places.
Also He had old and worn-out garments. (TA.)

Axlqhu He wore it out; namely, a garment; the verb being trans. as well as intrans. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [Hence,] Axlq Ald-ahoru AlX-aIoCa † Time wore out, or wasted, the thing. (TA.) [Hence also,] one says to the beggar, Oaxolaqota wajohaka ‡ (TA) [lit. Thou hast worn out thy face;] meaning ‡ thou hast used thy face for mean service [so that it has lost its grace, or has become disgraced]: and in like manner one says, Ouxoliqu lahu diyabaAjatiI, i. e. wajohiI: and yuxoliqu diybaAjatayohi ‡ He uses his face for mean service by begging. (Ḥar pp. 15 and 476.)

Also, (Ḳ,) or Axlqhu vawobFA, (Ṣ,) He clad him with an old and worn-out garment. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And AxlqinI vawobahu He gave me his old and worn-out garment. (JK.) And some say, Axlqhu xalaqFA He gave him an old and worn-out garment. (TA.)

And UixolaAqN Alv-awobi also signifies The cutting out of the garment: whence the saying, to UmmKhálid, OaboliI waOaxoliqiI [Wear out, and cut out new]; or, as some relate it, waOaxolifiI, i. e., “and replace,” which is the more likely. (TA.)

maA Oaxolaqahu and Oaxoliqo bihi [have both of the following significations; though it is said that] the former signifies How likely is he, or it! (JK, TA;) and the latter, How well adapted or disposed, or how apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, or proper, or how worthy, is he, or it! i. q. Oajodiro bihi and OaHori bihi. (TA. [See 4 in arts. jdr and HrI.])
5: see 1, a little after the middle of the paragraph.

txl-q bigayori xuluqihi means He affected a xuluq [or nature,, &c.,] that was not his own. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And txl-q bikacaA He feigned such a thing, it not being in his nature, or not being created in him. (TA.) And txl-q liln-aAsi bimaA layosa mino nafosihi, occurring in a trad., [He affected, to men, a nature,, &c., that did not belong to him; or] he pretended [to men] that there was in his nature (fiI xuluqihi) that which was contrary to his real intention; (Mbr, TA;) or that which was contrary to what he had in his heart: the verb is similar to taSan-aEa and tajam-ala. (TA.)

txl-q bihi; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and txl-qt bh; (Mṣb;) He was, or became, rubbed over, (Ṣ,) or perfumed; (Ḳ;) and she was, or became, so; (Mṣb;) [or he rubbed himself over, or perfumed himself; and she did so;] with it; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, with xaluwq. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 8: see 1, latter half, in two places.

12. Axlwlq, said of the back (maton) of a horse, It was, or became, smooth; (Ḳ;) [like xaliqa and xaluqa; or very smooth; for] the verb is of a form intensive in signification. (TA. [See its part. n., maxolawoliqN, below.])
Said of a rasom [i. e. a trace, or a remain or relic marking the place of a house or the like and cleaving to the ground,] It was, or became, even with the ground. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Axlwlq Als-aHaAbu The clouds became equable, or uniform, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) their sides becoming conjoined; or, as some say, they became smooth; (TA;) and, (Ḳ,) or as some say, (Ṣ, TA,) they became adapted, or disposed, to rain; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as though they were rendered smooth: or they became collected together after separation, and prepared to rain. (TA.) And Axlwlqt Als-amaMCuOano tamoTura The sky was near, and likely, to rain. (TA.)
See also 1, latter part.

xaloqN inf. n. of xalaqa. (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) You say rajulN taAm-u Alxaloqi [A man complete, or perfect, in respect of make, or proportion,, &c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.* [See also xiloqapN.]) [In this and similar instances,] Alxaloq signifies The fashion of the outer man, and its [peculiar] qualities and attributes; like as Alxuluqu signifies “the fashion of the inner man,”, &c. (TA.)

Alxaloqu is also used in the sense of Almaxoluwqu↓ [meaning What is created; the creature]: (TA, and Bḍ in xxiii. 17, &c.:) [and, collectively, the creation; as meaning the beings, or things, that are created;] all created things: (Bḍ ubi suprà, &c.:) and [particularly] mankind; as also Alxliyqapu↓: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) and mankind and the jinn, or genii, and others: (Jel in lv. 9, &c.:) and Alxliyqapu↓ and [its pl.] xalaAYiqu signify the same: you say, humo xaliyqapu Qll-ehi and also humo xalqu Qll-ehi [They are the creatures of God]: Alxaloqu being originally an inf. n.: (Ṣ, TA:) and Lḥ mentions [an instance of its having a pl., in] the saying, laA waQl-aciI xalaqa Alxuluwqa maA faEalotu kacaA, meaning [No, by Him who created] all creatures, [I did not such a thing.] (TA.) In the saying, falayugay-irun-a xaloqa Qll-ehi, in the Ḳur [iv. 118, lit. And they shall alter the creature of God], some say that castration is meant: (TA: [and Bḍ includes, with this, other unnatural actions:]) or the meaning is, the religion of God; (Bḍ, Jel, TA;) accord. to El-Ḥasan and Mujáhid. (TA.) And laA tabodiyla lixaloqi Qll-ehi, in the Ḳur [xxx. 29], means, accord. to Ḳatádeh, [There shall be no changing, or altering,] of the religion of God. (TA.)
xaloqN also signifies Anything made smooth. (TA.) [See also muxal-aqN.]
xuloqN: see xuluqN, in four places.
xalaqu inf. n. of xaliqa: as such, signifying The being smooth [&c.]. (JK, Ṣ.*) [As such also,] in a rock, Freedom from crack or fracture. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[And, as such,] The being old, and worn out. (Ḳ.)

[Hence, used as an epithet,] Old, and worn out: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [and as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; meaning an old and worn-out garment or piece of cloth:] pl. xuloqaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OaxolaAqN. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.) And [as an epithet] it is masc. and fem.; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) because it is originally an inf. n., the inf. n. of Oaxolaqu meaning “smooth,” (Ṣ,) [or rather of xaliqa meaning “it was, or became, old, and worn out;” although it has pls.; and] IB mentions an instance of its dual, xalaqaAni: (TA:) Ks says, We have not heard them say, xalaqapN in any instance: (Lḥ, TA:) Fr says that it is without p [as a fem. epithet] because it was originally used as a prefixed noun; for one said, OaEoTiniI xalaqa jub-atika and xalaqa EimaAmatika [lit. meaning Give thou to me what is old, and worn out, of thy jb-p and of thy turban]; but Ez-Zejjájee says that this is nought. (TA.) You say vawobN xalaqN [An old and worn-out garment or piece of cloth], and miloHafapN xalaqN [an old and worn-out outer wrapping garment]: (Ṣ:) also rum-apN xalaqN [an old and worn-out piece of rope]: and daArN xalaqN [an old and decayed house]: and jisomN xalaqN [an old and wasted body]. (TA.) One says also vawobN OaxolaAqN, meaning A garment, or piece of cloth, altogether, or wholly, old and worn out; (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) every portion of it being xalaq; (Fr;) like as they said buromapN OaEoXaArN, &c.: (Ṣ:) and in like manner, mulaMCapN OaxolaAqN. (IAạr.) And Ks mentions the saying, OaSobaHato viyaAbuhumo xuloqaAnFA waxalaquhumo jududFA [Their garments became old, and worn out; and their old and worn-out garments became replaced by new]; with the sing. [in the latter clause] in the place of the pl. xuloqaAn: (TA:) or jududFA may be here put for jadiydFA. (L in art. jd.) In the phrase miloHafapN xulayoqN↓ [An outer wrapping garment that is a little, or somewhat, old, and worn out], the dim. is without p because it is [the dim. of] an epithet [applied without p to a fem. n.], and p is not affixed to the dims. of epithets [of this kind]: it is like nuSayufN dim. of naSafN an epithet applied to a woman. (Ṣ, Ḳ.* [See Lumsden's Arab. Gram. p. 623: but some of the grammarians consider these instances as anomalous.])

baAEahu biyEapa Alxalaqi, and bayoEa ciI Alxalaqi, the latter as used by a poet, [lit. He bought it, or sold it, (app. the former,) as one buys, or sells, the old and worn-out garment, like as we say “dogcheap,” and “cheap as dirt”], are phrases mentioned, but not explained, by IAạr, who cites the following saying:
Oaboligo fazaArapa Oan-iI qado Xarayotu lahaA
majoda AlHayaApi bisayofiI bayoEa ciI Alxalaqi [app. meaning Tell thou Fezárah that I have purchased for them life-long glory (lit. the glory of life), with my sword, as cheaply, i. e as easily, as one purchases the old and worn-out garment]. (TA.)
saHaAbapN xalaqapN: see the next paragraph.
xaliqN [part. n. of xaliqa].

xuluqN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xuloqN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) A nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like; syn. sajiy-apN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) and TaboEN; (Ḳ, TA;) of which one is created: (TA:) and xiloqapN↓ signifies [the same; i. e.] the fiTorapN [or nature,, &c.,] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) of which a man is created; (TA;) like [xuluqN and] xuloqN↓: (Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, xaloq:]) and xaliyqapN↓ [also] signifies [the same; i. e.] the TabiyEap [or nature,, &c.,] (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) with which a man is created: (TA:) the proper signification of xuluqN is [the moral character; or] the fashion of the inner man; i. e. his mind, or soul, and its peculiar qualities and attributes; like as xaloqN signifies the “fashion of the outer man, and its [peculiar] qualities and attributes:” it signifies also custom or habit [as being a second nature]: (TA:) and, as also xuloqN↓, [which is merely a contraction thereof, and therefore identical with it in all its senses,] manliness; syn. muruwoCapN: and religion: (IAạr, Ḳ:) the pl. is OaxolaAqN only: (TA:) [this is often used as signifying morals: and ethics:] and the pl. of xaliyqapN↓ in the sense explained above [said in Ḥar p. 193 to be that of xuluqN] is xalaAYiqN. (Ṣ.) It is said in a trad., layosa XaIoCN fiI AlmiyzaAni Oavoqala mino Husoni Alxuluqi [Nothing is heavier in the balance in which good and evil will be weighed than goodness of the moral character,, &c.] (TA.) And one says, hecihi xaliyqatuhu↓ Al-atiI xuliqa↓ EalayohaA and xuliqahaA↓ and Al-atiI xuliqa↓ This is his nature,, &c., of which he was created. (Lḥ.) And Uin-ahu lakariymu Alxaliyqapi↓ Verily he is generous in respect of nature,, &c. (AZ.) And SaAra celika lahu xuluqFA That became to him [a second nature, a habit, or] a thing to which he was habituated. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxvi. 137], Uino hecaA Uil-aA xuluqu AlOaw-aliyna This is nought but a custom of the ancients. (TA.) And in the same [lxviii. 4], waUin-aka laEalaI xuluqK EaZiymK And verily thou art of a great religion. (Jel, TA.) And in a trad. of ʼÁïsheh, kaAna xuluquhu AlqaroMna, meaning That whereto he clung was the Ḳur-án, with its rules of discipline and its command and its prohibitions, and the excellences and beauties and gracious things comprised in it. (TA.)
nawomapu Alxulqi [i. e. Alxuluqi or Alxuloqi↓] The sleep of midday, which was prescribed by the Prophet. (Ḥar p. 223. [See also HumoqN and xuroqN.])

xuloqapN Smoothness; (Ḳ, TA;) as also xuluwqapN↓ and xalaAqapN↓: (Ḳ:) but the second of these three, correctly speaking, [as also the third, accord. to analogy, and perhaps the first also,] is an inf. n. of xaluqa. (TA.)

xiloqapN [primarily signifies A mode, or manner, of xaloq, generally as meaning creation; a particular make: and hence,] constitution; syn. tarokiybN: (Mgh:) [and particularly the natural constitution of an animated being, as created in the womb of the mother; also termed fiTorapN:] see also xuluqN. You say rajulN Hasanu Alxiloqapi [A man goodly, or beautiful, in respect of make]. (A, TA.) fiI masolakK huwa xiloqapN means fiI TariyqK xiloqiI-K↓ OaSoliI-K [In a way, or road, that is natural, and original]. (Mgh.)
xalaqapN: see xaliqN.

xiloqiI-N Natural; not accidental: [constitutional: of, or relating to, or belonging to, the natural constitution of an animated being, as created in the womb of the mother:] rel. n. of xiloqapN. (Mṣb.) You say EayobN xiloqiI-N A natural fault or imperfection, &c. (Mṣb.) And SifapN xiloqiy-apN [A natural quality]; opposed to QxotiyaAriy-apN. (Mṣb in art. mdH.) See also xiloqapN.
xalaqiI-N One who wears old and worn-out clothes. (TA.)
xuloqaAniI-N A seller of old and worn-out clothes. (TA.)

xalaAqN A share, or portion: (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb:) and a good, just, or righteous, share or portion: (JK:) or a full, a complete, or an abundant, share or portion of good, (Ḳ, TA,) and of goodness, or righteousness: (TA:) and religion: or a share, or portion, thereof. (TA.) One says, laA xalaAqa lahu fiI AlMxirapi There is no share, or portion, [of good] for him in the final state of existence. (Ṣ. [See the Ḳur iii. 71, &c.]) And laA xalaAqa lahu He has no desire for good, nor righteousness in religion. (TA.)
xilaAqN: see the next paragraph.

xaluwqN A certain species of perfume; (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) also termed xilaAqN↓; (Lḥ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) accord. to some of the lawyers, (Mṣb,) fluid, (Mgh, Mṣb,) but of thick consistence; (L, voce naDoxN;) and in which is a yellowness: (Mgh, Mṣb:) it is composed of saffron and other things; and redness and yellowness are predominant in it: it is forbidden [to men], because it is of the perfumes of women, who use it more than do men. (TA.)

xaliyqN, applied to a man, (Ṣ, TA,) Perfect, or complete, in make; (TA;) as also muxotalaqN↓: (Ḥam p. 561:) or perfect, or complete, in make, and just in proportion; (Ṣ, TA;) and so ↓the latter; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, muxotaliq; in the TA expressly said to be of the pass. form;]) fem. of the former with p {xaliyqapN}: (TA:) or ↓both signify goodly, or beautiful, in make: or the former is not applied to a man; but ↓each, with p, signifies a woman having [a goodly] body and make: (TA, in which this signification is said to be tropical:) and xaliyqN and xaliyqapN are alike, (JK, TA,) accord. to Lḥ, (TA,) in this last sense: (JK:) or the former of these two may be pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of the latter, like as XaEiyrN is of XaEiyrapN: (TA:) and muxotalaqN↓ signifies anything just in proportion: (IF, TA:) muxal-aqN↓, also, signifies perfect, or complete, in make; applied to a camel (jml): (TA:) [or jml, here may be a mistranscription for Hamol; for] muDogapN muxal-aqapN↓ signifies [a fœtus when it has become like a lump of flesh] perfect, or complete, in make; (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) so in the Ḳur xxii. 5; (Fr, TA;) or of which the make has become apparent. (IAạr, TA.)

Also Adapted or disposed [by nature], apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, competent, or worthy; (KL, PṢ;) syn. jadiyrN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and HariI-N (TA) [and HaqiyqN, &c.: pl. xulaqaMCu, and Freytag adds xuluqN]. You say, fulaAnN xaliyqN likacaA, i. e. jadiyrN bihi [Such a one is adapted or disposed by nature,, &c., for such a thing]; as though he were one of those in whom that was reckoned to be, and in whom the symptoms, signs, or tokens, thereof were seen. (Ṣ.) [And huwa xaliyqN liloxayori He is adapted or disposed by nature to good; i. e., to be, or to do, or to effect, or to produce, what is good.] And Uin-ahu laxaliyqN Oano yafoEala celika and biOano yfEl clk and liOano yfEl clk and mno Oano yfEl clk [Verily he is adapted or disposed, &c. for doing that; or worthy to do it]: so says Lḥ: and he adds that the Arabs say, yaA xaliyqu bicelika, using the nom. case; and yaA xaliyqFA bicelika, using the accus. case; [the latter being the usual form; both meaning O thou who art adapted or disposed, &c. for that;] but ISd says, I know not the reason of this. (TA.) And hecaA maxolaqapN↓ licaAka, i. e. majodarapN lahu [This is one that is adapted or disposed, &c. for that]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) and hecaA AlOamoru maxolaqapN↓ laka [This affair, or thing, is one that is adapted, &c. for thee]: and Uin-ahu maxolaqapN↓ mino celika [Verily it is adapted, &c. for that]: like majodarapN and maHoraApN and maqomanapN: and in like manner one says of two, and of more than two, and of a feminine: so says Lḥ. (TA.) [maxolaqapN↓ properly signifies A place, and hence a thing, an affair, and a person, adapted or disposed, &c.: it is of the same class as maEosaApN and maZin-apN and maYin-apN.] xaliyqN also signifies Habituated, or accustomed. (PṢ, TA.*) And one says, Uin-ahu laxaliyqN, i. e. laHariI-N, meaning Verily it is probable; or likely to happen or be, or to have happened or been. (TA.) And huwa xaliyqN lahu He, or it, is like to him, or it. (JK, TA.)
saHaAbapN xaliyqapN: see xaliqN.
[See also xaliyqapN, which, in several senses, is a fem. epithet used as a subst.]
xulayoqN: see xalaqN (of which it is the dim.), in the latter half of the paragraph.
xalaAqapN: see xuloqapN.
xuluwqapN: see xuloqapN.
xaliyqapN: see xaloqN, in two places.

Also The beasts, or brutes. (En-Naḍr, Ḳ.) The saying, respecting the xawaArij [a sect of heretics, or schismatics], humo Xar-u Alxaloqi waAlxaliyqapN is explained by En-Naḍr as meaning [They are the worst of mankind and] of the beasts, or brutes. (TA.)

And A well (biYorN) just dug: (AA, Ḳ:) or a well in which is no water: or a hollow, cavity, pit, or hole, formed by nature in the ground: or a small hollow or cavity, in a mountain, in which water remains and stagnates: accord. to IAạr, xlq [app. xuluqN, pl. of xaliyqapN, like as mudunN and SuHufN are pls. of madiynapN and SaHiyfapN,] signifies wells recently dug. (TA.)
And Land (OaroDN) that is dug. (TA.)
See also xuluqN, in four places.
xulayoqaMCu [dim. of xaloqaMCu fem. of Oaxolaqu]: see Oaxolaqu, in three places.

hom.sense: xalaAYiqu [pl. of xaliyqapN].

AlxalaAYiqu i. q. HamaAYiru AlmaMCi, i. e. Four large and smooth masses of stone at the head of the well, upon which the drawer of the water stands. (TA.) Accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, HawoDN baAdiI AlxalaAYiqi means [A watering-trough of which] the [stones termed] naSaAYib [appear]. (JK, TA. [See naSiybapN.])

entry.sense: xul-aqN: see Oaxolaqu.
xal-aAqN: see the next paragraph.

xaAliqN [act. part. n. of xalaqa:] A worker in leather and the like; (Ḳ, TA;) because he measures first, and then cuts. (TA.) To xaAliqaAt, meaning Women working in leather, as engaged in dividing a hide (Oadiym), El-Kumeyt likens genealogists. (TA.)

AlxaAliqu, as an epithet applied to God, (Ḳ, Mṣb, TA,) properly, He who brings into existence according to the proper measure, or proportion, or adaptation; (TA;) [and hence, the Creator; or] the Originator, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing: (Ḳ:) or He who hath brought into existence all things after they had not been in existence: (Az, TA:) and Alxal-aAqu↓ signifies the same; (Mṣb,* TA;) [i. e. the Creator of all things; or, as an intensive epithet, the Great Creator;] or the Creator of many creatures: (Ksh and Bḍ and Jel, in xxxvi. 81:) Az says that this epithet, with the article Al, may not be applied to any but God. (Mṣb.) Accord. to IAmb, tabaAraka Qll-ehu OaHosanu AlxaAliqiyna means AHsn Almuqad-ariyna [i. e. Blessed be God, the Best of those who make things according to their proper measures, or proportions, or adaptations]. (TA.)

xawaAliqu [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Smooth mountains: so in the saying of Lebeed,
waAlOaroDu taHotahumo mihaAdFA raAsiyFA
vabatato xawaAliquhaA biSum-i Aljanodala
[And the earth beneath them a firm expanse; its smooth mountains being rendered fast by hard and solid stones]. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, bDam-i is erroneously put for biSum-i.])

hom.sense: Oaxolaqu Smooth: (JK, Ḳ:) smooth and solid; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) applied in this sense to anything: (TA:) smooth and firm: (JK:) fem. xaloqaMCu. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say HajarN Oaxolaqu Stone that is smooth (Ḳ, TA) and solid, upon which nothing makes an impression. (TA.) And SaxorapN xaloqaMCu A rock, or great mass of stone, smooth (Ḳ, TA) and solid: (TA:) or free from crack and fracture. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And firosinN xaloqaMCu A camel's foot in which is no crack. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) And haDobapN xaloqaMCu [A hill, or the like,] destitute of herbage or vegetation. (TA.)

[Hence,] † Poor; syn. faqiyrN. (Ḳ.) You say rajulN Oaxolaqu mina AlmaAli † A man destitute of property. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., layosa Alfaqiyra faqiyru AlmaAli Uin-amaA Alfaqiyru AlOaxolaqu Alkasobi, i. e. † [The poor in respect of property is not the poor the poor is only] he who has no good deeds for which he will be rewarded in the world to come. (TA, in two places.)
AlOaxolaqu also signifies The exterior of a horse's hoof. (JK.)
And xaloqaMCu, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) applied to a woman, (JK, Ṣ,) Impervia coëunti; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also xul-aqN↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
See also xaliqN.
And AlxaloqaMCu [used as a subst.] The sky; because of its smoothness and evenness. (TA.)
And The side of a camel, &c. (Ḳ.) One says also, Darabotu xaloqaMCa janobihi (Ḳ, TA [in the CK ElI xaloqaACa janobihi]) I struck the outer part of his side. (TA.)

And The interior (Lth, Ḳ, TA) and smooth part (Lth, TA,) of the gaAr, (Ḳ,) i. e., of [the upper part of the interior of the mouth, or] what is termed AlgaAru AlOaEolaI; (Lth, TA;) as also AlxulayoqaMCu↓ [the dim. of AlxaloqaMCu]: (Lth, Ḳ, TA:) or both signify what appears of the gAr: and the dim. form is that which is predominant in this case. (TA.)

And The part of the forehead that is even (JK, Ḳ, TA) and smooth; (TA;) as also AlxulayoqaMCu↓. (JK, Ḳ, TA.) One says, suHibuwA EalaI xaloqaAwaAti jibaAhihimo [They were dragged along upon the even and smooth parts of their foreheads]. (TA [in which this is said to be tropical])

xulayoqaMCu↓ Alfarasi That [part] of the horse which is like the Eironiyn [or upper part of the nose] of man; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the part where the forehead of the horse meets the narrow portion of the bone of the nose: AO says that the xulayoqaAwaAni in the face of the horse are [the two parts] where his forehead meets the bone of his nose, on the right and left of the xulayoqaMC, sloping towards the eye; and the xulayoqaMC is [the part] between the eyes; and some call it the xaloqaMC. (TA.)
Uin-a Oaxolaqa bika Oano tafoEala kacaA is a phrase mentioned by Ks, as meaning Verily the most apt, meet, suitable, fit, or proper, thing for thee to do is such a thing. (TA.)

entry.sense: maxolaqapN: see xaliyqN, in four places, in the latter half of the paragraph.
muxal-aqN: see xaliyqN, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph.
Also, applied to an arrow, Made smooth (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and even. (TA.) [See also xaloqN, last signification; and muxotalaqN.]
maxoluwqN [pass. part. n. of xalaqa. When used as a subst., signifying A creature, or created thing, its pl. is maxoluwqaAtN]. See xaloqN.
qaSiydapN maxoluwqapN ‡ [An ode that is forged; or] ascribed to a person not its author. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.)
muxotalaqN: see xaliyqN, first sentence, in five places.
Also Made smooth. (TA.) [See also muxal-aqN.]
And Generous in [nature, or] natural dispositions. (Ḥam p. 561.)
muxotalaqN lilomuloki, in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh, means Created of a nature fitting for dominion: (Ṣ, TA:) and so liloOaSoHaAbi [for companions]; as in a verse of Ibn-Aḥmar. (TA.)
muxolawoliqN Very smooth; its measure being one of those that denote intensiveness. (Ḥam p. 358.)

xalanojN a Persian word, arabicized, (Ṣ,) A kind of tree, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the wood of which vessels are made: (TA:) or any [bowl of the kinds called] jafonap and SaHofap, or other vessel, made of wood having variegated streaks: (L:) pl. xalaAniju. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The word is mentioned [in the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. xlj; but] in the L and some other lexicons in a separate art., because all the letters of a word which is not Arabic are regarded as radical. (MF.)

hom.sense:
1. xalaA, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaxoluw, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. xuluw-N, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or xalaMCN, (Mṣb,) or both, (Ḳ,) said of a place, (Ḳ,) of a place of alighting or abode, (Mṣb,) and of a thing, (Ṣ, TA,) It was, or became, empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; (Ḳ, TA;) had none, and nothing, in it; (TA;) as also AxlI↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AstxlI↓, (Ḳ.) [xalaA AlmakaAnu mina Aln-aAsu waAlmaMCi waAlkalaO means The place was, or became, devoid, or destitute, of human beings and water and herbage or pasturage; without human beings, &c.] Of a place of alighting or abode, you say, xalaA mino Oaholihi and AxlI↓ [It was, or became, devoid, or destitute, of its occupants]. (Mṣb.) And of a vessel, xalaA mim-aA fiyhi It was, or became, empty of what was in it. (Mgh.) And xalawotu Eani AlT-aEaAmi (Ṣ) I became empty, in the belly, of food; (PṢ;) and Oaxolayotu↓ Eanohu signifies the same. (Ṣ.) And xalaA min AlEayobi, (Mṣb,) or Eani AlOamori, and minohu, (Kudot;,) inf. n. xuluw-N, He was, or became, free (Mṣb, Ḳ) from fault, (Mṣb,) or from the thing, or affair: (Ḳ:) and, accord. to IAạr, xlA alone signifies he was, or became, free from a fault, or the like, of which he was accused, or suspected. (TA.) And xalato Eano maAniEi Aln-ikaAHi, inf. n. xuluw-N, is said of a woman [as meaning She was, or became, free from any obstacle to marriage]. (Mṣb.) Accord. to the Ḳ, xalaA makaAnuhu [lit. His place became vacant] means ‡ he died: but accord. to IAạr, xalaA alone has this signification [from the same verb signifying maDaI. explained below]: and if you add mkAnh, you say xal-aI, with teshdeed; which see below. (TA.) You say also, xalaA laka AlX-aIoCu and AxlI↓, both signifying the same, (AA, Ṣ, TA,) i. q. faraga [i. e. The thing was, or became, vacant, or unoccupied, for thee: (see an ex. of the former verb in a saying of Tarafeh cited voce jaw-N:) and hence, the thing was, or became, exclusively for thee]. (TA.) AA cites as an ex. the saying of Maan Ibn-Ows,
OaEaAcilu halo yaOotiI AlqabaAYila HaZ-uhaA
mina Almawoti Oamo OaxolaI↓ lanA Almawotu waHodanaA
[O censurer, does their share of death come to the tribes in common, or is death exclusively for us alone?]. (Ṣ, TA.) See also the paragraph, below, commencing with xalaA as a word denoting exception.

[Hence,] xalaA and AxlI↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) said of a man, (TA,) or the same two verbs followed by binafosihi, said of a man, (Mṣb,) both signify the same; (Ṣ;) He was, or became, [without any companion, i. e.] alone, by himself; (Mṣb;) or he became (waqaEa [q. v.]) in a vacant place, in which he was not pressed against, or straitened. (Ḳ.) And xalaA bihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Uilayohi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and maEahu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xalowapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xalaMCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xalowN, (Ḳ, TA,) or xuluw-N, (CK,) or the first of these, i. e. xalowapN, is a simple subst., and the second and third are the inf. ns.; (TA;) and AxlI↓ bihi, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) and AxlAhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AstxlI↓ bihi; (Ḳ; [the last omitted in the CK;]) He was, or became, alone with him; (Mṣb;) he was, or became, in company with him, or he met him, or had a meeting or an interview with him, in a vacant place, or a place unoccupied [by others, i. e., in a private place]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) In the saying in the Ḳur [ii. 13], waUicaA xalawoA UilaI XayaATiynihimo, it is said that UilaI is used in the sense of maEa, [so that the meaning is And when they are alone with their devils,] as in that other saying in the Ḳur [iii. 45 and lxi. 14], mano OanoSaAriI UilaI Qll-ehu. (Ṣ.) A man says to another man, Auxolu maEiI Hat-aI Oukal-imaka, i. e. Be [or come] thou alone with me [that I may speak to thee in private]. (TA.) And one says, xalaA bizawojatihi, inf. n. xalowapN, [but see what is said of this noun above,] He was, or became, alone with his wife: but [properly speaking, according to the law,] the term xalowapN [or xalowapN SaHiyHapN, in this case,] is not used unless it be with the enjoyment of AlmufaAxacap, [see 3 in art. fxc,] and then it has an effect upon the circumstances of the marriage [by its rendering obligatory the payment of the dowry, though consummation has not taken place]: if with consummation, the act is termed duxuwlN. (Mṣb.) You say also, Oaxoli↓ Oamoraka and biOamorika Be thou alone in thine affair, with none to take part with thee in it; confine thyself to it exclusively of other things. (TA. [See also 5.]) And Oaxoli↓ Uilayoka Keep thou to thine affair, and be alone in it, with none to take part with thee therein. (JK.) And AstxlI↓ AlbukaMCu [app. for biAlbukaMCi] He was, or became, alone in weeping, with none to participate with him in it. (TA.) [And xalaA liloOamori: see 5.] And xalaAEalaI baEoDi AlT-aEaAmi He restricted himself to a portion of the food. (Ḳ.) Temeem say, xalaA fulaAnN EalaI All-abani waAll-aHomi (JK,* TA) i. e. Such a one fed upon milk and flesh-meat alone; (JK;) or such a one ate not, nor mixed, anything with milk and flesh-meat: and Kináneh and Keys say OaxolaI↓. (Lḥ, JK,* TA.) [And it seems to be indicated in the T that xalawoA signifies They selected a she-camel for a xaliy-ap, q. v.: or i. q. taxal-awoA bixalay-ipK: see 5.]

And xalaA bihi [sometimes] signifies ‡ He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, him: (Lḥ, Ṣ, Z, Ḳ, TA:) said by Az to be strange, and not known by him or any other authority than that of Lḥ: (TA:) from the saying, xalaA fulaAnN biEiroDi fulaAnK yaEobavu bihi [Such a one occupied himself alone with the honour, or reputation, of such a one, making sport with it]. (Ksh in ii. 13.) And i. q. xaAdaEahu ‡ [He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him;, &c.: or he strove to do so]: (TA:) as also xAlAhu↓, (JK, and Ḳ in art. xlI,) inf. n. muxaAlaApN. (JK.)
And xalaA Ealayohi He relied upon him; [as though he betook himself to him alone;] syn. AiEotamada. (TA.)

And xalaA, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. xuluw-N, (TA,) or xalaMCN, (JK,) said of a man (JK) and of a thing, (JK, TA,) He, or it, went, went away, or passed away. (JK, Ḳ.) Hence, (TA,) waUino mino Oum-apKUil-aA xalaA fiyhaA naciyrN, in the Ḳur [xxxv. 22], means [And there is not any people but a warner] hath gone, and hath been sent, among them. (Ṣ, TA.) [Hence also xalaA explained above as meaning He died.] And xalaA minohaA [an elliptical phrase] She became old; the greater part of her life passed. (TA from a trad.) And xalaAka cam-N [for xalaA Eanoka cam-N] Blame passed away from thee; or may blame pass away from thee. (Ksh and Bḍ in ii. 13.) You say, AifoEalo kacaA waxalaAka cam-N Do thou such a thing, and thou wilt have an excuse; [i. e.] blame will fall from thee. (Ṣ. [See art. cm.]) And xalaAhu AlHuzonu Grief passed away from him, and quitted him. (Ḥar p. 590, from the Tekmileh.)
xalaA Eani AlX-aIoCi: see 2.
xalaA [or xalaI, probably belonging to art. xlI, though mentioned in the present art.,] He ate what was good, sweet, or pleasant. (TA.)

2. xal-aI, inf. n. taxoliyapN, [He left a place, &c., empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied.] Hence, xl-I makaAnahu [He left his place vacant;] meaning ‡ he died: (TA, and so in Ḥam p. 478:) a meaning assigned in the Ḳ to xalaA↓ makaAnuhu, and by IAạr to xalaA alone, without teshdeed; but when mkAnh is added, it is with teshdeed. (TA.) And † He went his way. (Ḥam p. 379.) And xl-I sabiylahu [He left his way free, or open, to him]. (Ṣ, TA.) And xl-I bayonahumaA [He left the way, or space, free between them two; meaning he left them two free, each to do to the other as he pleased]. (TA.) [And xl-I bayonahu wabayona kacaA He left him free access to such a thing.] And xl-I bayonahu wabayona nafosihi He left him, or it, alone; syn. Oahomalahu. (Ṣ and O and Ḳ in art. hml.) [And xl-Ahu wafulaAnFA He left him to do as he pleased with such a one.] And xl-I AlOamora He left, left alone, or let alone, the thing, or affair; as also txl-I↓ minohu and Eanohu; and xAlAhu↓, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. xilaMCN. (TA.) For taxoliyapN signifies The leaving, and making a thing to be alone. (Ḥar p. 123.) [xl-Ahu and xl-I Eanohu both signify He left, or left alone, it, or him.] It is said in a trad., xl-I Eanohumo OarobaEiyna EaAmFA He (God) left them, or left them alone, and turned from them, forty years. (TA.) [And xl-Ahu likacaA He made him, or left him, vacant, unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure, for such a thing.]

taxoliyapN also signifies The act of loosing; contr. of Xad-N. (IAạr, Ḳ in art. AbD.) [Hence,] xl-I Eani AlX-aIoCi, (JK, Ṣ,* TA,) in the Ḳ xalaA↓, without teshdeed, but this requires consideration, (TA,) He dismissed, loosed, let loose, or let go, the thing. (JK, Ḳ, TA.)
[And hence xl-Ahu meaning He left it, permitted it, or allowed it: see the pass. part. n., below.]
xul-iyato, said of a she-camel such as is termed xaliy-ap; and hence, of a cooking-pot: see 1 in art. xlI.

entry.sense: 3. xAlAhu He left, forsook, relinquished, abandoned, deserted, or quitted, him, being left,, &c., by him; namely, another man; syn. taArakahu; (Ṣ;) inf. n. muxaAlaApN, syn. with muwaAdaEapN, (JK,) [and xilaMCN also: and he was, or became, distant, remote, far off, aloof, or apart, from him; for] xilaMCN is syn. with mubaAEadapN and mujaAnabapN (TA in art. xlO) and furoqapN. (TA in the present art.) And xAlI AlOamora, inf. n. xilaMCN: see 2.
[Also He went, or came, out, or forth, to him, in the field; for] muxaAlaApN is also syn. with mubaArazapN. (Sh, TA.)

Also, (Lth, JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaAlaApN, (Lth, JK,) He wrestled with him, each endeavouring to throw down the other; contended with him in wrestling: (Lth, JK, Ḳ: mentioned in the Ḳ in art. xlI:) because, when one does so, he is alone with the other, so that neither of them seeks aid from any other. (Az, TA.) And in like manner the word muxaAlaApN is used [app. as meaning The act of contending with another, by oneself,] in relation to any affair, or case. (Lth, JK, TA. [See its act. part. n., below.])
See also 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in eleven places.

AxlI AlmakaAna, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Almanozila, (Mṣb,) He made the place, (Ḳ,) or the place of alighting or abode, (Mṣb,) empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or it signifies, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or signifies also, (Mṣb,) he found it empty,, &c. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) One says in praying for another that he may have a long life, laA OaxolaI Qll-ehu makaAnaka [May God not make thy place vacant]. (TA.)
AxlAhu maEahu [He made him, or found him, to be alone with him]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. txl-I He went forth into the field, or open country, to satisfy a want of nature. (TA.) And txl-I fiI AlxalaMCi He went forth into the vacant tract, or into the privy, to satisfy a want of nature: or he satisfied a want of nature therein. (TA.)

Also He was, or became, or made himself, vacant from occupation, or business; [unoccupied; unemployed; or at leisure;] syn. tafar-aga: (Ṣ:) or so txl-I mina AlX-ugoli. (Ḳ in art. frg.) You say, txl-I liloEibaAdapi He was, or became, or made himself, vacant for, or he confined himself exclusively to, the service of God. (TA.) [See also 1, in the latter part of the paragraph. In like manner, one says also, xalaA↓ liloOamori He was, or became, or made himself, vacant for, or he confined himself exclusively to, the affair.] And taxal-awoA bixaliy-apK (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) They confined themselves exclusively to a she-camel, or to she-camels, such as they termed xlyp, (Ḳ, TA,) yaHolubuwnahaA [milking only her, or them]. (Ṣ, TA.) And txl-I xaliy-apF He took for himself a xly-p. (TA.)
And txl-I mina AlOamori and Eanohu: see 2.
And taxal-ati AlUibilu bilaA raAEK [The camels were left to themselves without a pastor]. (Ḳ in art. swE.)

hom.sense: 10: see 1, in three places. [And see also musotaxolK.]
AstxlAhu majolisahu He asked him to leave his sitting-place vacant, or unoccupied, for him. (Ṣ. [But found by me in only one copy of that work.])

AstxlI Almalika He asked the king to have a meeting, or an interview, with him in a vacant place, or a place unoccupied [by others, i. e., in a private place; he asked the king to grant him a private meeting or interview]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xalaA as a word denoting exception, (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ,) when it governs a gen. case, (Ṣ, Mughnee,) as when you say, jaAWuwniI xalaA zayodK [They came to me, except Zeyd], is a particle, (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ,) accord. to some of the grammarians, like HaAXaI; but accord. to some, a prefixed inf. n.
