(Ṣ.) ↓It also governs an accus. case, as a verb: (Ṣ, Mughnee:) so that you say, jaAWuwniI xalaA zayodFA [meaning as above]; the agent of xlA being implied, (Ṣ, Mughnee,*) like that of HaAXaI [used as a verb]: it is as though you said, xalaA mano jaMCaniI mino zayodK [i. e. those who came to me were without Zeyd]: (Ṣ:) or correctly, accord. to IB, xalaA baEoDuhumo zayodFA [for mino zayodK, like as you say, xalaAka cam-N, for xalaA Eanoka cam-N]. (TA.) When you say maA xalaA, it is followed only by an accus., because mA xlA is equivalent to an inf. n.; (Ṣ, Mughnee;) so that when you say, jaAWuwniI maA xalaA zayodFA [meaning as above], it is as if you said, jaAWuwniI xuluw-a zayodK [or xuluw-FA zayodFA], i. e. xuluw-ahumo mino zayodK, (Ṣ,) which two phrases mean jaAWuwniI xaAliyna mino zayodK [They came to me, they being without Zeyd]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [for] accord. to Seer, mAxlA occupies the place of a noun in the accus. as a denotative of state: but some say, as an adv. n. of time; so that, accord. to these, maA xalaA zayodFA means waqota xuluw-ihimo Eano zayodK [in the time of their being without Zeyd]. (Mughnee.) You say also, maA Oaradotu masaMCataka xalaA Oan-iI waEaZotuka, meaning [I desired not to displease thee,] but I admonished thee (Uil-aA Oan-iI waEaZotuka). (JK, TA.)
xilowN, and its fem. (with p) {xilowapN}, and dual: see xaAlK, in seven places.

hom.sense: xalowapN said by some to be an inf. n.: [see xalaA bihi, &c. in the first paragraph of this art.:] by others said to be a simple subst.; (TA;) meaning Loneliness; solitude; lonesomeness; solitariness; desolateness; syn. waHoXapN. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wHX.) [Hence, app.,] rajulN saholu Alxalowapi [A man easy in private conference]. (Mṣb in art. sls. [See also a phrase in the latter part of the next paragraph.])

Also An empty, a vacant, a void, or an unoccupied, place. (KL. [See also xalaMCN.]) [In the present day, it is often applied to A closet to which one retires for privacy; and particularly to a cell for religious retirement: and is vulgarly pronounced xilowap.] You say, AijotamaEa maEahu fiI xalowapK (Ṣ) or AjtmE bihi fI xlwp (Ḳ) [He had a meeting, or an interview, with him in a vacant place, or a place unoccupied by others, i. e., in a private place].
Also Each of the two sharp sides or edges of an arrow-head (AḤn, JK, TA) or of a spear-head: (AḤn, TA:) both together are called the xalowataAni: (AḤn, JK, TA.)
xalaMCN is primarily an inf. n. (MF, TA. [See 1, first sentence.])
[Then it is used as an epithet, syn. with xaAlK:] see xaAlK, in five places.

Then it is used [as a subst.] in the sense of A vacant place [in a general sense]: (MF, TA:) or a place in which is nothing: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [often applied in the present day to any open tract of country or desert:] and then, particularly, such as one takes for the purpose of satisfying a want of nature; (MF, TA;) i. q. mutawaD-aON, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but not as meaning only a place for the performance of AlwuDuwC, as might be imagined from this explanation: pl. OaxoliyapN. (MF, TA.) It is said in a prov., (Ṣ, Meyd,) xalaAWuka OaqonaI liHayaAYika, (Ṣ, Meyd, Ḳ,) [in Freytag's Arab. Prov., (i. 436,) biHayaMyika,] i. e. [Thy place of retirement is] most preservative (Oalozamu) [of thy sense of shame, or modesty]; meaning it is most fit for thee to be alone in thine abode; (Ṣ,* Meyd;) for he who is so needs not to be careful for his shame, or modesty: it is used in blaming the mixing with others. (Meyd.) HuSira Ealayohi xalaAWuhu [His place of retirement for satisfying a want of nature was straitened to him] is used as meaning he suffered suppression of the feces, or constipation of the bowels. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. HSr.)

Uin-ahu laHoluw AlxalaMCi, (TA,) or [as written in a verse in which it occurs in the TA in the present art., and in art. xlI,] AlxalaA, (JK, TA,) [without C, but whether this be the right reading, or only required by poetic license, seems to be doubtful,] is a phrase mentioned by Th, (TA,) meaning Verily he is good in speech. (JK, TA. [If the former reading be right, the meaning may be similar to that of saholu Alxalowapi, mentioned above: if the latter only, or rather An-h lHlw AlxalaI, be right, it probably belongs to art. xlI, and is tropical, from the herbage termed xalI; and this may also be the case if the former reading be right.])
xaliI-N; and its fem. xaliy-apN: see xaAlK, in twelve places.

The fem. also signifies, applied to a she-camel, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) Loosed from the cord, or rope, with which her fore shank and her arm have been bound together, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and left alone, or free, (Ṣ,) so that she pastures where she will. (Mṣb.) Hence, (Mṣb,) it is used by way of metonymy as meaning Divorced: (Lḥ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) one says to a woman, Oanoti xaliy-apN Thou art divorced; (Lḥ, Ṣ;) and thus a man used to say in the Time of Ignorance: (TA:) and one says, hiIa xaliy-apN She is divorced: (Mṣb:) and a woman is divorced thereby when divorce is meant. (Lḥ, TA.) Applied to a woman, it signifies also Free from any obstacle to marriage: pl. xaliy-aAtN. (Mṣb.)

Also A she-camel that is made to affect, with another she-camel, one young one, so that both yield their milk to it, and to which the people of a tent, or house, confine themselves exclusively of the other for the purpose of milking her: (Ṣ:) or a she-camel that is chosen as the one more abundant in milk, when one has brought forth and her young one is drawn away (yujar-u) as soon as born, before she smells it, and the young one of another, that has brought forth before her, is brought near to her, and she affects it; the other is left to suckle the young one, and is termed basuwTN, pl. bsT [app. busoTN or busuTN]: (Az, TA:) or a she-camel that is left, or left alone, to be milked: (Ḳ:) or that affects a young one [not her own], or is destitute of her young one, (JK, M, Ḳ,) whether she incline to another's young one or do not, or that is destitute of her young one by death or slaughter, (M, TA,) and whose milk one causes to flow by means of the young one of another; but only by her affecting a young one, and not suckling it: (M, Ḳ:*) or that brings forth, when abundant in milk, and has her young one drawn (yujar-u) from beneath her, and another put beneath her, and is then left, or left alone, to be milked; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) this being done because of her generous quality: (Lḥ:) or a she-camel, or two she-camels, to which the people of a tent, or house, confine themselves exclusively, for milking, when two or three she-camels are made to affect one young one, and to yield their milk to it; the young one [afterwards] sucking from one of them only: (Ḳ,* TA:) or a she-camel that brings forth, and whose young one is drawn away (yujar-u) in order that her milk may continue for their use, she being made to yield her milk by means of the young one of another, which is then withdrawn from her, and she is milked: sometimes, also, they bring together three and four xalaAyaA [pl. of xaliy-apN] to one young camel: and the doing so is termed talas-unN: (IAạr, TA:) in this case they take as a xly-p whichever of them they will. (ISh, TA.) [Applied to a she-camel in any of these senses, it seems to be an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; i. e., used without its having naAqapN prefixed to it.]
See also the paragraph next following, in two places.
xaliy-apN [as fem. of the epithet xaliI-N: see the next preceding paragraph, and the places there referred to in its first sentence.]

[As a subst. it signifies] A great ship: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a ship that goes of itself, without its being made to do so by the sailor: (JK, Ḳ:) or one that is followed by a small boat: (Ḳ:) the first held by Az to be the right meaning: (TA:) pl. xalaAyaA. (JK, Ṣ.)

Also, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) and xaliI-N↓, (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ,) The habitation (bayot) of bees, [whether it be a manufactured hive or a hollow in the trunk of a tree or in a rock,] in which they deposit their honey; (Ṣ;) the place in which bees deposit their honey: (Mgh:) or the thing in which bees deposit their honey, (Ḳ, TA,) not manufactured for them: (TA:) or a thing like the [kind of jar called] raAquwd, of clay, (Ḳ, TA,) made for bees: (TA:) or a certain thing for bees, well known, of clay or of wood: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to Lth, if made of clay, it is called kwArp, (Mṣb, TA,) i. e. [kuwaArapN and kuw-aArapN and kiwaArapN] with kesr: (Mṣb:) or a piece of wood hollowed out for honey to be deposited therein [by bees]: or the lower part of a tree that is called xazamapN, [n. un. of xazamN, q. v., hollowed out for that purpose,] resembling the [kind of jar called] raAquwd: (Ḳ:) or xaliI-N↓ signifies the part of the kuw-aArap which is the place of the honey: (JK:) pl. as above. (Mṣb, TA.)

entry.sense: xalaAwapu: see the next paragraph.

xaAlK Empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; (Mgh, TA;) having none, and nothing, in it: (TA:) applied to a place, (Mṣb, TA,) as also xaliI-N↓ (TA) and muxolK↓; (Mṣb;) and to a thing, as also xaliI-N↓; (TA;) or a vessel. (Mgh.) You say also makaAnN xalaMCN↓, [as well as xalaMCN alone,] meaning A place in which is none (Ḳ, TA) and nothing. (TA.) And wajadotu Ald-aAra muxoliyapF↓, meaning xaAliyapF [i. e. I found the house empty,, &c.]. (TA.)

Vacant, or free; from a thing or an affair; or devoid, or destitute, of a thing; (TA;) and so xaliI-N↓ and xilowN↓; which last is the same as masc. and fem., though it has xilowapN also for fem., and OaxolaMCN for pl.; (Ḳ;) but properly, accord. to Lḥ, it has no dual form, nor pl., nor fem., though some give it such forms: (TA:) or xaliI-N↓, which has a dual, [i. e. xaliy-aAni,] and pl., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) i. e. xaliy-uwna and OaxoliyaMCu, (Ḳ,) signifies free [from a thing]; or clear or quit [of a thing or person]; as also xalaMCu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) which, being [originally] an inf. n., has no dual nor pl. [nor fem.]; (Ṣ;) and xilowN↓. (Mṣb.) You say, Oanota xaliI-N↓ mino hecaA AlOamori and xaAlK, i. e. Thou art free from this thing, or affair. (TA.) And OanaA xaliI-N↓ mina Alham-i, meaning xaAlK [i. e. I am free from anxiety]. (Mgh.) And OanaA xilowN↓ mino kacaA, meaning xaAlK [i. e. I am free from such a thing]: (Ṣ:) and humaA xilowN, and humo xilowN; and some say, humaA xilowaAni, and humo OaxolaMCN, which is not proper. (T, TA.) And Oanota xilowN↓ mino muSiybatiI Thou art free in mind from my affliction, or misfortune. (TA from a trad.) And OanaA xaliI-N↓ minoka I am clear, or quit, of thee. (Ṣ.) And OanaA minoka xalaMCN↓ signifies the same. (Ṣ.) And naHonu minoka AlxalaMCu↓ and AlbaraMCu [q. v.] We are clear, or quit, of you. (Fr, T in art. brO.) And Oanota xalaMCN↓ mino hecaA AlOamori Thou art clear, or quit, of this affair. (TA.) And OanaA mino hecaA AlOamori kafaAliji boni xalaAwapa↓ [lit. I am, with respect to this affair, like Fálij Ibn-Khaláweh], (Ṣ,)
or faAliju bonu xalaAwapa, (so in the JK and Ḳ in this art., and in the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. flj,) meaning bariIoCN [i. e. I am clear, or quit, of this affair]: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) a saying originating from its being asked of Fálij Ibn-Khaláweh, on the day of Er-Rakam, when Uneys killed the captives, “Dost thou,” or “wilt thou,” “aid Uneys?” and his answering, “I am clear,” or “quit,” “of him.” (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. flj.) And xaliI-N↓ [alone] signifies xaAlK mina Alham-i [Free from anxiety]; contr. of XajiI-N. (Ṣ.) It is said in a prov., wayolN lilX-ajiI-i mina AlxaliI-i↓, i. e. Woe to him who is occupied by anxiety from him who is free therefrom: (TA:) and in another, maA yaloqaI AlX-ajiI-u mina AlxaliI-i↓, i. e. What will he who is occupied by anxiety experience from him who is free therefrom? meaning, accord. to AO, that the latter will not aid the former against his anxieties, but will censure him: it is said in the Tekmileh that AlxaliI- [in these provs.] is from xalaAhu AlHuzonu meaning “Grief passed away from him,” and “quitted him.” (Ḥar p. 590.) And Oanoti xaliy-apN↓ means xaAliyapN mina Alxayori [i. e. Thou, O woman, art devoid, or destitute, of good]. (Mgh.)

Also A man having no wife; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [for xaAlK mina Alz-awajaAti, a phrase occurring in the TA:] and a woman having no husband; (Ḳ;) thus without p: (TA:) pl. OaxolaMCN: (Ḳ:) and xilowapN↓, also, has the latter meaning; dual xilowataAni, and pl. xilowaAtN: and so has muxoliyapN↓: and xaliy-apN↓ means a woman having no husband nor children; pl. xaliy-aAtN. (TA.)

[And Alone; as also muxolK↓, and xilowN↓.] It is said in a prov., Alc-iYobu muxoliyFA↓ OaXad-u The wolf when [alone or] in a vacant place [is most courageous, or violent]; (TA;) or xaAliyFA [which means the same]. (JK. [And another reading is OasadN. See Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 500.]) And one says, wajadotu fulaAnapa muxoliyapF↓, meaning xaAliyapF [i. e. I found such a woman alone]. (TA.) And wajadahumaA xilowayoni↓ i. e. xaAliyayoni [He found them two alone]. (Ḳ.)
[Also Past, or past away: as well as going, going away, or passing away.] Alquruwnu xaAliyapu means [The generations] that have passed. (JK, Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: muxolK, and its fem. muxoliyapN: see xaAlK, in six places.
lasotu laka bimuxoliyapK, occurring in a trad., means I did not find thee destitute of wives beside me: it is not from AimoraOapN muxoliyapN signifying “a woman having no husband.” (TA.)

entry.sense: mixolaMCN A she-camel left alone, away from her young one. (IDrd, JK.)
muxal-FI pass. part. n. of 2. (Ṣ, TA.)
Left, permitted, or allowed. (M in art. bsl.)
muxaAlK [act. part. n. of 3, q. v.]. Accord. to IAạr, it signifies Contending with another in war. (TA in art. xlO.)

musotaxolK Devoting himself to religious services or exercises [app. in solitude or seclusion, or in a xalowap; or because one generally does so in solitude; or because the doing so involves abstraction from other affairs: see also 1 and 5]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xalaI, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaxoliI, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xaloIN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AxtlI↓; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He cut the herbage called xalFI: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he plucked it up. (Lḥ, Ḳ.) Hence, in a trad., (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) respecting the declaration of the sacredness of Mekkeh, (TA,) laA yuxotalaI↓ xalaAhaA, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) i. e. [Its fresh herbage] shall not be cut. (Mṣb.)

xalaI Ald-aAb-apa, (Ṣ,) or AlmaAXiyapa, (Ḳ,) aor. as above; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or AxlI↓ AlmAXyp, inf. n. UixolaMCN; (TA, as from the Ḳ;) He cut the herbage called xalFI (Ṣ, Ḳ) for the beast, (Ṣ,) or for the cattle: (Ḳ:) and he fed the beast, or the cattle, with xalFI. (TA.)
xalaI AlX-aEiyra He collected the barley in a mixolaAp. (Ḳ.)

xalaI Alqidori, (inf. n. as above, TA,) ‡ He put firewood beneath the cooking-pot: or he put flesh-meat into the cooking-pot. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA.) And AxlI↓ Alqidori † He kindled a fire for the cooking-pot with camels', or similar, dung; as though he put xalFI to it. (TA.) And Ouxoliyato↓, said of a cooking-pot, † It had firewood put to it, like as a she-camel has xalFI put to her, and kindled beneath it: or, as some relate a verse in which it occurs, xul-iyato↓, [belonging to art. xlw,] having a similar meaning, from this verb said of a she-camel such as is termed xaliy-ap, meaning “she had” a young one “put to her.” (Ḥam p. 663.)
xalaI Alfarasa, (Ḳ,) or xalaAhu All-ijaAma, (JK, TA,) ‡ He put the bit in the mouth of the horse, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) like fresh xalFI. (JK.)
And xalaI All-ijaAma, (Ḳ, TA,) Eani Alfarasi, aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) † He pulled out the bit [from the mouth of the horse]. (Ḳ, TA.)
See also 1, last sentence, in art. xlw.
2: see xalFI, below:
and see also 1.

entry.sense: 3. mentioned in this art. in the Ḳ: see art. xlw.

hom.sense: 4. UixlI AlmaAXiyapa, (inf. n. UixolaMCN, TA,) said of God, He made xalFI to grow for the cattle. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
See also 1, in three places.
Axlt AlOaroDu The land became abundant in xalFI. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[And hence,] AxlI † He uttered words, or expressions, without any great meaning. (Ḥam p. 391.)

entry.sense: 7. AnxlI, said of xalFI, It was cut. (Ṣ.)
8: see 1, in two places. [Hence,] Als-ayofu yaxotaliI AlOayodiI waAlOarojula ‡ The sword cuts off the arms and the legs. (JK, Ṣ,* TA.)
12. AxlwlI He constantly drank milk. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

xalFI Fresh, green, or juicy, herbage: (Ṣ, IB, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) that which is dry is termed HaXiyX [but see this word]: (Mṣb, from the Kf:) or dry HaXiyX: (so in one place in the Ṣ: [app. a mistake occasioned by an omission:]) or i. q. ruTobN, (IB, Mṣb,) with damm, (IB,) [i. e. fresh, or green, pasture; or such as consists of the herbs, or leguminous plants, of the rabiyE; or of these and of trees or shrubs:] or herbage that is cut, of the herbs, or leguminous plants, of the rbyE: (Lth, JK:) or, accord. to [the Imám] Moḥammad, anything that is eaten as pasture, not [growing] upon a stem: (Mgh:) or slender herbage as long as it remains fresh, green, or juicy: (IAth, TA:) it is also written xalaMCN↓, with medd, like qaDaMCN: (Mṣb:) n. un. xalaApN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or this signifies any herb (baqolap) that one pulls up: (Ḳ,* TA:) pl. OaxolaMCN, (Ḳ,) a pl. sometimes used [app. as meaning sorts of xalFI]. (TA.) [Hence,] EabodN waxalFI fiI yadayohi [A slave with fresh herbage in his hands, or arms]; meaning, though a slave, yet rich, or possessing sufficiency: (Ṣ, TA:) a prov., (Ṣ, Meyd,) applied to the case of property possessed by him who does not deserve it: or, as some relate it, waxul-iIa↓ fI ydyh [having fresh herbage put in his hands, or arms]: (Meyd:) but this latter reading is disallowed by Yaạḳoob: (Ṣ:) [see other readings, not belonging to this art., in Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 75:] hecaA, or huwa, is understood before EabodN. (Meyd.) And maA kunotu xalaApF limawoEidapK ‡ I was not a breaker of a promise. (TA.) And [hence also, app., if this be the right reading,] Uin-ahu laHulowu AlxalaA [or rather AlxalaI]; or AlxalaMCi↓: see xalaMCN, in art. xlw.
xalaMCN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
xaAlK and muxotalK↓ A cutter of xalFI. (Mṣb. [The pls. xaAluwna and muxotaluwna are mentioned in the Ṣ and TA.])
mixolFI The thing [or instrument] with which xalFI is cut. (Ṣ, TA.)

mixolaApN A thing [or bag] into which xalFI is put: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [and hence a nose-bag for a horse or the like; so in the present day;] a small sack that is hung to the head of a horse [or the like], in which he eats barley [&c.]: (Ḥar p. 76:) so called because they used to cut [and put] xalFI therein for their beasts: (JK:) pl. maxaAlK. (TA.)
maxaAliI Alqatabi: see HidojN.
muxotalK: see xaAlK.
AlmuxotaliI ‡ The lion: (Ḳ, TA:) because of his courage. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. xam-a, aor. _i {yaxomimu} (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and _u {yaxomumu}, (Ḳ,) [the latter irreg.,] inf. n. xumuwmN (JK, Ḳ) and xam-N, (Ḳ,) It (flesh-meat) was, or became, stinking; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) said of what is roasted, or cooked; (Ṣ;) or mostly said of what is cooked, and what is roasted: (IDrd, Ḳ:) or became altered for the worse in odour; said of roasted meat, and of meat cut into strips and dried: (AʼObeyd, TA:)
or became stinking after having been thoroughly cooked: (TA:) and said also of milk, (JK, Ḳ,) in like manner, (JK,) it became altered by the bad odour of the skin, (Ḳ, TA,) and corrupt: (TA:) and Axm-↓ signifies the same, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in both cases: (TA:) and xam-N also, said of a cake of bread not thoroughly baked, signifies the becoming altered in odour. (TA.) [Hence,] xam-a, inf. n. xumuwmN, is likewise said of a man. (TA. [See also 10.]) And one says, huwa laA yaxim-u, meaning † He will not become altered (JK, TA) from his state, or condition, (JK,) or from his liberality, and generosity. (TA.) And huwa Als-amonu laA yaxim-u, (Ṣ, TA,) [lit.] meaning [It is the clarified butter] that will not become altered [for the worse]: (TA:) a prov., relating to a man when one speaks well of him, and praises him. (Ṣ, TA.) And huwa Als-um-u laA yaxim-u, i. e. † It is unmixed poison. (TA.)
xam-N signifies also The act of weeping violently. (Ḳ.) You say, huwa yaxim-u He weeps violently. (TḲ.)

xam-a, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yaxomumu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. xam-u, (TḲ,) He cleaned out a well: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) and he swept a tent, or house, or chamber: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and Axtm-↓ signifies the same, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in both cases. (TA, and so in some copies of the Ḳ.)

[Hence,] huwa yaxum-u viyaAbahu ‡ He eulogizes him, commends him, or speaks well of him: (Ḳ, TA:) and xam-ahu bivanaMCK HasanK, aor. _u {yaxomumu}, inf. n. xam-N, ‡ He eulogized him: (TA:) [and so, app., xam-ahu alone; for] xam-N signifies The act of eulogizing. (Ḳ, TA.)
xam-N also signifies The act of cutting; and so AixotimaAmN↓. (Ḳ.)
And xam-a Aln-aAqapa, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxomumu}, inf. n. xam-N, (TA,) He milked the she-camel: (Ḳ:) or xam-a, aor. _u {yaxomumu}, signifies he turned in his thumb upon his palm when milking. (JK.)
xum-a, said of a domestic fowl, It was confined in a xum-, i. e. cage, or coop. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1.
5. txm-m maA EalaI AlxiwaAni † He ate what remained, of fragments, and scattered particles, upon the table, (Ḳ, TA,) by reason of his greediness. (TA.) [See also R. Q. 1.]
8: see 1, in two places.
Axtm- bihi He took it away. (JK.)
And He threw it down prostrate; and, from the foundation; or uprooted it. (JK.)

10. Uisotaxoma3a It is said in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh, mano OaraAda Oano yasotaxim-a lahu Aln-aAsu qiyaAmFA: thus, accord. to Et-Taháwee, with the pointed xaMC, meaning [Whoso desireth that men] should become altered in their odour to him by reason of their long standing in his presence: but it is also related otherwise, yasotajim-a [q. v.: see also 1 in the present art.]. (TA.) [See also 2 in art. xym.]

R. Q. 1. xamoxamapN [inf. n. of xamoxama] i. q. xanoxnapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. The [snuffling, or] speaking [indistinctly, through the nose,] as though one were maxonuwn [app. here meaning affected with the disease termed xunaAn], (so in a copy of the Ṣ and in the TA,) or majonuwn [i. e. bereft of reason, or mad, insane,, &c.; and this is another meaning of maxonuwn], (so in another copy of the Ṣ,) by reason of pride. (Ṣ.) [See ximoximN.]

Also † The eating in a certain foul manner; (JK, Ṣ, TA;) and so taxamoxumN↓ [inf. n. of taxamoxama]. (TA.) Hence, xamoxaAmN↓ [app. meaning † One who so cats], used as a proper name. (JK, TA.) [See also 5.]
R. Q. 2: see the next preceding paragraph,.

xam-N, (Ḳ,) or xaAm-N↓, (AA, Ṣ,) applied to flesh-meat (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ) that is roasted or cooked, (AA, Ṣ,) or mostly to what is cooked and what is roasted, (Ḳ,) Stinking; (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also muxim-N↓: (AA, Ṣ:) or this last signifies altered in odour, but not yet corrupt (Lth, JK, TA) like a stinking dead body. (Lth, TA.)
xum-N A cage, or coop, for domestic fowls: (ISd, Ḳ:) [and so, in modern Arabic, xun-N:] thought by ISd to be so called because of its foul smell. (TA.)
A [receptacle made of matting or of reeds, such as is called] qawoSar-ap, in which straw is put, for the domestic hen to lay her eggs therein, (Ḳ,) or to hatch therein. (TA.)
A hollow dug in the ground, in the bottom of which are put ashes, and then new-born lambs or kids are put therein: pl. ximamapN. (Ḳ.)
xumaAmN The refuse of anything. (JK.) [See also xum-aAnN.]
xamiymN Heavy, or sluggish, in spirit: (Ḳ:) from xumaAmapN signifying “sweepings.” (TA.)
† Praised: (Ḳ:) from xam-N signifying the act of “eulogizing.” (TA.)
Milk just milked. (Ḳ.)

xumaAmapN Sweepings; (Ḳ;) like qumaAmapN: (JK, Ṣ:) and the earth that is cleared out from a well: (Ṣ:) the dust, or earth, of a tent or house or chamber, and of a well, that is swept, or cleared, out, and thrown in a heap. (Lḥ, TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) or xumaAmapN maAYidapK, (TA,) Scattered fragments of food, which are [gathered up, or swept together, and] eaten, and on account of which a recompense is hoped for [from God]. (Ḳ,* TA.)
ximaAmapN A corrupt, bad, feather, beneath the other feathers. (Ḳ,* TA.)
xam-aAnN: see the next paragraph.
Also A weak spear. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

xum-aAnN (JK, Ḳ) and xam-aAnN↓, (JK, IDrd, TA,) or xim-aAnN↓, (Ḳ,) What is bad of household goods, or furniture, or utensils; (JK, IDrd, Ḳ, TA;) and of trees. (Ḳ.) Also the first and second, (JK, Ṣ,) or the first and third, (Ḳ,) † The refuse, or the low, ignoble, or mean, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the bad, (JK,) of mankind: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) the lowest, basest, or meanest, sort, and the mass, thereof or the weak thereof. (TA.) You say, caAka rajulN mino xum-aAni Aln-aAsi and xam-aAni Aln-aAsi † That is a man of the refuse,, &c., of mankind. (Ṣ.) [See also xumaAmN.]
xim-aAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.
ximoximN One who speaks with [or through] his nose. (TA.) [See R. Q. 1.]
xamoxaAmN: see R. Q. 1.
xaAm-N: see xam-N.
[xayomuwmapN, mentioned in this art. by Golius and Freytag, belongs to art. xym.]
mux-imN: see xam-N.
mixam-apN A broom; a thing with which one sweeps. (Ḳ.)
[Hence,] huwa mixam-apN wamivam-apN † He is a vehement eater [and one who sweeps together the good and the bad]. (JK.) [See also art. vm.]

qalobN maxomuwmN ‡ A heart clear from malevolence, malice, or spite, and envy. (Ṣ, TA.) And maxomuwmu Alqalobi ‡ Having the heart clear from malevolence, malice, or spite, and envy: (Ḳ, TA:) or from dishonesty, or dissimulation, and envy; as explained by Moḥammad himself, when used by him: or from dishonesty, or dissimulation, and corruption: or from pollution: all these explanations being from xam-a signifying “he cleaned out” a well. (TA.)

1. xamadati Aln-aAru, aor. _u {yaxomudu}; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and xamidat, (A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxomadu}; (Ḳ;) inf. n. xumuwdN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xamodN; (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ;) The fire subsided; its flaming; or blazing, ceasing; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) but its embers remaining unextinguished: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) when its embers have become extinguished, you say of it, hamadat: (Ṣ:) or it died away, and became utterly extinguished. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] xamadati AlHum-aI, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or xamidat, (A,) ‡ The fever became allayed: (A, Mṣb:) or the vehemence of the fever became allayed. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And xamada ‡ He (a sick man, Ṣ) fainted, or swooned: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he died. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 4. Axmd Aln-aAra He allayed the flaming, or blazing, of the fire; leaving its embers unextinguished: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he extinguished the fire utterly. (Mṣb.) And AxmdthA Alr-iyHu The wind allayed its flaming, or blazing. (A.)
‡ He was, or became, still, or motionless, and silent. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: xam-uwdN A place in which fire is buried in order that its flaming, or blazing, may cease; its embers remaining unextinguished: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or in order that it may become utterly extinguished: see 1.]

xaAmidN ‡ Silent; from whom no voice is heard: and in like manner, muxomidN↓ signifies still, or motionless, and silent: still, or motionless; having disposed and submitted himself to an affair, or event. (L.) xaAmiduwna in the Ḳur xxxvi. 28 means † Silent and dead: (Jel:) or silent; having died, and become like extinguished ashes. (Zj, Bḍ.*)
muxomidN: see the paragraph next preceding.

hom.sense:
1. xamara, aor. _u {yaxomuru}, (TA,) inf. n. xamorN, (Ḳ,) He veiled, covered, or concealed, a thing; (Ḳ,* TA;)
as also xm-r↓, inf. n. taxomiyrN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) which also signifies he covered over a thing; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Axmr↓, (TA,) inf. n. UixomaArN. (Ḳ.) [Hence,] xamarahaA [and app. xm-rhA↓ also, for the quasi-pass. is txm-rt as well as Axtmrt, He veiled her with a muffler;] he put on her a ximaAr. (A.) And xm-r↓ UinaMCahu, and wajohahu, He covered over his vessel, and his face. (Ṣ.) And xm-r↓ bayotahu He concealed his house, or chamber, or tent, [meaning its interior,] and ordered it aright. (TA, from a trad.) And Oaxomaratohu↓ AlOaroDu Ean-iI and min-iI and EalaI-a The land, or ground, concealed him, or it, from me. (Ḳ.) And Axmrhu↓ † He concealed it, or conceived it, in him mind. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Axmr↓ fulaAnN EalaI-a Zin-apF † Such a one concealed, or conceived, in his mind a suspicion, or an evil opinion, of me. (T, TA.) And xamara XahaAdatahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and xm-rhA↓, (A, Mgh,) and AxmrhA↓, (TA,) ‡ He concealed his testimony. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA.) And Alxamoru taxomuru AlEaqola † Wine veils [or obscures] the intellect; (Ḳ;) and so tuxaAmiruhu↓, lit. covers it: (Mṣb:) or the latter signifies † Infects it; [as though acting like leaven; and if so, from xamara AlEajiyna, which see in what follows; nearly the same as “intoxicates,” which properly signifies “empoisons,” or “infects with poison;”] syn. tuxaAliTuhu. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.) [See xamorN.]

xamira, aor. _a {yaxomaru}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xamarN, (Ṣ,) He became concealed, or hidden; or he concealed, or hid, himself; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) Ean-iI from me; (Ṣ;) as also xAmr↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaAmarapN; (Ḳ;) and Axmr↓: (Ḳ:) or this last signifies he concealed, or hid, himself in a xamar [or covert of trees or the like]. (TA.) One says also, xamira Ean-iI Alxabaru † The news, or story, became concealed from me. (Ṣ.) And one says to the hyena, xaAmiriI↓ Oum-a EaAmirK Hide thyself, O Umm-'Ámir: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) which is a prov.: (TA:) and is said to be also a phrase used as a surname of the hyena, in the manner of taOab-aTa Xar-FA. (Ḥam p. 242.) And xaAmiriI↓ HaDaAjiro OataAki maA tuHaAciro [Hide thyself, O hyena: what thou fearest has come to thee]: thus we have found it: (Ḳ:) and this is the reading commonly obtaining accord. to the authors on proverbs: (TA:) but it should properly be xaAmirN [and OataAka] or tuHaAciryna. (Ḳ.)
xamarN also signifies The becoming changed, or altered, from a former state or condition. (Ḳ.) You say, xamira AlX-aIoCu The thing became changed,, &c. (TḲ.)

xamara AlEajiyna, (Ks, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxomuru} (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _i {yaxomiru}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xamorN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [He leavened the dough;] he put xumorap, (Ks, A,) or xamiyr, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) into the dough; (Ks, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA;) as also xm-rhu↓: (TA:) or he left the dough until it became good [or mature]; (Ḳ;) and in like manner, accord. to the Ḳ, AlT-iyna [the clay, or mud: see faTara]: or, as in other lexicons, AlT-iyba [the perfume]; (TA;) and the like; as also xm-rhu↓, inf. n. taxomiyrN, in relation to any of these things; and Axmrhu↓ in relation to the first [and probably to the others also]: (Ḳ:) and xamara Aln-abiyca [he fermented the beverage called nbyc;] he put xumorap into the nbyc. (A.) [Mṭr says, in the Mgh, xam-ara↓ AlEaSiyra I have not found, n or txm-r↓ as its quasi-pass.]
xamarahu, aor. _u {yaxomuru}, (TA,) inf. n. xamorN; (Ḳ;) and Axmrhu↓; (Mgh;) He gave him (namely, a man, and a beast, such as a horse and the like, TA) wine (xamor) to drink. (Ḳ,* Mgh, TA.)
xumira, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. xamorN, (TA,) He suffered, or was affected with, xumaAr [i. e. the remains of intoxication]. (Mgh, TA.) [See also 5.]
xamarahu, aor. _u {yaxomuru}, (AA, Ṣ,) inf. n. xamorN, (Ḳ,) He was ashamed for himself, or of himself, or was bashful, or shy, with respect to him; was abashed at him, or shy of him. (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
2: see 1, in eight places:
and see also 3.
3. xAmr as an intrans. v.: see 1, in three places.

xAmrhu, inf. n. muxaAmarapN, It mixed, mingled, commingled, intermixed, or intermingled, with it; became incorporated, or blended, with it; infected, or pervaded, it; syn. xaAlaTahu. (Ṣ, A, Mgh,* Ḳ.) You say, xAmr AlmaMCa All-abana The water mixed with the milk. (A.) And xaAmarotu fulaAnFA ‡ I mixed with such a one in familiar, or social, intercourse; conversed with him; or became intimate with him; syn. xaAlaTotuhu. (A.) And Alxamoru tuxaAmiru AlEaqola: see 1. And xAmrhu Ald-aMCu † The disease infected, or pervaded, him; syn. xaAlaTahu: (Sh:) or infected, or pervaded, (xAlT,) his inside. (Lth.)
Also, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) † He approached it; or was, or became, near to it; (Ḳ,* TA;) namely, a thing. (TA.)

And xAmr AlmakaAna, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) ‡ He kept, or clave, to the place; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) did not quit it; (A;) remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in it; (Ḳ;) and in like manner, bayotahu his house, or tent; and so xm-rhu↓. (TA.)
xAmr, (TḲ,) inf. n. as above, (IAạr, Ḳ,) [app. in the dial. of El-Yemen, (see 10,)] also signifies He sold a free person as being a slave. (IAạr, Ḳ, TḲ.)
4. Axmr: see 1 in the former half of the paragraph, in six places.
Oaxomarati AlOaroDu The land abounded with xamar, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) meaning tangled trees. (TA.)
See also 1, latter part, in two places.

Axmrhu AlX-aIoCa He gave him the thing, or put him in possession of it, (Ḳ,) is a phrase common in El-Yemen: (Moḥammad Ibn-Ketheer, TA:) a man says, OaxomirniI kacaA, meaning Give thou me such a thing as a free gift: put me in possession of it: and the like. (Moḥammad Ibn-Ketheer, Ṣ.)
5. taxam-arato: see 8.
Also She (a woman) applied xumorap as a liniment to her face, to beautify her complexion. (TA.)
txm-r He was affected with languor by wine. (TA.) [See xumira.]
See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.
8. Aixotamarato She wore, or put on [her head], a ximaAr; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also txm-rt↓. (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Axtmr, said of dough, [It became fermented;] it had xumorap put into it: and in like manner one says of the beverage called nabiyc [it became fermented]: (A:) or, said of dough, and of clay, or mud, (Tiyn, as in the Ḳ, but accord. to other lexicons perfume, Tiyb, TA,) and the like, it was left until it became good [or mature]: (Ḳ:) and Axtmrt Alxamoru the wine became mature [and fermented]; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as it does when it becomes changed in odour: (TA:) or became changed in odour. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 10. Astxmrhu He made him, or took him as, a slave: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (Mgh, TA.) [See 3.] So in the trad. of Mo'ádh, mano Qsotaxomara qawomFA Oaw-aluhumo OaHoraArN wajiyraAnN musotaDoEafuwna falahu maA qaSara fiI bayotihi [Whosoever hath made slaves, or taken as slaves, persons the first state of whomhath been that of freemen and neighbours, regarded as weak, to him shall belong what he hath held in possession in his house or tent]: (Ṣ,* L:) i. e., hath taken them by force, and obtained possession of them: (Ṣ:) meaning, whosoever hath made slaves, or taken as slaves, persons in the Time of Ignorance, and then El-Islám hath come, to him shall belong those whom he hath held in possession in his house or tent: they shall not go from his hand. (Az, TA.) Moḥammad Ibn-Ketheer says, This is a phrase known to us in El-Yemen, where any other is scarcely ever used [in its stead]. (Ṣ.)

xamorN [Wine: or grape-wine:] what intoxicates, of the expressed juice of grapes: (ISd, Ḳ:) or the juice of grapes when it has effervesced, and thrown up froth, and become freed therefrom, and still: (Mgh:) or it has a common application to intoxicating expressed juice of anything: (Ḳ, TA:) or any intoxicating thing, that clouds, or obscures, (lit. covers,) the intellect; as some say: (Mgh,* Mṣb: [but see what follows:]) and the general application is the more correct, because xamor was forbidden when there was not in El-Medeeneh any xamor of grapes; the beverage of its inhabitants being prepared only from dates in their green and small state, or full-grown but unripe, or fresh and ripe, or dried: (Ḳ,* TA:) or the arguing thus, from this fact alone, requires consideration: (MF:) AḤn says, it is † sometimes prepared from grains: but ISd holds this to be an improper signification: (TA:) it is also sometimes applied to the † beverage called nabiyc, like as nbyc is sometimes applied to wine expressed from grapes: (L in art. nbc:) applied to ‡ expressed juice from which xamor [properly so called] is made, [i. e., to must, or unfermented nabiyc,] it is tropical: it is so used in a trad. in which xamor is said to have been sold by [a companion of Moḥammad named] Samurah: xamor [in its proper acceptation] is so called because it veils (taxomuru, i. e. tasoturu,) the intellect: (Ḳ:) or because it infects (tuxaAmiru, i. e. tuxaAliTu,) the intellect: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [as though acting like leaven: (see 1:)] so said ʼOmar: (TA:) or because it is left until it has become mature [and fermented]; (Ḳ;) or until its odour has changed: (IAạr, Ṣ:) [see 8:] the proper application of the root is to denote “covering,” and “commingling in a hidden manner:” (Ṣgh, Er-Rághib, TA:) it is of the fem. gender, and sometimes masc.: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) you say huwa Alxamoru as well as hiIa Alxamoru: but Aṣ does not allow it to be masc.: (Mṣb:)
and xamorapN↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ:) [or a kind of wine:] or xamorN and xamorapN are like tamorN and tamorapN; [the former a coll. gen. n., and the latter its n. un.;] (Ṣ;) and xamorapN [thus] signifies some wine; lit., a portion of xamor: (Mṣb:) the pl. of xamorN is xumuwrN. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) You say [also] xamorapN↓ SirofN [Some pure, or unmixed, wine; using a masc. epithet, contr. to rule]. (Ṣ.)

[Hence the saying,] maA Einoda fulaAnK xal-N walaA xamorN, (Ṣ,) or maA huwa bixal-K walaA xamorK, (Ḳ,) ‡ Such a one, (Ṣ,) or he, (Ḳ,) possesses neither good nor evil: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or neither evil nor good: for] AA says that some of the Arabs make Alxamoru to be good, and Alxal-u to be evil; and some of them make Alxmr to be evil, and Alxl- to be good. (Ḥar p. 153.)

xamorN also signifies † Grapes; (AḤn, M, Ḳ;) in the dial. of El-Yemen: (M:) like as EinabN signifies “wine” in that dial. (AḤn, TA in art. Enb.) It is said in the Ḳur [xii. 36], Uin-iI OaraAniI OaEoSiru xamorFA Verily I thought myself pressing grapes: (ISd:) or the meaning is, pressing out wine from grapes. (Ibn-ʼArafeh.)

xamarN A covert of trees, &c.: (ISk, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) or a place where the ground is eaten away by a torrent, or an oblong tract of sand collected together and elevated, forming a place for concealment: (ISk, Ṣ:) and a hollow, or cavity, in which a wolf conceals himself: and tangled trees. (TA.) You say, tawaAraI AlS-ayodu min-iI fiI xamari AlwaAdiI [The game, or wild animal or animals, concealed itself, or themselves, from me in the covert,, &c., of the valley]. (Ṣ.) And huwa yadib-u lahu AlD-araMCa wayamoXiI lahu Alxamara † [He creeps to him in the thicket, or place overgrown with trees; and he walks to him in the covert of trees,, &c.: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. 692ii. 913, and see art. Drw]: speaking of a man when he deceives, or circumvents, his companion. (Ṣ.) And jaMCanaA EalaI xamorK and ElI ximorapK↓ † He came to us secretly; unexpectedly; clandestinely. (Ḳ.)

Hence, (Ṣ,) xamarN and xumaArN↓ and xamaArN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xamorapN↓ (Ḳ) † A crowding, (Ṣ,) or congregation, (Ḳ,) and multitude, of men or people. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, daxala fiI xamaAri↓ Aln-aAsi and xamaArihimo↓, dial. vars. of gumaAr and gamaAr, i. e. ‡ He entered among the crowding and multitude of the men or people; (Ṣ;) and in like manner, fI xamarotihimo↓ and gamarotihimo; (TA;) as also fI xamarihimo and gamarihimo: (TA in art. gmr:) or among such [a crowd] of the people as hid him. (ISk, Ṣ.)

hom.sense: xamirN A place abounding with coverts of the description termed xamar; (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) a place concealing by dense trees. (TA.)
† A man infected, syn. muxaAmarN, (Sh, IAạr, Ṣ,) by a disease: (TA:) thought by ISd to be a possessive epithet: (TA:) or in the last stage of the remains of intoxication. (Ṣ.) [See also maxomuwrN.]
xamorapN: see xamorN, in two places.

Also, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and ximorapN↓ (Kr, Ḳ) and xumorapN↓, (Ḳ,) The odour of perfume: (Ṣ, A:) or a sweet odour: (Ḳ:) and the last signifies also an odour which has infected (xaAmara, i. e. xaAlaTa,) a person; (Ḳ;) as also xamarapN↓. (AZ, Ḳ.) You say, wajadotu xamorapa AlT-iybi I experienced, or smelt, the odour of the perfume. (Ṣ, A.)
See also xamarN, in two places.
xumorapN: see xamiyrN, in two places.

Also a dial. var. of gumorapN [q. v.], A thing [or composition] which is used as a liniment for beautifying the complexion; (Ṣ;) [the plant called] waros and certain perfumes which a woman uses as a liniment (so in the Ḳ, or applies as a liniment to her face, as in other lexicons, TA) to beautify her face. (Ḳ.)
See also xamorapN.
A small pot or jar: and a vessel for leaven. (KL.)

A small mat, (Ṣ, A,* Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [of an oblong shape,] large enough for a man to prostrate himself upon it, (Mgh, Mṣb,) used for that purpose [in prayer], (Ṣ, A,) made of palm-leaves (Ṣ, Ḳ) woven (turomalu) with threads or strings: (Ṣ:) so called because it veils the ground from the face of the person praying [upon it]: (Zj,* Mgh:) or because its threads or strings are hidden by its palm-leaves. (TA.)
ximorapN A hiding, or concealing, oneself: (IAạr, TA:) [or, accord. to analogy, a mode, or manner, of doing so.]
See also xamarN.

A mode, manner, or way, of wearing the ximaAr. (Ḳ,* TA.) You say, Uin-ahaA laHasanapu Alximorapi [Verily she has a beautiful mode of wearing the xmAr]. (Ṣ.) And hence the saying of ʼOmar to Mo'áwiyeh, maA OaXobaha Eayonaka biximorapi hinodK [How like is thine eye to Hind's (when she practises her) mode of wearing the xmAr!]. (TA.) Hence also, (TA,) Uin-a AlEawaAna laA tuEal-amu Alximorapa [Verily she who has had a husband will not require to be taught the mode of wearing the xmAr]: (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:) a prov., (Ṣ, TA,) applied to him who is experienced and knowing: (Ḳ:) i. e. the experienced woman is not to be taught how she should act. (TA.)
See also xamorapN.

entry.sense: xamarapN: see xamorapN.
xamoriI-N Grapes (EinabN) fit for wine. (TA.)
A colour resembling the colour of wine. (TA.)
ximir-N: see ximaArN.
xamaArN: see xamarN, in two places.

hom.sense: xumaArN: see xamarN, in two places:
and see also xumorapN, in two places.

entry.sense: ximaArN [A woman's muffler, or veil, with which she covers her head and the lower part of her face, leaving exposed only the eyes and part or the whole of the nose: such is the xmAr worn in the present day: a kind of veil which is called in Turkish yaXomaqo; as in the TḲ:] a woman's headcovering; (Mgh, TA;) a piece of cloth with which a woman covers her head; (Mṣb;) i. q. naSiyfN, (Ḳ,) pertaining to a woman; (Ṣ) as also ximir-N↓: (Th, Ḳ:) and any covering of a thing; anything by which a thing is veiled, or covered: (Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxomirapN (Ḳ) and [of mult.] xumurN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and xumorN. (Ḳ.)

Also A man's turban; because a man covers his head with it in like manner as a woman covers her head with her xmAr: when he disposes it in the Arab manner, he turns [a part of] it under the jaws [nearly in the same manner in which a woman disposes her xmAr]. (TA.) [Hence,] maA Xam-a ximaAraka, a prov., (TA,) [meaning] † What hath changed thee from the state in which thou wast? What hath befallen thee? (Ḳ.)

xamiyrN (Ḳ) and maxomuwrN↓ and muxam-arN↓, (TA,) applied to dough, [Leavened;] having had xamiyr [as meaning leaven] put into it: (TA:) or, applied to dough, and to clay or mud (Tiyn, as in the Ḳ, but accord. to other lexicons perfume, Tiyb, TA), and the like, left until it has become good [or mature]: (Ḳ:) pl. [of the first] xamoraI. (TA.) You say also xubozN xamiyrN Bread [leavened, or] into which leaven (xamiyr) has been put: (Lḥ, TA:) or yesterday's bread; bread that has been kept over a night: (Ṣ:) and xubozapN xamiyrN, without p [in the epithet]. (Lḥ, TA.) And xamiyrN is also applied to Bread itself: or leavened bread. (Sh, TA.)

xamiyrN [used as a subst.] (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xamiyrapN↓ and xumorapN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) signify Leaven, or ferment, expl. by maA xum-ira bihi, (Ḳ,) of dough, and of perfume; (TA;) what is put into dough, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) and into the beverage called nabiyc; (A;) and xumorapN↓ also signifies what is put into perfume, as well as what is put into dough and into nbyc: (Ks:) the xumorap of nbyc is its dregs, (Ḳ,) and its [ferment which is called] durodiI-; (TA;) or what is put into it, of wine (xamor) and of durodiI-; and so too of perfume; (Ṣ;) and the xumorap of milk is its ferment (ruwbap) which is poured upon it in order that it may quickly curdle, or coagulate, or thicken, or become thick and fit for churning. (TA.)
[Hence,] AijoEalohu fiI sir-i xamiyrika ‡ Conceal thou it (i. e. a secret, A) in thy mind. (A, TA.) And Oaxoraja mino sir-i xamiyrihi sir-FA ‡ He revealed, or disclosed, a secret. (TA.)
See also maxomuwrN.
xamiyrapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
xam-aArN A vintner; a seller of xamor [or wine]. (Ḳ.)
xim-iyrN (Ṣ) and musotaxomirN↓ (Ḳ) One who constantly drinks wine; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a great drinker; devoted to drink. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: muxam-arN † A horse having a white head, whatever be the rest of his colour; but not muxotamirN↓: (Lth:) and muxam-arapN, applied to a ewe or she-goat, (AZ, T, Ṣ, A,) accord. to Lth and the Ḳ muxotamirapN↓, but the former is the right term, (TA,) [in the CK muxotamir,] † whose head is white, and the rest of her black; like raxomaMCu: (Ṣ:) or having a white head; (AZ, T, A;) and in like manner, a mare: (Ḳ:) or a black ewe with a white head: from the ximaAr of a woman. (TA.)
See also xamiyrN.
And see maxomuwrN.

entry.sense: muxam-irN A maker of xamor [or wine]. (Ḳ.)
maxomuwrN: see xamiyrN.
Also, (Ṣ,) and muxam-arN↓ and xamiyrN↓, (TA,) A man affected with xumaAr, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e. the remains of intoxication. (Ṣ. [Like maboxuwrN. See also xamirN.])
muxotamirN, and with p {muxotamirapN}: see muxam-arN.
musotaxomirN: see xim-iyrN.

hom.sense: 1. xamasa Alqawoma, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxomusu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) [inf. n. xamosN,] He took the fifth part of the possessions of the people. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ.) And xamasa AlmaAla, (A, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaxomusu}, inf. n. xamosN, (Mṣb,) He took the fifth part of the property. (A, Mṣb.) xamosN signifies The taking one from five: and hence the saying of 'Adee Ibn-Ḥátim, rabaEotu fiI AljaAhiliy-ap waxamasotu fiI AlUisolaAmi [I took the fourth part of the spoil in the Time of Ignorance, and I took the fifth part thereof in the time of El-Islám]; meaning, I headed the army in both those states; for the commander, in the Time of Ignorance, used to take the fourth part of the spoil; and in El-Islám, the fifth part was assigned to him. (TA.)

xamasa Alqawoma, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxomisu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xamosN, (Mṣb,) He was, or became, the fifth of the people: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he made them five by [adding to their number] himself. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
xamasa also signifies He made fourteen to be fifteen. (T in art. vlv.)
And He made forty-nine to be fifty with himself. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ in that art.)
xamasa AlHabola, aor. _i {yaxomisu}, inf. n. xamosN, He made the rope of five strands twisted together. (TA.)
xamasati AlUibilu The camels drank on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first. (TA.) [See xamosN.]
xamasa, said of a horse, He came fifth in the race. (T, M, L; all in art. vlv.)

entry.sense: 2. xm-shu, inf. n. taxomiysN, He made it five. (EshSheybánee and Ḳ, voce waH-adahu.)
He made it to be five-cornered; five-angled; pentagonal. (Ḳ.)
xam-asato She brought forth her fifth offspring. (TA in art. bkr.)
And xm-shu He made it five-fifths. (Mṣb.)
xm-s liQmoraOatihi, or EinodahaA, He remained five nights with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA voce sab-aEa.)

taxomiysN also signifies [The watering of land or seedproduce on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first;] the watering of land that is [next] after the tarobiyE. (TA.)
4. Axms Alqawomu The party of men became five: (Ṣ, Ḳ:)
also, The party of men became fifty. (M and L in art. vlv.)
Axms Alr-ajulu The man was, or became, one whose camels came to water on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.) [See ximosN.]
xamosN fem. of xamosapN [q. v.].
xumosN: see xumusN.

hom.sense: ximosN The drinking of camels on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first; their drinking one day, then pasturing three days, then coming to the water on the fifth day, the first and last days, on which they drink, being thus reckoned: this is the correct explanation, accord. to Aboo-Sahl El-Khowlee; and Aboo-Zekereeyà says the like; (TA;) or their pasturing three days, and coming to the water on the fourth day [not counting the day of the next preceding watering; for it is evident that this explanation is virtually the same as that preceding]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to Lth, the drinking of camels on the fourth day, counting the day on which they returned from [the next preceding] watering; but Az says, that this is a mistake; the day of returning from watering not being counted [when it is explained as meaning the drinking on the fourth day]: (TA:) pl. OaxomaAsN, the only pl. form. (Sb, TA.) [See ZimoCN.] Hence, falaApN ximosN [as in copies of the Ḳ, or it may be falaApu ximosK,] A desert in which the water is far distant, so that the camels come to the water on the fourth day, exclusive of the [next preceding] day on which they drank. (Az, Ḳ, TA.) Hence also the saying, fulaAnN yaDoribu OaxomaAsFA liOasodaAsK (Ṣ, Ḳ *) ‡ Such a one makes a pretence of AxmAs [or fifth-day waterings] for the purpose of AsdAs [or sixth-day waterings]: i. e., he advances his camels from the ximos to the sidos: (Ḳ:) a prov.: (TA:) meaning, such a one strives to deceive, or circumvent: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) applied to him who acts towards another with artifice, pretending that he obeys him, or complies with his desire: (TA:) or to him who pretends one thing while he means another: (Ḳ:) and taken from the saying, related by AO and IAạr, Daraba OaxomaAsFA liOasodaAsK [He made a pretence of AxmAs for the purpose of AsdAs]; said of him who proposes a thing whereby he means another thing, which he commences and by slow degrees accomplishes: (TA:) for a man, when he desires to make a long journey, accustoms his camels to drink ximosFA sidosFA [i. e. on the fifth day and then on the sixth, in each case counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first]: (Ḳ, TA:) the origin of the saying, accord. to IAạr, being this: an old man was among his camels, accompanied by his sons, men, who pastured them, and who had been long far distant from their families; and he told them one day to pasture their camels riboEFA [i. e. watering on the fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first], which they did, proceeding in the way towards their families: then they proposed to do so ximosFA; and then, sidosFA: whereupon the old man, understanding what they meant, said, ye are doing nothing but making a pretence of AxmAs for the purpose of AsdAs: the object of your desire is not the pasturing of them, but it is only your families. (TA.) [See below, voce xumusN, a saying similar in words but different in meaning.]

It is also used for sayoru ximosK [A journey in which the camels are watered only on the first and fifth days; a journey in which the second and third and fourth days are without water]. (L in art. jlc.) You say ximsN baSobaASN, [and SaboSaAbN,] and qaEoqaAEN, and HavoHaAvN, [and HaSoHaASN, &c.,] i. e. A journey [in which the camels are watered only on the first and fifth days,] in the course of which, to the water, there is no flagging, by reason of its remoteness. (TA.) El-ʼAjjáj uses the expression
ximosN kaHaboli AlX-aEari AlmunoHat-i
meaning, A [journey of the kind termed] xms without any deviation, like a rope made of hair that has fallen off and that is free from any unevenness. (L, TA.)
ximosN also signifies The fifth young one, or offspring. (A in art. vlv.)

A [garment of the kind called] burod, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the fabric of El-Yemen; (Ṣ;) so called because first made for a king of El-Yemen named ximosN, (AA, Ṣ,) or Alximosu; (Ḳ, TA;) as also xamiysN↓. (TA.) For the latter word, we find in the work of Bkh, xamiyS, with S; which, if correct, is masc. of xamiySapN, which is a small kind of kisaMC. (IAth, and L.) [The pl. of ximosN applied to a burodap is OaxomaAsN.] See also maxomuwsN, in four places.

entry.sense: xumusN and xumosN↓ A fifth part; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also xamiysN↓, (Ṣ, in art. vlv, and IAmb and Mṣb,) agreeably with a rule applicable in the case of every one of the units, except valiyvN: (TA:) some allow this last; but AZ disallows it, and xmys also: (Ṣ in art. vlv:) pl. OaxomaAsN. (Mṣb, TA.)

xamosapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) masc.; and xamosN, fem.; (Ṣ;) [Five;] a certain number. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say xamosapu rijaAlK [Five men], and xamosu nisowapK [Five women]. (Ṣ.) You say also, EinodiI xamosapu daraAhimo [I have five dirhems], with refa: and if you please, you incorporate the p into the d [and say, xamosap d-araAhima]: but when you prefix Al to drAhm, you say, EinodiI xamosapu Ald-araAhimi [I have the five dirhems], with damm; and may not incorporate, because you have incorporated the l into the d: and in the case of a fem. n. you say, EinodiI xamosu Alquduwri [I have the five cooking-pots]: also, hecihi Alxamosapu Ald-araAhimi [These five dirhems]; and, if you please, Ald-araAhimu, using it in the manner of an epithet: and in like manner [you use the other nouns of number] to EaXarapN [inclusive]. (Ṣ.) You say also, SumonaA xamosFA mina AlX-ahori [We fasted during a period of five nights of the month with their days];
making layaAlK to predominate over Oay-aAm, when you do not mention the word Ay-Am, though the fasting is in the day; because the night of each day precedes the day: but when you mention the word Ay-Am, you say, SumonaA xamosapa Oay-aAmK [We fasted five days]. (ISk, TA.) yaEaD-u biAlxamosi means He bites the fingers: these being [five in number and] of the fem gender: (Ḥam p. 790:) [i. e.] xamosN means the five fingers. (Ḥar p. 76.) [Respecting a peculiar pronunciation of the people of El-Ḥijáz, and a case in which xamosap is imperfectly decl., see valaAvapN.]
[xamosapa EaXara, masc.; and xamosa EaXorapa, fem.; Fifteen. For variations thereof, see art. EXr.]

xamosuwna [Fifty, and fiftieth,] is also written and pronounced xamisuwna, with kesr to the xamasuwna, by poetic license, as related by Ks; or m, with fet-ḥ, as related by others, after the manner of xamosapN and xamasaAtN: (Fr, TA:) accord. to the T, the variation xamisuwna, with kesr to the m, is [dialectic, being] similar to xamosa EaXirapa, with kesr to the X [in the dial. of Nejd]. (TA.)

jaAWuwA xumaAsa, and maxomasa↓, They came five and five; [or five and five together; or five at a time and five at a time;] (Ḳ, TA;) like as they say, vunaMCa and mavonaI, and rubaAEa and marobaEa: (TA:) or, accord. to AʼObeyd, not more than OuHaAda and vunaMCa and vulaAva and rubaAEa has been heard, except EuXaAra occurring in a verse of El-Kumeyt. (TA in art. EXr.)

hom.sense: xamiysN: see xumusN:
and maxomuwsN, in two places.

An army; because consisting of five parts, namely, the van, the body, the right wing, the left wing, and the rear; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) or because the spoils are divided into fifths among it; but this latter assertion requires consideration; (ISd, MF;) for this division of the spoils is an affair of the Muslim law, whereas xmys [thus applied] is an old term: (MF:) or an army having numerous weapons; syn. jayoXN xaXinN. (TA.)

yawomu Alxamiysi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and simply Alxamiysu, Thursday; the fifth day of the week; thus used for AlxaAmisu, in like manner as Ald-abaraAnu is applied to the star [that follows the Pleiades, for Ald-aAbiru]: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxomisapN and [of mult.] OaxomisaMCu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OaxaAmisu. (Fr, TA.) AZ used to say, maDaI Alxamiysu bimaA fiyhi [Thursday passed with what happened in it], making it sing. and masc.: but Abu-l-Jarráh used to say, maDaI Alxamiysu bima fiyhin-a, making it pl. and fem., and using it as a n. of number. (Lḥ, TA.) It has no dim. (Sb, Ṣ in art. Ams.)
See also ximosN, last signification.
maA OadoriI OaI-u xamiysi Aln-aAsi huwa means I know not what company of men it is. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xumaAsiI-N A boy five spans (OaXobaAr) in height: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) said of him who is increasing in height [but has not attained his full stature]: (Mṣb:) fem. with p {xumaAsiy-apN}: (Lth, TA:) and in like manner you say rubaAEiI-N: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) but you do not say subaAEiI-N, (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) nor sudaAsiI-N; (Lth, Ḳ;) [i. e., in speaking of a boy;] for when he has attained seven spans, (Ṣ,) or six spans, (Lth, Ḳ,) he is a man: (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or to a slave you apply the epithet sdAsI- also; and to a garment, or piece of cloth, sbAEI-. (Mṣb.)
See also maxomuwsN.
[Also A word composed of five letters, radical only, or radical and augmentative.]
xamiysiI-N One who fasts alone on Thursday. (IAạr, Th.)

hom.sense: [xaAmisa EaXara and xaAmisap EaXorapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Fifteenth, are subject to the same rules as vaAliva EaXara and its fem., explained in art. vlv, q. v.]

UibilN xaAmisapN (TA) and xawaAmisu (Ṣ, Ḳ) Camels that drink on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first: [see ximosN:] (TA:) or that pasture three days, coming to the water on the fourth day [not counting the day of the next preceding watering]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: jaAWuwA maxomasa: see xumaAsa.
muxam-asN A thing five-cornered; five-angled; pentagonal. (Ṣ.) [See also muval-avN.]

maxomuwsN Five cubits in length; applied to a spear, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) as also xamiysN↓; (Ḳ;) and to a garment, or piece of cloth, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) as also xamiysN↓, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) which occurs in a trad. as meaning a small garment or piece of cloth, (Mgh,) and xumaAsiI-N↓ [q. v. suprà]; (TA;) and in like manner, burodapu OaxomaAsK↓ a [garment of the kind called] brdp fire cubits long. (ISk, TA.) Hence the saying, humaA fiI burodap OaxomaAsK↓ † They two have become near together, and in a state of agreement. (Ḳ.) A poet says,
Say-araniI juwdu yadayhi wamano
OahowaAhu fiI burodapi OaxomaAsi↓
i. e., † The bounty of his hands has made me and the person whom I love to be near together, as though we were in a brdp five cubits long: (Th, TA:) app. meaning that the person thus spoken of had purchased for him a female slave, or had given for him the dowry of his wife. (Az, Ṣgh, TA.) You also say, layotanaAfiI burodapi OaxomaAsK↓, a prov., meaning † Would that we were near together. (ISk, TA.) [See also burodN.]
Also A rope made of five strands twisted together. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

1. xamaXahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor _i (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xamoXN, (Mṣb,) He scratched it, namely, the face, with the nails, so as to cause bleeding or not; syn. xadaXahu: (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ:) only used in relation to the face: (A:) or also used in relation to the rest of the person: (TA:) and xm-Xhu↓, inf. n. taxomiyXN, signifies the same: (TA:) [or denotes intensiveness, or muchness, like xad-aXahu.] And xamaXati AlmaroOapu wajahahaA biZuforahaA The woman wounded the exterior of the scarf-skin of her face with her nail. (Mṣb.) One says also, by way of imprecation, xamoXFA [May thy, or his, or her, face be scratched]; like as one says jadoEFA and qaToEFA. (TA.)
He slapped it; namely, the face. (A, Ḳ.)
He beat him, or it, (Ḳ, TA,) with a staff, or stick. (TA.)
He cut off from him a limb, or member. (Ḳ.)
2: see 1.
xamoXN The mark made by scratching with the nails upon the face: (Mṣb, TA:) pl. xumuwXN. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.)

laA tafoEalo celika Oum-uka xamoXaI (Lḥ) Do not thou that: may thy mother, being bereft of thee by death, scratch her face for thee. (ISd.) One says also, on the occasion of a thing at which one wonders, xamoXaI EaqoraI HaloqaI. (Ṣ and TA in art. Hlq: see 1 in that art.)
xamuwXN Gnats: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) in the dial. of Hudheyl: (Ṣ:) n. un. with p {xamuwXapN}: or it has no n. un.; (TA;) one thereof being called baq-apN. (Ṣ.)

xumaAXapN A wound, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or mutilation, (Ṣ,) for which there is no fine, or mulct, (A,) or for which there is no certain fine, or mulct; (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or what is below the bloodwit; as the cutting off of an arm or a hand, or of an car, and the like: (Ḳ:) or a wound, or mutilation, of any kind below slaughter and the bloodwit; such as amputation, or a wound; or a blow, or plunder, or a similar injury. (L.) It is related in a trad., that Keys Ibn-' Ásim collected his sons at his death, and said, kaAna bayoniI wabayona fulaAnK xumaAXaAtN fiI AljaAhiliy-ahi [There were, between me and such a one, wounds,, &c., in the Time of Ignorance]. (L.) And you say, qado Oaxacotu xumaAXatiI mino fulaAnK I have retaliated upon such a one [my wound,, &c.]. (TA.)
xumaAXaAtN, also, (Ṣ, TA,) or xumaAXaAtu caHolK, (A, TA,) signifies ‡ Remains of caHol [or desire of retaliation, or the like]. (Ṣ, A, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xamiSati Alqadamu, aor. _a {yaxomaSu}, inf. n. xamaSN, The man's foot rose from the ground, [or was hollow in the middle of the sole,] so that it did not touch it. (Mṣb.)

xamaSa AlbaTonu, (A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxomuSu}; (TḲ;) and xamiSa, aor. _a {yaxomaSu} and xamuSa, aor. _u {yaxomuSu}; (A, Ḳ, TḲ;) inf. n. xmS [i. e. xamoSN or xumoSN or probably both] and xumuwSN and maxomaSapN; (TḲ;) The belly was, or became, empty; (A, Ḳ, TḲ;) i. e., hungry: (TḲ:) [and lank: see xamiySN.] And xamuSa AlX-aIoCu, aor. _u {yaxomuSu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xumoSN (Mṣb, TA) and xamoSN (A, TA) and maxamaSapN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) the last an inf. n. like magobaDapN and maEotabapN, (Ṣ,) [but in art. Etb in the Ṣ, maEotabapN is said to be a subst.,] The thing was, or became, hungry. (Ṣ,* A,* Mṣb, Ḳ.*)
xamaSahu AljuwEu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxomuSu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. xamoSN and maxomaSapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xumuwSN, (TḲ, [but this last I think doubtful,]) Hunger rendered him lank in the belly. (TḲ.)

entry.sense: 6. txAmS Eanohu ‡ He shrank, or drew away, from it; (A, Ḳ;*) i. e., from anything of which he disliked the nearness. (A.) You say, masasotuhu biyadiI wahoIa baAridapN fataxaAmaSa mino barodi yadiI ‡ [I touched him with my hand, it being cold, and he shrank from the coldness of my hand]. (A, TA.)
taxaAmaSo lifulaAnK Eano Haq-ihi ‡ [Relinquish thou, i. e.,] give thou, to such a one, his right, or due. (A, Ḳ.*)
txAmS All-ayolu ‡ [The night retreated;] the darkness of the night became thin a little before daybreak. (A, Ḳ.)
xamoSapN A hungering. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, layosa lilobaTonapi xayorN mino xamoSapK tatobaEuhaA [There is not anything better for repletion of the belly than a hungering which follows it]. (Ṣ, A.)
xamoSaI: see xamiySN.
xumoSaAnN: see OaxomaSu:
and see also xamiySN, in two places.
xamaSaAnN: see xamiySN.
xamiySN Empty; applied to the belly: (TA:) hungry. (Mṣb.)

xamiySu AlbaToni, (A,) or xamiySu AlHaXaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and xumoSaAnN↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and xamaSaAnN↓, (A, Ḳ,) A man empty in the belly, (A,) or lank in the belly; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xaAmiSN↓ AlbaToni: (Ḳ * and TA in art. rhf:) and slender in make: (TA:) fem. of the first with p {xamiySapN}, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and so of the second {xumoSaAnapN}, (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and so of the third {xamaSaAnapN}; (TA;) and IAạr mentions xamoSaI↓ as a fem., occurring prefixed to AlHaXaA in a verse of El-Asamm Ed-Dubeyree: (TA:) pl., (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) masc., (A, Ḳ,) ximaASN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and fem., [i. e., of xmySp,] xamaAYiSu: (A, Ḳ:) xumoSaAnN↓ has no pl. formed by the addition of w and n, though its fem. is formed by the addition of p; being made to accord with the measure faEolaAnN, of which the fem. is faEolaI. (TA.) ximaASN [also] signifies Hungry, in a pl. sense, (Ḳ,) and lank in the bellies: (TA:) mixomaASN↓ also signifies the same as xamiySN; and [its pl.] maxaAmiySu, lank in the bellies (xumoSu AlbuTuwni [whence it appears that OaxomaSu↓, sing. of xumoSN, is also syn. with xamiySN]). (TA.) You say also, huwa xamiySu AlbaToni mino OamowaAli Aln-aAsi, meaning ‡ He is one who abstains from [devouring] the possessions of men. (A.) And ximaASu AlbuTuwni mino OamowaAli Aln-aAsi xifaAfu AlZ-uhuwri mino damaAYihimo, (A, TA,) meaning ‡ Persons who abstain from [devouring] the possessions of men, whose backs are light with respect to [the] burden [of their blood]. (TA, from a trad.)
zamanN xamiySN ‡ A time of hunger. (A, TA.)

xamiySapN A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, black, square, and having EalamaAni [i. e. two ornamental or coloured or figured borders]: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ:) or a black ksAC, having a border such as is above described (muEolam) at each end, and which is of xaz-, [q. v.], or of wool: (Mṣb:) if not bordered, it is not so called: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or, accord. to Aṣ, a mulaMCap of wool, or of xaz-, bordered (muEolamap); not unless bordered: so called because of its softness and thinness, and smallness of bulk when it is folded: Aḥmad Ibn-Fáris says that it is the black kisaMC: and he says that it may be thus called because a man wraps himself with it, so that it is against his OaxomaS, meaning by this his waist: (Ḥar p. 21:) pl. xamaAYiSu: or xmAYS are garments of xaz-, thick, black, and red, and having thick OaEolaAm [or borders such as above described]; worn by people of old. (TA.) El-Aạshà says,
UicaA jur-idato yawomFA Hasibota xamiySapF
EalayohaA wajiroyaAla Aln-aDiyri Ald-ulaAmiSaA
[When she is stripped of her clothing, any day, thou wouldst think there was upon her a khameesah, and the glistening redness of gold]: Aṣ says, he likens her [long and spreading] hair to a xmySp, which is black. (Ṣ.) [See also xamiysN, voce ximosN, near the end of the paragraph.]
xaAmiSu AlbaToni: see xamiySN.

OaxomaSu Alqadami A man whose foot rises from the ground, [or is hollow in the middle of the sole,] so that it does not touch it: fem. xamoSaMCu: and pl. xumoSN: (Mṣb:) and xumoSaAnN↓ signifies having the middle of the sole of the foot moderately rising from the ground; which is a goodly quality; but when it is flat, or rises much, it is dispraised: so explained by IAạr when he was asked by Th respecting ʼAlee's saying of Moḥammad, [cited, but not explained, in the Ḳ,] kaAna xumoSaAna AlOaxomaSayoni: or, accord. to Az, xumoSaAnN signifies having the part [of the sole] of the foot which does not cleave to the ground in treading very much retiring from the ground. (TA.)

AlOaxomaSu [when without the article Al also written without tenween accord. to the best authorities, because the quality of an epithet is original to it, and that of a subst. is accidental,] also signifies The part [of the sole] of the human foot which does not cleave to the ground in treading; (Az, TA;) the part of the sole of the human foot which is hollow, so that it does not touch the ground; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) the part of the bottom of the human foot which is thin, and retires from the ground; or, as some explain it, [meaning the same,] the xaSor of the human foot: (TA:) pl. OaxaAmiSu. (Mṣb.)
See also xamiySN.
Also The waist of a man. (Ḥar p. 21.)
mixomaASN: see xamiySN.

xamoTN The [kind of tree called] OaraAk: (Bḍ in xxxiv. 15:) or a species of the ArAk, having a fruit which is eaten: (Lth, Ṣ:) or the fruit of the ArAk: (IB, Ḳ:) or any trees having no thorns: (IDrd, Bḍ, Ḳ:) or trees having thorns; cited from Fr; and by Z, in the Ksh, on the authority of AʼObeyd: (TA:) or certain trees like the sidor, (Ḳ, TA,) the fruit of which is like the mulberry: (TA:) or certain deadly trees: (Ḳ:) or deadly poison: (TA:) or any plant that has acquired a taste of bitterness, (Zj, Bḍ, Ḳ,) so that it cannot be eaten: (Zj, TA:) or scanty fruit of any trees: (AḤn, Ḳ:) or the fruit of what is called fasowapu AlD-abuEi: (Ḳ:) or a certain fruit called fasowapu AlD-abuEi, having the form of the poppy, friable, and of no use: (IAạr:) or it signifies, in the Ḳur xxxiv. 15, fruit that is disagreeable in taste, and choking: (Bḍ:) or, [as an epithet,] bitter, and disagreeable in taste, and choking: (Jel:) or bitter; applied to anything: or acid. (Ḳ.) In the Ḳur, ubi suprà, some read, cawaAtaIo Oakuli xamoTK: (Ṣ, IB, Jel:) this is the right reading accord. to him who makes xmT to mean the ArAk: but accord. to him who makes it to mean the fruit of the ArAk, the right reading of Akl is with tenween, and xmT is a substitute for that word. (IB.) [The pl. is ximaATN: see an ex. voce xal-N.]

1. xamaEa, (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaxomaEu}, inf. n. xamoEN (Lth, IDrd, Ḳ) and xumuwEN (Lth, Ḳ) and xamaEaAnN, (Az, Ḳ,) said of a hyena, (Ḳ,), &c., (TA,) He limped, or had a slight lameness, (IDrd, Ṣ,) in his gait, or manner of going; (Ṣ;) he went as though he had a lameness. (Ḳ, TA.)
ximoEN A wolf: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. OaxomaAEN. (TA.)
And hence, (TA,) † A thief. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
xumaAEN A limping, or slight lameness (IDrd, Ṣ;) a manner of going as though with a lameness; a subst. from the above-mentioned verb. (Ḳ.) You say, bihi xumaAEN [He has a limping,, &c.]. (Ṣ.)
xamuwEN, applied to a woman, Vitious, or immoral; an adulteress, or a fornicatress; as also xayomaEN↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
xaAmiEN [Limping, or having a slight lameness;] going as though having a lameness. (TA.)
And hence, (TA,) xaAmiEapN A hyena, or a female hyena: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. xawaAmiEu. (Ḳ.)
xayomaEN: see xamuwEN.

hom.sense: 1. xamala, aor. _u {yaxomulu}, inf. n. xumuwlN, It (a place of alighting or abode, Mṣb, TA, and a tattooing, TA) was, or became, effaced, or obliterated; (Mṣb, TA;) and imperceptible, or unapparent. (TA.)

And hence, (Mṣb,) said of a man, aor. and inf. n. as above, He was, or became, obscure, unnoted, reputeless, or of no reputation: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) [and] said of a man's reputation (cikoruhu, JK, Ḳ, and Sawotuhu, Ḳ), aor. as above, (JK,) and so the inf. n., (JK, Ḳ,) it was, or became, obscure. (JK, Ḳ.)
Some mention also xamula, inf. n. xamaAlapN; and this inf. n. occurs in a description of the Prophet; but it is only for the purpose of assimilation to its contr. nabaAhapN. (TA.)
[It is app. also said of speech, meaning It was, or became, low, soft, or gentle: see xaAmilN.]
xumila He (a man, and a beast, Ḳ, a horse, a sheep or goat, and a camel, TA) had, or was affected with, the malady termed xumaAl. (Ḳ.)
4. Axml He (a man, Ṣ, or God, Ḳ) rendered a person obscure, unnoted, reputeless, or of no reputation; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) contr. of nab-aha. (TA.)
He made a [garment such as is termed] qaTiyfap, and the like, to have what is termed xamol [i. e. a nap, or pile, or villous substance on its surface]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8. Axtml He pastured, or depastured, xamaAYil, (Ḳ,) i. e. meadows [&c., pl. of xamiylap]. (TA.)

xamolN [The nap, or pile, or villous substance on the surface, of cloth;] i. q. hudobN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or the hudob of the [kind of garment called] qaTiyfap [q. v.] and the like, (Ḳ, TA,) of woven cloths whereof portions [of the substance] are redundant; (TA;) or [rather] what resembles hudob on the surface of a kisaMC [or the like]; (Mgh;) the xamol of a [carpet such as is called] Tunofusap [or Tinofisap, &c.] and of a garment; as also xamiylapN↓, of which the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] is xamiylN↓. (JK.)

Also A Tinofisap [itself]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or so xamiylapN↓: and xamolN signifies as first explained above, and also a qaTiyfap [itself]: (Mṣb:) or xamiylapN↓ has this last meaning; as also xamolapN↓ and ximolapN↓; (Ḳ,* TA; [in the CK, kaAlxamiylahi wAlxamolapu is erroneously put for kAlxamolapi wAlximolapi;]) or signifies a qTyfp having xamol [or nap]: (TA:) and its pl. [or coll. gen. n.] is as above. (Mṣb, TA.)
And The feathers,, or plumage, of the ostrich; (JK, T, M, Ḳ;) as also xamaAlapN↓ and xamiylapN↓; (T, M, Ḳ;) of which last the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] is as above. (TA.)
xamolapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

Also, and ximolapN↓, A garment (Lth, Ḳ) of wool, (Lth,) having xamol [or nap], such as the kisaMC and the like: (Lth, Ḳ:) or an EabaMC of the fabric of Katawán, white, and with short xamol [or nap]. (Az, TA.)

hom.sense: ximolapN: see xamolN: and xamolapN.

Also A man's secret, which he conceals: and his secret disposition of the mind. (Ḳ.) One says, AisoOalo Eano ximolaAtihi [in the CK xamolAtih] Ask thou concerning his secrets, and his bad, evil, or foul, qualities, dispositions, habits, practices, or actions. (Ḳ, TA.) And huwa laYiymu Alximolapi [He is base, ignoble, or mean, in respect of the secret disposition of the mind], and kariymuhaA [generous in respect thereof]: (Fr, Ḳ:) or it is applied peculiarly to baseness, ignobleness, or meanness: (AZ, Ḳ:) Hasanu Alximolapi has not been heard. (AZ.)

entry.sense: xumaAlN Lameness: or, accord. to AʼObeyd, a limping, or slight lameness, in the legs of camels, which is cured by cutting the vein: (Ṣ:) or a malady in the joints of a man, (Ḳ,) resembling lameness, (TA,) and in the legs of a beast, (Ḳ,) a horse, a sheep or goat, and a camel, (TA,) occasioning a limping, or slight lameness: (Ḳ:) or a malady that affects the horse, (T, TA,) or the camel, (JK,) in consequence of which he will not move until he has a vein cut; otherwise he dies: (JK, T, TA:) and also a malady that affects a leg of the sheep or goat, and then shifts to the other legs, going the round of them. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: xamiylN pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of xamiylapN in three senses explained above: see xamolN.
Also garments having xamol [or nap]. (Ḳ.)
A black garment. (JK.)
‡ Dense clouds. (IDrd, Ḳ, TA.)
‡ Soft food; (Ḳ, TA;) meaning such as is termed variyd: mentioned by ISd. (TA.)
See also maxomuwlN.

entry.sense: xamaAlapN: see xamolN.
xamiylapN: see xamolN, in four places.

Also A dense collection of trees; (JK, Ṣ;) so says Aboo-Sá'id: (Ṣ:) or numerous tangled, or luxuriant, or dense, trees, (Ḳ, TA,) among which one sees not a thing when it falls in the midst thereof: (TA:) and a place abounding in trees, wherever it be, (Ḳ,) or, accord. to Az, only in plain, level, or soft, ground: (TA:) and a low, or depressed, tract of ground, (Ḳ,* TA,) or of sand, (M, TA,) or an intervening tract between low, or depressed, and hard, ground, (T, TA,) or an intervening tract amid sands, in low, or depressed, and hard, ground, (JK,) and producing good herbage or plants: (JK, T, Ḳ, TA:) or plain, or soft, land, producing herbage or plants, which are likened to the xamol [or nap] of the qaTiyfap: or a place where water remains and stagnates, and which produces trees; but only in plain, level, or soft, ground: (TA:) or a meadow (rawoDapN) in which are trees; that in which are no trees being termed jaloHaMCu: (Ḥar p. 118:) or a tract of sand producing trees: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a place where a tract of sand becomes thin, or shallow; where the main portion of it passes away, and somewhat of the soft part of it remains: pl. xamaAYilu: which is also explained as signifying meadows (riyaAD). (TA.)

xaAmilN A man obscure, unnoted, reputeless, or of no reputation; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) unknown, (JK, T,) and unmentioned; (T;) destitute of good fortune: (Mṣb:) and one says also xaAminN, by substitution [of n for l]: (TA:) pl. xamalN (Ḳ) and xamalapN, explained as signifying the lower or lowest, or meaner or meanest, sort of mankind. (TA.) You say also qawolN xaAmilN A low, soft, or gentle, saying or speech. (Az, TA.) And it is said in a trad., AucokuruwA Qll-ehi cikorFA xaAmilFA Celebrate ye God with a low, soft, or gentle, voice, in reverence of his greatness, or majesty. (TA.)
muxomalN A garment, (JK, TA,) or a kisaMC, (Mgh, Mṣb,) having xamol [or nap], (JK,* Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) i. e. what resembles hudob on its surface. (Mgh.)

maxomuwlN (JK, TA) and maxomuwlapN, (JK,) applied to a young camel, (JK,) or to a camel, and a horse, (TA,) and a sheep or goat, (XAp, JK, TA,) Having, or affected with, the disease termed xumaAl: (JK, TA:) and so xamiylN↓, applied to a young camel; pl. xamolaI. (JK.)

1. xamana, [aor. _u {yaxomunu},] inf. n. xumuwnN, said of [a man's] reputation (Alc-ikoru), It was, or became, obscure; i. q. xamala, inf. n. xumuwlN: and, said of a thing, it was, or became, obscure, unapparent, hidden, or concealed: whence xamanahu as syn. with xam-anahu, q. v. (Mṣb.)

2. xm-nhu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxomiynN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and xamanahu↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxominu}, inf. n. xamonN; (Mṣb;) He spoke of it conjecturally, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and opining; (TA;) or surmising: (Ḳ:) or he formed a surmise respecting it; or an opinion. (Mṣb.) IDrd says, I think it to be post-classical: (TA:) AḤát says that it is of Persian origin, (Mṣb, TA,) arabicized, (TA,) from xmAnA, [app. a mistranscription for GumaAnaA, or GumaAnaho, or GumaAno,] applied to “an opinion,” and “a conjecture,” or “conjectural saying.” (Mṣb, TA.)
taxomiynN is also syn. with taHoriyrN. (So in the TA. [But this, I doubt not, is a mistranscription for taHoziyzN, which, though perhaps post-classical, signifies The act of conjecturing.])
xamanN Stink. (Ḳ.)
[xamaAnN The elder-tree: and xamaAnN SagiyrN Dwarf elder-tree: so in the present day.]
xam-aAnN A weak spear: and qanaApN xam-aAnapN [a weak spear or spear-shaft]. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
What is bad of household-goods, or furniture, or utensils: (TA:) and The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, or mankind; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the bad thereof. (Ḳ.) [Mentioned also in art. xm.]
xaAminu Alc-ikori A man (TA) obscure, unnoted, reputeless, of no reputation; i. q. xaAmilu Alc-ikori. (Ḳ, TA.)
xaAmK (accus. xaAmiyFA) for xaAmisN: see the latter word.

hom.sense: 1. xan-a, (Sh, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yaxin-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xaniynN, (Sh, Ṣ,*, Ḳ * TA,) He made a sound from the nose, like Haniyn from the mouth: (TA:) he made a sound like weeping, (Ṣ,*, Ḳ * TA,) and (so in the Ṣ, but in the Ḳ “or”) like laughing, in the nose: (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA:) he reiterated a sound of weeping in the air-passages of the nose; and sometimes xaniynN is [the reiterating a sound in the nose] from faint laughing: (Sh, TA:) or he laughed faintly. (JK.) [See also xaniynN below.]
xun-a He (a camel) was affected with the disease termed xunaAn: (JK, TA:) [and in like manner, a bird: see maxonuwnN.]

entry.sense: 4. Ojn-ahu Qll-ehu i. q. Oajan-ahu [God caused him to be bereft of reason; or mad, insane,, &c.]. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

R. Q. 1. xanoxana, (TA,) inf. n. xanoxanapN, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) [like xamoxama,] He snuffled; i. e., spoke through his nose: (TA:) he spoke indistinctly, making a sort of twang (yuxanoxinu) in his xayaAXiym [or air-passages of the nose]. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.) A poet says,
xanoxana liI fiI qawolihi saAEapF
faqaAla liI XayoYFA walamo OasomaEi
[He snuffled to me in his speech awhile, and said to me something, but I heard not]. (TA.)
xanoxanapN also signifies The crying of the ape. (IAạr, TA.)

xun-apN i. q. gun-apN [i. e. A nasal sound or twang; or a snuffling sound]; (JK, Ḳ;) the latter word explained by Mbr as meaning a mixture of the sound of the xayoXuwm [or air-passage of the nose] in the pronunciation of a letter or word; (TA;) as also maxan-apN↓: (Ḳ:) or the first is like gun-apN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also xananN↓: (ISd, TA:) or, (Mbr, Ḳ,) as also maxan-apN↓, (TA,) louder than gun-apN: (Mbr, Ḳ, TA:) or more open than gun-apN: (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, OaqobaHu is put in the place of OafotaHu.])
xananN: see what next precedes.

xunaAnN A certain disease that attacks in the nose: (Ṣ, TA:) a disease that attack camels in their nostrils, and from which they die; (Aṣ, TA;) a rheum that affects camels; (Ḳ;) in camels, like the zukaAm in human beings. (JK.) zamanu AlxunaAni [The time of the xnAn] was in the age of El-Mundhir Ibn-Má-es-Semà; in consequence thereof the camels died: (Ḳ:) it is well known with the Arabs, is mentioned in their verses, (TA,) and became an era to them. (Aṣ, TA.)
Also A certain disease that attacks birds in their throats. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
And A certain disease in the eye. (M, Ḳ.)

xaniynN The issuing of a sound from the nose, like HaniynN from the mouth: [see HaniynN, in two places:] this is the primary signification: (TA:) and it is [the making a sound] like weeping, and (so in the Ṣ, but in the Ḳ “or”) like laughing, in the nose: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) IB says that there is a kind of xnyn like weeping in the nose: (TA:) or a weeping of women, (JK,) or a kind of weeping, (IAth, TA,) less than what is termed AinotiHaAbN: (JK, IAth, TA:) and a faint laughing. (JK.) [See also 1.]
And Stoppages in the xayaAXiym [or air-passages of the nose]. (TA.)

Oaxan-N i. q. Oagan-N [as meaning Having a nasal twang]; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) who snuffles; i. e., speaks from [i. e. through] his nose: (TA voce Oadogamu:) [or] as meaning having the xayaAXiym [or airpassages of the nose] stopped up: or, as some say, having the xyAXym [here app. meaning certain cartilages in the upper, or inmost, part of the nose] delapsed: [see 1 in art. xXm:] fem. xan-aMCu: (TA:) and pl. xun-N. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: maxan-apN: see xun-apN, in two places.
Also The nose: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) written by J [accord. to some of the copies of the Ṣ, but not accord. to all,] with kesr to the m: (TA:) or the extremity thereof. (Ḳ.)
And i. q. maOokalapN: so in the phrase, fulaAnN maxan-apN lifulaAnK [Such a one is to such a one a person from whom to obtain what to eat]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
