You say also, AlbiT-iyxu liI maxan-apN i. e. [The melon, or water-melon, is to me] a usual food. (JM.)

entry.sense: maxonuwnN A camel, and a bird, affected with the disease termed xunaAn. (TA.)
And i. q. majonuwnN [Bereft of reason; or mad, insane,, &c.]. (Lḥ, Ḳ.) [See R. Q. 1 in art. xm.]

hom.sense: 1. xanava, (Lth, L,) aor. _i {yaxonivu}, inf. n. xanovN, (L,) He folded, or doubled, a skin for water or milk, and a sack. (Lth, L.) And xanava Als-iqaMCa, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) and fama Als-iqaMCi, (A, TA,) and Axtnv↓ AlsqMCi, (Ṣ, A,* Mgh, Ḳ,) He doubled the skin, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the mouth of the skin, (A, Mgh, TA,) outwards, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) or inside-out, (TA,) and drank from it; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) the doing of which is forbidden (Mgh, TA) by Moḥammad: (TA:) when you double it inwards, you say, qabaEotuhu: (Ṣ, A, Mgh:) or xanava fama Als-iqaMCi signifies he turned the mouth of the skin outsidein or inside-out: and xanovN signifies any kind of inverting, or turning upside-down or inside-out or the like. (TA.)

[Hence, app.,] xanava lahu biOanofihi [He contracted his nose at him]; as though he mocked at, scoffed at, derided, or ridiculed, him: so in the A: but in the Ḳ, xanavahu, aor. _i {yaxonivu}, he mocked at, scoffed at, derided, or ridiculed, him. (TA.)

xanavN, aor. _a {yaxonavu}, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. xanavN; (A, Mṣb, TA;) and Anxv↓, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and txn-v↓; (A, L, Ḳ;) He (a man, L) affected a bending, or an inclining of his body, from side to side, and languor, or languidness; or he became bent and languid; syn. tavan-aI watakas-ara: (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:) [or he was, or became, flaccid, or flabby, and affected a bending, or an inclining of his body, from side to side: (see xanivN:) or he was, or became, effeminate: (see xunovN:)] or he was, or became, soft, delicate, tender, flabby, lax, or limber, and affected languor, or languidness; expl. by kaAna fiyhi liynN watakas-urN. (Mṣb.) ʼÁïsheh, describing the death of Moḥammad, says, Ainoxanava↓ fiI HajoriI, meaning He became bent and languid (AinovanaI watakas-ara), by reason of the flaccidness of his limbs, in my bosom. (TA.)
2. xn-vhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxoniyvN, (Ḳ,) He bent it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, a thing. (Ṣ.) Hence the epithet muxan-avN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He made him to be, or become, such as is termed xanivN. (Mṣb.)
xn-v kalaAmahu He made his speech like that of women, in softness and gentleness: so some say. (Mṣb.)
taxoniyvN also signifies The doing what is excessively foul, or obscene; [i. e. the acting the part of a catamite;] but this meaning was unknown to the Arabs [of the classical ages]. (MF.)

entry.sense: 5. txn-v It (a thing, Ṣ) bent, or became bent. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Also i. q. xaniva, q. v. (A,* L, Ḳ.) And He (a man) acted in the manner of the muxin-av [or effeminate,, &c.]. (TA.) [He became a muxan-av: used in this sense in the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. Tws.] And txn-v fiI kalaAmihi [He was soft, or effeminate, in his speech]. (Ṣ, Mgh.)
He (a man, &c.) fell down by reason of weakness. (TA.)
7. Anxnvt Alqirobapu The water-skin became folded, or doubled. (L.)
Anxnvt Eunuquhu His neck inclined, or bent. (TA.)
See also 1, in two places.
8: see 1, second sentence.

xunovN a subst. from Ainoxanava [An affectation of a bending, or of an inclining of the body, from side to side, and of languor, or languidness; or a bending and languidness: or flaccidity or flabbiness, and an affectation of a bending, or of an inclining of the body, from side to side: or effeminacy: or softness, delicacy, tenderness, flabbiness, laxness, or limberness, and an affectation of languor, or languidness]: (Ṣ, L:) as also xinaAvapN↓. (Mṣb.) Jereer says,
OatuwEiduniI waOanota mujaAXiEiI-N
OaraI fiI xunovi liHoyatika QDoTiraAbaA
[Dost thou threaten me, thou being a Mujáshi'ee? I see, in the softness and weakness of thy beard, or in the bending and languidness, or the effeminacy, of thy person, (for the beard is sometimes, by a synecdoche, put for the whole person,) an evidence of unsoundness, uncompactness, or weakness]. (Ṣ.)

xinovN, with kesr, sing. of OaxonaAvN and xinaAvN, (TA,) which signify The creases, or places of folding, of a garment, or piece of cloth. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, TawaI Alv-awoba EalaI OaxonaAvihi and xinaAvihi He folded the garment, or piece of cloth, at its creases. (TA.) And [hence,] OaloqaI All-ayolu OaxonaAvapu EalaI AlOaroDi † The night cast the folds of its darkness upon the earth. (TA.)
Also the former pl., (TA,) and the latter also, (Ḳ,) The parts of the dalow [or bucket] whence the water pours forth, between the EaraAqiI. (Ḳ, TA.)
The sing. also signifies The interior of the part of the cheek by the side of the mouth, next the molar teeth, (Ḳ, TA,) above and below. (TA.)
And A company in a state of dispersion. (Ḳ.)

xanivN One in whom is an affectation of a bending, or of an inclining of the body, from side to side, and of languor, or languidness; or in whom is a bending and languidness; expl. by mano fiyhi tavan-K watakas-urN: (A, L, Ḳ:) or flaccid, or flabby, and affecting a bending, or an inclining of the body, from side to side: (Ṣ:) [or effeminate; like muxan-avN]: or one in whom is softness, delicacy, tenderness, flabbiness, laxness, or limberness, and an affectation of languor, or languidness: (Mṣb:) fem. with p {xanivapN}. (TA.) And xunuvN↓ (TA) and mixonaAvN↓, (Ḳ,) applied to a woman, (Ḳ, TA,) Soft, delicate, tender, flabby, lax, or limber, (TA,) and affecting languor, or languidness: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. of the latter maxaAniyvu. (TA.)
One says to such a woman, yaAxanaAvi↓, (Ḳ,) [indecl.,] like qaTaAmi; (TA;) and to a man [of the same description], yaA xunavu↓. (Ḳ.)
yaA xunavu: see the next preceding paragraph.
xunuvN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: [A hermaphrodite;] one who has what is proper to the male and what is proper to the female: Kr makes it an epithet, and says rajulN xunovaI; (TA;) one who has what is proper to men and what is proper to women, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) together; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) one who has, by creation, the anterior pudendum of a man and that of a woman: (Mṣb:) in the language of the lawyers, one who has what are proper to both sexes; or who has neither that of a man nor that of a woman: but some of them say that the former meaning is the proper one; and that he who has no external organ of generation is adjoined to the class of the xnvI as being subject to the same special laws: (MF, TA:) the pl. is xanaAvaI (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xinaAvN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Also The plant called barowaAqN [i. e. the asphodel]. (Ḳ in art. brq.)

entry.sense: yaA xanaAvi: see xanitN.
xaniyvN A skin of the kind called qirobap folded, or doubled. (L.)
xunaAvapu: see muxan-avN.
xinaAvapN: see xunovN.
Hunayovapu: see muxan-atu.

Oaxonavu mino dalaAli [More effeminate, or more incapable of venery, than Delál]: a prov. (Ṣ, TA.) Delál was a certain man of El-Medeeneh, (TA,) who was made a eunuch, together with several other muxan-avuwn. (TA in art. dl. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 451; where the name is erroneously written dal-aAl.])

muxan-avN, from xan-ava “he bent,” (Ṣ, Ḳ,) because of his softness, delicacy, tenderness, flabbiness, laxness, or limberness, and affectation of languor, or languidness; (TA;) or from xunovaI; (Kh, JK, MṢ;) An effeminate man; (T in art. Anv, and TA;) one who resembles a woman in gentleness, and in softness of speech, and in an affectation of languor of the limbs: (TA voce muWan-avN, q. v.: [see also xanivN:]) it is written thus and muxan-ivN↓: (TA:) this latter is explained by some as meaning one who makes his speech like that of women, in softness and gentleness: (Mṣb, TA:) it is also said that both these epithets are used to signify one who affects languor, or languidness, of the limbs; one who makes himself like women in the bending of himself, and in affecting languor, or languidness, and in speech: but that one uses the latter epithet only when he means one who does what is excessively foul, or obscene; [i. e. a catamite; though this is a meaning often borne by the former also;] notwithstanding that taxoniyvN, as signifying the “committing such an action,” was unknown to the Arabs [of the classical ages], and is not found in their language: (MF, TA:) [often, also,] the former epithet signifies a man incapable of venery: (MA:) it is said in a trad. that they used to reckon the mxn-v as one of those having no need of nikaAH. (TA in art. Arb.) The muxan-av is also called xunaAvapu↓ and xunayovapu↓ [each imperfectly decl.]. (Ḳ, TA.)
muxan-ivN: see what next precedes.
mixonaAvN: see xanivN.

hom.sense: xanojarN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xinojirN (Mṣb) and xinojarN, (Ḳ,) the last of a rare form, like dirohamN, (TA,) A knife: or a great knife: (Ḳ:) or a kind of large knife [or dagger, generally curved, and double-edged], (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) called in Persian daXonaho: (Mgh:) pl. xanaAjiru. (Mṣb.) Some say, [as, for instance, the author of the Mṣb,] that the n is augmentative, the measure being fnEl. (TA.)
Also the first, (Ḳ,) and xunojuwrN↓, (Aṣ, Ṣ, TA,) or xunojuwrapN↓, and xanojarapN↓, (Ḳ,) A she-camel abounding with milk: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. xanaAjiru. (Ṣ.) And xunojuwrapN↓ A bulky she-camel. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xanojarapN: see above.
xunojuwrN and xunojuwrapN: see xanojarN, in three places.

xanodariysN Wine; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) so called because of its oldness: (Ṣ:) or old wine: (TA:) [accord. to some,] derived from xadorasapN, a word not explained: (Ḳ:) by some said to be of the measure fanoEaliysN, so that its radical letters are xdr; because wine is muxad-ir [i. e. a cause of torpor or languor]: by some said to be from xarosN; but to this it is objected that d is not augmentative: the truth is, that it is of the measure faEolaliylN, as Sb says: (MF:) by the author of the L and others, it is mentioned after art. xns: (TA:) or it is a Greek word, arabicized: (Ḳ:) [but I know not how this is, unless, as an epithet applied to wheat, (see what follows,) it be supposed to be from χόνδρος:] IDrd thought it to be an arabicized word: it may be an arabicized word from the Persian xanodaho riyXo, meaning “having a laughing beard,” [or rather “one whose beard is laughed at,” i. e., “a laughing-stock,”] because he who makes use of it [namely of wine] has his beard laughed at. (TA.)
You also say, HinoTap xanodariysN Old wheat: (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and tamorN xanodariysN old dates. (TA.)
Q. 1. xanodaqahu (Ḳ) and xanodaqa Hawolahu (TA) He dug a xanodaq, i. e. fosse, or moat, around it. (Ḳ,* TA.) [In the CK the words of this art. are with c in the place of d.]
xanodaqN A fosse, or moat, [such as is] dug around the walls of cities: arabicized, from kanodaho, (IDrd, Ḳ,) which is Persian: (IDrd:) pl. xanaAdiqu. (TA.)
And A valley. (TA.)
muxanodiqN One who makes a xanodaq [i. e. fosse, or moat]. (JK.)
xanodaquwqN Tall. (TA. [But perhaps this is a mistranscription for HanodaquwqN, q. v.])
xanaw-arN and Alxanaw-arN and Oum-u xanaw-arK: see what follows, in four places.

hom.sense: xan-uwrN and xanaw-arN↓ Any soft and weak tree: (Ḳ:) or such is called xnwrp [i. e. xan-uwrapN or Hanaw-arapN: each, without p, being app. a coll. gen. n.; and with p, a n. un.]. (TA.)
And hence, accord. to AḤn, (TA,) The reeds of [which are made] arrows. (Ḳ.)

Oum-u xan-uwrK (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Oum-u xin-aworK (Ḳ) The female hyena: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or she is called by the latter appellation, accord. to Aboo-Riyásh: or, as some say, these are surnames of the hyena. (TA.) And The cow [probably the wild cow]. (Aboo-Riyásh, Ḳ.)
Also Calamity, or misfortune. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, waqaEa Alqawomu fiI Oum-i xan-uwrK The people, or party, fell into calamity, or misfortune. (L, TA. But see two other explanations in what follows.)

And Plentifulness, and pleasantness or easiness, and softness or delicacy, of life; or a life of softness or delicacy, and ease, comfort, or affluence; syn. Aln-aEomapu: [in the CK Aln-iEomapu; which is in many instances in the CK, as I hold it to be in the present instance, erroneously substituted for Aln-aEomapu:] thus bearing two contrary significations: and Alxan-uwru and Alxanaw-aru↓ signify the same, such as is apparent; (Ḳ;) or, as some say, abundant. (TA.) Some explain the saying above-mentioned as meaning The people, or party, fell into a state of plenty, or abundance, and softness or delicacy or easiness of life. (TA.)
And The deserts; syn. AlS-aHaAraI: and so accord. to some in the saying mentioned above. (TA.)

And The podex, or the anus; syn. AlAisotu: (Ḳ:) but AḤát doubts respecting the teshdeed of the n; [app. whether this letter be doubled, or the w;] Aboo-Sahl says that it is Oum-u xin-aworK [only]: and IKh says that it means the Aisot of the bitch. (TA.)

entry.sense: 1. xaniza, aor. _a {yaxonazu}; (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) and xanaza, aor. _u {yaxonuzu}; (Mṣb;) inf. n. of the former, xanazN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of the former also, (Ḳ,) or of the latter, (Mṣb,) xunuwzN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) It (flesh-meat, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, and a date, and a walnut, TA) became stinking: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or altered [in odour]: (Mṣb:) or maggotty and stinking: (TA:) like xazina. (Ṣ.)
xanazN: see what next follows.
xanizN, applied to flesh-meat, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and to a date, and a walnut, (TA,) Stinking: (Ḳ:) or altered [in odour]: (Mṣb:) or maggotty and stinking: (TA:) as also xanazN↓. (Yaạḳoob, Ḳ.)
xunozuwapN: see what next follows.
xunozuwaAnN: see what next follows.

xunozuwaAnapN Pride; self-magnification; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also xunozuwaAnN↓, and xunozuwaAniy-apN↓, and xunozuwapN↓: (Ḳ:) so called because it changes one from the right state: (TA:) pl. of the first, xunozuwaAnaAtN. (Ṣ.) You say, huwa cuw xunozuwaAnaAtN [He possesses proud feelings]. (Ṣ.) And fiyhi xunozuwaAnapN In him is pride. (A.) And laOanozaEan-a xunozuwaAnataka [I will assuredly pluck out thy pride]. (TA.)
xunozuwaAniy-apN: see the next preceding paragraph.
xanaAzi Stinking: (Ḳ:) used as a proper name, (TA,) applied to a woman: (Ḳ, TA:) from xaniza said of flesh-meat. (TA.)
xanozara and xinoziyrN: see art. xzr.

hom.sense: 1. xanasa, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxonusu}, (Ṣ,) or _i, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or both, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xunuwsN, (A,) or xanosN, (Mṣb,) or both, (Ḳ, TA,) and xunaAsN, (TA,) He went, or drew, back or backwards; receded; retreated; retired; or retrograded: or he remained behind; held back; hung back; or lagged behind: syn. taOax-ara: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) Eanohu from him or it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or mino bayoni Alqawomi from among the company of people: and hid himself: (A:) or and shrank, or drew himself together: (TA:) and Anxns↓ signifies the same; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so Axtns↓; and xanusa, aor. _u {yaxonusu}, is mentioned by Ṣgh: (TA:) or xanasa signifies he went back,, &c., syn. tOx-r: and also, he shrank, or drew himself together: (Mgh, Mṣb:*) and he hid himself; became hidden or absent. (TA.) You say, xanasa Alkawokabu ‡ The star returned, or went back, or retrograded: syn. rajaEa; a tropical signification: (A: [and in the TA it is said that xanosN is syn. with rujuwEN, and is tropical in this sense:]) or became hidden, (Ḳ, TA,) like a gazelle in its covert, (TA,) or like the devil when he hears the mention of God: (Ḳ, TA:) or became concealed in the day-time: (TA:) and xunuwsN signifies also the being, or becoming, depressed. (Ḥam p. 332.) And xanasa Eani Alqawomi He held back, or hung back, from the company of people; remained behind them, not going with them; syn, taxal-afa; (Aṣ, on the authority of an Arab of the desert, of the Benoo- 'Okeyl;) as also Anxns↓. (Ḳ.) [This is said in the TA to be tropical; but why, I see not.] And xanasati Aln-axolu † The palm-trees were backward to receive fecundation, (taOax-arato Eano qabuwli Alt-aloqiyHi, lit, held back from receiving fecundation,) so that it had not any effect upon them, and they did not bear fruit that year. (TA.) And yaxonisu AlX-ayoTaAnu UicaA samiEa cikora Qll-ehi The devil shrinks when he hears the mention of God. (Mṣb.) And xanasa mino bayoni OaSoHaAbihi He hid himself from among his companions. (TA.) And xanasa Ean-iI ‡ He, or it, [app. the latter,] became hid from me. (A.) And xanasa bihi He went away with him; took him away; so that he was not seen; (ISh, Ḳ;) as also txn-s↓ bh: (Ḳ:) and he hid him, or it. (TA.)
See also 4, in four places.

xanisa AlOanofN, aor. _a {yaxonasu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xanasN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) The nose was, or became, [camous, or camoys, i. e.,] depressed in its bone: (Mṣb:) or depressed in its bone, (A,) or contracted therein, (TA,) and wide in the end: (A, TA:) or retiring from the face, with a slight elevation in the end; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) xanasN being nearly the same as faTasN: (TA:) or retiring towards the head, and rising from the lip, not being long nor prominent: or its bone lay close upon the elevated part of the cheek, and it was large in the end. (TA.) See also the inf. n. voce Oaxonasu.
xanisati Alqadamu, inf. n. xanasN, The foot was, or became, flat in the hollow part of the sole, and fleshy. (TA: but only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is there mentioned.)

entry.sense: 4. Axnshu He made him to go back or backwards; to recede, retreat, retire, or retrograde: or he put him, or placed him, or made him to be, behind, or after: or he made him to remain behind, hold back, hang back, or lag behind: or he kept him back: or he delayed, or retarded, him: syn. Oax-arahu: (T, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) as also xanasahu↓, (Fr, T, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaxonisu}, (Mṣb,) [and app., accord. to the Ḳ, _u also,] inf. n. xanosN; (Mṣb;) but the former is the more common: (TA:) and ‡ hid him, or it: or made him, or it, to hide himself or itself; (A;) or he left behind, (Aṣ, Ṣ:) and went away from, (Ṣ,) him, or it: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or both signify he contracted, or drew together, or made to contract or draw together, him [or it]: (Mṣb:) or the latter verb has this signification as well as that of Oax-arahu: (Mgh:) [and so has the former also, as will be seen below:] and the former also signifies ‡ he hid, or concealed, him, or it; (A;) as also xanasa↓ bihi, as mentioned above. (TA.) You say, Oaxonasotu Eanohu baEoDa Haq-ihi I kept back (Oax-arotu) from him part of his right, or due. (Fr, TA.) And OaxonasuwA AlT-ariyqa ‡ They passed beyond the road: (AA, TA:) or left it behind them: (TA:) or passed beyond it and left it behind them. (A.) And OaXaAra biOarobaEK waOaxonasa UibohaAmahu, (A,) and xanasahaA↓, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He [made a sign with four fingers and] contracted his thumb. (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is related of Moḥammad, that he said, “The month is thus and thus,” [twice extending the fingers and thumb of each hand,] and that, the third time, xanasa↓ UiSobaEahu, i. e., he contracted his finger, [meaning, one of his fingers,] to inform them that the month is nine and twenty [nights with their days]. (TA.)
5. tx-ns bihi: see 1.
7: see 1, in two places.
8: see 1.

hom.sense: xunusN: see Oaxonasu.
A place of gazelles: (Ḳ:) or a place to which gazelles betake themselves for covert. (L.)

entry.sense: xanaAsN: see Oaxonasu.

Alxan-aAsu The devil: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) an epithet applied to him, (Mṣb,) because he retires, or shrinks, or hides himself, (yaxonusu, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, i. e., yataOax-aru, as is implied in the Ṣ, or yanoqabiDu, Mṣb, or yagiybu, Ḳ,) at the mention of God; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) being an intensive act. part. n. from xanasa. (Mṣb.)
xin-awosN: see Oaxonasu, in two places.
xaAnisN Going back or backwards; receding; retreating; retiring; or retrograding: or remaining behind; holding back; hanging back; or lagging behind: syn. mutaOax-irN: pl. xun-asN. (TA.)

[Hence,] Alxun-asu, (in the Ḳur lxxxi. 15, Ṣ,) ‡ The stars; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., all of them; because they retire, or hide themselves, (taxonusu,) at setting; or because they become concealed in the day-time: (Ṣ:) or the planets: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the five stars, Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Venus, and Mercury: (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ, Jel:) because they return, (taxonusu, i. c., tarojiEu, Jel,) in their course: (Fr, Ṣ, Jel:) when you see a star [thereof] in the end of a sign of the zodiac, it returns to the beginning of it: (Jel:) or because of their retrogression; for they are the erratic stars (AlkawaAkibu AlmutaHay-aripu), which [at one time appear to] retrograde, and [at another time to] pursue a direct [and forward] course: (Ṣ:) or because they sometimes return (txns) in their course until they become concealed in the light of the sun: (TA:) or because they hide themselves, as the devil does at the mention of God. (Ḳ, TA.)

And hence, i. e., from xaAnisN in the sense of mutaOax-irN, the saying in a trad. of El-Hajjáj, AlUibilu Dim-arN xin-asN, meaning, † [Camels are lean, and lank in the belly, and] patient of thirst. (TA.)
And All-ayaAliI Alxun-asu The three nights of the lunar month during which the moon retires [from view]. (TA.)

Oaxonasu [Having a camous, or camoys, nose;] having the configuration termed xanasN in the nose: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [see xanisa AlOanofu:] accord. to some, having a nose of which the bone is short and the end turning back towards its bone: (TA:) fem. xanosaMCu: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. xunosN. (Ṣ, A.) xanasN↓ in its original application is in gazelles and bulls and cows: (TA:) all bulls and cows are xunos, (Ṣ, A, TA,) and so are all gazelles: (TA:) or xunusN↓, with two dammehs, (Ḳ,) but written by Sh xunosN, (TA,) is used to signify gazelles: and bulls or cows: (Ḳ:) and xanosaMCu is an epithet applied to the wild cow: (Ḳ:) also Oaxonasu, to the tick: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) and the lion; and so xin-awosN↓; (Ḳ;) which last is an epithet so applied as relating to his face and his nose: (Fr, TA:) and the last, xn-ws↓, is also applied to a young pig: (Aṣ, TA:) or in this sense it is with S: (Fr, TA:) and xanaAsN↓ is syn, with xin-awosN. (TA.)

[Hence,] xunosN is metaphorically applied [as an epithet] to arrows, in the following verse, describing a coat of mail:
lahaA EukanN tarud-u Aln-abola xunosFA
watahozaOu biQlomaEaAbili waQloqiTaAEi
[It has folds which repel the arrows turned up at the points, and mock at the broad and long, and the small and broad, arrow-heads]. (TA.)
qadamN xanosaMCu A foot flat in the hollow part of the sole, and fleshy. (TA.)

dictScrap.title: xanosarN / xinosirN / xanosariI-N / xinosiyrN / xanaAsiru / xanaAsiyru

entry.sense: xanosarN and xinosirN and xanosariI-N and xinosiyrN and xanaAsiru and xanaAsiyru: see art. xsr.
xinoSiySN: see xin-awoSapN.
xinawoSN The young of the swine: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the young, or little, of anything: (Ḳ:) pl. xanaAniySu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also xin-awosN.]
xin-awoSapN The young of the babor, q. v.; (Ḳ;) as also xinoSiySN↓. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
Also A palm-tree which does not rise beyond reach of the hand. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

xinoSirN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xinoSarN, (A, Ḳ,) the latter [of a rare form,] like dirohamN, (TA,) The little finger: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or the middle finger: (Ḳ:) the latter signification said by MF to be unknown; but it is mentioned in the L, as from the Book of Sb: (TA:) [and the little toe:] of the fem. gender: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. xanaASiru: (Sb, Ṣ, Ḳ:) like firosinN, it has no pl. formed by the addition of At: (Sb:) its pl. is also used as a sing., as though every part were termed xnSr; as in the phrase Uin-ahu laEaZiymu AlxanaASiri [Verily he has a large little finger]. (Lḥ.) You say, fulaAnN tuvonaI bihi AlxanaASiru [The little fingers are bent in mentioning such a one with others of his class]: i. e., one begins with him in mentioning persons of his class. (Mṣb.) [See 1 in art. vnI.] And in like manner you say, Ead-uwhu biAlxinoSiri [They counted him with the little finger]: i. e., they commenced with him in counting. (MF.)

hom.sense: 1. xanaEa Uilayohi, and lahu, (ISd,) [aor. _a {yaxonaEu},] inf. n. xunuwEN (Ṣ, ISd, Ḳ) and xanoEN; (ISd;) [and app. xaniEa, aor. _a {yaxonaEu}, inf. n. xanaEN; (see xanaEN, below; and xaniEN;)] He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, (Ṣ, ISd, Ḳ,) to him, and petitioned him, or solicited him, he, the latter, not being a fit person to be petitioned, or solicited: (ISd:) or xunuwEN signifies the being low, vile, base, abject, or submissive; almost always in an improper case. (Ḥam p. 44.)

Accord. to Lth, (TA,) xanoEN signifies The act of playing, toying, or dallying, and conversing with one of the other sex, enticing, or striving to induce, the latter to yield to one's desire, and behaving in a soft, tender, or blandishing, manner. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, xanaEa Aln-isaMCa, [or more probably, liln-isaMCi,] He played,, &c., with women, and behaved in a soft, tender, or blandishing, manner to them. (TḲ.)

xanaEa, aor. _a {yaxonaEu}, (Lth, Ḳ,) inf. n. xanoEN and xunuwEN, (Lth,) also signifies He acted in a suspicious manner, or so as to induce suspicion or evil opinion; (Ḳ;) he acted vitiously, or immorally; or committed adultery, or fornication. (Lth, Ḳ.) You say, xanaEa UilayohaA He came to her for a vitious, or an immoral, purpose; or for the purpose of adultery, or fornication: (Lth, TA:) or, as some say, he listened to her. (TA.)
And xanaEa bihi, aor. _a {yaxonaEu}, inf. n. xunuwEN, He acted perfidiously, unfaithfully, or treacherously, to him; or broke his compact, contract, covenant, or the like, with him. (TA.)
xanaEa fulaAnFA UilaI Als-awoCapi He, or it, invited such a one to that which was foul, abominable, or evil; as also xaDaEa. (TA in art. xDE.)

entry.sense: 4. OaxonaEataniI Uilayoka AlHaAjapu (Ṣ, Ḳ *) Want, or need, made me lowly, humble, or submissive, to thee; or constrained me to have recourse to thee, and to require thine aid. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)
xanaEN [app. inf. n. of xaniEa,] Lowness, vileness, baseness, abjectness, or submissiveness; almost always, in an improper case. (Ḥam p. 44.)
xaniEN [app. part. n. of xaniEa,] Low, vile, base, abject, or submissive. (KL.) [See what next precedes.]

hom.sense: xanoEapN A thing that induces suspicion or evil opinion; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a vitious, or an immoral, act; or adultery; or fornication. (Ḳ.) [See a remark on one of the pls. of xaAniEN.] You say, AiT-alaEato mino fulaAnK EalaI xanoEapK I became acquainted with, or got knowledge of, a vitious, or an immoral, act of such a one. (TA.) And waqaEa fiI xanoEapK He fell into a thing of which one is ashamed. (TA.)
A vacant place. (O, L, Ḳ.) You say, laqiytuhu bixanoEapK faqaharotuhu I found him, or met him, in a vacant place, and I overcame him. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: xunoEapN Necessity, or constraint: and excuse. (TA.)
rajulN cuw xunuEaAtK A man in whom is corruptness, or vitiousness, or corrupt or vitious conduct. (TA.)
xanuwEN Perfidious, unfaithful, or treacherous; one who breaks his compact, contract, covenant, or the like. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
One who turns away from, or shuns, or avoids, another. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
xanaAEapN The state of being bad, evil, abominable, foul, unseemly, ugly, or hideous; or excessively bad,, &c. (TA.)

xaAniEN One who acts in a suspicious manner, or so as to induce suspicion or evil opinion; who acts vitiously, or immorally; or commits adultery, or fornication: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. xunuEN (Ḳ, TA) and xanaEapN. (TA.) El-Aạshà says,
humo AlxaDaArimu Uino gaAbuwA waUino XahiduwA
walaA yarawona UilaI jaAraAtihimo xunuEaA
[They are the bountiful, if they be absent and if they be present; and they do not see persons acting in a suspicious manner,, &c., towards their wives]. (TA.) [The latter hemistich of this verse is cited in the Ṣ; in one copy of which I find yurawona in the place of yarawona: and it seems to be there implied that xunuEN is pl. of xunoEapN; but I do not know any instance of fuEulN as the measure of a pl. of a word of the measure faEolapN.]
One who commits a foul action whereof the disgrace returns upon him, and is ashamed of it, and hangs down his head towards the ground. (Aṣ, on the authority of an Arab of the desert.)

OaxonaEu AlOasomaMCi Einoda Qll-ehi maliku AlOamolaAki, (Ḳ,) or UilaI Qll-ehi, (TA,) The vilest and most abasing (Oacal-u and Oaqoharu) of names, (Ḳ,) for a man, and the most effectual to bring into a state of humility and humiliation, in the estimation of God, is “king of kings;” like [the Persian] XaAhinoXaAho; because this name belongs to God himself: a trad., which is variously related: (TA:) accord. to different relations, thus, and OanoxaEu, (Ḳ,) meaning “most effectual to kill, and destroy,” its owner, (TA,) and OaboxaEu, [which means the same,] (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK AanojaEu,]) and OaxonaI, (Ḳ,) meaning “most foul, abominable, or the like.” (TA in art. xnI.)

muxan-aEN applied to a camel, Broke; trained; rendered submissive, or manageable. (Ḳ, TA.) And in like manner applied to a place [app. as meaning Rendered easy to sit, or lie, upon; or, to travel]. (TA.)
xunofasN and its variations: see what here follows.

xunofasaMCu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) [in two copies of the Ṣ, in which it is without the article, written without tenween, but in the Mṣb and Ḳ it has the article prefixed, and is therefore necessarily without tenween,] and xunofusaMC, (Mṣb, TA,) which is more common, (Mṣb,) [but this I doubt, for I have found it nowhere else,] and xunofasN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xunofusN (TA) and xinofisN, (Ḳ,) which last is of the dial. of the people of El-Basrah, (TA,) and xunofusapN and xunofusapN, (Ḳ,) [The black beetle: or a certain species thereof:] a well-known creeping thing; (Mṣb;) a certain insect, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) black, (Ḳ,) of fetid odour, smaller than the juEal, found in the bottoms of walls: (TA:) the first and second of these words are both applied to the male and the female: (Mṣb:) or xunofasN is applied to the male, (AA, Mṣb,) by some of the Arabs, (Mṣb,) and is syn. with EunoZabN and HunoZabN, (AA, TA,) and xunofusN is not disallowable, being agreeable with analogy: (Mṣb:)
and xunofasaACapN is applied to the female, [which, if correct, shows xnfsMC to be with tenween,] and so is xunofasapN: (Ṣ:) or xnfsACp, with p, is not allowable; [and if so, xnfsMC is without tenween;] (Aṣ, TA;) and xnfsp is [not applied to the female, but] used by the Benoo-Asad for xnfsMC, as though they made the p a substitute for the A: (Mṣb:) [and this seems to indicate that the A is a fem. A, grammatically speaking, and that the word is therefore without tenween:] the pl. is xanaAfisu. (Mṣb.) One says, huwa OalaH-u mina AlxunofasaMCi [He is more persevering than the black beetle]: because it returns to thee as often as thou throwest it away. (TA.)

dictScrap.note: [Accord. to the Ḳ, the n in the words of this art. is radical; but accord. to the Ṣ and Mṣb, augmentative.]

entry.sense: 1. xanaqahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaxonuqu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. xaniqN (Ṣ Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xanoqN, (Mṣb, TA,) the latter a contraction of the former, (Mṣb,) or, accord. to El-Fárábee, the latter is not allowable, (Mgh,) He throttled him, or strangled him, i. e. squeezed his throat (Mgh, Mṣb) that he might die; (Mṣb;) [but it does not always mean he squeezed his throat so that he died; often meaning, simply, he, or it, throttled him, strangled him, or choked him; and frequently said of a disease in the throat, and of food;] and xn-qhu↓ signifies the same, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [or has an intensive meaning,] and its inf. n. is taxoniyqN. (TA.)
[Hence,] xan-aqatohu↓ AlEaborapu [and xanaqatohu] † Weeping [or sobbing] choked him; as though the tears throttled him. (Mgh.)
And xuniqa He (a horse) was affected with the disease, or wind in the throat, termed xunaAqiy-ap. (TA.)
And xanaqa Alwaqota, aor. as above, † He postponed, or deferred, and [so] straitened, the time: and xanaqa AlS-alaApa † He straitened the time of prayer by postponing it, or deferring it. (TA.)
2: see 1, in two places.
You say also, xn-q Als-araAbu AljibaAla, inf. n. taxoniyqN, ‡ The mirage nearly covered the heads of the mountains. (Ḳ, TA.)
And xn-q AlUinaMCa ‡ He filled the vessel: (Ḳ, TA:) or filled it up (sad-ada maloOahu): and in like manner, AlHawoDa [the watering-trough]. (Aboo-Saʼeed, TA.)
And xn-q AlOarobaEiyna ‡ He (a man) nearly attained to [the age of] forty [years]. (Ḳ, TA.)
7: see what next follows {8}, in three places.

8. Axtnq He was, or became, throttled, or strangled; i. e. he had his throat squeezed that he might die; (JK,* Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ;*) [and simply he was, or became, throttled, strangled, or choked;] as also Anxnq↓: (JK,* Mṣb:) or you say, Anxnqt↓ AlX-aApu binafosihaA [the sheep, or goat, became throttled, or strangled, or choked, by itself]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or AlAinoxinaAqu↓ signifies the having the xinaAq [q. v.] compressed upon one's throat: and AlAixotinaAqu, the compressing it upon one's own throat. (TA.)
xanoqN: see muxan-aqN.

hom.sense: xaniqN inf. n. of xanaqahu: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:)
and i. q. maxonuwqN q. v. (JK, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xunuqN: see xinaAqN.

xuniAqN [Quinsy;] a certain disease which pre vents the passage of the breath to the lungs and heart; (Ḳ;) as also [xunaAqapN↓ thus in modern Arabic, and] xun-aAqN↓: pl. xawaAniyqu (TA) [and xan-aAniyqu, thus in modern Arabic].
See also muxan-aqN, in three places.
xinaAqN A cord, (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or bow-string, or the like, (Mgh,) with which one is strangled; (JK,* Ṣ,* Mgh, Ḳ;*) also, metaphorically, termed mixonaqapu↓ xan-aAqK. (Mgh.)
See also muxan-aqN, in two places.

falohamN xinaAqN † A narrow vulva of a woman: (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, TA:) and xunuqN↓ [or furuwju xunuqN, for xunuqN is app. pl. of xinaAqN, like as kunuzN is pl. of kinaAzN,] † narrow vulvas (IAạr, Ḳ) of women. (IAạr.)
humo fiI xinaAqK mina Almawoti † They are in straitness by reason of death. (TA.)
xaniyqN: see maxonuwqN, in three places.
xunaAqapN: see xunaAqN.

xunaAqiy-apN A certain disease in the throats of birds and horses: (Ḳ:) or a certain disease that attacks the bird in its head, and the horse in its throat, and chokes it: (JK:) or a certain disease, or wind, that attacks men and horses or similar beasts in the throat, and sometimes attacks birds in the head and throat, mostly appearing in pigeons. (TA.)
xan-aAqN: see xaAniqN.
Also One who sells fish [taken] with the xan-aAqap [q. v.]. (TA.)
xun-aAqN: see xunaAqN.
xan-aAqapN A snare with which beasts of prey are taken (JK, TA) by the throat: and a snare with which fish are taken in El-Andalus. (TA.)
xaAniqN One who strangles; (Mṣb, TA;*) as also xan-aAqN↓: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or the latter signifies one whose office it is to strangle. (TA.)

[Hence,] xaAniqu Alc-iYobi and xaAniqu Aln-amiri and xaAniqu Alkalobi and xaAniqu Alkirosan-api [in the CK Alkarosan-apu] Four herbs: (Ḳ:) [the first and second, in the present day, wolfsbane, or aconite: or, as Golius says, referring for the former and latter respectively to Diosc. iv. 78 and 77, the former is the aconitum lycoctonon; and the latter, the aconitum pardalianches: the third, dogsbane, or colchicum; or, as Golius says, referring to Diosc. iv. 81, apocynon: and the fourth, strangle-weed, (because it strangles the kirosan-ap, or bitter vetch,) or broomrape, i. e., as Golius says, referring to Diosc. ii. 172 and Ibn-Beytár, orobanche:] the first is high (mXrf [but perhaps this should be muXoriq i. e. shining]) in the leaves, downy, and resembling the dlb [?]: the second is like the tail of the scorpion, glistening, about a span [in height], and has not more than five leaves: each of these is of the [season called] rabiyE; and they are poisonous; they kill all animals; the ciYob and the namir being particularized only because of the quickness of its acting in them: Ibn-Seenà says, in the “Kánoon,” the leaves of xAnq Alnmr, when mixed with fat, and kneaded and baked with bread, and given as food to wolves and dogs and foxes and leopards (nmr), kills them: whence it seems that this may be two herbs or one herb. (TA.)
xaAniqN signifies also ‡ A narrow road or ravine, in a mountain: (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA:) or a narrow place or pass, between two mountains, and between two tracts of sand. (JK.) [See also muxotanaqN.]
And ‡ A narrow street; syn. zuqaAqN; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) in the dial. of the people of El-Yemen. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also maxonuwqN, in two places.

xaAnaqaAhN A convent inhabited by righteous and good men, and Soofees; an arabicized word, from [the Persian] xaAnaho GaAho; [and post-classical, for] El-Makreezee says that the xAnqAh was instituted in the fifth century of the Flight, for Soofee recluses to employ themselves therein in the service of God: (TA:) [pl. xawaAniqu.]
xaAanqaAhiI-N A man of, or belonging to, a xaAnaqaAh. (TA.)
maxonaqN: see muxan-aqN, in two places.

mixonaqapN A necklace, or collar, or the like, syn. qilaAdapN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) that surrounds the neck; (Mgh, Mṣb;) wherefore it is thus called; (Mṣb;) [i. e., because] it lies against the muxan-aq: pl. maxaAniqu. (TA.)
See also xinaAqN. [And see ziraAdN.]

hom.sense: muxan-aqN: see maxonuwqN.
[Hence,] gulaAmN muxan-aqu AlxaSori † A boy slender in the waist. (Ḳ.)

Also The part, of the neck, which is the place of the cord [or the like] called xinaAq [wherewith one is strangled]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) i. e., (TA,) the throat; (Ḳ, accord. to the TA; in the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ maxonaq↓;) and so xunaAqN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, in the former said to be syn. with muxan-aqN,) and xinaAqN↓ (Ḳ) and xanoqN↓. (TA; and so, accord. to the TA, in the Ḳ.) You say, Oaxacotu bimuxan-aqihi [I seized his throat]. (Ṣ.) And Oaxacahu bimuxan-aqihi (Ḳ, accord. to the TA, but accord. to the CK and my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ bimaxonaqihi↓,) and bixunaAqihi↓ and bixinaAqihi↓, i. e. [He took him, or seized him,] by his throat. (Ḳ.) And Oaxaca bimuxan-aqihi (A in art. zrd) and bixunaAqihi↓ (Ṣ) [properly He, or it, seized his throat, or throttled him, or choked him; meaning] ‡ he, or it, straitened him; as also Oaxaca bimuzar-adihi. (A in art. zrd.) And Oaxaca minohu biAlmuxan-aqi ‡ He, or it, constrained him, and straitened him. (TA.) And balaga minohu Almuxan-aqa [properly It reached his throat; meaning † it straitened him, or distressed him]. (Ṣ.) balaga AlOamoru Almuxan-aqa signifies the same as balaga Almucam-ara, (A in art. cmr,) which means † The affair, or case, or event, reached a distressing pitch. (Ḳ in art. cmr.)

entry.sense: maxonuwqN and xaniqN↓ and xaniyqN↓ (JK, Ḳ) and xaAniqN↓, applied to a man, [and to any animal, as also muxan-aqN↓, Throttled, or strangled, i. e. having his throat squeezed that he may die; but not always meaning, so as to be killed thereby; often meaning, simply, throttled, strangled, or choked;] (JK;) all signify the same; from xanaqahu: (JK, Ḳ:) or xaAniqN↓, in the place of xaniyqN↓, signifies cw xnAq [app. meaning having a xinaAq, or cord,, &c., by which he is throttled, or strangled, round his neck; or perhaps having a xunaAq, or quinsy]: (TA:) and XaApN xaniyqapN↓ and munoxaniqapN↓ signify a sheep, or goat, throttled, or strangled, i. e. having its throat squeezed that it may die: (Mṣb:) or the latter of these two means a sheep, or goat, throttled, or strangled, or choked, by itself (Ainoxataqato binafosihaA). (Ṣ, TA. [See 8.]) It is said in a prov., (Meyd,) Aifotadi maxonuwqu, (Meyd, Ḳ,) i. e. yaA maxonuwqu [Ransom thyself, O thou who art throttled, or strangled, or choked]; applied to any one distressed and constrained; (Meyd;) meaning free thyself from difficulty (Ḳ, TA) and harm: (TA:) or, as some relate it, AifotadaI maxonuwqN [One throttled, or strangled, or choked, ransomed himself]. (Meyd.)
muxotanaqN A narrow place or pass. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also xaAniqN, near the end of the paragraph.]
muxotaniqN ‡ A horse whose blaze occupies his jaws, (Ḳ, TA,) extending to the roots of his ears. (TA.)
XaApN munoxaniqapN: see maxonuwqN.
1. xanaA, aor. yaxonuw, inf. n. xanowN and xanFA: see xaniIa, in the art. here following.

hom.sense: 1. xaniIa (Ṣ, Ḳ) Ealayohi (Ṣ) fiI manoTiqihi (TA,) aor. yaxonaI, inf. n. xanFI; (TA;) as also xanaA, (JK, Ḳ,) aor. yaxonuw, (JK, TA,) inf. n. xanowN (Ḳ, TA) and xanFA; (JK, TA;) and AxnI↓ (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) Ealayohi fiI manoTiqihi, (Ṣ, TA,) or fiI kalaAmihi, (JK,) He uttered foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene, speech (JK,* Ṣ, Ḳ) against him. (Ṣ, TA.)
xanaI, (JK, Ḳ,) [aor. yaxoniI,] inf. n. xanoIN, (TA,) He cut, or severed, the trunk of a palm-tree (JK, Ḳ) with an axe; (JK;) as also xanaOa. (JK, TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1.

AxnI Ealayohi also signifies He, (a man, Ṣ,) or it, (misfortune, Ḥam p. 430,) corrupted, or marred, his state. (Ṣ, Ḥam, TA.) And the same, (Ṣ,) or AxnI Ealayohimo, (JK, Ḳ,) said of time, or fortune, (JK, Ṣ,) It destroyed him, or them. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.) And the former, said of time, It became long to him. (Ḳ.)

AxnI bihi signifies Oasolamahu waxafara cim-atahu [or, app., bicim-atihi: a phrase which admits of two contr. meanings; He betrayed him, and broke his covenant, or the like; and he preserved him in safety, and fulfilled his covenant,, &c.]. (TA.)
AxnI AljaraAdu The locusts had many eggs. (AḤn, Ḳ.)
AxnI AlmaroEaI The pasturage had much and luxuriant herbage. (AḤn, Ḳ.*)

xanFA [more properly written xanFI, originally an inf. n.,] Foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene, speech: (Ṣ, TA, and Ḥam p. 489:) or the most foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene, of speech. (JK, T, TA.) And xnAyp↓ [written without any syll. signs, app. xanaAyapN, like faHaAXapN,] is of the measure fEAlp from xanFA [and seems to be syn. therewith as an inf. n. or as a subst.]: it occurs in the saying of El-Katámee,
daEuwA Alt-amora laA tuvonuwA EalayohaA xnAypF
faqado OaHosanota fiI jul-i maA bayonanaA Alt-amoru
[Leave ye dates: speak not of them in a foul manner, or speak not of them foul speech; for dates have benefited in most of what has occurred between us, or among us]. (TA.)
xanaA Ald-ahori The calamities of time or fortune. (JK, Ḳ.)

kalaAmN xanK Foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene, speech; and kalimapN xaniyapN a foul, an abominable, an unseemly, or an obscene, word or expression or sentence: (Ṣ:) or most foul,, &c.: (JK:) [or having a foul, an abominable, an unseemly, or an obscene, meaning; for] xanK is not a verbal epithet, since we know not xaniyati Alkalimapu, but a possessive epithet; like the instance, mentioned by Sb, in rajulN TaEimN, meaning cuw TaEaAmK; and nahirN, meaning [SaAHibu nahaArK or] sayamur-u biAln-ahaAri;, &c. (TA.)
xnAyp: see xanFA.
AxnI AlOasomaMCi The most foul, or abominable, or unseemly, of names. (TA.) [See OaxonaEu.]

hom.sense: xaw-N Hunger. (IAạr, Ḳ.) [And so xawFI and xawaMCu, belonging to art. xwI; with which the present art. is intimately connected.]

A wide valley: (Ḳ:) any wide valley in a soft, or plain, [low ground such as is termed] jaw-; (Az, TA;) as also xawFI: (Az, TA in art. xwI:) and low, or depressed, ground; (TA;) as also xuw-apN↓: (JK, TA:) or the former, a soft place: (JK:) or soft ground; as in the saying, waqaEa garosuka bixaw-F What thou hast planted has chanced to be in soft ground, in which it will take root and not fail to be productive. (TA.)

entry.sense: [xuw-N, by a mistake in the CK, in art. xwI, is made to signify Honey: see xuwaMCN in that art]
xw-p [app. xaw-apN] Languor: occurring in a trad., in which it is said, waOaxaca OabaA jaholK xw-pN falaA yanoTiqu [And a languor seized Aboo-Jahl, so that he spoke not]. (IAth, TA.)

hom.sense: xuw-apN A vacant land. (Ḳ.)
See also xaw-N.
Also a dial. var. of Ouxuw-apN. (IAth, TA in art. Axw: see 1 in that art.)

entry.sense: xaMCN The name of the letter x, q. v.; as also xaA: [it is called xaA in a case of pause, and xaMCN when made a noun:] it is fem. and masc.: [its dim. is xayay-apN, meaning a x written small, or indistinct: (see HaMCN in art. HwO:)] and its pl. is OaxowaMCN and OaxoyaMCN and xaAMtN. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally-np.)

xaMCi bika EalayonaA, (AZ * and Ṣ * and TA in bAb AlAlf Ally-np, and Ḳ and TA in the present art.,) in which xaMCi is a Sawot [or noun significant of a sound], indecl., with kesr for its termination; (Ṣ, TA;) and xaAYiI bk, as in the Book of the Nawádir by Ibn-Háni, (Az, TA,) in which latter, ISd says, the I is not for a sign of the fem. gender, because the word is a Swt; and, as Sh says, on the authority of AʼObeyd, xaAYibika; but correctly written as in the Book of Ibn-Háni; (Az, TA;) Hasten thou [to us]: (AZ, Az, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) it is also used in addressing a female, and two persons, and a pl. number: (Ṣ, TA:) you say [xaMCi biki, and] xaAYiI biki; and xMCi bikumaA, and xaAYiI bikumaA; and [xaMCi bikumo, and] xaAYiI bikumo. (TA.) In the saying of El-Kumeyt,
bixaAYiI bika QloHaqo yahotifuwna waHaI-a halo [which app. means Calling out “Hasten thou, come up with us,” and “Come,” or “come quickly, ”, &c.,] it is held by Ibn-Selemeh to be used as an imprecation, meaning xibota [mayest thou be disappointed of attaining that which thou desirest]; the poet saying bixaAYibika for biOamorika Ql-aciI xaAba waxasira [meaning By thine affair that shall result in disappointment, and be an occasion of loss]: which, as you see, is at variance with the explanation of AZ. (Ṣ, TA.)
xaAYiI-N and xaAwiI-N and xawiI-N [a mistranscription for xayawiI-N, like bayawiI-N and tayawiI-N] rel. ns. of xaMCN and xaA the names of the letter x. (TA in bAb AlAlf All-ynp.)
1. xaAba, aor. yaxuwbu, inf. n. xawobN, He was, or became, poor, needy, or indigent. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
See also xaAba in art. xyb.

hom.sense: xawobapN A state of utter destitution, in which nothing remains in possession: so in the saying, OaSaAbatohumo xawobapN [A state of utter destitution befell them]. (AʼObeyd, T.)

Hunger: (AA, T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) pl. xawobaAtN. (TA.) So in the phrase, OaSaAbatohu xawobapN [Hunger befell him]. (AA, Ṣ.) Sh knew not this word, and thought it to be a mistake for HawobapN; (T;) which latter signifies “want.” (Ṣ.) [See the latter word.]
A tract of land upon which rain has not fallen, between two tracts of land watered by rain. (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Land that is bad, (Ṣ,) in which is no pasture (Ṣ, Ḳ) nor water. (TA.) So in the saying, nazalonaA bixawobapK mina AlOaroDi [We alighted in bad land, without pasture or water]. (Ṣ.) [See also HuwbapN.]

1. xaAta, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. yaxuwtu, inf. n. xawotN (Ṣ, TA) and xawaAtapN; (TA;) and AxtAt↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AnxAt↓; (Ḳ;) He (a hawk, or falcon, Ṣ, Ḳ, and an eagle, A, TA) pounced down, or made a stoop, upon the prey, or quarry, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) to take it, or seize it, (Ṣ,) making a sound to be heard with his wings. (TA.) And xaAtati AlEuqaAbu, aor. taxuwtu, inf. n. xawaAtN, The eagle made a sound by the motion of its wings [in pouncing down]. (Ṣ.)

Also xAt, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xawotN, (TA,) He (for instance an eagle, TA) seized, or snatched away, (Ḳ, TA,) a thing; (TA;) and so txw-t↓, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and AxtAt↓. (TA in art. xyt [where this last is said to belong to the present art.].) You say of the hawk, AxtAt↓ AlT-ayora He seized, or snatched away, the birds: (TA in art. xyt:) and of the wolf, AxtAt↓ AlX-aApa (Fr, Ṣ, TA) He seized, or snatched away, the sheep or goat; (TA in art. xyt;) or he stole away the sheep or goat by stratagem. (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

xAt maAlahu He (a man) lessened, or diminished, his property; or took from it by little and little; syn. tanaq-aSahu; (Ḳ;) as also txw-t↓ maAlahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and txw-fhu: (Ṣ:) and xaAtahu maAlahu, aor. yaxuwtuhu and yaxiytuhu, [he lessened, or diminished, to him his property; or did so by taking from it by little and little;] both signify the same. (Ḳ in art. xyt.)
And xAt He (a man, TA) lessened, diminished, or impaired, his provision of corn or food (miyratahu); or made it defective, or deficient. (Ḳ.)
xAt, (aor. as above, Mṣb,) also signifies He (a man) broke his promise: (IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and broke, or dissolved, his compact, contract, or covenant. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. xAwt Tarofahu duwniI, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaAwatahu, (TA,) i. q. saAraqahu [i. e. He cast his eye furtively towards a spot between me and him; meaning, towards me: see similar phrases in art. dwn]. (Ḳ.)
5: see 1, in two places:
and see also 8, in two places.
7: see 1, first sentence.
8: see 1, in four places.
One says also, AxtAt baladFA, and txw-thu↓, He cut off for himself a land, or district. (IAạr, TA in art. xwI.)

And fulaAnN yaxotaAtu Hadiyva Alqawomi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) and yataxaw-atu↓, (Ṣ,) Such a one takes of the discourse of the people, or party, and learns it by heart [one part after another]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) In [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, in the explanation of AxtAt AlHadiyva, for fataHaf-aZahu is erroneously put fataxaT-afahu. (TA.)

And Uin-ahumo yaxotaATuwna All-ayoli, meaning yasoruwna wayaqoTaEuwna AlT-ariyqa [Verily they journey by night, and make the road to be feared, relying upon their strength, and robbing and slaying men]. (Ṣ: [in two copies of which I find yasiyruwna in the place of yasoruwna.])

xawaAtN The sound made by the motion of the wings of an eagle. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [In a copy of the Ṣ, I find it said that this word is fem., though its meaning is masc.; and the same is said in the TA, doubtless from another copy of the Ṣ; but this observation, which is omitted in one copy of the Ṣ in my possession, applies to xawaApN, mentioned in art. xwI in the Ṣ, as meaning SawotN.]) And A sound [absolutely]; (Ḳ;) as also xawaAtahu↓: (TA:) or the sound, or noise, of thunder, and of a torrent, or flow of water. (AḤn, Ḳ.) A poet says,
falaAHis-a Uil-aA xawaAtu Als-uyuwli
[And there was no sound but the noise of the torrents]; (AḤn, TA;) which shows that we should read in the Ḳ waAls-ayoli; not wAlsylu, as in some copies. (TA.)
xawaAtapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: xaw-aAtN A bold, daring, brave, or courageous, man. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
One who is always eating, but does not eat much. (Ḳ.)
A great promisebreaker. (Mṣb.)
xaAYitN [act. part. n. of 1]. xaAYitapN signifies An eagle (EuqaAbN) pouncing down, or making a stoop, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and thereby causing a sound to be heard. (Ṣ.)
Breaking his promise; or one who breaks a promise. (Mṣb.)
xawoxN [The peach, or peaches;] a well-known kind of fruit, (Ḳ, TA,) which is eaten; (TA;) i. q. duraAqinN: (Ḳ in art. drqn:) sing., (Ḳ,) or n. un., (Ṣ,) xawoxapN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also what follows.
xawoxapN: see above.
Also An aperture (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ) in a wall, (Ṣ, A, Mgh,) admitting the light (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) to a house, or chamber. (Ḳ.)

A passage (muxotaraqN) between any two houses, not having a door, or gate: (Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz; (TA;) [and of Egypt, where it is applied to a lane leading from one street or quarter to another: coll. gen. n. xawoxN↓:] accord. to some, a passage (muxotaraqN) between any two things: and a small door-way between two houses, or chambers, with a door affixed to it. (L.)
A wicket, or small door, (A, Mgh,) in a large door. (A.) [Golius, as on the authority of Meyd, explains it as meaning Fenestella in medio januæ.]
[Also applied to A sluice in a rivulet: see daraqapN.]
‡ The anus; syn. duburN. (Ḳ, TA.)
A kind of green garment: (Az, Ḳ:) of the dial. of Mekkeh. (TA.)

2. xw-d, (L,) inf. n. taxowiydN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) He (a camel, L) went quickly; or was quick in his pace or going: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) he went quickly, and threw out his legs: or, as some say, he shook, as though he were convulsed: and in like manner, a male ostrich: and sometimes it is said of a man, signifying as first explained above. (L.)
xaw-ada raOoluhu: see art. rOl.
He sent the stallion, fiI AlUibili among the camels. (L, Ḳ.)
He obtained somewhat of food. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. txw-d He (a camel) shook in going, by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (A.)
It (a branch) inclined, (A, TA,) or bent. (Ḳ.)

xawodN, applied to a girl, (Ṣ,) or young woman, (L,) or a female, (A, Ḳ,) Soft, or tender, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) and youthful: (A:) or goodly, or beautiful, in make, and youthful, (L, Ḳ,) not yet of middle age: (L:) pl. xawodaAtN (L, Ḳ) and xuwdN; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) the latter like ludonN as pl. of ladonN, an epithet applied to a spear. (Ṣ, L.)

hom.sense: 1. xaAra, aor. yaxuwru, (Ṣ, A, Mgh,) inf. n. xuwaArN (JK, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ *) and xaworN, (JK,) He (a bull) uttered his cry; [i. e. lowed, or bellowed;] (Lth, JK, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ;) this being its primary signification: (Er-Rághib:) the inf. n. xwAr, used agreeably with this explanation, occurs in the Ḳur xx. 90 [and vii. 146]: (Ṣ:) it signifies the loud crying [i. e. the lowing or bellowing] of a cow and of a calf: (Lth:) and the crying [i. e. bleating] of sheep, or that of goats, and of gazelles, (Ḳ,) and of any beast: (Er-Rághib:) and the sounding [i. e. whizzing] of arrows: (Ḳ:) of any of these, you say, xaAra, aor. and inf. n. as above. (TA.) [Hence,] lahu SawotN kaxuwaAri Alv-awori He has a voice like the bellowing of the bull. (A.)
[And hence, (see 10,)] xAr Ealayohi ‡ He bent, turned, or inclined, towards him. (A.)

xAr, aor. as above, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. xuWuwrN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, [for which Golius, as on these authorities, substitutes xuWuwrapN,]) said of a man, (Ṣ,) and of anything, (TA,) He, or it, was, or became, weak, or feeble, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and languid; (Ṣ, TA;) as also xawira, (TA,) aor. yaxowaru, (JK,) inf. n. xawarN; (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA;) and xiw-ir↓, (JK, TA,) inf. n. taxowiyrN. (Ḳ.) xAr and xawira both signify It was soft, or fragile; said of anything, like a reed. (JK.) It is said in a trad. of ʼOmar, lano yaxuwra qawiI-N maA daAma SaAHibuhaA banoziEu wayanozuw, meaning A possessor of strength (SaAHibu quw-apK) will not be weak as long as he can pull his bow and leap to his beast. (TA.) In a camel that is drinking, xawarN denotes, or implies, a quality that is praised; i. e. Patient enduring of thirst and fatigue: and a quality dispraised; i. e. the lacking patience to endure thirst and fatigue. (TA.)

Also, said of heat, (Ṣ, TA,) and of cold, inf. n. xuWuwrN and xuWuwrapN, (JK,) ‡ It became faint; it remitted, or abated; (JK, Ṣ, TA;) and so xawira, inf. n. xawarN; and xw-r↓. (TA.) And xAr Ean-aA, said of cold, It ceased from us; quitted us. (A.)
xaArahu, (JK, Ṣ,) inf. n. xaworN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He hit, or hurt, his xaworaAn, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,*) in thrusting or piercing him with a spear or the like. (JK, Ṣ.)
2. xw-r: see 1, in two places.
xw-rhu He attributed to him weakness, or feebleness, and languor. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AxArhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UixaArapN, (Ṣ,) [app., in its' primary acceptation, He caused him to utter a cry. (See 10.)]
[And hence,] † He bent, turned, or inclined, him, or it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, OaxaronaA AlmaTaAyaA UilaI mawoDiEi kacaA † We bent, or turned, the riding-camels to such a place. (Ṣ.)
6. txAwrti Alv-iyraAnu The bulls lowed, or bellowed, one to another. (A.)

10. AstxArhA [He endeavoured to make her (namely, a gazelle, or a wild cow,) to utter her cry; or] he uttered a cry in order that she should do the same. (TA.) The sportsman, coming to a place in which he thinks the young one of a gazelle or [wild] cow to be, utters a cry like that of her young one; and the mother, hearing it, if she have a young one, thinks the cry to be that of her young one, and follows the cry. (Ṣ,* TA.)

Hence, (Ṣ, TA,) AstxArhu ‡ He endeavoured to make him bend, turn, or incline: (JK, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA:) and he called him to him: and he interrogated him; or desired him to speak; syn. AisotanoTaqahu: namely, a man. (JK.) [AstxAr Almanozila is explained in the L and Ḳ as meaning AisotanoZafahu: to which is added in the TA, kOn-h Tlb xyrh, with the remark that it should therefore properly be mentioned in art. xyr: but an explanation in the sentence immediately preceding, and a verse cited below, evidently show that AstnZfh is a mistranscription for AisotanoTaqahu, and that xyrh should be xabarahu: so that the meaning is He interrogated the place of abode.] The author of the L cites, as an ex., the saying of El-Kumeyt,
walano yasotaxiyru rusuwma Ald-iyaAri
liEawolatihi cuw AlS-ibaI AlmuEwilu
[And he who is affected with youthful amorousness, wailing, will not ask the remains, or traces, of the dwellings to reply to his wailing: but for liEawolatihi I would rather read biEawolatihi; i. e., will not interrogate them with his wailing]. (TA.)

AstxAr AlD-ab-a, (Ḳ, TA, [in some copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, AlD-abuEa,]) and AlyarobuwEa, (TA,) He placed a piece of wood in the hole of the burrow of the [lizard called] Db-, (Ḳ, TA,) and of the jerboa, i. e. in the qaASiEaMC, (TA,) in order that it should come forth from another place, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. the naAfiqaMC, so that he might catch it. (TA.) Lth falsely assigns the act of AlAisotixaArap to the Db- and the jerboa. (Az, TA.)

xaworN Low, or depressed, ground or land, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) between two elevated parts; (JK, Ṣ;) like gawrN: (TA:) an inlet (lit. a neck) from a sea or large river, entering into the land: (Sh:) a place, or channel, where water pours into a sea or large river: (JK, Ḳ:) or a wide place or channel, where waters pour, running into a sea or large river; (TA:) or (as in the TA, but in the Ḳ “and,”) a canal, or cut, from a sea or large river: (Ḳ, TA:) and i. q. raHabapN [app. as meaning the part in which the water flows from the two sides of a valley]: (JK:) pl. xuWuwrN. (TA.)
xuwrN a pl. of xaw-aArapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) contr. to rule; (MF, TA;) and of xaw-Ar in the phrase xaw-Aru AlEinaAni. (JK, TA.) See xaw-aArN, in five places.

xuwrapN AlUibili, with damm, [app. originally xuyorap,] The best of camels, or of the camels; (IAạr, Ḳ;) [see xayorN, (in art. xyr,) near the end of the paragraph;] and so xuwaAruhaA↓, and AlxuwraI↓ minohaA. (Fr, TA.)
xuwraI fem. of Oaxoyaru, and properly belonging to art. xyr: see what next precedes.

xaworaAnN The maboEarN [or rectum], which comprises the HitaAr [or anus, with the extremities of its skin,] of the Sulob [or back], (Ḳ,) of a man, &c.: (TA:) or the passage of the rawov [or dung, properly of a horse or the like, but here app. meaning of a man also]: (Ṣ:) or the head [or extremity] of the maboEarap [or rectum]: or the part in which is the dubur [or anus]: (Ḳ:) or the dubur [or anus] itself; (TA;) or it has this meaning also; (JK;) and so xaw-aArapN↓, syn. AisotN; (Ḳ;) the dubur being so called because it is like a depressed place between two hills: (TA: [see xaworN:]) or the gap in which is the dubur [or anus] of a man; and that in which is the qubul [or anterior pudendum] of a woman: (TA:) or the gap in which is the dubur and the place of the cakar and that of the qubul of the woman: (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán:”) pl. xaworaAnaAtN and xawaAriyn: (Ḳ:) the former pl. of a form which any sing. subst. not significant of a human being may receive. (TA.)

hom.sense: xuwaArN an inf. n. of xaAra as explained in the first sentence in this art. (Ṣ, A, &c.)
xuwaAru AlUibilu: see xuwrap.

entry.sense: xaWuwrN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

xaw-aArN Weak, or feeble; (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) applied to a man; (Ṣ;) as also xaAYirN↓, (Ḳ,) and xaWuwrN↓: (AHeyth:) a weak man, who cannot endure difficulty or distress: (Lth:) and ‡ cowardly, or a coward: (A:) pl. of the first xaw-aAruwna, and of the third xuwarapN. (AHeyth.) Applied to a camel, Slender (raqiyq) and beautiful: (Ḳ, TA: [for AlHis-i in the CK, I read AlHasanu, as in other copies of the Ḳ and in the TA:]) and the fem., with p {xaw-aArapN}, applied to a she-camel, having soft flesh and fragile bones: (TA:) pl. of the former [and of the latter] xaw-aAraAtN. (Ḳ.) Applied to a spear, Weak: (Ṣ:) not hard: (Mṣb:) or weak and soft; (TA;) and in the same sense applied to an arrow, (A, TA,) as also xaWuwrN↓; (TA;) and so the fem. of the former, with p {xaw-aArapN}, applied to a reed or cane (qaSabapN); (A, TA;) and to land or ground (OaroDN) as meaning weak, (Ṣ,) or soft: (A, Mṣb:) pl. xuwrN↓. (Ṣ.) And xaw-aAru AlEinaAni ‡ A horse (A) that turns easily, (JK, A, Ḳ,) and runs much: (Ḳ:) pl. xuwrN↓. (JK, TA.) And bakorapN xaw-aArapN † A sheave of a pulley of which the pin runs [or turns] easily in the checks. (TA.) And xuwru↓ AlHaXaAyaA Beds, or the like, stuffed with soft substances. (TA, from a trad.) And xaw-aAru AlS-afaA Smooth stones that sound [when struck] by reason of their hardness. (IAạr.) And zanodN xaw-aArN A znd [q. v.] that emits much fire; syn. qad-aAHN. (AHeyth, Ḳ.) [Hence,] huwa xaw-aAru AlEuwdi [meaning † He is lavish when asked]: an expression of dispraise. (TA in art. ksr.) [Hence also,] xaw-aArapN ‡ A she-camel abounding with milk; pl. xuwrN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) which is contr. to rule, and said by MF to be without a parallel: (TA:) and so a ewe or she-goat: (TA:) or a she-camel whose milk flows easily; and so a ewe or she-goat: (A:) or a she-camel thin-skinned, and abounding with milk: (AHeyth:) or one that is of a hue between dustcolour and red, with a thin skin; and such is the most abundant in milk: (Kf:) or of a red colour inclining to dust-colour, thin-skinned, and having long fur with [coarse] hair protruding through it, longer than the rest: such a she-camel is less hardy than others, but abounds with milk. (ISk.) Also ‡ A palm-tree (naxolapN) that bears much fruit. (JK, A, Ḳ.)
xuwrN↓ as meaning † Women much suspected, on account of their corruptness, (Ḳ, TA,) and the weakness of their forbearance, (TA,) is [a pl.] without a sing. (Ḳ.)
xaw-aArapN fem. of xaw-aArN [q. v.].
As a subst.: see xaworaAnN.
xaAYirN: see xaw-aArN, first sentence.

1. xawiSa, aor. _a {yaxowaSu}, inf. n. xawaSN, He (a man, Ṣ) had the eye sunk, or depressed: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the inf. n. signifies the eye's being narrow, or contracted, and sunk, or depressed: (Mṣb:) or its being small, and sunk, or depressed: (A:) or its being sunk, or depressed, and narrow, or contracted, and small: or one eye's being smaller than the other: or the eye's being narrow in the slit, naturally, or by reason of disease: or accord. to AM, all that they have related respecting this word is correct except narrowness of the eyes; for the Arabs, when they mean this, use the term HawaSN, with [the unpointed] H; but when they mean the eye's being sunk, or depressed, this they term xawaSN, with [the pointed] x: (TA:) and accord. to AʼObeyd's relation on the authority of his companions, (TA,) [and accord. to Mṭr also,] xawiSato Eayonuhu signifies his eye became sunk, or depressed; (Mgh, TA;) but HawiSato, “it became narrow, or contracted.” (Mgh.)
Also xawiSato, inf. n. as above; and AxwAS-t↓, inf. n. AixowiySaASN; She (a ewe) had one of her eyes black, and the other white. (AZ, TA.)
2. xw-S AlX-ajaru, inf. n. taxowiySN, said of palmtrees, [and some others, see xuwSN,] The trees put forth leaves, [or only leaves of the kinds called xuwSi,] little by little. (L, TA.) See also 4.
xw-S Alt-aAja, inf. n. as above, He ornamented the crown with plates of gold (Ḳ, TA) of the width of palm-leaves. (TA.)
3: see 6, in two places.

4. OaxowaSati Aln-axolu The palm-trees put forth their xuwS [or leaves]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to the A, you say, xaw-aSati↓ Aln-axolu, meaning the palm-trees put forth their leaves. (TA.) [See also 2, above.] AxwS is also said of the Earofaj, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of the rimov, (TA,) [and of other trees, (see xuwSN,)] or of trees in general, (TA,)
or of trees (AlX-ajar) you say OaxaASa, inf. n. UixowaASN, (AḤn, ISd,) the verb being thus made infirm, and the inf. n. sound, (ISd,) or of all trees except thorny trees and herbs or leguminous plants, (TA,) meaning, It broke out with leaves: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, when said of the Erfj, its xuwS became perfect. (AA, TA voce EarofajN; and Ṣ voce vaq-aba.) And you say also, OaxowaSati AlxuwSapu The xuwSap [see xuwSN] appeared. (TA.)

6. txAwS, (A, Ḳ,) or txAwS fiI naZarihi, (TA,) He blinked, or contracted his eyelids, (A, Ḳ,) somewhat, (Ḳ,) looking intently, as though he were aiming an arrow; and so in looking at the sun; (A, Ḳ;) as also xAwS↓. (Ḳ.) [But the latter is trans.] You say, Uin-ahu yuxaAwiSu↓ fulaAnFA, and ytaxaAwaSa lahu, Verily he blinks, or contracts his eyelids, looking intently, at such a one, as though he were aiming an arrow. (A.) [See also taHaAwaSa UilaI AlX-amosi; and huwa yuHaAwiSu fulaAnFA.]
[Hence,] taxaAwaSati Aln-ujuwmu, (A,) or txAwSt Alnjwm liloguruwbi, (TA,) ‡ The stars inclined to setting. (A, TA.)
11: see 1, last signification.

xuwSN The leaves of the date-palm, (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of the muqol [or Thebaïc palm], (T, TA,) and of the naArajiyl [or cocoa-nut-tree], and the like, (TA,) and of the Earofaj, (T, Ḳ,) and of the vumaAm, (T, TA,) and of the naSiI-, (Ṣ voce OumoSuwxap, q. v.,) and of the OaroTaI, and of the OalaMC, and of the sabaT: (Ibn-'Eiyásh Ed-Ḍabbee, Ḳ:) n. un. with p {xuwSapN}: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.:) the xwSp of the Erfj is the green [part] thereof when it appears upon the white thereof; (TA;) [or] it resembles the leaves of the Hin-aMC: that of the ArTI is like the hadab [or evergreen leaves] of the Oavol: that of the AlMC has the form of the ears of sheep, or goats: and that of the sabaT has the form of the HalofaMC: (Ibn-'Eiyásh, TA:) there is also the xwSp of the [class of trees or plants called] janobap, which is of the plants, or herbage, of the [season called] Sayof, or, as some say, it is what grows upon a root-stock or rhizoma (EalaI OaruwmapK): (TA:) but to herbs, or leguminous plants, of which the leaves fall and become scattered when they dry up, there is no xwSp. (T, TA.)
xiyaASapN The trade, or art, of the xaw-aAS. (A, TA.)
xaw-aASN A seller of xuwS: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a weaver thereof [into baskets and mats and the like]: (A:) or both. (TA.)

OaxowaSu A man (Ṣ, Mgh) having the eye sunk, or depressed; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) having the quality of the eye termed xawaSN: [see 1:] fem. xawoSaMCu: (TA:) which is [also] applied to the eye, meaning sunk, or depressed: (Mgh:) or small, and sunk, or depressed: (A:) and to a ewe, meaning having one of her eyes black, and the other white: (AZ, Ḳ:) or having one eye black, and the other, with the rest of the body, white: (TA:) pl. xuwSN, which, prefixed to AlEuyuwn, is applied to camels. (A.)

[Hence,] biYorN xawoSaMCu ‡ A deep well; a well of which the bottom is deep; (A, Ḳ, TA;) of which the beasts see not the water: (TA:) because one contracts his eyelids (yataxaAwaSu) in looking into it: (A, TA:) or xwSAC applied to a well (rakiy-ap), signifies of which the water has sunk into the earth. (TA.) And the same epithet applied to a [mountain of the kind called] haDobap, (A,) or qaArap, (Ḳ,) ‡ High; lofty: (A, Ḳ:) because one contracts his eyelids in looking at it. (A, TA.) And riyHN xawoSaMCu ‡ A hot wind: (Ḳ:) or a vehemently-hot wind: (A:) that makes the eye to blink, or contract the eyelids, (takosiruhaA,) by reason of heat: (Ḳ,* TA:) in which one does not see without blinking, or contracting the eyelids. (A.) And ZahiyrapN xawoSaMCu ‡ A summer mid-day vehemently hot: (A:) or most vehemently hot; (Ḳ, TA;) in which one cannot look without blinking, or contracting the eyelids. (TA.)

muxaw-aSN applied to a crown, Ornamented with plates of gold like xuwS in width: (A,* TA:) and applied to a vessel, having in it what resemble xuwS in shape. (TA.) muxaw-aSN biAlc-ahabi, applied to diybaAj [or silk brocade], Woven with gold in the form of xuwS. (TA.)
OaroDN muxaw-iSapN Land in which are xuwS of the OaroTaI and OalaMC and Earofaj and sabaT. (Ibn-'Eiyásh Ed-Ḍabbee, Ḳ.)

1. xaADa AlmaMCa, aor. yaxuwDu, inf. n. xawoDN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xiyaADN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) [He waded, or forded, through the water;] he passed through the water walking or riding: (Ṣ:) or he entered into the water; (A, Ḳ;) as also xaw-aDahu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taxowiyDN; (TA;) [or this latter has an intensive signification, as it is said to have in a phrase below;] and AxtADhu↓: (Ḳ:) or he walked in, or through, the water; (Mṣb;) as also txw-Dhu↓: (TA:) or he entered into the water and walked in it, or through it. (TA.) You say also, xaADa biAlfarasi, meaning He brought the horse to the water; as also AxADhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UixaADahu; (AZ;) and xAwDhu↓, (Ḳ,) or xAwDhu fiI AlmaMCi, inf. n. muxaAwaDapN, as in the A: (TA:) or AxADwA↓ AlmaMCa signifies xaADuwhu bidawaAb-ihimo [They waded or forded through the water, or entered into it,, &c., with their beasts]: and you say also, xaAwaDotuhumo↓ fI AlmaMCi [I waded or forded with them through the water;, &c.; meaning with men, not with beasts]: (so I find in a copy of the A:) and AxAD↓ Alqawomu signifies xaADato xayoluhumu AlmaMCa [The people's horses waded or forded through the water]. (Ṣ.)
xaADati AlUibilu luj-a Als-araAbi ‡ [The camels passed through the great expanse of mirage]. (A.)
xaADa Albaroqu AlZ-alaAma ‡ [The lightning penetrated through the darkness]. (A, TA.)
xaADa Uilayohi Alr-imaAHa Hat-aI Oaxacahu ‡ [He forced his way to him through the spears until he took him, or it]. (A, TA.*)
xaADa Alqawomu fiI AlHadiyvi, (Ṣ, A,) and txAwDwA↓ fiyhi (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) ‡ The people, or company of men, entered [or waded] together into discourse. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
xaADa AlgamaraAti, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. as above, inf. n. xawoDN, (TA,) ‡ He plunged into the submerging floods of ignorance, or the like; syn. AiqotaHamahaA. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
xaADa fiI AlOamori † He entered [or plunged] into the affair. (Mṣb.)

In like manner you say, [xaADa fiI AlbaATili and] AxAD↓ AlbaATila † He entered [or plunged] into false, or vain, discourse or speech: (Mṣb:) and xaADa, alone, signifies ‡ He said, or spoke, what was false. (A.) It is said in the Ḳur [lxxiv. 46], (TA,) wakun-aA naxuwDu maEa AlxaAYiDiyna, i. e. fiI AlbaATili ‡ [And we used to enter into false, or vain, discourse or speech, with those who entered thereinto]; (Bḍ, Jel, Ḳ;) syn. naXoraEu: (Bḍ:) or and we used to follow the erring,, &c. (O, Ḳ.) And again, [lii. 12,] Al-aciyna humo fiI xawoDK yaloEabuwna ‡ [Who amuse themselves in entering into false, or vain, discourse or speech]; (TA;) fI AlbATl being here, again, understood. (Bḍ.) And again, [ix. 70,] waxuDotumo kaQl-aciI xaADuwA, i. e. kaxawoDihimo ‡ [And ye have entered into false, or vain, discourse or speech, like their entering thereinto]. (Ḳ.) And again, [vi. 67,] Al-aciyna yaxuwDuwna fiI MyaAtinaA ‡ [Who enter into false, or vain, discourse or speech respecting our signs; meaning the Ḳur-án]. (TA.) xaADa fiyhi is also explained as signifying † He said what was false respecting it. (TA.) And xawoDN signifies † The confusing, or confounding, in an affair. (TA.)
xaADa, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and xw-D↓, (A, TA,) also signify He mixed, (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA,) and stirred about, (TA,) the beverage, or wine: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or he stirred about the sawiyq with the mixowaD. (A, Mgh.*)
xaADahu biAls-ayofi ‡ He moved about the sword in him, having smitten him: (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:) or he put [or thrust] the sword into the lower part of his belly, and then raised it upwards. (A,* TA.)

xuDotu biqidoHK fiI AlqidaAHi, (A, TA,) inf. n. xiyaADN; and xaAwaDotu↓ AlqidaAHa, inf. n. xiwaADN; (TA;) ‡ I put an arrow, (A, TA,) which I had borrowed, and by which I expected to have good luck, (TA,) among the [other] arrows (A, TA) used in the game called el-meysir: (TA:) see an ex. (a verse of Sakhr-el-Gheí) in art. xD.
2: see 1, first signification:
and again {1} in the latter part of the paragraph.
xaw-aDa fiI najiyEihi [app. meaning He wallowed in his effused blood] is with teshdeed to render the signification intensive. (Ṣ.)
3: see 1, second sentence, in two places: and again {1} in the last sentence.

hom.sense: 4. OaxaDotu fiI AlmaMCi dAb-atiI [I made my beast to wade, or ford, through the water]. (Ṣ, A.*) AxAD Alqawomu xayolahumu AlmaMCa [The people, or company of men, made their horses to wade, or ford, through the water] is said when they wade, or ford, with their horses through the water. (TA.) AxAD Alqawomu: and AxADwA AlmaMCa: [which are evidently elliptical phrases:] and AxAD Alfarasa: see 1, second sentence.
AxAD AlbaATila: see 1.
AxAD AlmaMCu The water admitted of being walked [or waded or forded] in or through: contr. to general rule; being intrans. while the unaugmented verb is trans. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, first sentence.
txw-D also signifies He constrained himself to wade, or ford, in, or through, water. (Ḳ,* TA.) This is the primary signification: and hence,

txw-D fiI AlOamori ‡ He employed, or occupied, himself in the affair: and he used art or artifice or cunning, or his own judgment or discretion, in the affair, or in the disposal or management thereof: and so in the phrase txw-D fI AlmaAli: or, accord. to some, this means he acted wrongly in acquiring the property in an improper manner, in whatsoever way it was possible. (TA.)
6: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph.
8: see 1, first sentence.
maxaADN: see maxaADapN.

mixowaDN [The instrument with which beverage, or wine, is mixed and stirred about]; it is, for beverage, or wine, like the mijodaH for sawiyq: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the instrument with which swyq is stirred about. (A, Mgh.)

maxaADapN [A ford; i. e.] a place where people pass through water, walking or riding: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or a place where one walks through water: (Mṣb:) pl. maxaADN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [or this is rather a coll. gen. n.,] or maxaAYiDu, (as in one copy of the Ṣ,) and maxaAwiDu (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ) and maxaADaAtN. (Mṣb, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xaAfa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) originally xawifa, (Lth, L, &c.,) first pers. xifotu, (TA,) aor. yaxaAfu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) originally yaxowafu, (L,) imperative xafo, (Ṣ,) inf. n. xawofN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and xiyfN↓, [originally xiwofN,] (Lḥ, TA,) erroneously written in the Ḳ with fet-ḥ [to the x], but some say that this is a simple subst., not an inf. n., (TA,) and xiyfapN↓, (Lḥ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) originally xiwofapN, (Ḳ,) but some say that this also is a simple subst., not an inf. n., (TA,) and [therefore] its pl. is xiyfN, (Lḥ, JK, Ṣ, and so in the CK,) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ erroneously written xiyafN, (TA,) or this [as well as the next preceding] may be an inf. n., for some few inf. ns. have pls., (ISd, TA,) and maxaAfapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) originally maxowafapN, for which last, the first of these inf. ns. is used by a poet, and therefore made fem., (TA,) He feared; he was afraid or frightened or terrified; syn. faziEa. (Ḳ.) It is also trans.: (Mṣb:) you say, xaAfahu and txw-fhu↓ [He feared, or was afraid of, him, or it]; (Mṣb, TA;) both signifying the same: (TA:) [and so xaAfa minohu; or this may mean he feared what might happen to him from him, or it:] and txw-f↓ Ealayohi XayoYFA, meaning xaAfahu [i. e. xaAfa Ealayohi XayoYFA He feared for him a thing]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and xaAafahu EalaI maAlihi and txw-fhu↓ Ealayohi [He feared him, or it, for his property]. (Mgh.)

[Hence,] it is also used in the sense of Zan-a [He thought, or opined]: and in this case, the Arabs sometimes use it in the same manner as a verb signifying an oath, and give it the same kind of complement; as in an ex. cited voce darida [q. v.]. (Ṣ in art. drd.) And He knew. (Lḥ, Kr, Ḳ.) Hence, waUini QmoraOapN xaAfato mino baEolihaA nuXuwzFA [And if a woman know that there is, on the part of her husband, injurious treatment, or unkindness, or estrangement], (Ḳ,) in the Ḳur [iv. 127]. (TA.) And hence also, famano xaAfa mino muwSK janafFA [And he who knoweth that there is, on the part of the testator, an inclining to a wrong course, or a declining from the right course,, &c.], (Ḳ,) in the Ḳur [ii. 178]; thus explained by Lḥ. (TA.)

xaAfahu, (Ṣ,) first pers. xufotuhu, (Ḳ,) aor. yaxuwfuhu, (Ṣ,) He exceeded him in fear. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) You say, xaAwafahu↓ faxaAfahu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. of the former muxaAwafahu, (TA,) i. e. [He vied with him to see which of them would exceed the other in fear, and] he exceeded him in fear. (Ṣ.)

2. xw-fhu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxowiyfN, (TA,) i. q. OaxaAfahu. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) See the latter, in two places. He put fear into him. (JK, TA.) xaw-ifonaA [app. addressed to God] is mentioned by Lḥ as meaning Render the Ḳur-án and the Traditions beautiful to us in order that we may [give heed thereto and] fear. (TA.)

He made him to be in such a state, or condition, that men feared him; (JK, Ḳ;) he made him to be feared by men. (M.) Hence, in the Ḳur [iii. 169], Uin-amaA celikumu QlX-ayoTaAnu yuxaw-ifu OawoliyaMCahu, i. e. [Verily that is the devil:] he causeth his friends to be feared by you: [or that devil causeth, &c.:] or, as Th says, causeth you to fear by his friends. (TA.)
He diminished it, lessened it, or took from it; and so xw-f minohu. (TA.) [See also 5.]
xw-f ganabahu He sent away his sheep, or goats, flock by flock. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3: see 1, last sentence.

4. AxAfhu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UixaAfapN (Ṣ) and UixaAfN, like kitaAbN, (Lḥ, TA,) [but the latter is irreg. and rare,] He, or it, (an affair, a case, or an event, Mṣb,) caused him, or made him, to fear, or be afraid; put him in fear; frightened, or terrified, him; (TA;) and xw-fhu↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxowiyfN, (Ṣ, TA,) signifies the same. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) So in the phrase AxAf Alv-agoru [The enemies' frontier caused to fear,, &c.; was insecure:] or fear entered from it. (TA.) You say also, maAla AlHaAYiTu faOaxaAfa Aln-aAsa [The wall leaned, and caused the people to fear]. (Mṣb.) And OaxaAfa All-uSuwSu AlT-ariyqa [for OaxaAfa All-uSuwSu Oahola AlT-ariyqi The robbers caused the people of the road, or the passengers thereof, to fear,, &c.; or it may be rendered the robbers caused the road to be insecure]. (Mṣb.) And Oaxafotuhu AlOamora faxaAfahu [I caused him to fear the thing, or affair,, &c., and he feared it; making the verb doubly trans.]; as also xaw-afotuhu↓ Uiy-aAhu fataxaw-afahu. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., OaxiyfuwA AlhawaAm-a qabola Oano tuxiyfakumo Make ye the venomous reptiles and the like to fear before they make you to fear; (TA;) i. e. kill ye them before they kill you. (JM, TA.)
maA OaxowafaniI Ealayoka [How greatly do I fear for thee!]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5. txw-fhu: see 1, in three places.

Also He took by little and little (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) from it, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or from its sides; (L;) as also tHw-fhu: (Ṣ and Ḳ * in arts. Hwf and Hyf:) or he took from its extremities; so in the A; in which it is said to be tropical: accord. to IF, it is originally [txw-n,] with n [in the place of the f]. (TA.) Dhu-rRummeh says, (Ṣ,) or not he, but some other poet, for it is ascribed to several different authors, (L,)
taxaw-afa Alr-aHolu minohaA taAmikFA qaridFA
kamaA taxaw-afa Zahora Aln-aboEapi Als-afanu
[Her saddle abraded from a long and high, compact hump, like as when the piece of skin used for smoothing arrows has abraded from the back of a rod of the tree called nbEp]. (Ṣ. [See also 5 in art. Hwf, where another reading of this verse is given. In the TA, in the present art., in the places of AlrHl and Zhr, I find Als-ayoru and Euwd.]) Hence, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) accord. to Fr, (TA,) OawoyaOaxacihimo EalaI taxaw-ufK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the Ḳur [xvi. 49], (Ṣ,) which Az explains as meaning [Or are they secure from his destroying them] by causing them to suffer loss [by little and little] in their bodies and their possessions, or cattle, and their fruits: or, accord. to Zj, it may mean, after causing them to fear, by destroying a town, so that the one next to it shall fear. (TA.) You say also, txw-f mino maAliI He took by little and little from my property. (JK.) And taxaw-afanaA Als-anapu [The year of drought, or sterility, took from us by little and little]. (JK.) And taxaw-faniI Haq-iI [He diminished to me by little and little my right, or due]. (JK.) And taxaw-afahu Hmoquhu ‡ i. q. AhoDamahu [an evident mistranscription for AihotaDamahu or haDamahu, meaning His stupidity deprived him of his right, or due]. (TA.)

entry.sense: xaAfN A man very fearful or timorous; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [and so, in the present day, xaw-aAfN↓; the former originally] of the measure faEilN, like fariqN and faziEN; and similar to SaAtN, meaning a man “having a strong, or loud, voice:” (Ṣ:) or i. q. xaAYifN↓: (TA:) accord. to Kh, it may be [originally xaAwifN,] of the measure faAEilN, having the medial radical rejected; or [xawofN,] of the measure faEolN; and in either case, the dim. is [xuwayofN↓,] with w: so says Sb. (TA.)

hom.sense: xawofN inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.)
Also Slaughter: whence, walanaboluwan-akumo biXaIoCK mina Qloxawofi [And we will assuredly try you with somewhat of slaughter]; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) in the Ḳur [ii. 150]. (TA.) [See also 4.]
And Fighting: whence, faUicaA jaMCa Alxawofu [But when fighting cometh; in the Ḳur xxxiii. 19]. (Ḳ.)
See also xaAYifN.

Also A red hide from which are cut strips like thongs, (Kr, Ḳ, TA,) and then upon these are put [ornaments of the kind termed] Xacor; worn by a girl: (TA:) a dial. var. of HawofN [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) but this latter is preferable. (L, TA.)

entry.sense: xiyfN: see 1, first sentence.
