xaAfapN A [coat of the kind called] jub-ap, of hide, or leather, which the collector of honey wears; (Akh, JK, Ḳ;) and also worn by the water-carrier: (JK:) or a fur-garment, or hide with the fur or wool on it, worn by him who enters into the places occupied by bees, in order that they may not sting him: (TA:) or a [pouch of the kind termed] xariyTap, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of hide, or leather, (Ṣ,) narrow in the upper part and wide in the lower part, (TA,) in which honey is collected: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a [round piece of leather with a running string by means of which it may be converted into a bag, such as is termed] suforap, like the xariyTap, made, or sewed, small, [for muSoEadapN or muSaE-adapN, which I find in different copies of the Ḳ, and to which no appropriate meaning is assignable, I read muSogarapN or muSag-arapN, (see 2 in art. Sgr, and particularly OaSogara Alqirobapa,)] having its head [or border] raised, for honey; (Ḳ;) so says Skr, in explaining the following verse: or, as IB says, accord. to Aboo-ʼAlee, it is from the phrase Aln-aAsu OaxoyaAfN, meaning “men,” or “the people,” “are different, one from another;” for it is a xariyTap of hide, or leather, embellished with different kinds of embellishment; and if so it should be mentioned in art. xyf: (TA:) [but] the dim. is xuwayofapN↓. (JK.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, [describing a collector of wild honey,]
taOab-aTa xaAfapF fiyhaA misaAbN
faOaSobaHa yaqotariI maXadFA biXiyqi , (Ṣ,) [He put beneath his armpit a xAfp in which was a receptacle for honey, and betook himself to making successive endeavours to reach the most difficult part of a mountain by means of a rope, or rope of palm-fibres; for] he means XiyqFA bimasadK; the phrase being inverted: (Ṣ and TA in art. Xyq:) or he means, [betook himself to] taking successive holds of a rope (yatatab-aEu HabolFA) tied to a Xyq [here best rendered mountain-top] in his descent to the place of the honey; so that there is no inversion. (TA in that art.)
Also i. q. EayobapN [A kind of basket, or receptacle, of hide, or leather]; (TA;) the thing in which fruits are gathered; also called mixorafN. (Ḥar p. 374.)

And xaAfapu Alz-aroEi is said to mean The envelope of the grain of seed-produce; so called because it protects it: to this the believer is likened in a trad. [as some relate it]; but the reading [commonly known] is [xaAmap,] with m. (TA.) [See xAmp, in art. xym.]

hom.sense: xiyfapN; pl. xiyfN: see 1, first sentence.
[Sometimes it may mean, agreeably with analogy, A kind of fear.]
See also art. xyf.

entry.sense: xawaAfN Vociferation, clamour, or a confused noise, of a company of men. (JK, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
xuwayofN: see xaAfN.
xuwayofapN: see xaAfapN.
xaw-aAfN: see xaAfN.
[Hence, perhaps,] A certain black bird: ISd says, I know not why it is thus called. (TA.)

xaAYifN Fearing; being afraid or frightened or terrified: (Ṣ,* TA:) pl. xuw-afN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xuy-afN, (Ṣ,) or xiy-afN, (Ḳ,) or, accord. to Ks, xuy-afN and xiyfN and xuwfN, (L,) [but the second and third of these three should be xiy-afN and xuw-afN, for all are said to be of the measure fuE-alN,] and xawofN↓; or this last is a quasi-pl. n.; (Ḳ;) whence, in the Ḳur [vii. 54], xawofFA waTamaEFA, meaning Worship ye Him fearing his punishment and eagerly desiring his recompense. (TA.) See also xaAfN.
And see maxuwfN.
TariyqN muxaAfN [for muxaAfN Oaholuhu, A road of which the people, or passengers, are caused to fear, by robbers]. (Mṣb.) [See also what next follows.]

Tariyqu maxuwfN A road in which people fear: (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a road that is feared; (JK, TA;) as also maxiyfN↓, and xaAYifN↓; which last is tropical, of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; (TA;) or, thus applied, this last [is a possessive epithet, and thus] means having fear: (JK: [see also muxaAfN:]) you should not say TariyqN muxiyfN↓, because the road does not cause fear, but only he who robs and slays therein. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.) One says also vagorN maxiyfN↓ and mutaxaw-afN↓ An enemies' frontier [that is feared, or] from which one fears, or from the direction of which fear comes. (TA.) maxuwfN signifies A thing [of any kind] that is feared; as a lion, and a serpent, and fire, and the like. (Ḥar p. 369.) [Hence,] HaAYiTN maxuwfN A wall of which the falling is feared. (Lḥ, Mṣb, TA. [See also muxiyfN.]) And wajaEN maxuwfN [A pain that is feared]. (TA. [See, again, muxiyfN.]) And OamorN maxuwfN [An affair, or event, that is feared]. (Mgh, Mṣb. [See, again, muxiyfN.]) And faAsiqN maxuwfN EalaI maAlihi A transgressor who is feared for his property, that he will consume it, and expend it in that which is not right. (Mgh.)
maxiyfN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places: and see also what next follows.

HaAYiTN muxiyfN (Mṣb, Ḳ, in the CK maxiyfN↓,) A wall that causes one to fear that it will fall. (Mṣb, Ḳ.* [See also maxuwfN.]) And wajaEN muxiyfN (Ṣ, Ḳ) A pain that causes him who sees it to fear. (Ṣ. [See, again, maxuwfN.]) And OamorN muxiyfN An affair, or event, that is formidable; that causes him who sees it to fear. (Mṣb. [See, again, maxuwfN.]) And Almuxiyfu means The lion, (Ḳ, TA,) that frightens him who sees him. (TA.) See also maxuwfN, first sentence.

OaxowafN [More, and most, formidable, fearful, or feared: anomalous, like its syn. OaxoXaI, being from the pass. verb. Hence,] Oaxowafu maA OaxaAfu Ealayokumo kacaA [The most formidable, or fearful, of what I fear for you is such a thing]. (Mgh,* TA.)
maxaAfapN an inf. n. of 1, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) originally maxowafapN. (TA.)

[Also A cause of fear: a word of the same category as majobanapN and maboxalapN, &c.: pl. maxaAwifu. Hence,] Oaw-alu kutubihi AlmaxaAwifu [The first of his letters, or epistles, consisted of the causes of fear]. (TA.)
And maxaAwifu also signifies Places of fear. (KL.)
mutaxaw-afN: see maxuwfN.

hom.sense: 1. xuqo xuqo [imperative of xaAqa] Ornament thy young woman, or female slave, with the earring. (Ḳ. [See xawoqN.])
xaAqahaA He (a man, TA) made with her (a woman, TA) the sound termed HaAqi baAqi [during the act of nikaAH]. (Ḳ.)
xAq AlX-aIoCa He took away the thing, and extirpated it, or removed it utterly. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. xw-qhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taxowiyqN, (TA,) He made it wide; (Ḳ;) namely, an earring. (TA.)
4. AxAq He (a man, TA) went away into, or in, the country, or land. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
5. txw-q It (an earring, TA) was, or became, wide, or widened. (Ḳ.) [See also 7.]
txw-q Eanohu He went, retired, or withdrew himself, far away from him, or it. (Ḳ,* TA.) And He left, quitted, or forsook, it; namely, a course that he desired, or meant, to pursue. (TA.)
7. AnxAqt AlmafaAzapu The desert was wide within. (JK, Ḳ,* TA.) [See also 5.]

hom.sense: xaAqN The length of a desert. (JK, TA.)

AlxaAqi baAqi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or xaAqi baAqi, (IB, TA,) or the latter also, without Al, (Ḳ, accord. to the TA, [but not in the CK nor in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,]) The sound of the cakar in the flesh of the interior of the faroj; (IAạr, Ḳ,* TA;) or the sound of the faroj on the occasion of the act of nikaAH. (IB, TA.)
And hence, (IB, TA,) or because of its xawaq, i. e. width, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) The faroj [or vulva, itself]. (Ṣ, IB, Ḳ.) AlxaAqi baAqi is indecl., with kesr for its termination, (Ṣ,) like AlxaAzi baAzi. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xawoqN [in the L xuwq, which is evidently a mistranscription; and in one copy of the Ṣ, in one place, written xawoqap;] A ring (Ṣ, L, TA) of gold and of silver: (L, TA:) or, accord. to Th, a ring [that is worn] in the ear: he does not say of gold nor of silver: (TA:) or the ring of the [kind of earring called] quroT and of the [kind called] Xanof. (Lth, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: xawaqN Width (Ṣ, Ḳ) of a desert, and of a well, and of a vulva: (Ṣ:) or, of a desert, width of the interior: (JK:) or length, and breadth of expanse, and width of the interior: and of a well, depth and width. (TA.)
And The mange, or scab, in camels: (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or [a disease] like the mange or scab. (TA.)

Oaxowaqu [Wide; or wide in the interior; or farextending: fem. xawoqaMCu: pl. xuwqN].
You say xaroqN Oaxoraqu (JK, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK jawofN, and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ xawoqN,]) A wide [desert such as is termed] xaroq: (Ḳ:) or a xaroq wide in the interior. (JK.) And mafaAzapN xawoqaMCu (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and munoxaAqapN↓ (JK, Ḳ) A wide desert: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a desert wide in the interior: (JK:) and the former, also, a desert in which is no water. (TA.) And baladN OaxowaqN A wide, far-extending region or country. (TA.) And biYorN xawoqaMCu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and munoxaAqapN↓ (Ḳ) A wide well: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or rakiy-apN xawoqaACu a deep and wide well. (JK, TA.)
And the fem., xawoqaMCu, applied to a woman, Having no partition between her vulva and her anus: or having her vagina and rectum united: or wide in the vulva: (TA:) or tall and slender. (JK, TA.)
And, so applied, Foolish, or stupid: (ISh, JK, Ḳ:) pl. xuwqN. (ISh, Ḳ.)
And the masc., (applied to a man, JK,) Blind of one eye; or one-eyed: (JK, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (JK.)
Also, applied to a camel, Mangy, or scabby: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or having what resembles the mange or scab: (TA:) fem. as above. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: muxaw-aqN An earring having a large xawoq [or ring]. (IAạr.)
mafaAzapN munoxaAqapN and biYorN munoxaAqapN: see Oaxowaqu.

hom.sense: 1. xaAla, aor. yaxuwlu, inf. n. xawolN, He became possessed of xawal [so I read, meaning slaves, or servants, and other dependents, in the place of xwAl, an evident mistranscription, in the TA,] after having been alone. (TA.)

fulaAnN yaxuwlu EalaI Oaholihi Such a one pastures for his family: (Ṣ:) or yaxuwlu Ealayohimo signifies he milks and waters and pastures for them. (T, TA.) And xAl Ealayohimo He ruled, or governed, them. (JK.) And xAl maAlahu, (Ḳ,* TA,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. xawolN and xiyaAlN, (Ḳ,) He pastured his cattle, or camels, &c., and managed them, or tended them, and sustained them, (Ḳ,* TA,) well: (Ḳ:) or xulotu AlmaAla, aor. Oaxuwlu, I managed the cattle,, &c., well: (Ṣ:) and xAl EalaI AlmaAli, aor. yaxuwlu, he pastured the cattle,, &c., and managed them well; as also xAl, aor. yaxiylu. (TA in art. xyl.)
xAl, aor. yaxuwlu and yaxaAlu or yaxiylu, see AxtAl (with which it is syn.) in art. xyl.

entry.sense: 2. xw-lhu Qll-ehu AlX-aIoCa, (JK, Ṣ,) or maAlFA, (Mṣb,) or AlmaAla, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taxowiylN, (Ṣ,) God made him to possess, (JK, Ṣ,) or gave him, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or conferred upon him, as a favour, (Ḳ,) the thing, (JK, Ṣ,) or property, (Mṣb,) or the property. (Ḳ.) So in the Ḳur vi. 94 and xxxix. 11 [and 50]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Oaxowala (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Ouxowila (Ḳ) He (a man, JK, Mṣb) had maternal uncles: (JK, Ḳ:) or he had many maternal uncles: (Mṣb:) [both signify the same accord. to the Ḳ: but the latter properly signifies he was made to have maternal uncles, or many maternal uncles: see muxowalN.]
AxAl fiyhi xaAlFA↓ mina Alxayori He perceived, or discovered, in him an indication, or a symptom, sign, mark, or token, of good; as also txw-l↓ (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and txy-l. (Ḳ.) [See also 2 in art. xyl.]
See also 10, in two places.
5: see 4:
and see also 10, in three places.

txw-lhu also signifies He paid frequent attention, or returned time after time, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) to it, (JK,) or to him; syn. taEah-adahu. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, taxaw-alotuhumo biAlmawoEiZapi I paid frequent attention to them with exhorting, or admonishing; syn. taEah-adotuhumo. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., of the Prophet, kaAna yataxaw-alunaA biAlmawoEiZapi maxaAfapa Als-aMmapi [He used to pay frequent attention to us with exhorting, or admonishing, for fear of loathing on our part, or disgust]; (Ṣ;) or yataxaw-aluhumo, i. e. yataEah-aduhumo: (TA:) Aṣ used to say yataxaw-anunaA, i. e. yataEah-adunaA; (Ṣ;) or yataxaw-anuhumo: and some read yataHaw-aluhumo, with the unpointed H, explained in art. Hwl. (TA.) And sometimes they said, txw-lti Alr-iyHu AlOaroDa, i. e. taEah-adatohaA [app. meaning The wind returned to the land time after time]. (Ṣ.)
10. Aisotaxowalahumo He took them as xawal, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. slaves, or servants, and other dependents. (TA.)

Astxwl fiyhimo and AstxAl He took, or adopted, them as maternal uncles: and txw-l↓ xaAlFA he took, or adopted, a maternal uncle; (Ḳ;) like as one says, taEam-ama Eam-FA: and taxaw-alatohu↓ She called him her maternal uncle. (TA.) You say, Aisotaxilo xaAlFA gayora xaAlika and Aisotaxowilo (JK, Ṣ) and taxaw-ala↓ (JK) Adopt thou a maternal uncle other than thy [proper] maternal uncle. (JK,* Ṣ.)

AlAisotixowaAlu is also like AlAisotixobaAlu [as meaning The asking one to lend cattle, or camels, &c.: and AlUixowaAlu↓ is like AlUixobaAlu as meaning The lending cattle, or camels, &c.]: and AO used to recite thus the saying of Zuheyr:
hunaAlaka Uino yusotaxowaluwA AlmaAla yuxowiluwA↓
[There, if they be asked to lend cattle, they lend]. (Ṣ, TA. [See also 10 in art. xbl.])

xaAlN A maternal uncle; one's mother's brother: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. OaxowaAlN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OaxowilapN, (Ḳ,) [both pls. of pauc.,] the latter anomalous, (TA,) and (of mult., TA) xuw-alN and xuWuwlN (Ḳ) and xuWuwlapN: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) the fem. is xaAla, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) a maternal aunt; one's mother's sister: (JK, Ṣ:) and the pl. of this is xaAlaAtN. (Mṣb.) One says, humaAQbonaA xaAlapK [meaning Each of them two is a son of a maternal aunt of the other]; but one cannot say, QbonaA Eam-apK: (Ḳ:) and in like manner one says, QbonaA Eam-F; but one cannot say, QbonaA xaAlK. (TA.)
An owner of a horse: you say, OanaA xaAlu hecaA Alfarasi I am the owner of this horse. (Ḳ.) [See also xaAlN in art. xyl.]

huwa xaAlu maAlK and xaAYilu↓ maAlK He is a manager, or tender, of cattle, or camels, &c.; (Ḳ;) or a good manager or tender thereof; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) and so xawoliI-u↓ maAlK: (Ṣ:) xaAYilN↓ signifies also a keeper, or guardian, of a thing; (T, Ṣ;) or a pastor; (Fr, TA;) a people's pastor, who milks and waters and pastures for them; and one who pays frequent attention to a thing, puts it into a good or right state, or restores it to such a state, and undertakes the management of it: (T, TA:) xuw-alN [is a pl. of xaAYilN, like as nuw-amN is of naAYimN, &c., and] signifies pastors who take care of cattle, or camels, &c.: (TA:) and xawoliI-N↓, (Ḳ,) or, accord. to the M, xawaliI-N↓, (TA,) signifies a pastor who is a good manager of cattle, or camels, and sheep or goats; (M, Ḳ,* TA;) or a good manager and orderer of the affairs of men; (TA;) and its pl. [or quasi-pl. n. or n. un.] is xawalN↓; (M, Ḳ;) accord. to the M, like as EarabN is of EarabiI-N. (TA.) [See also xaAlN in art. xyl.]
An indication, or a symptom, sign, mark, or token, of good (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA) in a person. (Ṣ, TA.) See 4.
A mole; i. e. [a thing resembling] a pimple in the face, inclining to blackness: dim. xuwayolN↓ and xuyayolN: and pl. xiylaAnN. (JK. [See also art. xyl.])
The [kind of banner called] liwaMC, of an army or a military force. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [See also art. xyl.])

A kind of soft garment, or cloth, of the fabric of El-Yemen: (JK:) a kind of burod, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ,) having a red [or brown] ground, with black lines or stripes. (TA. [Mentioned also in art. xyl.])
A black stallion-camel. (IAạr, Ḳ. [See also art. xyl.])

xawalN A man's slaves, or servants, and other dependents: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) or slaves, and cattle, or camels, &c.: (JK:) or the cattle, camels, &c., [in the CK, Aln-iEam is erroneously put for Aln-aEam,] and male and female slaves, and other dependents, given to one by God: (Ḳ:) said to be (Ṣ) from 2 [q. v.]: (JK, Ṣ, TA:) it is said to be a quasi-pl. n.; (TA;) and the sing. is xaAYilN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) though used as sing. and pl., and masc. and fem.: (Ḳ:) sometimes used as a sing. applied to a male slave and a female slave: but Fr says that it is pl. [or quasi-pl. n.] of xaAYilN↓ meaning a pastor. (Ṣ.) You say heWulaMCi xawalu fulaAnK, meaning These are persons who have been subjected, and taken as slaves, by such a one. (TA.)
See also xaAlN.

Also A gift, or gifts: [and this seems to be the primary signification; whence “a slave”, &c., and “slaves”, &c., as being given by God:] so in the phrase, huwa kavru Alxawali [He is a person of many gifts]. (TA.)

Accord. to Lth, (TA,) it signifies also The lower part (OaSol) of the faOos [q. v.] of a bit: (JK, Ḳ, TA:) but Az says, “I know not the xwl of the bit nor what it is. (TA.) [See xaAlN, last sentence but one, in art. xyl.]

entry.sense: xawolapN A female gazelle. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
xawoliI-N: see xaAlN, in two places.
Also A measurer of land with the measuring-cane. (TA.)
xawaliI-N: see xaAlN.
xuwayolN: see xaAlN, of which it is the dim.

hom.sense:
xuWuwlapN The relationship of a maternal uncle [and of a maternal aunt]: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) an inf. n. (JK, TA) having no verb. (TA.)
You say, bayoniI wabayonahu xuWuwlapN [Between me and him is a relationship of maternal uncle]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also a pl. of xaAlN in the first of the senses assigned to the latter above. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xaw-aAlN A giver of many gifts. (TA.)
xaAYilN: see xaAlN, in two places:
and xawalN, also in two places.

hom.sense: taTaAyara AlX-araru Oaxowala Oaxowala The sparks flew about scattered; meaning the sparks that fly about from hot iron when it is beaten; as in a verse of Dábi [El-Burjumee] cited in art. sqT: see 3 in that art. (Ṣ.) And cahabuw Oaxowala Oaxowala They went away scattered, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) one after another, like as sparks are scattered from iron: or, as some say, AlOaxowalu itself means sparks: (JK:) [but here,] Axwl Axwl are two nouns made into one, and indecl., with fet-ḥ for the termination: (Ṣ:) Sb says that they may be like Xagara bagara, or like yawoma yawoma. (TA.)
huwa Oaxowalu mino fulaAnK He is prouder than such a one. (Suh, TA.) [See also Oaxoyalu, in art. xyl.]

entry.sense: muxaAlN: see muxowalN.
maxuwlN: see OaxoyalN, in art. xyl.

muxowalN and muxowilN↓ A man having maternal uncles: (TA:) or the former signifies a man made to have many maternal uncles; and ↓the latter, having many maternal uncles: (Mṣb:) and rajulN muEam-N muxowalN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and muxaAlN↓, (JK, Ḳ,) and muEim-N muxowilN↓, A man who has generous paternal and maternal uncles: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) but Aṣ disallows muEim-N and muxowilN↓: (Mṣb:) and the latter word in each case is not used, (Ḳ,) or is scarcely ever used, (TA,) without the former. (Ḳ, TA.)
muxowilN: see what next precedes, in four places.

Uin-ahu lamaxiylN liloxayori, (Ḳ in this art.,) or muxiylN, (Ṣ in art. xyl,) Verily he is adapted or disposed by nature to good [i. e. to be, or to do, or to effect, or to produce, what is good]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also muxiylN in art. xyl.]
4. AxAm: see art. xym.
xaAmN: see art. xym.
xaAmapN: see art. xym.

1. xaAnahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yaxuwnuhu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. xiyaAnapN and xawonN and maxaAnapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xaAnapN (Ḳ) and xaAYinapN, of the measure faAEilapN, like laAgiyapN, &c.; (TA;) and AxtAnhu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He was unfaithful, or he acted unfaithfully, to the confidence, or trust, that he reposed in him; (Ḳ;) [he was treache rous, perfidious, or unfaithful, to him; or he acted treacherously, perfidiously, or unfaithfully, towards him;] fiI kacaA [in such a thing]: (Ṣ:) xiyaAnapN is the contr. of OamaAnapN; and does not relate only to property, but also to other things: (Mgh:) or the neglecting, or failing in, OamaAnapN [which is trustiness, or faithfulness]: (El-Harállee, TA:) or i. q. nifaAqN, except that xyAnp regards a compact or covenant or the like, and trustiness, or faith fulness, and nfAq regards religion; so that the former is the acting contrary to what is right, by breaking a compact or covenant or the like: (Er Rághib, TA:) but [it is said that] the primary signification of xawonN is the making to suffer loss, or diminution; because the xaAYin makes the maxuwn to suffer loss, or diminution, of something. (TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [ii. 183], kunotumo taxotaAnuwna↓ Oanofusakumo [lit. Ye used to act unfaith fully to yourselves] means ye used to act un faithfully, one to another: (Ṣ,* TA:) or ye used to act wrongfully to yourselves: AixotiyaAnN has a more intensive signification than xiyaAnapN. (Bḍ.) One says also, xAn AlEahoda He broke the compact or covenant or the like: whence, taquwlu Aln-iEomapu kufirotu walamo OuXokaro wataquwlu AlOamaAnapu xunotu walamo OuHofaZo [The benefit says, I have been disacknowledged, and have not been requited with thankfulness; and the trust says, I have been betrayed, and have not been faithfully kept]: the verb [xunotu] being here of the measure fuEilotu, a verb of which the agent is not named. (Mgh.) And xaAnahu AlEahoda, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and fiI AlEahodi, (Mṣb,) and xAnhu AlOamaAnapa, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, inf. n. xawonN and xiyaAnapN and maxaAnapN, (Mṣb,) [He was unfaithful to him in respect of the compact or covenant or the like, and the trust.]

[Hence,] xAn sayofuhu † [His sword was unfaithful;] i. e., failed of taking ef fect upon the thing struck with it. (TA.) A cer tain person, being asked respecting the sword, said, Oaxuwka warub-amaA xaAnaka † [It is thy brother, but sometimes it is unfaithful to thee]. (TA.)
And xaAnatohu rijolaAhu † [His two legs were unfaithful to him;] he was unable to walk. (TA.)
And xAn Ald-alowa Alr-iXaMCu † The well-rope broke off, or be came severed, from the bucket. (TA.)

And xAnhu Ald-ahoru, inf. n. xawonN; (T, TA;) and txw-nhu↓; (TA;) † Time altered his state, or condition, (T, TA,) from softness, or easiness, to hardness, or difficulty, (TA,) or to evil; (T, TA;) and in like manner, Aln-aEiymu [enjoyment,, &c.]: and of everything that has altered thy state, or condition, [for the worse,] one says, taxaw-anaka↓. (T, TA.)
2. xw-nhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxowiynN, (Ḳ,) He attributed to him xiyaAnap [i. e. treachery, perfidy, or unfaithfulness]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 5, in two places.

hom.sense: 5. txw-nhu: see 1, last sentence, in two places. You say also, taxaw-anahumo meaning He sought [to discover, or show,] their xiyaAnap [i. e. treachery, perfidy, or unfaithfulness], and their slip, lapse, or wrong action; and suspected them, or accused them. (TA.)

Also He, or it, diminished it, wasted it, impaired it, or took from it; and so xw-nhu↓, and xw-n minohu: (Ḳ:) or diminished it, wasted it, impaired it, or took from it, by little and little; syn. tanaq-aSahu. (JK,* Ṣ, Mṣb.) You say, taxawananiI fulaAnN Haq-iI Such a one took from me by little and little of my right, or due. (Ṣ, TA.) And Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
laA balo huwa AlX-awoqu mino daArK taxaw-anahaA
mar-FA saHaAbN wamar-FA baAriHN taribu
[No, but it is, or was, yearning of the soul arising from a place of abode from which some times raining clouds, and sometimes a hot wind carrying with it dust, took away by little and little, so as gradually to efface the traces thereof]. (Ṣ, TA.) And Lebeed says, (Ṣ, TA,) describing a she-camel, (TA,)
taxaw-anahaA nuzuwliI waQrotiHaAliI
[Which my alighting and my journeying had wasted by little and little;] i. e. whose flesh and fat my alighting and my journeying had diminished by little and little. (Ṣ, TA.)

Also He paid frequent attention to him, or it; or he, or it, returned to him, or it, time after time; syn. taEah-adahu; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so xw-nhu↓: (Ḳ:) in this sense, the former verb is [said to be] from txw-lhu, by the substitution of n for l (TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, [describing a young gazelle,]
laA yanoEaXu AlT-arofa Uil-aA maA taxaw-anahu
daAEK yunaAdiyhi biQsomi AlmaMCi maboguwmu , (Ṣ,) [He raises not his eye, or eyes, except when a caller calling him by the sound of maMCi returns to him time after time, addressed by the cry termed bugaAm:] i. e. except when he hears the bugaAm of his mother calling him by the cry maMCi maMCi: (TA in art. bgm: [it is there added, that the pass. part. n. maboguwm is used in this instance for the act. part. n.; but for this I see no sufficient reason:]) he says that the young gazelle is slum bering, not raising his eye, or eyes, unless his mother comes to him time after time: or, as some say, unless his mother's call to him takes by little and little from his sleep. (Ṣ in the present art.) One says also AlHum-aItaxaw-anuhu [for tataxaw-anuhu] The fever returns to him time after time: (Ṣ:) or in its time. (TA.)

entry.sense: 8: see 1, in two places.

hom.sense: xaAnN A place in which travellers lodge: (Mṣb:) a place in which travellers pass the night: and the dayor [i. e. monastery, or convent,] is the xAn of the Christians: (Kull pp. 96 and 97:) or the xAn is for merchants; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. q. funoduqN; (Ḥar p. 325;) [a building for the reception of mer chants and travellers and their goods, generally surrounding a square or an oblong court, having, on the ground-floor, vaulted magazines for mer chandise, which face the court, and lodgings, or other magazines, above: a Persian word, arabi cized:] pl. xaAnaAtN (Mṣb.)
Also A shop: or a shop-keeper: (Ḳ:) a Persian word, arabicised. (TA.)

[It is also a title of honour, used by the Tartars (who apply it to their Emperor), the Turks (who apply it to the reigning and to a deceased Sultán), and the Persians (who apply it to the governor of a province, and to a man of rank).]

entry.sense: xawonN an inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And [hence,] ‡ Weakness. (JK, Ḳ, TA.) One says fiI Zahorihi xawonN ‡ In his back is weakness. (JK, TA.)
And † Languidness in the sight. (Ḳ.)
xaAniI-N Of, or belonging to, a xAn of the mer chants. (TA.)

xiwaAnN (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xuwaAnN (ISk, Mṣb, Ḳ) and UixowaAnN↓, (IF, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the first of which is the most common, (Mṣb,) A table; (JK;) a thing upon which one eats; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) a thing upon which food is eaten: (Ḳ:) but said to be not so called except when food is upon it: (Ḥar p. 360:) arabicized [from the Persian]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) the pl. (of pauc., of the first, Ṣ, Mṣb) is OaxowinapN and (of mult., Ṣ, Mṣb) xuwnN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said by IB to be the only instance of its kind except buwnN pl. of biwaAnN, (TA,) originally xuwunN, like kutubN pl. of kitaAbN, (Mṣb,) but xuwunN is not used: (Ṣ:) the pl. of AxwAn↓ is OaxaAwinu, (Mṣb,) or OaxaAwiynu. (TA, from a trad.)
xaWuwnN [for xawuwnN]: see xaAYinN.

hom.sense: xaw-aAnN: see xaAYinN.
[Hence,] Alxaw-aAnu The lion: (JK, Ṣ:) because he is [very] treacherous. (JK.) And † Time, or fortune. (TA.)
OaEuwcu biQll-ehi mina Alxaw-aAni means † [I seek protection by God] from the day of the exhaustion of provisions. (A, TA.)

Also, and xuw-aAnN↓, [accord. to the CK, each is with Al, but this seems to be a mis take, (see XahorN,)] The month [latterly called] rabiyEN AlOaw-ala: pl. OaxowinapN: (Ḳ:) but ISd says, “I know not how this is.” (TA.)

entry.sense: xuw-aAnN: see what next precedes.
Alxaw-aAnapu i. q. AlAisotu [meaning † The anus]. (TA.)

xaAYinN and xaAYinapN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter an intensive epithet, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) like Eal-aAmapN and nas-aAbapN, (Ṣ,) [and also fem. of xaAYinN,] and xaWuwnN↓ and xaw-aAnN↓, (Ḳ,) [which are likewise intensive epithets,] Unfaithful, or acting unfaithfully, to the confidence, or trust, reposed in him; (Ḳ;) [treacherous, perfidious, or unfaithful; or acting treacherously, perfidiously, or unfaithfully: thus the first signifies: the others signifying very un faithful,, &c.:] pl. [of the first] xawanapN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which is anomalous, (M,) like HawakapN [pl. of HaAYikN], (Ṣ,) and xuw-aAnN. (Ḳ.) [Hence,] xaAYinN Aln-aZari Looking treacherously, and clandestinely, at a thing at which it is not allowable to look. (TA.)
xaAYinu AlEayoni † [The languid in respect of the eye] is an appellation applied to the lion; (Ḳ, TA;) because of a languidness in his eye when he looks. (TA.)

hom.sense: xaAYinapN: see xaAYinN.

It is also an inf. n. of xaAna. (TA.) [Hence,] xaAYinapN AlOaEoyuni (as used in the Ḳur xl. 20, TA) A surreptitious look (JK, Mgh, Ḳ) at a thing at which it is not allowable to look: (JK, Ḳ:) or the looking with a look that induces suspicion or evil opinion: (Th, Ḳ:) or the making a sign with the eye to indicate a thing that one conceals in the mind: (TA:) or, as some say, the contracting of the eye, or eyes, by way of making an obscure indication: or the looking intentionally [at a thing at which it is not allowable to look]. (Mṣb.)
UixowaAnN: see xiwaAnN, in two places.
[It is also a pl. of OaxN: see art. Axw.]

entry.sense: mutaxaw-anN One to whom xiyaAnap [i. e. treachery, perfidy, or unfaithfulness,] is attributed. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. xawati Ald-aAru, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. taxowiI, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xawaMCN (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) and xuwiI-N, (Mṣb,) The house became empty, vacant, or un occupied: (Ṣ:) in [some of the copies of] the Ṣ with teshdeed, [i. e. xaw-at,] which is incorrect: (TA:) or became devoid, or destitute, of its occu pants; as also xawiyat, aor. taxowaI, inf. n. xawaMCN: (Mṣb:) or its occupants perished: (JK:) and it fell down: (Ṣ:) or it became demolished: and xawat and xawiyat, inf. n. xaI-N and xuwiI-N and xawaMCN and xawaAyapN, it became devoid, or destitute, of its occupants, (Ḳ, TA,) standing, without inhabitant. (TA.) And xawaI AlmakaAnu, aor. yaxowiI, inf. n. xaI-N, The place became empty, vacant, or unoccupied. (Mgh.) And xawiIa AlbaTonu, aor. yaxowaI, inf. n. xawFI, The belly became empty of food. (Mgh.)

[Hence,] xawiIa, aor. yaxowaI, inf. n. xawFI [and xawaMCN], He was, or became, hungry; (JK;) as also AxwI↓: (Ḳ:) or his belly became empty of food: (Ḥar p. 167:) or xawaI, like ramaI, [aor. yaxowiI,] inf. n. xawFI and xawaMCN, he was affected with un interrupted hunger. (Ḳ.) And xawato, said of a woman, She became empty in her belly on the occasion of childbirth; as also xawiyato: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, xaw-ato is here erroneously put for xawiyato. (TA.) And She abstained from food on the occasion of childbirth; (JK, Ḳ;) as also xawiyato. (JK, TA.)

xawati Aln-ujuwmu The stars inclined to setting: (so in two copies of the Ṣ:) or so xaw-at↓, inf. n. taxowiyapN. (JK, Mṣb, and so in some copies of the Ṣ.) And the former, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. taxowiI, (JK, Ṣ,) inf. n. xaI-N, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) The stars set; as also Axwt↓: and the stars brought no rain: (JK:) or the stars set aurorally and brought no rain; (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ;*) as also Axwt↓ (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xw-t↓. (Ḳ.)
xawaI Alz-anodu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xawFI (TA) [or xaI-N], The znd [q. v.] failed to produce fire; as also AxwI↓. (Ḳ.)
xawiIa, aor. yaxowaI, He called, or cried, out. (JK.)
xawaI, (TA,) inf. n. xaI-N, (Ḳ, TA,) i. q. qaSada [He, or it, pursued a right, or direct, course;, &c.: if trans., it may mean he aimed at, intended, or purposed, a thing]. (Ḳ,* TA.)
xawaAhu, inf. n. xawFI and xawaAyahu, He seized it; took it, or carried it off, by force; or snatched it away; (Ḳ;) and so AxtwAhu↓. (IAạr, TA.)
2. xw-t AlUibilu, inf. n. taxowiyapN, The camels became empty (JK, M, Mṣb) and drawn up (M) in their bellies. (JK, M, Mṣb.)
See also 4.

And xw-I, inf. n. as above, said of a camel, (JK, Ṣ, TA,) He lay down upon his breast, and then set firmly upon the ground his [callous protuberances called the] vafinaAt: (JK:) or he made his belly to be separated by some interval from the ground, in lying upon his breast, (Ṣ, TA,*) and set firmly [upon the ground] his vafinaAt. (TA.) And in like manner, (Ṣ,) xw-I fiI sujuwdihi, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said of a man, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) He raised his belly from the ground in his prostration: (Ṣ,* Mṣb:) or he put, or set, his upper arms apart, or remote, from his sides therein: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or he drew up his body, and made a space between his upper arms and his sides, in his prostration: (Ḳ:) thus a man is directed to do in prostrating himself in prayer. (Mgh, TA.)
Said of a man, it signifies also He lowered his eyes, or looked towards the ground, desiring to be silent. (JK.)
Said of a bird, It hung down its wings: (Ṣ:) or it spread its wings, (JK, TA,) and stretched out its legs, (TA,) desiring to alight. (JK, TA.)
xaw-ati Aln-ujuwmu: see 1, in two places.

xaw-ayotuhaA, inf. n. as above, I dug (Ḳ, TA) for her, namely, a woman, (TA,) a hole, or hollow, in the ground, and kindled [fire] in it, and then seated her in it, or upon it, (fiyhaA [i. e. fiI AlHafiyrapi],) on account of a disease that she had. (Ḳ, TA.) One says of a woman for whom this is done, xuw-iyato. (Aṣ, TA.)
And xw-I lahaA, (JK, Kr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and xaw-aAhaA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, He made for her (namely, a woman,) the food called xawiy-ap, (JK, Kr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) that she might eat it. (Ṣ.)
4: see 1, in four places.
See also 8.
8. AxtwI He abstained from food: and it may mean he became void of everything but anger. (Ḥam p. 219.)
He lost his reason, or intellect. (Ḳ.)
See also 1, last sentence.
Also He took away a thing. (JK.) He took altogether, or entirely, what another possessed; as also AxwI↓. (JK, Ḳ.)
He (a beast of prey) stole and ate the young one of a cow. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
He cut off for himself (AiqotaTaEa) a land, or district; (IAạr, Ḳ;) as also AxtAt and txw-t. (IAạr, TA.)
He thrust at a horse in his xawaMC; i. e., the space between his fore legs and his hind legs. (JK, Ḳ.)

xawFI Emptiness of the belly; (JK, Ḳ;) i. e. its emptiness of food; as also xawaMCN↓; (Ḳ;) [both inf. ns.;] the former of higher authority than the latter. (TA.) And Hunger; (JK, Mṣb;) as also xawaMCN↓, (TA,) i. q. xaw-N. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, wAlxuw-u bAlD-am-i AlEasalu is erroneously put for wAlxaw-u wabiAlD-am-i AlEasalu. The word xaw-N belongs to art. xw, q. v.])
See also xawaMCN.

Also, [AlxawiI-N in the CK being a mistake for AlxawaI,] A low, or depressed, tract between two moun tains: and a soft tract of land: (Ḳ, TA:) or a low, or depressed, tract, in plain, or soft, and in rugged and hard, ground, sinking into the earth, larger than the [tract termed] suhob, producing much herbage: (AḤn, TA:) or any wide valley in a soft, or plain, [low ground such as is termed] jaw-; (Az, TA;) as also xaw-N: (Az, TA in art. xw:) or a soft, far-extending, valley. (Aṣ, TA.)
Also i. q. vaAbitN [Continuing, subsisting, lasting,, &c.]: (Ḳ:) of the dial. of Teiyi. (TA.)
And A flow of blood from the nose; or blood flowing from the nose. (Ḳ. [In this instance the word is correctly given in the CK.])

xawaApN The space between the udder and the vulva in the she-camel and other cattle; (Ḳ,* TA; [accord. to the CK and JK, xawiy-apN↓; but this is app. a mistake;]) also with medd [i. e. xawaAyapN↓, for xawaApN is originally xawayapN]. (Ḳ.)

Also A sound: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, TA:) and the confused and continued sound (Hafiyf) of pouring of rain: (IAạr, TA:) and xawaAyapN↓ signifies the confused and continued sound (Hafiyf [in the CK, erroneously, xafiyf,]) of the running of horses: (Ḳ, TA:) and a sound like what one fancies. (Aboo-Málik, TA.)

entry.sense: xawaMCN: see xawFI, in two places.

Also An intervening space between two things. (JK, Mgh,* TA.) The space between the fore legs and the kind legs of a horse; (JK, Ḳ;) as also xawFI↓. (JK.) A vacant space between two things; (Ḳ;) such between the heaven and the earth; (TA;) like hawaMCN. (Ḳ, TA.)
A wide, or spacious, open tract of the earth, containing no herbage nor trees nor habitations. (TA.)
xuwaMCN (like guraAbN [in measure], TA) Honey. (Ez-Zejjájee, Ḳ, TA. [By a mistake in the CK, mentioned above, voce xawFI, the word thus explained is there made to be xuw-N.])
xawiI-N, of the measure faEiylN, A low, or de pressed, soft, or plain, tract of land. (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: xawaAyapN: see xawaApN, first sentence.
Also The part that a horse closes with his tail, of the space between his hind legs. (TA.)
The part of a spear-head into which the shaft enters. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And The wide part of the interior of a raHol [or camel's saddle]. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, mn Alr-ajuli is erroneously put for mn Alr-aHoli.])
See also xawaApN, second sentence.
xawiy-apN Food prepared for a woman on the oc casion of childbirth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also xawaApN.

entry.sense: [xaAwK part. n. of 1.] fatiloka buyuwtuhumo xaAwiyapF, in the Ḳur [xxvii. 53], means [And those are their houses,] empty; or, as some say, fallen down: like the phrase in the same [ii. 261 and xxii. 44], xaAwiyapN EalaI EuruwXihaA having fallen down upon its roofs: (Ṣ:) or this means empty; its walls having fallen upon its roofs. (Bḍ in ii. 261. [See also EaroXN.]) You say also OaroDN xaAwiyapN A land devoid of its inhabitants: (Ḳ:) and some times it means, of rain. (TA.) kaOan-ahumo OaEojaAzu naxolK xaAwiyapK, in the Ḳur [lxix. 7], means [As though they were trunks of palm-trees] torn up: (TA:) or eaten within: (Bḍ:) or fallen down and empty. (Jel.)
xaAwiyapN [fem. of xaAwK: and hence, as a subst.,] A calamity, or misfortune. (Kr, TA.)
xaAwiI-N: see xaAYiI-N, in art. xwO.
muxaw-FI The place of a camel's lying down in the manner described above voce xaw-aI: [and so app. muxaw-aApN; for] the pl. is muxaw-ayaAtN. (JK.)
2. xay-ayotu xaMCF I wrote a x. (JK, TA.)
[xuyay-apN. dim. of xaMCN, q. v. in art. xwO.]

1. xaAba, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. yaxiybu (Mṣb, Ḳ) and yaxuwbu, (TA,) inf. n. xayobapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He (a man, Ṣ) was disappointed of attaining what he desired or sought; was balked; was unsuccessful; failed of attaining his desire: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) he was denied, refused, prohibited from attaining, or debarred from, what he desired or sought. (A, Ḳ.) You say, mano haAba xaAba [He who fears will be disappointed]. (A, TA.) And xaAba saEoyuhu waOamaluhu [His labour, and his hope, or expectation, resulted in disappointment; were disappointed, balked, or frustrated;] he attained not what he sought or desired. (A, TA.) [See also xayobapN, below.]
Also He suffered loss. (Ḳ.)
And i. q. kafara [He disbelieved; or be came an unbeliever, or infidel;, &c.]. (Ḳ.)

2. xy-bhu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxoyiybN, (Ṣ,) He (God, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, or a man, Ṣ) disappointed him; or caused him to be disappointed of at taining what he desired or sought, to be balked, to be unsuccessful, or to fail of attaining his desire: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) he denied him, refused him, prohibited him from attaining, or debarred him from, that which he desired or sought. (A, Ḳ.)

xayobapN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in a prov., (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) AlhayobapN xayobapN [Fear is a cause of disappointment]. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And one says, xayobapF lizayodK [May God send dis appointment to Zeyd], and xayobapN lizayodK [Disappointment be to, or befall, Zeyd]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) xybp in the former instance being in the accus. case as governed by a verb understood; and in the latter, in the nom. case as an inchoative: (Ṣ:) each being a form of imprecation. (Ḳ.)

qadoHN xay-aAbN ‡ [An endeavour to produce fire with a zanod] that does not produce fire (laAyuwriI). (A, Ḳ.* [In some copies of the Ḳ, for qadoH, we find qidoH. Golius explains xay-aAbN as meaning ignitabulum fallens, quod non excudit semina ignis: but I cannot anywhere find qadoHN or qidoHN in the sense which he assigns to one of these words, which is that of miqodaHapN, &c.])

In the following verse, quoted by Th,
Ausokuto walaA tanoTiqo faOanota xay-aAbo
kul-uka cuw EayobK waOanota Eay-aAbN Hy-Ab may be [an epithet] of the measure faE-aAl from Alxayobapu; [so that the meaning may be † Be thou silent, and speak not, for thou art habitually unsuccessful; thou art altogether vitious, or faulty, and thou art a great imputer of vices, or faults, to others;] or the person there men tioned may be meant to be likened to the qdH above mentioned. (TA.)
One says also, saEoyuhu fiI xay-aAbi boni hay-aAbK ‡ His labour [has ended, or ends, or will end,] in loss. (A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: xaAYibN part. n. of 1. (Mṣb, TA.)
xaAYibika and bixaAYibika: see xaMCa bika in art. xwO.

entry.sense: qidoHN Oaxoyabu † An arrow of those employed in the game called Almayosir, to which no lot, or portion, pertains: for there are three such arrows; namely, the maniyH, the safiyH, and the wagod: occurring in a trad. of ʼAlee. (TA.)

waqaEuwA fiI waAdiI tuxuy-iba, (Ks, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, but in the last waqaEa,) and tuxay-iba, (A, Ḳ,) the last word being imperfectly decl. [in each of these instances], (Ks, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) meaning fiI AlbaATili [i. e. They fell into that which was vain, unreal, nought, futile, or the like, and consequently, into disappointment], (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or fI baATilK [into a state of things that was vain,, &c.]. (A.)

hom.sense: xaAtahu maAlahu, aor. yaxiytuhu: see 1 in art. xwt.

entry.sense: 1. xaAra, aor. yaxiyru, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xayorN, (TA,) He (a man, TA) was, or became, possessed of xayor [or good,, &c.]. (Ḳ, TA.)

[He was, or be came, good: and he did good: contr. of Xar-a.] You say, xirota yaA rajulu [Thou hast been good; or thou hast done good, or well; O man]. (Ṣ.) And xaAraQll-ehu laka fiI hecaA AlOamori [May God do good to thee, bless thee, prosper thee, or favour thee, in this affair: or] may God cause thee to have, or appoint to thee, good in this affair: (Ḳ:) or may God choose for thee the better thing [in this affair]. (A.) Al-ehum-a xiroliI occurs in a trad., meaning O God, choose for me the better of the two things. (TA.)
See also 8.

xaArahu EalaI SaAHibihi, aor. as above, inf. n. xiyrapN and xiyarN (Mṣb, Ḳ *) and xiyarapN (Ḳ) and xayorN; (Mṣb, TA;) and xy-rhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taxoyiyrN; (TA;) He preferred him before his companion, (Mṣb, Ḳ.*)
xaAyarahu faxaArahu: see 3.

2. xy-rhu He gave him the choice, or option, (Ṣ, A,* Mgh,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,) bayona AlX-ayoYayoni [between the two things], (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) or byn AlOamorayoni [between the two affairs]: fataxay-ara↓ [so he had the choice, or option, given him]. (A.)

See also 1. It is said in a trad., xay-ara bayona duwri AlOanoSaAri, meaning He preferred some among the houses of the Assistants before others of them. (TA.) And in another trad., xuy-ira, meaning He was preferred, and pronounced to have surpassed, or overcome, or won, in a contest, or dispute. (IAth.)

3. xaAyarahu faxaArahu↓, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. muxaAyarapN, (A,) He vied with him, or strove to surpass him, or contended with him for superiority, in goodness, or excellence, (A, Ḳ,) in, or with respect to, (fiI,) a thing, (A,) and he surpassed him therein. (A, Ḳ.)

4. maA Oaxoyara fulaAnFA, (A,) and maA xayorahu↓, which latter is extr. [with respect to form, though more commonly used than the former], (TA,) [How good is such a one!] phrases similar to maAOaX-arahu and maA X-arahu [which have the contr. meaning]. (TA.) maA xayora↓ All-abana lilomariyDi [How good is milk for the diseased!], (Ḳ,* TA,) with nasb to the r and n, is an expression of wonder: (Ḳ:) it was said to Khalaf El-Aḥmar, by an Arab of the desert, in the presence of Aboo-Zeyd; whereupon Khalaf said to him, “What a good word, if thou hadst not defiled it by mentioning it to the [common] people!” and Aboo-Zeyd returned to his companions, and desired them, when Khalaf El-Ahmar should come, to say, all together, these words (mA xyr Allbn llmryD), [in order to vex him], and they did so. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5. txy-r, as an intrans. v.: see 2.
As a trans. v.: see 8.

entry.sense: 6. txAyrwA fiyhi UilaI HakamK They contended together for superior goodness, or for excellence, in it, or with respect to it, appealing to a judge, or an arbiter. (A.)

8. AxtArhu; and txy-rhu↓, (Ṣ,* A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. [or rather quasi-inf. n.] xiyarapN↓, said by IAth to be the only instance of the kind except TiyarapN; (TA voce taTay-ara;) and AstxArhu↓; (A;) and xaArahu↓; (Ḳ;) He chose, made choice of. selected, elected, or preferred, him, or it. (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ.) You say also, Aixotarotuhu Alr-ijaAla, and mina Alr-ijaAli, [I chose him from the men,] and Ealayohimo, (Ḳ,) which last signifies in preference to them. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [vii. 154], waQxotaAra muwsaI qawomihi saboEiyna rajulFA [And Moses chose from his people seventy men]. (TA.) walaqadi QxotaronaAhumo EalaI EilomK, in the Ḳur [xliv. 31, Verily we have chosen them with knowledge], may be indicative of God's producing good, or of his preferring them before others. (TA.)

10. AstxAr He sought, desired, or asked for, xiyrap (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) or xiyarap (as in some copies of the Ḳ) [i. e. the blessing, prospering, or favour, of God;, &c.]. [And it is trans.; for] one says, Aisotaxiri Qll-eha yaxiro laka [Desire thou, or ask thou for, the blessing, prospering, or favour, of God;, &c.; and He will bless, prosper, or favour, thee;, &c.]. (Ṣ.) And Aisotaxarotu Qll-eha fiyhi faxaAra liI I desired, or asked, of God, the better of the two things, [or rather the better in it, meaning a case, or an affair,] and He chose it for me. (A.)
See also 8.

hom.sense: xayorN [Good, moral or physical; anything that is good, real or ideal, and actual or potential; and, being originally an inf. n., used as sing and pl.;] a thing that all desire; such as intelligence, for instance, and equity; (Er-Rághib, and so in some copies of the Ḳ;) [or goodness;] and excellence; and what is profitable or useful; benefit; (Er-Rághib;) contr. of Xar-N: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) pl. xuyuwrN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and also, accord. to the Mṣb, xiyaArN↓: (TA:) [but this latter seems to be properly pl. only of xayorN used as an epithet (see below) and as a noun denoting the comparative and superlative degrees: it may however be used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant:] xyr is of two kinds: namely, absolute xyr, which is what is desired in all circumstances and by every person: and what is xyr [or good] to one and Xr- [or evil] to another; as, for instance, (Er-Rághib,) wealth, or property: (Zj, L in art. Xd, Er-Rághib, Ḳ:) it has this last signification, namely wealth, or property, in the Ḳur, ii. 176 (Ṣ, TA) and ii. 274 and xxiv. 33 and xli. 49: or in the first and second of these instances it is thus called to imply the meaning of wealth, or property, that has been collected in a praiseworthy manner, or it means much wealth or property; and this is its meaning in the first of the instances mentioned above, agreeably with a trad. of ʼAlee; and also in the Ḳur, c. 8: (TA:) [being used as a pl. (as well as a sing.), it may be also rendered good things:] and it is also used by the Arabs to signify horses; (Ḳ,* TA;) and has this meaning in the Ḳur, xxxviii. 31: (TA:) [it is often best rendered good fortune; prosperity; welfare; wellbeing; weal; happiness; or a good state or condition: and sometimes bounty, or beneficence.] rajulN qaliylu Alxayori means [A man possessing little, or no, good; possessing few, or no, good things; or poor: and in whom is little, or no, good or goodness; or niggardly: and also] a man who does little good: (TA in art. ES:) or [who does no good;] who is not near to doing good; denoting the nonexistence of good in him. (Mṣb in art. ql.) [Thus it sometimes means the same as rajulN laA xayora fiyhi A man in whom is no good or goodness; devoid of goodness; worthless.] And qil-apu xayorK means Poverty: and also niggardliness. (A and TA in art. jHd.) huwa mino Oaholi Alxayori waAlxiyri is explained voce xiyrN. EalaIyadaIi Alxayori waAlyumoni [May it be with the aid of good fortune and prosperity] is a prayer used with respect to a marriage. (AʼObeyd, TA.) And Uin-aka maA waxayorFA means maEa xayorK, i. e., Mayest thou meet with, or attain, good. (Ḳ.)

xayorN in the phrase fulaAnN xayorN resembles an epithet [like xay-irN↓, and signifies Good; or possessing good]; (Akh, Ṣ;) therefore the fem. is xayorapN, of which the pl. is xayoraAtN, (Akh, Ṣ, Mṣb,*) as occurring in the Ḳur, lv. 70; and they do not [there] mean by it [the comparative or superlative signification of the measure] OafoEalu: (Akh, Ṣ:) you say rajulN xay-irN↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) meaning [A good man; or] a man possessing xayor [or good]; (Mṣb;) and rajulN xayorN: (Ṣ:) and in like manner, AimoraOapN xay-irapN↓ and xayorapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) meaning [A good woman; or] a woman excellent in beauty and disposition: (Mṣb:) or xayorN and xay-irN↓ signify possessing much xayor [or good], (Ḳ,) applied to a man; (TA;) and in the same sense you say rajulN xayoraI↓, and xuwraI↓, and xiyarI↓: and the fem. of the first is xayorapN; and of the second, xay-irapN↓: (Ḳ:) and the pl. [of pauc.] (of the first, TA) is OaxoyaArN, and [of mult.] xiyaArN: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) you say also xiyaAru AlmaAli, meaning The excellent of the camels or the like: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) and in like manner you say of men, &c.: (TA:) [see also below:] and the fem. is xayorapN, of which the pl. is xayoraAtN: (Mṣb:) xiyaArN is contr. of OaXoraArN, (Ṣ, Mgh,) [thus] used as an epithet: (Mgh:) and xayorapN↓ [used as a subst.] signifies anything excellent; and the pl. thereof in this sense, xayoraAtN, occurs in the Ḳur, ix. 89: (Ṣ:) or xayorN, (Ḳ,) or the fem. xayorapN, (Lth,) or each, (Ḳ.) signifies excellent in beauty: (Lth, Ḳ:) and xay-irN↓ and xay-irapN signify excellent in righteousness (Lth, Ḳ) and religion: (Ḳ:) or there is no difference in the opinion of the lexicologists [in general] between xayorapN and xay-irapN↓: (Az:) accord. to Zj, xayoraAtN and xay-iraAtN↓, both occurring in different readings of the Ḳur, lv. 70, signify good in dispositions: accord. to Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, xayorapN, applied to a woman, signifies generous in race, exalted in rank or quality or reputation, goodly in face, good in disposition, possessing much wealth, who, if she bring forth, brings forth a generous child: (TA:) [xiyaArN↓ is also applied as an epithet to a sing. subst., either masc. or fem.:] you say jamalN xiyaArN and naAqapN xiyaArN, meaning A he-camel [that is excellent or] excellent and brisk and so a she-camel. (TA.) See also muxotaArN, in three places. In the saying laEamaru Oabiyka Alxayoru, the word xayor is in the nom. case as an epithet of Eamor; [so that the phrase lit. means By the good life of thy father;] but properly it should be laEamoru Oabiyka Alxayori [By the life of thy good father]: and the like is said with Xar-. (TA.) [See also art. Emr.]

xayorN is also used to denote superiority: one says, hecaA xayorN mino hecaA This is better than this: and in the dial. of the Benoo-'Ámir, hecaA Oaxoyaru↓ mino hecaA, with O, and in like manner, OaX-aru; but the rest of the Arabs drop the O in each case: (Mṣb:) you say, huwa Oaxoyaru↓ minoka [He is better than thou], and in like manner, OaX-aru minoka; and huwa xayorN minoka, and in like manner, Xar-N minoka; and, [using the dim. form of xayorN,] xuyayorN↓ minoka, and in like manner, XurayorN minoka. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) You also say, when you mean to express the signification of superiority, fulaAnapN xayoru Aln-aAsi [Such a woman is the best of mankind];
but not xayorapu: [see, however, what will be found cited hereafter from the Ḳ,] and fulaAnN xayoru Aln-aAsi [Such a man is the best of mankind]; but not Oaxoyaru↓ [unless in the dial. of the Benoo-'Ámir]: and [it is said that] xayoru when thus used does not assume the dual form nor the pl., because it has the signification of [the measure] OafoEalu: for though a poet uses the dual form, he uses it as a contraction of the dual of xay-irN, like mayotN and may-itN, and hayonN and hay-inN: (Ṣ:) [but. this remark in the Ṣ is incorrect: for both xayor and Oaxoyar↓, when used in such phrases as those to which J here refers, have pl. forms of frequent occurrence, and of which examples will be found below; and, as is said by I’Aḳ (p. 239), and by many other grammarians, you may say, Alz-ayodaAni OafoDalaA Alqawomi, and Alz-ayoduwna OafoDaluw Alqawomi and OafaADilu Alqawomi, and also hinodu fuDolaI Aln-isaMCi, &c.; and such concordance is found in the Ḳur, vi. 123; and is even said by many to be more chaste than the mode prescribed by J:] it is said in the Ḳ, that you say, huwa Oaxoyaru↓ minoka, like xayoru; and when you mean the signification of superiority, you say fulaAnN xayorapN Aln-aAsi, with p, and fulaAnapu xayoruhumo, without p: but [SM says,] I know not how this is; for in the Ṣ is said what is different from this, and in like manner by Z in several places in the Ksh; and what is most strange is, that the author of the Ḳ quotes in the B the passage of J [from the Ṣ], and adopts the opinion of the leading authorities [as given in the Ṣ]: (TA:) or you say, fulaAnapu Alxayorapu mina AlmaroOatayoni [Such a woman is the better of the two women]: and hiIa Alxayorapu, and Alxiyrapu↓, [so in the TA, but in the CK Alxiyarapu,] and AlxiyraI↓, and AlxuwraI↓, [the last being fem. of Oaxoyaru, originally xuyoraI, and so, app., the last but one, She is the better, or best:] (Ḳ:) and [using the dim. form of xayorN] you say, huwa xuyayoru↓ Oaholihi [He is the best of his family]: (Ibn-Buzurj, TA:) one says also, to one coming from a journey, xayora maA rud-a fiI OaholK wamaAlK, meaning May God make that with which thou comest [back] to be the best of what is brought back by the absent with family and property; (Aṣ, Meyd, TA;) or, as some relate it, xayoru, i. e. rad-uka xayoru rad-K [may thy bringing back be the best bringing back]; and fI is used in the sense of maEa: (Meyd:) [OaxoyaArN is pl. of pauc., and xiyaArN pl. of mult., and so app. is xiyraAnN, of xayorN thus used; and OaxaAyiru↓ is pl. of Oaxoyaru, and so is Oaxoyaruwna applied to rational beings: in the TA, OaxaAyiru is said to be a pl. pl. of Oaxoyaru, and so xiyraAnN; but this is app. a mistake, probably of transcription:] you say rajulN mino xiyaAri Aln-aAsi and OaxoyaArihimo and OaxaAyirihimo↓ [A man of the best of mankind]: (A, TA:) and laka xiyaAru hecihi AlUibili, and xiyratuhaA↓, [Thine are, or is, or shall be, the best of these camels,] alike with respect to a sing. and a pl.: (TA:) and naHara xiyrapa↓ Uibilihi and xuwrapa↓ Uibilihi [He slaughtered the best of his camels]: (IAạr, TA:) and humu AlOaxoyaruwna↓ [They (meaning men) are the better, or best]. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.)
maA xayora for maA Oaxoyara: see 4, in two places.
xayoru baw-aMCu [from the Persian xiyrobuwaA Lesser cardamom;] a kind of small grain, resembling the qaAqul-ap [or common cardamom], (Ḳ,) of sweet odour. (TA.)

entry.sense: xiyrN Generousness; generosity; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) liberality; munificence. (Mṣb.) You say, fulaAnN cuw xiyrK Such a one is a possessor of generousness, or generosity,, &c. (Mṣb.) And huwa mino Oaholi Alxayori↓ waAlxiyri [He is of the people of good, or of wealth,, &c., and of generosity]. (A.)
Eminence; elevated state or condition; nobility. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
Origin. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
Nature, or disposition. (A, Ḳ.) You say, huwa kariymu Alxiyri He is generous in nature, or disposition. (A.)
Form, aspect, or appearance; figure, person, mien, feature, or lineaments; guise, or external state or condition; or the like; syn. hayoYapN. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
xayorapN fem. of xayorN [q. v.] used as an epithet: pl. xayoraAtN. (Akh, Ṣ, Mṣb.)

[Also, used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, A good thing, of any kind: a good quality; an excellency: and a good act or action:, &c.: pl. as above:] see xayorN, in the former half of the paragraph.
xiyrapN: see xayorN, in three places, towards the end of the paragraph:
and see xiyarapN, in four places:
and xiyaArN.

It is also a subst. from xaAraQll-ehu laka fiIhecaAAlOamori, (Ṣ,) and so xiyarapN↓; both signifying [The blessing, prospering, or favour, of God; his causing one to have, or appointing to one, good in an affair: or his choosing for one the better thing in an affair: or] the state that results to him who begs God to cause him to have good, or to choose for him the better thing, in an affair. (TA.) You say, kaAna celika xiyrapF mina Qll-ehi [That was through God's blessing, prospering, or favour;, &c.: or through God's choosing the better thing in the affair]. (A.)

xiyarapN and xiyrapN↓ (of which the former is the better known, TA) are substs. from AixotaArahu, (Ḳ,) or from AixotaArahu Qll-ehu, (Ṣ,) both signifying A thing, man, or beast, and things,, &c., that one chooses: (TA:) or [a thing,, &c.,] chosen, selected, or elected: (Mgh:) as in the saying, muHam-adu xiyarapu Qll-ehi mino xaloqihi and xiyratuhu↓ [Moḥammad is the chosen, or elect, of God, from his creatures]: (Ṣ, Mgh:*) or xiyrapN↓ is a subst. from AlAixotiyaArN, like fidoyapN from AlAifotidaMCu; and xiyarapN is syn. with xiyaArN and AixotiyaArN; or is from taxay-arotu AlX-aIoCa: or, as some say, xiyrapN and xiyarapN are syn.: (Mṣb:) see 8; and see also xiyaArN: and hecihi xiyratiI↓ (Mṣb, TA) or xiyaratiI (TA) means This is what I choose; (Mṣb, TA;) and so hecaA xyrtI: and heWulaMCi xyrtI These are what I choose. (TA.) [See muxotaArN.]
See also xiyrapN.
xuwraI: see xayorN, in two places.
xayoraI: see xayorN.
xiyraI: see xayorN, in two places.
[xayoriI-N Of, or relating to, xayor, or good,, &c.]

hom.sense: xiyriI-N Of, or relating to, or possessing, generousness, generosity, liberality, or munificence. (Mṣb.)

And hence, (Mṣb,) or [thus applied] it is an arabicized word, (Ṣ,) [from the Persian xiyriIo,] The manovuwr [or gilliflower:] but generally applied to the yellow species thereof; [so in the present day;] for it is this from which is extracted its oil, which is an ingredient in medicines. (Mṣb.) [Accord. to Golius, “Viola alba, ejusque genera: Diosc. iii. 138:” and he adds, as on the authority of Ibn-Beytár, “spec. luteum.”]
And xiyriI-u Albar-i The xuzaAmaI [q. v.]; because it is the most pungent in odour of the plants of the desert. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: [xayoriy-apN The quality of xayorN; i. e. goodness.]

hom.sense: xiyaArN a subst. from AlAixotiyaAru; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) meaning Choice, or option; (Mṣb;) and so xiyarapN↓ in the Ḳur [xxviii. 68], maAkaAna lahumu Alxiyarapu They have not choice, or option; (Mgh;) or the meaning of these words is, it is not for them to choose in preference to God; (Fr, Zj;) and so, accord. to Lth, xiyrapN↓, as being an inf. n. [or rather a quasi-inf. n., though this seems doubtful,] of AxtAr. (TA.) You say, Uin-a fiI AlX-ar-i xiyaArFA [Verily in evil there is a choice, or an option]; i. e. what may be chosen: a prov. (TA.) And Oanota biQlxiyaArK and biQlomuxotaAri↓ [in some copies of the Ḳ bAlmxyAr, which, as is said in the TA, is a mistranscription, Thou hast the choice, or option]; i. e. choose thou what thou wilt. (Ḳ.) And AlbayoEu SafoqapN Oawo xiyaArN Selling is decisive or with the option of returning. (Mgh in art. Sfq.) Hence, xiyaAru Alr-uWoyapi The choice of returning [on seeing it] a thing which one has purchased without seeing it. (Mgh,* Mṣb,* KT.) And xiyaAru Almajolisi [The choice of returning a thing purchased while sitting with the seller]. (TA.) And xiyaAru AlEayobi [and Aln-aqiySapi] The choice of returning a thing to the seller when it has a fault, a defect, or an imperfection. (KT.) And xiyaAru AlX-aroTi The choice of returning a thing purchased when one of the two contracting parties has made it a condition that he may do so within three days or less. (KT.) And xiyaAru Alt-aEoyiyni The choice of specifying [for instance] one of two garments, or pieces of cloth, which one has purchased for ten pieces [of money, or some other sum,] on the condition of so doing. (KT.)

See also muxotaArN, in three places. And see xayorN, in the middle of the paragraph, where it is explained as an epithet applied to a sing. subst., either masc. or fem. See also the first sentence of that paragraph.
It is also a pl. of xayorN [q. v.] as an epithet, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [and as a noun denoting the comparative and superlative degrees.]

Also [A species of cucumber; cucumis sativus Linn. a fructu minore: (Delile, Flor. Aeg. Illustr., no. 927:)]
i. q. qiv-aMCN: (Ṣ:) or resembling the qv-MC; (Ḳ, &c.;) which is the more suitable explanation: (TA:) or i. q. qavadN [q. v.]: an arabicized word: (Mgh:) [from the Persian xiyaArN:] not Arabic. (Ṣ.)

xiyaAru Xanobara [The cassia fistula of Linn.;] a well-known kind of tree; (Ḳ;) a species of the xar-uwb, resembling a large peach-tree; (TA;) abounding in Alexandria and Misr; (Ḳ;) and having an admirable yellow flower: (TA:) the latter division [or rather the whole] of the name is arabicized [from the Persian xiyaAro Janobaro]. (TA.)

entry.sense: xuyayorN: see xayorN, [of which it is the dim.,] in two places, in the latter half of the paragraph.
xay-irN, and its fem. xay-irapN, and pl. fem. xay-iraAtN: see xayorN, (used as an epithet,) in eight places, in the former half of the paragraph.
xaAYirN [Doing good, or well:, &c.:] act. part. n. of xaAra. (Ṣ, TA.)
Oaxoyaru, and its pls. OaxaAyiru and OaHoyaruwna: see xayorN, in eight places, in the latter half of the paragraph.

AixotiyaAriI-N [Of, or relating to, the will, or choice]. SifapN QxotiyaAriy-apN [meaning A quality which originates from, or depends upon, the will, or choice, i. e. an acquired quality,] is opposed to xiloqiy-apN. (Mṣb in art. mdH, &c.)
maxoyarapN [A cause of good: and hence,] excel-lence, and eminence, or nobility: so in the phrase, fulaAnN cuw maxoyarapK [Such a one is a possessor of eminence,, &c.]. (A, TA.)
muxay-irN: see what follows.
muxotaArN act. part. n. [of 8, signifying Choosing, selecting, or electing]. (TA.)

And pass. part. n.[of the same, signifying Chosen, selected, elected, or preferred: and choice, select, or elect; as also xiyaArN↓, which signifies like wise the best of anything; often used in this sense, as a sing. and as a pl.; and excellent, or excellent and brisk, applied to a he-camel and to a she-camel; as mentioned above, voce xayorN]. (TA.) You say also jamalN xiyaArN↓ in the sense of muxotaArN [A choice he-camel], and naAqapN xiyaArN↓ in the sense of muxotaArapN [A choice she-camel]. (TA.) [See also xiyarapN.] The dim. of muxotaArN is muxay-irN↓: the t is thrown out because it is augmentative; and the I is changed into I because it was changed from I in mxtAr: (Ṣ:) one should not say muxayotiyrN. (El-Ḥareeree's Durrat el-Ghowwáṣ, in De Sacy's Anthol. Gr. Ar. p. 49 of the Arabic text.)
See also xiyaArN.

xayoXN Garments, or pieces of cloth, of the worst of flax: (Ṣ:) or garments, or pieces of cloth, of thin texture, and of coarse threads, made of the hards, or hurds, of flax, (Ḳ,* TA,) and of the worst thereof: (TA:) or of the coarsest of [the stuff called] ESb [i. e. EaSob, q. v., in the copies of the Ḳ in my hands incorrectly written EaSab]: (Lth, Ḳ:) or coarse flax: (Mgh:) or a cloth of coarse flax. (Ḥar p. 544.)
[Hence,] † A low, vile, or mean, man. (Ḳ.)
xayoXiI-N and xay-aAXN↓ [A weaver, or seller, of xayoX.The former mentioned in the Ḳ, and the latter in the TA, as surnames of men.]
xay-aAXN: see what next precedes.

1. xaATa, (Mṣb, TA,) first pers. xiTotu, (Ṣ,) aor. yaxiyTu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. xiyaATapN, (Ṣ, TA,) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb, TḲ,) and the inf. n. is xayoTN, (TḲ,) which is said in the Ḳ to be syn. with xiyaATapN, but this last is a mistake for xiyaATN as signifying “thread,” (TA,) or “a thread,” (AZ, TA,) though xiyaATN is also syn. with xiyaATapN, (TA,) He sewed, sewed together, or sewed up, a garment, or piece of cloth; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) as also xy-Thu↓, inf. n. taxoyiyTN. (TA.)
[Hence,] xaATa baEiyrFA bibaEiyrK ‡ He coupled a camel with a camel [by tying the end of the halter of one to the tail of the other]. (TA.)
xaATati AlHay-apu, (TA,) inf. n. xayoTN, (Ḳ, TA,) ‡ The serpent ran along upon the ground. (Ḳ,* TA.)

xAT Uilayohi xayoTapF↓ ‡ He passed by him, or it, [or to, or towards, him or it,] once: or xAT xayoTapF↓ he passed along quickly: (Ḳ,* TA:) and so AxtAT↓ and AixotaTaI. (Ḳ.) It is said by Kr to be formed by transposition from AlxaTowu: but this is a mistake; for, were it so, they would have said, xAT xawoTapF, not xayoTapF. (ISd.) Accord. to Lth, xAT xayoTapF↓ waAHidapF means † He made his journey [or a journey] without interruption. (TA.) In the A it is said that xAT fulaAnN xayoTapF↓ means ‡ Such a one journeyed on, not pausing for anything: and in like manner, xAT UilaI maqoSidihi ‡ [He journeyed on, not pausing for anything, to his place, or object, of aim]. (TA.)
2: see 1.

xay-aTa AlX-ayobu fiI raOosihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxoyiyTN, (Ḳ,) means ‡ Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, appeared upon his head (Ḳ, TA) in streaks, or lines: (TA:) it is like waxaTa: (Ṣ, TA:) or became like threads: (Ḳ:) and in like manner, fiI liHoyatihi in his beard. (TA.) Bedr Ibn-ʼÁmir El-Hudhalee says,
Oaqosamotu laA OanosaI maniyHapa waAHidK
Hat-aI tuxay-iTa biAlbayaADi quruwniI
(Ṣ, TA) [I swear that I will not forget the loan (here meaning the qaSiydap, Skr) of one (meaning Abu-l-ʼIyál with whom he was carrying on a controversy, Skr)] until the sides of my head become streaked with whiteness: (TA:) but some read tuxay-aTa; and Ibn-Habeeb says that xay-aTa AlX-ayobu Alr-aOosa signifies † Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, became conjoined and continuous upon the head, as though one part thereof were sewed to another: (IB, TA:) some read taxay-aTa↓; and accord. to the Ḳ, you say, taxay-aTa raOosuhu biAlX-ayobi, meaning † His head became streaked, or marked as with threads, by whiteness of the hair, or hoariness: [the best reading seems to be taxay-aTa, for tatatxay-aTa:] and some read tawax-aTa [for tatawax-aTa, from tawax-aTa as having the meaning here assigned to taxay-aTa]. (TA.)
5: see 2.
8: see 1.
xaATN: see xay-aATN.

xayoTN Thread, or string; or a thread or string; syn. silokN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the thing with which one sews; (Mṣb;) [often used as a coll. gen. n.; n. un. with p {xayoTapN};] and xiyaATN↓ [likewise] signifies the thing with which a garment, or piece of cloth, is sewed; as also mixoyaTN↓; besides having another signification, common to it with the last, namely “a needle;” (Ḳ;) the pl. of xayoTN is OaxoyaATN [a pl. of pauc.] (IB, Ḳ) and xuyuwTN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xuyuwTapN [both pls. of mult.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., Oad-uwA AlxiyaATa↓ waAlmixoyaTa, meaning [Bring ye] the xayoT and the needle. (TA.) And you say, OaEoTiniI xiyaATFA↓ and niSaAHFA, i. e. [Give thou to me] a single xayoT. (AZ, TA.) [OaEoTinaI xiyaATFA waniSaAHFA may, however, mean Give thou to me a needle and thread.]
xayoTu Alr-aqabapi † The nuxaAE [or spinal cord] of the neck. (Ṣ, Ḳ) You say, jaAHaXa fulaAnN Eano xayoTi raqabatihi, meaning ‡ Such a one defended his blood. (Ṣ, O, L.)

AlxayoTu AlOaboyaDu and AlxayoTu AlOasowadu, mentioned in the Ḳur ii. 183, mean † The true dawn, and the false dawn: (Mṣb:) or the whiteness of the dawn, and the blackness of night; (Ḳ, TA;) likened to a thread because of its thinness: (TA:) or the whiteness of day, and the blackness of night: (AʼObeyd, Nh:) or the dawn that extends sideways, and the dawn that rises high, or, as some say, the blackness of night: (Ṣ:) or what appears of the true dawn, which is the musotaTiyr, and what extends with it of the darkness of night, which is the dawn termed the musotaTiyl: (Mgh:) or what first appears of the dawn spreading sideways in the horizon, and what extends with it of the darkness of the last part of the night: (Bḍ:) or the dawn that rises high, filling the horizon, and the dawn that appears black, extending sideways: (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ:) or the real meaning is the day and the night. (TA.) AlxayoTaAni also signifies † The night and the day. (L in art. wsd.) tabay-ana AlxayoTu mina AlxayoTi means ‡ [The night became distinct from the day: or] what is termed AlxayoTu AlOaboyaDu became distinct from what is termed AlxayoTu AlOasowadu. (TA.) And xayoTN mina AlS-uboHi is also said to signify † A tint of the dawn. (TA.) [See bariymu AlS-uboHi in art. brm.]

xayoTu baATilK ‡ What is called luEaAbu AlX-amosi and muxaATu AlX-ayoTaAni, (Ṣ, TA,) which last is explained by Z and IB as meaning what comes forth from the mouth of the spider: (TA: [the author of which says that, accord. to this explanation, this term differs from lEAb AlXms: but in so saying he seems to be in error: both evidently signify gossamer:])
it was applied as a surname, or nickname, to Marwán Ibn-El-Hakam; because he was tall, and loose, or uncompact, in frame: (Ṣ:) or it signifies the air; syn. AlhawaMCu [perhaps a mistranscription for AlhabaMCu, occurring in another explanation hereafter]: (Ḳ:) or light entering from an aperture in a wall [into a dark place] (Th, Ḳ:) or xayoTu AlbaATili signifies the scattered habaMC [or atoms that are seen in the rays of the sun] entering from an aperture in a wall [into a dark place] when the sun is hot: and one says, fulaAnN Oadaq-u mino xayoTi AlbaATili ‡ [Such a one is less in estimation than the scattered atoms that are seen in the rays of the sun]; a prov., applied to him who is in an abject state; thus related, on the authority of Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà, by Az and others; but by Ṣgh, erroneously, Oaraq-u mino xayoTi baATilK. (TA.)
See also what next follows, in two places.

xiyTN (Aṣ, IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ) and xayoTN↓ (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xayoTaI↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) † A collection, or flock, of ostriches, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) and a swarm of locusts, (Ḳ,) and a xayoT↓ is sometimes of [wild] bulls or cows: (L, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxoyaATN (IB) and [of mult.] xiyTaAnN: (Ḳ:) ↓which last, as also xayoTaAnN↓, signifies likewise a company of men. (TA.) [xiyTN may perhaps be originally xuyoTN, pl. of xayoTaMCu, q. v.]

xayaTN ‡ Length of the neck of an ostrich, (Ṣ, TA,) and of the [bones, such as are termed] qaSab thereof: or, as some say, a constant mixture of blackness with whiteness therein: or their being in an uninterrupted line, like an extended xayoT [or thread]. (TA.)

hom.sense: xayoTapN [n. un. of xayoTN, q. v.]

[Also,] in the dial. of Hudheyl, (Ṣ,) A wooden peg or stoke, (Skr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is fixed in a mountain, in order that one may let himself down [by means of a rope attached thereto] over against the place where [wild] honey is deposited [to gather it]. (Skr.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, (Ṣ, TA,) describing the gathere of honey, (TA,)
tadal-aI EalayohaA bayona sib-K waxayoTapK
bijarodaMCa mivoli Alwakofi yakobuw guraAbuhaA , (Ṣ, TA,) i. e. He let himself down [over against it, meaning the place of the honey, partly] by means of a rope (for so sib- signifies) and [partly by means of] a wooden peg or stake [to which the rope was attached, fixed] in a rock smooth like the [leather termed] wakof, i. q. niTaE, [the crow of which rock would fall prone upon its face for want of something therein to which to cling:] (TA:) or (in the Ḳ “and”) xyTp signifies a rope; (Aṣ, Az, Ḳ, TA;) [and if so, sib- here means “a wooden peg,” which is a signification assigned to it in the Ḳ in art. sb:] or, accord. to AA, a slender rope (Ṣ, L, TA) made [of the bark] of the tree called salab: (L, TA:) and (accord. to some, TA) a string which is with the gatherer of honey, (Ḳ, TA,) and with which he pulls the rope [app. when he has detached himself from the latter to gather the honey], it being tied to him: (TA:) or a [tunic of the kind called] dur-aAEap, [of leather,] which he wears. (Ibn-Ḥabeeb, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, dur-AEapK is erroneously put for dur-aAEapN.])
See also 1, in four places. One says also, maAMtiyka Uil-aA AlxayoTapa † I do not come to thee save sometime. (TA.)

entry.sense: xayoTaI: see xiyTN.
xayoTaMCu ‡ A she-ostrich long in the neck. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
xayoTaAnN and xiyTaAnN: see xiyTN.
xiyaATN A needle; as also mixoyaTN↓. (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ.) Hence the saying in the Ḳur [vii. 38], Hat-aI yalija AlHabalu fiI sam-i AlxiyaATi [Until the camel enter into the eye of the needle]. (Ṣ.)
See also xayoTN, in three places.
And see maxiyTN.
xiyaATapN The art of sewing. (Mṣb, TA.) [See also 1.]
xay-aATN A seamster; one whose occupation is that of sewing; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also xaAYiTN↓ (Ḳ) and xaATN↓. (Ṣgh, Ḳ. [in the CK xaAT-N.]) [In the present day, its predominant application is to A tailor.]
Also † One who passes along quickly. (TA.)
xaAYiTN: see xay-aATN.

maxiyTN and maxoyuwTN↓ A garment, or piece of cloth, sewed: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the I in the former is the w of the measure mafoEuwlN, changed into I because of its being quiescent and the preceding letter's being with kesr; the letter preceding it being made movent because it and the w are quiescent after the I has fallen out; [for by dropping the I it becomes changed from maxoyuwTN to maxowoTN;] and it is made movent with kesr [and thus changed from maxowoTN to maxiwoTN, which necessarily becomes maxiyTN,] in order to its being known that the letter which has dropped out is I: some say that the I in maxiyTN is the radical, and that the letter thrown out is the w of the measure mafoEuwlN, in order that the word with w [for its medial radical] may be known from that with I; [so that it is changed from maxoyuwTN to maxoyuTN, and then to maxoyoTN, and then to maxiyTN;] but the former saying is the right, because the w is a formative augment, and it is not proper that such should be thrown out. (Ṣ.)
Also, the former, † The whole of the exterior of the belly. (ISh.)

And † A place of passage; (O, L, TA;) a meaning erroneously assigned in the Ḳ to xiyaATN↓ and maxoyaTN↓: (TA:) and particularly, ‡ of a serpent; (TA;) the place of creeping along of a serpent. (Ḳ, TA.)
mixoyaTN: see xayoTN:
and xiyaATN.
See also maxiyTN.
maxoyuwTN: see maxiyTN.

1. xayafN The having one of the eyes blue and the other black: (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) inf. n. of xayifN, aor. yaxoyafu: (JK, Mṣb:*) said of a horse, (Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ,), &c., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. of any animal. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also The being wide in the sheath of the penis: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in this sense [likewise] inf. n. of xayifa: (Ṣ:) said of a camel. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And [app. in like manner having for its verb xayifato] A she-camel's being such, as is termed xayofaMC [i. e. wide in the udder, or in the skin thereof, or only when it is empty of milk, and flaccid]. (Ṣ)

hom.sense: 2. xy-ft, (JK,) or xy-ft OawolaAdahaA, (TA,) ‡ She (a woman) brought forth her children different, one from another. (JK, TA.)
xuy-ifa bayonahumo, (JK, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxoyiyfN, (Ḳ,) ‡ It (a thing, JK, Ḳ, or property, A) was divided, or distributed, among them. (JK, A, Ḳ.)
xuy-ifato Eumuwru All-ivapi mina AlOasonaAni, (JK,) or bayona AlOasonaAni, (Ḳ,) ‡ The portions of the flesh of the gums between the teeth became separated (JK, Ḳ) from the teeth. (JK.)
xy-f He (a man, JK) alighted, or descended and stopped or sojourned or abode, in a place; (JK, Ḳ;) as also xy-m. (JK.)
xy-f Einoda AlqitaAli, (JK,) or Eani AlqitaAli, (Ḳ,) He receded, drew back, or desisted, (JK, Ḳ,) on the occasion of fight, (JK,) or from fight. (Ḳ.)

4. AxAf, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UixaAfapN; (TA;) and Oaxoyafa; (JK, Ḳ;) said of a man, (JK, TA,) or of a party of men, (JK, Ṣ,) He, or they, alighted, or descended and stopped or sojourned or abode, in a [tract such as is termed] xayof: (JK:) and [particularly] came to the xayof of Minè, and there alighted, or descended and stopped, &c.; (JK,* Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AxtAf↓. (Yoo, Ḳ.)
AxAf Als-ayolu Alqawoma The torrent made the party, or company of men, to alight, or descend and stop or sojourn or abide, in a [tract such as is termed] xayof. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
5. txy-f OalowaAnFA He (a man, TA) altered so as to become of different colours. (Ḳ, TA.)
txy-ft AlUibilu The camels took different directions in the place of pasturage (Lḥ, JK), &c. (Lḥ.)
txy-fhu He took by little and little from it; (IAạr, JK;) as also txw-fhu [q. v.]. (JK.)

entry.sense: 8: see 4.

xayofN [sing. of OaxoyaAfN]. You say, Aln-aAsu OaxoyaAfN ‡ Men, or the people, are different, one from another, (JK, Ṣ, A, Ṣgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) in their states, or conditions, (JK,) or in their forms, shapes, or semblances; (Ṣgh;) or of various sorts in natural dispositions, and in forms, shapes, or semblances: (L:) from xayafN signifying the “having one of the eyes blue and the other black.” (Ṣ. [See 1.]) And OaxoyaAfN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or UixowapN OaxoyaAfN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) † Brothers who are sons of one mother but of different fathers: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) and in like manner, banuw AlOaxoyaAfi, if of good authority. (Mgh.)
And hence, OaboyaAtN OaxoyaAfN ‡ Verses diversified by having one word thereof composed of dotted letters and another composed of letters not dotted. (Ḥar p. 611 and 612.)
Also, the sing., Land, (ISd, TA,) or a place, (Mgh,) of which the stones are of different colours. (ISd, Mgh, TA.)
A side, region, quarter, or tract; syn. naAHiyapN. (Ḳ.)

The part that slopes down from the rugged portion of a mountain and rises from the channel in which the water flows; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) whence masojidu Alxayofi [the mosque of the xyf] in Minè: (Ṣ) or an elevated place, like the xyf of Minè: (Mgh:) or the part, of a valley, that rises a little from the channel in which the water flows, and only between two mountains; and hence msjdAlxyf, originally masojidu xayofi minFI: (Mṣb:) and any declivity and acclivity at the foot of a mountain: and a white place in the black mountain that is behind Aboo-Kubeys; and hence the name of msjdAlxyf; or this is so called because it is [in] a naAHiyap [or side, &c.] of Minè; or because it is at the foot of a mountain: (Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxoyaAfN (TA) and [of mult.] xuyuwfN. (Mgh, TA.)
Also The skin of the udder: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the side of the udder: or the skin of the she-camel's udder: (Ḳ:) or a she-camel's udder: or the anterior part of her neck: and the skin of her podex. (JK.)
xiyfN: see 1 in art. xwf, first sentence.
xaAfapN, accord. to Aboo-ʼAlee belonging to this art.: see art. xwf. (TA.)

hom.sense: xayofapN A knife, (AA, Ḳ,) such as is termed ramiyD [q. v.]. (AA, TA.)

Also, (thus in the Ḳ,) or xiyfapN↓, (so in the JK, [and app. accord. to Ṣgh,]) The place of resort a lion: (JK, Ḳ:) mentioned in this art. by Ibn-ʼAbbád; but accord. to Ṣgh, it may be from Alxawofu. (TA.)
xiyfapN: see what next precedes:
and see also art. xwf.

xayofaAnN Locusts before their wings are fullgrown: (Lth,* Ḳ, TA:) [see jaraAdN:] or when they have upon them streaks of different colours, white and yellow: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or when they have changed from their first black or yellow colour to red: (Aṣ, Ḳ:) or when yellowness has appeared in their red colour, but some of the redness remains: (AḤát, TA:) or [in the CK “and”] emaciated red locusts of the brood of the next preceding year: (Ḳ:) accord. to Lḥ, you say jaraAdN xayofaAnN, meaning locusts of different colours: (TA:) [but xyfAn is generally used as a subst.:] the n. un. is with p {xayofaAnapN}. (Ṣ.)
Hence the n. un. is applied to a mare, as meaning † Brisk, sprightly, active, or agile, and leaping. (Ṣ, TA.)
[Hence also, app.,] xayofaAnN mina Aln-aAsi † A multitude of men. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.*)

Also A certain plant of the mountains; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) a certain herb growing in the mountain, having no leaves, rising more than a cubit in height, having a sanamap [or head resembling an ear of corn], which is green in the upper part and white below, with a white awn, or beard. (L.)

entry.sense: Oaxoyafu, applied to a horse, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) and a camel, (TA,) and any animal, (Ṣ, TA,) Having one of the eyes blue and the other black: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) fem. xayofaMCu. (Ḳ, TA.)
And, applied to a camel, Wide in the sheath of the penis. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And the fem., applied to a she-camel, Wide in the udder, (Ḳ,) or in the skin thereof, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) or only when it is empty of milk, and flaccid: pl. xayofaAwaAtN; (Ḳ;) which is extr., for a pl. like this belongs [regularly] only to a subst., and to an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.)
The pl. of Oaxoyafu is xiyfN and xuwfN, (Ḳ, TA, [the latter erroneously written in the CK xawofN,]) with kesr and damm. (TA.)
maxiyfN: see art. xwf.
muxay-afN [Diversified in colour]; applied by El-Kumeyt to a horse of which one part was of the colour termed warod, and the rest jawon. (L and TA voce haDobN.)
mixoyaAfN A woman who brings forth one year a boy and another year a girl. (JK.)

hom.sense: 1. xaAla is syn. with Zan-a and tawah-ama: (TA:) you say, xaAla AlX-aIoCa, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) first pers. xilotu, (JK, Ṣ,) aor. yaxaAlu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) first pers.
