UixaAlu and OaxaAlu, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) the former irregular, (Mṣb,) but the more chaste of the two, (Ṣ,) and the more used, (Mṣb,) of the dial. of Teiyi, but commonly used by others also, (El-Marzookee, TA,) the latter of the dial. of Benoo-Asad, accord. to rule, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) but of weak authority, (Ḳ,) though some assert it to be the more chaste, (TA,) inf. n. xayolN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xayolapN and xiylN (Ḳ) and xiylapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xaAlN and xayalaAnN, (Ḳ, TA, [the last accord. to the CK xayalaAlN,]) or, as in the T [and JK], xiylaAnN, (TA,) and xayoluwlapN and maxiylapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and maxaAlapN; (Ḳ;) and xaAla AlX-aIoCa, aor. yaxiylu, is a dial. var. thereof; (Mṣb;) meaning Zan-apu [He thought, or opined, the thing: and sometimes (see I’Aḳ p. 109) he knew the thing: but it seems to have originally signified twh-m AlXICa, i. e. he surmised, or fancied, the thing: see xaAlN, below]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) This verb, being of the class of Zan-a, occurs with an inchoative and an enunciative; if commencing the phrase, governing them; but if in the middle or at the end, it may be made to govern or to have no government. (Ṣ.) You say, UixaAlu zayodFA OaxaAka [and, if you will, zayodN UixaAlu Oaxuwka and zayodN Oaxuwka UixaAlu, I think Zeyd is thy brother and Zeyd I think is thy brother and Zeyd is thy brother I think]. (JK.) Hence the prov., mano yasomaEo yaxalo, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e. He who hears the things related of men and of their vices, or faults, will think evil of them: meaning that it is most safe to keep aloof from other men: or, accord. to some, it is said on the occasion of verifying an opinion. (TA.)
See also 8.
xAl EalaI AlmaAli, aor. yaxiylu: see xaAla in art. xwl.
xAl said of a horse, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) aor. yaxaAlu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. xaAlN, (JK, Ḳ,) He limped, or halted, or was slightly lame. (JK, Ḳ.*)

2. taxoyiylN signifies The imaging a thing in the mind, or fancying it; the forming an image, or a fancied image, thereof in the mind: (TA:) [and taxay-ulN↓ has the same, as well as a quasi-pass., signification.] You say, [xay-alotuhu fataxay-ala↓ liI and] taxay-alotuhu↓ fataxay-ala↓ liI [I imaged it in the mind, or fancied it, and it became imaged in the mind to me, or an object of fancy to me]; like as you say, [Saw-arotuhu fataSaw-ara liI and] taSaw-arotuhu fataSaw-ara liI: (Ṣ:) for taxay-ulN↓ [as inf. n. of a quasi-pass. verb] signifies a thing's being imaged in the mind, or fancied: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and txy-l↓ AlX-aIoCu lahu means taXab-aha. (Ḳ. [And the same is indicated in the Mṣb.]) You say also, xuy-ila lahu kacaA [Such a thing was imaged to him in the mind; i. e. such a thing seemed to him]; from Alwahomu and AlZ-an-u: (Mṣb:) and xuy-ila Uilayohi Oan-ahu kacaA (Ṣ) It was imaged to him [in the mind, i. e. it seemed to him,] that it was so; syn. Xub-iha; (PṢ;) from Alt-axoyiylu and Alwahomu: (Ṣ, TA:) and taxay-ala↓ lahu Oan-ahu kacaA signifies [in like manner it became imaged, &c.; i. e.] taXab-aha; as also txAyl↓: (Ṣ:) and so the first of these three verbs is used in the Ḳur xx. 69. (TA.) And fulaAnN yamoDiI EalaI maA xay-alato, (JK and Ṣ in explanation of the phrase fulaAnN yamoDiI EalaI Almuxay-ali↓,) i. e. Xab-ahato [Such a one goes on, notwithstanding what (the mind, or the case,) may image to him, or what is fancied by him, of danger of difficulty; Aln-afosu, or AlHaAlu, accord. to Z, (see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 94,) being understood]; meaning, notwithstanding peril, or risk; without any certain knowledge. (Ṣ.) Whence the prov.,
EalaImaA xuy-ilato waEovu AlqaSiymi
i. e. I will go on, notwithstanding what the soft tracts abounding in sand in which the feet sink may be imagined to be: [or the right reading is probably xay-alato, i. e. notwithstanding what the soft tracts, &c. may image to the mind, of danger or difficulty:] the t in xy-lt relates to the word wEv, which is [regarded as] pl. of waEovapN; and ElI is a connective of a suppressed verb, namely, OamoDiI, with what follows it: the meaning is, I will assuredly venture upon the affair, notwithstanding its terribleness. (Meyd.) And AifoEalo celika EalaI maA xay-alato, i. e. EalaI maA Xab-ahato [Do thou that, notwithstanding what (the mind, or the case, as explained above,) may image to thee, of danger or difficulty]; (JK;) meaning, in any case. (TA.)
[Hence,] xy-l liln-aAqapi, and Oaxoyala↓, He put a xayaAl [q. v.] near the she-camel's young one, in order that the wolf might be scared away from him, (JK,* Ṣ, Ḳ,*) and not approach him. (JK, Ṣ.)

And xy-l fiyhi Alxayora He perceived, or discovered, in him an indication, or external sign, of good; as also txy-lhu↓ (Ḳ, TA) and txw-lhu: (TA: [see also 4 in art. xwl:]) or you say, taxay-alato↓ Ealayohi, (T, Ṣ, TA,) meaning I knew him; or knew his internal, or real, state; (taxab-arotuhu, T, TA;)
or I chose him; (Aixotarotuhu, Ṣ, TA;) and perceived, or discovered, in him an indication, or external sign, of good. (T, Ṣ, TA.)

And xy-l Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf.n. taxoyiylN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and taxay-ulN↓, (Ḳ,) [the latter anomalous, being properly inf. n. of taxay-ala,] He conveyed doubt, or suspicion, (Alt-uhomapa, Ṣ, Ḳ, or Alwahoma, Mṣb,) to him; so in the M, on the authority of AZ; (TA;) i. q. lab-asa Ealayohi [he made (a thing, or case) dubious to him]. (Mṣb.)

And xy-lt EalayonaA Als-amaMCu The sky thundered and lightened [over us], and prepared to rain: but when the rain has fallen, the term taxay-ulN↓ [so in my two copies of the Ṣ, app. used as an inf. n. of the verb in this phrase, as in a case above, or perhaps a mistranscription for taxoyiylN, though it will be seen from what follows that xy-lt and txy-lt are both said of the sky in the same sense,] is not used: (Ṣ:) or xy-lt Als-amaMCu signifies the sky became clouded, but did not rain; (JK, and Ḥar p. 36;) as also AxAlt↓ and txy-lt↓ and xAylt↓: (Ḥar ibid.:) or, as also txy-lt↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and AxAlt↓, (Mṣb,) or Oaxoyalat↓, (Ḳ,) the sky prepared to rain, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) and thundered and lightened, but did not yet rain: (TA:) or, accord. to Az, AxAlt↓ Als-amaMCu signifies the sky became clouded: (Mṣb, TA:) and txy-lt↓ Als-amaMCu the sky became clouded, and prepared to rain. (Ṣ.) [In like manner,] one says also, AxAlt↓ Als-aHaAbu and Oaxoyalat↓ and xAylt↓ The clouds gave hope of rain: (Ṣ:) or AxAlt↓ Als-aHaAbapu the cloud showed signs of rain, so that it was thought [or expected] to rain. (Mṣb.)

xy-l also signifies, (JK, TA,) or txy-l↓, (Ḥam p. 39,) [or each of these,] He (a man) was cowardly, or weak-hearted, on the occasion of fight, (JK, TA, and Ḥam,) and did not act, or proceed, firmly, or steadily. (Ḥam.) And xy-l Eani Alqawomi and Oaxoyala↓, [but the former only is explained in this sense in the TA,] He held back from the people, or party, through cowardice: (Ḳ, TA:) so says Az, on the authority of' Arrám. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. xAylhu, (JK, TA,) inf. n. muxaAyalapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He vied with him, rivalled him, or imitated him, (JK, Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) in pride and self-conceit; (JK;) did as he did. (TA.)
xAylt Als-amaMCu, and Als-aHaAbu: see 2, in the latter part of the paragraph.

hom.sense: 4. AxAl It (a thing) was, or became, dubious, or confused, or vague, (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) Ealayohi to him. (JK, Mgh.) One says, hecaA OamorN laA yuxiylu [This is a thing, or an affair, or a case, that will not be dubious,, &c.]. (Ṣ.) And laA yuxiylu caAka EalaI OaHadK That will not be dubious,, &c., to any one. (JK.)

AxAl AlX-aIoCu UilaI Alxayori, and Almakoruwhi, The thing exhibited an indication, or indications, of good, and of evil, or what was disliked or hated. (Mṣb.) [Hence,] AxAlt Als-amaMCu, and Oaxoyalat: see 2, in the latter part of the paragraph, in four places. And AxAlt Als-aHaAbu and Oaxoyalat, or AxAlt Als-aHaAbapu: see, again, 2, in the latter part of the paragraph, in three places.

And hence, in the opinion of ISd, the she-camel in this case being likened to clouds [giving hope, or showing signs, of rain], (TA,) AxAlt Aln-aAqapu ‡ The she-camel had milk in her udder, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) and was in good condition of body. (JK, TA.)
AxAlt AlOaroDu biAln-abaAti, (Ḳ,) or, as in the M, AxtAlt↓, (TA,) ‡ The land became adorned, or embellished, with plants, or herbage. (Ḳ, TA. [See also 5.])
AxAl fiyhi xaAlFA mina Alxayori: see 4 in art. xwl; and see xaAlN, below.

OaxoyalonaA and OaxalonaA We watched, or observed, or looked at, a cloud which it was thought would rain, to see where it would rain. (Ḳ,* TA.) And Oaxalotu Als-aHaAbapu and OaxoyalotuhaA I saw the cloud to be such as gave hope of rain. (Ṣ. [See also 10.])
Oaxoyala liln-aAqapi: see 2, in the middle of the paragraph.
Oaxoyala Eani Alqawomi: see 2, last sentence.
5. txy-l, as a trans. v., syn. with xay-ala; and its inf. n., syn. with taxoyiylN: see 2, first two sentences, in two places.
txy-l fiyhi Alxayori, as syn. with xay-ala: and taxay-alotu Ealayohi: see 2, in the latter half of the paragraph.
Also, as a quasi-pass. v., similar in signification to xuy-ila; and its inf. n.: see 2, first three sentences, in five places.
And taxy-ulN used as an inf. n. of xay-ala Ealayohi: and app. as an inf. n. of xay-alato EalayonaA Als-amaMCu: see 2, latter half, in two places.
txy-lt Als-amaMCu: see 2, latter half, in three places.
txy-l as syn. with AxtAl: see the latter verb.

[Hence, app.,] txy-lt AlOaroDu † The land became abundant in its plants, or herbage: (JK:) [and, (as is shown by an explanation of the part. n. of the verb, below,) † the land had its plants, or herbage, in a state of full maturity, and in blossom; and so txAylt↓; whence,] a poet says,
taOaz-ara fiyhi Aln-ayotu Hat-aI taxaAyalato
rubaAhu waHat-aI maA turaI AlX-aMCu nuw-amaA
[The herbage in it became, or had become, tangled, or luxuriant, and strong, so that its hills were clad with plants in full maturity, and in blossom, and so that the sheep, or goats, were seen sleeping]. (Ṣ, TA. [In both, the meaning of the verb in this ex. is indicated by the context. See also 4, where a similar meaning is assigned to AxAlt or AxtAlt.])

taxay-ulN also signifies The being, or becoming, of various colours. (JK, Ḥam p. 39.*) [Hence the saying,] taxay-ala Algaroqu biAls-afori, i. e. [The desert, or far-extending desert] became of various colours with the travellers, by reason of the Ml [or mirage]. (JK.)
Also The going on, or away; or acting with a penetrative energy; and being quick. (JK, Ḥam p. 39.)
See also 2, last sentence but one.

entry.sense: 6: see 2, third sentence:
and 8, in two places:
and see also 5, in two places.

8. AxtAl He was proud, or haughty; or he behaved proudly, or haughtily; (Ṣ;) as also xaAla↓, (JK, Ṣ,) aor. yaxiylu, (JK,) or yaxaAlu, (Ḥam p. 122,) and yaxuwlu, (JK, Ḥam,) inf. n. xaAlN and xawolN; (Ḥam;) and txy-l↓ and txAyl↓: (Ḳ, TA:) or he was proud, or haughty, and selfconceited: (Mṣb:) and he walked with a proud, or haughty, and self-conceited, gait: (MA, KL:) said of a man, and of a horse: (Mṣb:) and taxaAyulN↓ signifies the behaving, or carrying oneself, with pride, or haughtiness, combined with slowness. (JK.) You say of a horse, yaxotaAlu fiI miXoyatihi [He is proud and self-conceited in his gait]. (TA.)
AxtAlt AlOaroDu: see 4.
10. AstxAl Als-aHaAbapa He looked at the cloud and thought it to be raining. (TA. [See also 4, last sentence but two.])

hom.sense: xaAlN i. q. Zan-N and tawah-umN [meaning Thought, or opinion: and surmise, or fancy: though tawah-umN is often explained as syn. with Zan-N]: (Ḳ:) an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (TA.) So in the saying, OaSaAba fihi xaAliI [My thought or opinion, or surmise or fancy, was right respecting him, or it]. (TḲ.)
For another sense in which it is syn. with maxiylapN see the latter word, below.
A nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like; syn. xuluqN. (TA.)
I. q. xuyalaMCu, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ *)
A limping, or halting, or slight lameness, in a horse or similar beast: in this sense an inf. n. of xaAla. (JK, Ḳ.*)
Gout; or gout in the foot or feet; syn. niqorisN. (TA.)
Lightning: (Ḳ:) [app. as being a sign, or token, of coming rain.]

Clouds; syn. gayomN: (Ṣ:) or clouds (gym) lightening: (JK, M, TA:) and also rising, and seeming to one to be raining; and the single cloud (saHaAbap) is termed muxiylapN↓: (JK:) or rising, and seeming to one to be raining, and then passing beyond one; but when having thunder, or lightning, therein, termed muxiylapN↓, though not when the rain has gone therefrom: (Ḥar p. 36, from the ʼEyn:) or clouds (saHaAbN) raining: (T, TA:) or clouds (sHAb) that fail not to fulfil their promise of rain; (Ḳ,* TA;) and a cloud of this description is termed maxiylapN↓: (JK:) or in which is no rain, (Ḳ, TA,) though thought, when seen, to be raining. (TA.)
† A liberal, bountiful, or generous, man: (JK, T, M, Ḳ:) as being likened to the raining clouds, (T, TA,) or to the lightening clouds, (JK, M, TA,) which are so termed. (JK, T, M, TA.)
A man in whom one sees an indication, or a sign, or token, of goodness. (Ḳ, TA.)
Free from Alt-uhomap [as meaning what occasions suspicion]. (Ḳ.)

A man who manages cattle, or camels, &c., (Ḳ, TA,) and pastures them, (TA,) well: (Ḳ, TA:)
or xaAlu maAlK one who manages cattle,, &c., and watches them, well. (JK.) And One who keeps to a thing, (Ḳ, TA,) and manages, orders, or regulates, it. (TA.) A king who manages, orders, or regulates, the affairs of his subjects. (JK.) [See also xaAlN in art. xwl.]
An owner of a thing: (Ḳ:) from xaAlahu, aor. yaxuwlu, meaning “he managed it,”, &c. (TA.) You say, mano xaAlu hecaA Alfarasi Who is the owner of this horse? (TA.) [See xaAlN in art. xwl.]
See also muxotaAlN, in three places.
A man free from an attachment of love. (Ḳ.)
A man having no wife. (Ḳ.)
A man weak in heart and body: (Ḳ:) but this is most probably [xaAl-N,] with teshdeed, from xal-a laHomuhu, meaning “he became lean.” (TA.)
As meaning A maternal uncle, it is mentioned in art. xwl. (TA.)

A mole, syn. XaAmapN, (Ḳ,) a black XAmp, (TA,) upon the person; (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb, TA;) [a thing resembling] a pimple in the face, inclining to blackness; (JK, T, Mgh, TA;) or a small black spot upon the person: (TA:) dim. xuyayolN↓ (JK, Ṣ) accord. to him who says maxiylN and maxoyuwlN [as meaning “marked with many moles upon the person”], (Ṣ,) and xuwayolN (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb) accord. to him who says maxuwlN, (Ṣ,) which shows it to be, in one dial., of the art. xwl [in which it is also mentioned]: (Mṣb:) pl. [of mult.] xiylaAnN (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OaxiylapN. (Mṣb.)

A garment, or cloth, of the garments, or cloths, of the juh-aAl [here meaning people of the Time of Ignorance]: (Ṣ:) a soft garment or cloth (JK, Ḳ, TA) of the garments or cloths of El-Yemen: (JK, TA:) and a [garment of the kind called] burod, of the fabric of El-Yemen, (Ḳ, TA,) red [or brown], with black lines or stripes, which used to be made in the first ages: but Az makes these two to be one: it has been mentioned before, in art. xwl, to which also it may belong. (TA.)
A garment, or piece of cloth, with which a corpse is shrouded. (Ḳ.)

The [kind of banner called] liwaMC (JK, T, Ḳ) that is tied [to its spear-shaft] for a commander, (Ḳ,) or to denote one's having the authority of a prefect, commander, ruler, or the like: (T, TA:) [SM adds,] I do not think it to be so called for any other reason than that it was of the buruwd of the kind termed xaAlN. (TA.) [See also xaAlN in art. xwl.]
The office of Khaleefeh; (Ḳ;) because belonging to one for whom a banner is tied [on the occasion of his appointment]. (TA.)
A big mountain. (Ḳ.)
And (as being likened thereto, TA) † A big camel: (JK, Ḳ:) pl. xiylaAnN: to such, a poet likens certain men, as resembling camels in their bodies and in their being devoid of intellect. (TA.)
And A black stallion-camel. (IAạr, Ḳ,* TA.) Mentioned also in art. xwl. (TA.)
A place in which is no one, or no one by whose company one may be cheered. (Ḳ.) [Probably from xaAlK, part. n. of xalaA, aor. yaxoluw.]
A small [hill such as is termed] Oakamap. (Ḳ.)
The lijaAm [i. e. bit, or bit with its appertenances,] of a horse: (Ḳ:) app. a dial. var. of xawalN, q. v. (TA.)
A certain plant, having a blossom, well known in Nejd. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xaAlK, formed by transposition from xaAYilN: see muxotaAlN.

hom.sense: xayolN Horses, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) collectively; (JK, Ḳ;) as some say, (Mṣb,) applied to Arabian horses and [such as are of inferior breed, termed] baraAciyn; (Mgh, Mṣb;) the males thereof and the females: (Mgh, TA:*) but of the fem. gender: (Mṣb, TA:) a quasi-pl. n., (Mgh,) having no sing. (Mṣb, Ḳ) formed of the same radical letters: (Mṣb:) or the sing. is xaAYilN↓: (Ḳ:) so called because of their AixotiyaAl, (Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,*) i. e. pride and self-conceit, (Mṣb,) in their gait: so says AO; but ISd says that this is not well known: (TA:) or because no one rides a horse without experiencing a feeling of pride: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl., (Mṣb, CK,) or pl. pl., (so in copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) [of mult.,] xuyuwlN (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ) and xiyuwlN and [pl. of pauc.] OaxoyaAlN. (Ḳ.) And the dual form is used, [although xayolN has a pl. signification,] like as are [the duals UibilaAni and ganamaAni and] liqaAHaAni and jimaAlaAni. (ISd, TA.) One says, fulaAnN laAtusaAyaru xayolaAhu, or laAtuwaAqafu, (Ḳ, TA,) and laAtusaAyaru xayolaAhu walaA tuwaAqafu, (TA, and so in the CK,) [Such a one, his two troops of horses will not be competed with in going, or running, nor in standing still,] meaning ‡ he is not to be endured in respect of calumny and lying: (Ḳ, TA:) it is said of a great, or frequent, liar. (TA in art. syr.) And Alxayolu OaEolamu mino furosaAnihaA [The horses are more knowing than their riders]; (Meyd, Ḳ;) a prov., (Meyd,) applied in relation to him of whom thou formest an opinion (Meyd, Ḳ, TA) that he possesses, or possesses not, what suffices, (TA,) and whom thou findest to be as thou thoughtest, (Meyd, Ḳ, TA,) or the contrary. (Meyd.) And Alxayolu OaEolamu bafurosaAnihaA [The horses are possessed of most knowledge of their riders]; a prov., meaning † seek thou aid of him who knows the case, or affair. (Meyd.) And Alxayolu tajoriI EalaI masaAwiyhaA, another prov. [explained in art. swO]. (Meyd.)
Also Horsemen, or riders on horses. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Thus in the Ḳur [xvii. 66], waOajolibo Ealayohimo bixayolika warajolika. (Ṣ. [See 1 in art. jlb.])
See also xuyalaMCu.

entry.sense: xayalN: see xuyalaMCu.
xayolapN: see xuyalaMCu.
xiylapN: see xuyalaMCu.
xayalapN: see xuyalaMCu.
xayoliI-N An equerry; one who has the superintendence of horses. (TA.)

xuyalaMCu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and xiyalaMCu↓ (Ṣ, Ṣgh, TA) and xaAlN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xayolN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or xayalN↓, (CK,) and xayolapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or xayalapN↓, (CK,) or xiylapN↓, (JK,) and maxiylapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Oaxoyalu↓, (Lth, JK, Ḳ,) [of all which the first is the most common,] Pride (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and self-conceit; (Mṣb;) [or vanity; i. e.] pride arising from some fancied, or imaginary, excellence in oneself. (TA.) One says, huwa cuw xuyalaMCa, &c. He is possessed of pride [and self-conceit, or vanity]. (Ṣ.)
xiyalaMCa: see what next precedes.

hom.sense:
xayaAlN primarily signifies An incorporeal form or image; such as that which is imaged in sleep, and in the mirror, and in the heart or mind: then applied to the form of anything imaged; and to any subtile thing of a similar kind: (Er-Rághib, TA:) anything that one sees like a shadow: and the image of a man in a mirror, (T, Mṣb, TA,) and in water, (Mṣb,) and in sleep: (T, TA:) and a thing that sometimes passes by one, resembling a shadow: (T, Mṣb, TA:) xayaAlN and xayaAlapN↓ both signify the same; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. i. q. TayofN [meaning an apparition; a phantom; a spectre; a fancied image; an imaginary form; and particularly a form that is seen in sleep]; (Ṣ, TA;) anything that one sees like a shadow [as the former word is explained above]; and a thing that is seen in sleep; (JK;) a form that is imaged to one in the mind when awake, and when dreaming: (Ḳ:) the former word is both masc. and fem.: (Ḥam p. 316:) pl. OaxiylapN (Ḳ) [a pl. of pauc.; and probably xiylaAnN also, as a pl. of mult., mentioned as one of the pls. of xayaAlN in another sense, below]. You say, taxay-ala liI xayaAluhu [His apparition, or phantom,, &c., became imaged to me in my mind]. (Mṣb, TA.) And a poet says, (Ṣ,) namely, El-Bohturee, (TA,)
falasotu binaAzilK Uil-aA Oalam-ato
biraHoliI Oawo xayaAlatuhaA↓ Alkacuwbu
[And I do not alight but she visits my abode, or her false apparition]. (Ṣ.)

[In philosophy it signifies] A faculty that retains what the fancy perceives of the forms of objects of sense after the substance has become absent, so that the fancy beholds them whenever it turns towards them: thus it is the store-house of the fancy: its place is the hinder part of the first venter of [the three which are comprised by] the brain. (KT. [In this sense, it is incorrectly written in Freytag's Lex. (in which only the Arabic words of the explanation are given, preceded by the rendering “phantasia,”) xiyAlN.])

The xayaAl of a bird is The shadow of himself which a bird sees when rising into the sky; whereupon he pounces down upon it, thinking it to be a prey, and finds it to be nothing: he is [the bird] called xaATifu Zil-ihi. (TA.)
xayaAlN and xayaAlapN↓ signify also The person, or body, or corporeal form or figure which one sees from a distance, syn. XaxoSN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of a man; and his aspect. (Ḳ.)

And the former also signifies A piece of wood with black garments upon it, (Ṣ,) or with a black [garment of the kind called] kisaMC upon it, (Ḳ,) which is set up to make the beasts and birds fancy it to be a man: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a piece of wood with a garment thrown upon it, which is set up for the sake of the sheep or goats, in order that the wolf, seeing it, may think it to be a man: (T, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaxiylapN (Ks, TA) and [of mult.] xiylaAnN. (TA.) A poet says,
OaxiI laA OaxaA liI gayoruhu gayora Oan-aniI
karaAEiI xayaAlK yasotaTiyfu bilaAfikori
(Ṣ, TA)
[cited by J as an ex. of xyAl in the former of the senses explained in the sentence immediately preceding: but the meaning seems to be, My brother: I have no brother but he: but I am like one watching an image dressed up to decoy; going round about without reflection: for,] as some say, (TA,) raAEiI AlxayaAli means the young ostrich for which the sportsman sets up a xayaAl [i. e. an image dressed up to decoy], (JK, TA,) in order that it may become familiar therewith, and the sportsman may then take it, and the young ostrich may follow him. (TA.)
Also A thing that is set up in land in order that it may be known to be prohibited to the public, and may not be approached. (T, Mṣb.)
And A certain plant. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: xuyayolN: see xaAlN, of which it is a diminutive.
xayaAlapN: see xayaAlN, in three places.
[xayaAliI-N Of, or relating to, the fancy: a rel. n. from xayaAlN.]
xay-aAlapN Owners, or attendants, of horses. (JK, Ṣ.) [In modern Arabic, Horsemen; and a troop of horsemen.]
xaAYilN [act. part. n. of 1]: see muxotaAlN, in two places:
and see xayolN, first sentence.
Applied to a horse, Limping, halting, or slightly lame. (JK, TA.)

hom.sense: [Oaxoyalu More, and most, proud and self-conceited. (See also Oaxowalu, in art. xwl.) Occurring in several provs.; as, for ex.,] Oaxoyalu mino guraAbK [More proud and self-conceited than a crow]: because the grAb is proud and self-conceited in its gait. (Meyd.)
See also xayalaMCu.

Also Having a xaAl, meaning [a thing resembling] a pimple, inclining to blackness, [i. e. a mole,] upon his face: (Mgh:) or, as also maxiylN↓ and maxoyuwlN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maxuwlN, like maquwlN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) this last belonging to art. xwl, as xaAlN, whence it is derived, does in one dial., (Mṣb,) A man (Ṣ, Mṣb) having [or marked with] many xiylaAn [or moles upon his person]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) fem. [of the first] xayolaMCu. (Ḳ.)

AlOaxayolu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) when indeterminate, [OaxayolN or Oaxayolu,] perfectly decl., [thus] used as a subst., but some make it imperfectly decl. both when determinate and when indeterminate, and assert it to be originally an epithet, from Alt-axay-ulu, (Ṣ, O,) [though accord. to others it seems to be from Oaxoyalu as meaning “having many moles,”] A certain bird, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) regarded as of evil omen, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) that alights upon the rump of the camel, and is app. for that reason held to be of evil omen; (TA; [see maxoyuwlN;]) [applied in the present day to the green wood-pecker, picus viridis;] the Surad [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) or the green Surad: (TA:) or the Xiqir-aAq [a name likewise now applied to the green wood-pecker, and to the common roller, coracias garrula]: (Fr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so called because upon its wings are colours differing from its general colour: (Skr, TA:) or so called because diversified with black and white: (Ḳ:) or the XaAhiyn [q. v., a species of falcon]: (JK, TA, and Ḥam p. 705:) pl. OaxaAyilu, (JK, T, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA, and Ḥam ubi suprà,) or xiylN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: OuxaAyilN: see muxotaAlN, in two places.

hom.sense: maxiylN: see its fem. maxiylapN, in the next following paragraph, in three places:
and see also Oaxoyalu.

entry.sense: muxiylN A thing dubious, confused, or vague. (TA.)

Exhibiting a xayaAli [or fancied image, or rather a xaAl or maxiylap, i. e. an indication,, &c., (see 4,) of anything, as, for instance,] of good [and of evil]. (TA.) You say XaIoCN muxiylN UilaI Alxayori, and Almakoruwhi, A thing exhibiting an indication, or indications, of good, and of evil, or what is disliked or hated. (Mṣb.) Hence, (TA,) huwa muxiylN liloxayori, (Ṣ, TA,) said of a man, (Ṣ,) He is adapted or disposed by nature to good [i. e. to be, or to do, or to effect, or to produce, what is good]. (Ṣ, TA. [See also maxiylN in art. xwl.]) And saHaAbapN muxiylapN (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ) and muxay-ilapN↓ (Ḳ, TA, in the CK muxay-alapN) and muxay-ilN↓ and muxotaAlapN↓ (Ḳ) and mxAylp [i. e. muxaAyilapN↓] (Ḥar p. 36) and maxiylapN↓ (Mṣb [but see what follows]) A cloud thought [or expected] to rain, (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA, and Ḥar ubi suprà,) when seen, (TA, and Ḥar,) because showing signs of rain: muxiylapN, with damm, being an act. part. n., as meaning causing to think; and maxiylapN↓, with fet-ḥ, being a pass. part. n., as meaning thought: and in like manner, accord. to Az, samaMCN muxiylapN and maxiylapN↓, meaning a clouded sky: (Mṣb:) or you say maxiylapN↓, with fet-ḥ, when [you use the subst.] meaning a cloud itself [showing signs of rain]; and its pl. is maxaAyilu: (T, TA: see xaAlN, in the former half of the paragraph:) and saHaAbapN muxiylapN lilomaTari a cloud giving hope of rain. (Ṣ.) See also xaAlN, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph. You say also, Als-amaMCu muxiylapN lilomaTari, meaning The sky is ready to rain. (Ḥar p. 36.)
AimoraOapN muxiylapN A woman having no husband. (JK.)
maxiylapN as fem. of the pass. part. n. maxiylN: see muxiylN, in three places.
As a subst.: see, again, muxiylN. And see xaAlN, mentioned a second time in the former half of the paragraph.
Hence, A great banner or ensign; as likened to a cloud that fails not to fulfil its promise of rain. (JK.)

Also An indication; a symptom; a sign, mark, or token, by which the existence of a thing is known or inferred; syn. XiyapN (JK) and maZin-apN; (TA;) and so xaAlN↓, q. v.: (JK:) pl. of the former maxaAyilu: originally used in relation to a cloud in which rain is thought to be. (TA.) You say, Zaharato fiyhi maxaAyilu Aln-ajaAbapi, i. e. The indications, &c. [of generosity, or nobility, appeared in him]. (TA.)
You say also, of a cloud (saHaAbap), maA OaHosana maxiylatahaA and xaAlahaA↓ How good is its [apparent] disposition to rain! (Ṣ, TA.)
See also xuyalaMCu.

muxay-alN [A thing imaged to one by the mind or by a case; or fancied]. You say, fulaAnN yamoDiI EalaI Almuxay-ali; explained above: see 2. (JK, Ṣ.) And waqaEa fiI muxay-alaI kacaA [Such a thing occurred in what was imagined, or fancied, by me], and fiImuxay-alaAtiI [among the things imagined, or fancied, by me]. (TA.)

hom.sense: maxoywulN: see Oaxoyalu.
Also A camel lacerated in his rump by a bird of the kind called Oaxoyal that has alighted upon it. (TA.)
And hence, † A man whose reason has fled in consequence of fright: a sense in which it is used by the vulgar; but correct. (TA.)

entry.sense: saHaAbapN muxaAyilapN: see muxiylN.

muxotaAlN and xaAYilN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and xaAlN↓ and xaAlK↓, which is formed by transposition, (Ḳ,) and OuxaAyilN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like OudaAbirN and OubaAtirN, (Ṣ,) which are [said to be] the only other epithets of this measure, (TA,) [i. e. of the measure OufaAEilN, though there are many of the measure fuEaAlilN,] applied to a man, Proud (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and self-conceited: [or vain:] (TA in explanation of all, and Ḳ in explanation of xaAlN:) or xaAlN↓ signifies having much xuyalaMC [or pride and self-conceit, or vanity]: and OuxaAyilN↓ one who walks with a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side: (JK:) xaAYilN↓ has for its pl. xaAlapN; (Ṣ, TA;) which is also fem. of xaAlN↓. (TA.)
See also muxiylN.
OaroDN mutaxay-alapN † Land having its plants, or herbage, in a state of full maturity, and in blossom; (JK, Ṣ;) as also mutaxaAyilapN↓. (Ṣ.)
OaroDN mutaxaAyilapN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: 1. xaAma as syn. with xay-ama: see the latter.

xaAma Eanohu, aor. yaxiymu, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. xayomuwmapN (Ṣ) and xayomN and xayamaAnN and xuyuwmN and xuywmapN and xiyaAmN, (Ḳ, the last but one omitted in the CK,) He held back, or refrained, from him, or it, through cowardice, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and fear: (JK, Ḳ:) i. e., from war, (JK,) or from encounter, or conflict. (Ḥam p. 164.) And one says also, xaAmuwA fiI AlqitaAli They held back, or refrained, through cowardice, in fight, and attained no good: and the poet Junádeh Ibn-'Ámir El-Hudhalee says, xAm AlqitaAla for xAm fiI AlqitaAli. (TA.)
And xAm also signifies He drew back, (JK, Ḳ,*) through cowardice and fear, (JK,) from a stratagem, or plot, after he had devised it, (JK, Ḳ,*) not seeing in it what he liked, or approved. (TA.)
xAm rijolahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. as above, inf. n. xayomN, (Ṣ,) He raised his leg, or foot. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
2. xy-m, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taxoyiymN, (TA,) [originally] He pitched his tent; (TA in art. rfD;) [like txy-m: and hence,]

He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in a place; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also xAm↓, aor. yaxiymu: whence, in a trad., mano OaHab-a Oano yasotaxiyma↓ lahu Alr-ijaAlu qiyaAmFA [Whoso loveth that men should remain before him standing]; as some relate it; but others relate it differently, saying yasotaxim-a, and yasotajim-a, as mentioned before [in arts. xm and jm]. (TA.) He alighted, or descended and stopped or sojourned or abode, in a place; as also xay-afa. (JK in art. xyf.) And xy-m AlwaHoXiI-u fiI kinaAsihi The wild animal remained in his covert, not quitting it. (TA.) And xay-amati Alr-aAYiHapu, (TA,) or Alr-iyHu AlT-ay-ibapu, (JK,) ‡ The odour, or sweet odour, remained; (JK, TA;) as also txmy-t↓; (Ḳ, TA;) in a garment, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) and in a place. (TA.)
xay-amuwA They entered into a xayomap [q. v.]. (JK, Ḳ.)
xy-mhu He made it like a xayomap. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also 4.
Also † He covered it with a thing in order that its odour might cling to it. (Ḳ, TA.)

4. UixaAmap, [inf. n. of OaxaAma,] in the phrase UixaAmap Alfarasi, (Ḳ, TA,) which signifies The horse's standing upon three legs and the extremity of the hoof of the fourth, (TA,) or raising one of his fore legs or one of his hind legs, (JK,) belongs to the present art. and to art. xwm. (Ḳ, TA.) Accord. to Fr and IAạr, yuxiymu fiI UiHodaI rijolayohi, inf. n. as above, signifies He (a man, or a beast,) is unable to place one of his legs, or feet, firmly upon the ground, and to rest upon it, by reason of a fault therein. (L, TA.)
OaxaAma xayomapF, and OaxoymahaA, He constructed a xayomap; (IAạr, Ḳ;) as also xay-amahaA↓. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. txy-m bimakaAni kacaA, (Ṣ,) or txy-m hunaA, (Ḳ,) [like xy-m,] He pitched, or fixed, his xayomap [in such a place, or here]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 2.

hom.sense: xaAmN A skin, or hide, untanned: or not tanned much, or thoroughly: and a kirobaAs [or coarse garment or piece of cloth, or garment or piece of cloth of white cotton,] unwashed: (Ḳ:) a Persian word, (TA,) arabicized. (Ḳ.) Unbleached cloth. (Mṣb, in art. xwm.) Paper that is polished, [app. a mistake for not polished,] or to be polished. (TA.) [Crude, or raw; applied in this sense to silk, contr. of maTobuwxN; and to sugar, &c.: anything unprepared for use.] Honey of dates (dibos) untouched by fire: (AḤn, T:) which is the best thereof. (TA.)
See also xaAmap.

entry.sense: xayomN: see xayomapN, in three places.

xiymN Natural, or innate, dispositions or tempers or the like: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) a Persian word, arabicized: (TA:) having no sing. (Ṣ, Ḳ) of its own radical letters: (Ṣ:) or largeness, or liberality, of disposition: (JK, TA:) and the original, or primary, state, or condition, syn. OaSol, of the soul, or mind. (TA.) You say, huwa kariymu Alxiymi [He is generous in respect of natural dispositions, &c.]. (TA.)
The diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, syn. firinod, of a sword. (Ḳ.)
And I. q. HamoDN [app. meaning the kind of plants called HamoD]. (TA.)

xaAmapN belongs to the present art., and J has erred, (Ḳ,) in mentioning it in art. xwm: (TA:) [but why this is said, I know not; nor do the commentators on this passage, as is observed in the TA, give any explanation of it worthy of notice:] it signifies A fresh, or juicy, plant: (Ṣ, Mṣb: both in art. xwm:) or an ear of corn: (IAạr, TA:) or a shoot of seed-produce when it first grows forth upon a single stalk: (JK:) or xaAmapu Alz-aroE signifies what grows forth, of seedproduce, upon a single stalk: (M, Ḳ:*) or the fresh, or juicy, bunch thereof: or the fresh, or juicy, plant thereof: (M, Ḳ:) pl. xaAmaAtN (Mṣb) and [coll. gen. n.] xaAmN↓. (Mṣb, TA.) It is said in a trad., mavalu AlmuWomini mavalu AlxaAmapi mina Alz-aroEi tumiyluhaA Alr-iyHu mar-apF hekacaA wamar-apF hekacaA [The similitude of the believer is that of the fresh, or juicy, plant of seed-produce,, &c., which the wind bends, at one time thus, and at one time thus]: (Ṣ, TA:*) but Fr related it differently, saying AlHAfp, [app. a mistranscription for AlxaAfap, which see in art. xwf,] and explained this as meaning “the bunch” of seed-produce. (TA.)

xayomahN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) with which xayomN↓ is syn., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [though said by some to be a pl., as will be seen below,] A bayot [here meaning booth, or the like,] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of any kind (Ḳ) such as is built, or constructed, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) by the Arabs, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) of the branches of trees: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so says Aṣ, holding that the xymp is only of trees, and that otherwise it is called bayotN [q. v.]: but others hold that it is [a tent; i. e.] made with pieces of cloth and tent-ropes; because taxoyiymN signifies the “remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding;” wherefore it is thus called, as being used on the occasion of alighting: (IB, TA:) this latter is the meaning commonly known; but accord. to the saying of Aṣ, it is tropical: (TA:) or, accord. to IAạr, it is applied by the Arabs only to a construction of four poles roofed over with vumaAm [or panic grass]; and is not of cloths; (Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) the miZal-ap, he says, being of cloths and of other things: or i. q. miZal-ap: (TA:) accord. to AḤát, the same as the Persian xaro PuXotaho [lit. “ass's back;” like the French “dos d'âne;” meaning a high-pitched span-roof]: (Mgh:) or any round bayot [which may here mean either booth or tent]: or three poles, or four, over which is laid vumaAm; by means of which one is shaded in the heat: (Ḳ:) or poles set up, with rafters laid across, covered with trees; so that it is cooler than are Oaxobiyap [pl. of xibaMC]: or poles upon which xiyaAm [pl. of xayomN] are constructed: or a construction of trees and palmbranches with their leaves upon them, which a man uses for shade when he brings his camels to water: and applied by the Arabs to a bayot [or tent, &c.], and a place of abode [in an absolute sense]: (TA:) the pl. of xayomapN is xayomaAtN and xiyamN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xayomN↓, (Ḳ,) or this last is [a coll. gen. n., or] syn. with xayomapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and xiyaAmN, (Ḳ,) or this is pl. of xayomN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and is applied also to ‡ [women's vehicles of the kind called] hawaAdij; these being likened to xiyaAm [properly so termed]. (TA.) It is said in a trad., AlX-ahiydu fiI xayomapi Qll-ehi taHota AlEaroXi † [The martyr is in the tabernacle of God, beneath the empyrean: this signification of xymp being perhaps taken from the phrase ἡ σκηνὴ τοῦ θεοῦ in Rev. xxi. 3]. (TA.)
xaAmiI-N (Ḳ, TA) A preparer of skins, or hides, of the kind termed xaAmN. (TA.)
xiyamiI-N: see what next follows.
xay-aAmN and xiyamiI-N↓ One who applies himself to the fabrication of the [kind of tent, or booth, called] xayomap. (TA.)

maxiymN, like makiylN, (in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, like mikotalN, TA, [in the CK like mikoyalN,]) A collection of bundles, or handfuls, (juraz), [in the CK jizar,] of reaped seed-produce. (Ḳ, TA.)
[xayawiI-N rel. n. of xA: see xaAYiI-N, in art. xwO.]
